DOC.HEADLINE: UNAXIS TO BUILD RESEARCH CENTER FOR MONITORS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Unaxis, a Europe-based company, will plunge NT$1 billion (US$29.92 million) into a research center in Taiwan, a Ministry of Economic Affairs official said Tuesday.
Construction on the research center, to be located in Chunan Science-based Industrial Park in Miaoli County, is slated for June 8.
Economics Minister Ho Mei-yueh and Unaxis Executive Director Heinz Kundert will jointly preside over a ground-breaking ceremony on that day in Chunan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 61% MOTORISTS FOLLOW RULES ABOUT CHILD SAFETY SEATS ON FIRST DAY

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 1 (CANA) More than 60 percent of motorists were abiding by a rule requiring safety car seats for children on the first day of the new measures taking effect, police sources said Tuesday.

A statement issued by the National Police Administration said that 5,266 cars out of 8,623 cars stopped and checked by police had followed the rules whereby children aged four and under must be strapped into safety seats.

Although motorists who fail to follow the rule are punishable by fines of NT$500 (US$15), no offenders were ticketed Tuesday, as the police are allowing a three-month grace period before enforcing the new rule, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN SHOULD DIVERSIFY OVERSEAS INVESTMENTS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen should diversify their overseas investments, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Tuesday.
Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said that Taiwan's overseas investment has tilted too much toward mainland China, which accounts for 57 percent of the total.
Given that cross-Taiwan Strait interaction is not stable, he claimed that it remains very risky for Taiwan businessmen to do business on the mainland.

Chen made the remarks while commenting on Beijing's recent vilification of Chi Mei Corp. founder Hsu Wen-long as "a shameless anti-Chinese bigot" and claims that the mainland does not welcome "this kind of Taiwanese businessman."

In tune with the trend of increasing globalization and the regional economic and trade integration, Chen suggested that Taiwan businessmen should pay more attention to emerging markets around the world and global deployment.
Taiwan businessmen should not limit their vision to the mainland market, where, he claimed, its capacity to absorb investment is nearly full.
It is an established government policy to help Taiwan businessmen diversify their investments around the world, the vice minister added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC DEFENDS COMBINATION OF REFERENDUM, ELECTION

TEXT.P: A member of the Central Election Commission (CEC) disputed before the court Tuesday claims made by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) that it was illegal to hold the referendum and presidential election together on March 20.

Chou Chih-hung said in the trial of a lawsuit brought by the KMT and PFP seeking to annul the March 20 presidential election that the CEC was ordered by the Executive Yuan to carry out the referendum along with the presidential election.

Neither of the two opposition parties in the case at no point prior to the election took issue with the Executive Yuan's decision to hold the referendum in conjunction with the presidential election. Now, he said, they cast doubt on the results of the election simply because they lost and want to overthrow it altogether.
Chou said that the legality of the referendum has nothing to do with the presidential election.
However, a lawyer for the two opposition parties argued that the Referendum Law forbids a defensive referendum to be held along with the presidential election.

He also claimed that the government's emergency measures after the assassination attempt against President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of election day stripped many military personnel and policemen of the right to vote.

He asked the court to subpoena documents relating to the March 19 shooting and the emergency measures taken by the government from the National Security Council, the Executive Yuan and the Ministry of National Defense.
The five judges hearing the case ordered the plaintiffs lawyer to present evidence at the next hearing slated for June 25 to substantiate what he claimed were irregularities in the March 20 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER INTERIOR MINISTER TAPPED TO BE HEAD OF NEW POLITICAL PARTY

TEXT.P: Former Interior Minister Chang Po-ya will head the organizing committee for a new political party and might serve as chairwoman of a nonpartisan alliance of freedom when it is founded, Chen Chieh-ju, a would-be founder of the alliance, said Tuesday.
Chen said that Chang has agreed to lead the party, founded mainly by 10 of more than a dozen independent lawmakers in the Legislative Yuan.
Chen, who is a former opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker, said he will quit the KMT when the founders of the alliance gather for the first time June 7.

In a statement issued by the organizing committee, the 10 independent lawmakers said the grouping will provide them with a platform to advocate their political views and enable them to play a more active role in the party-dominated legislature.
If everything goes smoothly, the new party, formed on the basis of the Alliance of Independent Legislators, is expected to begin operating by late August.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED NOT TO INTIMIDATE TAIWANESE BUSINESSES

TEXT.P: Beijing should ensure legal protection for Taiwan investors and refrain from "unreasonable political interference" with their normal business activities in mainland China, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner said Tuesday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu made the remarks after the mainland's official mouthpiece -- the People's Daily -- said in a front-page editorial a day earlier that the mainland does not welcome Taiwanese businessmen who use profits made on the mainland to finance the pro-independence movement in Taiwan, "such as Chi Mei Group Chairman Hsu Wen-lung."

"I think everyone knows that if the mainland Chinese government tries to suppress Taiwan internationally and intimidate Taiwanese businesses and people, it will only drive the two sides of the Taiwan Strait farther and father apart, " Wu said. "This is something mainland Chinese leaders should think about carefully."

Stressing that Taiwan businessmen on the mainland should not have to suffer unreasonable political interference, Wu said the MAC is evaluating the situation and will if necessary take proper response measures.

Taiwan companies have invested an estimated US$100 billion in mainland China since the late 1980s, moving much of the island's manufacturing sector there to take advantage of the mainland's cheap labor.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO PROMOTE CONVENIENT CROSS-STRAIT CARGO TRANSPORTATION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Tuesday that the government will prioritize promotion of convenient cargo transportation across the Taiwan Strait.
Yu made the promise while delivering an administrative report to the Legislative Yuan.
The premier said the government will continue to promote cross-strait commercial exchanges and give priority to boosting easier and more convenient cross-strait cargo transportation services.

In addition to Kaohsiung, Yu said, the government has opened two additional ports -- Taichung and Keelung -- for offshore direct cross-strait transshipment services, as part of its efforts to realize the government's goal.

Yu further said in his report that the government will step up efforts to negotiate free trade agreements with the United States and other countries to beef up Taiwan's trade competitiveness in the face of mainland China's continued diplomatic embargo.

"Signing free trade agreements (FTAs) is one of our priority tasks for the coming four years, " Yu told lawmakers. "Since efforts to expand our diplomatic relations are always blocked by Beijing, and economic and trade ties across the Taiwan Strait are not normalized, we must adjust our strategic positioning in international trade."

In order to break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic embargo, Yu said, Taiwan needs to sign FTAs with the United States and other countries to connect to the world and avoid becoming overly reliant on the mainland market.

Taiwan signed its first-ever FTA with Panama last year and is now seeking to sign similar agreements with the United States, Japan, Singapore, New Zealand and many other major countries around the world.

With the mainland's rise as a major economic power, Yu said, Taiwan must endeavor to achieve a balance so that the ever-growing cross-strait economic ties will not lead to the nation's over-reliance on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, IDAHO STATE SIGN JOINT STATEMENT TO ENHANCE BILATERAL TIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan Province and the state of Idaho in the United States signed a joint statement Tuesday to further strengthen bilateral ties.

The signing ceremony was held at Chung Hsing New Village in the central Taiwan county of Nantou, the location of the Taiwan provincial government headquarters. Taiwan Provincial Governor Lin Kuang-hua and Roger Madsen, director of the Idaho Department of Commerce, inked the documents on behalf of their respective sides.

According to the joint statement, Taiwan and Idaho will continue to promote their friendly relations based on the cordial friendship that has existed between the two sides over the past 20 years since June 11, 1984, when they first established sisterhood ties.

In addition to further promoting mutual understanding, it adds, the two sides will also increase exchanges in trade, technology, education, tourism, environmental protection, culture and other sectors that are mutually beneficial.

Lin thanked the state of Idaho for its support for Taiwan's bids to join the United Nations, the World Health Organization and other international organizations and he expressed hope that Taiwan-Idaho relations will be further strengthened.
For his part, Madsen encouraged Taiwan people to visit Idaho and promised to further promote bilateral ties and exchanges.
The signing of the joint statement marked the 20th anniversary of the establishment of Taiwan-Idaho sisterhood ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER: GOVERNMENT CAPABLE OF GUARANTEEING NATIONAL SECURITY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday that his administration is capable of maintaining national security, stability across the Taiwan Strait and friendship with the United States.

Answering questions from lawmakers, Yu lamented that Beijing failed to realize President Chen Shui-bian's sincerity in wishing to step up exchanges across the strait and preserve peace with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST-PHASE WATER RESTRICTIONS REMOVED FOR NORTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The first of a four-phase water restriction plan put in place in northern Taiwan over the past year was removed Tuesday thanks to this year's plentiful rainfall, a spokesman for the Water Resources Agency (WRA) said Tuesday.

The decision was made during a national meeting called by an anti-drought task force set up in March last year under the Ministry of Economic Affairs to tackle the water shortage problem, the WRA official said.

The restriction -- a reduction in water pressure during off-peak hours imposed since May last year in Taipei City, Taipei County, Keelung City, Taoyuan County, Hsinchu City and Hsinchu County -- was lifted from Tuesday, the official said.

Thanks to abundant rainfall since the beginning of this year, including recent monsoon rain, major reservoirs in northern Taiwan have taken in considerable quantities of water, the official said, adding that the decision was made as typhoon season is approaching.

In contrast, the shortage in southern Taiwan remains serious as a result of scarce rainfall since November last year, which he said might lead to the second crop on the Chianan Plain -- Taiwan's main granary -- lying fallow. The first crop earlier this spring was also halted for the same reason.
Meanwhile, the water levels of the Tsengwen and Wushantou reservoirs in Tainan County have fallen to very dangerously low levels.

However, the official said that the anti-drought task force did not discuss issues related to stopping irrigation for the second crop in southern Taiwan, which is slated to start in late June, because more monsoon rain is likely to come before that time.
The anti-drought task force will hold a meeting later this month to decide whether the planned irrigation program will be halted, he added.
Taiwan has been hit hard by a continued dry spree over the past two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM URGES ECONOMIC TIES WITH MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) makes economic ties with mainland China top priority in its 2004 Taiwan White Paper, released Tuesday.
The AmCham report emphasizes three major areas of concern in the Taiwan-based U.S. business community: cross-Taiwan Strait, cross-agency, and cross-party issues.

This year, the six themes are the same as those presented last year: improve Taiwan's public health and health care environment; insist on world-class infrastructure; tighten intellectual property rights protection; reduce government involvement in business hiring decisions; complete essential financial reforms; and strengthen the battle against corruption.
However, a seventh item was added and placed at the top of the list -- encourage economic ties with mainland China.
AmCham President Andrea Wu said that without direct cross-strait transportation, Taiwan's plan to develop itself into a regional hub is in jeopardy.
Noting that Taiwan and the mainland are geographically close, Wu said that Taiwan should see this proximity as an economic strength to be embraced, not guarded against as a political risk.
She pointed out that direct cross-strait trade, postal and transportation links are improvements everyone engaged in business in Taiwan hopes to see, not just U.S.-based business groups.

She said that the mainland is a vast market and that a lot of companies in Taiwan have set up footholds there. Doubling the length of what should be a short trip between the two sides because of political factors has a big impact on Taiwan's plan to become a regional hub, she added.
She pointed out that multinational enterprises encounter various difficulties because of the indirect cross-strait transportation situation.
Looking over the past year, she said, Taiwan has made "significant progress" regarding financial reforms and the protection of intellectual property rights.

She further noted that there have been recent appointments of several economic and financial heads, such as Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh, who have experience of close cooperation with foreign businesses.

Following the release of the white paper, Wu will lead an AmCham delegation to Washington, D.C. from June 13-16. This annual "Washington doorknocking" trip will involve calls on leading members of Congress, key executive-branch agencies involved with economic relations with Taiwan, as well as think tanks. Both before and after the trip, AmCham will brief high-level officials in Taiwan on the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER OUTLINES FOUR MAJOR POLICIES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun pledged to accomplish four major tasks -- fostering a national identity, establishing a failsafe security network, building a clean political environment and forging strategic alliances -- in a report Tuesday to the legislative Yuan on the policy of his administration.
Yu reaffirmed the government's determination to establish a Taiwanese identity on the basis of pluralistic ethnicity by putting emphasis on harmony between national pluralistic ethnic groups.

He also vowed to do everything possible to protect the collective rights and interests of all ethnic groups in Taiwan while safeguarding both civil rights and cultural rights for foreign spouses, including those from mainland China.

With respect to the establishment of a failsafe security network, Yu outlined a government plan to develop criminal investigation know-how and renew all equipment with a view to preventing organized crime.

As for building a clean political environment, Yu reiterated the government's determination to continue to intensify the political donation management system and to set up an anti-corruption mechanism.

He also called on the legislature to speed up screening of several major draft bills on political reforms, including a draft political party law, a draft lobbying law and a draft law governing the disposal of ill-gotten party assets.

Touching on forging strategic alliances, the premier said his administration will seek to sign free trade agreements with other major nations so that the country will not be marginalized in the face of global economic integration, while continuing to upgrade Taiwan's global competitiveness.

In the face of a new cross-Taiwan Strait situation following the March 20 presidential election, the premier pledged that the government will continue to devote itself to stabilizing relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and expanding bilateral trade and economic exchanges under the basic principles of "Taiwan first, reciprocity and risk management."

The premier was expected to deliver his report Tuesday morning but was delayed to the afternoon because of the interruption of lawmakers from the Kuomintang and the People First Party who protested against what they claimed to be the government's refusal to find the truth behind the March 20 presidential election that they claim was "unfair."

DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Britain aims to lift arms ban on China.
Tony Blair is planning to ditch the 15-year-old embargo on selling arms to China imposed after the Tiananmen Square massacre.
Britain is expected to side with France and Germany in arguing that it is time for the EU ban to be lifted.
The Times understands that Mr Blair hopes that a decision could be linked to improving human rights in China.
But resistance is so strong in America that Colin Powell, the Secretary of State, has said that any European country lifting the ban would be denied access to US military technology.
Financial Times: M&S wields axe on top tier as Â£10bn Green bid looms.
Marks and Spencer, the iconic British retailer, on Monday night threw out its chairman and chief executive in a dramatic attempt to fend off an expected Â£10bn (? 15bn) takeover bid from Philip Green, the flamboyant retailing entrepreneur.
Preparing itself for what is set to be one of Europe's biggest corporate power struggles this year, M&S said Luc Vandevelde, the Belgian who was already due to depart as chairman, and Roger Holmes, chief executive for less than two years, would leave the ailing company with immediate effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND CLOSELY MONITORING PLA ACTIVITIES: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Tuesday it has so far not detected obvious signs showing that mainland China will conduct military exercises in the near future.

Military spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng was responding to media reports that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) will conduct combined services military drills on Dongshan Island in the Taiwan Strait that separates Taiwan from the Chinese mainland.

Huang said the PLA has usually conducted routine military exercises in the Dongshan area between May and August because the weather and the Taiwan Strait wave situation during the period are suitable for military training drills.
Therefore, Huang said, the MND doesn't rule out the possibility of the PLA conducting training exercises in the Dongshan area off the southeastern mainland coast opposite Taiwan in the coming months.
"But so far, we have not detected signs of major PLA movements or deployments, " Huang said, adding that in any event, the MND will continue to monitor PLA activities closely.
According to foreign wire service reports, mainland China is preparing for a combined services war game aimed at "taking control of the Taiwan Strait."
The reports said that up to 18,000 mainland troops will take part in the training exercise to focus on a mock amphibious landing on Taiwan.

The reports quoted a pro-Beijing Hong Kong newspaper as saying that the war game would take place in June and July on Dongshan Island off the southeastern mainland province of Fujian just 150 nautical miles west of Taiwan's Penghu Island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER REFUTES ALLEGATIONS OF DEFECTIVE REACTOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) -- builder and operator of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power plant -- refuted allegations Tuesday that the second of the two reactors for the plant under construction is defective.

Taipower officials said that the newly built reactor -- expected to be delivered from Japan before the end of June -- is safe and was built under strict manufacturing standards. "There will be no safety worries about the reactor since there is a full series of production and test run records, plus accreditation certificates issued by a number of relevant companies," Taipower officials said.

They said that like the first one, the second reactor for the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant was designed by General Electric (GE) and co- built by Hitachi and Toshiba. Full documentation on the production and test runs comply with the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) Codes and Standards, and the reactors have passed security and operational checks by engineers from GE and Taipower as well, they added.

The reactor, an Advanced Boiling Water Reactor (ABWR) , is the same model as the sixth and seventh ABWRs installed in the Tokyo Power Company's Kashiwazaki-Kariwa Nuclear Power Plant in Japan's Niigata prefecture.

Japanese and Taiwanese anti-nuclear activists have threatened to protest the delivery of the second ABWR from Japan to Taiwan, saying that the ABWRs at the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa facility had eight reactor trips in the first three-and-a-half years of operations from 1996, mostly as a result of cracks in fuel rods, a core and vital system of the reactors.
A reactor trip is an unscheduled shutdown to avoid overheating. Causes of a reactor trip can vary from mechanical to human error to acts of nature or a combination of all three.

To avoid such problems, Taipower officials said that they have seen to it that the designs, materials and manufacturing process of the two ABWRs for the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant have all been changed or modified.

Taipower officials denied the postponement of the ABWR's delivery from early June to the end of this month was the result of recent announcements by Taiwanese and Japanese anti-nuclear groups that they would protest the arrival of the second reactor on June 4 in Kungliao, Taipei County.
The NoNuke Taiwan Union lodged a protest last Friday against the delivery of the second ABWR, originally scheduled to arrive in Taiwan June 4.

NoNuke Taiwan Union Executive Director Ho Tsung-hsun said that several environmental protection activist groups in Taiwan and Japan will jointly launch protests and rallies in Taiwan and Japan, beginning Tuesday to express their opposition to the usage of the fault-ridden ABWRs.
The GE-Hitachi-Toshiba-built ABWRs are notorious for their frequent reactor trips over the past years of operation due to mechanical defects, Ho said.

A group of Japanese anti-nuclear environmentalists were also scheduled to launch a series of protests on the seas near Yokosuka Harbor Tuesday. The protests will be backed up by similar rallies to be held on land in a few other Japanese cities, Ho said.

He added that in Taiwan, environmental protection groups and social and human rights activist groups will also launch demonstrations at the Interchange Association, Taipei Office, which is Japan's liaison office in Taiwan, and in Kungliao, Taipei County, where the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant is located.
According to Ho, Taiwan could become only the second country in the world to use the ABWRs, which have proven to be unreliable.

Ho lambasted the government and Taipower for insisting on continuing construction on the controversial nuclear power plant and on using the ABWRs, noting that even the Japanese authorities have refused to endorse the safety of the core systems.

Japanese legislators had questioned the regulations on export permission for the ABWRs to Taiwan a couple of years ago, only receiving a reply from Japanese administration officials that "Taiwan should bear the full security responsibility for the import of the ABWRs, and we [the government] have no plans to suspend the export, " according to Ho.
The first of the two reactors for the Fourth Nuclear Power Plant was unloaded June 20, 2003, despite protests from residents near the construction site in Kungliao.
Construction on the controversial Fourth Nuclear Power Plant has only been half completed amid years of political wrangling over the issue dating back to 2000.

Construction was abruptly halted in October 2000 by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) just five months after it came to power with the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian in May of that year. The administration ordered a resumption of construction in February 2001 after encountering an enormous backlash from the opposition camp and the public.

The government even planned to allow a referendum to be held in Kungliao to enable the local residents to decide the future of the plant, as a nuclear-free Taiwan has long been a top priority of the DPP and was one of Chen's election promises. The referendum, however, has never been held.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION ARRIVES IN ATHENS TO INSPECT OLYMPICS VENUES
DOC.DATELINE: Athens, June 1 (CNA) (By Wu Shei-chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A 32-member Taiwan delegation arrived in Athens Tuesday to look over the venues for the upcoming summer Olympic Games.
The delegation was warmly greeted by Hsieh Tung-liang, Taiwan's representative to Greece, who also offered his views to the delegation.
Hsieh said that if Taiwan's team can win its first-ever gold medal -- something he said he was confident could be achieved -- it would raise the profile of Taiwan in the eyes of the world.

Hsieh noted that Athens won the right to host the Olympics Games in 1997, but it started construction projects only after stalling for three years, so that there are some small problems remaining on the main stadium, the starting point for the marathon as well as the swimming pools. The main stadium is scheduled to be complete on June 30, and workers are busy putting on the final touches.

He noted that the Olympics Games are scattered around 17 regions, and that the soccer stadiums are in four regions, including the more remote island of Crete, and that traffic among the venues of the Games could be a serious problem.

Hsieh reminded the delegation that in the marathon competition, after 17 kilometers, there will be a stretch of 15 kilometers of uphill roads, and that Taipei competitors will have to adjust their physical conditions.
He also pointed out that Greece has recruited Greek-American baseball players from the U.S. Major Leagues.
The delegation also called on the Athens Olympics Organization Committee to listen to their briefing Tuesday, and then went to the venues for badminton, taekwondo, baseball and softball.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES US$10,000 TO HELP FLOOD VICTIMS IN CARIBBEAN
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 1 (CNA) (By P.C. Fan and P.C.tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government recently donated US$10,000 in response to Pope John Paul II's appeal for help for flood victims in Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
The pope has called for the international community to enhance the humanitarian spirit by helping victims of the recent floods in the two Caribbean countries.

Tou Chou-seng, ROC ambassador to the Vatican, recently made two separate donations of US$5,000 to churches in the two countries through Vatican authorities to express the Taiwan government and people's concerns for the flood victims.

According to media reports, many houses in the two countries were destroyed by the floods caused by heavy storms over the past few days. At least 1,400 people have died, while thousands of others have lost their homes.

DOC.HEADLINE: BETTER MEASURES NEEDED TO STOP PASSPORT FRAUD: FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will actively study ways to step up measures to prevent passport counterfeiting, a ministry official said Tuesday.

Anna A. Kao, the foreign ministry's deputy director-general of the Department of Information and Cultural Affairs, made the remarks in the wake of Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan's suggestion at the Legislative Yuan the previous day to add fingerprint ID on key documents such as ROC ID card or passports.

Kao didn't respond directly to the suggestion, saying only that various problems do occur because of forged ROC passports and that they undermine the credibility of valid passports and anti-counterfeiting measures have to be strengthened.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved down Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June fell 22 points to close at 5,906, with 41,623 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July lost 11 points to end at 5,865, with 418 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 49 points to end at 5,845, with six contracts finalized.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, ended mixed.

No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 8.36 points to close at 5,986.2.
The bourse opened at 5,991.49 and fluctuated between 5,999.77 and 5,895.17.

A total of 3.36 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$66.21 billion (US$1.97 billion) , a decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 3.37 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$74.65 billion.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 4.8 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.7 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.4 percent, textile issues and foodstuff stocks both at 0.2 percent.

The other three major stock categories posted gains, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 0.9 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 0.4 percent, and electrical shares at 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 566 to 225, with 179 stocks remaining unchanged.

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, gaining NT$0.056 to close at NT$33.445.
A total of US$613 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.422 and fluctuated between NT$33.420 and NT$33.475.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT PROPOSES NEW MODE FOR COOPERATION WITH EL SALVADOR
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, May 31 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu said Monday she will try to persuade major Taiwan business groups to cooperate with El Salvador in building new cities or rural townships in the Central American country.

Lu, who arrived in San Salvador Sunday evening to attend Salvadoran President-elect Elias Antonio Saca's June 1 inauguration on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian, made the remarks while attending a cocktail reception hosted by ROC Ambassador to El Salvador Hou Ping-fu in her honor.
Speaking on the occasion, Lu said Taiwan and El Salvador have many things in common.

"We have shared values in freedom, democracy and human rights. Both of our countries were hit by devastating earthquakes several years ago. In 2000, the people of Taiwan elected its youngest-ever president, Chen Shui-bian, and its first-ever female vice president. Earlier this year, Salvadoran voters elected a 39-year-old as their new president, and Ana Vilma Albanez de Escobar, as their first-ever female vice president," Lu said, adding that she believes El Salvador will enter a new stage of accelerated national development under the leadership of Saca.
Lu told well-wishers that during a visit to a Tzu Chi community in Chanmico City on the outskirts of San Salvador earlier in the day, an idea occurred to her.

The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan's largest charity, cooperated with the Chanmico City Government and the Sacacoyo City Government in building a special residential community each in the two cities in 2001 after two strong earthquakes wreaked havoc in El Salvador.

The Tzu Chi foundation's U.S. branch spent US$6.5 million on building the two communities to accommodate displaced earthquake refugees. In addition, the Tzu Chi Foundation has continued offering free medical services, vocational training and basic computer education programs in the areas to help improve their residents' living conditions.

Inspired by Tzu Chi's success story, Lu said she plans to encourage Taiwan's elite business groups and agricultural experts to cooperate with Salvadoran authorities in building new cities or townships in the vicinity of San Salvador, El Salvador's capital, to help boost the ROC diplomatic ally's economic development.

Many Salvadoran government officials and social celebrities, including the wife of outgoing Salvadoran President Francisco Guillermo Flores Perez, Salvadoran Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Eduardo Calix and National Assembly Speaker Ciro Cruz Zepeda.

Later in the day, Lu delivered a speech on science, technology and life at El Salvador's National Science and Technology University. Elite members from El Salvador's various social quarters turned out to listen to Lu's speech.

Lu told the audience that Taiwan has come a long way in transforming itself from authoritarian rule to a full democracy. In 2000, she said, Taiwan completed its first-ever transition of power between different political parties in a peaceful, democratic manner.

Over the past five decades, Lu said, Taiwan has also scored outstanding achievements in economic development. Nowadays, she said, Taiwan is the world's 15th largest economy, with per capital national income of US$15,000 and the world's third-largest foreign exchange reserves. At the moment, Taiwan ranks among the world's three largest producers of 44 kinds of high-tech products and is the world's No. 1 manufacturer of 17 kinds of information-technology products. Moreover, 178 foreign business groups have set up regional operations headquarters in Taiwan.

Lu said Taiwan is now pursuing balanced national development, with equal emphasis on economic growth, environmental protection, social justice, human rights protection, gender equality and narrowing the wealth gap.

Meanwhile, Lu said, Taiwan is scheduled to complete sweeping constitutional reforms by 2008. Lu said she hopes the amended ROC Constitution will include a provision stipulating that the number of elected representatives of the same sex in the Legislative Yuan or local councils should not fall below one-third of the total seats.

Lu, who is the ROC's first-ever female vice president, said that since President Chen took power in 2000, Taiwan has made progress in recruiting more women into public service. "We now have a female vice president and a female vice premier," she said proudly.

As part of her effort to promote relations between Taiwan and El Salvador, Lu said she will launch a campaign to encourage Taiwan's university students to forge friendships by mail with their counterparts at El Salvador's National Science and Technology University.
After a two-day transit stop in Las Vegas, Lu arrived in San Salvador Sunday evening at the head of a large delegation to attend Saca's inauguration.

Members of Lu's entourage include Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Lung-yuan, and members of the Presidential Office's Science and Technology Advisory Commission and its human rights advisory panel.

Lu left Taipei Friday for her first overseas trip since she was sworn in for a second four-year term May 20. In addition to El Salvador, the 14-day diplomatic journey will also take Lu to Costa Rica and Guatemala. On her way back to Taipei, Lu will make a transit stop in San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES US$300,000 TO HAITI, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC FOR FLOOD RELIEF

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has donated US$150,000 each to Haiti and the Dominican Republic in the aftermath of devastating flooding, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday.

James Wu, the foreign ministry's deputy director-general of the Department of Central and South American Affairs, made the announcement against the backdrop of wire reports that over 1,700 people along the south-central border of Haiti and the Dominican Republic were killed after a week of torrential rain.
Wu said that more help would be required in the form of tents, clothing and food.
The foreign ministry will continue to coordinate with local charitable and non-governmental organizations to seek donations to help the two countries, Wu said.
Meanwhile, Wu also said that the prospects for Taiwan's entry into the Organization of American States (OAS) is good.
Wu's remarks came on the heels of the United States' support of Taiwan's entry into the regional organization as an observer. The proposal is now on the agenda for the next meeting.

In addition, former Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez is expected to assume the post of secretary-general of the OAS, and the rotating chairmen in the third and fourth quarters will be served by the representatives from Nicaragua and Panama, two of the ROC's allies.

He noted that the OAS is a major regional organization as is the United Nations and that Taiwan has worked toward joining the OAS for years. Through cooperative projects with American countries and bilateral exchanges, American nations have begun to understand that Taiwan is willing to contribute to the OAS, he added.
The OAS was set up in 1948 to promote democracy, human rights, peace, security and economic prosperity in central, south and north America and in the Caribbean area.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTEX TAIPEI 2004 KICKS OFF

TEXT.P: Computex Taipei 2004, the second-largest computer-related products exhibition in the world, kicked off at four halls of the Taipei World Trade Center and at the International Conference Center in Taipei, simultaneously, Tuesday.

Lin Hsin-yi, former vice premier and current senior adviser to the Presidential Office; Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou; and Taipei Computer Association Chairman Huang Chung-jen attended the opening ceremony of the trade show and spoke to offer their best wishes for the event.

Stan Shih, founder and CEO of Acer Computer, delivered a keynote speech at the opening ceremony. Shih said that he feels particularly honored as Computex Taipei -- which he established and named 20 years ago when he was the chairman of the Taipei Computer Association -- has prospered and become the world's second largest of its kind. Acer is now the fifth largest PC maker in the world.

Computex Taipei 2004 is expected to attract 25,000 buyers from abroad and some 70,000 local visitors during its five-day run, said Hsu Chih-jen, chairman of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), key organizer of the trade fair.

Although the venue has expanded for this year's event, Hsu said, some companies still have had difficulty finding display spaces as the numbers of both exhibitor companies and display booths have hit record highs.
A total of 1,347 companies are using 2,828 booths for Computex Taipei 2004, marking a year-on-year growth of 8.5 percent and 16.9 percent, respectively, according to Hsu.

The expansion has also made Computex Taipei the second-largest computer-related products exhibition in the world this year, edging out the Las Vegas autumn computer show (COMDEX) , which had been the second largest in recent years, said Hsu. The CeBIT Hanover Computer Show in Germany remains the largest.

Taipei Computer Association Chairman Huang Chung-jen said that of the three largest computer shows around the world, only Computex Taipei has continued to expand in scale and scope, indicating that the gravitational center of the world's information technology industries has shifted to Asia, with Taiwan being a stronghold.
Products on display at the exhibition include telecommunications equipment, computer system components, monitors, Internet applications equipment, various home digital products, and software.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT VISITS TZU CHI VILLAGES IN EL SALVADOR
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, May 31 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu praised Taiwan's Buddhist Compassionate Tzu Chi Society on Monday for showing "great love" to people around the world.

Lu, who is in El Salvador on an official visit, headed to a residential community in Chanmico City on the outskirts of San Salvador Monday morning. The community was one of the two "Tzu Chi" villages built by Tzu Chi, Taiwan's largest charitable organization, to accommodate displaced people after two devastating earthquakes rocked El Salvador in 2001.
Arriving to a warm welcome by the newly-moved-in residents of the "Tzu Chi" village in Chanmico, who waved small ROC banners flags, Lu said she was overwhelmed by the Salvadoran people's passion.
"Tzu Chi is a source of pride for Taiwan and an example of the fact that love has no borders," Lu said.
The two deadly earthquakes that hit El Salvador in 2001 killed more than 1,2000 people, injured more than 7,000 others, and destroyed some 300,000 houses.

Immediately after the earthquakes struck, members of the Tzu Chi Chapter in the United States rushed to the disaster scene and collaborated with the local governments on a plan to build 1,175 housing units at a cost of US$6.5 million.
The two "Tzu Chi" villages are located in Chanmico City and Sacacoyo City. In addition to houses, Tzu Chi has also worked to build schools, clinics, police offices and bus stations in the two cities.
President Chen Shui-bian officiated at a ground-breaking ceremony to mark the launch of the two "Tzu Chi" villages' development when Chen visited El Salvador at the end of 2001.

Two and a half years later, the two "Tzu Chi" communities are now fully developed. The local residents were so enthusiastic about the visit by Taiwan's vice president that some kindergartens even suspended classes so that students could go onto the streets and greet Lu.

According to volunteers from the Tzu Chi Chapter in the United States, despite the fact the two "Tzu Chi" villages have already been built, the Tzu Chi members have continued to visit the two cities frequently to offer free medical care, vocational training and computer lessons to the local residents in a bid to help them to be able to pull their own weight.

At the "Tzu Chi" village, Lu said that Taiwan had also received compassionate relief aid from around the world after a deadly earthquake struck Sept. 21, 1999. From the "Tzu Chi" communities, Lu said, she sees the fact that "love is without borders."

Lu, who initiated a campaign in 2001 to encourage Taiwan citizens to sponsor orphans in El Salvador, said she sees the Salvadoran children as children of her own. After several years of financial support, she said, the task now is to enable these children to receive a good education.

Lu, at the head of an ROC official delegation, arrived in El Salvador's capital of San Salvador Sunday evening to attend Salvadoran President-elect Elias Antonio Saca's June 1 inauguration on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian.
More than 100 ROC expatriates turned out to welcome Lu in front of the hotel where she will be staying. They waved ROC national flags and chanted slogans to welcome Lu and show their patriotism.

Lu left Taipei last Friday for her first overseas trip since she was sworn in for a second four-year term May 20. In addition to El Salvador, the 14-day journey will also take Lu to two other ROC diplomatic allies in Central America, namely Costa Rica and Guatemala. On her way back to Taipei, Lu will make a transit stop in San Francisco for two days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 1, or the 14th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1815: Napoleon Bonaparte, emperor of France from 1804 to 1814, swears fidelity to the French Constitution. His military and political might gripped Continental Europe but failed to encompass Great Britain.
1868: James Buchanan, the 15th president of the United States, dies at the age of 77. The first bachelor to be elected president, he tried to maintain a balance between pro-slavery and anti-slavery factions, but his moderate views angered radicals in both North and South, and he was unable to forestall the secession of South Carolina on Dec. 20, 1860.
1926: Marilyn Monroe, the American actress who led a turbulent life and became an icon after her death, is born. She appeared in several motion pictures, including "Some Like it Hot" and "The Misfits."
1929: A state funeral for China's Dr. Sun Yat-sen is held in Nanking at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Mausoleum on Mount Tzuchinshan.
1931: The Provisional Constitution for the Period of Political Tutelage of the Republic of China is promulgated.
1941: British forces are finally withdrawn from Crete with heavy losses. Some 3,000 Australians are also killed in the evacuation.
1946: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. is established in Shanghai.
1946: The Land Bank of Taiwan is inaugurated.
1957: Chiang Ching-kuo becomes chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen under the ROC Executive Yuan.
1958: The ROC wins the football championship at the Third Asian Games in Tokyo.
1958: General Charles de Gaulle becomes prime minister of France.
1960: O.K. Yu (Yu Hung-chiun), governor of the Central Bank of China, dies at the age of 65. Yu had formerly served as governor of Taiwan and premier of the ROC.
1968: Helen Keller, the blind and deaf American author and teacher, dies at home in Easton, Connecticut, at the age of 87, ending a life of outstanding courage that brought hope and inspiration to thousands.
1968: The Joint Service Committee for Overseas Chinese and Foreign Investors is established in Taipei.
1972: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Fredrick F. Chien as director-general of the Government Information Office; Chen Kuei-hua as director of the Personnel Administration Office; Hsieh Tung-min as governor of Taiwan; Chang Feng-hsu as mayor of Taipei; C.C. Chang as chairman of the Economic Planning Council; and Yang Chia-lin as chairman of the Administrative Research and Evaluation Committee of the Executive Yuan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Chaveng Youngcharoen, commandant of the Royal Thai War College, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1973: The ROC opens regular shipping service to Indonesia.
1975: An automated terminal radar system is installed at Taipei International Airport.
1976: ROC President Yen Chia-kan confers the Order of Propitious Clouds with Special Grand Cordon on Leabua Jonathan, prime minister of the Kingdom of Lesotho, and the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Lesotho Foreign Minister Charles D. Molapo.
1978: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the appointment of Lin Yang-kang as governor of Taiwan Province, and of Lee Teng-hui as mayor of Taipei City.
1979: Rhodesia takes the name Zimbabwe, with Bishop Abel Muzorewa as its first black prime minister, ending 89 years of white rule.
1979: The Taiwan Provincial Government decides to raise NT$28.82 billion before 1980 for the construction of the South Link Railroad which is planned for completion in December 1990. Upon completion of the project, a trip around the island will take only a day.
1989: Lee Huan is sworn in as premier of the ROC.
1990: U.S. President George Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev sign a bilateral agreement to stop producing chemical arms and to start destroying existing stocks by the end of 1992.
1999: Dr. Lien Wen-pin, chief physician of President Lee Teng-hui at National Taiwan University Hospital, says the president, now 77 years old, has the body of a 60-year-old and is in extremely good health.
1999: Francisco Flores, 39, is sworn in as the youngest-ever president of El Salvador.
2000: After four years of lackluster operations, the EVA Airways Corporation suspends its flights on the Taipei-Panama City route.
2001: The Republic of China Directorate General of Posts (DGP) issues a set of memorial stamps in commemoration of Canadian missionary doctor George Leslie Mackay, who died in Taiwan 100 years
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure derived from the study and criticism of the polite arts, pleasure in admiring and speaking of the excellent qualities of men, and pleasure in having many friends of virtue and talent: these pleasures are beneficial." ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MILITARY BUILDUP DESTABILIZING: U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 1 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States considers the mainland Chinese military buildup as destabilizing, according to the spokesman for the U.S. State Department.
"We do see the military buildup and missile deployment (against Taiwan) as destabilizing, " spokesman Richard Boucher said during a regular press briefing Tuesday.

"We've said that publicly as well, because it's a situation that is of importance to us and concern to us. We want to see peaceful resolution, we don't want to see coercion. And we want to be quite clear on that," Boucher noted.

The Pentagon warned in a report May 28 that mainland China was developing "credible military options" to prevent Taiwan from achieving independence, including tools to discourage the United States from coming to Taiwan's aid in the event of a cross-strait conflict.
Beijing on Tuesday defended its military buildup as essential to "safeguarding national sovereignty" and brushed off the Pentagon report as being hostile and based on a Cold War mentality.

Boucher was asked during the press briefing how he can reconcile the fact that the United States and mainland China are enjoying a warmer relationship and better cooperation, like in Iraq, while the United States at the same time still publicly treats China as a threat.

Boucher answered that he would not speak for the Pentagon report or comment on the Chinese reaction to it, but he did say that "we have had a very consistent policy of cooperating with China wherever we can but also being clear about our differences."

"And when it comes to the Taiwan Straits, I think we have a very consistent policy supporting peaceful resolution. We have opposed the use of force to settle the conflict in the Taiwan Straits, and we view military coercion as counterproductive. So that's been a very steady policy that we've enunciated before," Boucher said.

As to reports that the United Kingdom is about to join France and other E.U. members to lift the European Union ban on arms sales to mainland China, Boucher answered that he hasn't heard anything from the British on the issue.
However, Boucher added that "we've been fairly consistent in our talks with European Union members, making clear our view that it's not time to lift the arms embargo on China that they have."

DOC.HEADLINE: DELEGATION FROM RUSSIA VISITS TAIPEI COUNTY SEEKING EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: A delegation from Tomsk, Russia, paid a call on the Taipei County Government in Panchiao Wednesday, seeking exchange opportunities with Taiwan.
Led by Zinchenko Vladislav Ivanovich, deputy governor of Tomsk province, the delegation was greeted by Lin Hsi-yao, acting magistrate of Taipei County.
Ivanovich presented a plan for cooperation with Taipei County on 20 projects.

Tomsk is one of the most beautiful provinces in Russia, according to Ivanovich. In the capital, Tomsk, a fortress was commissioned in 1604 and served to protect a river crossing area. Gold mining in the 1830s in Siberia brought more people to the area. Tomsk State University was the first university in Siberia and was founded in 1878.

Ivanovich said that nowadays, Tomsk is widely known in Russia and beyond as a cultural and educational center. It is justly called the "Siberian Athens" that takes first place in Russia for the number of students and scholars per capita.
The 12-member delegation arrived in Taiwan on Tuesday for a six-day tour of Taiwan. Their itinerary will take them to many hi-tech companies as well as many universities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL SCIENCE COUNCIL TO FOCUS ON PROJECTS CONCERNING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The National Science Council (NSC) will focus on projects underlining Taiwan's uniqueness, said NSC Chariman Wu Maw-kuen Wednesday.

Wu said he exchanged views with Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Minister of Health Chen Chien-jen and Minister of the Council of Agriculture Lee Chin-lung on Saturday, exploring the possibility of cooperating with their offices in designing scientific research projects.
Wu said his council will devote its resources to studies concerning Taiwan's uniqueness, such as its culture, its multiple ethnic groups, and diversified races.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU TO MEET WITH AMCHAM EXECUTIVES ON CROSS-STRAIT LINKS ISSUE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun is willing to meet with members of the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) to exchange views on the opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Wednesday.
Chen made the remarks after AmCham unveiled its 2004 Taiwan White Paper a day earlier which said Taiwan risks to become irrelevant if direct cross-strait shipping and air links cannot be opened soon.
Since Taiwan was admitted to the World Trade Organization in 2002, Chen said, Taiwan has continued to ease restrictions on cross-strait trade, capital flow and visitor exchanges.
Chen attributed to slow progress in opening direct cross-strait shipping and air links mainly to Beijing's refusal to resume cross-strait dialogue.

Nevertheless, Chen said, Taiwan still has made all what it can do unilaterally to facilitate cross-strait transportation services, such as opening direct shipping services between its two frontline islands of Kinmen and Matsu as mainland China's Xiamen and Mawei as well as opening three of its sea ports for direct cross-strait transshipment services.

As opening direct cross-strait shipping and air links involve exercise of public authority and national security issues, Chen said, the two sides must hold direct negotiations to work out viable terms before such services can be launched.
Chen said the ROC government hopes that the AmCham can correctly understand Taiwan's efforts in this regard and convey Taiwan's goodwill message to mainland authorities.
"We earnestly hope that AmCham can play a catalyst role in helping push for resumption of cross-strait negotiations on direct shipping and air links," Chen said.

Chen also called on mainland authorities to make a goodwill response to President Chen Shui-bian's innovative and construction proposals outlined in his May 20 inauguration address to cross-strait rapprochement.
"Beijing should not impose political barriers to hinder cross-strait commercial exchanges and transportation services," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLITICAL WISDOM URGED TO SETTLE CROSS-STRAIT RIFT FOR COMPANIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan authorities need political wisdom to settle the cross-Taiwan Strait rift for mainland-based Taiwan businesses to operate smoothly in the mainland, a lawmaker who owns a computer company with mainland investments said Wednesday.

Kao Yu-jen, a lawmaker from the main opposition Kuomintang and chairman of Twinhead International Corp., made the comments after former Chi Mei Group Chairman Shu Wen-long was attacked by the Beijing-based People's Daily in its May 31 edition as reaping profits in mainland China to back Taiwan independence at home.

Expressing his hope that the two sides of the Strait can deal with each other peacefully due to frequent and close trade and economic exchanges, Kao urged the government to engage the mainland with wisdom and do its best to set up the three direct links across the Strait as quickly as possible.

Taiwan investments in mainland China are mutually beneficial for the two sides, as Taiwan businesses create job opportunities and prosperity for mainland people while the mainland serves as a cheap manufacturing base for Taiwan enterprises to become more competitive, he said.

For instance, Taiwan registered a trade surplus of US$38 billion with mainland China in 2003, far sufficient to compensate the US$20 billion trade deficit that the country recorded with Japan, Kao pointed out.
"Talking business as a businessman, 'peace' is what we need most," Kao stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT TO LEAD TAIWAN COMPANIES TO PROMOTE SALES IN WORLD MARKETS

TEXT.P: The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is planning to send eight trade delegations to major global market destinations this year, with India and South Korea as primary targets, BOFT officials said Wednesday.

The planned trade delegations will visit Latin America, Japan, South Korea, Eastern Europe, South Asia, Southeast Asia, the Middle East and Africa, with the economics minister or the vice minister leading the delegations, according to the officials.

For example, the officials added, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang embarked Wednesday on a trade promotion tour to four Southeast Asian countries, with representatives from 46 companies participating, the largest group in the last few years.

The officials went on that although mainland China has become Taiwan's largest trading partner, the recent unfriendly words by mainland Chinese officials toward Taiwan and its plan to cool down the economy on the mainland have made Taiwanese companies hesitant toward investing in the mainland Chinese market.

In order to help Taiwan enterprises reduce the risk for their investments in mainland China, the BOFT has held several symposiums to teach Taiwanese entrepreneurs how to evade risk and has, therefore, planned eight trade promotion tours to other markets.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs has South Korea as its main target to promote trade to reduce the trade deficit, while India, with a strong software industry, qualified high tech workers, as well as cheap wages, has been considered as a promising production base that can replace mainland China.

BOFT officials stressed that although the trade campaign conforms to part of the new economics minister's promise to help Taiwan entrepreneurs reduce risk in their investments and scale down investment in mainland China, it does not signify that Taiwanese companies should abandon the mainland Chinese market.
Instead, Taiwan companies should look to every market in the world, and strengthen the island's economic power through global resources, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM SUGGESTIONS WILL BE PASSED ON TO CABINET FOR REVIEW: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said the ministry will relay foreign business people's request for the establishment of direct transportation links with the mainland to the Executive Yuan.

Fielding questions from lawmakers, Shih, who attended the legislative session for his superior, Minister Ho Mei-yueh, said that for the time being the economics ministry will adhere to a three-step plan laid down by President Chen Shui-bian for opening direct links with mainland China.
While this plan might not live up to the expectations of some foreign businessmen, it does balance national security with the country's economic development, Shih said.

Furthermore, the vice economics minister said, the ministry continues to encourage local business people to diversify their overseas investments beyond mainland China. Brazil, Russia and India are three markets with potential, Shih added.

Shih pointed to the fact that Taiwan is already the biggest foreign investor in Vietnam; however, he admitted that except for India, there is no plan underway to promote investment in the other two countries.

Shih made the comments after the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei appealed for the rapid establishment of direct transportation links with the mainland in its Taiwan White Paper 2004, which was released the previous day. The report said that Taiwan is marginalizing itself and losing competitiveness because of the lack of direct links with the mainland.

Opposition lawmakers backed the conclusions in the White Paper and called for the Executive Yuan to accept the suggestions of foreign business people to open direct links with the mainland rather than encouraging local businessmen to invest in places other than the mainland.

However, an official from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said that the current efforts to speed up the existing transfer of goods across the Strait has gone nowhere since any changes must be done with the cooperation of the mainland, and Beijing remains intransigent.

Beijing has refused to cooperate with Taiwan on this program, claiming that it is a scheme by Taipei to create the facade of an international shipping lane across the Strait, when, according to Beijing, the lane would necessarily be a domestic route, given Beijing's insistence on its "one-China" principle.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CHIEF OF AVIATION SAFETY COUNCIL SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Kay Yong, the managing director of the Aviation Safety Council, was sworn in Wednesday as the council's chairman, replacing Vicky Liu, whose term expired on May 25.
Yong said he hopes the council will devoted its resources to the study of aviation safety, rather than investigating aircraft accidents.
The Aviation Safety Council is an independent government agency responsible for civilian aircraft accident investigations and the improvement of aviation safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR MILITARY PROCUREMENT AIMED AT SELF-DEFENSE: MND VICE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Major military procurement plans designed by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) are aimed at bolstering Taiwan's deterrent and self-defense capabilities, and do not translate to an arm race with mainland China, Vice Defense Minister Hou Shou-yeh said Wednesday.

Hou made the remarks to reporters after the Executive Yuan approved the ministry's special budget allocations for major military procurement programs worth a total of NT$610.8 billion (about US$18.23 billion).

Military procurement has been a key segment of the government's long-term military build-up policy to step up Taiwan's self-defense clout, which should not be affected by other factors, he pointed out.

According to the MND vice minister, the budget allocations put forward by the ministry include spending on weapons such as submarines, anti-missile systems and aircraft to hunt and destroy enemy submarines and to provide surveillance of surface shipping -- all prime items listed in the 2001 procurement program.
He stressed that Taiwan needs submarines very much to beef up its defense capabilities and that the defense ministry will do its best to promote the goal of building Taiwan's own submarines.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE SPEAKER TO HEAD DELEGATION TO U.S. FOR ARMS DEAL ISSUE

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will head a legislative delegation to visit the United States later this month to discuss arms procurement budget issues, political sources said Wednesday.

The sources revealed the travel plan after the Cabinet passed a Ministry of National Defense-proposed budget plan at its weekly meeting to buy anti-missile defense systems, anti-submarine aircraft and diesel-powered submarines from the United States.

The NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) budget proposal needs the opposition-controlled legislature's approval. Against this backdrop, the sources said, the United States has invited Wang to head a legislative delegation to visit Washington, D.C. as part of its efforts to lobby Taiwan lawmakers' support for the budget plan.

In addition to Wang, the delegation will be composed of a representative from the legislative caucus of each political party as well as the three conveners of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee.
The delegation is scheduled to leave Taipei June 17 or June 18, the sources said, adding that the itinerary has yet to be finalized.

The sources said the delegation has yet to decide whether to visit Washington, D.C. first and then travel to Hawaii on the way back to Taipei or to visit Hawaii first and then travel to the U.S. capital. Hawaii is the seat of the U.S. Pacific Command. The visit will take about 10 days, the sources said.
The proposed budget would cover six sets of Patriot Advanced Capability III anti-missile systems, eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Taiwan's defense spending has dropped in recent years because of overall government budget cuts, which could weaken the island's defenses in the face of mounting military threats from mainland China.
"Beijing has continued to boost it military spending in recent years, and we are worried about it," Chen said.
The Cabinet proposed raising the needed funds by issuing bonds or selling government-owned stocks and land, Chen said.
U.S. officials have complained that Taiwan has been taking too long to finalize the weapons procurement deals.
Chen said the Patriot missiles would cost NT$145 billion (US$4.3 billion) , the submarines NT$412 billion (US$12.3 billion) and the anti-submarine aircraft NT$53 billion (US$1.5 billion).
Opposition lawmakers have questioned if the Patriot missiles could effectively knock down mainland China's ballistic or cruise missiles, and have complained about the high costs of other weapons.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI AND UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT BERKELEY FORM RESEARCH CENTER

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) announced Wednesday that it established a research center at the University of California at Berkeley (UCB) on June 1.

ITRI President Johnsee Lee and UCB Vice Chancellor for research Beth Burnside signed a collaboration agreement on June 1 at the U.S. university on behalf of the two sides to establish the ITRI-UCB Research Center.

According to ITRI officials, Lee said at the signing ceremony that the cooperation project between the two sides will allow ITRI researchers to do research in an environment close to Silicon Valley, while UCB can accelerate the application of their researchers' vanguard ideas in the market, especially the Asian and Chinese markets.
It will be a win-win cooperation project for both, Lee added.
In the initial stage, both sides will focus their research on nanotechnology, energy and biochemistry, with exchanges of personnel, joint releases of theses, and intellectual property rights sharing.
Burnside noted that the establishment of the research center between ITRI and UCB will help the integration of engineering technology and different scientific spheres of both sides.
According to Lee, the ITRI will send five researchers to the center this year, and will consider enlarging the scope of the cooperation in the future.
