DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO RESUME TALKS TO SOLVE ILLEGAL IMMIGRANT PROBLEM

TEXT.P: Both sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume talks as soon as possible to solve the problems resulting from illegal immigrants sneaking into Taiwan from mainland China, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.
The premier made the remarks during a floor meeting of the Executive Yuan in which he heard that a recent crackdown by the authorities has nabbed more than 1,400 illegal mainland immigrants so far.

The Executive Yuan launched an inter-government agency project Nov. 1 last year, dubbed Operation Snakehunt, to crack down on illegal mainland immigrants that have strained the nation's financial burden and caused "major social order problems."
Statistics show that Taiwan has nabbed 1,437 illegal mainland immigrants over the past six months and exposed 25 human smuggling or syndicated crime rings.
The premier said that the operation has borne fruit in exposing smuggling and sex trade organizations, as well as tracking down illegal mainland immigrants hidden in Taiwan.
But he also said that the root of the problem lies with Beijing and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume talks as soon as possible to establish a crime-fighting mechanism.

He asked the Mainland Affairs Council to coordinate with Beijing in speeding up the repatriation of illegal mainland immigrants and supplying related information to mainland government agencies so as to "cut the flow at the root."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER LEAVES FOR SOUTHEAST ASIA TO PROMOTE TRADE

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang led a delegation Wednesday to several Southeast Asian countries to promote trade opportunities.
The delegation is composed representatives from a machinery association and the gift sector as well as officials from the Bureau of the Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

Shih and the delegation flew into the Philippines first. He will then roceed to Turkey to attend a meeting before going on to Thailand to meet up with the delegation and continue to Malaysia and Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET PASSES US$18.23 B. SPECIAL BUDGET FOR MAJOR ARMS PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has passed a special budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) for major military procurement to strengthen anti-missile defense and sea-control capability, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said Wednesday.

Chen Chi-mai made the remarks after the Executive Yuan passed major military procurement regulations and a major military procurement budget proposal, which will now be sent to the Legislative Yuan for review.

According to the budget appropriation for the special budget, the army will appropriate NT$144.92 billion to buy Patriot PAC-3 missile systems, the navy will appropriate NT$412.13 billion to buy diesel-powered submarines and the air force will get NT$53.04 billion to buy anti-submarine planes.

Chen noted that the money to finance the special budget will come from NT$94 billion through the release of shares of state-owned enterprises, NT$100 billion from the selling of state-owned land, and the raising of the national debt of NT$420 billion.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed related government officials during the Executive Yuan floor meeting that they must step up communications with the Legislative Yuan to solicit the support of the legislators, according to Chen.
Chen said that with mainland China's military expenditure increasing every year, the Executive Yuan has decided to appropriate the special budget so as to strengthen the nation's defense capability.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL LAUNCHES REGULAR TAIPEI-HIROSHIMA FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) -- Taiwan's largest carrier -- launched regular commercial flight services covering the Taipei-Hiroshima route Wednesday, with 152 passengers aboard the maiden flight.

CAL General Manager Philip H.H. Wei presided over the maiden flight ceremony at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, with scores of dignitaries from Taiwan and Japan taking part, including Association for East Asian Relations Chairman Hsu Shui-teh, Tourism Bureau Director-General Su Cheng-tien and officials from the Tokyo-based Interchange Association.

CAL uses Boeing 737-800 airplanes on the thrice-weekly flights and has marketed special package tour programs featuring Hiroshima to attract more Taiwan passengers that have long been an important tourist resource for Japan.

In a separate development, Wei told reporters that CAL has decided to impose a fuel surcharge of US$7 on each passenger for each travel section between two destinations -- for instance, travel between Taipei and Hong Kong or travel between Taipei and Los Angeles -- in the face of soaring oil prices.
The measure will take effect after the Civil Aeronautics Administration gives its approval, Wei added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SETS TIMETABLE FOR PARTY PRELIMINARIES FOR LEGISLATIVE POLL

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) set a timetable Wednesday to hold party preliminaries for the national legislative elections slated for December of this year, KMT spokesman Tsai Cheng-yuan said Wednesday.

The timetable was agreed upon by members attending the weekly meeting of the Central Standing Committee -- the policy-making unit of the KMT. KMT Chairman Lien Chan and Vice Chairman Ma Ying-jeou, who is also Taipei mayor, took part in the meeting, among others.

It was decided that June 7 will be open for would-be candidates to register, while the coming week-long period between June 8-14 will be available for them to submit their registration forms. On June 25, a seminar will be held to decide the contestants' participation numbers through a draw, and they are slated to air their political views during the June 26-July 9 period.

The party will conduct a public opinion survey from July 3-16, and party members will vote July 18, with the results of the poll made public that same day. A composite outcome that a contestant receives pending the poll, coupled with the party's vote results, will decide whether he or she will be nominated to represent the party in the year-end legislative elections.

It was also decided in the meeting that Legislator Liao Fung-te, a whip of the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan, will assume the post as head of the party's Department of Organization Development, taking over from Ting Shou-chung.

Liao, a veteran legislator from eastern Ilan County, vowed to help the KMT win the poll and grab a larger number of seats in the legislature. At present, it controls 66 at the 225-member Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CONVEYS GREETING TO U.S. PRESIDENT FOR LONG-TERM SUPPORT
DOC.DATELINE: San Salvador, June 1 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu Tuesday asked Florida Governor Jeb Bush, brother of United States President George W. Bush, to convey greetings to the U.S. president.

Lu, who sat beside the Florida governor at a national banquet given by El Salvador President Elias Antonio Saca, asked Bush to convey her appreciation to President Bush for his long-term support for Taiwan.

Knowing of Jeb Bush's friendship with Therese Shaheen, former chairperson of the American Institute in Taiwan, which is in charge of dealing with Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties between Taipei and Washington, Lu also asked him to convey her greetings to Shaheen.

They also talked about increasing trade exchanges between Taiwan and Florida. Bush said that he has visited Taiwan four times, with the last visit in 1991. Lu invited him to visit the island again, and Bush said he would consider this. In turn, the Florida governor also invited Lu to visit his state.

Lu also spoke about the impact on the world brought about by severe acute respiratory syndrome, adding that if Taiwan were allowed to join the World Health Organization, it would able to contribute its experience in fighting the disease.
Earlier, Lu attended the inauguration of Saca and Vice President Ana Vilma Albanez de Escorbar.
Although she has not completely recovered from the leg wound she received during the March 19 election-eve shooting, she did not use crutches.

She also refused wheelchairs prepared by her entourage for the trip, preferring crutches, although they have caused bruising to her left hand because of her busy schedule during her two-day transit stay in Las Vegas.
Since arriving in El Salvador Sunday evening, she kept the use of crutches to a minimum, but her schedule was even tighter.

On Monday, she called on El Salvador's president and vice president, as well as the president-elect and vice president-elect. She also delivered a speech at El Salvador's University of Technology and visited a residential community in Chanmico City on the outskirts of San Salvador, which was build in 2001 by Taiwan's largest charity group -- The Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation -- after two strong earthquakes wreaked havoc there.
During the inauguration Tuesday, Lu walked about 70 meters without crutches to the grandstand to the warm applause of all participants.
She said afterwards that "as a representative of my country, I think I have performed well."

Lu will attend a banquet given by overseas Chinese residing in El Salvador in her honor Tuesday night and will hold an international press conference Wednesday before continuing her trip to Costa Rica, the second leg of her Central American trip.
Despite her leg wound and tight schedule, she said that "with will, I will complete the trip."

The vice president left Taipei Friday for her first overseas trip since being sworn in for a second four-year term May 20. In addition to El Salvador and Costa Rica, her 14-day diplomatic visit will also take her to Guatemala. On her way back to Taipei, she will make a transit stop in San Francisco.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS RESCUE NETWORK FOR ABUSED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun issued a directive Wednesday on the building of a nationwide information and rescue network for the protection of abused children and youths.

Speaking at a regular meeting at the Executive Yuan, Yu said his heart goes out to children and youths who have been physically and mentally abused and tortured and have had their human rights deprived as a result of family crises.

Yu instructed the relevant agencies to look into the matter by having specialists make field trips to communities and households before building a nationwide network that can inform, rescue and protect those underprivileged youngsters.

He said public authorities must intervene in efforts to save the mentally and physically tortured children and youths from families and institutions where economic, marital or social problems have made their living environment hell.
The premier also urged parents to discard the mentality that their children are private assets and instead learn to raise and educate their offspring in the right manner.
Yu issued the directive in response to a recent spate of social incidents involving children and youths being abused and even killed.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING HAS YET TO UNIFY BASIC TAIWAN POLICY TONE: NSB

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese authorities have yet to unify their basic policy tone toward Taiwan, a senior national security official said Wednesday.
National Security Bureau (NSB) Deputy Director Huang Lai made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee.

During the session, opposition lawmakers asked about Huang's views on Beijing's recent saber-rattling against Taiwanese investors in the mainland. Earlier this week, Chinese Communist Party mouthpiece the People's Daily ran an editorial saying that Beijing does not welcome pro-independence Taiwanese businessmen. The editorial even accused Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the Chi Mei Group, of making money on the mainland to fund Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and publicly calling for Taiwan independence.

In response, Huang said the verbal attack is part of the mainland's "psychological warfare" ploy. Beijing used a similar strategic in 2000 when the DPP came to power for the first time, Huang recalled.
Quoting intelligence reports, Huang said that the mainland has yet to set its basic Taiwan policy tone after President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration for a second four-year term.

He said the NSB has continued to keep a close eye on developments in Beijing's Taiwan policy formulation. Moreover, he said, the bureau has been conducting long-term research of cross-Taiwan Strait economic exchanges and relevant issues.

"We are also studying the background of Beijing's current round of saber-rattling against Taiwan businessmen with interests in mainland China, " Huang said, adding that the mainland fingerpointing at Taiwan businessmen marks a violation of its own promise not to politicize business issues.
Noting that Beijing has said on numerous occasions that it would not politicize trade issues, Huang said it should abide by its words and protect Taiwan businessmen's investments on the mainland.
Given Beijing's fickleness and capriciousness, Huang said, Taiwan businessmen should understand that investing in the mainland is very risky.

Commenting on reports that the mainland is gearing up preparations for combined services war games on Dongshan Island off the southeastern mainland province of Fujian just 150 nautical miles west of Taiwan's Penghu Island, Huang said it has become routine for the People's Liberation Army (PLA) to conduct training drills in the Dongshan area.

"For the past five to six years, the PLA has conducted a series of training exercises on Dongshan Island between July and August annually, " Huang said, adding that the training drills have usually focused on mock amphibious landing exercises.

According to a pro-Beijing Hong Kong newspaper, up to 18,000 mainland troops will take part in the Dongshan Island drills from June to July with the aim of practicing strategies and tactics for taking control of the Taiwan Strait.

Huang said attacking Taiwan is the PLA's long-term goal. "Beijing has consistently been preparing to take Taiwan by force. But so far, we have not yet detected obvious signs of large-scale mainland military movements or deployments," Huang said, adding that the NSB will continue monitoring the PLA's activities in order to work out suitable response measures to protect Taiwan's national security.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved down Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June fell 116 points to close at 5,790, with 32,455 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July lost 111 points to end at 5,754, with 250 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 88 points to end at 5,769, with six contracts finalized.
December futures fell 110 points to close at 5,750, with three contracts concluded.
No transactions were recorded for next March.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,906 for June, 5,865 for July, 5,857 for September, 5,860 for December and 5,873 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved down.
June TE futures fell 5.1 points to close at 239, with 3,979 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 5.25 points to end at 237.95, with 29 contracts transacted.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures lost 19.6 points to end at 927.4, with 3,307 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures dropped 19.4 points to end at 917.6, with 78 contracts traded.
Next March TF futures fell 4.2 points to close at 937, with two contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: RULES ON RESIDENCE APPLICATIONS BY MAINLAND CHINA SPOUSES EASED

TEXT.P: Rules on residence applications by Taiwan people's mainland Chinese spouses have been eased after the Bureau of Immigration under the Ministry of the Interior agreed to simplify the process, a bureau spokesman said Wednesday.

In the future, undisputed applications submitted by mainland spouses to reside in Taiwan will be immediately approved after being examined by the bureau, the spokesman said, adding that qualified documents do not have to be further processed in a joint screening meeting and neither do applicants from the mainland have to go through an interview with immigration officials, the spokesman said.

According to the spokesman, the first joint screening meeting was held May 18 to scrutinize a total of 704 applications. Except for a very small number of disputed cases due to the background of the applicants, who were found to be either Chinese Communist Party members or to have criminal records, the vast majority of the applications were approved in the meeting, he noted.

In a related development, representatives of a cross-Taiwan Strait marriage promotion association kicked off an endorsement campaign outside the Bureau of Immigration Tuesday in protest against what they claim is the government's "unfair treatment" of mainland husbands and wives in Taiwan.
They criticized the joint screening process as damaging the interest of mainland spouses and asked the government to stop fueling resentment between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 110.53 points to close at 5,875.67.
The bourse opened at 5,908.01 and fluctuated between 5,945.54 and 5,875.22 during trading.

A total of 2.64 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$55.47 billion (US$1.66 billion) , a decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 3.36 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$66.21 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 2.2 percent, followed by cement stocks and bank and insurance shares both at 2 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.7 percent, construction stocks at 1.4 percent, textile issues and plastics and chemical shares both at 0.9 percent.
Pulp and paper issues, however, rose 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 758 to 81, with 125 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG, MACAU URGED TO SET UP REPRESENTATIVE OFFICES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) is hoping that the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau can set up representative offices in Taiwan soon, an MAC official said Wednesday.

Chang Yung-shan, director of the MAC's Department of Hong Kong and Macau Affairs, noted that 3,073 students from Hong Kong and Macau are studying in Taiwan, accounting for a third of the overseas students presently on the island.

In addition, there are also residents from the two regions coming to live in Taiwan, Chang said. As neither Hong Kong nor Macau have set up representative offices in Taiwan, they cannot help deal with problems their residents face while living in Taiwan, he said.
In view of the situation, the department is studying measures to take care of Hong Kong and Macau people living here, he said.
But he stressed that "such a unilateral move will not be comprehensive" and he expressed the hope that the two special administrative regions will address the issue squarely and set up offices here.
However, he went on, Hong Kong has not responded positively or showed any intention to set up a Taiwan office, despite having been contacted by the MAC.

In contrast, Macau people residing in Taiwan have exerted greater pressure in the Macau Administrative Region, and as far as his department understands, Macau has heeded their voices and is now studying the issue, he said.

Chang also spoke of the visa application of Pao Cheng-kang, Taiwan's new representative to Hong Kong, expressing the hope that Hong Kong will pragmatically address the importance of Taiwan-Hong Kong affairs so as to grant the visa application speedily.
He expressed hope that the review procedure of Pao's application will be faster than that of his predecesor, Chang Liang-jen, who had to wait for three months before getting his visa four years ago.
He also said that both the MAC and Taiwan businessmen are watching closely economic and political developments in Hong Kong.

Saying that it has been three months since the signing of a closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) between mainland China and Hong Kong, he added that it will take six more months to see the effect of the CEPA on Hong Kong.
He also noted the greater restrictions placed on Hong Kong by the mainland, despite the Hong Kong people's calls for more democratic rights to select their leaders and legislators.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST TAIWAN-RUSSIA WATER RESOURCES CONFAB HELD IN MOSCOW
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, June 1 (CNA) (By Vlogya Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Officials and specialists from Taiwan and Russia gathered in Moscow Monday for the 1st Taiwan-Russia Water Resources Conference to exchange views on and experiences in hydrology, fresh water resources management and related technologies.

The participants struck an agreement upon the conclusion of the conference that Taiwan and Russia will engage in bilateral exchanges in water resources management and related technological fields on a regular basis in the future.

The 12-member Taiwan delegation, comprised of officials from the Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, as well as academics from universities and representatives from the private industrial sector, was led by WRA Director-General Chen Shen-hsien.
The Russian delegation, meanwhile, was comprised of scholars and specialists from the water resources research institute under the prestigious Russian Academy of Sciences.
Russian expertise and research in water and ocean resources is renowned worldwide. The Russian "water" researchers have long been keenly interested in Taiwan's research in the same field.

Most of the Russian participants said that they are amazed at the depth and scope of Taiwan's research in hydrological sciences, water resources management and related technologies, particularly in the integration of public water utilities and related technologies. One of the Russian participants said that he has gained unexpected knowledge about his particular field after coming in contact with Taiwan's research.

In addition to taking part in the water conference, the Taiwan delegation will also attend an international hydrology exposition -- ECWATECH-2004, the 6th International Trade Fair and Congress Water: Ecology and Technology, slated to open in Moscow this week.
The visit to Moscow by the Taiwan delegation is also part of warm-up efforts ahead of an international water-related technology exposition slated to open in Taiwan Sept. 3, according to Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-PARAGUAY TIES REMAIN FIRM AND SOLID: MOFA

TEXT.P: Diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Paraguay remain firm and solid, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Richard Shih said Wednesday.
Shih was responding to media reports that mainland China has been lobbying Brazil to pressure Paraguay to switch its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing.

Shih said the reports were speculative. As a matter of fact, Shih said, Taiwan-Paraguay relations have been in good shape. For instance, Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte just concluded a state visit to Taiwan late last month during which he attended President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration for a second four-year term.

After his return to Asuncion, Shih said, Duarte told the Paraguayan press that his Taiwan visit was very fruitful and that the two countries will negotiate and sign a free trade agreement within a year.

Asked whether Paraguay is likely to yield to pressure from its Southern Common Market allies to switch its diplomatic allegiance, Shih said Duarte has reiterated on many public occasions that Paraguay's diplomatic ties with the ROC have contributed much to the country's economic development over the past decades.
"All these events point to cordial and solid relations between our two countries," Shih said.
The Southern Common Market groups four South American countries, namely Paraguay, Argentina, Brazil and Uruguay. Paraguay is the ROC's only diplomatic ally in South Amercia.

Moscow, June 2 [CNA] The Moscow Times:Regions in for a Dose of Kremlin Reform.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 2, or the 15th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1886: Grover Stephen Cleveland, the 22nd and 24th president of the United States, marries Francis Folsom in the White House. He was known as an honest independent president opposed to corruption and the "spoils" system.
1896: Italian engineer and inventor Guglielmo Marconi patents in London his wireless telegraph apparatus, a device that transmits spoken messages over long distances without the aid of wires or cables. He shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics after transmitting long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1904: Johnny Weissmuller, American and Olympic swimming champion, is born. He later turned to acting, playing Tarzan in many films.
1922: Hsu Shih-chang resigns as president of the Beijing government.
1927: Wang Kuo-wei, a master in the study of Chinese literary classics, commits suicide at the age of 50 by jumping into Kunming Lake in the Yi-ho Garden in Beijing. The garden was built by Empress Dowager Tsu Hsi at the end of the Ching dynasty.
1942: Chinese Foreign Minister T.V. Soong and U.S. Secretary of State Cordell Hull sign the Sino-American Lend-Lease Agreement in Washington.
1953: The Archbishop of Canterbury at London's Westminster Abbey lowers the crown of St. Edward onto the head of Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary, making her Queen Elizabeth II of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The ceremony marks the first televised coronation.
1964: The Palestine Liberation Organization is formed in Jerusalem.
1966: Surveyor I, a U.S. automated spacecraft, lands in the southwest sector of the moon's Oceanus Procellanum and begins sending back the first close-up pictures of the moon's surface.
1969: The Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne collides with the U.S. destroyer Frank E. Evans in the South China Sea, killing 74 American sailors.
1973: A three-nation invitational basketball tournament opens in Taipei.
1974: China Airlines starts all-cargo services to the United States' West Coast.
1974: Jig Singhi Wangchuk, 18, is crowned king of Bhutan, becoming the youngest monarch in the world.
1976: Dr. Adnan Khasoggi, chairman of the Saudi Arabian Triad Holding Corporation, and a party of 20 members arrive in Taipei to explore investment possibilities.
1979: Pope John Paul II, the first non-Italian to be elected pope in 456 years, sets foot again on the soil of his native Poland to an emotional welcome. The pope's visit marks a major opening-up in the relationship between the Roman Catholic church and the countries of the Communist bloc.
1983: The ROC Executive Yuan approves a revision to raise by tenfold the compensation for "wrongful detentions and executions."
1984: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Chiu Chuang-huan, former vice premier, as commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Assembly and, concurrently, as governor of Taiwan Province.
1985: English football clubs are banned indefinitely from playing in Europe because of hooliganism by English fans abroad.
1985: Hu Nai-yen, an ROC violinist residing in the United States, wins an international music contest held in Belgium.
1990: British actor Sir Rex Harrison dies at the age of 82. He is best remembered for his role as Professor Henry Higgins in the musical "My Fair Lady," a part that he played both on Broadway and on the London stage as well as in the 1964 film version, for which he won a Tony and also an Academy Award.
1992: Representatives from 185 nations take part in the world's largest environmental summit in Rio De Janeiro, Brazil.
1999: Women in Japan finally win the right to use the birth control pill.
2000: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh accepts President Chen Shui-bian's appointment to head a supra-party task force on cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
2000: Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh Chang-ting is the sole candidate in the running for Democratic Progressive Party chairman, as the official registration deadline ends today.
2001: The Chinese-Taipei Olympic Committee (CTOC) and the Mongolian Olympic Committee sign a sports cooperation and exchange agreement in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Pleasure in dissipation, in extravagance, in mere conviviality, are injurious."

Oil prices slipped on Wednesday away from a fresh record high of $42.45 struck on fears that a campaign of violence by Islamic militants in Saudi Arabia could destablize the world's biggest crude exporter.

DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: All boxes to be opened before canvass No end is in sight as far as determining the results of the May 10 presidential and vice presidential elections. Not wanting to trigger another time-consuming debate with the minority, the Congress leadership abandoned yesterday the proposal to tally Certificates of Canvass (CoCs) and open ballot boxes simultaneously to speed up the ongoing proceedings and ensure the proclamation the winners by the end of June.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Congress opens more than half of ballot boxes CONGRESS has opened more than half of the 223 ballot boxes containing votes for president and vice president. As it ended its session on Wednesday at 9 p.m., the joint session, sitting as the National Board of Canvassers, had examined the contents of 55 more ballot boxes, making the total of opened ballot boxes 137 since Monday.
The Manila Times: SC asked: Stop canvass The opposition on Wednesday asked the Supreme Court to order Congress to stop the canvassing of the election returns for president and vice president through its committee composition created by the Senate President and Speaker of the House of Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: Church says Charles can marry.
Friends of Prince Charles and Camilla Parker Bowles have admitted that the couple are actively considering wedding plans after the Archbishop of Canterbury Dr Rowan Williams dropped his objections after secret talks with the Prince.
Financial Times: Spitzer hits GSK with drug lawsuit.
GlaxoSmithKline, the pharmaceutical giant, was accused on Wednesday of fraudulently suppressing research that suggested its anti-depressant Paxil was ineffective and unsafe in treating children.
The civil suit, filed in New York by Eliot Spitzer, the state's activist attorney-general, is significant because it adds to the scrutiny of communications between pharmaceutical sales forces and doctors.
The suit alleges that studies by GSK found a possible link between use of Paxil and "an increased risk of suicidal thoughts and acts in adolescents".

The government is poised to release an investigation report today, rebutting allegations that the university entrance exam was leaked in March, the education minister said yesterday. (Franics Kuo)

DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Interim Iraqi Government Is Installed.
With car bomb and rocket attacks sounding in the background, an interim Iraqi government representing a delicate mix of the country's main ethnic and religious group was appointed after weeks of wrangling over who would lead the country when the U.S.tranfers sovereignty this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO SIGN FREE TRADE AGREEMENT WITH PHILIPPINES: OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 3 (CNA) (By Emerson Lim and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: Taiwan hopes to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with the Philippines to further promote two-way trade and mutual benefits, an official of the Republic of China government said Thursday.

Shih Yen-hsiang, ROC vice economics minister, who was visiting Manila at the head of a trade mission, said that the two nations signed a memorandum of understanding at last November's Taiwan-Philippine trade and economic cooperation meeting, pledging to further promote bilateral trade and exchange of information and to organize more trade promotion activities in the two nations.
Given that regional economic integration is a new global trend, Shih said that Taiwan expects to sign an FTA with its neighbor.

The Philippines is Taiwan's 10th-largest trading partner and the second-largest in Southeast Asia, with two-way trade of US$5.3 billion recorded last year, leaving a surplus of US$780 million in the Philippines' favor, Shih noted.
Furthermore, he added, Taiwan's investment in the Philippines had accumulated to US$1.1 billion as of 2003.

For his part, the Philippine Vice Minister of Trade and Industry said that Taiwan-Philippines economic relations has extensive room for improvement, given that the two nations are very close geographically.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIAN DELEGATION TO VISIT TAICHUNG TO CANVASS INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: A delegation from India's Gujarat Province will pay a call on the Taichung Branch of the Economic Processing Zone Administration in Tantzu, Taichung County, June 11 to hold one-to-one talks with local businessmen who are interested in venturing into the South Asian country, according to a press release issued Thursday by the Economic Processing Zone Administration.

The press release said Gujarat, located close to Mumbai, is an ideal place for Taiwan businessmen seeking to break into India, which is the world's seventh-largest country in terms of size and the second-largest in terms of population.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT AGREES WITH AMCHAM ON MAINLAND CHINA LINKS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that his administration fully agrees with the views of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei about the urgency of opening direct transportation links with mainland China.

Two days after AmCham warned in its 2004 white paper that Taiwan is marginalizing itself and putting in jeopardy its plan to develop itself into a regional business hub because of the lack of direct transportation links with the mainland, the president said the responsibility does not rest solely upon Taiwan, which has already done its best to bring about such links.

If Beijing would put its differences with Taiwan into perspective and face up to issues in a pragmatic way, it would certainly be conducive to the establishment of a relationship beneficial to both sides and would narrow the gap between them, Chen said.
However, the president took comfort from the white paper's affirmation of the country's achievements in his first four-year term and the high expectations it holds for his second term.

As to the white paper's criticism of the lack of coordination between government organizations, especially between the executive, judiciary and legislative branches, the president ascribed this to the ruling party's failure to control the legislature over the last four years and he expressed hope that this will be addressed if his Democratic Progressive Party wins a majority at the legislature in the year-end legislative elections.
At that time, the president said, the persistent political struggle between the legislature and the Executive Yuan will stop and the pace of reform will be accelerated.

Chen said he shares the white paper's points of view that Taiwan has been consumed with political concerns in the past year and that competing political parties need to cooperate, compromise and communicate in civil fashion for the sake of the overriding national interest.

Noting that friends who are blunt, considerate and informed are most valuable, the president thanked AmCham for its opinions about the country's business climate and promised to take the white paper seriously while laying down policy in the future.
The president made the comment while receiving a group of distinguished engineers at the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVENTS CHIP TO EXAMINE FOR SARS

TEXT.P: A chip which can help diagnose severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in its preliminary stage was invented by the National Health Research Institutes (NHRI) and the Center for Disease Control under the Department of Health, according to a news release issued by the NHRI.

The chip, which matches the DNA in a specimen with that of the coronavirus which prompted SARS, can detect the existence of the virus when there are only a few of them and will be a valuable tool in diagnosis, especially when it is used in combination with the polymerase chain reaction, the ordinary test for the coronavirus, the release said.
A report about the invention will be published in the Laboratory Investigation monthly in July. (By Maubo Chang) ENDITE/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI TO RECRUIT TALENTED INDIVIDUALS IN U.S.

TEXT.P: The Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) will start a two-week talent recruitment program in the United States June 5, offering more than 200 job opportunities, ITRI officials said Thursday.

ITRI President Johnsee Lee will head a delegation comprised of various department chiefs of the institute to tour Silicon Valley, San Diego, Chicago and Boston to introduce their talent recruitment programs and hold individual interviews with prospective applicants, the officials said.

The officials quoted Lee as saying that his upcoming trip is to recruit talented individuals who are interested in research and innovation of advanced technologies in the electronic, information industry, telecommunications, biomedicine, nanotechnology, manufacturing, systematics and energy sectors.

The officials said that the ITRI has been seeking international cooperation and talented individuals around the world in recent years in order to upgrade the standards of research and development of the institute, as well as of Taiwan's technological industry.
Over the past five years, they noted, the ITRI has recruited a total of 172 talented individuals with doctorates and 185 with masters degrees from abroad.
The ITRI will continue its overseas recruitment programs with the aim of making its research personnel globalized, they emphasized.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND ISSUES POSITION PAPER ON ARMS PROCUREMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) issued a position paper Thursday to solicit public support for its three important arms procurement projects which will cost an estimated NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion).
This marked the first time in recent memory that the MND has ever issued a position paper to enlist public support for the its weaponry purchase plans.
The ministry issued the position paper after many lawmakers from across the political spectrum questioned the high cost of the procurement projects.

The Cabinet passed the MND-proposed budget plan for purchasing anti-missile defense systems, anti-submarine aircraft and diesel-powered submarines from the United States. The US$18.23 billion budget proposal needs the opposition-controlled legislature's approval.
The MND said in its position paper that in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat, the military needs those new weapons to beef up its defense capabilities.
The proposed budget would cover six sets of Patriot Advanced Capability III anti-missile systems, eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

The Patriot missiles would cost NT$145 billion (US$4.3 billion) , the MND position paper said, adding that this purchase project will be carried out from 2005 to 2012. Installation of the new Patriot anti-missile defense systems will help deter mainland Chinese missile attacks, the MND said.

Meanwhile, the MND position paper said, the procurement of eight conventional submarines will cost NT$412 billion (US$12.3 billion) to be carried out from 2005 to 2019, and the purchase of 12 anti-submarine aircraft will need NT$53 billion (US$1.5 billion) to be carried out from 2005 to 2011.
These purchase projects will help enhance the armed forced combined services combat capabilities and as well as their maritime and aerial monitoring and reconnaissance abilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD INCREASE ARMS PURCHASES: CABINET SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Thursday that Taiwan should raise its military expenditures amid mainland China's increasing military buildup, in terms of both quality and quantity.

Chen made the remarks the day after the Cabinet passed a special budget plan for arms procurement from the United States. The budget plan, worth NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion), will be sent to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

Chen revealed that this year's U.S. report on the mainland's military power contains much criticism of Taiwan's defense budget and that the U.S. government is also worried that Beijing's arms purchases have seen double-digit growth in recent years, with its annual military expenditure oscillating between US$50 billion and US$70 billion.
Amid the increasing military imbalance between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan needs to raise its military expenditure to ensure its anti-missile capability, Chen added.

He added that the mainland has strengthened the combat capability of its joint forces and the accuracy of its long-range missiles since the U.S.-led war in Iraq, so it is of tremendous importance that Taiwan purchase anti-missile Patriot defense systems, among others.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORENSIC REPORT ON MARCH 19 SHOOTING TO BE COMPLETED IN SEPTEMBER
DOC.DATELINE: Connecticut, June 2 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A comprehensive forensic report on the March 19 shooting of Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu will be completed in September at the earliest, Dr. Henry Lee, a world-renowned Chinese-American forensic expert, said Wednesday.

Lee, who traveled to Taiwan in April to examine evidence and scene of the election-eve shooting in the southern city of Tainan, made the remarks before attending a cocktail reception marking the world premiere of a new TV drama series featuring criminal investigations, with Lee himself as the leading actor.
Lee said he has kept in close contact with Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau and other relevant agencies since his April trip to the island.

"I know they will simulate the March 19 shooting later this month, including a bullet test-firing, to determine the trajectory of the bullets that hit Chen and Lu. When the test-firing is completed, they will fax the results to me. I'll then analyze the test results and come up with a comprehensive report on the forensic evidence, " Lee said.

If all goes smoothly, Lee said, the report can be finalized in September. He stressed that he is only responsible for forensic examination of the evidence, not for the criminal investigation or a solution of the case.
Lee further said he will determine whether to come to Taiwan again after he receives the trajectory test report.

As to why the CIB has not conducted a mock shooting earlier, Lee said the delay mainly resulted from difficulties in creating a home-made toy gun and bullets similar to those used in the shooting. "It takes time to complete these difficult tasks," he added.

Lee said he has taken part in forensic examinations of assassinations of top leaders and politicians in many countries around the world. "But I have never seen a country's president and vice president shot simultaneously, " he said, adding that if the crime scene had been preserved well, it would have been much easier to solve the case.

One bullet grazed Chen's stomach and another hit Lu's knee while they were parading in an open-topped jeep past crowds of flag-waving supporters in Tainan on the eve of the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election.

The shooting has given rise to a wide range of increasingly bizarre conspiracy theories, including allegations by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) that the president staged the attack to win sympathy votes in the election, which he won by a narrow margin.
The opposition has said it cannot accept Chen's re-election victory until the election-eve shooting has been solved.

Although police have not announced any solid leads or suspects, the "pan-blue alliance" has not found any compelling evidence that the shooting was faked. Lee and several other U.S. forensics experts have analyzed Chen's and Lu's injuries and concluded that they were genuine gunshot wounds caused by bullets fired from outside the jeep, not from inside, as has been claimed by opposition lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLANNED NEW PARTY HOPES TO GRAB 15 SEATS IN NEXT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: A planned new party to be formed by independent lawmakers has set a goal of seizing 15 seats in the legislative elections slated for December, a founder and would-be chairwoman Chang Po-ya said Thursday.
Chang, who heads an organizing committee to prepare for the party's formal establishment, made the remarks to reporters in her native Chiayi City in southern Taiwan.

According to Chang, the purpose of the plan to form a new party, which will follow a "middle road, " is to provide the people with a third option in addition to the opposition "pan blue alliance" or the "pan-green camp" -- principally the ruling Democratic Progressive Party -- at a time when Taiwan has become polarized as a result of a deep rift caused by disputes over Taiwan's cause and ethnic grouping after the March 20 presidential election.

The new party, which will be named "non-partisan freedom alliance, " will be formally set up after registration has been completed in early August, she said, adding that founding members -- 10 independent lawmakers without party affiliation -- will first call an establishment meeting in July.
Chang, who has served as Chiayi mayor, lawmaker, interior minister and Taiwan provincial governor, is one of the country's few prominent female political figures.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEPORTS JAPANESE YAKUZA MASTERMIND

TEXT.P: Taiwan deported Thursday a Japanese citizen allegedly involved in Japan's largest-ever cross-border money laundering case.
Takashi Yamane, 35, was deported under the escort of three Japanese police officers via a Japan Asia Airways flight Thursday afternoon, a Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) official said.

Yamane, the top financial manager of Yamaguchi-gumi, Japan's largest yakuza group -- or organized crime syndicate -- is accused of masterminding Japan's largest-ever cross-border money laundering case, which was uncovered in March 2003. He fled Japan and traveled around Southeast Asia.

Japanese police sought the CIB's assistance in tracking Yamane down in late April. Initial investigations showed that Yamane entered Taiwan April 25 via a Cathay Pacific Airways flight. However, the CIB could not find out where he was staying.

As Yamane's visa-free stay expired May 24, the joint task force formed by Taiwan and Japanese police authorities carefully scrutinized ticket reservation lists of various air carriers for the period from May 20 through May 24. The task force then discovered that Yamane had booked a seat on a May 21 Air Macau flight bound for Hong Kong.
CIB agents did not arrest Yamane until after he had entered the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport's control area and he was then sent to a foreigners detention center on the outskirts of Taipei.
Japanese police authorities in charge of organized crime sent staff members to Taipei May 27 to discuss the time and formula for deporting Yamane.

Both the Japanese Interchange Association -- the de facto Japanese embassy in Taipei -- and the Republic of China's representative office in Japan sent officials to oversee Thursday's deportation procedure.

According to CIB agents, Yamane is a graduate of a prestigious Japanese university. As he was versed in financial transactions, he quickly emerged as the most powerful financial manager in Yamaguchi-gumi, a legally registered underworld syndicate.

Yamane is accused of having laundered the yakuza syndicate's illegal profits worth more than 46 billion yen (US$418.18 million) in Hong Kong and several Southeast Asian countries. A total of 43 suspects involved in the case, including Yamane, have been arrested so far.
According to newly revised Japanese law, Yamane could face a maximum five-year prison term plus a fine of up to 100 million yen.

Local media reports said Yamaguchi-gumi maintains close ties with major Taiwan criminal rings, particularly the Four Seas gang. CIB sources said they believe that local underworld rings provided shelter for Yamane during his stay in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL DRAGON BOAT RACE CHAMPIONSHIP TO BEGIN

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taipei International Dragon Boat Race Championship will run from June 20 to June 22 at the Keelung River to celebrate Dragon Boat Festival, Taipei City Government officials said Thursday.
It is expected that nearly 100 teams from around the world will participate in the race, which was suspended last year due to the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

Heading a group of city government officials at a news conference, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a sports enthusiast, encouraged the team of high-ranking city officials to give it their all since they have been defeated two years in a row by a team of physically and mentally retarded persons.
Dragon boat races are held and glutinous rice wrapped in bamboo leaves are eaten in remembrance of Chu Yuan, a famous poet and official (343-290 B.C.) of the Warring States Period.
Chu drowned himself after failing to convince the king of Chu to guard the kingdom against an enemy. The festival is held on the fifth day of the fifth month of Chinese lunar calendar.
In additional to dragon boat races, a series of performance activities will also be held at the Tajia Riverside Park to observe the Dragon Boat Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA HAS NOT DISCUSSED LOAN ISSUE WITH MONGOLIA: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday that his ministry has discussed setting up representative offices with Mongolia, but has never talked about providing loans to the country.
Chen was responding to reports that said Mongolia is planning to withdraw its representative office in Taiwan after Taiwan failed to deliver on its promise to provide loans.
Chen said that since both sides reached agreement on setting up bilateral representative offices, the ministry has never talked about anything concerning loans.
But if domestic businesses are willing to provide loans to Mongolia, then they are not related to the ministry, he continued.

Chen also denied reports that quoted him as saying that former Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien will serve as the new representative to the European Union to replace David Ta-wei Lee, who has been designated to serve as the new representative to the United States.
Chen dismissed the reports, saying that with the experience and talents of Chien, he will be entrusted with a major post, although he was not clear which one that might be.

Asked whether Chen's appointment will only be published after Lee, the current ROC representative to the EU, receives formal approval from the United States to serve as the ROC's representative to the U.S., Chen didn't give a direct answer.
Chen said that as far as he understands, the U.S. has yet to officially approve Lee's appointment, although it has in principle agree to such an arrangement.
Meanwhile, Lee is scheduled to return to Belgium Friday to handle the EU office and his personal businesses.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC WELCOMES U.S. PROPOSAL FOR TAIPEI-WASHINGTON-BEIJING CONTACTS

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) welcomes any recommendation that can boost reconciliation or rapprochement across the Taiwan Strait, a senior official said Thursday.

MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san made the remarks after James Kelly, U.S. assistant secretary of state for East Asia and the Pacific, said at a hearing of the Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific of the House Committee on International Relations a day earlier that the United States strongly supports "track two" unofficial or quasi-official talks among Taiwan, mainland Chinese and American representatives.
Kelly said unofficial or quasi-official contacts are a good way for testing various initiatives to break the current cross-strait impasse.
"We share Kelly's view, " Chiu said, adding that the MAC always welcomes any proposal that can contribute to positive developments in cross-strait relations.

As a matter of fact, Chiu said, President Chen Shui-bian has on many occasions suggested that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait exchange representative offices to facilitate direct dialogue and avoid misunderstandings and misjudgments.

Chiu said the biggest difficulty for the moment lies in Beijing's reluctance to resume cross-strait dialogue. Beijing unilaterally shut the dialogue channel between the two quasi-official intermediary bodies -- Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- in July 1999 over then-ROC President Lee Teng-hui's describing cross-strait ties as a special "state-to-state" relationship.
Just last week, Chiu said, MAC Chairman Joseph Wu invited ARATS President Wang Daohan, the top mainland Chinese negotiator with Taiwan, to visit Taipei.

"We hope Beijing can make a goodwill response to our invitation and resume the long-stalled SEF-ARATS dialogue, " Chiu said, adding that so long as the two sides can sit down to talk, any dispute or topic can be discussed.

In the past two days, two major foreign trade associations -- the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei and the European Chamber of Commerce Taipei (ECCT) -- issued recommendations that Taiwan take immediate steps to open direct cross-strait transportation links. The two trade groups warned that Taiwan might risk becoming irrelevant if it drags its feet on opening direct shipping and air links with the mainland.

"We appreciate their recommendations. But direct cross-strait transportation links involve many complicated issues that must be addressed through bilateral consultations. We have drawn up many complementary measures. Mainland China should also do its part in preparations. We hope AmCham and the ECCT can help persuade Beijing not to impose too many prerequisites or political barriers and to resume dialogue with Taiwan as soon as possible," Chiu said, adding that the two sides should resume contacts and increase engagements steadily to forge a consensus to resolve sensitive disputes in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CADET GRADUATES FROM U.S. AIR FORCE ACADEMY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 3 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Chang Chi-jung, an air force academy cadet from the Republic of China, graduated from the United States Air Force Academy (USAFA) Wednesday after studying there for four years, becoming the first ROC air force cadet to have completed USAFA education.
President George W. Bush delivered the commencement speech to the more than 900 graduates at Colorado Springs and later shook hands with each of them.

With his diploma in his left hand, Chang took the rare opportunity to shake hands with the U.S. president to express appreciation for his support of Taiwan, with Bush nodding his head and smiling to acknowledge his thanks.
Chang's parents flew in from Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan to attend their son's graduation ceremony, and officials from the ROC's representative office also witnessed the ceremony.
Chang, 23, came to the United States after studying one year in Taiwan's Chinese Air Force Academy. He finished in the top one third of graduating cadets in the USAFA.
Chang is one of three ROC military academy cadets who recently graduated from U.S. military academies.
Tang Tzu-wei and Lee Wu-ling graduated from the United States Naval Academy and United States Military Academy at West Point on May 28 and May 29, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AVRDC PRESIDENT BESTOWED DECORATION FOR EXCELLENT CONTRIBUTION
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 3 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China's Representative in Britain Tien Hung-mao bestowed a decoration Wednesday upon the former president of the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center (AVRDC), Declan J. Walton, for his contribution in elevating Taiwan's status in agricultural research.

On behalf of the ROC government, Tien conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Violet Grand Cordon to Walton, an Irishman who served as president of the AVRDC, headquartered in Tainan, southern Taiwan, from 2000 to 2003.

The AVRDC is an internationally known center for agricultural research and development aimed at reducing poverty and malnutrition in developing countries through improved production and consumption of vegetables.

Established in 1971 by the ROC, the United States, Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Vietnam, the Philippines, and the Asian Development Bank, the AVRDC is one of the few international organizations of which Taiwan is a member.
Tien noted that Walton's leadership has strengthened the operations of the AVRDC and elevated Taiwan's status in agricultural research.

Walton's contributions to the AVRDC and to Taiwan are quite significant at a time when Beijing is using every means to squeeze Taiwan's space in the international community, including blocking the operations of the AVRDC, Tien stressed.

Walton revealed two difficulties he had encountered when serving as AVRDC president: Some donor countries were hesitant in making donations for fear of offending mainland China, and the organization's limited budget.
However, Walton added, ROC government's generous financial support has largely resolved the organization's budget problems.
The former AVRDC president also suggested that the organization extend the scale of its operations and do more to help backward areas of the world to reduce poverty.

According to ADB estimates, the AVRDC has generated revenue worth US$1.8 billion in Southeast Asia, with an investment return rate reaching 91 percent, the highest among all Asian agricultural research and development centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA PLASTICS TYCOON VISITING MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group Chairman Wang Yung-chin is currently visiting mainland China and is probably inspecting a petrochemical zone that the group invests in, in southeastern China, an executive with the group said Thursday.

Wang's trip comes at a sensitive time with mainland China stepping up verbal attacks on Taiwan businessmen. The People's Daily, the Beijing's mouthpiece newspaper, said in a front-page editorial Monday that it does not welcome Taiwanese businessmen who use profits made on the mainland to finance the pro-independence movement back in Taiwan. The article singled out Chi Mei Group Chairman Hsu Wen-lung for specific scorn.
Wang maintains a low profile during his trip to the mainland and does not publicize his itinerary.
The executive said that Wang is probably inspecting the petrochemical zone in Ningpo, Zhejiang province, and could also visit some friends on the mainland.

Commenting on reports that Wang might donate a sum of money to an elementary school on the mainland, the executive said that if this is the case, then it is Wang's own wish and has nothing to do with the group's operations.

The executive said that Wang usually stays no more than one week during each trip to the mainland, mainly because of his advanced age. The 87-year-old tycoon, who departed Wednesday, is expected to return to Taiwan for work next Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WILL NOT SEEK OR WELCOME TAIWAN TROOPS IN IRAQ: U.S OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 2 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States will not seek or welcome Taiwan sending troops to Iraq, U.S. Assistant Secretary of States for East Asian and Pacific Affairs James Kelly said Wednesday.

Kelly made the remarks when he was testifying at a hearing on U.S. policy in East Asia and the Pacific at the U.S. House Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific under the Committee on International Relations.

Congressman Dana Rohrabacher (R-Ca.) -- the co-chairman of a pro-Taiwan group, Taiwan Caucus, who proposed last week that the U.S. government ask Taiwan to send 5,000 marines to fight alongside the U.S.-led coalition in Iraq -- asked Kelly if the Bush administration would be amenable to Taiwan offering to send troops to help in Iraq.

In response, Kelly said that Taiwan has "helped out in Iraq with humanitarian and tangible items for use in construction. I do not believe that we would seek or welcome the advent of Taiwan troops, because that would require a degree of cooperation that might help things in Iraq, but it would raise tensions significantly in East Asia."

Rohrabacher said that the United States would certainly not want to provoke any confrontation while its troops are engaged in Iraq; however, he added: " Sending 5,000 troops from Taiwan, a democratically-elected government, to help establish a democracy in Iraq would be a good thing, and it is so sad that we are afraid to anger a dictatorial regime in Beijing, and that's why we are not willing to look at that alternative."

Rohrabacher and Jim Ryan (R-Kan.) introduced a proposal to the House Committee on International Relations May 20 suggesting that Taiwan send troops to fight alongside U.S.-led coalition forces to signify their shared values of promoting democracy and opposing terrorism.
The proposal has sparked heated debate and concerns among Taiwan society, although both U.S. and Taiwan government officials have denied that the two sides have ever discussed the issue.

TEXT.P: New York Times: Polygraph Testing Starts at Pentagon in Chalabi Inquiry

Federal investigators have begun aadministering polygraph examinations to civilian employees at the Pentagon to determine who may have disclosed highly classified intelligence to Ahmad Chalabi, the Iraqi who authorities suspect turned the information over to Iran, government officials said Wednesday.

The polygraph examinations are focused initi ally on a small number of Pentagon employees who had access to the information that was compromis ed. American intelligence officials have said that Mr. Chalabi informed Iran that the United States had broken the secret codes used by Iranian intelligence to transmit confidential messages to posts around the world. Mr. Chalabi has denied the charge.
Wall Street Journal: Granbury, Texas, Isn't a Rural Town: It's a 'Micropolis'

Between 1990 and 2000, the population of Granbury and surrounding Hood County increased 40 percent, to 48,000. A sparkling lake, affordable housing and the promise of a quieter life have drawn many people to Granbury, out in cattle country some 70 miles southwest of Dallas.

Marketers and demographers are starting to pay attention to places like Granbury: growing population centers far removed from the nearest large city, often 100 miles or more. They are drawing refugees both from rural America and suburbia.

Last summer, the U.S. Census Bureau officially recognized these places as "micropolitan" areas. To qualify, a locale must have at least one town of 10,000 to 49,999 people -- and it can have several of these -- and proportionally few of its residents commuting outside the area. The government figure d there were 567 such micropolises in the continental U.S. More than 28 million people, or one in 10 Americans, reside in them.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT CONFERRED HUMAN RIGHTS MEDAL IN COSTA RICA
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Costa Rica, June 2 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu received a human rights medal from the University of Costa Rica (UCR) Wednesday for her life-long efforts in promoting democracy and human rights.

Lu arrived in Costa Rica at around noon Wednesday after a three-day official visit to neighboring El Salvador where she attended the inauguration of new Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian.
Shortly after her arrival, Lu kicked off a hectic visit schedule. In the afternoon, she delivered a speech on the new vision for the 21st century at the prestigious University of Costa Rica.
Lu lauded Costa Rica as a beautiful country which rejects both war and armed forces while upholding peace as its ultimate national goal.

"I have traveled halfway around the globe to Costa Rica from the other side of the Pacific Ocean with the hope of promoting bilateral cooperation in creating a new democratic Pacific alliance to work for the well-being of humankind," Lu said.
While Costa Rica has long been reputed as a "Switzerland in the Americas, " Lu said, the ROC government is now endeavoring to build Taiwan into a "Switzerland in Asia."
"Our two countries have ample room for cooperation to realize our common goals of peace, freedom, democracy and prosperity," Lu said.

Stressing that democracy, peace and prosperity are the universal values of the new Pacific century, Lu said Taiwan and Cost Rica should jointly push for the formation of a new alliance of all democratic Pacific countries and glorify the "soft power" values of freedom, democracy, science, technology, love and peace.
Lu's speech drew a capacity audience at the UCR auditorium. The audience included UCR faculty and students as well as elite members from Costa Rica's various social quarters.
At the end of the speech, the university presented the "best human rights fighter" medal to Lu in recognition of her contributions to promoting democracy and human rights over the past decades.

Lu was imprisoned for more than six years for her pro-democracy campaign during Taiwan's martial law era. Lu, who has a master's degree in law from Harvard University, had been a lawmaker and a local government chief before becoming the ROC's first-ever female vice president in 2000.

After her arrival in San Jose, Lu was greeted by Costa Rican Vice President Lineth Saborio at the airport. She first paid a visit to Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella and then held talks with Saborio. Both Pacheco and Saborio expressed their gratitude for the ROC's longstanding assistance to their national development and assured Lu of Costa Rica's continued support for Taiwan's cause, including its bid to join the United Nations and other major international organizations.

Later in the day, Lu visited the Costa Rican National Assembly where she attended a ceremony marking the 60th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the ROC and Costa Rica. The two countries signed an amity agreement in 1944 on forging "lasting peace and friendship."

A congratulatory message celebrating the two countries' 60-year-old diplomatic relationship was read at the ceremony. Costa Rican National Assembly Speaker Gerardo Gonzalez and scores of lawmakers joined Lu in wtinessing the ceremony.
Costa Rica is the second leg of Lu's current 14-day diplomatic tour, which will also take her to Guatemala.

This is Lu's first overseas trip since she was sworn in for a second four-year term on May 20. She made a two-day transit stop in Las Vegas en route to El Salvador and will also make a transit stop in San Francisco on her way back home.

Members of Lu's entourage include Presidential Office Deputy Secretary-General James Huang, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Huang Lung-yuan, and members of the Presidential Office's Science and Technology Advisory Commission and its human rights advisory panel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 3, or the 16th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1839: China's Ching Commissioner Lin Tse-hsu orders the burning of the more than 20,000 chests of opium handed in by foreign merchants in Kwangtung, sparking the Opium War between China and the British. Since 1930, June 3 has been observed in China as Opium Suppression Movement Day.
1896: The Ching court and Russia sign a treaty in Moscow forming a defensive alliance for 15 years and granting Russia the rights to operate railways in northern Manchuria.
1899: Johann Strauss the Younger, Austrian conductor and composer of waltzes, dies at the age of 74. He is sometimes called "the Waltz King" and is best remembered for his numerous waltzes such as "The Blue Danube."
1924: Austrian writer Franz Kafka dies in a sanitarium in Kierling, near Vienna, at the age of only 40 after losing a seven-year battle with tuberculosis. The writer, whose stories include "The Trial" and "Metamorphosis," exerted a huge influence on modern writers.
1925: American actor Tony Curtis is born as Bernard Schwartz. His many films include "Some Like It Hot," "The Boston Strangler," "Spartacus" and "The Vikings."
1937: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves the adoption of the KMT's party song as the national anthem of the Republic of China. The words of the ROC national anthem were first issued by Dr. Sun Yat-sen as his opening instruction to the students of Whampoa Military Academy on June 16, 1924.
1937: The Duke of Windsor, formerly King Edward VIII of Great Britain, marries his American sweetheart, Wallis Warfield Simpson, in Paris.
1942: The Battle of Midway, a turning point for the Allies in the war in the Pacific, begins. The U.S. Navy launches an attack against the Japanese fleet, sinking four Japanese aircraft carriers and battleships as well as six transport ships.
1946: Chen Kung-po, former acting president of the Nanking government, is executed for treason. The puppet regime had been established in China by breakaway government official Wang Ching-wei on March 29, 1940, and reorganized by Japan on Nov. 19, 1940.
1946: The first bikini goes on show in Paris.
1959: Singapore gains internal self-government under a new constitution, with Lee Kuan Yew, leader of the People's Action Party, as prime minister.
1965: Astronaut Edward H. White becomes the first American astronaut to take a walk in space when he steps outside his Gemini 4 spacecraft.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan, who was elected president of the Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement Committee to succeed late President Chiang Kai-shek, urges members of the committee to follow the example of the late president in propagating traditional Chinese culture.
1976: Shyzo Toda, president of the Japanese Chuo (Central) University, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: The 445,000-ton tanker Burmah Endeavour, built by the China Shipbuilding Corp. for U.S. Gatx Oswego, is launched at Kaohsiung. It is the world's third largest vessel.
1985: ROC nationals Chen Chi-le and Wu Tun are sentenced to life in prison by the Taiwan High Court for the murder of outspoken writer Liu Yi-liang, also known as Chiang Nan, in the United States.
1987: The Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang approves a revised draft of the ROC National Security Law.
1989: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, spiritual leader and head of the state of Iran, dies at the age of 86.
1991: Mt. Unzen erupts in Japan, killing some 40 people.
1994: An earthquake rocks Java, Indonesia, killing more than 170 people.
1998: A train derails in Lower Saxony, Germany, killing 98 people.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen visits the offshore islands of Tungyin and Matsu, his first visit to the frontline islands since he assumed the post on May 20.
2001: Chang Jung-kung, director of the Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Department, says that the 1989 crackdown on the unarmed pro-democracy students in Beijing's Tiananmen Square is a major factor which has driven the Chinese communists toward a more open society.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three kinds of errors to which men are liable when in the presence of their superiors. First, to speak out when one is not called upon to speak: that is called being forward. Second, to keep silent when called upon to speak: that is called being disingenuous. Third, to speak out without taking into consideration the expression in the eyes of the person spoken to: that is called blindness."

DOC.HEADLINE: LU TO STICK TO ITINERARY OF OFFICIAL VISIT DESPITE PHYSICAL PAIN
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Costa Rica, June 3 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu has insisted that the itinerary of her official visit in Costa Rica will be followed without interruption despite her checking into a hospital in San Jose briefly Thursday due to pain in her limbs.

Lu arrived in Costa Rica Wednesday after a three-day official visit to neighboring El Salvador where she attended the inauguration of new Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian.

Taiwanese doctor Chen Yao-chang said the vice president has been suffering from a muscle fracture to her left arm and a slight dislocation in her left thumb and left elbow as well as from the injury to her left knee sustained in the March 19 assassination attempt. He said the vice president's hectic schedule over the past week in the United States and Central America has aggravated the injuries.

Lu had declined to use a wheelchair or even a walking cane over the past several days to avoid creating a "negative image" for the ROC as she visits overseas in her capacity as vice president of the country.
Nevertheless, Dr. Chen fitted the vice president's arm with a sling on Wednesday and advised her to use a walking stick to prevent a further aggravation of her injuries.

Continuing with her original itinerary, Lu visited the POAS volcanic national park in a suburb of San Jose Thursday morning and attended a luncheon at the Hotel Fiesta hosted by ROC Ambassador to Costa Rica Wu Tzu-dan.
On Wednesday, Lu received a human rights medal from the University of Costa Rica in recognition of her contributions to promoting democracy and human rights over the past decades.

She met with Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella around noon Wednesday. Pacheco expressed his gratitude for the ROC's longstanding assistance to Costa Rica's national development and assured Lu of his country's continued support for Taiwan's cause, including its bid to join the United Nations and other major international organizations.

Later that day, Lu visited the Costa Rican National Assembly where she attended a ceremony marking the 60th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the ROC and Costa Rica. The two countries signed an amity agreement in 1944 on forging "lasting peace and friendship."

Asked by Taiwan reporters about recent reports that Taiwan's monetary aid to Costa Rica was used to pay the salaries of Costa Rican Foreign Ministry officials, Lu said monetary aid to the ROC's diplomatic allies should continue despite untrue allegations.

Lu said extending monetary aid to diplomatic allies is the set policy of the ROC as one of the means of consolidating bilateral ties. Meanwhile, she said, it is the duty of the members of the ROC Legislature to strengthen their supervision over Taiwan's diplomatic expenses.

She added that the legislators can visit more of the country's diplomatic allies, instead of countries that maintain no formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan, to examine how and where the money has been used.
Costa Rica is the second leg of Lu's current 14-day diplomatic tour, which will also take her to Guatemala.

This is Lu's first overseas trip since she was sworn in for a second four-year term on May 20. She made a two-day transit stop in Las Vegas en route to El Salvador and will also make a transit stop in San Francisco on her way back home.

Legislator Lee Chun-yi, the secretary of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said Yu told a group of DPP lawmakers at a dinner party Friday that the arms-purchase budget meets the country's urgent requirements and should enjoy the support of different parties.

The chance that the special budget for arms purchases will be discussed at the legislature soon is slim in light of the fact that the current legislative session is supposed to end by June 11. The premier is eager to cinch the deal for 388 patriot missiles, eight submarines, and 12 anti-submarines airplanes.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-JAPAN NGO FORUM OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The second Taiwan-Japan NGO Forum began Friday at National Chengchi University in Taipei to strengthen exchanges among the non-governmental organizations (NGO) in Asia.
The forum was organized by the NGO Affairs Committee of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Center for the Third Sector of Chengchi University, and the Japan-based NGO BHN.
Chiang Ming-hsiu, director of Chengchi University's Center for the Third Sector, noted that the Third Sector, similar to NGOs, has played an active role in the development of modern Asian society.

The concept of the Third Sector originates especially in those fields where private and public sectors are reluctant to get involved, and the emergence of the Third Sector is to fill the gap to ensure public interests are met, particularly those of minority groups.

Chiang said Taiwan and Japan are geographically close and have similar religions, society types and cultures; therefore, the exchanges of the Third Sector between the two countries, especially in disaster rescue experiences, are of tremendous importance.

Lu Ching-lung, deputy director of MOFA's NGO Affairs Committee, encouraged Taiwan's civil organizations to propose cooperation plans to their Japanese counterparts to let their Japanese friends know Taiwan people's determination to contribute to the world community.
Iwahito Asahara, president of the BHN, said he was pleased to see that NGOs from Taiwan and Japan can work more closely through the exchanges.
