DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESSMAN QUESTIONED FOR EXPORTING INFRARED EQUIPMENT TO MAINLAND

TEXT.P: An executive of a hi-tech company in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, was questioned Friday by prosecutors under suspicion of having exported hi-tech equipment to mainland China.

Shih Kuei-chung, general manager of the Queenning Hi-Tech Corp. in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, was referred to the Prosecutors' Office of the Hsinchu District Court for investigation by agents from the Investigation Bureau.
An investigator said Shih's company, which engages in the production of infrared cameras and components, was suspected of selling infrared thermal imaging systems to mainland customers since 1998.

Besides medical applications, these infrared thermal imaging systems can also be used on night vision equipment for tanks, jet fighters and missiles and were, therefore, forbidden to export to the mainland.

Shih Kuei-chung's brother, Shih Kuei-shong, who serves as the company's vice general manager, was arrested in San Francisco on May 23 by FBI agents, which tipped off local law enforcement officials on Queening's potentially illegal deals.
An anonymous military official said the infrared thermal imaging systems are widely used by the military in equipment used to detect and locking onto targets in the dark.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND ELABORATES ON BUDGET ALLOCATIONS FOR MAJOR MILITARY PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) called a news conference Friday to elaborate on its budget allocations worth NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for major military procurement programs amid grave public concern over the issue.

Vice Minister Hu Chen-pu chaired the news conference, with ranking representatives from the army and navy explaining and detailing the contents, timetables and purposes of their military build-up programs for the years to come in conjunction with the United States.

Yang Tien-shiao, a lieutenant-general and chief of the general staff of the Army General Headquarters, said the army plans to purchase six batteries of Patriot PAC-3 missiles for an eight-year period from 2005 to 2012, with a price tag of NT$144.92 billion.

According to Yang, the installation of the advanced missiles in northern, central and southern Taiwan will effectively help the military protect at least 70 percent of the civilian population and more than 60 percent of the country's industries, a noticeable improvement from the current levels of 25 percent and 8 percent.

At present, the army only has three Patriot PAC-2 missile batteries in northern Taiwan, making it unable to provide comprehensive protection for the whole island by countering multi-headed missiles or those carrying biochemical agents, he explained.

Lee Tung-hai, chief of the general staff of the Navy General Headquarters, said the navy aims to purchase submarines with effective deterrent capabilities in an effort to strike a balance and even achieve naval supremacy in the Taiwan Strait.

The navy is intent on buying eight diesel-fueled submarines, with the delivery for the first unit slated for 2013 and for the last unit in 2019, Lee said, adding that the total spending, including ammunition and relevant facilities, is estimated at NT$412.1 billion.
Turning to the navy's need for 12 P-3C anti-submarine airplanes, Lee said that NT$53.4 billion has been allocated for that expenditure, he said.
While the establishment of the squadron will take seven years, deliveries for the first seven units and the remaining five are scheduled for 2009 and 2011, respectively, he said.
The navy's current squadron composed of 26 S-2T anti-submarine airplanes has fallen short of its goal of serving as an adequately combat force.
All the budget appropriations have been approved by the Executive Yuan and are awaiting the final green light from the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CONDEMNS MAINLAND SCHOLARS OVER ANTI-TAIWAN RHETORIC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) condemned a handful of mainland Chinese scholars Friday over their irresponsible remarks against Taiwan.
The council also urged mainland Chinese authorities to prevent their scholars or commentators from issuing irresponsible anti-Taiwan comments.

The council was responding to certain mainland scholars' recent claims that Beijing authorities will impose economic sanctions against Taiwan due to its current Democratic Progressive Party administration's allegedly pro-independence policy line. However, Zhang Mingqing, spokesman for mainland China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said a day earlier that Beijing doesn't have such a plan.

Speaking at a regular news conference, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said mainland academics' irresponsible, thoughtless remarks have not set well with the people of Taiwan and will hinder interactions and rapprochement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"Mainland authorities should prohibit their scholars or political observers from making unnecessary 'psychological harassments' against the people of Taiwan. Otherwise, such moves would cause harm to Taiwan people and hamper cross-strait engagements," Chiu said.

Rumors of mainland trade sanctions against Taiwan, such as some form of punishment of Taiwan investors in mainland China, have caused the Taiwan Stock Exchange to drop substantially over the past few days.

As a matter of fact, Chiu said, both Taiwan and mainland China have benefited from ever-increasing cross-strait relations. "Cross-strait economic exchanges have been reciprocal. If Beijing imposes trade sanctions on Taiwan investors in mainland China simply for political reasons, both Taiwan and the mainland itself will be hurt," he warned.
For one thing, Chiu said, mainland China now has more than 50,000 Taiwan-funded companies that employ at least 10 million mainland workers.

"If mainland authorities adopt unfair measures against them, they will reconsider their future investment projects and may even relocate their operations to other destinations. Should that be the case, it will have a significant impact on the mainland economy," Chiu said.

Moreover, Chiu said, the two sides have developed a vertical division of labor system in exporting products to the United States and other major countries around the world. Unnecessary restrictions on Taiwan-funded companies on the mainland will deal a severe blow to mainland China's export industries, he added.

In the future, Chiu said the MAC will refer to mainland scholars' remarks while screening their applications to visit Taiwan. "We may not necessarily reject their visits, but we'll ask them to explain to some extent their unfriendly statements about Taiwan, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY STILLBORN IN CHINA, RETARDED IN HONG KONG: TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Democracy was stillborn on the mainland, is retarded in Hong Kong, but well-developed in Taiwan, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

In a seminar held in Taipei to observe the 15th anniversary of the Tiananmen pro-democracy demonstration, Ma urged mainland intelligentsia not to lose confidence in democracy because of the disputes following the March 20 presidential election in Taiwan.

Ma said Taiwan is a society with the capacity of self-examination and can better its democracy as time goes on, and the allegations brought by the losing candidate about the results of the election will eventually be resolved through legal processes.

The mayor, who has marked each anniversary since the Tiananmen Massacre in 1989, urged the Beijing authorities to admit its error in ordering the Chinese military to storm the square in Beijing and put an end to a student-led pro-democracy demonstration, in the same way that Taiwan authorities admitted its error in handling the Feb. 28, 1947 Incident.

In addition to speaking out for democratic activists in the seminar, Ma also wrote a public letter to intelligentsia on the mainland, urging them to keep pursuing democracy -- the common choice of people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The letter was published in several Chinese-language newspapers in Taipei, Hong Kong, Singapore, Malaysia and North America on the same day.

Also speaking at the seminar in Taipei was Wang Min, the chairman of the California-based Chinese Democratic United Frontline. He warned the public not to trust the Chinese Communists, since they have never backed down from cracking down on political dissents since 1989 despite the country's stunning economic growth.
He urged the people of Taiwan to back mainland Chinese people's struggle with the Chinese Communists for democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK MARKET LACKS MOMENTUM DESPITE REBOUND: ANALYSTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market is expected to hover around its current level next week because of a lack of sufficient momentum despite short-term rebounds, analysts said Friday.

Uncertainties over cross-Taiwan Strait ties will remain the main factor affecting the performance of the domestic bourse next week after the effects of increasing oil prices and forthcoming U.S. interest hikes have gradually faded, analysts said.

The weighted index, the key barometer of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX), rose by 53.44 points to close at 5,724.89 Friday on a slim turnover of NT$70.489 billion (about US$2.1 billion) . Construction and steel shares posted the largest increases of 5.1 percent and 2.3 percent, respectively.
The rebound was a result of buying by the government's National Stabilization Fund to sustain the market after a plummet of 204 points a day earlier.
The weighted index fell by more than 200 points, or 3.5 percent, Thursday following mainland media reports that Beijing might impose a trade embargo on Taiwan in two months.
The rumor was denied by Beijing officials earlier Friday and they dismissed that mainland-based Taiwan businesses not engaged in pro-Taiwan independence activities will not be affected.
Minister of Finance Lin Chuan said he is confident that the domestic stock market will undoubtedly move up once uncertainties surrounding both the home market and those abroad are removed.

Lin expressed his belief that the bourse will perform better in the third and fourth quarters, judging from the country's economic fundamentals. So long as international markets rebound, the strongly pegged domestic bourse will also rebound quickly, he said.

Hsu Kuo-chung, an assistant manager at JIH SUN Securities Consulting Co., Ltd., said that the recent bullish sentiment has given way noticeably in the stock market and he predicted that the weighted index will hinge around the 5,500 mark over the next week.

Noting that this week's market turnover totaled only a little more than NT$350 billion, a new low for recent weeks, Hsu said that bearishness is likely to prevail in the market in the short term and that low priced shares of traditional businesses are more likely to advance.

A fund manager at Jardine Fleming Funds (Taiwan) said that Taiwan shares are at a low level and are a good buy for investors, should no further foreign capital and large hedge funds put out of the domestic stock market and if mainland China refrains from saber-rattling.

Heavy selling pressure resulting from Beijing's comments should be temporary and the long-term prospects of Asian shares, including Taiwan stocks, remains positive because of their good economic fundamentals, he said.
Since mainland China's announcement of its decision to cool its overheated economy, Taiwan share prices have dropped by an average 11 percent.

An analyst at Hsbcgsset Management (Taiwan) Ltd. called on investors to remain calm since continued falls in recent weeks will help clean up the market and that it will quickly rebound once it hits bottom.
Stressing that non-economic elements will only have a short-term impact on the bourse, he urged investors not to miss the present good opportunity for investment.

Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far Eastern Group, contended that mainland China is unlikely to impose trade sanctions on Taiwan and will not boycott future investments by Taiwan businesses in the mainland.

In the face of a series of stock market plunges, Hsu encouraged investors to buy Taiwan shares now, as their EPS (earning per share) are at such a low level, providing an extremely good chance to invest.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT DONATES AMERICAN MOVIE HISTORY FILMS TO KAOHSIUNG MOVIE LIBRARY

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Friday donated a series of documentaries chronicling the development of American film history to the movie library of Kaohsiung.
AIT's Kaohsiung Office Director Robert Forden said American movies are considered as having tremendous economic might and are a powerful kind of artistic expression.
Liu Hsien-hui, director of the Kaohsiung movie library, thanked AIT for the gift, saying that this will add flavor to an international movie exchange activity that the city government is planning.

The series of films, produced by the New York Center for Visual History, KCET in Los Angeles, and the British Broadcasting Corp., cover sections of some 300 great American movies and include interviews with movie stars and film directors.
The Kaohsiung movie library will offer the public free viewings of the series from June 8 to June 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL BETEL NUT SEIZED, BUT IMPORTER COULD AVOID PUNISHMENT

TEXT.P: Taipei customs officials on Friday seized 765 kilograms of betel nuts at CKS International Airport that were apparently being smuggled into the country illegally from Thailand, but the alleged smuggler may not be punished as officials confiscated the betel nuts before anyone had even declared the cargo.

Customs officials said that since the supply of betel nuts in Taiwan is not stable during the period between April and June, some individuals try to bring in betel nuts illegally to cash in on the higher prices.

The officials said that betel nuts can be imported legally from Thailand, but a quota system is in place whereby taxes are small for a certain amount of betel nuts and higher for imports over this limit.
The excess tariff is NT$810 (US$24) per kilogram.

The officials said that the betel nuts were from a China Airlines flight and were in cargo marked as containing garments. The owner of the shipment, a company called Min Shung, could avoid punishment by simply not claiming the cargo.
The betel nuts are now in the custody of the Council of Agriculture for disposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES SPECIAL HONORS IN COSTA RICA
DOC.DATELINE: San Jose, Costa Rica, June 3 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Costa Rican President Abel Pacheco de la Espriella decorated visiting Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu Thursday with the nation's highest honor -- the Juan Mora Fernandez en el Grado de Gran Cruz Placa de Plata.
Pacheco said the decoration is in recognition of Lu's contributions to promoting democracy, human rights and relations between the ROC and Costa Rica.

Lu said it is great honor for her to receive the decoration and added that Costa Rica is her "dreamland, " as nearly all of her life-long goals of gender equality, freedom, democracy, human rights and lasting peace prevail there.

Pacheco later hosted a state banquet in honor of Lu and her entourage. At the end of the banquet, all the Costa Rican dignitaries sand "Happy Birthday to You" in Spanish to wish Lu many happy returns of the day -- Lu will turn 60 on June 6. Lu kissed Pacheco's cheek to express her gratitude for her host's surprise arrangement. She then cut a birthday cake to share with all the well-wishers.

Lu arrived in Costa Rica Wednesday after a three-day official visit to neighboring El Salvador, where she attended the inauguration of new Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian.
Over the past two days, she has met with nearly all influential Costa Rican politicians to discuss measures to further boost bilateral ties.

Lu said she has reached a preliminary agreement with Costa Rica's women's affairs minister on promoting exchanges of visits by outstanding women from both countries. After her return to Taiwan, Lu said, she will organize a delegation composed of female politicians to visit Costa Rica and other ROC diplomatic allies. Costa Rica will also send a delegation of women leaders in various fields to visit Taiwan in the near future, Lu said.

During her talks with senior Costa Rican political leaders, including Pacheco, Vice President Lineth Saborio, National Assembly Speaker Gerardo Gonzalez and former President Oscar Arias Sanchez, who is a Nobel Peace Prize winner, Lu said they agreed to further boost bilateral and multilateral cooperation in human rights and other fields in order to enhance Taiwan's international profile.
Lu checked into a local hospital briefly Thursday due to pain in her limbs.

Dr. Chen Yao-chang, who is accompanying Lu on her diplomatic tour, said she was suffering a torn muscle in her left arm and a slight dislocation of her left thumb and left elbow, as well as from the injury to her left knee sustained in the March 19 shooting. Her hectic schedule during her transit stop in Las Vegas and official visit to El Salvador have aggravated the injuries, the doctor said.
Lu received treatment at a Costa Rican hospital and was later seen with her arm in a sling and walking with a cane.

Despite her physical pain, Lu insisted on adhering to her busy itinerary. She visited the POAS volcanic national park on the outskirts of San Jose Thursday morning and attended a luncheon hosted by ROC Ambassador to Costa Rica Wu Tzu-dan.

On Wednesday, Lu delivered a speech on new visions for the 21st Century at the University of Costa Rica, which presented a human rights medal to Lu in recognition of her contributions to promoting democracy and human rights. Later that day, she attended a ceremony marking the 60th anniversary of the establishment of diplomatic relations between the ROC and Costa Rica. The two countries signed an amity agreement in 1944 on forging "lasting peace and friendship."
Costa Rica is the second leg of Lu's 14-day diplomatic tour, which will also take her to Guatemala.

This is her first overseas trip since she was sworn in for a second four-year term May 20. She made a two-day transit stop in Las Vegas en route to El Salvador and will also make a transit stop in San Francisco on her way home.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 SUSPECTS NABBED FOR SMUGGLING MARIJUANA FROM CANADA

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 4 (CAN) Three suspects were arrested Friday in connection with smuggling 1.1 kg of marijuana from Canada via express delivery, according to aviation police.

Aviation police were tipped off earlier this year that a smuggling ring was mailing marijuana from Canada to Taiwan via an express delivery service, and formed a task force to track down possible suspects.
Police found that Pan Wei-li, 18, was in charge of receiving the parcels, while Chen Yi-kuang, 23, and Lee Chien-hsin, 34, used the Internet to sell the marijuana.

Police found a marijuana parcel labeled as garments at the CKS International Airport Thursday and when Pan acknowledged receipt of the parcel in Taipei the following day, police arrested him and tracked down the other two suspects.
The three suspects were turned over to the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office for violation of drug laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROCSAT-2 SENDS BACK FIRST BATCH OF PHOTOS

TEXT.P: ROCSAT-2 has sent back its first batch of test photos, with better-than-expected results, the National Space Program Office (NSPO) reported Friday.

NSPO officials said that the ROCSAT-2 satellite successfully transmitted one color and one monochrome photograph of an area of western Taiwan covering an area 24 km wide and 324 km long stretching from Hsinchu Harbor down to Kaohsiung harbor.
The test pictures came one month ahead of the scheduled time, to the delight of the office staff, although they said that it will take some time to make adjustments so that the pictures can be sold.
National Science Council Chairman Wu Mao-kun joined the NSPO team at its office to open champagne to celebrate the successful transmission of the photos.
He expressed his appreciation to the NSPO team and announced the formal start of ROCSAT-2's five-year mission.
ROCSAT-2 was launched into orbit from the Vandenberg air force base in California May 20, and after 12 days of flight, reached its orbit 891 km above Earth.

Passing over Taiwan twice daily, ROCSAT-2 will regularly collect information and data for use in several areas, including agriculture and forestry, natural disaster evaluation, environmental monitoring, education, and fostering international cooperation in various scientific research projects and activities. In addition to its remote sensing mission, ROCSAT-2 will also investigate upper atmospheric lighting phenomena.
The successful launch of ROCSAT-2 and its observance of upper atmospheric lighting phenomena have received a write-up in the prestigious science magazine Nature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, PHILIPPINE POLICE CRACK YAKUZA ARMS TRAFFICKING RING

TEXT.P: Philippine law enforcement authorities, in collaboration with their counterparts from Taiwan, busted a cross-border firearms trafficking operation Thursday that was masterminded by a prominent Yamaguch-gumi figure.

Akire Nemoto, believed to be the right-hand man of Yamaguchi-gumi leader Yasuo Takagi, was arrested by Philippine police Thursday at his luxury residence in a suburb of Manila, together with a haul of firearms, including a U.S.-made KG99 assault rifle, two mini pistols and numerous rounds of ammunition, according to officials from Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the Ministry of Justice.

Tipped off by CIB authorities, some 40 Manila police and investigators raided Nemoto -- who has the nickname of "overseas arsenal" -- early Wednesday morning in an anti-narcotics and anti-firearms operation that lasted until Friday morning, said officials from the CIB's International Affairs Department.

CIB investigators discovered in January that members of Taiwan's Bamboo Union gang had traveled to Manila to meet with Nemoto and his ring members for transactions involving illicit drugs, firearms smuggling and cross-border money laundering.
CIB officials discovered that the Bamboo Union and other Taiwanese gangland operators had already placed orders worth more than US$100,000 with Nemoto for firearms.
They believe that more than 100 state-of-the-art firearms and unknown amounts of heroin and amphetamines have been smuggled into Taiwan via fishing boats through this channel.

Meanwhile, CIB Chief Secretary Kao Cheng-sheng denied categorically that a retired senior police officer from Taiwan was a "Taiwan connection" in another cross-border money laundering operation involving major Yamaguchi-gumi member Yamane Takashi, who was expelled from Taiwan to Japan Thursday.

Kao said there is no evidence to show that a retired senior Taiwan police officer was involved in Yamaguchi-gumi money laundering operations, which are believed to have laundered some 4.6 billion yen (US$41.8 million) illegally earned by the criminal syndicate last year.
Takashi was escorted back to Japan Thursday by three Japanese police officers after being arrested at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport May 21 as he was trying to leave on a flight to Macau.

Kao said Takashi was in Taiwan for one month -- his first-ever visit to Taiwan -- that he was under full-scale surveillance during his stay and that he had not been found to have made contact with any Taiwan policemen, retired or otherwise.
Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan also discounted reports that a Taiwan policeman was involved in yakuza money laundering operations.
Su said no Taiwan policemen, incumbent or retired, have been found to have extended assistance to Yamaguchi-gumi in cross-border money laundering.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI TO SEEK SCIENTIFIC TALENT IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 4 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) President Johnsee Lee will head for the United States Saturday to begin a two-week talent-hunting tour.
Heading a delegation comprised of 12 high-ranking executives, Lee will visit four cities and areas -- Silicon Valley, San Diego, Chicago and Boston.

During the tour, the ITRI plans to offer some 200 job opportunities to those interested in research and development in the electronic, information, telecommunications, biomedicine, nanotechnology, systematics, manufacturing and energy resource sectors.
In the last five years, the ITRI has attracted 172 researchers with doctorate degrees and 185 master's degree-holders from abroad to work in Taiwan.

The ITRI, established by the Ministry of Economic Affairs in 1973, has played a vital role in Taiwan's industrial research and development. With more than 6,000 researchers and employees, the ITRI is also becoming an active member in the global R&D community.

In addition to seeking talent abroad, the ITRI has also established strategic ties or cooperation projects with various eminent universities and scientific research institutes such as the University of California at Berkeley, Carnegie Mellon University, and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
In the last three years, an ITRI innovative research plan has created 806 patents, 1,000 theses and has resulted in 70 global cooperation projects.

During the last 30 years, the ITRI has helped create many high-tech companies, including the island's two biggest chip makers - Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Ltd. and United Microelectronics Corp. -- and has trained numerous experts who have become chief executives of major local firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 53.44 points to close at 5,724.89.
The bourse opened at 5,667.08 and fluctuated between 5,734.48 and 5,630.12 during trading.

A total of 3.22 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$70.49 billion (US$2.1 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session, which saw 3.61 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$85.15 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 5.1 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.3 percent, foodstuff stocks at 0.9 percent, textile issues, plastics and chemical shares and electrical shares all at 0.8 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
Pulp and paper issues, however, fell 0.4 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 422 to 337, with 201 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE APPROVES NEW EXAMINATION YUAN DEPUTY CHIEF APPOINTMENT

TEXT.P: The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan approved Friday President Chen Shui-bian's nomination of Wu Rong-ming as vice president of the Examination Yuan.

Wu was originally minister of the civil service, which is responsible for the nation's civil service system, including examination, qualification screening, security of tenure, scale of salaries, promotion, transfer, retirement of civil servants and related matters.
The legislature approved Wu's new assignment by a vote of 175-11, with six invalid ballots.
Wu said afterward that the number of "yes" votes far exceeded his expectations. "Before the vote, I didn't think I would receive so many ballots," a grateful Wu said.
Wu, a former deputy governor of the now-marginalized Taiwan provincial government, said he appreciates the president's nomination and the legislators' support for his new assignment.

As many legislators from across the political spectrum had presented valuable recommendations for improving the nation's civil service system in the process of screening his qualifications, Wu said he will convey these opinions at future Examination Yuan meetings for discussion and possible adoption.
"After assuming my new post, I'll do my utmost to assist Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen in updating the nation's civil service system," Wu said.

The Presidential Office also issued a statement expressing its gratitude for legislative support for Wu as the post has been vacant for quite some time. Due to a boycott by the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) , Chen's previous nomination for the post -- Chang Po-ya, a former interior minister -- failed to clear the legislative floor last year.

The legislative caucuses of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally -- the Taiwan Solidarity Union, as well as the Independent Lawmakers Alliance, mobilized their members to support Wu's new assignment in Friday's vote, while the KMT and the PFP allowed their lawmakers to decide whether to endorse Wu's appointment on their own.

Still, many hawkish PFP lawmakers either voted against the nomination or chose to absent themselves from the vote as a way to protest what they claim is Chen's alleged reluctance to solve the mysterious election-eve shooting that slightly wounded himself and Vice President Annette Lu.

Wu once resigned from his post as a minister-without-portfolio to campaign for PFP Chairman James Soong in the run-up to the 2000 presidential election. At that time, Soong ran for the presidency as an independent and narrowly lost to Chen.

In the 2004 presidential election, Soong served as KMT Chairman Lien Chan's running mate and the Lien-Soong ticket lost to the incumbent Chen-Lu ticket by a razor-thin margin. Lien has filed two lawsuits to challenge Chen's re-election victory and has called for a new election.

A full-scale judicial vote recount has been concluded and the Taiwan High Court is required to mete out rulings on whether to overturn Chen's re-election victory or call a new election within six months. No evidence has so far been found to back up the "pan-blue alliance's" allegations that the March 20 presidential election was rigged and that the March 19 shooting was fake.

Wu said that although some PFP lawmakers did not support his new assignment, he still wanted to thank them and added that Soong had congratulated him by phone. "I appreciate my former superior's blessing," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT WILL FOLLOW PROTOCOL ON MAINLAND CHINESE ACTIVISTS

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 4 (CAN) The government will handle the issue of mainland Chinese pro-democracy activists wishing to enter Taiwan according to set procedures, a Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) official said Friday.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san made the remarks following reports that mainland pro-democracy activist Yen Peng from Qindao, Shandong Province, had arrived in Taiwan.
Chiu said the government will first confirm his identity and will then "respect the wishes of each individual and act in line with international protocol in its follow-up moves."

He claimed that anyone who is in pursuit of democracy, whether they are from other countries or are pro-democracy activists from the mainland, is welcome in Taiwan and that there is no reason to reject them.
The MAC also welcomes people pursuing democracy to come to Taiwan to exchange experiences, he said.

Chiu noted that pro-democracy activist Hsu Po came to Taiwan early this year and that the government has already arranged for him to travel to the Marshall Islands in line with international practice and out of respect for his wishes.
On Wednesday, Yen Peng boarded a Xiamen fishing boat, jumped overboard 100 meters from Tatang islet near the outlying island of Kinmen, and then swam to the islet.
Kinmen coast guard personnel took him from Kinmen to a detention center for illegal mainland immigrants in Ilan, eastern Taiwan, Friday.

Meanwhile, in remembrance on the 15th anniversary of the Tiananmen square massacre, Chiu noted that 15 years have passed since the tragic event but he lamented the gap between the mainland's democratic reforms and its economic performance.
"The experience of Taiwan going from authoritarian rule to democracy can serve as a reference for the world and also for the mainland authorities, " he said.
Chiu said that in terms of press freedom, religious freedom, economy and human rights, the mainland still has ample room for improvement.

"Taiwan hopes to offer its experience in implementing democratic elections, the pursuit of freedom and human rights protection to the mainland for reference, and is willing to provide assistance, " Chiu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE ENGLISH CLASSES OFFERED FOR UNDERPRIVILEGED CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education has decided to earmark a budget that will allow it to offer free English classes for underprivileged school children in five counties, a ministry spokesman said Friday.

The free and intensive English class program is slated to begin in the summer and winter vacations of the 2005 academic year and will cover between 70,000 and 80,000 children preparing to enter fourth grade at elementary schools in Miaoli, Yunlin, Pingtung and Lienchiang counties, according to Wu Tsai-shun, director of the Elementary Education Department.

For the time being, more than 600 elementary schools in the five counties do not provide the beginner English classes for first-graders or third-graders given at other schools, and the free English class program is designed to compensate these underprivileged children that lag behind in English learning, Wu said.
Starting from next year, English classes at primary schools nationwide will begin teaching English in third grade.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA WELCOME TO OBSERVE LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government hopes that mainland China can move toward democracy and would welcome mainland representatives coming to Taiwan to observe the year-end legislative elections, Cabinet Spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Friday.
Chen made the remarks on the 15th anniversary of Beijing's bloody crushing of a pro-democracy movement on the mainland -- the Tiananmen massacre of 1989.

Chen said that the government is willing to help the mainland establish an election system and nurture talent to lay a solid basis for democracy and achieve its goal of becoming a rising power in a peaceful way.

He noted that during the 1989 pro-democracy protests and the June 4 massacre that brought them to an end, Beijing suppressed and arrested pro-democracy activists and has since restricted the flow of information on the Internet.

"This totalitarian way of controlling the nation is still ingrained in the minds of the world's people, and the freedom and democracy aspired to by the mainland people have yet to be achieved," Chen said, lamenting that "the human rights record in mainland China has yet to show an obvious improvement."
He said that the government hopes the Beijing authorities will give due respect and protection to basic freedom of speech and right of assembly.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun has urged the international community to continue to be concerned about the democratic and human rights conditions on the mainland so that mainland people can enjoy the universal values of democracy, plurality and freedom as do the people of Taiwan, according to Chen.
He said the truth of history will come out and that democracy should become the core of Chinese culture, saying that the much-touted "Taiwan values" are based on this.
"A pluralistic, democratic and open society would apply well to the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait," he added.

He expressed the hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can base their relations on "goodwill reconciliation, active cooperation and lasting peace" as espoused by President Chen Shui-bian and the establishment of a cross-strait peace and stable exchange mechanism in his inaugural speech so as to promote the wellbeing of the peoples on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and meet the expectations of the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 4, or the 17th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: King George III of Great Britain is born. His mishandling of the American colonies fed American discontent, leading to the American Revolution in 1776.
1928: Chang Tso-lin, leader of the Fengtien army in China's northeast (Manchuria), is killed by a bomb on a train at Wangkutun near Mukden (Shenyang). His son, Chang Hsueh-liang, succeeds him as the ruler of Manchuria.
1940: A flotilla of naval and civilian craft complete the safe evacuation of some 335,000 out of a total of 400,000 Allied troops from the French coastal town of Dunkirk after the might of the German army swept northward through France.
1944: Rome is liberated by the Allies with U.S. Gen. Mark Clark leading the way into the city.
1954: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek appoints Yen Chia-kan governor of Taiwan.
1956: Egypt refuses to extend the Suez Canal Company's concession after its expiration in 1959, leading to the Suez Crisis.
1959: Charles de Gaulle stuns French colonists in Algeria by telling them they must integrate with the Muslim Algerians if they wish to stay.
1965: The ROC joins a provisional committee on communications satellites.
1970: Dr. Chien Shih-liang becomes president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1970: Tonga, a British protectorate, becomes independent.
1982: U.S. Senator Barry Goldwater restates in Taipei that the United States government has no intention of amending the Taiwan Relations Act.
1989: The first partially free parliamentary elections in Poland in nearly 50 years end the communist rule imposed by Moscow.
1989: According to an estimate by the International Red Cross, more than 3,000 people are killed as soldiers open fire on student demonstrators in Beijing's Tienanmen Square.
1989: ROC President Lee Teng-hui issues a statement condemning the Tienanmen Massacre.
1990: President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea meets with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev in Washington.
1999: The Basic Education Law passes three readings at the Legislative Yuan, paving the way for the Ministry of Education to implement a 12-year system of compulsory education for ROC nationals.
2000: An ROC Navy goodwill flotilla reaches the Marshall Islands after sailing 2,220 nautical miles.
2001: The 21st Taipei International Computer Show -- Computex Taipei 2001 -- kicks off at the Taipei World Trade Center, attracting a record high of 1,071 firms from home and abroad to take part in the five-day event.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are three things which a man should beware of in the three stages of his life. In youth, when the constitution of his body is not yet formed, he should beware of lust. In manhood, when his physical powers are in full vigor, he should beware of strife. In old age, when the physical powers are in decay, he should beware of greed."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS

DOC.HEADLINE: DIVERSIFY FROM CHINA MARKET TO PROTECT INVESTMENT: TAIWAN THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan businesses should not put all their overseas investments in mainland China given Beijing's recent comments that could restrict investment and increase risk, the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) warned Sunday.

CIER researchers said the economic interdependence of Taiwan and mainland China has reached an unprecedented level in recent months as a result of increased interactions between the private sectors of the two sides.
Taiwan businesses also face ever-increasing risks on the mainland because of Chinese authorities' sudden announcement of clamp-down policies on Taiwanese investment, CIER researchers said.

CIER is calling for mainland China-based Taiwan business people to hedge their investments against mainland China's policy about-face and consider seeking other investment locations beyond the mainland.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs commissioned CIER to conduct a public opinion poll recently to look into investment barriers and incentives that Taiwanese investors have faced or enjoyed regarding their overseas investments.

The poll found that 75 percent of the Taiwanese companies that have made investments overseas focused their overseas business operations on the Chinese mainland (including Hong Kong), followed by Southeast Asia -- constituting about 15 percent -- and the United States and other areas, in that order.
More than 70 percent of the responding companies said barriers to investing on the mainland include restrictions on fund outflows and restrictions on product distribution on the mainland.

Commenting on the high risks of investing in mainland China, former Mainland Affairs Council Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Taiwan businesses should maintain a "double-base" investment strategy when relocating business operations overseas to help lower investment risks. The government, meanwhile, should accelerate the signing of bilateral or multilateral free trade accords with countries that maintain close trade ties with Taiwan, Tsai said.

The Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) Secretary-General Lee Yi-an said the government has long stressed the importance of market diversification. The Bureau of Foreign Trade and TAITRA, for example, have actively encouraged Taiwan companies to shift their overseas investment fronts from mainland China to Russia, the Czech Republic, Kazakhstan, India and Eastern Europe, in addition to Southeast Asia, to help lower investment risks.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING POLITICAL INTERFERENCE IN ECONOMICS WILL HURT BOTH SIDES

TEXT.P: Beijing's political interference in economics will seriously hurt both Taiwan and mainland China in view of their close and frequent two-way exchanges, a government official in charge of trade and economics said Sunday.

Taiwan investments in mainland China over the past 14 years have increased rapidly, with the ratio of mainland-bound investments to the country's overall outbound investments growing from 9.5 percent in 1991 to 53.7 percent in 2003, according to statistics compiled by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development.

The Asian financial crisis in 1997 could be viewed as a turning point when Taiwan businesses shifted from Southeast Asian countries to mainland China in search of profitable investment destinations overseas.

In 2000, mainland China opened up its market to foreign competition following its entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) , providing another opportunity for Taiwan companies to jockey for a position in the mainland market.

According to the tallies compiled by the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Taiwan enterprises channeled US$2.61 billion in to their mainland investment projects in 2000, double the 1999 level.
Last year, Taiwan investors funneled US$4.06 billion into mainland China, accounting for 53.7 percent of Taiwan's overall outbound investment.
During the first four months of this year, mainland-bound investment reached US$1.74 billion, making up 65.7 percent of the country's total outgoing investment, the commission tallies showed.

After both Taiwan and mainland China joined the WTO, investments by Taiwan companies in the mainland are projected with a long-term market deployment strategy as part of their efforts to compete against world-class organizations, such as Intel, Nokia and Samsung, the official said.

As Taiwan investments in mainland China are mutually beneficial to both, the mainland Chinese authorities should realize that political meddling in mainland-based Taiwan businesses is unfair to Taiwan investors, as they have created many job opportunities for mainland people, the official pointed out.

Beijing responded last week to President Chen Shui-bian's second inaugural address on May 20 that mainland China does not welcome Taiwan businesses which reap profits in the mainland to back pro-Taiwan independence at home and singled out former Chi Mei Group Chairman Shu Wen-long as an example.
Beijing's unexpected rhetoric sent Taiwan's stock market plummeting by 204 points that same day and has provoked grave concerns among Taiwan businessmen with investments in mainland China.
The Taiwan authorities have called on Beijing in recent days to separate politics from economics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TTV AND CTS TO BE DONATED BY GOVERNMENT TO PUBLIC TELEVISION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Two government-owned terrestrial television companies, Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd (TTV) , and Chinese Television System (CTS) will be donated to the Public Television Cultural Development Foundation, under a plan to be discussed by the Executive Yuan this week.
The plan will be examined by a panel headed by Minister-without-Portfolio Chen Chi-mai.

Under the plan worked out by the Government Information Office (GIO) , TTV and CTS, of which most stocks were owned by the government, will be run by the Public Television Cultural Development Foundation after some stock owned privately was bought by the GIO.

In addition to the two terrestrial television companies, the All-Hakka Channel ran by the Council for Hakka Affairs and the Taiwan Macroview TV run by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission will also be donated and controlled by the Public Television Cultural Foundation, according to the proposal presented by the GIO.

This idea has alarmed some lawmakers of the opposition. Legislator Pang Chien-kuo of the People First Party criticized the proposal as a scheme by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party to control all television outlets, although journalists support the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ANTI-FORGERY ID CARDS RESERVE SPACE FOR FINGERPRINT

TEXT.P: New ROC ID cards will contain anti-forgery features and contain a space reserved for the owner's fingerprint, despite activists claims that such a requirement violates the cardholder's human rights.

The Ministry of the Interior announced Sunday that the new ID cards will be designed using horizontal left-to-right Chinese writing to follow legislation passed in early May mandating that all official documents and related paperwork in Taiwan should be changed to the horizontal left-to-right format from the current vertical right-to-left format, ministry officials said.
The vertical, top-to-bottom characters and right-to-left columns writing format has been the main style used by the Chinese for thousands of years.

As with the existing ones, the new ID cards will carry the cardholder's name, gender and address, as well as his or her parents' names and the name of his or her spouse. The new ID card, however, will not carry the cardholder's original domicile, but only the place of birth.

A space will be reserved on the bottom right of the ID card's reverse for the cardholder's fingerprint, despite the fact that some human rights activist groups have said that they are firmly opposed to such a design, saying that mandatory fingerprinting is a violation of the public's human rights.
The new cards will have 20 markers to discourage counterfeiting, including hidden lines, fluorescent paint and embossing, the officials said.
The new ID cards are expected to be circulated nationwide next year at the latest, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR FORCE PARTICIPATION RATE DECLINES AMONG TEENAGERS AND YOUNG MEN

TEXT.P: The labor force participation rate among people aged between 15 and 24 declined to 33.8 percent in 2003, or 1.38 percent less than the previous year, according to statistics compiled by the Council of Labor Affairs.
The labor force participation rate represents the ratio of the workforce to the overall population of a certain age group
The council's statistics show that 1,144,000 people aged between 15 and 24 entered the workforce in 2003, 70,000 fewer people than the previous year.

Officials from the council said the decline continues a 10-year trend which has seen an accumulated decrease of 14.63 percent in the last decade in inverse proportion to a 10-year 12.2 percent increase in the number of people of this age group attending schools.

Thanks to the booming economy, officials said Taiwan's unemployment rate of people in the age group has declined by 0.47 percent in 2003 to 11.44 percent, although it is still the highest jobless rates of all age groups because of lack of work experience among teenagers and young men has limited their chances of landing jobs and the frequent changes of jobs among them.
In the age group between 15 and 19, the labor force participation rate is less than 20 percent in most countries, except for the United States, which registered a rate of 44.5 percent in 2003.

In Taiwan this rate increased to 44.5 percent in the age group of 20 to 24, which is lower than the 57 percent in South Korea, and is far behind that of Singapore, Hong Kong and Japan, said officials at the Council of Labor Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS GOOD MODEL FOR MAINLAND IN DEMOCRATIZATION: MAC OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 5 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Democracy and freedom are universal values for the whole world, and Taiwan has set a good example for mainland China in this regard, Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) , said Saturday in New York.

Chiu made the remarks in a seminar held in New York to commemorate the 15th anniversary of the student-led June 4 Tiananman Massacre in 1989, in which scholars from around the world and mainland Chinese pro-democracy activists also took part, including Feng Congde, a prominent student leader in the June 4 pro-democracy movement in Beijing, who now lives in exile overseas.

Expressing his admiration for the sacrifice that the students and people made for the movement, Chiu said that 15 years later, amid changing times, Taiwan's democratization has caught up with the mainstream trends of the international community, while the whole world is paying more heed to democratic developments in mainland China.

If greater democratization in mainland China can help reduce tensions and differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Taiwan's experiences in democratic developments in turn are good examples for the mainland, Chiu said.

The MAC vice chairman urged the Beijing regime to study the proposal raised by President Chen Shui-bian in his second inaugural address on May 20 that Taiwan and mainland China should seek to engage in improving bilateral ties based on dignity, reciprocity and security.
"The status quo must be fully respected and negotiations should replace confrontation," Chiu quoted Chen as having said.

Yu Jie, a scholar from Beijing, said the increasing popularity of the Internet has provided a new space for the public and intellectuals in mainland China to dedicate themselves to the promotion of pro-democracy activities on an equal footing.

Feng attributed the failure of the bloody 1989 pro-democracy movement to unsuccessful organization and the way the activity was handled by the students, which led to it being crushed by the mainland Chinese military.

Pan Qing, who has lived in exile in New Zealand since 1989, called the Tiananman Massacre a vigorous reflection of the Beijing regime's nature, one based and cemented by ignorance of human rights and by authoritarian rule.

Chen Xiaoya, an historian, said that the Tiananman Massacre brought to light the fact that the Beijing regime has maintained power by the use of violence and cheating. She said she envisions that a day will come when politics on the mainland is conducted on a level playing field.
Chiu arrived in New York June 4 for a weeklong visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAN FRANCISCO TRANSIT WILL TEST TAIWAN-U.S. RELATIONS: VP LU
DOC.DATELINE: Guatemala City, June 5 (CNA) (By Tsai Su-jong and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Saturday in Guatemala that her transit stop in San Francisco Saturday will serve as a test of the relations between Taiwan and the United States.

Lu made the remarks in Guatemala City at the end of a three-nation Central American tour that also included El Salvador and Costa Rica. She is prepared to leave for San Francisco and make a stopover there on her way back to Taiwan.

While in San Francisco, she will receive a human rights award from Representative Tom Lantos at a gathering with overseas Republic of China nationals in recognition of Taiwan's outstanding achievements in this field and participate in a party hosted in Napa Valley by California Lieutenant Governor Cruz Bustamante in her honor, the vice president said.
In addition, she will also meet well-known scholars from the Bay Area and take part in a seminar to recruit hi-tech talent based in the United States.
By that time, the public will be able to gauge Taiwan- U.S. relations through her activities in San Francisco, she added.

Taiwan-U.S. ties hit a low point prior to Taiwan's March 20 presidential election because President Chen Shui-bian insisted on holding a historic referendum on the same day as the presidential election amid strong opposition from Beijing, which called it an explicit time table to advocate Taiwan independence.
The vice president also revealed her plans to forge fresh joint ventures with the three Central American countries after returning to Taiwan.

Apart from inviting more artist groups from the region to visit Taiwan to allow Taiwan people to gain a better understanding of Latin American culture, Lu said she will push for closer cooperation in human rights, peace and women affairs with Costa Rica.
In cooperation with El Salvador, Lu said that efforts will focus on agriculture by helping that country set up special fruit and flower production facilities through technology transfers.

As Guatemalan President Oscar Berger has called for Taiwan aid in the medical field, Lu said that she will pay attention to this matter and initiate a donation campaign to collect clothes for Guatemala's aboriginal people living in mountainous regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER MEETS APEC COUNTERPARTS FOR BILATERAL TALKS

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh has met with her counterparts from five member economies of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum for talks over the past two days, officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Sunday.

Ho, who was sworn in as economics minister May 20, met with her counterparts from Canada, Indonesia, Singapore, South Korea and Japan for bilateral talks during the APEC ministerial meeting held in Pucon, southern Chile June 4-5, economics ministry officials said.

In her talks with the Canadian minister of international trade and investment, Ho stressed the importance of Taiwan and Canada cooperating with each other under the APEC framework and sought preferential import duties from Canada for goods and services from Taiwan.
The Canadian minister, meanwhile, urged Ho to see to it that Taiwan removes the import ban on Canadian beef and related products as quick as possible, according to economics ministry officials.
During the talks with her counterpart from Indonesia, Ho invited the Indonesian APEC delegation to take part in the First APEC Incubator Forum to be held in Taipei July 30-Aug. 1.

Ho also expressed concern over Indonesia's restriction on imports of live birds from Taiwan. In this regard, the Indonesian secretary of economic affairs agreed that Indonesia will handle the matter based on the regulations set forth by the Office International des Epizootics (OIE).

The two sides also reached consensus on bilateral cooperation in the textile and garment industries to jointly meet the new globally competitive situation after the world's textile quota systems are removed.

Ho exchanged views with her Singaporean counterpart on the possibility of Taiwan and Singapore cooperating in developing regional distribution centers and sought Singapore's experience in making headway into markets in India and making investments there.
With her South Korean counterpart, according to economics ministry officials, Ho sought stepped-up efforts from both sides to expand bilateral economic and trade exchanges.

In talks with her counterpart from Japan, Ho stressed the importance of revving up substantive cooperation between private industrial sectors from the two countries as part of paving the way for the two countries to sign a free trade agreement.

Ho also urged the Japanese government to remove the import ban on live birds from Taiwan and nullify the order of mandatory checks on the import of live eels from Taiwan, according to economics ministry officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 6, or the nineteenth day of the fouth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1901: Sukarno, Indonesia's first president, is born. He led the country's independence movement against the Dutch colonists.
1916: Yuan Shih-kai dies at Hsinhua Palace in Beijing at the age of 58, and the republican form of government is restored. Yuan, who forced the Congress to elect him president on Oct. 6, 1913 and annulled the provisional constitution on May 1, 1914, proclaimed himself emperor on Dec. 1915.
1934: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission is established to protect the interests of investors.
1944: Under the supreme command of U.S. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, around one million Allied troops in 4,000 ships disembark for the coast of Normandy, France to launch the largest military invasion in the world's history and begin the final campaign to defeat Nazi Germany.
1946: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek accepts General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1967: Egypt closes the Suez Canal during the Six-Day Arab-Israeli War. The canal remained closed to international shipping for eight years.
1974: A three-year agreement on the exchange of science information is signed by the Republic of China and South Korea.
1976: Paul Getty, the American oil billionaire who made his first million by the time he was 22, dies in London at the age of 83. He amassed one of the world's largest fortunes through the oil business.
1978: The 7th Sino-American Conference on Mainland China draws 50 American and 38 Chinese scholars plus four observers from Hong Kong, Canada, the United States and South Korea. The main theme of the meeting is "Mainland China in the Post-Mao Period."
1981: Seven coaches of an overcrowded passenger train are blown off the tracks into the River Kosi in Nihar, India, killing some 3,000 people.
1988: In New York City, Davis Stern becomes the blower of the world's biggest bubble when he blows one measuring a record 15.24 meters in length.
1994: A Chinese airliner on a domestic flight from the tourist center of Xian crashes, killing all 160 people on board.
1994: An earthquake rocks Colombia, killing some 1,000 people and leaving thousands of others homeless.
1994: Mainland Chinese air pirate Chou Weichiang hijacks a Southern Airlines passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: Premier Lien Chan pays the first visit by a high-ranking ROC official to Mexico in the 23 years since the two countries severed diplomatic relations.
1995: Japanese Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama and his ruling coalition agree to express "deep remorse" for Japan's acts of aggression in World War II.
1998: The United Nations Security Council votes to condemn both India and Pakistan for their nuclear weapons tests.
1999: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, leading a 59-member delegation, arrives in Taipei for a six-day official visit.
1999: The ROC bans meat, poultry and other agricultural products from Belgium in the wake of a dioxin contamination in that European country.
2000: The acting chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, Lien Chan, says that the "mini three links" between the ROC's outlying islands and mainland China should serve a political purpose.
2001: An army battalion stationed at the Chengkungling base in Taichung County is quarantined after one of its soldiers died from spinal meningitis the previous day.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The highest class of men are those who are born with a natural understanding. The next class are those who acquire understanding by study and application. There are others again who are born by nature dull, but who by strenuous efforts, try to acquire understanding: such men may be considered the next class. Those who are born by nature dull and yet will not take the trouble to acquire understanding are the lowest class of people." (
