DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MODEL OF GOVERNMENT ROLE IN ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: U.N. AGENCY
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 7 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Globalization and liberalization will not guarantee economic development, which depends more on the correct industrial policy formulated by the government and Taiwan is a model in this respect, according to a report issued here recently by the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD).
In the report, which explores the government's role in steering economic development, UNCTAD said Taiwan is an example of the importance of government policy in stimulating economic growth.

Instead of encouraging the formation of big business conglomerates and stressing the development of heavy industries as in South Korean, Taiwan has opted for fostering the development of small- and medium-sized business and has built up a most advanced system that supports the development of such businesses, according to the report.
The government in Taiwan has helped local small- and medium-sized businesses to seek foreign partners whose technology and capital helps promote their Taiwan counterparts, said the report.
The government has also invested in complicated technology such as semiconductors and the aeronautic industry, the report said.
Taiwan's success in these fields is a valuable lesson for other developing countries, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RECEIVES HUMAN RIGHTS AWARD IN SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 6 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Congressional Human Rights Caucus presented a human rights award to Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu in San Francisco Sunday in recognition of her contribution to the promotion of human rights over the decades.

Rep. Tom Lantos (D-Calif.) , a co-chairman of the Congressional Human Rights Caucus, bestowed the award on behalf of the caucus at a dinner hosted by major Taiwanese associations in the Bay area in honor of Lu and her entourage.
Lu arrived in San Francisco earlier in the day for a transit stop on her way back to Taipei after a three-leg Central American tour that took her to El Salvador, Costa Rica and Guatemala.

Addressing the award-presentation ceremony, Lantos said Taiwan has made remarkable progress in promoting freedom, democracy, human rights and peace over the decades and that he hopes President Chen Shui-bian and Lu can visit Washington, D.C.
For her part, Lu said it is a great honor for her to receive the award, adding that she will continue to dedicate herself to promoting peace, democracy and human rights.

Lu said she hopes both sides of the Taiwan Strait can use innovative thinking to develop new cross-strait ties characterized by peace and goodwill. "Let's forget the old confrontational cross-strait ties and forge a new and constructive relationship," she added.

Touching on the lingering ethnic disharmony in Taiwan in the wake of the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election, Lu said the major source of disputes between Taiwan's two political camps lies in their attitudes toward "Taiwan identity."

To address this issue and promote ethnic harmony, Lu suggested that the people of Taiwan can call their nation "Taiwan, the Republic of China" in the future. "This is my personal view and I'll discuss this proposal after returning to Taipei. I think this title can satisfy both the demands of pro-independence activists and pro-unification people in Taiwan," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARENTS ACCOUNT FOR 80 PERCENT OF CHILD ABUSERS: POLL

TEXT.P: Parents account for more than 80 percent of the child abusers in Taiwan, a local private association dedicated to promoting children's welfare said Monday.
The Children's Welfare Alliance said it handled 8,013 child abuse cases last year.

Of these, 81.06 percent of the abusers were the victims' parents and 6.92 percent were the victims' main guardians. In those cases, an alliance spokesman said, the victims often felt helpless and did not know how to protect themselves because the abuse came from their parents or next of kin.

According to the alliance's study, the main causes of abuse included a lack of parenting knowledge (30.06 percent) , marriage dysfunction (20.07 percent) , drug abuse (11.65 percent) , poverty (10.9 percent) and unemployment (9.8 percent).

The alliance said the government should assign more trained staff and contribute more budget to help abused children. At the moment, the government has only 250 full-time staff members responsible for protecting abused children.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 OPTONICS WEEK TO KICK OFF WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: A record 1,000 booths from more than 500 companies from Taiwan and overseas will take part in the 2004 Optonics week to be held at the Taipei World Trade Center June 9-12.

Lin Ying-yi, an official of the Optonics Industry and Technology Development Association, said in a pre-show press conference that production value of Taiwan's optonics industry hit NT$500 billion (US$14.92 billion) in 2002, and reached around NT$664.6 billion in 2003, an increase of 33 percent.

It is estimated that the production value will climb to NT$838 billion, or a growth of 26 percent and that the annual growth over the next three years will be 17 percent annually, with the production value surpassing NT$1 trillion by 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD PASSES TAIPOWER PLAN TO BUILD POWER PLANT IN CHANGHUA

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) passed Monday a plan by state-owned Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) to invest NT$50 billion (US$1.42 billion) in building a power plant in Changhua, central Taiwan.
The CEPD passed the plan during its first meeting presided over by new Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng.

Two coal-fired generators will be installed at the plant, each one capable of generating 800 megawatts. The budget for the plant will be appropriated from next year and the two generators will start operating in January and July 2011, respectively.

Taipower officials said that power demand at peak times is increasing by 1,400 megawatt every year and that the newly installed ninth and tenth generators at the Taichung thermal power plant cannot meet the demand, hence the plan for the new power plant in Changhua.

Taipower also plans to build a coal-fired generating plant at Taipei Harbor, generating 6,000 megawatts in the mid-term. Initially, two generators will be installed, at a cost of about NT$60 billion. Budget will be appropriated from 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC GROUP DELEGATION FROM MAINLAND CHINA ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: A delegation of the mainland China-based China Disabled Persons' Federation arrived in Taipei Monday for a week-long visit at the invitation of the Taiwan-based Chinese Assistive Technology Association.
The delegation, headed by Cheng Kai, vice president of the federation, will exchange experiences and points of view with its Taiwanese counterparts during the visit.

Upon arrival at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Cheng said that he and his delegation hope to learn from Taiwan's experiences on how to provide a more convenient living environment for the disabled with the use of assistive technology and how to help the disabled engage in the assistive technology businesses.
There is a great number of disabled people on the mainland, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU ARRIVES IN SAN FRANCISCO FOR STOPOVER ON WAY HOME
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 6 (CNA) (By S.J. Tsai and P.C.Tang)

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu arrived in San Francisco Sunday for a stopover on her way back to Taiwan after a 14-day official visit to Republic of China diplomatic allies in Central America.

The vice president was jointly greeted upon arrival by Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's representative to the United States, and a representative of the American Institute in Taiwan, an unofficial organization dealing with U.S.-Taiwan relations.

Lu and her entourage were welcomed by the U.S. authorities under the principles of respect, courtesy, convenience and comfort even though the United States has been tightening its anti-terrorist measures at the airport.

Twelve police motorcycles cleared a path for the vice president on her way from the airport to the Fairmont Hotel where she will staying during her stopover. Lu also received a warm welcome from hundreds of the "pan-green camp" supporters waving the ROC and U.S. national flags and chanting "Taiwan go! go! go!" and "Lu we love you" in front of the hotel when she arrived.

However, members of certain local "pan-blue alliance" organizations also gathered a bit later near the hotel to unfurl banners protesting the March 20 presidential election result as well as any moves toward Taiwan independence.

Lu will receive a human rights award from Rep. Tom Lantos (D-Calif.) , member of the U.S. House of Representatives and co-chairman of the Congressional Human Rights Caucus, in honor of her contributions toward the development of human rights at a dinner party hosted by local Taiwan expatriates Sunday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT URGES BUSINESSMEN TO DIVERSIFY EXPORT MARKETS

TEXT.P: As Taiwan businessmen's dependence on the mainland Chinese market is still high, the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Monday urged firms to diversify their export markets to avoid risk.

Citing statistics released Monday by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) , BOFT officials said that in the first five months of this year, Taiwan's exports to the mainland, including Hong Kong, increased by 40.2 percent over the same period of last year, a figure representing 37 percent of Taiwan's total exports.

To prevent domestic companies' overdependence on the mainland market, BOFT officials said that the agency will conduct a study with the Industrial Development Bureau and the Industrial Development and Investment Center on ways to diversify local enterprises' investment markets, and plans to send several trade delegations to major global market destinations this year to increase export outlets.

Fortunately, BOFT officials said, mainland imports from Taiwan in the first four months increased by only 39.9 percent, far less than the 57.6 percent growth registered in its imports from Australia, 52.1 percent growth from South Korea, and 43 percent growth from Malaysia.

In addition, the percentage of Taiwan-made products in the mainland's total imported goods fell from last year's 11.72 percent to 11.52 percent, indicating that Taiwanese firms have noticed the risk of investing in the mainland, BOFT officials said.

The officials also predicted that Taiwan's foreign trade may register double-digit growth in the second half of this year, considering the strong global economy -- which apparently has not been affected much by the rising international oil prices -- and the island's healthy exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES DENY CREDIT CURB ON TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Instead of tightening up, Taiwan is set to relax regulations on loans by local banks' offshore banking units to Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China, according to the Taipei-based Central Bank of China (CBC) and the Ministry of Finance (MOF).

Officials at the CBC and the MOF denied unanimously local press reports Monday that they have asked local banks to curtail their offshore banking units' loans to Taiwan businessmen on the mainland in the wake of Beijing's recent hostility toward Taiwan.

The reports pointed to recent criticism carried in the mainland's People's Daily of Shu Wen-lung, chairman of Taiwan's Chi Mei Group, for what it claims is his support for Taiwan independence, and a call on a Web site by a mainland scholar for economic sanctions against Taiwan.

CBC and MOF officials said Taiwan has allowed local banks to extend loans to Taiwan businessmen on the mainland since August, 2002 and further eased the restrictions in April and May this year to allow local firms to borrow money from local banks for their mainland operations.
They said this policy and the trend of further relaxing the restrictions has not been changed.

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO VERIFY DOCUMENTS TO PREVENT RECURRENCE OF TOXIC WASTE EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Environmental protection agencies at central and local levels will carefully verify all relevant documents to prevent any recurrence of illegal toxic waste exports, a senior official said Monday.

Chen Hsiung-wen, director of the Solid Waste Management Bureau under the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) , made the remarks after a local company allegedly shipped more than 11,000 tons of toxic industrial waste to Malaysia last year without proper authorization from the Kuala Lumpur government.

Chen said the EPA revoked late last month its industrial waste export permit to Hong You Co. after it found that the Malaysian import permit only allowed for shipments of industrial waste, not toxic materials.

Chen said the EPA has asked international police organizations to assist in probing whether the Taiwan firm's Malaysian partner forged the Malaysian import permit to deceive Hong You or whether the two companies colluded to use fake documents to dupe Taiwan and Malaysian authorities.

In the future, Chen said, the EPA and local environmental protection offices will contact the recipient countries' environmental protection authorities by fax or e-mail to verify whether the import permits produced by local industrial waste exporting firms are genuine.
"We hope such prior document verification will help prevent a recurrence of this," Chen said.
The multilateral Basel Convention prohibits trans-boundary movement of hazardous waste among signatory countries.

Chen said the EPA has established channels with the United States, Belgium, Germany, France and South Africa for verifying industrial waste export documents. The recent incident has also prompted the EPA to forge similar channels with Malaysia.

As for the 11,000 tons of toxic waste that has already been sent to the southern Malaysia state of Johor, Chen said the EPA will check whether Hong You's Malaysian partner has the ability to treat the waste. If it cannot dispose of the waste, Chen said, the EPA will order the Taiwan firm to bring the waste home for disposal.
In 1998, Taiwan's Formosa Plastics Corp. violated Cambodian law by shipping mercury-laden waste to the Southeast Asian nation. The company was later forced to ship the material back to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA TO LAUNCH WEB SITE FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: A Web site catering for Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China will be launched Tuesday by the Central News Agency (CNA) in Taipei.

The site is aimed at keeping Taiwan businessmen on the mainland informed of world news, give them access to air their views and provide them with a platform to exchange opinions, according to a press release issued Monday by CNA.

In addition to breaking news, the Web site also supply viewers with customized information through columns such as "Taiwan Businessman Hall of Fame, " "Speeches by Taiwan Business Experts, " "The Latest News about Taiwan Businessmen, " and "Calendar of Major Events on Both Sides of the Strait."
The Web site will also provide free mobile phone messages to the chiefs of 78 Taiwan Businessmen's Associations on the mainland, as well as to other leading Taiwan businessmen.

In ceremony scheduled for Tuesday to mark the launch of the Web site, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu, Chinese National Federation of Industries Chairman Ho Chen-hsiung and CNA Chairman Su Tzen-ping will jointly press a button to send out mobile phone messages to leading Taiwan businessmen on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT LOCAL CHIEF HAILS TAIWAN-U.S. COOPERATION IN FIGHT AGAINST DRUGS

TEXT.P: Douglas Paal, director-general of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , said Monday that Taiwan-U.S. cooperation in the fight against drug trafficking has achieved admirable results.
The de facto U.S. ambassador to Taipei made the remarks at the opening of a training workshop for Taiwan's middle- and high-ranking law enforcement personnel in charge of the war on contraband drugs.
Paal headed a group of four staffers from the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA) stationed in Hong Kong and Seoul to attend the opening ceremony.

Noting that the workshop will enable law enforcement officers from both sides to share their experiences in the crackdown on drug trafficking, Paal said that Taiwan-U.S. anti-drug cooperation has paid off in recent years, with many cross-border drug trafficking rings smashed.

Paal even that said if his former superior, Ronald Reagan, were still alive, the late U.S. president would have been proud of the outcome of the bilateral cooperation in the campaign against drug trafficking and abuse. Reagan died at his home in Simi Valley on the outskirts of Los Angeles Saturday at the age of 93.

The DEA began to send staff members to lecture on anti-drug trafficking strategies and tactics in 2002. This year, the two sides will exchange views and experiences in undercover investigations, wiretapping practices and intelligence sharing.

A total of 155 Taiwan law enforcement officers from the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) , prosecutor's offices at various levels, the National Police Administration, the Coast Guard Administration, the Aviation Police Bureau and the Criminal Investigation Bureau participated in the workshop.

MJIB Director Yeh Mao-sheng, who presided over the opening ceremony, noted that Taiwan seized 8,482 kg of contraband drugs last year, the largest amount in a decade. The major drug trafficking cases uncovered in 2003 with the cooperation between Taiwan-U.S. law enforcement officers included the discovery of an amphetamine production facility in the United States operated by a Taiwan citizen and the seizure of 4.7 kg of cocaine that a Nigerian citizen had attempted to smuggle into Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSCRIPTS TAKE 27 DAYS TO LAND JOBS AFTER DEMOB

TEXT.P: Conscripted military personnel take an average of 27.23 days to find a job after being demobbed, according to the results of a survey released Monday by the 1111 Manpower Bank, a local employment agency.

Providing a glimpse of the issues facing conscripts when they try to land a job after finishing their one year and ten months' compulsory military service, the manpower bank survey obtained 2,451 valid responses and found that 66 percent of the respondents entered the workforce immediately, while 13 percent went back to school and worked only part time.
Among those who opted for work, 59 percent had already found jobs, with the remainder still looking for work.

As for the time taken them to get a job, 27 percent said it took them 10 days or less, 17 percent said it took them between 11 and 20 days, 20 percent said it took them between 21 and 30 days and 11 percent said it took them between 31 and 40 days, giving an average of 27.23 days.
Although 49 percent of the respondents said their military service expanded their horizons, 56 percent said it was a waste of time and 77 percent said they will not return to the armed forces.
The survey was conducted between May 21 and June 1, with a confidence level of 95 percent and an error of margin of plus or minus 2.4 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOWER RELIANCE ON IMPORTED CRUDE OIL GOOD FOR CONSUMER PRICES

TEXT.P: The nation's reliance on imported petroleum has been lower recently than in the past and recent oil price hikes have had only a modest effect on consumer prices, Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) officials said Monday.

DGBAS officials said that compared with the energy crisis of 1980, the nation's reliance on imported crude oil has been lower, and that consumer prices have seen only modest increases over the past few months, which they said is favorable for economic growth.

Although two domestic oil companies -- Chinese Petroleum Corp and Formosa Petrochemical Corp -- have yet to adjust upward their prices, the hike of international oil prices in recent months and the dramatic hikes of international raw materials mean that domestic consumer prices are poised to increase.

DGBAS officials said that imported crude used to account for a large share of imports in past years, saying that in 1980, crude imports accounted for 20.8 percent of the total imports, while the ratio was 10.88 percent in 1989 and 7.52 percent in 2003.
They said that with the reliance on imported crude lowered, its effect on consumer prices has also dropped.
They noted that if the price of domestic petroleum products rises by 10 percent, it will increase wholesale prices by 0.53 percent and consumer prices by 0.37 percent.
They said that the consumer price index stood at 100.68 in May, up a modest 0.89 percent from the same month of the previous year,
The officials said that the increase was due mainly to the rise in petroleum prices since last year, with fuel prices increasing by 11.61 percent.
The wholesale price index was 108.81 percent in May, up 6.76 percent from the same month of last year, mainly because of the high prices of crude and steel, as well as related products.

DOC.HEADLINE: FINE FOR FALSE CUSTOMS DECLARATION TO BE RAISED

TEXT.P: The Finance Committee at the Legislative Yuan approved a revision Monday to the Statute Governing Customs Declarations which raises the maximum fine for a false customs declaration from NT$30,000 (US$896) to NT$1 million (US$29,868).
The revision, initiated by the Ministry of Finance, was meant to deter local smugglers from exporting stolen cars. It still must be approved by the whole Legislative Yuan before taking effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWWAN-THAILAND TRADE PROMISING: ROC VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, June 7 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang said Monday that he foresees considerable growth in trade between Taiwan and Thailand this year, as bilateral trade in the first quarter has already registered double-digit growth.

Shih, who is in Bangkok heading a trade promotion tour to four Southeast Asian countries, said at the opening of a seminar that Taiwan's exports to Thailand in the first quarter increased 26 percent over the same period of the previous year, while its imports from Thailand also registered a 21 percent growth over the same period.

According to Shih, as of the end of 2003, Taiwan businessmen have poured some US$10.9 billion as investments in Thailand, becoming the Southeast Asian country's third-largest foreign investor, behind only Japan and the United States.
If adding in those investments not registered with the government, Shih added, Taiwanese investments in Thailand may exceed US$16 billion.

Shih noted that as Thailand will become one of Taiwan businessmen's major investment bases abroad, the two countries should strengthen economic and trade ties, suggesting that the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Thailand play an active role in promoting cooperation projects between enterprises of the two countries.

Thai Premier Office's adviser Krasae Chanawongse, who was also present at the opening, said that the Thai government attaches great importance to Taiwanese businessmen's investments by offering them many preferential investment conditions.

In addition to Bangkok, the delegation comprised of representatives from 46 Taiwan companies has visited the Philippines and will head for Malaysia and Indonesia after finishing its current visit in Thailand on June 9.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT PAYS PUBLIC TRIBUTE TO REAGAN IN SAN FRANCISCO
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 6 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government unprecedentedly allowed visiting Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu Sunday to issue a public statement mourning late U.S. President Ronald Reagan, who died a day earlier at the age of 93.

Lu, who arrived in San Francisco earlier in the day for a transit stop on her way back to Taipei after a three-leg diplomatic tour of Central America, said she delivered the posthumous tribute to Reagan on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian and the 23 million Taiwan people.
For fears of offending Beijing, the U.S. government has traditionally banned senior ROC leaders from conducting public activities or meeting the media during their transit stops.

Lu said Reagan had made outstanding contributions to reviving the U.S. economy and laying a solid foundation for world peace during his two terms in office from 1981 to 1989. The popular, infectiously optimistic late U.S. president devoted much energies to destroying Soviet communism but later worked with Soviet leaders to negotiate crucial arms control accords to defend world peace, Lu said.

Reagan once visited Taiwan during his tenure as California State governor to signify his support for the ROC's efforts to pursue freedom and resist communism, Lu said, adding that Reagan's friendship and support for Taiwan is memorable and cherished.
Lu said she was deeply moved and impressed by Reagan's lifelong achievements during her visit to the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library last August when she was making a transit stop in Los Angeles.
Lu further said Reagan's death is an immeasurable loss both to the United States and to the world as a whole. She also extended her sympathy and condolences to the Reagan family.

This is Lu's first overseas trip since she was sworn in for a second four-year term on May 20. She first visited El Salvador to attend the country's presidential inauguration on behalf of President Chen and then visited Costa Rica and Guatemala. On her way to El Salvador, Lu and her entourage made a two-day transit stop in Las Vegas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES TAIWANESE BUSINESSMEN TO HALT INVESTMENT IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) on Monday urged the government and domestic businessmen to halt their active investment policies toward mainland China amid the increasing political interference that Beijing imposes on Taiwanese businessmen.

Siew Kuan-yu, director of the TSU's Department of Social Development, suggested that the government halt the opening of direct trade, postal and transport links between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait following reports that mainland Chinese authorities began to imposed stringent policies toward investment from Taiwanese businessmen who Beijing believe are pro-Taiwan's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and thus are supporters of Taiwan independence.

Beijing has never hidden the fact that it does not welcome pro-DPP Taiwanese businessmen with investments on the mainland, accusing them of using profits gained on the mainland to finance the independence movement in Taiwan.
Recently, the mainland government, through its official mouthpiece -- the People's Daily -- named some of these businessmen, among them Hsu Wen-lung, chairman of the well-known Chi Mei Group.

According to mainland Chinese newspapers, the Chi Mei Group's plant on the mainland was denied loans from local banks and its investment project in Zhejiang province was halted by China's State Council, although Chi Mei denied it.

Noting that Beijing's use of political means to interfere in economic affairs represents unfair treatment to Taiwanese businessmen, Siew urged the government to take quick and necessary reactions to prevent Taiwan businessmen from suffering more from their investments on the mainland.

Siew suggested that the government halt its approval of investments of domestic eight-inch wafer manufacturers in mainland China to avoid China from easily obtaining Taiwan's high technology without making any efforts, stressing that it is necessary that the lawmakers draw a high-tech protection bill to further protect the country's high technology from flowing to unfriendly countries.

Meanwhile, Siew also urged local businessmen interested in investing in the mainland not to have too much "illusions" about China, and called on local people to "boycott Chinese goods and use local products" as a way of protesting against Beijing authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB ISSUES SEA WARNING FOR CONSON

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning for Typhoon Conson Monday afternoon.
CWB officials said that Conson was currently located 600 kilometers south-southwest off Oluanpi and was moving north-northeast at a speed of 14 kilometers per hour.
The officials said that Conson is now approaching the Bashi Channel, which they said will pose a threat to ships in the area and Tungsha (Pratas) island.
The officials also said that because of Conson, torrential rains are expected in Taiwan's southernmost tip of Hengchun, as well as
eastern and southern parts of the island.
Conson is the fourth tyhppon of the year in the Pacific area.

The Times: Queen hails last parade of the D-Day veterans.
The Queen spoke of her sadness last night that the veterans of D-Day had gathered for their last parade and hailed the Normandy invasion 60 years ago as one of the proudest moments in British history,
Financial Times: Airlines attack BAA on Heathrow
A group of the world's leading airlines including Germany's Lufthansa, United Airlines of the US and Japan's ANA, launched a bitter attack at the weekend against BAA, the operator of London Heathrow, the world's busiest international airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN MEETS WITH OVERSEAS CHINESE IN GREATER NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 6 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san met with overseas Chinese living in the greater New York area Sunday and talked about recent developments in Taiwan.
Chiu spoke of the recent re-count of more than 13 million presidential election ballots, and the simultaneous holding of the presidential election and a referendum on March 20.
He said that the holding of the two polls was not without precedence in the world, citing as an example that New York held a mayoral election and a referendum in 1997.

On the year-end legislative election, Chiu said that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's goal is to win more than half of the seats, saying that nomination strategy and nominated candidates will hold the key. As there are still several months before the elections, both the ruling and the opposition parties cannot be overly optimistic, he added.

As for constitutional reforms, Chiu said that the proposal to cut the number of the 225-seat Legislative Yuan in half must be weighed carefully, and that there should be other measures or the chaotic situation in the legislature could become worse.

On the development of cross-strait relations, Chiu said the basic policy of mainland China is still to have political issues as the premises for talks, which he said have become the hurdle for cross-strait exchanges.

In fact, he said, non-political exchanges have continued, citing cultural and educational exchanges as an example, saying that there were more than 300 cross-strait visits in March, and the number increased to more than 500 visits in May.

Chiu arrived in New York Friday night to attend a seminar on the 15th anniversary of the Tiananmen Massacre the next day. He will call on think tanks in New York Monday to exchange views on cross-strait relations with U.S. scholars before proceeding to Boston. He is scheduled to return to Taipei May 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved up Monday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June rose 283 points to close at 5,890, with 45,734 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July gained 265 points to end at 5,839 with 628 contracts traded, while September futures rose 253 points to end at 5,814, with six contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Monday at 5,607 for June, 5,574 for July, 5,561 for September, 5,647 for December and 5,577 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved up.
June TE futures gained 11.2 points to close at 240.5, with 4,306 contracts traded, while July TE futures rose 11.5 points to end at 239.5, with 78 contracts transacted.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures gained 59.2 points to close at 964.8, with 6,837 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures rose 58 points to end at 953, with 401 contracts traded.
September TF futures gained 37.2 points to close at 935, with two contract transactions, while December TF futures rose 43 points to end at 941, with two contracts concluded.
No transactions were recorded for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER CALLS FOR ROC-MEXICO INVESTMENT GUARANTEE ACCORD

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh has said in Chile that she welcomed Mexico's invitation to Taiwan's semiconductor manufacturing plants to invest in Mexico, but signing a bilateral investment guarantee agreement would be a prerequisite.

According to officials from the economics ministry, Ho met with Mexico's secretary of economy, Fernando Canales Clariond, for talks during the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) ministerial meeting held in Pucon, southern Chile June 4-5.

During the talks, Clariond reportedly extended an invitation to Taiwan's microchip foundries to relocate part of their semiconductor processing operations to Mexico to take advantage of the country's geographical proximity to North America as well as offering other investment benefits.

Mexico's invitation is welcome news for Taiwan authorities because they have long been concerned that Taiwan's overseas foundry investments have relied too much on mainland China, with about 60 percent of their products being churned out by the "Chinese factory."

Relocating part of the processing operations to Mexico will not only help Taiwan microchip foundries diversify manufacturing bases, it will also help Taiwan make inroads into the much larger and more mature markets in North America, Ho said.

Nevertheless, Ho noted that since the semiconductor manufacturing industry is a capital- and technology-intensive industry requiring at least US$3 billion for one plant to become operational, the signing of a bilateral investment guarantee agreement is thus crucial and imperative.

For his part, Clariond said that he will see to it that Mexico seeks to conduct bilateral talks with Taiwan under legal frameworks of both countries on the signing of an investment guarantee agreement to facilitate the realization of Taiwan's semiconductor investment in Mexico.

Clariond also noted that Mexico -- whose two-way trade markets have been focusing on North America as a result of NAFTA -- is keenly interested in developing closer business and trade relations with major economies in Asia, including Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Singapore.

Ho, who was sworn in as economics minister May 20, has also met with her counterparts from Canada, Indonesia, Singapore, South Korea and Japan for bilateral talks during the two-day ministerial meeting, ministry officials said.
Ho and her ministry delegation are expected to return to Taipei Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

A total of US$599 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's high of NT$33.580 and fell to NT$33.460.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 210.93 points to close at 5,935.82.
The bourse opened at 5,803.01 and fluctuated between 5,938.04 and 5,793.96 during trading.

A total of 3.75 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$78.3 billion (US$2.34 billion) , an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 3.22 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$70.49 billion.

All of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance shares moving up the most at 5.8 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 4.6 percent, textile issues at 4 percent, cement stocks at 3.7 percent, construction stocks at 3.6 percent, electrical shares at 3.4 percent, foodstuff stocks at 2.8 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 784 to 88, with 93 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Reagan legacy looming large over campaign.
U.S. President Bush and his political advisers embraced the legacy of Ronald Reagan, suggesting that even in death, Mr. Reagan had one more campaign in him -- this one at the side of Mr. Bush.
The Wall Street Journal: How Reagan recast debate on markets, taxes -- and deficits.
The weekend death of Ronald Reagan brought an outpouring of eulogies that agreed on many things the 40th president had been to his country: a towering political figure, a slayer of Communism, and a sunny optimist at a time when that's what Americans needed most. However, even upon his death, no agreement could be reached on the virtues and vices of the economic revolution he wrought -- or on how much of it endures today.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLASTICS TYCOON WANG UPBEAT ON INVESTMENT PROSPECTS IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's giant Taiwan Plastics Group who just returned from mainland China said Monday that he is optimistic about business opportunities that could be realized by mainland China's future economic growth.

Wang Yung-ching also said that he plans to make some investments that will benefit people. These include projects involving petrochemical and power plants in mainland China, if he has the opportunity.

Wang refused to comment on Beijing's recent admonition of Hsu Wen-long, another wealthy Taiwan businessman and former chairman of the ChiMei Group, that investors from Taiwan who take their profits derived from the mainland and use them to bolster Taiwan independence moves would not be welcome in the mainland.
Wang said that he does not know the politics nor understand the relevant matters.

Turning to economic issues, Wang pointing out that the current adjustment and control measures adopted by the mainland on its macro-economy are helpful for the mainland's sustainable economic development. He said that he found during his recent tour in mainland China that enterprises operating legally have not been influenced by such measures and that the finance work for the enterprises has also been proceeding normally.

He also said that he believes Taiwan business people's investment in mainland China will be warmly received by local authorities if the investments are reasonable since investments are welcomed everywhere if they are helpful for local development and prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW POLITICAL PARTY TAKING SHAPE

TEXT.P: The preparatory committee of the tentatively-named Nonpartisan Solidarity Union (NSU) was established Monday, bringing the country a step closer to seeing the realization of a new political party.

Former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya said during a news conference marking the committee's establishment that she does not exclude the possibility of serving as chairwoman of the new party when it is founded.

Chang, who had also been a health minister during the latter part of the era of Kuomintang rule, said the establishment of the NSU will effectively offer a "third" or "middle-way" choice for the people of Taiwan, who have long been divided into only two groups -- either "pro-unification Blue" or "pro-independence Green."

The new party's 40-odd founders include some well-known politicians such as Chang, former Hsinchu Mayor Shih Hsin-chung, and 10 of the 13 independent legislators of the country who have grouped under the banner of the existing Alliance of Independent Legislators.
The NSU preparatory committee will file a list of its founders Monday with the Ministry of the Interior in the first step toward forming the new party, said Chiu Chuang-liang, one of the founders.

Tsai Hao, one of the founders and head of the Alliance of Independent Legislators, said the new party's goals include enabling independent lawmakers to play a more useful role in the party-dominated legislature and being committed to be the voice of the country's underprivileged.

Tsai said the NSU is expected to flex its muscles in the year-end legislative elections and is determined to win more than 15 seats. The party will name no more than one candidate in each constituency in the legislative elections, in hopes of winning more than 5 percent of the votes, which is the threshold for political parties seeking government grants and at-large legislative seats, Tsai noted.

He added that all 10 members of the Alliance of Independent Legislators will stand for re-election in the legislative elections, which should quell speculation that the ruling Democratic Progressive Party is trying to win over the alliance's support in the legislature by offering its members Cabinet positions or seats in the Control Yuan.
If everything goes smoothly, Tsai said, the NSU is expected to convene its first party congress by Aug. 3 and the party will be formally founded Sept. 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER SCHEDULED TO VISIT EUROPE IN JULY

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Shan Chen said Monday he is scheduled to visit Europe in July as part of his efforts to forge closer ties between the Republic of China and E.U. member countries.

Tan made the remarks while delivering a speech at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Foreign Affairs Committee on the nation's diplomatic situation in the wake of President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration for a second four-year term.

During the session, opposition Kuomintang Legislator Sun Kuo-hua said the European Union's vote against Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly -- the World Health Organization's governing body -- in May indicated that Taiwan should devote more energy to boosting substantive ties with the 25-member bloc.

In response, Chen said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has consistently given priority to forging closer ties with the European Union. With the number of E.U. member states expanding from 15 to 25 in May, Chen said Taiwan must make even more efforts to promote relations with the bloc.

Barring unexpected developments, Chen said he will leave for a European tour in July with a view to integrating the resources of ROC representation offices in various European countries and working out innovative measures to promote cooperative ties with the European Union.

Asked whether the MOFA has felt pressure from the United States over the arms procurement budget issue, Chen said that "although our diplomatic staff may talk about arms procurement plans with American officials in private, the weaponry procurement issue is principally handled by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) . The MOFA has not so far felt any U.S. pressure over the arms procurement plan."

Opposition lawmakers brought up the arms purchase issue because the Cabinet passed an MND-proposed NT$610.8 billion budget plan last week to buy six advanced Patriot anti-missile defense batteries, 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and eight conventional submarines from the United States. Many opposition lawmakers have questioned the wisdom of buying these weapons at allegedly exorbitant prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
[Turkish Daily News]: [Reagan bows out at 93]
Ronale Reagan's enemies and friends agreed he changed the world. The popular, infectiously optimistic late president devoted most of his energies to destroying Soviet communism - but later worked with Soviet leaders to negotiate crucial arms control accords.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON CONSON LIKELY TO AFFECT TAIWAN: CWB

TEXT.P: Typhoon Conson, which formed Monday morning from a low pressure system lurking near the South China Sea, is likely to affect Taiwan in the following couple of days, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.

The weather bureau will issue a sea warning Monday afternoon at the earliest if the newly-developed typhoon continues to gain momentum and keeps moving in a north-north-easterly direction, CWB meteorologists said.

Typhoon Conson, with a radius of 100 kilometers and packing maximum sustained winds of up to 75 kilometers per hour, was centered about 660 km south-southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Hengchun at 8 a.m. Monday, moving north-north-easterly toward Taiwan at a speed of 10 kilometers per hour.
Since the storm is located pretty near to Taiwan, the CWB meteorologists said the bureau may first issue a sea warning for the Bashi Channel and Dongsha Islands areas later Monday.

Whether Typhoon Conson directly hits Taiwan depends on how a stationary front from northern mainland China, which is moving southward, interacts with the typhoon's moisture system in the following days, the meteorologists said.
Conson is the fourth typhoon of the year in the Pacific area.

Meanwhile, another low pressure system has been detected lurking near Guam. The system was located about 2,000 kilometers from Taiwan at 8 a.m. Monday, moving westward toward the island at a speed of 10 kilometers per hour, the CWB reported.
The meteorologists said it is still too early to tell whether the low pressure system will directly affect Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 7, or the 20th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1893: Indian leader Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy of passive resistance begins when he is thrown off a segregated train in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, where he had lived for 21 years.
1905: Norway declares its independence from Sweden.
1909: Jessica Tandy, American actress, is born in England. She became the oldest person to receive an Oscar at the age of 80 in 1990 for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy."
1939: King George VI and Queen Elizabeth cross from Canada into America to become the first British monarchs to visit the United States.
1973: The Far East Senior League baseball play-offs open in Taipei.
1974: A memorandum to strengthen economic ties between the Republic of China and Saudi Arabia is signed by Sheik Mahmond Talba, deputy minister of commerce and industry, and Wang Yi-ting, director-general of the Chinese Board of Foreign Trade.
1975: The last two U.S. combat aircraft based on Taiwan are pulled out.
1976: Dr. Arthur J. Barsky, founder of the International Rehabilitation Center for Disabled Children, arrives in Taipei to discuss establishing a rehabilitation center for Southeast Asia.
1979: The ROC Cabinet names Dr. James Soong director general of the Government Information Office.
1981: Taipei Mayor Lee Teng-hui leads a 10-member delegation to the United States to attend the annual meeting of American city mayors.
1982: Israel mounts major air and ground attacks against Beirut, Tryre and Sidon on the second day of its invasion of Lebanon to destroy the Palestine Liberation Organization.
1983: The Legislative Yuan approves the Firearms Control Law during its third reading, tightening controls on the manufacture, possession or use of firearms and other weapons. Punishments for violating the law are to range from 7 years to life imprisonment.
1989: A Surinam Airways DC-8 on a flight from Amsterdam crashes near Paramaribo's international airport, killing 169 of the 182 people on board.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui of the Republic of China arrives in the United States for a reunion at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: At his first press conference as vice president and premier, Lien Chan indicates that the ROC has not ruled out the possibility of the two sides of the Taiwan Straits exchanging visits by high-ranking officials. He also emphasizes the need to reopen channels to allow cross-strait talks.
1999: President Lee Teng-hui announces that the ROC will donate US$300 to help Kosovar refugees rebuild their homes.
2000: A Taiwan hospital reports the first case of Costello Syndrome, a debilitating genetic disease that causes a host of physical abnormalities.
2001: Samuel C. Ting, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist, gives a speech at National Cheng Kung University in Tainan on the composition of the universe.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are nine objects which a wise man aims at. In the use of his eyes, his object is to see clearly. In the use of his ears, his object is to hear distinctly. In the expression of his look, his object is to be gracious.
"In his manners, his object is to be serious. In what he says, his object is to be sincere, In business, his object is to be earnest. In doubt, his object is to seek information. In anger, his object is to think of consequences. In view of personal advantage, his object is to think of what is right."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO SPONSOR TRADE SHOWS IN MONGOLIA, ST. VINCENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is scheduled to sponsor two trade shows abroad in June as part of efforts to bolster Taiwan's diplomatic and economic ties with friendly countries while helping Taiwan manufacturers explore overseas markets around the world.

MOFA, in cooperation with the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), is sponsoring a trade show in Mongolia and another in St. Vincent and the Grenadines this month under a two-pronged mindset of strengthening diplomatic relations via trade and promoting trade via diplomatic ties, said Liu Jong-tsuo, director of the MOFA's Department of Economic and Trade Affairs.

The MOFA-TAITRA co-sponsored trade show, titled "2004 International Spring Trade Fair in Mongolia," is scheduled to be held in Ulan Bator June 8-12, with 15 Taiwan companies taking part. Products to be displayed at the trade fair include agricultural and livestock products and related tools and machinery; electrical appliances; textiles and garments; and sporting goods, according to Liu.
The trade show to be held in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, titled "ROC and St. Vincent and Grenadines Show of Catalogs, " is scheduled to be held June 17-23, Liu said.

The MOFA and TAITRA jointly sponsored 43 Taiwan computer and information technology companies to take part in the 2004 GITEX computer expo held in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia April 18-22. Saudi Arabia is the largest market for information technology products in the Middle East, according to Liu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, JAPAN, KOREA LAND SURVEY SYMPOSIUM TO BE HELD IN TAINAN

TEXT.P: Scientists and specialists from Taiwan, Japan and South Korea are scheduled to gather in Tainan, southern Taiwan Wednesday for the Fourth International Symposium on Land Survey.

Some 100 specialists from the government and private sectors of the three countries are expected to take part in the one-day symposium, titled "Land Survey in the E-Age, " to be held at a scenic resort in Tainan County.

The specialists, including 30-odd from Japan and a dozen from South Korea, are expected to discuss legal frameworks, regulations, technologies, information and applications regarding land survey and policy, according to officials from the Land Survey Bureau (LSB) under the Ministry of the Interior.

The specialists are also expected to share their experiences on land survey and policy so that the three countries can improve land research and survey technologies to make their lands and related development sustainable, said LSB officials, who are sponsoring the symposium.
The biennial land survey symposium was first held in 1998. This will be the second time that Taiwan hosts the symposium, the LSB officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Tributes Paid to Reagan Legacy.
As the family of former President Ronald Reagan remained in seclusion,officials announced a week of memorial events on both coasts that will include an overnight viewing at Reagan's library near Simi Valley, and the first president state funeral in Washington in more than 30 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD NABS 21 FEMALE MAINLAND STOWAWAYS

TEXT.P: Twenty-one female mainland Chinese stowaways aboard a Taiwan fishing boat were nabbed off Ilan, eastern Taiwan, the coast guard reported Tuesday.

Coast guard officials stationed in Suao said the captain of the "Mingchunchia, " surnamed Yeh, and a crew member surnamed Lien have been turned over to the Ilan Prosecutor's Office for violation of the Statue Governing the Relations Between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area as well as the National Security Law.

Coast guard official Chiang Chao-lin noted that since the Central Weather Bureau issued a sea warning for Typhoon Conson Monday afternoon, ships have flocked into the harbor to seek safe haven from the inclement weather. Smuggling rings might see this as an opportune time to carry out their illegal activities, he added.
Chiang said that he has asked all coast guard forces to step up their monitoring and crackdown on any illegal activities at sea.

He said the coast guard had been tipped off earlier about the Keelung-registered "Mingchunchia, " adding that officers boarded the ship off Toucheng, Ilan, at around 2 a.m. Tuesday. They found no fish haul or fishing equipment, and instead discovered the 21 illegal mainland Chinese immigrants in the cabin of the boat.

Captain Yeh said during his initial arraignment that he had gotten into a quarrel with another ship days earlier and that because he could not pay the compensation, he had agreed to smuggle the women into Taiwan in lieu of the payment.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Military drills to include terror threat.
Deffence ministers from the Five Power Defence Arrangements (FDPA) have agreed to expand the scope of military exercises to include counter-terrorism drills, starting with a maritime exercise to be held in the South China Sea later this year.
The Lianhe Zaobao: FPDA to focus on non-conventional threats to regional maritime security.
The Five Power Defence Arrangements, or FPDA, have been expanded beyond traditional territorial threats to also deal with non-conventional security threats such as maritime terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PREMIER: TRADE IS COMMON GROUND BETWEEN TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Trade exchanges are the common ground between Taiwan and mainland China and should serve as the basis connecting the two sides, former Premier and Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation Chairman Vincent Siew said Tuesday.

In a seminar on ties with the mainland, Siew said Beijing, which recently criticised a Taiwan business tycoon for his political preference for Taiwan independence, will undermine this basis to the detriment of both sides by doing so, said Siew.
He urged the Beijing authorities not to interfere with economic exchanges with Taiwan on political grounds, as this will only scare away Taiwan investors.

Although Beijing is threatening to impose economic sanctions on Taiwan because of the island's resistance to reunification with the mainland, Siew took the threat with a grain of salt, saying that Taiwan is not Beijing's top priority, as it is going all-out to significantly enhance its people's living standards by 2020.
Until then, trade will be the strongest factor gluing the two sides together, Siew predicted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER RETURNS FROM CHILE

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh returned to Taipei Tuesday night from Pucon, Chile, where she attended a June 4-5 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) meeting of ministers responsible for trade.
Speaking at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Ho said the APEC meeting examined the progress made by member economies in facilitating international trade.
On the sidelines of the meeting, Ho went on, she met with her counterparts from eight member economies, including Indonesia, Singapore, South Korea, Japan and Chile.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO LEAD DPP TO VICTORY IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Tuesday to lead his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to a majority in the year-end legislative elections.

Chen, who doubles as DPP chairman, told a meeting of the DPP Central Standing Committee that he has achieved two of the three goals he outlined at the last DPP founding anniversary -- to carry out the country's first national referendum and to win the 2004 presidential election.
Now, he said, it is time to complete the remaining goal -- to win a majority in the legislature.
He urged DPP members to win public support by doing things that meet the people's desires.
As for ties with mainland China, Chen said the overall approach was spelled out in his May 20 inaugural address and his administration will do everything it can to resume dialogue with Beijing.

Meanwhile Chen's national policy adviser, Juan Ming, gave a speech at the meeting to counter Beijing's recent criticism of Shu Wen-lung, founder of Taiwan's Chi Mei Group, for what it calls Shu's support of Taiwan independence.

Juan said Shu's approach of considering the mainland a part of Chi Mei's plan to venture into the global market is much better than the approach of Morris Chang, founder of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., who wants to transfer Taiwan's advanced technology to the mainland.

Juan said Shu's approach is obviously much better for Taiwan and is beneficial to the mainland as well. Direct transportation links with the mainland opened on the basis of Shu's approach would benefit both Taiwan and the mainland, he said.

He also defended Chen's decision to seek Washington's opinion in advance on the parts of his inaugural address concerning the mainland, claiming that Taiwan's ties with the mainland are not a domestic issue but an international issue, so it is only natural for Chen to consult Washington.
Beijing, for the same reason, told Washington in advance about its May 17 lambasting of Chen, according to Juan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GOVERNMENTS URGED TO HEIGHTEN TYPHOON ALERT

TEXT.P: Minister of Interior Su Jia-chyuan inspected the central disaster prevention center Tuesday and called on county and city government chiefs to strengthen preparations against approaching Typhoon Conson.
The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for Typhoon Conson at around noon Tuesday.
The typhoon, located about 230 km south-southwest of Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, at 8: 30 p.m., was moving in a north-northeasterly direction at a speed of 11 kph, the CWB reported.
The land warning involves Hengchun, Pingtung, Taitung, Orchid Island, Kaohsiung, Tainan and Green Island.
The Ministry of National Defense also set up a special task force to cope with any possible emergencies deriving from the typhoon -- the fourth typhoon of the year in the Pacific area.
Disaster prevention centers have also been established in various cities and counties around the island.
In addition to pushing for government preparations, Su also urged the public not to climb mountains or swim in the sea and to park their cars on high ground to prevent possible water damage.

Officials of the Ministry of the Interior reminded the public not to visit areas designated as dangerous by the government during natural disasters, pointing out that anyone requiring rescue from such areas will have to foot the bill for the rescue.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PURCHASES MUST CORRESPOND TO REAL NEEDS: LEGISLATURE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday that Taiwan's arms purchases from the United States should correspond to the country's real needs and that the prices of the weapons must be reasonable.

Wang made the remarks after hearing that the Executive Yuan's arms purchase budget plan could not be included on the June 10 agenda of the Legislative Yuan for screening due to differing opinions from the opposition lawmakers.
The Executive Yuan presented a budget plan to the legislature earlier this month worth NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) to buy defense weapons from the United States

At the same time, the United States also extended an invitation to Wang to lead a legislative delegation on a visit to the United States in order to obtain support for the arms procurement plan. The delegation is expected to head for the United States in mid-June.
Wang said it is more suitable that the Legislative Yuan should deal with the issue after he returns from his 10-day visit.

Concerning the prices of the weapons, Wang insisted that they should be similar to international market prices, as there are doubts that the prices offered to Taiwan are much higher than those offered to other countries.
Meanwhile, Wang also expressed the hope that the Cabinet's "Ten Major Construction Plans" program can be approved by the Legislative Yuan before its June 11 recess.
He said he had instructed Legislative Yuan Vice President P.K. Chiang to discuss the issue with the legislative caucus leaders of the ruling and opposition parties to first reach a consensus.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPERT WARNS WASHINGTON AGAINST FAVORING BEIJING HARDLINERS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 8 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Huang Kwang-chun)

TEXT.P: A United States expert on China suggested recently that President George W. Bush's administration should guard against letting the China-Taiwan balance slip in favor of Beijing's hardliners and away from the democratic leaders in Taipei.

John Tkacik, a research fellow at the Heritage Foundation, said in an article in the latest issue of DefenseNews Weekly that a Bush administration tilt toward Beijing hardliners will only reward bad behavior by the militarists, undermine Beijing's moderates, and instruct China's leaders that the way to get American cooperation is with military threats.

He criticized the Bush administration's policy of "strategic ambivalence" on cross-Taiwan Strait issues, which he said leaves both Beijing and Taipei dangerously confused about American goals in East Asia.

Noting that there are moderates in China's leadership, Tkacik cited President Hu Jintao and Premier Wen Jiabao as examples. He said that they focus on China's economic and social problems and probably argue in internal circles that war in the Taiwan Strait would be a disaster for China.

The militarists led by Military Affairs Commission Chairman Jiang Zemin and Vice President Zeng Qinghong, Jiang's man in the Politburo, want to simply talk tough to Taiwan, the China expert pointed out.

Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed in his inaugural speech May 20 that his government "would not exclude any possibility" in seeking a new relationship between Taiwan and China, Tkacik said, adding that the U.S. State Department lauded the speech as constructive.
He shared the U.S. State Department's view that "the ball is firmly in Beijing's court."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER LAMENTS EXPLOSION AT ILLEGAL FIREWORKS FACTORY

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun lamented Tuesday an explosion at an illegal fireworks factory in Chiayi County a day earlier in which six people died and three were wounded, and instructed the relevant agencies to crack down on illegal fireworks factories.
The factory was hidden in an abandoned pig farm in Liuchiao village.
According to Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai, Yu instructed the Ministry of the Interior to crack down on the illegal factories as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNAXIS BEGINS CONSTRUCTION OF LCD PANEL RESEARCH CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Unaxis, a Swiss-based high-tech company, began the construction of an LCD panel research laboratory in the Chunan Science-based Industrial Park in Miaoli County Tuesday.

Once the LCD panel research laboratory and assembly center completed in 2005, the center is expected to directly offer Taiwan's LCD panel manufacturers the equipment and coating technology needed for LCD panels.
This is the largest investment Unaxis has ever made in Asia -- NT$1 billion (US$29.8 million).

Having access to many areas of high technology, Unaxis makes equipment for processing semiconductor wafers, assembling and packaging finished microchips, and applying thin film coatings to LCDs and flat-panel displays, and offers a wide variety of high-tech optical components.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang, Unaxis CEO Heinz Kundert, and several other high-ranking government officials witnessed the ground-breaking ceremony in Miaoli, where officials of Unaxis and the economics ministry also signed a letter of intent to cooperate in developing the coating technology of LCD panels.

Unaxis will also cooperate with nearby high-tech organizations and universities, including the Industrial Technology Research Institute, National Tsinghua University and National Chiao Tung University to develop technology for producing equipment such as PECVDs and PVDs.

Shih noted that since the equipment to produce LCD panels are increasingly bigger, almost beyond what a large truck can carry, it is of tremendous importance that the LCD panels are produced in Taiwan.
The completion of Unaxis's factory in Taiwan in 2005 will make the island's LCD panel industry more robust, Shih added.
Unaxis, with 80 subsidiaries in 25 countries, employs some 6.500 workers around the world. Its investment in Taiwan is expected to create some 200 jobs.

The Swiss company also revealed that after the current center in Taiwan, it plans to enlarge the scale of their investment on the island, focusing on semiconductors and optical products in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SPOONBILL SPECIALISTS STUDY RARE BIRDS IN KOREAN DMZ

TEXT.P: A Taiwan wildlife conservation group entered the demilitarized zone (DMZ) between North and South Korea in late May to watch a natural sanctuary for the endangered migratory black-faced spoonbill, a bird club in Tainan County said Tuesday.

The three-member Taiwan group -- comprised of Prof. Wang Chien-ping from National Cheng Kung University and Wang Cheng-chi and Huang Chun-hsien, two wildlife conservationists from the Tainan County-based Wild Bird Society of Happy Family -- visited the Korean DMZ May 31 to familiarize themselves with the breeding grounds of the rare birds, most of which fly to Taiwan to overwinter and then return to the Mt. Geumgangsan area near the Korean DMZ to breed in spring.
The group became the first Taiwan group to visit the DMZ for bird-watching.

According to Huang, they feasted their eyes on the breathtaking scenery in the DMZ and saw for the first time the breeding grounds of the black-faced spoonbills, which they have watched every year in Taiwan.
Huang said that the visit to the DMZ was part of the International Symposium on Black-faced Spoonbills in North Asia, held in Seoul May 26 - June 4.

Delegates from Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau, Vietnam and host South Korea took part in the symposium co-sponsored by South Korea's ministry of environment and the Korean Federation of Environment Movement, a non-profit environment-conscious body, according to Huang.

During the symposium, said Huang, Korean officials suggested that Taiwan and South Korea sponsor workshops and activities every year for the conservation of black-faced spoonbills, whose population is no more than 1,500 worldwide, mainly in Asia.

Korean officials suggested that South Korea host a black-faced spoonbill conservation month in May every year, while Taiwan sponsor a similar activity in November or December every year, according to Huang.
In addition, according to Huang, National Cheng Kung University has maintained an academic exchange program with Korean University of Education, South Korea, on studies of black-faced spoonbills.

Of all the Asian countries where black-faced spoonbills have regularly visited, the wetlands in the southern Taiwan county of Tainan still boasts the world's largest number of black-faced spoonbills with more than 700 of the rare migratory birds reportedly having arrived there last year to overwinter.

Black-faced spoonbills migrate from North Asia to the warm wetlands in Taiwan and other Asian lower-latitudinal countries between late September and early December every year to spend the winter and avoid their cold northern breeding grounds. The birds then return north around April or May of the following year.

The Tainan wetlands are not just an ideal habitat for black-faced spoonbills alone as there were many other kinds of migratory wild birds overwintering around Tsengwenchi River, and the Chiku and Sitsao areas, making the southern wetlands a haven for Asian migratory feathered species.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDATORY SEPARATION OF GARBAGE TO BEGIN NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will start to promote its "compulsory garbage separation" plan next year in seven cities and will then spread the program to the rest of the cities and counties around Taiwan in 2006, EPA officials said Tuesday.

The officials said that since the administration promoted resource recycling and kitchen waste recycling, the amount of recycled waste has continued to climb and garbage continued to drop over the years.

They said that after Taipei imposed garbage fees by requiring the purchase of special garbage bags, it has achieved the goal of reducing garbage. The compulsory garbage separation program in Keelung, Taichung, Tainan and Kaohsiung have also borne good results.

To achieve the goal of reducing garbage by 25 percent by 2007, the EPA will still divide garbage into three categories: recyclable garbage -- including cans and bottles, kitchen waste and general garbage in the first stage.

In the first stage which begins Jan. 1, 2005, the three kinds of garbage will be collected in the two municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung and the five cities of Keeling, Hsinchu, Taichung, Chiayi and Tainan.
The second stage will begin Jan. 1, 2006 in those villages and townships that have yet to implement the plan to impose garbage collection fees with special garbage bags.

On whether to impose punishment if the public cannot act along with the regulations of the garbage division plan, the officials said that if public support for the garbage division plan is over 70 percent, then the punishment will be the major way to handle such violations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET SPOKESMAN DISMISSES HONG KONG PAPER REPORT

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 8 (CAN) A spokesman for the Executive Yuan on Tuesday dismissed a Hong Kong newspaper report that said mainland China might consider withdrawing its missiles deployed along its southeast coast opposite Taiwan if the United States does not sell advanced weapons to the island.
Chen Chi-mai made the remarks in response to a report by Wen Wei Pao, a pro-Beijing newspaper in Hong Kong.
Chen said that the Cabinet has reminded the public that for a long time, mainland China's military deployment has only increased instead of decreased in quality and quantity against Taiwan.

He noted that Wen Wei Pao's report has not been substantiated by the Beijing authorities and should be considered to be rumor. In addition, the military expenditure by mainland China over the past two years has grown at a double digit rate of between US$50 billion and US$70 billion.
"The quality and quantity have been upgraded, posing a serious threat to the security in the Taiwan Strait," he said.

Chen pointed to Beijing's May 17 statement regarding building military mutual trust between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, as well as the establishment of a peaceful and stable exchange framework, as being the "same language" used by Taiwan about establishing a peaceful and stable exchange mechanism.

Instead of speaking through the media, Chen urged Beijing to create an environment conducive to reducing military expansion, establishing a way to ensure mutual trust and resuming negotiations on cross-strait issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE PASSES RESOLUTION TO SUSPEND SALE OF CHINA STEEL SHARES

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Tuesday passed a resolution demanding that the government suspend the release of shares of the China Steel Corporation and continue to hold at least 20 percent of the shares.

The legislature discussed the proposal by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party. Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng afterwards announced the results.

Since the privatization of China Steel in 1995, the Ministry of Economic Affairs still held 40 percent of the shares, but the ministry started to release its shares since last year, and the ministry - meaning the government -- is still the biggest shareholder with about 23 percent of the shares.
Worried that the government's release of shares could undermine the rights of employees, the company's workers' union staged several rallies in front of the legislature.

After learning of the news, an economics ministry official said that he would respect the decision by the legislature, although the ministry has listed the release of China Steel shares in the budgets of the years between 2000 and 2002, and the budgets have already passed legislative review.

Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long said that the ministry now owns 23.52 percent of China Steel's shares, but that if the corporation had adhered to its earlier sell-off plan it would now only hold 9. 34 percent of the shares. The reason that the economics ministry still has as many shares as it does is because of fluctuations in share prices that made sales occasionally slow.

Chen was pointing out that if not for the slow release of shares due to market forces, the ministry would have fewer shares than what the legislature had just said was an acceptable minimum. He wondered if the ministry ought to continue with the government-approved sell-off or the new instructions to halt at 20 percent.

Chen said that although China Steel has completed privatization, it still shoulders the responsibility of the policy of the nation. He said the sell-off was only slowed by legislators themselves because they had imposed a minimum price for the sale of the shares.
"The urgent task now will be to step up communications with the Legislative Yuan," he said, as well as "set the priority on Tuesday's resolution and the review passed on the budget earlier."
In addition to continuing communications, Chen also said that the ministry will study how many retained shares would best benefit the country.

Meanwhile, officials from the Department of Treasury under the Ministry of Finance said that to retain the nation's financial integrity and for it to conform to established systems, the budgets that passed legislative review should be carried out.

Regarding the claims by some that the suspension of the release of China Steel shares would help prop up its own share prices, the officials said that the government also released China Steel shares last year, but share prices of the corporation continued to climb, showing that the more shares that were offered, the higher the price paid for them.
The share price of China Steel closed at NT$30.6 (US$0.91) on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA OPENS WEB SITE FOR TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The Central News Agency (CNA) launched a new Web site Tuesday that will cater to the needs of Taiwan business people operating in mainland China, commonly known as "taishang."

Addressing the opening ceremony, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu said he looks forward to seeing the new CNA "taishang" Web site serve as a conduit between the government and the business community by offering "taishang" with updated and convenient information services and by helping them increase their understanding of the risks and pitfalls of doing business on the mainland.

Wu said commercial exchanges have become the most important part of cross-Taiwan Strait relations. Cross-strait trade amounted to US$46.3 billion last year. Moreover, unofficial tallies showed that Taiwanese business people have poured more than US$70 billion into mainland China for various investment projects and that there are more than 500,000 "taishang, " their employees and dependents now living in the mainland.

As the mainland economic environment has been changing rapidly and cross-strait interactions have been increasing steadily, Wu said "taishang" face many problems. Before mainland China's legal system becomes healthier and more modernized and cross-strait dialogue is resumed, Wu said providing "taishang" with full and updated information and helping them better understand the risks of investing in the mainland are some of the MAC's most important tasks.

Since April 1996, Wu said, the MAC has joined forces with the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Straits Exchange Foundation and the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) in operating a centralized "taishang service counter" to offer "taishang" needed assistance and services.

In addition, Wu said, the MAC has operated a "taishang trade net" Web site since January 1997. More than one million Internet users have so far browsed the Web site, indicating that "taishang" need "real time" trade information.

Noting that CNA is Taiwan's oldest and largest national news agency, Wu said he is very glad to see CNA inaugurate a new Web site to satisfy "taishang's" need for up-to-the-minute and diversified market information.

Speaking on the same occasion, CNFI Chairman Hou Chen-hsiung said CNA has consistently provided Taiwan business people, including those with businesses in mainland China, with diverse commercial information for the past decades.

"We hope the inauguration of the new CNA "taishang" Web site will provide correct, updated and even more detailed business information to Taiwanese business people operating in mainland China where information remains relatively scant," Hou said.

CNA Chairman Su Tzen-ping said the new CNA Web site is aimed at keeping Taiwan businessmen on the mainland informed of world news, giving them access to air their views and provide them with a platform to exchange opinions.

In addition to breaking news, the Web site will also supply viewers with customized information through columns such as the "Taiwan Businessman's Hall of Fame, " "Speeches by Taiwan Business Experts, " "The Latest News about Taiwan Businessmen, " and "Calendar of Major Events on Both Sides of the Strait."
Meanwhile, the Web site will provide free mobile phone messages to the chiefs of 78 Taiwanese chambers of commerce on the mainland, as well as to other leading Taiwan businessmen there.
During Tuesday's ceremony, Wu, Hou and Wu jointly pressed a button to send out mobile phone messages to leading Taiwan businessmen on the mainland.
