DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 50.94 points to close at 5,986.76.
The bourse opened at 6,004.99 and fluctuated between 6,010.5 and 5,937.73 during trading.

A total of 4.53 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$97.95 billion (US$2.92 billion), an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 3.75 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$78.3 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 2.4 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.7 percent, foodstuff stocks and plastics and chemical shares both at 1 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.8 percent, electrical shares at 0.7 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.6 percent.
Construction stocks, however, fell 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC VICE CHAIRMAN MEETS WITH U.S. THINK TANK SCHOLARS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 7 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san met with noted U.S. think tank scholars in the New York area Monday for wide-ranging talks.

Accompanied by Andrew L. Y. Hsia, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, Chiu met with Dr. Donald Zagoria, director of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy's Project U.S.-China-Taiwan Relations, and representatives from several other think tanks.

Chiu told Taiwan journalists stationed in the New York area after the closed-door meeting that U.S. scholars generally recognized President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 second inaugural address as "constructive" to the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
"Nevertheless, they are more concerned about which concrete measures President Chen will take to break the current cross-strait impasse," Chiu said.

In his view, Chiu said, the U.S. side kept a low profile about cross-strait relations before Taiwan's bitterly fought March 20 presidential election. After the election, Chiu said, the United States now holds positive expectations of seeing a breakthrough in deadlocked cross-strait ties.

Chiu said he has briefed American academics on the ROC government's determination on promoting non-political cross-strait exchanges in cultural, educational, trade and economic fields. As to the much-anticipated opening of direct cross-strait shipping and air links, Chiu said it takes bilateral negotiations to work out viable terms because such direct links involve many complicated security issues.

Chiu arrived in New York last Friday to attend a seminar sponsored by exiled mainland Chinese pro-democracy activists to mark the 15th anniversary of the Tiananmen Massacre. He will travel to Boston to meet with American scholars and Taiwanese expatriates there. He is scheduled to return to Taipei May 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE SURROUNDED BY CIGARETTE ADS

TEXT.P: People in Taiwan are never far away from ads by cigarette manufacturers, a communications professor said Tuesday.

Kuo Liang-wen, director of the Institute of Communication Studies of Chiao Tung University, said at a press conference on media literacy on cigarette ads that cigarette manufacturers are willing to spend big money on advertising and that they are omnipresent in Taiwan, although the average person may not be aware of their presence.

He said that according to figures provided by AC Nielsen, a leading marketing information company, cigarette manufacturers spent more than NT$200 million (US$5.97 million) between January 2003 and March 2004 on ads in 126 domestic and foreign magazines in Taiwan, with the United States and Japanese cigarette brands accounting for the lion's share of the spending.

The Japanese brand Mild Seven Super Lights topped the list at NT$28.84 million during the 15-month period, followed by another Japanese brand Mine at NT$25.06 million. The top nine spenders on ads were all foreign brands, with the Long Life Gentle series from Taiwan's Tobacco & Wine Corp. coming in 10th place with spending of NT$7.92 million during the period.
Meanwhile, a survey on media literacy unveiled Tuesday showed that teenagers received only 70 points in a 100-point score rating.

The Bureau of Health Promotion under the Department of Health unveiled the survey conducted on students from all levels of schools in Taiwan starting from elementary school through to colleges between May 11 and 21.
A total of 4,290 valid samples were collected in the survey, which is said to have a margin of error of plus or minus 1 percentage point.

Huang Tung-yi, associate professor of Shih Hsin University who conducted the survey at the commission of the Bureau of Health Promotion, said that more than 70 percent of the children and teenagers in Taiwan are not aware of the marketing of cigarette manufacturers under the cover of other activities.
When asked if they are aware that cigarette manufactures are actually trying to promote their products through sponsoring such activities as ball games or concerts, most said they aren't.

Those who have a higher education, such as college or university students, are unable to read into cigarette ads that try to lure them for a puff, but unfortunately, their determination to resist the tobacco hazard tends to be the weakest, Huang said.
In terms of channels for cigarette advertising, convenience stores topped the list, followed by the Internet, magazines and advertising boards on roadsides, movies, and newspapers, in that order.
According to the survey, youngsters receive the most anti-smoking messages, from awareness campaigns at their schools.
The survey also found that the trend is that the smoking population is getting younger, with 17 percent of males and 4.1 percent of females aged between 15 and 17 smoking.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB ISSUES LAND WARNING FOR TYPHOON CONSON

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a land warning for Typhoon Conson at around noon Tuesday.

Conson, which developed from a low pressure system in the South China Sea only a day earlier, is expected to affect Taiwan with torrential rains and gusty winds in the following couple of days, CWB meteorologists said.

The tropical storm, with a radius of 150 kilometers and maximum sustained winds of up to 100 kilometers per hour, was centered about 350 km south-southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Hengchun at 11: 30 a.m. Tuesday, moving north-north-easterly toward Taiwan at a speed of 11 kilometers per hour, the CWB reported.
The Hengchun Peninsula is expected to come under Conson's onslaught beginning early Wednesday morning, the CWB meteorologists said.

Boats plying the Bashi Channel or waters near the Tungsha (Pratas) Islands and the southern part of the Taiwan Strait, as well as Taiwan's southeastern offshore areas, should be on high alert against gusty winds and torrential rains to be triggered by Typhoon Concon -- the fourth typhoon of the year in the Pacific area, the CWB said.

People in the Hengchun Peninsula, Orchid Island, Green Island, southern Taiwan and southeastern Taiwan should be on guard against possible torrential rains, floods, and mud and rock slides that may be triggered by the typhoon, the meteorologists said.

They said that between late Wednesday and Thursday noon -- when Typhoon Conson will be about 110 kilometers southwest of Oluanpi -- will be the crucial period for determining whether the typhoon directly hits Taiwan.
Authorities from Kaohsiung Harbor, southern Taiwan, announced a suspension of ferry services between Kaohsiung and Penghu Island in the Taiwan Strait for Tuesday and Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN PRESIDES OVER SWEARING-IN CEREMONY FOR SENIOR OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presided over a swearing-in ceremony for a group of new senior government officials at the Presidential Office Tuesday.

The officials, led by Examination Yuan Vice President Wu Rong-ming, took their oath of office in front of a national flag and a photo of the late national founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen, pledging to dedicate themselves to serving the country and the people without any infraction of the law or dereliction of duty.

At the end of the swearing-in ceremony, Chen shook hands with each official and offered his congratulations and encouragement. They were the second batch of senior government officials to be sworn in since Chen began his second four-year term on May 20.

In addition to Wu Rong-ming, other officials sworn in at the ceremony included Vice Defense Ministers Tsai Ming-hsien and Huo Shou-yeh, Army Commander-in-Chief Chu Kai-sheng, Air Force Commander-in-Chief Liu Kuei-li, Vice Interior Minister Lee Chin-yung, Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau, Vice Finance Minister Lee Jui-chang, Vice Economics Minister Chen Ruei-lung, Vice Justice Minister Hsieh Wen-ting, Vice Labor Affairs Council Chairman Lai Ching-lin, and Wu Chin-fa, vice chairman of the Council for Cultural affairs.

Several senior officials witnessed the swearing-in ceremony, including Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tzeng-chang, Defense Minister Lee Jeyh and National Security Council Secretary-General Chiou I-jen.

DOC.HEADLINE: ""TAIWAN R.O.C."" PROPOSAL NOT RELATED TO CONSTITUTIONAL REFORM

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu's proposal of using "Taiwan Republic of China" as the country's official name has nothing to do with issues related to proposed constitutional reform, a statement by the Public Affairs Office of the Presidential Office said Tuesday.

The statement also said that Lu was not trying to use the proposal to express her stance on constitutional reform since her and President Chen Shui-bian's positions regarding such reform are totally the same.

The statement, which was made under Lu's instruction, was a response to various media reports that have played up the proposal that the vice president made Sunday evening at a gathering organized by Taiwan expatriates in San Francisco.
Lu and her entourage arrived in San Francisco earlier in the day for a stopover on her way back to Taiwan after a 14-day visit to ROC diplomatic allies in Central America.

Lu made the proposal because she feels that the disputes between "the pan-blue alliance" and "the pan-green camp" after the March 20 presidential election and the instability in Taiwan's internal political situation are not due to ethnic divisions, the statement said, adding that the vice president also thinks that the real problem is divergence over historical feelings between those who prefer to identify with the Republic of China and those who prefer to identify with Taiwan.

In order to resolve the dispute and divergence as soon as possible and to further consolidate harmony and unity in Taiwan society, the vice president therefore suggested that both the camps make a concession and call the nation "Taiwan Republic of China," the statement added. By P.C.Tang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 8, or the 21st day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: German composer Robert Alexander Schumann is born. He is known particularly for his song cycles, piano works, and symphonies. A leading romanticist and a noted critic, he encouraged Chopin and influenced Brahms.
1845: Andrew Jackson, the seventh president of the United States, dies at the age of 78. As a general in the war against the British, he defeated British forces at New Orleans in 1815. As president, he opposed the Bank of America and increased presidential powers.
1916: British biologist Sir Francis Crick is born. Along with James D. Watson, he proposed a spiral model -- the double helix -- for the molecular structure of DNA. He shared a 1962 Nobel Prize for advances in the study of genetics.
1928: The National Revolutionary Army, led by commander Chiang Kai-shek, conquers Beijing in its Northern Expedition, formally ending the civil war in China.
1940: The German battle cruisers Scharnhorst and Gneisenau sink the British aircraft carrier Glorious and the destroyers Ardent and Acasta in the Arctic Sea. At least 1,500 men are lost from the three ships.
1941: Israeli military leader and politician Moshe Dayan loses his left eye while serving in the British army when his telescope is shot by French troops under the Vichy regime during World War II. Dayan later directed the 1956 Sinai campaign and the 1967 Six-Day War.
1945: The government of the United States declares that in accordance with the Joint Declaration of the Cairo Conference, Korea is permitted to gain independence.
1948: Yu Yow-renn is nominated the Control Yuan's first president under the new Constitution of the Republic of China.
1969: U.S. President Richard M. Nixon meets the leader of South Vietnam on Midway Island and announces the withdrawal of 25,000 U.S. troops from Vietnam.
1973: Generalissimo Franco hands over Spain's premiership to Luis Carrero Blanco and remains as head of state.
1976: Wu Chien-hsiung and S.S. Chen, members of the ROC's Academia Sinica, win the U.S. National Medal of Science.
1976: The Fifth Sino-American Conference on mainland China opens in Taipei with nearly 100 scholars and experts from both countries participating.
1980: The ROC-Indonesian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1983: Taylor Wang becomes first Chinese-American astronaut.
1987: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hua arrives in Singapore for a five-day visit as the guest of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew. Yu also called on Singapore President Wee Kim Wee and other government officials.
1987: The governor of the ROC's Central Bank of China, Chang Chi-cheng, announces that the ROC's foreign exchange reserves have exceeded US$60 billion.
1995: Lee Teng-hui becomes the first ROC president to visit the United States, angering Beijing.
1996: Mainland China conducts a nuclear test explosion at the remote Lop Nor test site in northwestern Xinjiang Province.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui receives a delegation headed by Burkina Faso National Assembly Speaker Traore Melegue.
2000: Doctors at the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Kaohsiung carry out a successful 12-hour liver transplant operation, giving Wu Feng-ying, 50, a section of liver donated by her son, Lin Yun-ju, 24.
2001: "The Mountain," a political alliance in the spirit of Britain's "Fabian Society," is formed by a dozen founding members, including two chairmen of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and a former justice minister. The Fabian Society, a society formed by British intellectuals in the late 19th century, exerted an important influence over the government of the time.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men who, when they see what is good and honest, try to act up to it, and when they see what is bad and dishonest try to avoid it as if avoiding scalding water: Such men I have known and the expressions of such principle I have heard." "But men who live in retirement in order to study their aims and who practice righteousness in order to carry out their principles: The expression of such principles I have heard, but I have not seen such men."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REITERATES ITS SUPPORT FOR DOHA ROUND TRADE TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 8 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's chief delegate to the World Trade Organization (WTO) on Monday reiterated the island's stance in support of the Doha Round trade talks.

Yen Ching-chang, the ROC's permanent representative to the WTO, voiced Taiwan's support for the talks at a private meeting with Shotaro Oshima, chairman of the WTO General Council, the decision-making body of the organization.

During the meeting, Oshima, also Japanese ambassador to the global trade regulatory body, briefed Yen on the planned mechanism of the "July Package" that tries to push WTO members to make efforts to reach agreement by July on the key issues that will provide a clear way forward for the stalled Doha Round trade negotiations. He also asked Yen about Taiwan's stance on the new round of trade talks.

The Doha Round trade talks are at a turning point, and the question of whether the WTO's 142 member states will reach an agreement related to the "July Package" mechanism by the end of next month is crucial to the development of the talks.

Talking about the nine-point mechanism of the "July Package," the ambassador said that he hopes to know Taiwan's viewpoint regarding certain WTO members' stance in support of first talking only on the trade facilitation issue of the so-called "Singapore Issues" and not putting the rest of the issues -- namely investment, transparency in government procurement, and competition policy -- on the agenda of the new round trade negotiations.

In response to Oshima's request, Yen said that he had made a report to President Chen Shui-bian as well as other high-ranking officials of the Executive Yuan and Legislative Yuan regarding the development of the Doha Round trade talks during his recent consultation trip to Taiwan and reiterated the ROC's government's support for the trade talks.
He also said that the smooth passage of the "July Package" is very important to the future progress of the trade talks.

Emphasizing Taiwan's support for the mechanism of the "July Package" in principle, Yen however expressed the hope that the WTO member states will not repeat the mistakes they made at the WTO ministerial meeting held last year in Cancun, Mexico.

Those talks collapsed after a dispute between developing and industrialized states over richer states' farming subsidies and tariffs imposed on agricultural imports from developing countries as well as differences related to the "Singapore Issues".

Taiwan is in favor of holding only talks on the trade facilitation topics of the "Singapore Issues" since such talks could facilitate quicker customs clearance procedures and reduce customs clearance costs, Yen said, adding that the island also suggests that the other issues contained in the "Singapore Issues" should also be included in the agenda of the Doha Round trade talks without being discussed by the WTO members at the present time.

He noted that if the WTO members are unable to reach a consensus on what order the issues contained in the "Singapore Issues" should be tackled, then he is not optimistic about the future development of the new round of trade talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSON SHIFTS DIRECTION SLIGHTLY, POSING LESS THREAT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Conson, whose outer edge reached Hengchun Pennisula in the southernmost part of Taiwan early Wednesday morning, had shifted direction slightly eastward as of noon Wednesday, therefore posing less of a direct threat to the island, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported.

Although Typhoon Conson is not likely to make landfall in Taiwan, the weather bureau still warned people on the island to be on high alert against gusty winds and torrential rains that could be triggered by the storm.

Conson, with a radius of 150 kilometers and maximum sustained winds of up to 120 kilometers per hour, was centered about 60 kilometers south-southeast of Orchid Island located off southeast Taiwan at 11 a.m. Wednesday, moving northeastward at a speed of 17-15 kilometers per hour, the CWB reported.

With the typhoon's course shifting slightly eastward and its speed reducing, Conson's outer edge is expected to move off Taiwan by nightfall as the typhoon sweeps through the ocean corridor to Taiwan's east, CWB meteorologists said.

Despite this good news, the bureau has expanded the area for its land warning against gusty winds and torrential rains, from the Bashi Channel, the Tungsha (Pratas) Islands, Taiwan's southeastern offshore areas, including Orchid Island and Green Island, to the south, southeastern, eastern and northeastern parts of Taiwan, until late Thursday.

Residents in these areas should particularly be on guard against possible flash-floods and mud or rock slides that could be triggered by the typhoon, the meteorologists said, adding that people in low-lying areas should also be on watch against sudden inundations of sea water.
The typhoon has partially disrupted highway traffic as well as air and sea transportation in south and southeastern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO MAKE SUITABLE CONSTITUTION FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Wednesday to make a suitable, feasible and updated constitution for Taiwan in the coming four years.

Speaking at a dinner party he hosted to entertain lawyers representing the ruling Democratic Progressive Party in the presidential election vote re-count in northern Taiwan, Chen said that constitutional reform is one of the most important tasks to be undertaken during his second four-year term.
"We need a suitable, feasible and updated constitution, " Chen said.
However, Chen said that there exist different views and expectations on how to achieve this goal.

The existing Republic of China Constitution poses a certain restriction on constitutional reform, Chen noted, adding that it is necessary to make a breakthrough while taking current realities into consideration.

Chen did not elaborate on the content of the constitutional reform. Nevertheless, he said in his May 20 inaugural speech that there are many problems in the nation's current Constitution that need to be tackled, among which the more immediate and obvious include whether to have a three-branch or five-branch separation of power, whether to adopt a presidential or parliamentary system of government, whether the president should be elected by a relative majority or an absolute majority, reform of the national legislature and relevant articles, the role of the National Assembly and its retainment versus abolishment, and whether to suspend or abolish the provincial government.

He also noted in the speech that it is not appropriate to include the issues of sovereignty, territory and the subject of Taiwan's independence or unification with mainland China in the scope of his proposed constitutional reform.
During the campaign for his re-election, Chen promised that a new constitution would be written and vetted through a referendum by 2006 and then put into effect in 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER IN MANILA FOR APEC MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 9 (CNA) (By Emerson Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long arrived in Manila Wednesday to attend a ministerial- level meeting on energy of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum that will open Thursday.

Chen and 13 officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Taiwan Power Company, Chinese Petroleum Corp. and the Industrial Technology Research Institute were greeted warmly at the airport by officials of the Republic of China representative office based in Manila.

According to Chen, the delegates from Taiwan are prepared to voice their viewpoints and proposals in the meeting designed to seek both long-term and short-term ways to secure energy sources and supplies amidst rising oil prices in the international market.

While in Manila, they will also hold two-way talks with their counterparts from Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines and Japan to exchange opinions on a wide variety of cooperative ventures related to consumption, and shared exploration for energy, he added.

The Asia-Pacific region, with a population of 2.4 billion, consumes 60 percent of the world's energy but only generates 40 percent of the world's total, he said, adding that how to secure constant energy development and supply has become one of the top priorities for countries in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: Adoring Public Says Goodbye.
Under mournful skies, a motorcade carried former President Reagan along miles of cleared freeways from a Santa Monica funeral home to his presidential library near Simi Valley, the first step in a weeklong journey to the nation 's Capitol and back.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT SETS GOOD MODEL FOR TRANSIT STOP IN U.S.: AIT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 8 (CNA) (By S. J. Tsai and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Annette Lu has set a good model for future transit stops by senior Taiwan leaders in the United States, a spokesman for the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) said Tuesday.
Lu arrived in San Francisco Sunday for a four-day transit stop on her way back to Taipei after a three-leg diplomatic tour that took her to El Salvador, Costa Rica and Guatemala.

During her stay in San Francisco, many influential U.S. politicians, including House Democratic Party Leader Nancy Pelosi, telephoned Lu to express their welcome for Lu's visit and congratulate her on her re-election.

California Lieutenant Governor Cruz Bustamante also hosted a reception at California's noted Napa winery in Lu's honor. Many Californian political figures and social celebrities attended the reception to welcome Lu.
The U.S. authorities also unprecedentedly allowed Lu to issue a public statement mourning the late U.S. President Ronald Reagan, who died Saturday at the age of 93.

Lu visited the University of California at Berkley and Stanford University Monday. Lu held closed-door meetings with scholars at the two universities versed in China and Taiwan affairs. They exchanged views on Taiwan-U.S.-mainland China relations.
Lu also attended a Taiwan-U.S. high-tech seminar aimed at attracting U.S. high-tech firms to invest in Taiwan.

Lu left Taipei May 28 at the head of a large entourage to attend the presidential inauguration in El Salvador on behalf of President Chen Shui-bian. En route to El Salvador, she made a high-profile transit stop in Las Vegas.
Lu said during her three-leg Central American diplomatic tour and transit stops in the two U.S. cities, she received the highest-level reception, which glorifies Taiwan's national dignity.
Lu and her entourage left San Francisco Wednesday and is scheduled to arrive at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport early Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO MAINTAIN CROSS-STRAIT STABILITY WITH WISDOM

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he will improve cross-Taiwan Strait relations and maintain regional stability with wisdom, patience and perseverance.

Chen made the remarks at a dinner hosted by him in honor of hundreds of attorneys who volunteered their services in helping re-count votes cast in the March 20 presidential election in northern Taiwan constituencies.

Chen said it's no easy task to break the current cross-strait impasse. Even though Chen has again extended an olive branch and softened his tone on Taiwan's constitutional reform plans in his May 20 inauguration address, Beijing has still declined to make any goodwill response.

"We know Beijing will not be satisfied unless we yield to its 'one China' and 'one country, two systems' unification terms. But those conditions are unacceptable to us. Nevertheless, we should not be daunted by any difficulties or challenges that lie ahead. We must overcome all obstacles with wisdom, patience and perseverance. We should make every possible effort to improve cross-strait ties and maintain peace in the region," he added.

Chen won re-election by a slim margin. His sole challenger, opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan, declined to concede defeat and has filed two lawsuits to nullify Chen's re-election victory and even the entire election so that a new one can be held.

With Chen's consent, all of the 13 million ballots cast in the bitterly fought election have been retallied. The Taiwan High Court is expected to mete out a final ruling in six months. No solid evidence has so far been found in the re-count and a thorough scrutiny of voter rosters to back up the opposition camp's claims that the election was rigged has been undertaken.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FAMILIES WEALTHIER: CITIBANK GROUP

TEXT.P: The assets and wealth of Taiwan families have steadily increased over the past 10 years, with the total swelling to US$809 billion at the end of 2003, according to a report released Wednesday by the Citibank Group.
The figure marks a 10-year high and 2.6-fold of the level of Taiwan's gross domestic product, a Citibank Taiwan executive said.

Taiwan families still prefer to hold cash and deposits in banks as their major means of financial management, which account for 54 percent of their wealth, he said, adding that some 16 percent and 15.2 percent of their wealth is invested in stock markets and used for buying insurance, respectively.
At the same time, Taiwan families spend 10.9 percent of their economic means to purchase mutual funds, a relatively high ratio as compared to that in other Asian countries, he pointed out.

Although the Taiwan people have increasingly become accustomed to having professional managers handle their assets and wealth, he claimed that the 28 percent figure still lags the United States' 54 percent, he noted.

Financial assets possessed by families in the four Asian "little dragon" countries have steadily increased by more than 8 percent each year over the past decade, an executive of the group in charge of investment affairs in the Asia-Pacific region said.

Asian families now spend an average 48 percent of their economic resources in investment, the same level of 10 years ago and a marked difference compared to the United States' 82 percent, he said, adding that most Asians, like the Taiwan people, prefer to hold cash as their top option for financial management.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES NATIONAL LAND PLANNING BILL

TEXT.P: The Cabinet approved a draft bill on national land development planning which, if enacted, would provide a legal basis for harsh punishment on those who begin land development projects without prior government permission.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun said at a weekly Cabinet meeting that the enactment of a national land development planning bill is long overdue.

"Our neighbors, such as Japan and South Korea, have long ago enacted national land development planning bills to ensure orderly land development, " Yu said, adding that the Cabinet has decided to prioritize natural ecology conservation in order to achieve sustainable economic development.
The bill will soon be referred to the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan for deliberation and approval, Yu said.
According to the draft bill, the nation's land will be zoned into three areas in terms their functions, namely conservation areas, agricultural development areas and urban/township development areas.

Under the new bill, those who launch land development projects in the three functional areas without prior permissions from relevant government agencies may be fined between NT$1 million and NT$5 million. If the violations are very serious, those involved in the project may face a maximum five-year prison term plus a fine of up to NT$10 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 47 CANDIDATES REGISTERED FOR KAOHSIUNG CITY COUNCIL BY-ELECTION

TEXT.P: A total of 47 candidates were registered to participate in the by-election of the Kaohsiung City Council slated for July 17 when the registration deadline expired Wednesday, according to the Kaohsiung City Election Commission.
The registered candidates will vie for 18 seats left vacant in the 44-member city council, officials of the election commission said.

The Kaohsiung City Election Commission was forced to call the by-election because 18 councilmen have left their posts since last year, some of whom were stripped of their councilman qualification after being found guilty of accepting bribes and others quit from their posts to take part in this December's legislative elections.
The disqualified city councilmen were involved in the bribery case in which former council speaker Chu An-hsiung offered NT$5 million (US$149.000) cash to each of them to be elected.

Chu himself was also convicted of buying his way into the city council and was sentenced to 22 months in prison, while his role in the vote-buying scandal of the council speakership election is pending for trial.
However, Chu has become a fugitive after failing to report to the court to serve his 22-month sentence and was stripped of his post too.
According to the regulations governing local elections, if three-tenths of the 44 seats, or 14 members, of the Kaohsiung City Council are vacant, a by-election is mandatory.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE FORMER BANK OF TAIWAN MANAGERS IN TOKYO BRANCH IMPEACHED

TEXT.P: The Control Yuan, the nation's supreme watchdog body, decided Wednesday to impeach three former senior staff members at the Tokyo branch of the state-owned Bank of Taiwan (BOT) due to the branch's violations of Japanese financial regulations.

The Control Yuan said Lin Hsin-hung, a former manager at the BOT's Tokyo branch, Peng Meng-hung, a former deputy manager at the branch, and Wu Hung-teh, a former section chief at the branch should be held responsible for Japan's slapping of a 350 million yen (US$3.18 million) fine on the BOT's Tokyo branch late last year.

According to the Control Yuan impeachment notice, Japanese financial authorities discovered in May 2003 that the BOT Tokyo branch had illegally listed non-OBU (official banking units) accounts as OBU accounts for five years. Worse still, Japanese financial authorities found that the BOT Tokyo branch had on several occasions violated Japan's interest income tax regulations for OBU deposits.

Japanese authorities have since put the BOT Tokyo branch on its "priority watch list" to be subject to stringent inspection. They also ordered the BOT branch to improve its operations. If the branch fails to correct its flaws, Japanese authorities said they may revoke the BOT Tokyo branch's license.

DOC.HEADLINE: Q1 OUTPUT VALUE OF LCD INDUSTRY JUMPS: ITRI

TEXT.P: The first quarter production value of Taiwan's LCD industry jumped by 115.3 percent from a year ago to NT$171.32 billion (US$5.13 billion) this year, an official with the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) reported Wednesday.

The figure was made up of NT$128.68 billion generated by LCDs themselves and NT$42.65 billion from related businesses that provide key parts and components, up by 21.7 percent and 36.3 percent, respectively, from the previous quarter, the official said at a news conference.
The official attributed the growth to the increasing global popularity of digital home appliances that include LCD TVs, cell phones and PDAs.

Taiwan-made large TFT LCD goods now enjoy a 40.2 percent share in the world market as of the end of March this year, up by 25.5 percent compared to the ratio posted for the fourth quarter of last year. Locally produced small TFT LCD products account for just 5.9 percent in the global market at present, registering a quarterly increase of 83.4 percent.

At the same time, Taiwan also has outperformed Japan and South Korea to emerge as the world's leading manufacturer of LEDs, with its Q1 output value moving up by 27.9 percent from the previous three- month period to NT$760 million.

It is expected that the annual output value of large TFT LCD products will amount to NT$450 billion for the whole of 2004, an estimated growth of 70 percent over the 2003 level, the official elaborated.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE SPEAKER TO HEAD DELEGATION TO U.S. FOR ARMS DISCUSSIONS

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will head a delegation of lawmakers from across the political spectrum to visit the United States next week to discuss budget issues regarding Taiwan's new arms procurement plans, legislative sources said Wednesday.

The Wang-led mission will leave Taipei June 17 for Hawaii where Taiwan lawmakers from ruling and opposition parties will exchange views with senior officials at the U.S. Pacific Command on Taiwan's defense needs.

The delegation is scheduled to arrive in Washington, D.C. June 20. The lawmakers will meet with officials from the U.S. Department of State and Department of Defense on June 21. The group will visit major U.S. military facilities June 22.
The mission will fly to Texas June 23 to tour major U.S. military bases before leaving for home on June 26.

This is the second consecutive year that the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, has invited Taiwan lawmakers to visit the United States to lobby their support for the President Chen Shui-bian administration's budget proposal for new arms procurement projects.
The Cabinet has approved a special military budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the purchase of advanced weaponry from the United States amid mounting mainland Chinese military threats.

The draft budget calls for the procurement of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992.
The special budget bill is now pending approval of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Security Council, in a 15-0 vote, backs measure on Iraq turnover.
The Security Council voted unanimously on Tuesday in favor of an American and British resolution to end the formal occupation of Iraq on June 30 and transfer " full sovereignty" to an interim Iraqi government.
The Wall Street Journal: U.N. Security Council approves President Bush's Iraq resolution.
United Nations Security Council has endorsed a U.S.-sponsored resolution on restoring that country' s sovereignty. The 15-member U.N. Security Council yesterday unanimously approved the fifth version of a resolution.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOLK AND COSTUME CARNIVAL SHOWCASING MANY NATIONS TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A folk carnival representing many nations' traditional dances and music will be held in Taipei this Sunday June 13 as part of celebrations for Taiwan's 2004 Year of Tourism, the Association of Tour Managers of the Republic of China announced Wednesday.
The carnival, to be held in the Chungshan Hall square in downtown Taipei between 1:45 p.m. and 5 p.m. Sunday, will feature displays and demonstration of various countries.

Association officials said that there will be music and dance performances by participants in traditional outfits representing Malaysia, South Africa, Australia, Hong Kong, Hawaii, Palau, New Zealand, Indonesia, Russia, the United States, Germany, Sweden, Austria, the Philippines, Indonesia, Brunei, Thailand, Costa Rica, Oman and Taiwan's aboriginal people.
The sponsors, which include the Council for Hakka Affairs and the Tourism Committee of Taipei City, will also offer prizes and air tickets to lucky winners in a draw.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONDOLENCE BOOK AVAILABLE AT AIT CULTURAL CENTER FOR REAGAN

TEXT.P: A condolence book will be available at the American Cultural Center for signing in memory of the late U.S. President Ronald Reagan, the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced Wednesday.

The center, located at the International Trade Building on Keelung Road in Taipei, will be open from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. June 10 and June 14 for those who wish to sign the condolence book, the AIT said in a news release.

The center will be closed Friday, June 11, which the U.S. government has declared as a national day of mourning, said the AIT, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Reagan, 93, died last Saturday at his home in Simi Valley, California following a 10-year battle with Alzheimer's disease. According to foreign wire service reports, tens of thousands of Americans paid non-stop personal tributes Tuesday to the popular, infectiously optimistic late president, queuing for up to seven hours for a chance to file past his coffin ahead of a state funeral on Friday.

The flood of people overwhelmed staff at the Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, which stayed open throughout the night to allow the snaking lines of admirers to bid farewell to the 1980s "Cold War Warrior," the reports said, adding that more than 70,000 people were expected to pass the coffin after the viewing hours were extended by four hours Tuesday when the line of well-wishers reached a length of around 1.6 kilometers (one mile).

DOC.HEADLINE: LAND WARNINGS FOR TYPHOON CONSON LIFTED

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau lifted land warnings for Typhoon Conson at 5:30 p.m. Wednesday.

Weathermen said the typhoon has left the Taiwan area and was located at sea 190 kilograms north of Orchid island as of 5 p.m. and was moving at a speed of 30 kilometers an hour in a northeasterly direction.

They noted that the Bahsi Channel and the seas off southeast, northeast and northern Taiwan are still under the sphere of the fourth typhoon formed in the Pacific this year. The weathermen are expected to lift sea warnings Wednesday night at the earliest.
The typhoon has brought ample rain to northeastern Taiwan, the weathermen said, adding that Tungshan in Ilan had 228 millimeters as of 5:30 p.m. and Lotung 200 millimeters.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT EXPECTS TO NOMINATE 62-68 CANDIDATES FOR LEGISLATIVE ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The main opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has decided to nominate between 62 and 68 candidates for the legislative elections slated to take place in December, a KMT official said Wednesday.

Liao Fung-te, head of the KMT's Department of Organization Development, made the announcement after the proposal was approved during the weekly meeting of the party's policy-making Central Standing Committee.

However, the number does not include those for the constituencies of Penghu, Hualien, Kinmen and Lienchiang counties, Liao said, adding that KMT Vice Chairman Wang Jin-pyng, who is also speaker of the Legislative Yuan, has instructed party officials to coordinate the issue with the opposition People First Party (PFP) and the New Party (NP).

Once the exact nomination number has been fixed, the KMT will immediately begin making arrangements for party's primaries that will be decided by a composite outcome of a public opinion survey, from July 3-16, and a party member vote July 18.

The opposition "pan-blue alliance" has reached consensus to impose a quota for nominations for the year-end legislative polls in a joint effort to maintain control of the legislature so as to form an effective method of checks and balances for the administration led by President Chen Shui-bian of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The KMT, PFP and NP formed the "pan-blue alliance" to compete against the "pan-green camp" composed of the DPP and the Taiwan Solidarity Union in the March 20 presidential election, in which KMT Chairman Lien Chan was defeated by Chen.

Chen narrowly won the election, which has been described as "unfair" and "fraudulent" by the opposition due to a series of incidents, including an abortive election-eve assassination attempt on Chen that prompted the activation of the so-called "national security mechanism" by the government that the opposition believes prevented "tens of thousands of military and police personnel" from casting their ballots.
Lien has filed two lawsuits to get a vote recount and a new election. The recount has been completed and a final verdict by the Taiwan High Court is due in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA SELLS TZONGTZE ON INTERNET

TEXT.P: With the Dragon Boat Festival approaching and people keen to eat traditional tzongtze (rice dumplings) to celebrate the day, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is offering a number of regional tzongtze variations on the Internet.

The Web site -- http: //www.mymarket.com.tw -- features 40 well-known tzongtze styles from around 15 traditional markets in Taiwan, including Huchou-style and health-conscious from the old Southgate Market in Taipei, aboriginal style from Taitung, and others from Kaohsiung and Changhua.

Officials from the MOEA's Commerce Department, which is sponsoring the Web site, said that to promote the purchase of tzongtze for the festival, which falls on June 22 this year, they also offer prizes to buyers, including air tickets to Hong Kong with accommodation, as well as digital and traditional cameras.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. WARNING SHOWS NEEDS OF CROSS-STRAIT MILITARY BALANCE: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: The Pentagon's latest warning that mainland China is likely to launch an attack against Taiwan, probably in 2006, underlines the crucial importance of seeking military balance across the Taiwan Strait, a legislator said Wednesday.

Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, a ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) whip at the Legislative Yuan, said the Pentagon warning has strengthened the imperative of accelerating Taiwan's military buildup.

Tsai urged legislators from across the political spectrum to support the passage of a Cabinet-approved special military budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the purchase of advanced weaponry amid the mounting mainland military threat.

The draft budget calls for the procurement of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a fleet of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan's National Defense Committee Wednesday, Vice Minister of National Defense Tsai Ming-hsien quoted the latest Pentagon report as indicating that the mainland threat to the Asia-Pacific and Taiwan Strait security has increased steadily and that the mainland is likely to launch a small-scale attack or take some military action against Taiwan in the near future, either in 2006 or 2008.

As the United States has extensive intelligence concerning the mainland's military strength, Tsai said, the Pentagon forecast was based on its evaluation of the mainland's increasing air and naval superiority over Taiwan.

Tsai said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has formulated various response measures to cope with new developments. Nevertheless, he went on, self-defense and establishing an elite deterrent force remain the MND's top military buildup goals.

According to the U.S. weekly "DefenseNews, " the U.S. Department of Defense furnished Congress with a 54-page mainland military strength evaluation report May 28 that said the mainland's military modernization is gradually eroding Taiwan's air superiority and other advantages and that the cross-Taiwan Strait military balance is steadily tilting in favor of the mainland.

Also commenting on the Pentagon report, DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung, one of the members of the legislative National Defense Committee, said the Pentagon report is a professional assessment from a purely military rather than political perspective.

Echoing the report, Lee said the increasing imbalance in combat power across the Taiwan Strait and the erosion of Taiwan's military capabilities will ignite a mainland attempt to launch an attack against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CUSTOM OFFICIALS SEIZE BETEL NUTS SMUGGLED FROM THAILAND

TEXT.P: Taipei Custom officials reported Wednesday that they had intercepted 3,775 kg of smuggled betel nuts that arrived from Thailand at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
Custom officials said that the betel nuts arrived at the airport disguised as a shipment of cotton fiber Tuesday night on a China Airlines plane and were sent to a warehouse for re-export.

The officials said they believe the sender might try to switch the betel nuts with old electronic pianos at the airport and added that they were trying to trace the sender, in addition to seizing the betel nuts.
They said that as the supply of local betel nuts has been unable to meet demand recently, smuggling the nuts from Thailand is seen as a lucrative option.

The officials noted that betel nuts can be imported legally from Thailand, but a quota system is in place whereby taxes are small for a certain amount of betel nuts and much higher -- NT$810 (US$24) per kilogram -- over this limit.
It was the second time in a week that customs officials had seized smuggled betel nuts from Thailand. Customs officials seized 765 kg last Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT PITCHES FOR CULTIVATION OF NEW DIPLOMATIC STAFF

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan Wednesday to pass organic rules for a new diplomacy research institute as early as possible so that Taiwan can train more new-style diplomatic personnel.
Chen made the remarks at the inauguration ceremony for a new building for the Foreign Service Institute under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Noting that upgrading the Foreign Service Institute (FSI) to a full-fledged diplomacy research institute was one of his diplomatic policy initiatives during his first presidential campaign back in 2000, Chen said his administration presented a draft bill on the organization of the new diplomacy institute to the legislature for deliberation and approval in March 2001.
Chen said that although the draft bill has yet to clear the legislative floor, he is still glad to see the completion of the new FSI building.

Despite Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, Chen said, the Republic of China has not absented itself from the global war on terrorism and nearly all major international humanitarian aid projects.

"We must make every possible effort and use innovative thinking to break the Beijing-imposed diplomatic isolation and play an active and constructive role in the international arena, " Chen said, adding that realizing this goal needs the devoted efforts of all of the nation's diplomatic staff.

Amid the current wave of globalization, Chen went on, traditional diplomatic staff who usually majored in political science or international relations during their college years, need training in new professional fields because international relations now face many new complicated problems, such as economics, environmental protection, public health and immigration.

"In the future, we need many qualified professionals from diverse fields to join the diplomatic corps, including promotion of bilateral or multilateral economic cooperation and international publicity. And this trend further signifies the importance of manpower training and the need to upgrade the FSI into a full-fledged diplomacy institute," Chen said, adding that he hopes the legislature will pass the draft organic bill at the earliest possible date.
In his speech, Chen also stressed that diplomatic work should transcend partisan stances and interests.

"National interests or the common interests of all of the 23 million Taiwan people should be the only consideration in our diplomatic work. There is no room for partisan consideration in the diplomatic domain. We have only one country. All diplomatic staff should work for our national cause, protect our national sovereign status, safeguard our national dignity and secure our 'living space' in the international community," he added.

The FSI now offers training courses for newly recruited diplomatic and consular staff. The proposed new diplomacy institute will even offer advanced study courses for career diplomats and organize research programs to help with diplomatic policy formulation.

Many well-wishers attended the new FSI building inauguration ceremony, including Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan San Chen, as well as members of the diplomatic corps. Douglas Paal, director-general of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, was also present at the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market reported mixed results Wednesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June fell 21 points to close at 5,960, with 25,188 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July rose 18 points to end at 5,933, with 893 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 27 points to end at 5,873, with nine contracts finalized.
December futures fell 155 points to close at 5,866, with three contracts concluded, while next March futures gained 38 points to end at 5,930, with four contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Wednesday at 5,981 for June, 5,915 for July, 5,900 for September, 6,021 for December and 5,892 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, ended mixed.
June TE futures fell two points to close at 241.2, with 3,089 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 2.6 points to end at 239.2, with 103 contracts transacted.
September TE futures rose four points to close at 242.1, with one contract traded, while December TE futures lost 1.5 points to close at 240, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for next March.
June TF futures gained 6.6 points to end at 977.6, with 6,250 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures rose two points to end at 957, with 630 contracts traded.
Next March TF futures fell seven points to close at 970, with two contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 21.06 points to close at 5,965.7.
The bourse opened at 5,972.13 and fluctuated between 6,010.05 and 5,948.93 during trading.

A total of 3.16 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$65.24 billion (US$1.95 billion) , a decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 4.53 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$97.95 billion.

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 0.8 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 0.6 percent, construction stocks at 0.5 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.4 percent, and cement stocks at 0.1 percent.
The other three major stock categories posted gains, with textile issues moving up the most at 1.4 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 0.7 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.3 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 437 to 304, with 218 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL TAX REVENUE IN MAY TOPS NT$258 BILLION

TEXT.P: The national coffers took in NT$258.8 billion (US$7.75 billion) worth of tax revenues in May, an increase of NT$67 billion, or up by 34.9 percent, over the year-earlier level, a Ministry of Finance (MOF) official said Wednesday.

Income tax revenue rose by NT$53.2 billion last month, posting an annual growth rate of 70.5 percent compared to other sources of tax, said Hsu Kuo-chung, head of the MOF's Department of Statistics. He attributed the expansion to delays in collecting some taxes that should have been collected last year.

Corporate tax turnover reached NT$104.5 billion, up by NT$50.4 billion year-on-year, or a 93 percent rise, while composite taxes totaled NT$24.1 billion, up by NT$2.8 billion, or 13.1 percent, over the previous year's level.

In addition, total trading volume on the listed market hit NT$1.88 trillion in May, translating into a daily average of NT$89.579 billion and resulting in stock transaction taxes worth NT$ 7.1 billion, which is up by NT$3.9 billion over the level of a year ago and represents a 122.1 percent growth.

In the January-May period, the national coffers collected taxes amounting to NT$644.2 billion, a jump of NT$137.9 billion over the 2003 level, or a 27.2 percent expansion. The nation's tax income for the first five months accounted for 48.3 percent of the government's annual target for 2004, an improvement from last year's 36.9 percent, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TOBACCO, LIQUOR CORP. CRITICIZED FOR IMPROPER EXPENDITURE

TEXT.P: A legislator of the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) claimed Wednesday that the Taiwan Tobacco and Liquor Corp. (TTLC) incurs improper expenditure of NT$1.2 billion (US$35.82 million) annually.

Legislator Apollo Chen held a press conference at the legislative Yuan together with representatives of the TTLC's labor union in which they urged the company to stop the practice of purchasing tobacco leaves improperly.

Chen noted that the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly Bureau -- the predecessor of the TTLC -- after scrapping its monopoly system in anticipation of the the nation's entry into the World Trade Organization in 2002, terminated its contracts with tobacco growers by compensating them to the tune of NT$1.05 million (US$31,343) per hectare.
The company also commissioned the Council of Agriculture to help the tobacco growers plant other crops.
The union alleged that some of the tobacco growers, after receiving compensation, have continued to grow tobacco and have pressured the company through elected officials to purchase their crops.

This has caused the company to spend NT$900 million on purchasing the tobacco leaves and between NT$300 million and NT$400 million in processing them. In total, the improper spending is NT$1.2 billion annually, which they said has resulted in an imbalance in supply and demand, with tobacco sold cheaply or left to rot.

The union alleged that there are still over 20 million kilograms of tobacco leaves with a market value of NT$7 billion stockpiled in the company's warehouses, which they claimed will not be used up for five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 100,000 PERSONAL BANK CODES FEARED TO HAVE BEEN HACKED

TEXT.P: Over 100,000 personal secret codes of Internet banking clients in Taiwan are feared to have been stolen by hackers from across the Taiwan Strait, leaving the Taiwan public in panic.

Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) officials said Wednesday that a Taiwan man surnamed Chen had been arrested in Hualien City, eastern Taiwan, together with a haul of confidential data, including 45 million bank account numbers and corresponding personal secret codes.
CIB officials urged the public to change their bank codes immediately to avoid losing their money.

CIB investigators found that Chen, 30, has been collaborating with hackers from mainland China since February this year to steal Internet bank codes by planting "shell" or "revised" versions of "Trojan horse" programs into the computer systems of Taiwan's bank institutions that operate Internet banking services.

Using these "shell" versions -- which were provided by the mainland hackers -- Chen managed to gain access to the banking systems as well as many other organizations, even those with three-layer firewalls against invaders and hackers, according to CIB investigators.

Hundreds of thousands of bank account numbers and corresponding personal codes have been exposed to the hackers' download machines, according to CIB investigators, who added that the bank accounts include savings accounts with funds in excess of NT$200 million (US$5.9 million).

The investigators quoted Chen as confessing that after the ring obtained the bank account numbers and codes, the hackers transferred the money to figurehead bank accounts in Taiwan and then drew the cash from mainland ATMs.

Describing this type of Internet crime as "secretive, shapeless, borderless, anonymous and without restrictions of distance, " CIB officials said that the fallout of the latest cross-strait hacking operation has yet to be revealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. CONGRESSMEN SAY FAREWELL TO ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 8 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Several senior members of the U.S. Congress highly praised Tuesday the contributions of Chen Chien-jen, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, to U.S.- Taiwan relations.
Chen will soon retire from his post after around 20 years of service as an ROC diplomat in the United States.

During a reception held by the congress, U.S. Senate Democratic leader Tom Daschle (D-S. Dakota) said that Chen has done a lot for his country and that his performance in strengthening bilateral relations has been affirmed by both Republican and Democratic members of Congress.

Describing Taiwan-U.S. relations as very special, James Leach (R-Iowa), chairman of the subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific of the House of Representatives' Committee on International Relations, said that Chen has an outstanding performance and has made many friends in the United States.

Former senator and Republican presidential candidate Bob Dole also expressed his gratitude for Chen's contributions, saying that the work of him and his colleagues work has improved U.S.-Taiwan relations.
Rep. Tom Lantos (D-Calif) described Chen as one of the most outstanding diplomats in the U.S. capital, while Senator Jay Rockefeller (D-W. Virginia) said he is a reliable person.
Senator Daniel Akaka (D-Hawaii) said Chen has helped the members of Congress to know what they can do for Taiwan, and he praised the envoy as "a soldier for Taiwan."

Former congressman Lester Wolf, who was a strong supporter of the passage of the Taiwan Relations Act, said that Chen has made a great contribution to the two countries in terms of pushing the enactment of the bill.
A total of 20 members from the two houses attended the farewell reception.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON REPORT DOES NOT SUGGEST THREE GORGES DAM TARGETED: MND

TEXT.P: Vice Defense Minister Tsai Ming-hsien said Wednesday that the U.S. Department of Defense has never suggested that Taiwan should aim missiles at mainland China's Three Gorges dam as a way to deter any possible mainland invasion.

Tsai made the remarks at a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Defense Committee, where opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiang Chi-wen asked about Tsai's view on a U.S. media report that the Pentagon has suggested that Taiwan consider aiming missiles at certain large mainland infrastructure projects, such as the Three Gorges dam, with a view to deterring any possible mainland attack.

The U.S. weekly "DefenseNews" reported in its latest issue that the Pentagon furnished Congress with a 54-page mainland military strength evaluation report May 28 that said the mainland's military modernization is gradually eroding Taiwan's air superiority and other advantages and that the cross-Taiwan Strait military balance is steadily tilting in favor of the mainland. Against this backdrop, the weekly said, the Pentagon came up with the "targeting the Three Gorges dam" proposal.
Tsai told lawmakers that the U.S. weekly report is incorrect and that the Pentagon report made no such suggestion.

According to Tsai, the Pentagon report mentioned that the mainland threat to the Asia-Pacific and Taiwan Strait security has increased steadily and that the mainland is likely to launch a small-scale attack or take some military action against Taiwan in the near future, either in 2006 or 2008.

As the United States has extensive intelligence concerning the mainland's military strength, Tsai said, the Pentagon forecast was based on its evaluation of the mainland's increasing air and naval superiority over Taiwan.

Tsai said the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has formulated various response measures to cope with new developments. Nevertheless, he went on, self-defense and establishing an elite deterrent force remain the MND's top military build-up goals.

"We'll never take any action to provoke China. We'll adopt appropriate countermeasures only after China launches the first strike against Taiwan," Tsai said, adding that Taiwan's armed forces will launch counterattacks primarily on mainland military facilities or the base from where a first strike against Taiwan is launched. In any event, Tsai said, the Three Gorges dam is not Taiwan's target.
The Cabinet has approved a special military budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the purchase of advanced weaponry amid the mounting mainland military threat.

The draft budget calls for the procurement of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a fleet of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992.

Foreign Affairs Minister Tan San Chen said earlier in the day he thinks the large military procurement plan can to some extent serve as a bargaining chip or diplomatic clout for Taiwan in promoting substantive relations with the United States.

Tsai's comments on the Pentagon report drew mixed reactions from legislators of different political stripes. While ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmakers said legislators from the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party (PFP) should support the special arms procurement budget plan in view of ever-mounting mainland military threat, opposition lawmakers said they doubt the correctness of the Pentagon prediction of a "small-scale mainland attack on Taiwan" in 2006 or 2008.

PFP Legislator Chin Hui-chu said she believes that so long as President Chen Shui-bian does not push for the enactment of a new constitution for Taiwan or take other pro-independence moves, Beijing is not likely to attack Taiwan.

KMT Legislator Chiang Chi-wen said if the Pentagon assessment is correct, Taiwan should study the feasibility of pruchasing some offensive weapons from the United States in order to more effectively protect its security.

Chiang's colleague, Lu Hsiu-yen, said the MND should not quote the Pentagon report to intimidate the people of Taiwan and to force the legislature to approve the huge arms procurement budget plan. In her view, it's already too late for Taiwan to propose this 15-year arms procurement plan should the Pentagon prediction is truly correct.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE POSTPONES SCREENING OF ARTIFICIAL REPRODUCTION BILL

TEXT.P: Legislators decided Wednesday to postpone the screening of a draft bill on artificial reproduction after failing to reach any sort of consensus.

Members from the Legislative Yuan Committee of Health, Environment and Social Welfare remained divided mainly over the fact that the draft bill -- authored by Legislator Lai Ching-teh from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and independent Legislator Chiu Chuang-liang -- lacks a corresponding version from the Executive Yuan as an administrative support.
DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung was the most vocal opponent, arguing that the Legislative Yuan should not go ahead with the bill without an Executive Yuan version as a support.

Shen, who claims to be the first lawmaker to initiate legislation on the issue of surrogate motherhood, said there must be reasons why the Department of Health has delayed in producing an Executive Yuan version of the bill dealing with artificial reproduction and related matters.
Shen added that if the Department of Health has doubts about the bill, then the Legislative Yuan should by no means go forward on its own by passing the bill.

Commenting on the Legislative Yuan's decision to postpone screening of the bill, Health Minister Chen Chien-jen said that considering the strong need for legislation on artificial reproduction and related technologies, the Department of Health has been working to delink artificial reproduction from surrogate motherhood and considering to complete an artificial reproduction draft bill first.

On the controversial issue of surrogate motherhood, Chen said a government policy will not be formulated until after National Taiwan University studies the matter and holds meetings to arrive at some sort of public consensus on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 9, or the 22nd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1870: Charles Dickens, British writer known for his tales of Victorian life and times, dies at the age of 59. Immensely popular both then and now, his works include "The Pickwick Papers," "Oliver Twist," and "David Copperfield."
1898: The Ching court signs an agreement with Britain under which Hong Kong is leased to Britain from China for a period of 99 years.
1902: West Point graduates celebrate the 100th anniversary of their alma mater.
1916: Robert McNamara, American industrialist, is born. He was defense secretary during the Vietnam War, and president of the World Bank from 1968 to 1981.
1928: The ROC's Academia Sinica is established with Tsai Yuan-pei as its first president.
1951: The judgment of the Nuremberg court is fulfilled in the United States as the noose slips over the head of the last Nazi condemned by the Nuremberg tribunal to hang for "crimes against humanity." In all, 24 of Hitler's top men were accused on a number of different counts. Twelve men, including Nazis Hermann Goering and Joachim von Ribbentrop, were given the death penalty.
1959: The United States launches the George Washington, the first nuclear submarine with Polaris missiles.
1967: Israel seizes the Golan Heights on the fifth day of war with Syria, Egypt, and Jordan.
1973: Lt. Gen. Richard M. Hoban, vice-commander of the US Air Force Logistics Command, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The Republic of China terminates its diplomatic relations with the Republic of the Philippines as Manila recognizes the mainland Chinese communist regime.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo praises US President Ronald Reagan's call for a campaign to promote democracy and consign communism to the "ash heap of history."
1986: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs agreed to use the name "Chinese Taipei" when participating in the women's World Cup basketball championships in Moscow in August.
1989: In mainland China, show trials of the leaders of the demonstrations in Tienanmen Square begin in Beijing.
1991: Mount Pinatubo, a volcano northwest of Manila that had been dormant for more than 600 years, erupts and forces the evacuation of US troops from their airbase nearby.
1995: ROC President Lee Teng-hui delivers a speech titled "Always in My Heart," at his alma mater, Cornell University.
1996: Thailand celebrates the 50th anniversary of the coronation of King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
1996: Mainland China releases dissident Ren Wanding after seven years in prison for his role in the 1989 democracy demonstrations.
1999: Premier Vincent Siew appoints Yang Chao-hsiang, former vice minister of education and current chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, to succeed Lin Ching-chiang as education minister.
1999: The Macedonian Embassy in the Republic of China is formally inaugurated in Taipei to facilitate bilateral exchanges.
2000: Republic of China Representative to Russia Chang Wen-chung confers a medal upon Oleg Lobov, head of the Moscow-Taipei Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, in recognition of his contributions to Taipei-Moscow relations.
2001: The Board of the Zoological Park Organization of Thailand and the Republic of China's Taipei Zoo signs a memorandum to promote the exchange of animals between the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you do not study poetry, you cannot make yourself agreeable in conversation. If you do not study the arts, you will lack judgment and taste."

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT RETURNS HOME AFTER FRUITFUL TRIP

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu returned to Taiwan Thursday morning after a 14-day official visit to Republic China allies in Central America that included transit stops in the United States on her way to and from the region.

Lu, in a brief statement delivered at CKS International Airport upon her arrival, said that she was accorded the highest level of respect and dignified treatment by all the countries she visited regardless of the presence or absence of official diplomatic ties with the ROC.

During her trip which she termed "fruitful, " the vice president attended the inauguration of Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian, and then visited Costa Rica and Guatemala.

Lu said that she received an honorary doctoral degree from the University of San Carolos in Guatemala and was awarded a human rights medal in Costa Rica, adding that she received a human rights award presented by U.S. Rep. Tom Lantos (D-Calif.) , co-chairman of the Congressional Human Rights Caucus, during her stopover in San Francisco on her way back to Taiwan.
"All this shows that the concerted efforts of the Taiwan people have helped build up the nation's reputation and have won it high recognition from the international community," she said.

Pointing out that although the post-election situation in Taiwan may have left some people feeling uncertain about the future of the nation, Lu said she was "deeply touched" to see the recognition and love shown toward Taiwan by its allies abroad.

The vice president also mentioned that the United States treated her based on the principles of "dignity, safety, convenience and comfort" during her transit stops in Las Vegas and San Francisco. Lu said this made her realize that bilateral relations between the two countries, which she said were strained prior to the March 20 presidential election because of President Chen's insistence on holding a referendum and his advocacy of writing a new constitution for Taiwan and putting it to a referendum by 2006, are now in a good state.

Lu also spoke about her visit to the sites where the U.N. Charter and the San Francisco Peace Treaty were signed, adding that the Fairmont Hotel where she stayed while in San Francisco raised the flags of both the United States and the Republic of China, which she said signified that relations between the two countries will flourish based on the common belief in the universal values of democracy, freedom and human rights.

Those greeting Lu at CKS Airport included Presidential Office Secretary-General Su Tseng-chang, Democratic Progressive Party Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung and Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen. Also present were Burkina Faso Ambassador to the ROC Jacques Sawadogo who concurrently serves as the head of the diplomatic corps in the ROC, Costa Rican Ambassador Oscar Alvarez Araya and Guatemalan Ambassador Manuel Ernesto Galvez.
The vice president, who led a 50-odd entourage on the trip which kicked off May 28, also said that normalizing cross-strait relations is crucial.
She will speak about her trip and her thoughts about cross-strait relations in a press conference Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN AFFAIRS MINISTER SIGNS REAGAN CONDOLENCE BOOK

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Michael Ying-mao Kau represented the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in signing a condolence book at the American Cultural Center Thursday in memory of the late U.S. President Ronald Reagan.
Reagan, 93, died last Saturday at his home in Simi Valley, Calif., after a 10-year battle with Alzheimer's disease.

Judith Mudd-Krijgelmans, spokeswoman for the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, expressed her gratitude to Kau after he signed the condolence book.

Representatives of many other countries stationed in Taipei also showed up at the American Cultural Center to sign the condolence book in memory of the popular, infectiously optimistic late U.S. president.

The center, located at the International Trade Building on Keelung Road in Taipei, will be open from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. June 10 and June 14 for those who wish to sign the condolence book. The center will be closed June 11, which the U.S. government has declared a national day of mourning.

President Chen Shui-bian has appointed Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien to attend Reagan's state funeral in Washington, D.C., on his behalf. ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen will also be a member of Taiwan's special delegation to the Reagan funeral.
