DOC.HEADLINE: AROUND 30 BILLS PENDING IN LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: With one day to go before the recess of the Legislative Yuan Friday, there are still around 30 bills awaiting debate, only a few of which seem likely to be passed on the last day of the session, and both the ruling and opposition camps have asked their lawmakers to attend Friday's session to defend their party's stances.

Among the bills urgently needed by the Executive Yuan is one renewing the existence period of the financial reconstructing fund by one year. As the Executive Yuan has bowed to the opposition parties' demands on some of the issues in the bill, it is likely to be passed Friday.

However, another bill, which stipulates the fundamental organic principles of central government, is surrounded by uncertainty, as the Executive Yuan will not agree with the opposition's demand to give the legislature the power to ratify nominees for the governor of the Central Bank of China and for the chief of a proposed financial supervising committee.
The ruling party is engaged in intense negotiations with the opposition parties on the issue and if no consensus is reached, the whole bill will be put to a showdown vote Friday.
Another bill for a special NT$500 billion (US$14.9 billion) budget for ten major construction projects is also pending last-ditch negotiations between the ruling and opposition parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHIPOWNER WEIGHING DAMAGES CLAIM AGAINST U.S. GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: The owner of a Taiwan fishing boat that was detained by U.S. law enforcement officials for 20 months said in Ilan, eastern Taiwan, Wednesday that she is consulting with her lawyers to see if it is possible to claim damages against the U.S. government.

Lai Hsiu-luang claimed that she lost more than NT$20 million (US$599,975) because her fishing ship, the Kuaile No. 366, was impounded by U.S. law enforcement officials in San Francisco from October 2002 to April 2004.
The losses included NT$900,000 in legal fees during the investigation of the ship, NT$4 million for fuel and supplies during the 20 months and NT$16 million in loss of fishing income.
If it is possible to win a damages claim, Lai said she will not rule out a lawsuit against the United States government.

The Kuaile No. 366 was commandeered by its 10 mainland Chinese crew, who overpowered the ship's Taiwanese captain and first engineer, sailed it into waters near San Francisco and sneaked into the United States.
The ship was then detained by U.S. law enforcement officials under suspicion of carrying Chinese illegal immigrants into the United States.
U.S. prosecutors determined not to indict the captain and first engineer in March, 2004 and released the ship in April.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU URGES GOVERNMENT TO HALT MAINLAND INVESTMENT POLICY

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Chu-wen urged the government Thursday to halt its investment policy toward mainland China amid the increasing political intimidation from Beijing of Taiwanese doing business there.
Huang made the suggestion at a banquet hosted by President Chen Shui-bian at the Presidential Office in honor of TSU lawmakers.

Huang said that the TSU firmly opposes the proposal of "bold westward march" (toward the mainland) and he suggested that Chen readjust his mainland policy of "active opening, efficient management" as a protest against Beijing's intimidation.

Huang's suggestion came after the mainland authorities began to impose stringent policies toward investment from Taiwanese businessmen who Beijing believes are pro-ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and thus supporters of Taiwan independence.

Beijing has never hidden the fact that it does not welcome pro-DPP Taiwanese businessmen with investments on the mainland, accusing them of using profits gained on the mainland to finance the independence movement in Taiwan.
Recently, the Beijing authorities, through its official mouthpiece -- the People's Daily -- named some of these businessmen, among them Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the well-known Chi Mei Group.

According to mainland newspapers, a Chi Mei plant on the mainland was denied loans from local banks and its investment project in Zhejiang Province was halted by China's State Council, although Chi Mei denied this.
Other DPP supporters with investments on the mainland also claimed that they were victims of "political interference" from the mainland authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARP LAWSUIT PLAN SAID TO BE BUSINESS TACTIC

TEXT.P: A planned move by the Japan-based Sharp Corp. against the Taiwan-based TECO Electric & Machinery Co., Ltd. is viewed here as a business tactic arising from fierce competition, a government official said Thursday.

Chen Chao-i, director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, made the comment after a Japanese daily reported that Sharp is planning to file a lawsuit against TECO, which is accused by the Japanese home appliance maker of having infringed upon its intellectual property rights by using TFF-LCDs made by Taiwan-based AU Optronics (AUO) Corp.

According to Chen, bureau officials have contacted the AUO authorities over the issue and have suggested that Sharp's planned court action might just be a business tactic aimed at blocking the fast-growing AUO.

Chen urged Sharp not to seek to put on pressure on its Taiwan competitor through such indirect means, as it will strip Japanese consumers of their right to use cheaper and fine-quality Taiwan-made products.

Four years ago, Sharp lodged lawsuits in Taiwan, Japan and the United States against various Taiwan-based TFT-LCD makers, including AUO, demanding that they pay royalties for infringing upon its technology.
However, AUO claims that its technology is acquired through cooperation with IMB Japan and Fujitom.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW POLITICAL PARTY TO BE ESTABLISHED NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: The planned Non-partisan Solidarity Union (NSU), a new political party initiated by independent legislators, is expected to be formally established next week, according to officials of the party's preparatory committee.
The officials said that a party congress will be held June 15 in Taipei to mark the party's establishment.

The preparatory committee has sent some 600 invitations to political figures and social dignitaries, ranging from President Chen Shui-bian to village chiefs around the nation, inviting them to witness the ceremony, they added.
Former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya is heading the preparatory committee that was established June 7 and is expected to be elected the new party's head.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 AUSTRONESIAN CULTURAL FESTIVAL TO BEGIN IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: The 2004 Austronesian Cultural Festival will begin Aug. 1 in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, Taitung county government officials said Thursday.

Taitung County Magistrate Hsu Ching-yuan noted that the organization of Taitung's Austronesian Cultural Festival has been so successful in previous years that the Ministry of Transportations and Communications has designated it as one of Taiwan's 12 major folk festivals.
This year's festival will be held in conjunction with the harvest rituals of various aboriginal tribes in the Taitung area, focusing on the myths of indigenous people.

The Austronesian race consists of people who speak what linguists call Austronesian languages, whose family reaches from the island of Madagascar off the east coast of Africa to tiny, isolated Easter Island off the west coast of South America, and extending to Taiwan, Vietnam, Northern Australia, New Zealand and most of the Melanesian and Polynesian islands.
Recent research indicates that Taiwan might be the place from where some Austronesian culture originated.

Chen Chien-nien, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Aboriginal Affairs (COAA), expressed the hope that various indigenous tribes in Taitung will take part in the festival by presenting performances, and that local tourism agencies will organize package tours during the 15-day festival to boost Taitung's tourism, adding that the COAA will offer NT$3 million (US$89,550) to help finance the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES LEGISLATIVE BACKING FOR MILITARY PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian asked Thursday for legislative support for a major military procurement program put forward by the Ministry of National Defense (MND) for the sake of the country's long-term defense capabilities, according to lawmakers of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

TSU lawmakers made the revelation following an informal gathering with Chen in which TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen, ranking officials of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) such as DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung and his deputy, Lee Ying-yuan, as well as Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Su Tseng-chang, also took part.

Chen was cited as pointing to the planned purchase of submarines -- the most disputed item on the MND's procurement list -- as an example by calling on the legislature to approve the ministry's budget allocations as soon as possible on the grounds that the administration of U.S. President George W. Bush has been friendly in agreeing to provide the procurement opportunity to Taiwan.

As the procurement of the eight diesel-fueled submarines has been procrastinated over for three years since the Bush Administration gave its permission for the sale, the Legislative Yuan should give a green light as quickly as possible as part of the government's efforts to display its resolve to safeguard Taiwan, the president was quoted as saying.
Since Taiwan is still unable to build submarines on its own, the government remains firm on its decision to buy them from the United States, Chen said, according to the TSU lawmakers.
Chen went on to urge the legislature to cooperate in giving its nod quickly now that the issue also has gained some public support, they said.

Chen also stressed that the price asked by the United States can be discussed, but he added that the budget appropriations must be approved in time so as to secure U.S. willingness to construct the vessels for Taiwan.

The president gave its assurances that the MND's military buildup program spanning the next 15 years will not cause a financial burden on the government and he expressed his hope that the budget allocations will clear the legislature as soon as possible.

The MND called a news conference last Friday to detail their budget allocations worth NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the program in conjunction with the United States amid grave public concern over the huge spending amount.

Top navy brass said that they are intent on purchasing eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C anti-submarine planes, while their army counterparts said that they project to acquire six batteries of Patriotic PAC-3 missiles and relevant facilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN URGES TSU TO SUPPORT ARMS PROCUREMENT BUDGET

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian hosted a luncheon Thursday in honor of senior executives and lawmakers of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU).

The TSU, which advocates a separate Taiwan identity and respects former President Lee Teng-hui as its spiritual leader, controls 12 seats in the Legislative Yuan. It is usually seen as an ally of the Chen's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the Legislative Yuan.

TSU Chairman Huang Chu-wen and Secretary-General Lin Chih-chia led the party's 12 lawmakers to attend the luncheon at the Presidential Office. Su Tzen-chang, President Chen's chief of staff, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung and Deputy Secretary-General Lee Ying-yuan were also present at the occasion.

During the luncheon, Chen first thanked the TSU executives and lawmakers for their support for hie re-election bid. He then asked the TSU legislative caucus to support the Cabinet-proposed NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) budget bill for procurement of advanced weapons from the United States amid mounting mainland Chinese military threats.

The draft budget bill calls for the procurement of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992.
The special budget bill is now pending approval of the opposition "pan-blue alliance"-controlled Legislative Yuan.

TSU Legislators Ho Min-hao quoted Chen as having said during the luncheon that three years have passed since the Bush administration agreed to sell those weapons to Taiwan. As the United States will hold a presidential election in November, Chen said if President George W. Bush fails to win re-election, the U.S. arms sale plans may become uncertain. Against this backdrop, Chen said, he hopes the legislature can pass the budget bill as early as possible so that the Ministry of National Defense can strike deals with the United States.

Chen told TSU lawmakers that there is room for price negotiations for the eight submarines if Taiwan doesn't insist on U.S. technology transfer for Taiwan's state-own China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) to take part in construction of the eight submarines.

According to Chen, the insistence on CSBC participation in submarine construction will increase cost by NT$80 billion. Chen further said Taiwan took the initiative to purchase the submarines in the face of mainland China's mounting military threat. The United States has never pressured Taiwan to buy submarines, Chen was quoted as saying.
Chen also assured TSU lawmakers that the 15-year arms procurement plan will not result in the government's financial straits.

DOC.HEADLINE: WILLIAM JONES CUP BASKETBALL TOURNAMENT TO BEGIN IN JULY

TEXT.P: The William Jones Cup Basketball Invitational Tournament 2004 will begin July 18, with teams from nine countries participating, officials of the Chinese Taipei Basketball Association said Thursday.
The tournament was suspended last year due to the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome.

Sponsored by Mazda Taiwan, the tournament will be held at the stadium of the Taipei Physical Education College, with the participation of 10 male teams and five female teams from Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, Germany, Russia, Canada, Australia and Qatar.

Mazda Taiwan CEO Hu Kai-chang, a basketball enthusiast, noted that basketball is the most popular sport in Taiwan and expressed the hope that the company's sponsorship of the tournament will further increase the popularity of the sport here.
Chinese Taipei Basketball Association Deputy Secretary-general Wang Jen-sheng said he expects more exciting games than in previous years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO LEAVE FOR SEOUL SATURDAY TO ATTEND WORLD FORUM

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou will leave for Seoul Saturday to attend the Asia Strategic Insight Roundtable to be sponsored by the World Economic Forum, a Taipei city government spokesman said Thursday.
According to the spokesman, Ma will take part in two sessions scheduled for Sunday and Monday, with "an Asia outlook" and "dynamic Northeast Asia" as their main themes.
He will also attend a closed-door luncheon to be hosted by South Korean President Roh Moo-jyun at the presidential Blue House Monday, the spokesman said.

Other participants at the roundtable will include Singapore Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Tony Tan Keng Yam, Japanese Finance Minister Heizo Takenaka, Mongolian Foreign Affairs Minister and Senior Adviser to the Prime Minister Luvsangiin Erdenechuluun, the Russian president's economic adviser, Andrei Illarionov, Shanghai Mayor Song Yuanfang and senior executives of noted Asian business groups.

Besides attending the roundtable, Ma will meet with Seoul Mayor Lee Myung-bak and tour major infrastructure construction projects in the city, including a river clean-up project, as well as visit the city's youth service agency and Internet cafe management agency. He will also visit Busan to meet with that city's mayor and visit the main stadium where the 2002 Asian Games were held.

Ma will be accompanied by several city government officials on his South Korean visit, including Environmental Protection Bureau Director Chen Yung-jen and Bureau of Public Works Director Chen Wei-jen. He is scheduled to return Tuesday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70% VEGETARIAN PRODUCTS ADULTERATED WITH ANIMAL PRODUCTS: LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 10 (CAN) A lawmaker of the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union said Thursday that 70 percent of 21 vegetarian products examined by the Department of Health (DOH) were found to contain animal products.

Chen Chien-ming said in a press conference that the DOH should carefully examine all products described as being vegetarian and should impose stiff fines on producers who add animal products to their merchandise.

Chen noted that statistics provided by the DOH show that of the population aged 19-44, one out of every 10 are long-term vegetarians, meaning that the vegetarian population surpasses 2 million in Taiwan.

According to the Food Health Management Law, if food producers produce counterfeit or adulterated products, they will be subject to fines of between NT$40,000 (US$1,193) and NT$200,000. Those who falsely label their products will be subject to fines of up to NT$150,000.
"To protect the rights of vegetarians in Taiwan, the DOH should impose stiff fines," he urged.
He also urged consumers to pay attention when buying vegetarian products.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING SHIP RETURNS AFTER BEING WRONGLY DETAINED IN U.S.

TEXT.P: A Taiwan fishing ship returned to Suao, Ilan, in eastern Taiwan Thursday after being detained in the United States for 20 months because the captain was accused of smuggling mainland Chinese fishermen into the U.S.
Chen Lai-fa and Lin Tsung-hsien, captain and chief engineer of the Suao-registered ship, "kuaile" (Happy) No. 366, were happily reunited with their family members upon their return.
In line with Taiwanese tradition, officials from Suao Fishermen's Association prepared pork feet rice noodles for the two to remove all the bad luck because of the incident.

Recalling the incident, Captain Chen said that the 10 mainland Chinese fishermen first united to have a strike and then put him in the cabin of the ship. Lin was compelled by the mainland fishermen to follow their order to sail toward waters near San Francisco before they snuck into the U.S.

Chen said that he was ready to admit his bad luck and sail the ship back, but the U.S. considered him guilty of smuggling in mainland Chinese fishermen because of past occurrences involving Taiwan fishing boats.
Convinced that he was not guilty, he said he accepted the U.S. investigation, but never thought he would have to stay in the U.S. for 20 months.

During his detainment, he said that he was unfairly treated and subjected to high suspicion by U.S. prosecutors. Thanks to the assistance of the government, he was able to return safely home. The "kuaile" No. 366 sailed out from Nanfangao, Ilan, on Aug. 16, 2002 with the 10 mainland fishermen aboard to operate in the east Pacific and Captain Chen had contacted his family daily. On Oct. 9, 2002, Chen told another Taiwan fishing boat operating in the same Mexico sea that mainland fishermen were striking and afterwards the ship lost contact. The Taiwan government learned from a Keeling-registered fishing boat that the "kuaile" No. 366 had been commandeered by mainland Chinese fishermen in waters near San Francisco, and that the fishermen later used life rafts to sneak off the boat. Chen later broke out of his bindings and repaired the radio to call for help.
Chen followed instruction to sail into San Francisco harbor, but was detained by U.S. prosecutors and his ship was impounded for assisting in the mainland fishermen smuggling operation.

Chen and his first engineer were released after U.S. prosecutors announced that they would forfeit prosecution in March 2004, but they were arrested again by the U.S. immigration and naturalization authorities for illegal entry and turned over to the immigration court, which overturned the charges in April and returned them to the ship.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST-HALF IC INDUSTRY OUTPUT VALUE ESTIMATED TO GROW BY 39 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The output value of Taiwan's IC industry, including the IC design and manufacturing sectors, is estimated to grow to NT$496.4 billion (US$14.9 billion) in the first half of 2004, a spokesman for the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) said Thursday.

Chen Wu-tung, a senior researcher and manager at the ITRI's Industrial Economics and Knowledge Center, said the figure will represent a 39 percent growth over the year-earlier level amid an encouraging economic revival around the world.
Chen made the forecast based on the fact that the domestic industry's first-quarter output value hit NT$240.2 billion, a 42.4 percent expansion year-on-year.

He warned that rising oil prices and the threat of terrorist attacks will remain as big a factor affecting the world's economic development and thus the industry, but pointed out that many Taiwan companies in the industry still hold an optimistic view about the overall outlook.

In terms of the IC design sector, output value in the first six-month period will reach NT$122.1 billion, up by 46.5 percent from a year ago, while in terms of the IC manufacturing sector, output value will hit NT$282.5 billion for the first six-month period, marking an annual growth rate of 37.8 percent. IC foundries are expected to contribute NT$182.7 billion to that value, a 32.2 percent increase.

The packaging and testing sector will also see growth of 28.8 percent and 45 percent, respectively, in their first-half production value, which will amount to NT$67.1 billion and NT$24.7 billion, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 3 MILLION TAIWAN PEOPLE VISIT INTERNET VIA BROADBAND

TEXT.P: According to a report made by the Institute for Information Industry (III), as of the end of March, 8.88 million Taiwan people went online, and among them 3.08 million visited it via broadband.
The III's report was conducted at the commission of the Ministry of Economic Affairs to better understand the growth of Taiwan's Internet users and the types of their connections to the Web.

According to the report, 39 percent of Taiwan's residents frequently used the Internet, with 3.62 million people going online with dial-up connections, and 3.08 million using broadband connections to surf the Internet, which included 2.7 million surfing the Internet via xDSL, and 380,000 through cable modem, with the rest of the Internet surfers connecting to ISDN or academic TANet.
The number of broadband users represented a growth of 180,000 over the fourth quarter of last year, due largely to the increase of xDSL subscribers.
Meanwhile, the number of Internet surfers via dial-up connections fell 360,000, or a 9 percent decline over the fourth quarter of 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRODUCTION VALUE OF AGRICULTURE UNDERESTIMATED: FORMER PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui said Thursday that the production value of the agriculture sector is more significant than many understand and advocated creating a central bank for agriculture to safeguard the healthy growth of the nation's agricultural financial system.
Lee made the remarks in a seminar on the development of the agricultural and fishery industries sponsored by the Council of Agriculture.

The agroeconomist-turned-politician noted that Taiwan identity and agricultural problems have been important issues in his life but that given the pressing issues in the past of the lifting of martial law, the creation and legalization of political parties and bringing more openness to the media, he had not paid as much attention to agricultural issues as he would have liked.
However, he said that he was now happy to see that since President Chen Shui-bian assumed office, the government has attached great importance to the lives of farmers.
Chen's administration earmarked NT$100 billion (US$2.98 billion) for the agriculture sector to soften the impact of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization in 2002.

The former president was particularly dismayed that the public only understood the width and breadth of the agriculture sector by looking at its contribution to the nation's gross national product (GNP). This view of the sector as nothing more than two percentage has lead the people to feel that it is an unimportant aspect of society.

Lee said that the production value of the agriculture sector should include tourism, leisure farms, and fishery and agricultural product processing, saying that if all these were added together, the production value of the agriculture sector would reach about 10 percent of the nation's GNP.
On how to develop agriculture and build up the countryside, Lee said that sound grassroots agricultural financial institutions are crucial.

He said that he was gratified to see the agriculture finance law finally pass the legislature, but he also said that only with a large-scale bank exclusively serving farmers will there be healthy development of the agricultural financial system.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June fell 120 points to close at 5,840, with 43,557 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July lost 148 points to end at 5,785, with 1,807 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 100 points to end at 5,764, with 12 contracts finalized.
December futures fell 111 points to close at 5,767, with four contracts concluded, while next March futures dropped 121 points to end at 5,809, with three contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,960 for June, 5,933 for July, 5,864 for September, 5,878 for December and 5,930 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved down.
June TE futures fell eight points to close at 233.2, with 5,062 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 7.6 points to end at 231.6, with 333 contracts transacted.
September TE futures dropped 5 points to close at 235, with two contract traded.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures lost 6.6 points to end at 971, with 7,963 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures rose 7.8 points to end at 964.8, with 1,576 contracts traded.
Next March TF futures fell 13 points to close at 957, with two contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON CONSON BRINGS NO RELIEF TO PARCHED SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Conson failed to bring rain for much of the parched south of Taiwan as was expected, as the typhoon slowly veered away from the island a day earlier, officials said Thursday.

Wu Yueh-hsi, general-secretary of the Water Resources Agency under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that he was pinning his hopes on Typhoon Conson to bring precipitation to the southern Tainan and Chiayi regions, but since the typhoon did not make landfall on the west coast as had been forecast by the Central Weather Bureau, reservoirs were barely affected.
Taking the Tsengwen Reservoir in Tainan County as an example, Wu said, "Conson hardly produced any rainfall in the region, leaving prime reservoirs in the area still facing serious water shortages."
The Tsengwen Reservoir and the nearby Wushantou Reservoir currently hold a combined 45 million tons of water, while the Nanhua Reservoir holds some 47 million tons.

The total amount of some 92 million tons of water is expected to supply normal civic and industrial use for two more months, Wu said, but pointed out that water for irrigating rice paddies in the region will be insufficient.
According to Wu, the planned irrigation for the second crop of about 18,000 hectares of farmland on the Chianan Plain -- Taiwan's leading granary -- will need approximately 300 million tons of water.
For the time being, the Chianan Irrigation Association has divided the farmland under its charge into eight groups, and irrigation will be carried out alternately pending future rainfall, he noted.
In the past, the amount of rainfall in June in the catchment area of the Tsengwen Reservoir averaged 500 millimeters. It rained 800 millimeters in June last year.
Different regions in Taiwan have in recent years been troubled by water shortages as a result of a steep decrease in rainfall.
In 2002 and 2003, Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu in the north were hit hard by an acute dry spell, forcing a national anti-drought task force to impose water conservation measures on local residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN COMMERCE OFFICE ENHANCES VISA SERVICES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Australian Commerce and Industry Office (ACIO) in Taipei completed the refurbishment Thursday of its office and will upgrade its visa services due to the increasing number of Taiwanese tourists and students visiting Australia.
The ACIO issued some 76,000 visas for Taiwan people last year, mainly for tourism and study, followed by business.
In the first half of this year, more than 37,000 Taiwan people applied for Australian visas, an increase of 33 percent over the same period last year.
Expecting a flood of visa applications this summer, the ACIO will now offer more convenient visa services, which will allow applicants to collect information or apply for visas via the Internet.

Those interested can visit the ACIO's Chinese Web site: www.australia.org.tw/visas or the Web site of the Australian government's Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs: www.immi.gov.au.

Chen Chun, section chief in charge of visa services of the ACIO, noted that they are planning to issue "e-visas" within 24 hours in collaboration with 46 local tourist agencies, and allow students who have already obtained entrance permits to get their visas through the Internet.

In January, the Australian office began issuing guardian visas to parents wishing to accompany their children under 18 to study in Australia, and are studying issuing visas for young part-timer workers in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended the day lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 98.19 points to close at 5,867.51.
The bourse opened at 5,915.96 and fluctuated between 5,938.61 and 5,834.04 during trading.

A total of 3.28 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$68.7 billion (US$2.05 billion) , an increase from the previous day's trading session that saw 3.16 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$65.24 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 2.6 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 1.6 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.2 percent, cement stocks at 1 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.9 percent, textile issues at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent.
Construction stocks, however, rose 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 587 to 186, with 191 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SPONSOR 12TH WORLD SCOUT MOOT

TEXT.P: More than 8,000 college students from some 80 countries around the world will travel to Taiwan to take part in the 12th World Scout Moot to be held from July 30 to Aug. 10, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Thursday.

Speaking at a regular news conference, Lu Ching-lung, vice chairman of the foreign ministry's NGO Affairs Committee, said the ministry is assisting the Taiwan Scouts Association in organizing the upcoming world scout jamboree.

"We are satisfied with the success in securing the opportunity to sponsor the large non-governmental organization (NGO) event, " Lu said, adding that it will show the world Taiwan is willing and able to organize massive NGO activities.
A world scout moot is one of the world scout events, with the participation of senior members of national scout associations (traditionally called Rovers) and other young adult members.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: The capital pays homage to 'a graceful and a gallant man'.
The body of Ronald Wilson Reagan returned Wednesday evening to the capital. "While others worried, President Reagan persevered, " Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois told members of Congress, the Supreme Court, the diplomatic corps and invited guests. "When others weakened, President Reagan stood tall. When others stepped back, President Reagan stepped forward. And he did it all with great humility, with great charm and with great humor."
The Wall Street Journal: Big Three's outsourcing plan: make parts suppliers do it.
Global trade and American labor are creating a quandary for the Big Three auto makers. Facing intense price competition, they want to take advantage of the plunging cost of manufacturing in China. Yet their labor agreements at home make it hard to shift jobs overseas. Now the auto giants have hit upon an unusual strategy: Push their suppliers to do the outsourcing for them.

Manila Bulletin: 12th Congress adjourns today
12th Congress adjourns today, but canvassing of votes for President, VP by joint panel conti- nues Senate President Franklin Drilon and Speaker Jose de Venecia are expected to preside over their separate sessions to temporarily stop their canvassing chores to adjourn the 12th Congress today as scheduled.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Cardinal to Pimentel: Stop filibustering
FORMER Manila Archbishop Jaime Cardinal Sin rang up Senator Aquilino Pimentel Jr.'s resi- dence in Marikina on Tuesday to try and ask the opposition senator to desist from further delay- ing the canvass of the May 10 presidential and vice presidential elections.
The Philippine Star: Canvass proceeds as Poe takes lead
The congressional canvassing picked up some speed as opposition standard-bearer Fernando Poe Jr. took the lead over President Arroyo yes- terday.
The Manila Times: Congress ends; count in question
THE third and last regular session of the Twelfth Congress adjourns sine die today, with the unfinished canvassing of the votes for pre- sident and vice president creating confusion over how the winners could be proclaimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIB DIRECTOR RECEIVES DOCTORAL DEGREE IN CRIMINOLOGY

TEXT.P: Hou You-yi, director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) under the National Police Administration, received a doctoral degree in criminology from Central Police University's Graduate Institute of Criminology Thursday.
Hou said he had used his leisure time in the afternoons and evenings over the past five years to complete his doctoral program.

Hou's dissertation focuses on 42 sensational rape-murder cases reported in Taiwan over the past decades. With rich practical criminal investigation experience, Hou said he didn't encounter any great difficulties writing the paper.
"I hope my dissertation can offer some inspiration in future domestic criminal investigations," Hou said.
Hou was among the 685 students who graduated from Central Police University's undergraduate and graduate programs Thursday.
President Chen Shui-bian attended the school's commencement ceremony for the third straight year.
Addressing the ceremony, Chen said his attendance signifies the importance his administration has attached to police education and administration.
"Crime prevention is critical to maintaining social stability. This goal cannot be realized without the concerted efforts of all police officers," Chen said.

He encouraged all the new graduates to dedicate themselves to serving the people and upholding the rule of law in performing their duties as well as to promoting community cooperation in crime prevention and strengthening professionalism.

Noting that police competence and integrity are important symbols of national progress, Chen said he hopes all police staff will continue pursuing progressional expertise and skills in crime fighting and prevention.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, June 10 [CNA] The Moscow Times:Bush Sees Bigger NATO Role in Iraq.
U.S. President George W. Bush, hoping to build on momentum from a unanimous United Nations Security Council vote on Iraq, said Wednesday at the Group of Eight summit that he envisions a wider role for NATO in post-occupation Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 10, or the 23rd day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Nikolaus August Otto, the German inventor of the four-stroke internal combustion engine, is born.
1836: Andre-Marie Ampere, the French physicist and mathematician, is born. He formulated Ampere's law, a mathematical description of the magnetic field produced by a current-carrying conductor.
1900: More than 2,000 troops from eight nations -- Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria, crush the Boxer Rebellion, killing some 300 boxers at Langfang near Beijing.
1922: American singer and actress Judy Garland is born as Frances Gumm. She starred in such films as "Meet Me in St. Louis," "A Star is Born," as well as "The Wizard of Oz," in which she sang "Somewhere Over the Rainbow," winning an Academy Award for her performance.
1939: Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, summons Chou En-lai and Yeh Chien-ying to admonish communist forces to keep their promise to obey orders.
1940: Italy declares war on France and Britain.
1945: U.S. marines invade the Japanese Ryukyu islands, completing their occupation of the islands on June 21.
1947: The Republic of China protests to the Soviet Union against the Soviet invasion of Sinkiang Province in northwestern China.
1967: Israel wins a decisive victory in the Six-Day War against its Arab neighbors and expands its territory by 200 percent.
1971: The United States formally ends its 20-year-old embargo on trade with mainland China.
1972: Chang Feng-hsu assumes office as the new mayor of Taipei, succeeding Henry Kao.
1975: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo, addressing the Kuomintang, pledges to carry out Dr. Sun Yat-sen's Three Principles of the People and the late President Chiang Kai-shek's anti-communist policy.
1976: Lin Yang-kang, commissioner of the Taiwan Provincial Reconstruction Department, is appointed mayor of Taipei City by the Executive Yuan.
1980: The Ninth Sino-American Conference on Mainland China opens at the International Hall of the Civic Aeronautic Administration in Taipei with 109 Chinese and American scholars and experts participating.
1982: ROC Premier Sun Yun-suan says that there is no "Taiwan issue," only the "China issue," which relates to whether there is to be a "strong and hostile communist China or a peace-loving non-communist China."
1985: Dr. Chen Hung-ping, 48, a native of Heilungkiang in northern mainland China, defects at the ROC's Chiang Kai-shek International Airport after attending an international academic meeting.
1989: Direct telephone links are opened between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
1992: A revised copyright law goes into effect in the ROC, providing explicit legal protection for intellectual property rights and imposing heavier penalties for copyright infringements.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui meets with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski and reaffirms the ROC's determination to substantiate various exchange and cooperation programs with Macedonia.
2000: The 2000 Taipei International Dragon Boat Race kicks off at Tachia Park, located alongside the Keelung River, with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presiding over the opening ceremony.
2001: The Chinese version of "President Inside the Tiger's Mouth," a new book by the Japanese historian and novelist Fuyuko Kamisaka, has been released in Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men by nature are alike; but in practice, they are widely different. It is only men of the highest understanding and men of the grossest dullness who do not change."

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB CLOSELY WATCHING NEW TYPHOON IN SOUTH CHINA SEA

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) said Friday that it is closely watching a newly-formed typhoon located in the South China Sea near the Spratly Islands.

Although Typhoon Chantu is not likely to hit Taiwan judging from its current course, CWB meteorologists said Friday morning that they will still keep an eye on it since weather conditions change fast in the area.

Chanthu -- the fifth typhoon reported in the Pacific area this year -- was centered about 1,200 kilometers south-southwest of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Hengchun at 8 a.m. Friday, moving in a northwest direction at a speed of 19 kilometers per hour.

The typhoon, with a radius of 100 kilometers and packing winds of up to 65 kilometers per hour near its center, is forecast to move towards the Indochina Peninsula over the following two days if its current course remains unchanged, CWB meteorologists said.
Meanwhile, in northern Taiwan, temperatures Friday were cool due to the influence of the northeast trade winds, with forecast highs of around 28 degrees Celsius.
Afternoon thunder showers are expected in mountainous areas in central and southern Taiwan, where the forecast highs are 31-32 degrees Celsius.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA, Loren lead as vote canvass resumes.
The 22-man Joint Committee of Congress started late yesterday afternoon in resuming the tabulation of votes for the presidential and vice presidential elections as they chose to ignore demands on a cloture rule that would forestall filibusters from delaying the proceedings.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: New round of power rate increases looms.
THE Energy Regulatory Commission (ERC) approved Thursday higher generation rates for electricity supplied by state-run National Power Corp. (Napocor) to customers in the Luzon, Visayas and Mindanao grids, including Manila Electric Co.
The Philippine Star: 'Canvass done in 2 weeks'
Despite delays in the ongoing canvass of votes in Congress, an opposition representative in the joint committee said yesterday that winnners in this year's presidential election will be proclaimed in two weeks at the latest.
The Manila Times: Church vents ire on filibusterers.
Manila Archbishop Gaudencio Rosales, dismayed at the filibustering of opposition lawmakers during the canvassing of votes for president and vice president, said on Thursday that the soon-er the country's rancorous political pro-cess "self-destructs, the better."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: Suzhou park: Right move and a success.
After years of criticism, the Suzhou Industrial Park (SIP) yesterday received vindication of sorts from the major stakeholders, during the park's 10th anniversary celebrations.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Lee Kuan Yew says Suzhou Industrial Park has to go up value-added ladder.
In Suzhou to mark the SIP's 10th anniversary, Singapore's Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew attributed the SIP's current success to the high standard of urban planning and management, as well as the strong vote of confidence by its investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles Times: The Times Poll: Voters Shift in Favor of Kerry
Widespread unease over the country's direction and doubts about President Bush's policies on Iraq and the economy helped propel Sen.John F. Kerry to a solid lead among voters nationwide, according to a new Times poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow,June 11 [CNA] The Moscow Times:Thousands Rally Over Social Policies.
Thousands of trade union supporters across the country took to the streets Thursday to protest government plans to replace healthcare and transportation benefits for socially vulnerable groups with nonindexed cash payments, and called for higher salaries for low-paid state employees.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR EXTRAORDINARY LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called on the Legislative Yuan Friday to open an extraordinary session to deal with some urgent bills immediately after the legislature recessed.

Noting that only 23 out of 149 bills presented by the Executive Yuan were enacted in the just-concluded session, Yu said the lack of action will hamper the governing of his administration unless some urgent bills are enacted during an extraordinary session.
The premier said that the accumulated number of bills mired down in the legislature has reached 303.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT LIFTS OVERSEAS TRAVEL BAN ON CONTROVERSIAL BANKER

TEXT.P: A court lifted the overseas travel ban on former banker Liu Tai-ying Friday, although he was involved in at least 12 criminal cases.

The Taipei District Court said in a ruling that investigations into Liu's role in most of the 12 cases have already been completed, and he has reported to the court at every hearing, not to mention that he has put up bail of NT$60 million (US$1.79 million).

Furthermore, the court said, none of the crimes Liu was alleged to have committed in the 12 cases carries the death penalty, life imprisonment or a minimum penalty of five-years imprisonment; therefore, it is unnecessary to keep the overseas travel ban.

As a confidante of former President Lee Teng-hui, Liu was the chief of the Kuomintang's (KMT) Business Management Committee between 1993 and 2000, which made him the virtual treasurer of the party and gave him considerable political power.

After leaving his job at the KMT, Liu become the chairman of the China Development Industrial Bank until early last year when he was taken into custody by prosecutors in connection with his role in a financial scandal involving the Zanadau Development Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 12 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are major events scheduled to take place Saturday, June 12:
09: 00, An academic seminar will be held at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research at the international conference room of the institution's headquarters in Taipei.
09: 30, Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng will attend the commencement of National Taipei Teachers College at the college's campus.

campus.

18: 20, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will attend the commencement of National Sun Yat-sen University in Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO SIDES OF TAIWAN STRAIT SHOULD ESTABLISH MUTUAL MILITARY TRUST

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should establish a mechanism of mutual military trust, Taiwan's top mainland policy planner said Friday.

Noting that keeping the peace in the Taiwan Strait is a common responsibility for both sides, Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, said that it is necessary to establish a mechanism for mutual military trust between them, which he said is part of President Chen Shui-bian's proposal for establishing a stable framework of peaceful cross-strait interactions.

Wu said that his council will actively promote the realization of this goal in the coming years, including informing each other in advance about military drills, not designing military exercises with the two sides as virtual targets, avoiding the possibility of launching a first strike via military drills and setting up a military hotline between the two sides.
It is a given that the two sides inform each other in advance of their military exercises, Wu stressed.
Referring to how to make a breakthrough in the current cross-strait stalemate, Wu said that Taiwan will make goodwill gestures in an active manner to improve cross-strait ties.
He also call on Beijing not to inject political matters into trade and economic exchanges between the two sides, or the opening of direct cross-strait trade, postal services and transportation links.
The opening of the so-called direct "three links" is an established policy of Taiwan, Wu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BASIC ORGANIC LAW FOR CENTRAL GOVERNMENT PASSED

TEXT.P: A bill providing for the basic framework of the Central Government was passed by the Legislative Yuan Friday, although the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) vowed to revoke a provision inserted into the bill by opposition parties that gives the legislature the power to approve the appointment of heads of five independent agencies.

The Basic Organic Law for the Central Government, passed on the last day of the current legislative session, stipulates that the Executive Yuan should have no more than 13 ministries, four commissions and five independent agencies.
The Executive Yuan, which now has eight ministries and 27 councils, commissions and administrations should come up with a organic law in line with the new legislation within three months.

The ministries, councils and independent agencies under the Executive Yuan, if reorganized, should come up with their individual organic laws one year after the Organic Law of the Executive Yuan is revised and promulgated.

The chiefs and deputy chiefs of the five independent agencies, namely Taiwan's Central Bank of China, the Central Election Commission, the Fair Trade Commission, and the two proposed commissions of financial supervision and communications should be named by the premier and approved by the Legislative Yuan, according to a provision railroaded through by the two major opposition parties of the Kuomintang and the People First Party.

The premier's nominees should first be reviewed by relevant committees in the Legislative Yuan before being referring to the whole floor for a vote, according to a resolution of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.
As the provision was not contemplated by the Executive Yuan, the ruling DPP condemned it as an infringement on the power of the executive branch and claimed it is unconstitutional.
The DPP lawmakers said their party will do whatever it can to strike this provision.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Nation: Soccer defeat fallout/ "Zico" hits out at Thaksin.
Thailand's rare soccer talent Kiattisak "Zico" Senamuang yesterday became a rare political commodity too - a man who dares to stand up to Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra.
Having led the national team in its humiliating 4-1 defeat by North Korea in a World Cup qualifier in Bangkok on Wednesday night, and perhaps bitter over the Liverpool episode, Kiattiasak exploded following the prime minister's comment yesterday that Thai soccer players had no heart. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: RTC FUND GETS LEGISLATIVE APPROVAL FOR ONE-YEAR EXTENSION

TEXT.P: The Resolution Trust Corporation (RTC) fund was granted final approval Friday by the Legislative Yuan for a one-year extension after lengthy negotiations amid the government's intensive financial reform efforts.

Under the original regulations, the RTC fund was to expire on July 10 this year. The one-year extension, proposed by the Ministry of Finance (MOF), will provide a platform for legislators to conduct a comprehensive revision of the law before Oct. 19 -- a deadline agreed upon by legislators of various political parties.

It was also agreed upon that non-deposit debts of the poorly managed banking and financial institutes that are under government supervision before Jan. 15, 2005 will be fully secured with the fund's extension should relevant rules be revised to that end before the deadline.

An additional resolution was also attached to the slated law overhaul on the same day, the last working day of the current legislative session, which requires the fund to clearly stipulate that 20 percent of its amount will be used to cover losses and repayments of the debt-ridden farmers and fishermen's associations -- Taiwan's grassroots financial institutions.

Upon learning the news, Chang Ming-tao, director of the MOF's Bureau of Monetary Affairs, thanked the Legislative Yuan's for its cooperation, as he called the fund a vital element to the success of the government's financial reform drive.

The RTC fund was set up in June 2001 by the MOF under legislative permission to help government financial reform efforts by granting bailout packages to poorly-operated monetary institutions due to bankruptcies, closures, mergers and consolidations.

The Executive Yuan originally planed to raise only NT$ 40 billion (US$1.19 billion) by imposing a 2 percent tax on business revenues of monetary institutions during the period between 2001 and 2004, but it proposed last year to boost the scale of the fund to NT$1.05 trillion through the issuance of public bonds and extending its four-year lifespan indefinitely.
Reforming country's farmers and fishermen's associations are a major task high on the government's agenda since President Chen Shui-bian came to power in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER RETURNS TO TAIWAN FROM APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: ROC Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long arrived in Taiwan Friday night after concluding his visit to Manila, where he attended the energy meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum held Thursday.
On arriving at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Chen told reporters that officials at the meeting discussed short- and long-term energy security problems.

According to Chen, officials of APEC countries agreed that a quick energy supply and demand reporting system can be established for all member countries, and encouraged more stockpiling of oil for these countries.
On long-term energy security, these officials discussed new energy development and the sustainable use of energy.
During his stay in Manila, Chen also held bilateral talks with officials of Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines and Japan on energy issues and other economic topics.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER HOLDS BILATERAL TALKS WITH APEC COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Chen Ruey-long held bilateral talks with officials of Australia, New Zealand, the Philippines and Japan during the energy ministers' meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum concluded in Manila Thursday.

According to the ROC delegation, Philippine officials have expressed much interest in Taiwan's petrochemical industry and have encouraged Taiwanese petrochemical enterprises to invest in the Philippines or start cooperation projects with their Philippine counterparts.
Japanese Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry Shoichi Nakagawa exchanged opinions with Chen on a wide variety of issues, including energy problems and the economic situations of Taiwan and Japan.
In his talks with Australian and New Zealand officials, Chen expressed the hope that Taiwan can cooperate with these two countries in energy research projects.
Chen left Manila for home Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN HOPES TO VISIT PARAGUAY SOON

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Friday that he hopes to visit Paraguay soon and sign a free trade agreement with the South American country.
Chen revealed his intention in a telephone call to Paraguayan President Nicanor Duarte Frutos, in which he expressed gratitude to Duarte for his attendance at Chen's second inauguration on May 20.
According to a news release from the Presidential Office, President Duarte said he was moved by the hospitality that the Republic of China offered to him during his Taipei trip.

Duarte stressed that the friendship between the ROC and Paraguay is based on the same ideals and it will never be affected by "economic manipulation" of Beijing authorities, refuting as untrue some news reports that member countries of the South Common Market (MERCOSUR) in South America have been lobbied by Beijing to pressure Paraguay, a MERCOSUR member, to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing, as this trade block hopes to sign a free trade agreement with China.
Other MERCOSUR members include Argentina, Brazil, and Uruguay, and Paraguay is the only member that maintains diplomatic ties with the ROC.

Chen noted that China has been using economic affairs to undermine ROC-Paraguayan ties; however, Duarte's firm support of the ROC moved him greatly, which also reflects the cordial relations between the two countries.
Duarte also expressed hope that President Chen can visit Paraguay soon to conclude a free trade agreement between the two countries.
Chen told Duarte that he has instructed related agencies to promote the signing of a free trade agreement with Paraguay, the only diplomatic ally of the ROC in South America.
Earlier in the day, Chen also telephoned Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso and thanked her for coming to his inauguration.
After telephoning Moscoso and Duarte, Chen completed his telephone thanks to all 15 foreign heads of states who visited Taiwan for his inauguration.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT APPARENTLY PROMPTS LAWMAKER TO APOLOGIZE TO AIT CHIEF

TEXT.P: It apparently took a gentle nudge from President Chen Shui-bian to force Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Lin Chung-mou to backtrack Friday from his pledge to never apologize for calling the chief of the American Institute in Taiwan a " vicious dog."

Lin said at a news conference that he was sorry for causing any misunderstandings on the part of the United States by his rude behavior, and in the interest of Taiwan and relations with the U.S., he apologized to Douglas Paal, director-general of the American Institute in Taiwan's Taipei office, the de-facto U.S. ambassador to Taiwan.

Lin who is known for often using offensive language, scolded Paal in the Legislative Yuan for what he claimed was his pushing Taiwan to conclude an arms purchase contract with the U.S. that carried a price tag of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion).
Lin said he would not support the Executive Yuan's request for a special budget to finance the deal "unless Washington withdrew Paal first."
Thursday, Lin said he would never apologize to Paal, but apparently the matter caught the attention of President Chen Shui-bian,
Lin then said that he would hold a news conference Friday to request that Washington recall Paal if the United States still wants to sell arms to Taiwan.

The news conference was postponed for half an hour and was changed to a new revenue at the Legislative Yuan. Lin finally showed up with three DPP leaders at the Legislative Yuan in tow: Ker Chien-ming, Tsai Huang-liang and Trong Chai and, to the surprise of the media present, he apologized to Paal, although reluctantly.
He left the news conference without answering journalists' questions as to whether President Chen's intervention had prompted the apology; however Ker said, "Of course."

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PLAN FOR IMMEDIATE ELECTRICITY PRICE HIKE: TAIPOWER

TEXT.P: Electricity prices will remain stable for the time being, but could be raised in the future to reflect higher global costs for coal, oil and natural gas, Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) said Friday.
Taipower President C. C. Lin noted that prices for coal, oil and natural gas are increasing in international markets, with the current price for coal being 130 percent higher than last year.

Although Taipower purchased coal in advance last year, reducing slightly the electricity generation cost for the company, it is expected to spend NT$24.87 billion (US$742 million) on oil and NT$34.08 billion for natural gas this year, far more than was budgeted. The budgets were NT$18.68 billion for oil and NT$31.41 billion for natural gas.

Lin added that Taipower will discuss the matter with the Ministry of Economic Affairs and other agencies, taking into account the reaction of the industrial sector and the public so that a consensus on electricity prices can be reached.

After that, Taipower will present the results to the Executive Yuan for approval. Lin stressed that although he knows that his company must conform to government policy, he cannot guarantee that prices will not be raised by the end of this year.
"Taipower will make the proper readjustments for electricity prices at the proper time, "Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PROCESSING ZONES GOING ALL OUT TO COURT FOREIGN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: The Economic Processing Zone Administration (EPZA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs has been going all out to entice foreign investors by improving conditions in nationwide economic processing zones (EPZs) , an administration official said Friday.

In line with an economics ministry drive to court potential investors from India and countries in Southeast Asia late this month, the official said that EPZs across Taiwan have been working on upgrading their facilities and services to welcome new investors, both foreign and overseas Chinese companies, and assist present EPZ-based small and traditional businesses to seek industrial upgrades.

As personnel from Paraguay, Uruguay, Vietnam and mainland China have recently concluded courses in learning Taiwan's EPZ operations and management, future cooperation with those countries are in sight to explore the world market jointly, he said.

Once foreign-headquartered companies open plants in Taiwan's EPZs, they will have effective access to logistics, capital and information flows for their business expansion across the world, benefits that they can use for technology transfers and value-added processing for re-shipments.

Taiwan's EPZs are also suitable for foreign-based Taiwan companies to run their research and operations hubs, as the EPZA has launched preparations to build adequate facilities for that purpose, he said, adding that they can also set up distribution centers here by taking advantage of Taiwan's location and high-quality manpower.

Currently, a majority of companies operating in Taiwan's EPZs are small- an medium-sized businesses of traditional industries, which once were the major driving force behind the country's rapid economic development in the 1970s.
In recent years, those EPZs have sought to play a greater role in the present knowledge-based era by attracting hi-tech businesses to open plants in their complexes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE SPEAKS OUT FOR TRADE FACILITATION
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 11 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) , Yen Ching-chang, called here Friday for the inclusion of trade facilitation into the Doha Round talks of the WTO.

Speaking at a meeting of APEC member economies' WTO representatives, Yen said trade facilitation, a process aimed at making doing business easier and less costly, should be included as an item for discussion under the WTO framework.
Yen said his country would support a roundtable conference among WTO APEC members in Geneva to share their experiences in facilitating trade among them.
Friday's meeting was called by Chile's WTO ambassador, who briefed his APEC counterparts on the conclusion of the June 4-5 APEC meeting of ministers responsible for trade in Pucon, Chile.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN AIRPORT FALLS SHORT OF INTERNATIONAL STATUS: OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: The new terminal at the Hualien Airport has been built to international standards, but the airport itself is not an international one, even though it is open for international charter flights, airport officials said Friday.

The officials made the remarks after complaints from some tour operators who said that they were under the impression that since the addition of the new terminal, Hualien Airport was to be considered an international airport. The tour operators were disappointed to learn that many foreign charter flights that were originally scheduled to come in summer have been canceled because the airport is unable to handle the waste from the chartered planes.
The operators said this was a huge blow to the tourism industry in Hualien.
Airport officials said that although the new terminal was constructed with an international design in mind, it has a long way to go before becoming a truly international airport.
The officials said that the number of passengers and inbound and outbound cargo has yet to reach the level of an international airport.

Even if the new terminal had been installed with an incinerator to handle charter planes' waste, officials said that they expected that they would have been criticized for squandering the government's money.

At the present stage, they said that they could only ask the charter planes to depart and carry away their own waste. If there is stable growth of passengers and cargo in the future, the terminal will have to ask for money from the central government to build facilities to accommodate the increase.

The tour operators also asked for the help of the Hualien County Government, although county government officials said that the matter is beyond their jurisdiction. Although they said that they will do all they can to help.
Charter planes that have landed at Hualien Airport have come mostly from Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT FROM U.S. FAR TOO EXPENSIVE: LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Two more legislators on Friday criticized a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) budget passed by the Executive Yuan earlier this month for the purchase of weapons from the United States as being "far too expensive."

Legislator Ku Chung-lien of the opposition People First Party and independent Legislator Su Ying-kuei said they support government arms procurements from the United States, but they also claimed that the deal is exorbitantly expensive.
They said that not only should the Control Yuan -- the nation's highest watchdog body -- conduct an investigation, but that the legislature should also "keep the taxpayers' money in mind."
Ku, who is a former navy commander-in-chief, said that the budget will be mainly for the purchase of Patriot PAC III anti-missile systems, diesel-powered submarines, and P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

But he said that the eight submarines have an estimated cost of NT$400 billion, meaning that one such conventional submarine could buy a nuclear-powered submarine in the United States, making the cost of the diesel subs is "simply too high."
Su said that cost is much higher than that charged for other countries, noting the same price could buy an equal number of F-14 fighter planes.

In addition, Su said that the defense area covered by the navy is mainly the Taiwan Strait. He claimed that the depth of the 160-km-wide strait is insufficient for the deployment of submarines and that he is afraid the submarines would be rendered useless in the event of war.

According to Executive Yuan's arms procurement draft budget bill, Taiwan will purchase eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the arms to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992.
The special budget bill is now pending approval of the opposition "pan-blue alliance"-controlled Legislative Yuan.
