DOC.HEADLINE: MOUTH-BREEDER RAISERS HOPING FOR GOVERNMENT HELP OVER OVERSUPPLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's production of mouth-breeders this year is expected to reach 90,000 tons, a level that will far exceed local demand, according to statistics compiled by the Council of Agriculture (COA).

COA Vice Chairman Hu Fu-hsiung reported at a recent legislative committee meeting that the council is planning to purchase 1,000 tons of mouth-breeders of inferior quality in the Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan areas to make fertilizer in an effort to help tackle the oversupply problem. It has so far bought 660 tons, he noted.
Fu also pointed out that the COA is not considering buying more of the fish for that purpose and instead is mulling ways to help raisers expand their exports.
The COA is hoping to increase the amount of Taiwan outbound shipments of mouth-breeders to 63,000 tons per year from the current level of 53,000 tons, officials said.

Affected by soaring commodity prices in the international market, costs for local mouth-breeder raisers have also jumped. In the face of the pressure from the overproduction and rising costs, they have demanded that the government increase its purchase amount as a means of helping them overcome their difficulties.
Mouth-breeders, a typical and popular fish for Taiwan consumers, are presently being sold at about NT$26 (US$0.776) per kilogram on average on the domestic market.

In response, Legislator Yu Cheng-tao voiced the hope that the COA will also purchase the fish in the Pingtung and Kaohsiung areas and his call was endorsed by colleagues Tsao Chi-hung and Ke Shu-min, who asked the council to buy an additional 3,000 tons of mouth-breeders in central and southern regions, where aquaculture ponds are clustered.
Legislator Lin Feng-shi, however, was opposed to the proposal, claiming that making such large purchases will have an impact on the market.

He also questioned how the government plans to ensure the quality of the mouth-breeders bought from local raisers, as some fish exported to the European Union late last year were returned to Taiwan after the buyers discovered they contained excessive amounts of chemicals.
For this reason, coupled with emerging price competition from mainland China, Thailand and Vietnam, Taiwan-raised mouth-breeders have hit a snag in exports, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD PARAGLIDING CHAMPIONSHIP TO BEGIN IN TAITUNG IN JULY

TEXT.P: A World Paragliding Championship will begin July 17 in Taitung, eastern Taiwan, in conjunction with a series of other flying activities, Taitung county government officials said Friday.

The paragliding competition, which will be held on the heights of Luyie village and mountainous areas of Yungkang village in Taitung County, is expected to attract paragliders from the United States, Japan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Australia, Middle East countries, Germany and France.

As some translators will be needed during the competition, the tourism office of the Taitung county government said it would welcome applications by people aged over 20 who can translate German, French, Spanish, Japanese or Korean.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE AMOUNT OF SMUGGLED BETEL NUTS SEIZED

TEXT.P: Customs officials seized a large batch of betel nuts smuggled into Taiwan from Thailand Friday.

The seized betel nuts, weighing a total of 3,584 kg and packed in 128 cases, were airlifted to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport -- Taiwan's main gateway -- a day earlier. Customs officials said the labels on the cases had been changed after their arrival at the airport warehouse, indicating that there were local accomplices involved in the smuggling operation.
It was the third batch of smuggled betel nuts uncovered by airport customs authorities in the past two weeks.
As now is the off-season for betel nut harvesting in Taiwan and the Council of Agriculture has banned imports of the product, there has been a sharp hike in local betel nut retail prices.

Customs officials said they suspect that local smuggling rings have colluded with airport staff to change the labels of the betel nuts from Thailand to facilitate the smuggling of the products into Taiwan.
Customs officials urged airport police and criminal investigators to tighten their monitoring of suspicious people who might change the labels after the arrival of the betel nuts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were lower Friday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June fell 125 points to close at 5,715, with 33,329 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July lost 140 points to end at 5,645, with 3,585 contracts traded, while September futures dropped 115 points to end at 5,650, with 13 contracts finalized.
December futures fell 122 points to close at 5,658, with one contract concluded, while next March futures dropped 91 points to end at 5,680, with two contracts traded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Friday at 5,840 for June, 5,785 for July, 5,765 for September, 5,780 for December and 5,771 for next March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also moved down.
June TE futures fell 7.2 points to close at 226, with 5,554 contracts traded, while July TE futures lost 9.8 points to end at 221.8, with 1,483 contracts transacted.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
June TF futures lost 16 points to end at 955, with 9,045 contracts changing hands, while July TF futures dropped 27.8 points to end at 937, with 2,023 contracts traded.
September TF futures closed at 953, with one contract transaction.
Next March TF futures fell two points to close at 955, with one contract finalized.
No transactions were recorded for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, gaining NT$0.075 to close at NT$33.605.
A total of US$519 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$33.530 and fluctuated between NT$33.486 and NT$33.620.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Bush doesn't expect NATO to provide troops for Iraq.
U.S. President Bush said Thursday that after two days of consultations with the leaders of France and other nations, he did not expect NATO to provide troops to bolster or replace American forces in Iraq. But he continued to press for a more limited NATO role in training Iraqis to take on the burden of security in their own country, if the new Iraqi government requested the help.
The Wall Street Journal: Harvard parents got a hard lesson in investing perils.
A key fund-raiser for school is convicted of bilking wealthy donors. Gregory Earls, a deal maker with a penchant for high-risk investments, stole much of the money of some Harvard parents invested with him, siphoning off cash as he passed it through another company he controlled. Prosecutors say, Mr. Earls defrauded more than 100 investors of US$13.8 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT, PREMIER TO VISIT CENTRAL AMERICA: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Yu Shyi-kun will visit Central America and the Caribbean in the near future to boost the Republic of China's relations with its allies in the two regions, Vice President Annette Lu said Friday.

Lu made the remarks at a news conference at the Presidential Office on the achievements of her just-concluded 14-day diplomatic tour that took her to El Salvador, Costa Rica and Guatemala in addition to two American cities -- Las Vegas and San Francisco -- for transit stops.

Lu noted that the ROC has 13 diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean. "This time I visited only three of those countries. President Chen and Premier Yu will visit our other allies in the two regions in the not-too-distant future," she added.

Describing her fruitful visit as the result of a "diplomatic symphony orchestra," Lu said she just played the role of conductor. "I'm grateful for the devoted services of our diplomatic staff and the members of my entourage. Their concerted efforts helped make the journey a great success."

Nevertheless, Lu said she feels that some of the ROC diplomats stationed in the three Central American countries are not qualified to do their jobs. "I'll advise Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen to designate an ambassador-at-large versed in the Spanish language and Latin American affairs to strengthen supervision of diplomatic work there," she said.

Lu again called for a new vision and new perspective for the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait. She urged Taiwan businessmen to follow the prevailing trend of globalization in establishing their business empires or footholds.

"Taiwan businessmen should look east toward the Pacific Ocean instead of looking west toward mainland China. There are many other good overseas investment destinations outside the Chinese mainland, " Lu said.

During her visit to El Salvador, Lu said, she urged the Salvadoran government to designate a large piece of land for Taiwan investors. Lu said she will encourage Taiwan entrepreneurs to invest in the farming and agricultural processing industries in El Salvador.
In addition, Lu went on, Taiwan can assist Costa Rica in digitalization and cooperate with Guatemala in restoring its cultural and historic relics.

Lu said she will launch a new publicity campaign to help local people better understand the Central American allies' culture, history and general political and social situations, including encouraging local college students to forge friendships via mail with their Central American counterparts, inviting performing arts groups to perform in Taiwan, encouraging local travel agencies to organize package tours to those countries and urging local people to sponsor children from impoverished families in the region.

She also noted that 50 percent of lawmakers and 40 percent of Cabinet members in Costa Rica are female. "I plan to organize a delegation of local female politicians and business executives to visit Costa Rica to see for themselves Costa Rica's achievements in promoting gender equality in political and other fields," she said

Lu said she received the highest-level honors and dignified treatment during her three-leg Central America visit and transit stops in the two American cities. "It was a journey of honor and dignity and the visit glorified our national dignity."

Lu further said the unexpectedly high-level courtesy treatment she received during her transit stops in Las Vegas and San Francisco symbolized a thaw in substantive Taiwan-U.S. ties, which were strained in the run-up to Taiwan's March 20 presidential election over President Chen's insistence on holding a "defensive referendum" that the Bush administration saw as provocative to Beijing.

During her transit stop in San Francisco on her way back to Taipei, Lu said she asked Chen by phone whether she could change her schedule and travel to Washington, D.C. to represent the ROC government at the late U.S. President Ronald Reagan's state funeral.

"President Chen told me that we should respect the U.S. State Department's opinion. ROC Representative Chen Chien-jen then contacted the U.S. authorities over the issue. In consideration of my busy schedule, the U.S. State Department unprecedentedly agreed to let me read a public statement mourning Reagan's death," Lu recalled.

Due to the absence of formal diplomatic ties with the United States and Beijing's diplomatic embargo against Taiwan, senior ROC officials have traditionally been banned from issuing any public statement during their rare transit stops on U.S. soil.
However, Lu returned to Taipei Thursday as scheduled and Chen designated Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien to attend Reagan's funeral on his behalf.

During a meeting with Taiwan expatriates in San Francisco, Lu also suggested that the nation be called "Taiwan Republic of China, " an idea she thought would pacify domestic disputes over Taiwan's identity. The proposal drew heavy fire in local society, but Lu claimed that Chen fully understands her true intention.
"My proposal was aimed at ending the domestic disputes and promoting social harmony. It had nothing to do with constitutional amendments or the sensitive national title change issue," she added.
Heading a large entourage, Lu attended new Salvadoran President Elias Antonio Saca's inauguration on Chen's behalf. Lu said Saca has agreed to visit Taipei in August.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATER PRICE HIKE NO LESS THAN 30%: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Water Resources Agency (WRA) Director Chen Sheng-hsien said Friday that the WRA will discuss with related agencies to determine a readjustment of water prices, but predicted that water prices will rise by no less than 30 percent.
Chen said that the conclusions reached at their discussions will be presented to the Executive Yuan before the end of this month and that a final decision on prices is expected to be made in July.
Taiwan has been hard-hit by drought over the last few years.

The official added that as a water quality and service improvement program should be presented in conjunction with the water price readjustment plan, he estimated that the water price readjustment can be implemented early next year at the soonest.

Given that there will still be a preferential rate for those customers who consume less than a basic level of water, Chen predicted that some 60 percent of the population will not be affected by the price hike.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 132.44 points to close at 5,735.07.
The bourse opened at 5,806.83 and fluctuated between 5,827.51 and 5,728.2 during trading.

A total of 3.35 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$75.34 billion (US$2.25 billion), an increase from the previous day's trading session that saw 3.28 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$68.7 billion.

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 3 percent, followed by construction stocks at 2.9 percent, bank and insurance shares at 2.2 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.8 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.7 percent, textile issues at 1.5 percent, cement stocks at 1.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.6 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 719 to 102, with 136 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVISER WARNS OF CROWD-OUT EFFECT OF SOARING MAINLAND-BOUND INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: A national policy adviser to the Presidential Office warned Friday that soaring Taiwan investments in mainland China might have triggered a crowd-out effect on domestic investment.

National policy adviser Huang Tian-lin claimed at a round-table discussion that Taiwan investments in the mainland have exceeded half of Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP), a situation that might well crowd out investment at home.

Huang urged the government to look into the issue and encourage Taiwan businessmen to relocate their investment operations from the mainland to elsewhere, such as Southeast Asia, so that they can provide a more useful and constructive influence on Taiwan's business and industrial sectors.

To back up his argument, Huang said that by comparison, Japanese investment in the mainland constitute only 0.6 percent of that country's GDP, while South Korean investments there are equal to 2.7 percent of South Korea's GDP.

Huang said that although the South Korean mainland investments constitute only 2.7 percent of the country's GDP, South Korea's exports to the mainland have grown remarkably to the tune of about the same amount exported by Taiwan.

He claimed that Taiwan's mainland-bound investments have actually already crowded out domestic investments, pointing out that the annual growth rate of domestic investments in recent years has been lower than that of Japan, a nation that has suffered an economic downturn for more than 10 years.
Quoting a research report by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Huang said that only 26 percent of mainland-bound Taiwan investment projects have used raw materials, parts and components from Taiwan.
By comparison, he said, counterparts in Southeast Asian countries purchased 72 percent of their raw materials, parts and components from Taiwan for their manufacturing overseas.

Huang added that mainland-bound Taiwanese companies have reduced their employment of Taiwanese employees by an average of 5 percent on a year-on-year basis, while Southeast Asia-bound counterparts have increased their employment rate in Taiwan by 5.6 percent.

He said the government should do something positive before it is too late given that the mainland has gradually and increasingly reduced its reliance on Taiwan for economic expansion while suppressing Taiwan businessmen via political means.

However, Huang's theories were discounted by all the other speakers at the round table meeting, including Tsai Hung-ming, deputy secretary-general of the Chinese National Federation of Industries; Hung Teh-sheng, vice president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research; and Lin Tzu-chia, an economics professor at National Chengchi University, all of whom noted that mainland-bound Taiwanese businessmen are just like all other investors elsewhere in the world in that profits are their only concern.

They argued that the most imperative thing that the government should do now is to improve Taiwan's investment climate. If Taiwan investors find that their investments in Taiwan will make money, they will naturally direct their funds and technology back to Taiwan from the mainland, the round-table participants pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER MEETS WITH AMCHAM PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Friday that a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States would be in the interests of both countries and expressed the hope that the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei will help bring about the signing of such an agreement.

The premier made the remarks when he met with AmCham President Andrea Wu and other AmCham members at the Executive Yuan. Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Hu Sheng-cheng, Finance Minister Lin Chuan, Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh, Public Construction Commission Chairwoman Kuo Yao-chi and other related government officials were also present to exchange views with AmCham members.

The meeting came after AmCham published its 2004 Taiwan White Paper June 1 in which it strongly urges the opening of direct transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, saying that without these, Taiwan's goal of becoming a regional hub will be in jeopardy and the island risks being marginalized in the fiercely competitive environment.

The premier expressed his appreciation for the long-term support of American businessmen and asked related government agency heads to reflect upon the suggestions by the American enterprises, adding that globalization and liberalization are established policies of the administration.
Yu also explained to them Taiwan's efforts in the liberalization of the flow of talent and capital and on the crackdown on the violation of intellectual property rights over the years.

Noting that stable cross-strait relations are still the focus of his administration, he also said that direct cross-strait transportation links will involve discussion of government authorities and will need judicial assistance. He expressed hope that the United States will play the role of a mediator to bring about such cross-strait talks.
Yu also said that one of the major tasks of his administration is to sign an FTA with the United States and he expressed the hope that AmCham members will convey this back to Washington.

Wu will lead an AmCham delegation to Washington, D.C. from June 13-16. The annual "Washington door-knocking" trip will involve calls on leading members of Congress and key executive-branch agencies involved with economic relations with Taiwan, as well as think tanks.

Noting that American enterprises are increasing their investments in Taiwan every year, the premier said a speeding-up of globalization and liberalization will be in the interests of both Taiwan and the United States.

He stressed that Taiwan has demonstrated its utmost sincerity in dealing with Beijing, citing as examples the expansion of offshore transshipment centers and the more convenient cross-strait cargo transportation.
But he said that direct cross-strait transportation will require consultations and that he hopes American businesses can play the role of mediator to bring about such consultations.

On AmCham's concern about the protection of pharmaceutical data exclusivity, the premier promised that he would see to it that a revision of the Law of Pharmaceutical Affairs will give a set of clear-cut regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS URGE PASSAGE OF EDUCATION-BOOSTING BUDGET LEGISLATION

TEXT.P: Presidents of 23 public and privately run universities around Taiwan appealed to the Legislative Yuan Friday for the passage of a five-year NT$50 billion budget plan to upgrade higher education in the country.

Twenty-three varsity presidents, including National Chengchi University President Cheng Juei-cheng, National Taiwan University President Wei-jao Chen and Shih Hsin University President Paul T. Mu signed an endorsement pushing for the passage of the budget plan for the development of "first-class universities and top-notch research centers" as part of the Executive Yuan's five-year NT$500 billion national development plan.

In the written endorsement, the presidents called for legislators from across the political spectrum to pass the education budget plan, stressing that Taiwan's international competitiveness hinges on an upgrading of the standards of higher education institutes and related research centers.

They also called for the legislators -- who have begun to screen a special statute governing public investments -- to remove a legislative article that sets restrictions on current accounts and capital accounts in educational institutions.
The academics want the existing restrictions -- that a school's current account spending should not exceed a half of the school's capital account -- repealed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MARRIAGE RATE DOWN SLIGHTLY, WHILE NUMBER OF FOREIGN BRIDES UP

TEXT.P: Taiwan witnessed a total of 173,000 weddings in 2003, with nearly 30 percent of the brides being nationals of mainland China or Southeast Asian countries, the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported Friday.

The latest MOI tallies show that 173,000 couples tied the knot in Taiwan last year, down 0.2 percent from the year-earlier level, representing a marriage rate of about 0.77 percent for the Taiwan area. The 2003 marriage rate was about 0.005 percentage points lower than that posted in 2002, MOI officials said.

The number of newlyweds from abroad, however, increased during the same period, with the number foreign-national bridegrooms (including those from Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China) increasing by 1,448, and the number of foreign-national brides (including those from Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China) growing by 3,557 over the previous year's figure, according to the MOI statistics.

In 2003, 3.4 percent of the bridegrooms in Taiwan were foreign or mainland Chinese nationals, while 28 percent of the brides were. Of the latter group, nearly 65 percent were mainland Chinese citizens, and nearly 35 percent were nationals from Southeast Asia.

In 2003, the average age of the bridegrooms was 33.8 years old, compared with 28.4 years old for the brides. A breakdown of the brides' ages show that Taiwanese brides' average age was 28.3, compared with 31.3 for mainland Chinese brides, and 23.6 for Southeast Asian brides.

The Washington Post: Use of Dogs to Scare Prisoners Was Authorized; Military Intelligence Personnel Were Involved, Handlers Say.
U.S. intelligence personnel ordered military dog handlers at the Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq to use unmuzzled dogs to frighten and intimidate detainees during interrogations late last year, a plan approved by the highest-ranking military intelligence officer at the facility, according to sworn statements the handlers provided to military investigators.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF APPRECIATES LEGISLATIVE PASSAGE OF RTC EXTENSION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) said Friday it appreciates the Legislative Yuan's passage of a draft package of revisions to the Statute Governing the Financial Restructuring Fund that will allow for a one-year extension of the fund.
The ministry expressed its gratitude after the opposition-controlled Legislature passed the amendment bill at a plenary session earlier in the day.

Under the original law, the Financial Restructuring Fund, which is patterned after the Resolution Trust Corporation (RTC) invented in the United States in the 1980s to resolve bad loan issues created by poorly-managed or bankrupt credit cooperatives, will be invalidated July 10. The MOF has used business taxes paid by local banks and other financial institutions to set up the Financial Restructuring Fund.
The MOF said the restructuring fund should be extended for one year as it takes more time to resolve issues left by certain sloppily managed financial institutions.
"The restructuring fund has played a key role in the implementation of our current financial reform projects, " said Chang Ming-tao, director of the MOF's Bureau of Monetary Affairs.

Meanwhile, Chang said he hopes the Legislature can pass certain other regulations before Oct. 19 so that the scale of the restructuring fund can be further expanded. If this goal can be reached, Chang said, creditors of poorly managed banks or credit departments of grass-roots farmers' and fishermen's associations that are taken over by the MOF before Jan. 15, 2005, will be able to get full repayment of their non-deposit investments.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR APOLOGIZES FOR VERBAL ATTACK ON AIT HEAD

TEXT.P: A Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker on Friday apologized for what he referred to as any confusion or misunderstanding that his comments three days earlier may have caused for the U.S. government.

Legislator Lin Chung-mo on Tuesday had criticized Douglas Paal, director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), by referring to him as a "vicious dog." The AIT is an unofficial organization dealing with U.S.-Taiwan relations in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Lin made the apology in a short statement at a venue of the DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan, saying he was doing so based on considerations of the national interest.

A day earlier, Lin had defiantly refused calls by opposition legislators for an apology for his "vulgar" comment by insisting he would "never" say sorry to Paal. Lin went even further by saying he planned to hold a press conference Friday to ask Washington to recall Paal.

However, the DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan suggested to Lin that he cancel the press conference and make an appropriate apology in order to prevent the matter from having any further negative impact on Taiwan-U.S. relations.
When giving the apology, Lin explained his about-face by saying that he is capable of changing his position when it is in the nation's interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 11, or the 24th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1864: Richard Strauss, German composer, is born. He is known chiefly for his symphonic poems, such as "Don Quixote," and his operas, including "Salome."
1880: Jeannette Rankin, American reformer, pacifist, and politician, is born. A leader in the women's suffrage movement in Montana, she later was elected as a U.S. House of Representatives and was the only legislator to oppose American involvement in both world wars.
1922: Li Yuan-hung resumes the presidency following the resignation of Hsu Shih-chang as president of the Peking government.
1940: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini declares war on the Allies.
1955: Twenty-two years of Liberal rule ends in Canada with the federal election victory of the Progressive Conservatives, headed by John G. Diefenbaker.
1963: Buddhist monk Quang Duc sets fire to himself in Saigon to protest the South Vietnamese government's treatment of Buddhists.
1968: The National Taiwan University Hospital announces that its first kidney transplant operation, performed on May 27, was successful.
1969: Soviet and communist Chinese troops clash on the Sinkiang border.
1972: Chen Ta-ching assumes the office of defense minister of the Republic of China.
1974: The opening ceremony of the 20th Asian Film Festival is held in Taipei and is presided over by Fredrick F. Chien, director-general of the Government Information Office. Nearly 400 performers, directors and producers attend the festival.
1976: China Airlines signs a US$86.4 million loan agreement with an international banking syndicate led by Citibank for the purchase of one Boeing 747SP, one 747, and three 737s.
1979: John Wayne, veteran Hollywood star, dies at the age of 72. Known as "Duke," the American actor played tough heroes in cowboy movies such as "Stagecoach," "Red River" and "True Grit," winning an Academy Award for his role in the latter.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates an order to resume in December the election of additional central parliamentarians, suspended Dec. 16, 1978 when the United States announced the severance of diplomatic relations with the Republic of China.
1981: A strong earthquake rocks Iran, killing more than 1,000 people and destroying the town of Golbaf in Kerman province.
1983: Zhu Jianhua, an athlete from mainland China, breaks the men's high jump record by clearing 2.37 meters.
1989: Michael Chang, 17, an ethnic Chinese American, beats Stefan Edberg of Sweden and becomes the youngest-ever winner of the French Open tennis championships.
1993: President Lee Teng-hui receives former Philippine President Corazon Aquino.
1995: International Business Machines of the United States purchases and merges with the Lotus corporation after investing US$3.52 billion.
1999: The United States, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and the European Union sign a new, multilateral joint statement on semiconductors designed to ensure fair and open global trading in the chips industry.
1999: The Chinese-Taipei taekwondo team returns to Taipei from the 1999 World Taekwondo Championships in Canada with two gold and four bronze medals.
2000: Officials from 30 Asian-Pacific cities reach an agreement at "the 2000 Asia-Pacific Cultural Summit" in Taipei to establish a mechanism for the promotion of cultural exchanges.
2000: An earthquake measuring 6.7 on the open-ended Richter scale hits the central Taiwan county of Nantou, injuring 16 people.
2001: Panamanian Minister of Commerce and Industry Joaquin Jacome Diez arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If you are considerate to others, you will win the hearts of the people. If you are trustworthy, men will trust you. If you are diligent, you will be successful in your undertakings. If you are generous, you will find plenty of men who are willing to serve you."

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY GOVERNMENT MARKS POLICE DAY

TEXT.P: The Police Department of Kaohsiung County Government celebrated Police Day Saturday with a series of lively activities, with juvenile delinquents at a local reformatory school also participating in the activities.
More than 500 guests participated in the celebration activities, which focused on performances by youths, including traditional Chinese dragon dancing, street dancing, and a drum performance.

In addition to honoring some 60 distinguished and veteran police officers, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing urged the Kaohsiung County Police Department to introduce a more humane work scheme to reduce the level of stress on police officers.
Meanwhile, a group of student representatives made a public vow to pursue a healthy life without committing crimes, abusing drugs, running away from home, or skipping classes.

DOC.HEADLINE: REAGAN REGRETTED BEING UNABLE TO DO MORE FOR TAIWAN: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Late U.S. President Ronald Reagan was very devoted to the Republic of China and regretted that he was unable to do more for Taiwan during his term in office due to the political realities of the time, the ROC's special envoy to Reagan's state funeral said Friday.

Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, who represented President Chen Shui-bian in attending the late U.S. president's national funeral service at Washington National Cathedral, made the remarks while meeting with Taiwan media stationed in the U.S. capital.
Reagan, 94, died at his home in California on June 5 after a ten-year battle with Alzheimer's disease. He served two terms as U.S. from 1981 to 1989.

Chien, who served as Taiwan's top representative to the United States from 1983 to 1988, said that he could "see it in Reagan's eyes" every time he shook hands with the president that he felt sorry for not being able to do more for Taiwan.

Pointing out that he and Chen Chien-jen, Taiwan's current representative to the United States, who was Chien's deputy at the time, had met with Reagan several times, the special envoy said that he perceived Reagan's dynamism and his love and friendship for the ROC every time he met with him.

Chien also revealed that late ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo had given him two instructions before he was sent to the United States to assume his post as top representative, namely to always show patience and to comply with Reagan's requests.
After attending the funeral, Chien, who arrived in Washington, D.C., Thursday, will leave for Colorado where he will join ROC Foreign Minister Chen Tan-sun to attend the World Forum's annual meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHANG CHENG-HSIUNG TO BE NEW CEC CHIEF

TEXT.P: Chang Cheng-hsiung, a commissioner of the Central Election Commission (CEC), has agreed to serve as the new chief of the commission, Cabinet sources said Saturday.
Chang, a lawyer who has no party affiliation, will succeed Huang Shih-cheng as the new CEC chairman. Huang's tenure will expire June 16.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun asked Chang June 7 whether he would fill the position to be left vacant by Huang's departure, the Cabinet sources said, adding that Chang gave a positive answer to Yu Saturday evening.

Although the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan passed a new bill Friday that requires legisaltive approval of the appointment of new CEC chief, this new regulation cannot be applied to Chang's new assignment because the bill has not been formally promulgated.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER YU URGES YOUNG PEOPLE TO DELIVER MORE BABIES

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun encouraged young people Saturday to show their love for Taiwan by delivering more babies.

Yu made the appeal in a speech delivered at a commencement at National Sun Yat-sen University in the southern Taiwan port city of Kaohsiung. The commencement was unprecedentedly held at the Hsitzuwan beach at sunset.
In addition to giving his congratulations and best wishes to new graduates, Yu urged them to give birth to more children as a way to show their patriotism.

Yu said Taiwan's birth rate has fallen even below those registered in the United States, France, Germany and Singapore. declined. In 2003, 100 couples in Taiwan gave birth to 122 babies, compared to America's 200, France's 190, Germany's 140 and Singapore's 134.
Should this trend continue, Yu said, Taiwan's population will decline from the current 23 million to 19 million by 2054.

"With our population greying and the childbirth rate declining, our social burden will increase further. Therefore, I hope young people can deliver more babies to inject new blood and vitality into our society," Yu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND RECONSIDERS WHETHER TO REMOVE 3 ARMED FORCES GENERAL HEADQUARTERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) confirmed a newspaper report Saturday that it is reconsidering a previous plan to either marginalize or cancel the army, navy and air force general headquarters and to merge various military academies.

MND spokesman Maj. Gen. Huang Suey-sheng said Defense Minister Lee Jye indeed told lawmakers during a recent closed-door meeting that he has ordered a re-evaluation of the previous plan to marginalize the three armed forces general headquarters and merge relevant military academies.

The "headquarters marginalization and military academies merger" plan was initiated by former Defense Minister Tang Yiau-min as part of his second-stage troops reduction project with an aim to establish an elite deterrent force in the face of mainland China's military threat.

Tang intended to marginalize the army, navy and air force general headquarters so that Taiwan's armed forces will become the "national defense force" without clear division into three separate branches to save resources and enhance operational efficiency. Against this backdrop, Tang also pushed for a 10-year plan to merge existing army, navy and air force academies and several other military schools into an armed forces university and several professional military research institutes.

According to media reports, Tang's plan had met lukewarm response from Lee who was then chief of the General Staff. Lee reportedly didn't think that the general headquarters of the three military branches should be marginalized or canceled. Without the existence of separate general headquarters to handle manpower training and logistic support, Lee said, each military branch might not be able to realize their missions smoothly.

And consequently, Lee was quoted as having said, the army, navy and air force academies should not be merged because different military branch needs different school to train cadets to meet its particular needs.

Acting on Lee's instruction, MND spokesman Huang said the ministry is now re-assessing whether to marginalize or remove the army, navy and air force general headquarters and whether to merge various military academies.
"We are also working on a new military restructuring plan with a view to trimming redundant military personnel and units while beefing up our overall defense capabilities," Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT HOLDS SENIOR CITIZENS SPORTS EVENT

TEXT.P: Taipei City Government on Saturday held a sports event for senior citizens for the first time at the Taipei Track and Field Stadium, with a 92-year-old man who had competed in the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin lighting the torch to open the games.
Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou, a sports enthusiast, attended the event, which included swimming and ball sports competitions as well as several performances by seniors.

Ma pointed out that he has noticed while participating in long-distance races over the last few years that there have been many senior citizen participants, which he said indicates that more and more elderly people are showing concern for their own health and exercising.
He indicated that senior citizens account for more than 11 percent of Taipei's population, representing the highest percentage among cities and counties around the island.
In order to create an excellent sports environment, the city government will organize more athletic activities and construct more health centers around the city, Ma said.

The mayor added that people should continue exercising, stressing that age should not be an excuse for not staying fit. Ma had said recently at a swimming competition for physically- and mentally-challenged people that he wanted to keep exercising until 2038, when he will be 88-years-old.
Ma urged elderly residents to come out and exercise to make Taipei the city with the healthiest senior citizen population.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:

The legislature passes landmark labor pension scheme.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR LEAVES FOR SOUTH KOREA TO ATTEND WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou left for the South Korean city of Inchon Saturday to attend the Asia Strategic Insight Roundtable to be sponsored by the World Economic Forum (WEF).

Ma said prior to his departure that he will speak on Taiwan's general economic situation and its basic stance on cross-Taiwan Strait relations at the two-day meeting, which has "an Asian outlook" and "a dynamic Northeast Asia" as its main themes.
In his view, Ma said, political stability and regional peace are prerequisites for the Asian economy to reach yet another pinnacle of development.

Ma said he will take advantage of the occasion to express the Taiwan people's common desires for improving cross-strait relations, maintaining permanent regional peace and actively taking part in regional efforts to boost Asian economic integration.

"I'll convey our country's wishes to sign free trade agreements with major Asian countries and take part in regional economic integration as well as to forge rapprochement with mainland China, " Ma said.

During his visit, Ma said, he will attend a closed-door luncheon to be hosted by South Korean President Roh Moo-jyun at the presidential Blue House Monday in honor of all participants in the roundtable.

Other participants at the roundtable will include Singapore Deputy Prime Minister and Defense Minister Tony Tan Keng Yam; Japanese Finance Minister Heizo Takenaka; Mongolian Foreign Affairs Minister and Senior Adviser to the Prime Minister Luvsangiin Erdenechuluun; Andrei Illarionov, economic adviser to the Russian president; Shanghai Mayor Song Yuanfang; and senior executives of noted Asian business groups.
Ma attended the WEF-sponsored roundtable held in Singapore last October.

Besides attending the Inchon roundtable, Ma said he will meet with Seoul Mayor Lee Myung-bak and tour major infrastructure construction projects in the city, including a river clean-up project, as well as visit the city's youth service agency and Internet cafe management agency. He will also visit Busan to meet with that city's mayor and visit the main stadium where the 2002 Asian Games were held.

Ma is accompanied by several city government officials on his South Korean visit, including Environmental Protection Bureau Director Chen Yung-jen and Bureau of Public Works Director Chen Wei-jen. He is scheduled to return to Taiwan Tuesday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: VEGETARIAN FOODS SUSPECTED OF CONTAINING ANIMAL INGREDIENTS SEIZED

TEXT.P: The Health Department of Kaohsiung County Government on Saturday seized vegetarian products suspected of containing animal ingredients in raids on several vegetarian food factories and markets around the county.
Under orders from the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) , Kaohsiung County Government health officials carried out the raids to investigate whether the products contained animal ingredients.
The raids were made following a legislator's claim that 70 percent of 21 vegetarian products examined by the DOH were found to contain animal ingredients.

The health officials found in the raids that some vegetarian-labeled products from a factory in Yenchao Village might contain animal products. The owner of the factory admitted it at first, but later denied it. The officials then took seven samples for further tests.
The officials said that if the vegetarian foods are found to contain animal ingredients, the factory will be fined between NT$40,000 (US$1,194) and NT$200,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUALIEN RESIDENT BAGS NT$600,000 FOR QUITTING SMOKE

TEXT.P: Hualien County resident Chang Chien-kuo got the sweetest taste of quitting smoking when he bagged the top prize of NT$600,000 (US$17,910) in a 2004 "quit and win" contest Saturday.

The John Tung Foundation, which sponsored the contest, congratulated Chang and all the other participants in the contest for their determination to bid farewell to cigarettes and move toward a more healthy lifestyle.
Foundation officials said that 30,096 people took part in this year's contest, with Chang being chosen as the luckiest winner in a random computer draw.

Chang, 33, a four-year-smoker who at one time puffed up to 50 cigarettes a day, said he made up his mind to quit after learning that his wife was pregnant early this year. Encouraged and supported by his wife, he said he was able to kick the habit.

Minister of the Department of Health Chen Chien-jen, speaking on the same occasion, noted that over 50 percent of people in Taiwan start smoking before the age of 18 and that the number of deaths resulting from smoking in Taiwan totals 18,000 a year.
He also noted that the direct medical costs to Taiwan from smoking totals NT$16 billion a year, with the indirect social costs reaching as high as NT$50 billion.
The nation's top health official said that quitting smoking is not only an act of self-love, but also an act of love toward one's family and friends.

The successful quitters cited different reasons for wanting to kick the tobacco habit, with one father saying that he decided to quit after seeing his three-year-old son mimicking his puffing manner. But all those who successfully quit said that they are happy and want to share their happiness with their families and others about taking on the "impossible mission."

John Tung Foundation Chairman Lai Tung-ming, in handing out a prize to one of the contest winners, Fu Hsueh-li, 58, who smoked for 30 years and is the cousin of Miaoli County Magistrate Fu Hsueh-peng, urged Fu to relate his experience to the magistrate and encourage the latter to participate in the contest next year.

The "quit and win" contest was initiated in 1980 in the United States, and under the support of the World Health Organization, an international quit smoking contest was formally launched in 1994. By 2002, 670,000 people in 76 countries had taken part in the international contest.

Taiwan held the contest simultaneously with the international community this year. According to the contest rules, each participant must find a non-smoking witness to take part in the contest as their partner during the four-week period of the contest, which ran from May 2 to May 29 this year. The participants must also undergo tests for nicotine and carbon monoxide during the four weeks, as well as periodic testing for one year after the contest ends.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS HIS OVERSEAS TRAVEL PLAN HAS YET TO TAKE SHAPE

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Saturday that his overseas travel plan has yet to take shape and that he will brief the press on the itinerary when the planning work is finalized.

Yu was responding to press inquiries about his view on Vice President Annette Lu's remarks at a news conference a day earlier that both President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Yu will visit the Republic of China's diplomatic allies in Central America and the Caribbean in the near future following her just-concluded, three-leg Central American tour that took her to El Salvador, Costa Rica and Guatemala.
Yu said it is still in the planning stage whether he will take advantage of the current legislative recess to make an overseas journey to further cement Taiwan's relations with its diplomatic allies.
"If a concerted overseas travel plan takes shape, I'll certainly brief the press on my itinerary," Yu said.
The opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan went into summer recess after a grueling marathon session Friday.

While expressing his gratitude for the Legislature's approval of several critical reform bills on the final day of its fifth legislative session, Yu said he feels regret over the fact that the Legislature only approved 23 of the 149 "priority" bills initiated by the Cabinet.

Yu said he hopes the Legislature can hold an extraordinary session in the near future to screen over 300 bills that remain stalled and are crucial to the government's various reform plans, including the draft national pension bill, the four "sunshine" bills designed to establish clean politics, and the packages of revisions to three major existing labor laws.
Addressing a commencement at National Taipei College of Nursing, Yu encouraged new graduates to dedicate themselves to serving patients and to continue pursuing professional expertise and excellence.

As Taiwan society is greying with the number of people aged over 65 increasing rapidly, Yu said he hopes all nursing college graduates can support the government's policy of encouraging childbirth by delivering more babies themselves.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSU TO BE FORMALLY INAUGURATED AS PARTY TUESDAY

TEXT.P: An official of the planned Non-Partisan Solidarity Union (NSU), a new political party initiated by independent legislators, said Saturday the party will be formally inaugurated next Tuesday as scheduled.
NSU Secretary General Chen Chieh-ju made the remarks after a review committee of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) raised questions about using the term "non-partisan" in the name of the new party.
Chen said that the party has been in the planning for some time, adding that if the MOI has any opinions about the NSU, the party is willing to communicate with the ministry.
The party will apply to and register with the MOI as scheduled, adding that "there is no plan to change the name," he said.
He said that the party has drafted a charter and is scheduled to form a 21-member central standing committee, with current legislators serving as the natural central standing committee members.

As to when Chang Po-ya, chairwoman of the new party's preparatory committee, will become the party's chairwoman, he said that the party will not rule out the possibility of calling for an extraordinary central standing committee meeting to nominate her for the post.

Chang, a health minister during the latter part of the era of Kuomintang (KMT) rule, mentioned earlier that the establishment of the NSU will effectively offer a "third" or "middle-way" choice for the people of Taiwan, who she said have long been divided into two camps -- the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its two splinter parties, namely the People First Party and the New Party, and the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union.

The new party's 40-odd founders include some well-known politicians such as Chang, former Hsinchu Mayor Shih Hsin-chung, and 10 of the 13 independent lawmakers in the Legislative Yuan who have grouped together under the Alliance of Independent Legislators banner.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER PROPOSES DISBANDING OF FACTIONS WITHIN THE PARTY

TEXT.P: A lawmaker from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Saturday he will propose the disbanding of factions within the party following President Chen Shui-bian's announcement that party officials should step out from faction operations.

Legislator Wang Hsing-nan said that he will present his proposal, which has already obtained the endorsement of more than 50 of the party's lawmakers, to the DPP National Party Congress to be held in July for more support.

Wang noted that his proposal stipulates that DPP members should not establish factions, including the forming of faction offices, the recruiting of members, or the convening of policy meetings, and that those who violate the rules should have their party membership rights suspended for one to two years.

Reaction to the proposal has been mixed, with some party members saying that the DPP's faction problems are serious and should be resolved immediately, and others considering factions to be a natural thing.

Mainstream faction lawmaker Trong Chai noted that although there are factions when there are political parties, he opposes the establishment of faction offices and the recruitment of faction members, which he said would undermine the DPP's reputation.

He stressed that party factions should not be institutionalized as this would strengthen the power and interests of the factions. If the trend continues, the interests of the factions will replace those of the party or of the nation, he claimed.

Former Taichung City Mayor Chang Wen-ying, who withdrew from the DPP in order to campaign for re-election after the party didn't nominate her, said that some DPP factions have been working eagerly to grasp power, resulting in an imbalance in the party's development.
If the faction problems are not properly handled, it will damage the DPP's solidarity and operations in the future, Chang added.

Legislator Tsai Huang-liang, secretary-general of the Justice Alliance faction, suggested that people "review" the factions instead of dismissing them, noting that the factions in the DPP have played a role as a stabilizing force in the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAD URGES MERGER OF OPPOSITION PARTIES TO FORM MIDDLE-WAY FORCE

TEXT.P: Chairman Lien Chan of the opposition Kuomintang kicked off his post-election, island-wide "thanksgiving" journey in Keelung, northern Taiwan Saturday by calling for an integration of the opposition parties to form a middle-way force.

Lien lost to incumbent President Chen Shui-bian in the March 20 presidential election by a razor-thin margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million cast, but Lien has yet to concede defeat and has filed two lawsuits to contest Chen's re-election victory and call for the nullification of the election so that a new one can be held.
Lien, accompanied by KMT Vice Chairman Ma Ying-jeou and KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng, came together with grass-roots KMT cadres and elected representatives in Keelung in a meeting.
Claiming that "democracy used to be the pride of Taiwan" but that it is "now faced with an unprecedented crisis, " Lien said that the process of the presidential election was not fair or just.

He said that democracy cannot operate without a system of checks and balances, adding that the KMT not only needs to unite itself, it needs to invite those who share the same ideals to work toward the goal of democracy.
He said the KMT, the People First Party, the New Party and the independents must move from cooperation toward merger, forming "a middle-way, rational and plural" force.
He said that the goal will be to integrate the opposition parties to win more than half of the 225 seats in the Legislative Yuan in the year-end elections.

Ma, who presided over the meeting, noted that world renowned Chinese-American forensic expert Henry Lee came to Taiwan to help investigate the election-eve shooting of President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu.

Even though Lee confirmed that both suffered from gunshot wounds, he pointed out the shooting was not a political assassination, Ma said, adding that this is why the KMT and the PFP want an investigation to get to the bottom of the incident, which they believe unfairly swayed the bitterly contested election in Chen's favor.
Ma also talked about the defects and negligence uncovered in the the vote recount process.

He also spoke of the significance of a merger of the KMT and the PFP, saying that democracy depends on a system of checks and balances and that the system now hinges on the "pan-blue alliance " of the KMT and its two splinter parties of the PFP and the New Party.

But he also said that in addition to a merger, reforms are needed, saying that the pace of reforms concerning party affairs, party assets and intraparty democratization must be quick enough so that it will be "felt by the general public."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POLITICIANS URGED TO PROMOTE NATIONAL RECONCILIATION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 11 (CNA) (By Oliver Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Wise Taiwan politicians should take effective measures to promote national reconciliation, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien said in Washington, D.C., Friday.

Chien, who attended the state funeral of the late U.S. President Ronald Reagan on behalf of ROC President Chen Shui-bian earlier in the day, made the appeal while meeting with a group of Taiwan journalists stationed in the U.S. capital.

Chien, a former career diplomat who served as the ROC's minister of foreign affairs from 1990 through 1996, encountered a demonstration launched by supporters of Taiwan's opposition "pan-blue alliance" when he arrived in Washington on Thursday as President Chen's special envoy to Reagan's funeral.

The "pan-blue alliance" ticket of Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong lost to incumbent President Chen and Vice President Annette Lu by a razor-thin margin of 29,518 votes, or 0.228 percent of the more than 13 million ballots cast in the March 20 presidential election.

Lien and Soong have so far refused to concede defeat and have filed two lawsuits to challenge the Chen-Lu ticket's re-election victory and to demand an annulment of the election so that a new one can be held.

With Chen's consent, a full-scale judicial recount of the ballots cast in the bitterly fought election has been completed. No solid evidence has been found to back up the alliance's claim that the election was rigged. The Taiwan High Court has yet to mete out rulings on the two law suits.

Chien said the election outcome indicates that Taiwan society has become polarized, a situation similar to that faced by Reagan during the early days of his eight-year presidency. When Reagan took the helm in January 1981, Chien said, U.S. society was still covered by the shadows of the Vietnam War and the Watergate scandal of the previous decade.
In the face of a divided society, Chien said, it's imperative that politicians use wisdom to promote national reconciliation and heel the wounds and rifts.
As the head of the nation's supreme watchdog body, Chien said he is not in a position to talk about domestic political issues, such as how to achieve national reconciliation.

Nevertheless, Chien mentioned that President Chen had already declared in his May 20 inaugural speech that he would not push for changes to the national title and flag while carrying out constitutional reforms during his second term to avoid provoking mainland China which has threatened to attack Taiwan should the island pursue de jure independence.
During a meeting late last month with senior executives of foreign financial groups with interests in Taiwan, Chien said, President Chen had reaffirmed his commitment to no provocation to Beijing.

As to the post-election disputes, Chien said the Control Yuan has formed a special task force to investigate why relevant government authorities had failed to take effective measures to prevent the occurrence of the March 19 shooting of President Chen and Vice President Lu, whether there was a national security mechanism to be activated in an emergency situation like the post-March 19 shooting, and whether the simultaneous holding of a nationwide referendum on the presidential election day had caused any problems to the presidential election itself.
Starting in July, Chien said, the Control Yuan team will publish a series of comprehensive investigative reports on all those issues.

As for the criminal investigations into the election-eve shooting, Chien said it's none of the Control Yuan business. "It's up to law enforcement authorities to investigate who was involved in the criminal case," he added.
Touching on Taiwan's government restructuring plan, Chien said the Control Yuan should continue to exist to supervise the executive branch's operations.
"The Control Yuan's function is like that of an independent director of a business corporation. It can supervise the Cabinet's operations without any political interference," Chien said.

In his view, he went on, such supervisory power should not be delegated to the Legislative Yuan as some people have suggested because the Legislature is a political body and cannot be free of partisan influence in its operations.

In the run-up to the 2004 presidential election, President Chen often assured voters that he wouldn't cave in to Beijing, and he often questioned his sole challenger Lien Chan's willingness to stand up to Beijing. Political and ethnic divisions have become more serious after Taiwan-born Chen narrowly defeated mainland China-born Lien.

Except for a small group of aboriginal tribes, most of Taiwan's 23 million people are ethnic Chinese. But the population can be divided into two sub-ethnic groups: the "mainlanders" whose families fled to Taiwan when the Chinese Communists took over the mainland in 1949, and the "native Taiwanese" whose ancestors began arriving on the island in the 17th century or earlier.

The mainlanders, about 15 percent of the population, have largely supported the "pan-blue alliance, " whose support base is in northern Taiwan. The native Taiwanese tend to favor the "pan-green camp" of Chen's Democratic Progressive Party and its smaller ally the Taiwan Solidarity Union, whose support base is in southern Taiwan.
The mainlanders have traditionally supported eventual unification with mainland China, while the native Taiwanese lean more toward formal independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOOD TAIPEI 2004 TO KICK OFF JUNE 17

TEXT.P: "Food Taipei 2004, " the 14th Taipei International Food Show, is scheduled to kick off June 17 at the Exhibition Hall of the Taipei World Trade Center with the participation of 741 exhibitors from 23 countries around the world.

According to the China External Trade Development Council (CETDC), the organizer of the event, the four-day food exhibition is primed to come back stronger than ever this year with an expanded menu of top exhibitors from across the industry after the show was canceled last year due to the outbreak of SARS.

The CETDC also said that in order to promote Taiwan's agricultural products, the Council of Agriculture is planning to push the Taiwan Provincial Association of Agriculture and other relevant local associations to jointly participate in the event by setting up a "Taiwan Pavilion" of 146 booths at the show.

Foreign exhibitors from twenty-three countries, including the United States, Japan, Spain, Canada, Australia, Ukraine and Slovenia, will also have their own national pavilions at the show, showing their strong intention to sell products in the Taiwan market, according to the CETDC.
With 1,469 booths in total, the first two days of the show will be reserved for buyers, while the last two days will be open to the public, the organizer said.

It also said that at the last show held in 2002, more than 52,000 people from food-related industries were attracted to visit the event, along with some 1,500 foreign buyers to sample the show's menu.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 12, or the 25th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1809: Pope Pius VII, originally Barnaba Gregorio Chiaramonti, who was forced to crown Napoleon Bonaparte emperor in 1804, excommunicates him.
1924: George Bush, the 41st president of the United States, is born. Before becoming president, the Republican politician served as U.S. ambassador to the United Nations and China, director of the Central Intelligence Agency, and vice president under Ronald Reagan.
1929: Anne Frank, the Dutch Jewish schoolgirl and wartime diarist, is born in Germany. In hiding from the Nazis, she wrote her famous diary before being taken to her death in a German concentration camp in March 1945 at the age of 16.
1938: China's Yellow River ruptures a dike, killing some 150,000 people.
1944: Chinese communist leader Mao Zedong announces that he will support Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek, chairman of China's National Military Council, in the War of Resistance Against Japan.
1947: Chinese troops recapture Peitashan in Sinkiang Province from Mongolian troops which are aided by the Soviet Union in their invasion of the northwestern province of China.
1964: South Africa's Nelson Mandela and seven others are sentenced to life imprisonment.
1973: China Airlines inaugurates night flight services between the Taiwan cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
1976: Juan Maria Bordaberry, president of Uruguay, is overthrown and replaced by Alberto Demichelli.
1978: A strong earthquake rocks Miyagi prefecture in Japan, killing 38 people and injuring more than 1,000 others.
1978: Kuo Mojo, a Chinese communist writer, dies in Beijing at the age of 86.
1979: American Bryan Allen pedals his way across the English Channel in a human-powered aircraft to win a US$185,000 prize.
1979: Mohammed Ali Khoguir, charge d'affaires of the Saudi Arabian Embassy in the Republic of China, presents US$100,000 to National Chung Hsing University to establish a graduate school of Arabic.
1980: Tsiang Yen-si, secretary-general of the Kuomintang, cables condolences to Yasuhiro Nakasone, secretary-general of the Japanese Liberal Democratic Party, on the death of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira.
1982: The 16th Ministerial Conference on Economic Cooperation between the ROC and the Republic of Korea ends, with both countries pledging to cement closer cooperation in trade and technology.
1987: Britain's Conservative Party leader Margaret Thatcher, who in 1979 became the first woman ever to hold the office of British prime minister, is elected for the third time. She served in the post for over 11-and-a-half years, longer than any other British prime minister in the 20th century.
1987: Jean-Bedel Bokassa, former emperor of the Central African Republic, is sentenced to death for crimes committed during his 13-year rule.
1987: The ROC's Democratic Progressive Party leads its supporters in a demonstration outside the Legislative Yuan building in Taipei to protest against the National Security Law. In an ensuing clash with members of the Anti-Communist Patriotic Front, who support the National Security Law, several members from both sides are injured.
1991: In a referendum, the people of Leningrad vote by 55 percent to 43 percent to change the name of their city back to St. Petersburg.
1991: Boris Yeltsin beats five communist rivals in the country's first-ever democratic elections to become president of the Russian republic.
1998: The Japanese economy is in recession for the first time since the 1974-75 fiscal year.
2000: The 2000 World Congress of Information Technology kicks off its three-day session in Taipei with 1,500 experts and scholars from 80 countries around the world participating.
2001: The Republic of China opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan gives a speech at Oxford University in the United Kingdom in which he focuses on Taiwan's economic and political situations and the future of his party.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a thing is really hard, you may pound it and yet it will not crack; if a thing is really white, you may besmirch it, and yet it will not become black."

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRICITY SUPPLIES SECURED FOR THIS SUMMER: TAIPOWER

TEXT.P: Electricity supplies across the country for this summer will remain normal, despite widespread public concern that there might be a shortage due to factors at home and abroad, according to the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower).

Although the public are worried that electricity consumption will jump because of an improved economy, a Taipower official gave his assurances over the weekend that supplies this summer will be sufficient as the relevant agencies have made moves to tackle a possible power shortage resulting from rising fuel prices in the world market and a shortage of liquefied natural gas in the home market.
During the first five months of this year, the country's electricity supplies increased by 7.8 percent, marking a noticeable growth over the previous year's level of 3.2 percent.

According to the official, Taipower has asked Chinese Petroleum Corp. to increase its purchases of liquefied natural gas, while four newly opened power plants -- Chiahui, Kuokuang, Hsingchang and Fengte -- are to join the ranks with Taipower to provide supplies for industry.

The four power plants have a combined a capacity of 2.62 million kilowatts per month, which will help secure normal supplies in various regions, the official noted, adding that together with Taipower, a total of 35.38 million kilowatts of electricity will be secured each month.
Taipower estimates that single-month consumption in July and August may peak at around 29.8 million kilowatts and that it may break the 30 million kilowatt level -- a 15-year high.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO EARLY TO TALK ABOUT U.S.-TAIWAN FTA: BOFT

TEXT.P: It is too early to talk about the signing of a free trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the United States as the stances on both sides on relevant concerns are still hugely divided, a top trade official said Sunday.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that at present, he does not see any intent on the part of the United States to begin even assessing or talking about signing an FTA with Taiwan.

Trade officials were scheduled to meet in Taipei June 27-28 for bilateral talks on issues of mutual concern. However, the meeting has been sensationalized by the Taiwan media as a prelude paving the way for the two countries to eventually sign an FTA.

As a result, according to Huang, his U.S. counterparts informed him recently that big differences between the U.S. and Taiwan stances on many issues remain and that currently, the United States has not yet assessed the possibility of signing an FTA with Taiwan.
The U.S. officials said the Taiwan media should not have sensationalized the meeting so as to cause misunderstandings, according to Huang.

Huang said that officials from the two countries are expected to exchange views during the June 27-28 meeting on issues including intellectual property rights protection; Taiwan's rice imports; pharmaceutical data exclusivity and pricing system and Taiwan's opening of its fixed broadband infrastructure market. He added that there is a possibility that the meeting may be postponed.

According to Huang, Taiwan and the United States had indeed made attempts to make preparations for signing a bilateral FTA, which is why the two countries began talks on a trade and investment framework agreement (TIFA) . The TIFA was never signed and the Taiwan-U.S. TIFA talks have stalled as a result of differences between the two sides on many vital issues, Huang said.

Huang noted, however, that although the United States has stressed that it is not prepared to talk about a FTA with Taiwan, the BOFT may formally ask the United States to resume the TIFA talks first if the upcoming meeting is fruitful.

Meanwhile, a CNA reporter based in Geneva quoted the Bureau of National Affairs (BNA) Inc. Sunday as having reported that although the Executive Yuan has made signing an FTA with the United States a top priority in efforts to bolster trade with friendly countries, the United States suspects that Taiwan has political rather than economic motives in pushing for the signing of an FTA.

A reporter from the BNA -- the largest independent publisher in the United States of specialized news and information for professionals in business and government -- who visited Taiwan recently, reported this week that the building of FTA relations between Taiwan and the United States is entwined with complicated political wrangling involving not only the two sides but also mainland China.

While the U.S. suspects that Taiwan's motives for an FTA are political rather than economic, the Taiwan authorities have complained that the U.S. has stalled TIFA and FTA talks with Taiwan because of pressure from Beijing, the BNA report said.

The report reiterated Washington's stance that before Taiwan efficiently handles issues like opening its telecommunications market, revising its copyright law, intellectual property rights protection, pharmaceutical data exclusivity and pricing system and rice imports, the United States will not consider engaging in FTA talks with Taiwan.

In a meeting with American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei President Andrea Wu and other AmCham members at the Executive Yuan last Friday, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said that an FTA between Taiwan and the United States would be in the interests of both countries and expressed the hope that AmCham will help bring about the signing of such an agreement.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Washington Post: Al Qaeda Claims to Kidnap American; 2nd U.S. Contractor Killed in Saudi Arabia.
Islamic radicals in Saudi Arabia allied with al Qaeda said Saturday that they had kidnapped a U.S. military contractor in Riyadh, while in a separate incident, another American expatriate was gunned down at his house. The captive will be treated the way Iraqi prisoners were treated at the Abu Ghraib prison, the radicals said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: GMA appeals for unity
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo yesterday appealed for unity and cooperation among freedom- loving Filipinos, urging all citizens to put the tightly contested election behind them and work to reconcile differences to be able to move on as a nation.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Macapagal provides fireworks on rainy Independence Day MAYBE the rains were to blame. But Independence Day celebrations Saturday were nearly as cheerless as the weather, protests were small, and only President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo provided what little fire there was.
The Philippine Star: GMA: No more EDSAs for us
President Arroyo said yesterday the May 10 elections brought back the power of the ballot to the Filipinos, who no longer need to take to the streets to have the kind of leaders they want in office.

The Lianhe Zaobao: The safe environment in Singapore is a key selling point for attracting foreign investment here: says DPM Tony Tan
In Singapore, not only the loyal, industrious and high-quality labour force who satisfy all the foreign investors but also the safe environment is a key selling point for attracting foreign investment here, says Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Tony Tan in Japan when interviewed by Singapore's medias. Japanese companies are looking to Singapore as more than a manufacturing hub, says Dr Tan.
Dr Tan, who led a delegation to Tokyo aiming to expand trade and investment with Japan, found the world's second largest economy positive about expanding their businesses in Singapore.
He found the atmosphere of the corporate sector much improved compared to his visit 3 years ago, when Japan was still struggling to come out of recession.
Dr Tan said: "There's a positive mood to Japan among Japanese companies here. They're all doing well. They're talking about expansion and establishing new plans."
During the last 5 years, new investments in Singapore were between 1.2 billion to 1.8 billion dollars in fixed assets a year.
Trade between the two countries, during the period of January to April rose 20 percent this year, compared to the same period last year.

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen confirmed Sunday that he plans to travel to Europe in the near future to chair a meeting of the chiefs of Taiwan's representative offices in the region.
Chen said that the meeting will be held sometime in July, but added that the exact date and venue of the annual meeting are yet to be finalized.
Chen also revealed that Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Kau will visit Taiwan's diplomatic allies in the South Pacific.
Following instructions from President Chen Shui-bian, the minister said, Kau will represent the Republic of China at celebrations in Kiribati July 12 to mark the country's 25th anniversary.
Kau will also visit Tuvalu and the Solomon Islands after concluding his visit to Kiribati, which established diplomatic ties with Taiwan last November.
