DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA TIMES MOST POPULAR DAILY NEWSPAPERS IN TAIWAN: POLL

TEXT.P: China Times is the most popular daily newspaper in Taiwan, with the leading readership rate of 51.6 percent, according to the results of a survey released Sunday.

The Liberty Times and the United Daily News came second and third, with readership rates of 50.8 percent and 49 percent, respectively, in the public opinion poll carried out by Shih Hsing University on the market shares of Taiwan's mass communication media outlets.
The Liberty Times had the highest rate of 26.2 percent in terms of detail and faithful reporting, while China Times and the United Daily News scored 24.2 percent and 21.7 percent, respectively.

However, the Apple Daily, run by a Hong-based media group, led the three major dailies in terms of variety, with 31.8 percent. It was also rated by respondents to the survey as having the largest negative influence on society, with 27. 5 percent.

Formosa TV network was found to be the most public terrestrial TV station, while the FM channel of the Broadcasting Corporation of China (BCC) was selected as the most popular channel because of its well-projected programs.
BCC was also ranked as the most influential and the highest quality radio station, according to the survey.
Commonwealth and China Times Weekly magazines were rated as the best magazines in terms of content.
The poll surveyed 600 people aged between 15 and 64 living in the Taiwan area, and had a margin of error of 4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY 280,000 FOREIGN LABORERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: There were nearly 280,000 foreign laborers working in Taiwan at the end of April, according to statistics released Sunday by the National Police Administration (NPA).
Of the foreign laborers who had obtained Alien Residence Certificates, 119,000 were male and 160,500 were female, the statistics show.
Thailand was the largest foreign laborer supplier for Taiwan with 98,200, followed by the Philippines with 80,000, Vietnam with 60,100 and Indonesia with 41,300.

The manufacturing sector absorbed the largest number of foreign laborers with 159,400, followed by the caregiving sector with 105,300 and the construction industry with 9,100. Some 3,000 foreign laborers were serving as maids.
The statistics also show that Vietnamese constituted the largest proportion of the 12,439 absconders who had not yet been found thus far, with 5,463, followed by Indonesians with 3,548.
Vietnamese were also listed as having the largest absconding rate in terms of nationality with 396.87 per 10,000 during the January-April period, followed by Indonesians with 144.1 per 10,000.
A total of 3,668 foreign laborers ran away from their workplaces in the first four months this year, 689 up on the previous year's level, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN TO SUE TV TALK SHOW HOSTESS FOR SLANDER

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan has retained a lawyer to file a slander lawsuit against a TV talk show hostess and others after a guest on her show claimed that Lien and his family laundered cash in Lugano, a Swiss city that she described as a "city state."

Tsai Cheng-yuan, a KMT spokesman, said Saturday that it is ridiculous for the hostess and her guest to claim that Lien and his family laundered cash simply because he and his family drove to Lugano rather than flying there while on a tour of Europe.

Lien instructed his lawyer to bring a complaint of slander against Chou Yu-ke, the hostess at Eastern Television, her guest Chen Chung-hsiung, and several news workers on her program "Taiwan Summit" which was broadcast by Eastern Television a day earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER HEADS FOR U.S. FOR NAAG ANNUAL MEETING

TEXT.P: Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan left for Los Angeles Sunday to take part in the 2004 conference of the National Association of Attorneys General (NAAG).

Chen will give a speech at the "state dinner" of the annual meeting, in which attorneys general from the 50 states of the United States will participate. Taiwan has for many years dispatched prosecutors to attend the important meeting and has invited NAAG members to visit in order to bolster mutual understanding and exchanges.
While in the United States, Chen will also meet overseas Chinese in other cities. He is slated to return to Taiwan June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION LEGISLATORS ATTACK FUEL SURCHARGES BY AIRLINES

TEXT.P: Opposition legislators demanded Sunday that to better protect passenger interests as the peak summer season approaches, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications should stop various airlines from charging fuel surcharges.
People First Party legislators Liu Wen-hsiung, Lee Hong-chun and Pan Chien-kuo made the call in a joint news conference.

Complaining that the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the ministry approved fuel surcharge applications submitted by seven carriers without detailed elaboration, they questioned the fairness of the measure.

As airplane ticket fees will soon surge for the peak summer months, any additional price hikes will constitute a further burden on travelers, they argued. They demanded that the CAA instruct the airlines to make public their fuel costs to give a public explanation for their planned surcharges.

The CAA approved Friday the fuel surcharge applications submitted by China Airlines (CAL) , EVA Airways Corp., Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd., Singapore Airlines, Dragon Airlines Ltd., Malaysia Airlines and Thai Airways International Ltd., allowing the carriers to impose a surcharge ranging from US$5 to US$15 for each travel section between two destinations from June 16.

Aviation companies said that the fuel surcharge has been planned to reflect rising operating costs as a result of soaring oil prices, and they promised to cancel the surcharges as soon as international oil prices drop. CAL and EVA Air -- Taiwan's two largest carriers -- have claimed that they will review their fuel surcharges in three months.
According to a CAA official, the surcharges are just a reflection of rising airline costs, and they will be rescinded immediately once oil prices slide to US$36 a barrel.
Cheng Hong-jen, secretary-general of the non-profit Consumers' Foundation, also expressed his dissatisfaction over the surcharge plan.
He called the proposed price hike a "double exploitation of passengers " and pointed out that Taiwan travelers are already charged more for airplane tickets than people in other countries.

Accusing the carriers of damaging passengers' interests by imposing fuel surcharges at an unappropriated time without transparent information offered to the public, Cheng called for the establishment of a mechanism under which aviation companies must elaborate on their fuel costs as a basis for the public to gauge their surcharges.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES CRY FOUL OVER NOMINEE FOR CHIEF ELECTION OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The two major opposition parties cried foul Sunday over the nomination of a controversial person for chief of the Central Election Commission (CEC), saying unanimously that they would ask the Council of Grand Justices to annul the nomination.

One day after the Executive Yuan announced that Chang Cheng-hsiung, a member of the CEC, will be promoted as chairman of the commission, Legislator Huang Teh-fu, the deputy secretary of the Kuomintang (KMT) caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said the nomination is questionable not only because of its timing but also because of the person chosen.

According to the Basic Law for the Central Government Organization that was passed by the Legislative Yuan before it went into recess Friday, Huang said, the nominee for the CEC chairman should be approved by the Legislative Yuan to ensure that the commission will carry out national elections free from political influence.
The Executive Yuan's decision to name a person to head the CEC before the new law takes forces is obviously an attempt to sidestep the legislature's supervision.

Worse yet, Huang said, the nomination is a blatant political reward for Chang, who is known for vigorously defending the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) government's decision to hold a referendum alongside the March 20 presidential election, although he is not affiliated to any policial party.

With a head heavily involved in politics, Huang said, the CEC cannot be expected to carry out its job as an organization independent of the Executive Yuan's influence. He adding that his party could turn to the Council of Grand Justices for a ruling against the nomination.
His views were echoed by the KMT's political ally, the People First Party (PFP).
PFP convener at the Legislative Yuan Liu Wen-hsiung said the nomination is controversial as it runs against the newly enacted Basic Law of Central Government Organization.

As the national supreme representative organization, Liu said, it is only natural for the Legislative Yuan to have a say in the appointment of the CEC chief to ensure the commission is detached from politics.

If the CEC is controlled by the ruling party, no fair election is possible. It is for this reason, Liu said, that his party is mulling whether to ask the Council of Grand Justices to intervene by ruling against Chang's nomination.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER REVEALS POSSIBLE NOMINEES FOR OVERSEAS POSTS

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen revealed Sunday various possible nominees for the ministry's overseas posts, including Taiwan vice representatives to the United States and Japan.

Chen said that both Joanne J.L. Chang, a researcher at the Institute of European and American Studies under the Academia Sinica, and Stanley Kao, vice permanent representative to the World Trade Organization, will be appointed as new vice representatives to the United States.
Kao will travel with Taiwan's representative-designate David Lee to Washington to take over their new offices, Chen added.
He also revealed that there exists a great possibility that his predecessor Eugene Chien will be named as Taiwan's new representative to the European Union to fill the post vacant left by Lee.

Furthermore, he said that the appointment of Koh Se-kai as Taiwan's representative to Japan should present no problems and that Koh's deputy, Chen Hung-chi, will travel with him to Tokyo to take over their new offices.
Chen announced May 18 that Koh, a professor at Providence University in central Taiwan's Taichung County, would be Taiwan's new representative to Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRECT TRANSPORT TALKS GATEWAY TO CROSS-STRAIT PEACE FRAMEWORK

TEXT.P: Direct transportation talks is a door to building a cross-Taiwan Strait peace framework, former Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Chen Ming-tong said Sunday.

Chen, currently a professor at National Taiwan University's National Development Institute, said of the so-called "three direct links" -- direct trade, transport and postal services between Taiwan and mainland China -- that after the two sides entered the World Trade Organization a couple of years ago, "two-and-a-half links" have already opened, with deadlock remaining only in direct shipping and air links.

Speaking at a discussion on the prospects for direct cross-strait links and security in the Taiwan Strait, Chen said the government has been pragmatically pushing for direct air and shipping links across the Taiwan Strait. The efforts include President Chen Shui-bian's three-stage policy of "preparation, negotiation and gradual realization."

Noting that direct transportation links is the most challenging and hard to achieve task among the three direct links because of political implications, Chen said that if both sides could conquer relevant problems, put aside political differences and return to negotiating table to discuss the issue, then other cross-strait affairs could be easily tackled.
Chen added nevertheless that opening direct cross-strait air and shipping links might not give Beijing a major economic gain, but could help Beijing secure big political gains.
Consequently, he warned, Taiwan should be extra careful when dealing with Beijing in regard to opening direct cross-strait transportation links.

He warned that opening direct cross-strait air and shipping links might have an adverse impact on Taiwan's defense security. Such opening could also cause a hollowing-out of Taiwan's industrial development and related needs, could cause Taiwan's unemployment rate to rise and could increase bilateral private sector exchanges, eventually blurring the Taiwan people's ability to tell who is the enemy.

Opening direct cross-strait transportation links is a two-edged sword -- hostility and political deadlock would ease, lifting shares and economic prospects but raising fears about Taiwan's defense -- and a responsible government should be able to "bring about good and prevent bad" so as to seek workable solutions to the thorny issue, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL DESIGNATION SHOULD BE DECIDED BY ALL TAIWAN PEOPLE: ADVISER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's official designation should be decided upon by all the 23 million people of the country, a Presidential Office senior adviser said Sunday.

Taiwan is a sovereign state and its official title and constitution should be decided by all of its people in a process in which the people agree, pass and support the title and the law, said Koo Kuan-min, a pro-independence adviser to President Chen Shui-bian.
Speaking at a constitution rewriting forum, Koo brushed aside notions such as "Taiwan Republic of China, " or "Republic of China Taiwan" as unrealistic.

During a meeting with Taiwan expatriates in San Francisco early last week, Vice President Annette Lu suggested that the nation be called "Taiwan Republic of China, " an idea she thought would pacify domestic disputes over Taiwan's identity.
Also speaking at the forum, academic Juan Ming, who is also a national policy adviser to the Presidential Office, said he does not support Lu's "Taiwan Republic of China" notion either.
Juan said that except for the few diplomatic allies of the Republic of China, no countries in the world call Taiwan by its official designation of the ROC.

"The entire world calls us 'Taiwan, ' the PRC calls us 'Taiwan' and even the United States calls us 'Taiwan, '" Juan pointed out, adding that it is meaningless to suggest that the nation be called "Taiwan Republic of China."

Juan stressed that Taiwan is Taiwan. In Taiwan, he went on, everyone enjoys freedom of expression. Nevertheless, he said, if the vice president wants to express her opinions about the nation's official designation, she probably should have been more careful.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 13, or the 26th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1774: Rhode Island becomes the first American colony to ban the importation of slaves and to assure their freedom.
1865: Irish poet and playwright William Butler Yeats is born. The dramatist was the co-founder of the Abbey Theater in Dublin and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1923.
1931: Dr. Shibasaburo Kitazato, noted Japanese bacteriologist, dies of a stroke at the age of 78.
1944: London comes under attack as Hitler lets loose a devastating new weapon on the city. The so-called V1 flying bomb, or "doodle bug," as it has been nicknamed, is a long-range device that can be launched safely from within enemy territory.
1951: United Nations troops capture Pyongyang, capital of North Korea.
1956: Communist China's Premier Zhou Enlai requests a meeting with the U.S. Secretary of State John Foster Dulles. His request is rejected.
1956: The last British troops leave the Suez Canal Zone, ending 75 years of British rule in Egypt.
1971 Geraldine Brodrick gives birth to nine babies in Australia, one of the few recorded instances of nonuplets.
1973: Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, commander-in-chief of the U.S. Army in the Pacific, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1978: President Chiang Ching-kuo, in an interview with Edward W. Scripps II, director of the Scripps-Howard Newspaper in the United States, warns that the Chinese communists are trying to push the United States to the brink of war with the Soviet Union.
1978: Pu Chung-chiang, 10, labeled as the "fastest boy in the world" by the press, receives a silver medal from the ROC Ministry of Education in distance races in the United States.
1982: Saudi Arabian King Khalid ibn Abul-Aziz dies and is succeeded by his brother Prince Fahd.
1987: Republic of China Premier Yu Kuo-hua, in a statement made after returning from Singapore and learning of violent protests outside the Legislative Yuan, says the government's determination to implement constitutional democracy will never change, but unlawful acts will be dealt with in accordance with the law.
1989: Beijing orders the arrest of the leaders of the pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square.
1989: Russian President Mikhail Gorbachev and West Germany's Chancellor Helmut Kohl agree that East and West Germany should be reunited.
1994: The Foreign Ministry of North Korea announces it is withdrawing from the United Nations' International Atomic Energy Agency and will no longer permit U.N. nuclear inspectors into the country.
1996: Copper prices tumble around the world after Sumitomo Corp. says it has lost an estimated US$2.6 billion over 10 years due to unauthorized copper trade.
1998: Lucio Costa, Brazilian architect who planned the Brazilian capital Brasilia, dies at the age of 96.
1999: The fifth Taiwan-Poland Economic Cooperation Conference opens in Taipei with trade officials and business leaders from both countries taking part.
2000: The United States Senate passes a resolution in recognition of Stephen Chen, the Republic of China's representative to the United States, for his distinguished service.
2000: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates praises Taiwan's companies as a key that "made things happen" in the growth of the global computer industry over the past 25 years.
2001: A three-day symposium on adult education on both sides of the Taiwan Strait begins in Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who is austere in his look, but a weakling and a coward at heart -- is he not like one of your small, mean people? Is he not like a sneaking thief or a cowardly pickpocket?"

DOC.HEADLINE: PLAN FOR CABLE CAR IN NANTOU TAKES SHAPE

TEXT.P: A plan for a cable car line connecting scenic Sun Moon Lake with the Formosan Aboriginal Culture Village, both in Nantou County, was jointly worked out Monday by the Public Construction Commission (PCC) -- which wants to build the facility -- and other related government agencies.

An anonymous PCC official said details of the plan were hammered out almost one year after a private builder applied for permission to build the cable car line, which carries construction costs of between NT$540 million (US$16.08) and NT$620 million.
A construction contract is expected to be signed by the end of July and the line is expected to be completed within a year, said the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: DETENTION CENTERS OVERCROWDED WITH ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's three detention centers for illegal immigrants from mainland China are overcrowded because of Beijing's foot-dragging in taking back detainees, the chief of the detention center in Hsinchu County said Monday.
Lai Chie-yi said the Beijing authorities have stopped repatriation operations since March 6, claiming that their only ship assigned for this purpose was undergoing annual repairs.

However, new illegal mainland immigrants continue to stream in and the country's three detention centers in Hsinchu, Ilan and Matsu are overflowing with a record high of 2,617 detainees, including 1,100 in the Hsinchu detention center alone, Lai said.

As the summer is coming and the weather is getting warmer, the endless wait for repatriation in the overcrowded centers has caused unrest among the detainees, not to mention the approach of the Dragon Boat Festival, a major Chinese festival for family reunions on the fifth day of the fifth month of the lunar calendar, Lai went on.
Weeping is often heard among the homesick detainees during the night and it spreads from one to the other, fueling the miserable atmosphere at the Hsinchu center, Lai said.
What is worse is the chilling of ties between Taiwan and the mainland, which dampens the hope that the repatriation operation will be resumed before the Dragon Boat Festival, Lai went on.
Lai said that all he and his crew can do is to explain the situation to the detainees and encourage them to write or make phone calls to their mainland families.

He added that he and his staff are preparing a concert as well as a feast for Dragon Boat Festival to try to ease the detainees' homesickness. The hot weather also poses a severe challenge in terms of maintaining hygiene at the overcrowded center, Lai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SNUBS CENTRAL ELECTION COMMISSION IN PROTEST

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) refused to name its representative to the Central Election Commission (CEC) Monday to protest what it claimed is the Executive Yuan's getting ahead of itself by naming a chief of the commission.

Huang Teh-fu, deputy secretary of the KMT caucus at the Legislative Yuan, said his party will not name a representative to serve on the CEC as requested by the Executive Yuan, in order to protest the Executive Yuan's appointment of Chang Cheng-hsiung as CEC chairman before the CEC members were appointed.
Huang said the CEC chairman should be elected by the CEC members, not by the Executive Yuan.

As the Executive Yuan has made no attempt to conceal its intention of controlling the CEC, Huang said, election problems are sure to crop up in the year-end legislative elections, and the KMT does not want a share of that blame by taking part in the CEC.
He made the statement after the Executive Yuan, as widely expected, named lawyer Chang Cheng-hsiung as the CEC head.
The KMT opposes Chang's appointment to the politically sensitive job, saying that Chang favors the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Also named by the Executive Yuan were ten CEC members, including seven who are supposed to be political independents, and one each representing the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of the Interior and the DPP.
At the same time, the Executive Yuan asked the KMT, as well as two other political parties at the legislature to each name a CEC member.
The four-year term of incumbent CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng ends Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2004 OUTPUT VALUE OF SEMICONDUCTOR INDUSTRY TO TOP NT$1 TRILLION

TEXT.P: The production value of Taiwan's semiconductor industry is expected to post an all-time high of more than NT$1 trillion (US$29.7 billion) for 2004, a spokesman for the Industrial Development Bureau reported Monday.

The bureau made the promising forecast based on the domestic industry's first-quarter output value of NT$239.6 billion, which represents a 42.1 percent increase over the year-earlier level, the spokesman said.
The bureau official attributed the growth to stronger global demand for electronic products after the impact of the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome in the first half of last year.
The domestic industry registered a production value of NT$818.8 billion for 2003, up by 28.7 percent over the 2002 level, he elaborated.
In terms of the various sectors, IC manufacturing, design and packaging all posted growth in production value for the first quarter, ranging from some 49 percent to 30 percent year-on-year.

Morris Chang, chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corporation, the world's largest foundry, forecast recently that the domestic industry will expand by 30 percent in output value this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR SIGNS AGREEMENT ON HOSTING 8TH WORLD GAMES

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh signed an agreement with the International World Games Association (IWGA) Monday on hosting the eighth World Games in 2009.

It marks the first time that Taiwan has obtained the right to host an international multi-sports event. The World Games is the world's second-largest multi-sports contest after the Olympic Games and covers mainly sports that are not included in the Olympics.

The Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS) , the Kaohsiung city government, the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee and various sports associations have made concerted efforts over the past two years to secure the right to host the 8th World Games.

IWGA President Ron Froehlich and IWGA Secretary-General Co Korean signed the agreement with Hsieh and NCPFS Chairman Chen Chuan-shou in a ceremony held at the Kaohsiung city government offices in southern Taiwan.

According to the agreement, the 8th World Games will be held from July 16-26, 2009, with contests in 34 sports, including billiards, bodybuilding, bowling, boules, faustball, sports aerobics, gateball and karate, plus three demonstration games -- croguet, Tchoukball and dragon-boat racing.
Hsieh said the city government has formed a World Games preparatory committee and is scheduled to form an organizing committee June 1, 2005.

When the 7th World Games are held in the German city of Duisburg next summer, Hsieh said the city government will organize a delegation to take part in a torch handover ceremony, symbolizing Kaohsiung's formal acceptance of the mission to host the 2009 World Games.
Hsieh said the central government will give full support in assisting the city government to host the games, also known as the "Little Olympics."

The city government has designated a 6-hectare plot of land to house a modern multi-functional stadium capable of accommodating 15,000 people. Construction of the stadium will begin this September, Hsieh said, adding that athletes will live at I-Shou University and National Kaohsiung First University of Science and Technology while the games are taking place.

Hsieh said the city government will expand and renovate various existing sporting facilities in addition to building the main stadium. Some sporting events will be held in neighboring Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties, he added.
Hsieh said he feels proud and excited about Kaohsiung's success in winning the right to host the games after Taipei City won the right earlier this year to host the 2009 Deaflympics.

Speaking on the same occasion, Froehlich said Taiwan has performed well in previous World Games. After two years of careful evaluation of Kaohsiung's general environment and infrastructure, Froehlich said, the IWGA decided to grant the right to the city. "I'm confident that Kaohsiung will be able to successfully host the event," he added.

Earlier in the day, President Chen Shui-bian also hailed Kaohsiung City's success in winning the right to host the 2009 World Games, saying it will contribute to Taiwan's drive to play a more active role in the world arena.
Chen made the remarks while receiving Froehlich and Koren at the Presidential Office in Taipei.
After Froehlich told Chen that the IWGA has decided to grant the right to Kaohsiung to host the 8th World Games, Chen said it is encouraging news for Taiwan.

"We are excited and grateful for being able to host the large multi-sports event in 2009, " Chen said. "I wants to extend my heartfelt thanks to the IWGA and the International Olympic Committee (IOC)." The IWGA is under the patronage of the IOC.

Noting that international sports meets provide a good platform for forging friendships and promoting world peace, Chen said bilateral and multilateral athletic exchanges should transcend political barriers.
However, Chen said, Taiwan had often failed in its drive to host international sporting events in the past simply because of mainland China's opposition or boycott.

"So we are very pleased to obtain the rights to host the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung and the 2009 Deaflympics in Taipei. We cherish these opportunities and will make every possible effort to ensure that the events proceed smoothly," Chen assured his guests.

The IWGA was founded in 1980 and the World Games is held once every four years. Taiwan has consistently sent delegations to take part in the World Games since its inception. In the 6th World Games held in the Japanese city of Akita in 2001, Taiwan ranked 13th among the 87 participating countries or areas in terms of medal count, surpassing mainland China. Taiwan has so far won 18 gold, 13 silver and 11 bronze medals in the previous six World Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIAT PLANS TO INCREASE PURCHASES OF TAIWAN-MADE AUTO PARTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan-made car parts, components and accessories have gained recognition from Italian car giant Fiat, which has decided to increase its purchases of Taiwan-manufactured products, an official of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Monday.
The official made the comment after Fiat informed the Milan office of the semi-official Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) of its decision. The MOEA oversees TAITRA's operations.
A delegation organized by TAITRA and composed of representatives of 18 Taiwan companies visited nine leading automobile makers in Europe in May in search of business opportunities.

Fiat responded to the delegation's efforts by announcing that it will start to increase its purchases of Taiwan-made car parts, components and accessories from this year and that it will officially include Taiwan companies in its global supply chain, the official said.

According to the official, the delegation created a new image for Taiwan manufacturers of auto parts and components among European carmakers, who used to view Taiwan companies as only able to serve as suppliers of repair and maintenance parts. Now, however, they see that Taiwan makers are competitive enough to produce high quality parts for compact vehicles, he noted.

The inclusion of Taiwan by Fiat in its worldwide supply chain will not only help Taiwan makers increase their profits, but will also help push for technology transfers from Fiat, a TAITRA spokesman said.

Fiat hopes to reduce production costs by purchasing Taiwan-made parts and components, which are cheaper than goods produced by Italian companies, the spokesman said, adding that the Italian carmaker has suffered losses over the past two years and wishes to become profitable by setting up cooperative ventures with Taiwan suppliers.

The Fiat group puts out about 2 million sedans annually and employs 16,000 workers in 192 plants across the world. It recorded a business turnover of 47 billion euros for 2003, with losses of 500 million euros as a result of its heavy reliance on Italian suppliers.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MINISTER OF CIVIL SERVICE APPOINTED

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has appointed Chu Wu-hsien, secretary-general of the Examination Yuan, as new minister of the civil service, Examination Yuan officials said Monday.
Chu will take over the post vacant left by Wu Rong-ming, who was promoted to Examination Yuan vice president, at a ceremony slated to be held June 16, the officials revealed.
At the same time, they added, Chiayi Vice Mayor Lee Chun-i has been named as Chu's deputy and outgoing Vice Minister of Civil Service Yen Chiou-lai will serve as advisor to the Executive Yuan.
The Civil Service Ministry is in charge of the nation's government personnel system.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS TO VISIT U.S. MILITARY BASES FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: The United States will arrange for a group of Taiwan lawmakers to visit major U.S. military bases later this week to seek their support for a huge budget for Taiwan's new arms procurement projects, government sources said Monday.

According to an itinerary revealed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the legislative delegation will also meet with senior officials of the U.S. National Security Council, the Department of State and the Department of Defense, in addition to visiting a U.S. P-3C anti-submarine aircraft base and a Patriot PAC-III missile base.
At the U.S. invitation, the 14-member delegation of lawmakers from across the political spectrum, led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, will leave for Hawaii Thursday.
The delegation will first visit the U.S. Pacific Command in Hawaii to receive a briefing on the general regional security situation and visit a P-3C anti-submarine aircraft base.

The delegation will then travel to Washington, D.C. via San Francisco. In the company of ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-Jen, the delegation will visit relevant U.S. administrative departments June 21 and exchange views with their senior officials on Taiwan's defense needs.

On the following day, the delegation will be briefed on special functions of the weaponry systems that the United States intends to sell to Taiwan. The mission will also meet with U.S. congressmen before leaving for Texas June 24 to visit a U.S. Patriot PAC-III missile base. The delegation is scheduled to return to Taipei June 28.
The Cabinet has approved a special military budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the purchase of advanced weaponry from the United States amid mounting mainland Chinese military threats.

The draft budget calls for the procurement of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992.
The special budget bill is now pending approval of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

As many lawmakers have criticized the proposed submarine procurement project as being too expensive, Defense Minister Lee Jye met with Legislative Yuan President Wang Monday to brief him on a new two-stage budget plan formula for the submarine deal.
Lee said he hopes the legislature will pass the draft budget plan for the eight submarines first, to allow the Ministry of National Defense (MND) to negotiate detailed terms with the United States.

The MND will furnish the legislature a more detailed budget plan after it comes to a conclusion with the U.S. authorities on how the eight submarines will be built, Lee said. There could be three options for construction of the submarines -- U.S. contractors could build them, they could cooperate with other foreign contractors, or they could cooperate with Taiwan's China Shipbuilding Corporation (CSBC) . It has been estimated that the cost will increase by NT$80 billion if Taiwan insists on the CSBC participating in the construction.
Wang said this two-stage budget plan formula might be more acceptable to lawmakers.

Members of Wang's mission will include three legislators from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, three from the opposition Kuomintang, four from the opposition People First Party, two from the Taiwan Solidarity Union and two independent lawmakers.
The legislature went into summer recess last Friday and it remains uncertain whether the legislature will call an extra session to screen the draft arms procurement budget bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEMOCRACY FOUNDATION MARKS 3RD ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The establishment of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy marked a milestone in Taiwan's democratization and represented Taiwan's ability to feed back to the international community, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Monday.

Wang, who chairs the foundation, made the remarks at a tea party to celebrate the foundation's third anniversary and the inauguration of its new office. The foundation, set up by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is composed of 15 representatives from political parties, non-government organizations and the academic, business and government sectors.

Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen, foreign diplomats stationed in Taiwan, and scores of foreign dignitaries, including Carl Gershman, president of the United States-based National Endowment for Democracy, and Charles Zorgbibe, head of the international relations institute at Paris University, also took part in the activity.

Wang said that he feels deeply honored to chair the non-partisan, non-profit foundation, which has over the past few years helped promote Taiwan's exchanges with parliamentarians and political parties of other countries.

Chen stressed that the purpose of the foundation is to upgrade Taiwan's democracy, economy and security -- key segments of the country's overall national strategy -- and to create a transparent and institutionalized mechanism based on national consensus to help further strengthen human rights and democracy across the country and around the world.
Gershman hailed Taiwan's resolve to advocate democracy and said that the United States views this as a very important trait of the country.

Zorgbibe said that Taiwan's success in democratization underscores a lack of democracy in mainland China and he criticized harshly the timidity displayed by various European countries in their dealings with Taiwan, which has shown a great deal of new thinking in universally recognized values and democracy.
Pro-democracy activists in Europe have the responsibility to correct this mindset by pushing European institutions to work with Taiwan in the promotion of democracy around the world, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GROUP OF SCHOLARS OPPOSE ARMS PURCHASE

TEXT.P: A group of scholars spoke out Monday against the government's plan to purchase NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) in arms from the United States.

Lin Shen-ching, executive director of the Democracy Action Alliance, said the huge price tag for the arms would certainly squeeze out other government budgets and that the money could be better used in places besides acquiring weapons.

Lin said his group would support the armed forces' request to maintain a significant capability to wage war, but would not agree to finance this with a special budget that is not subject to legal restrictions on the government's capability of raising money via loans.

Noting that rising tensions across the Taiwan Strait is aproblem for the nation, Lin said instead of defusing the crisis, arms purchases will add fuel to the fire and increase the likelihood of a conflict, when this could be avoided through political maneuvering.

Hsieh Ta-ling, a professor at National Chung Cheng University in Chiayi and convener of the alliance, said the arms purchase betrays President Chen Shui-bian's lack of trust in his own power and his reliance on the protection of the United States.

Hsieh said he is pessimistic about the possibility that the Legislative Yuan will strike down the budget, especially since Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, is set to travel to the United States at the head of a group of lawmakers. Wang and the lawmakers are certainly going to be influenced by their American hosts on the issue.
The two said their alliance will hold a forum to discuss the advantages and disadvantages of the purchases, and will protest the purchases on June 20.
The arms purchases, covering 388 PAC-III missiles, eight submarines and 12 P-3C anti-submarine airplanes, will take 15 years for delivery, if the deal is successfully concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS OPTIMISTIC ABOUT DEVELOPMENT OF CROSS-STRAIT TIES
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 13 (CNA) (By N.K. Han and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A scholar from a Taiwan think tank said Sunday that he is optimistic about the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and that a new situation can emerge as a result of positive exchanges.

Lo Chih-cheng, executive director of the Institute for National Policy Research, made the remarks when he met with overseas Chinese in London to discuss Taiwan's political situation and future development.

Lo, who is an associate professor at Soochow University in Taipei, said that Beijing's present approach entails applying pressure on Taiwan via the United States, and although it harbors some hope in this regard, it knows it cannot depend on Washington.

Since President Chen Shui-bian won a second term in the March 20 presidential election, he said, Beijing has started to think seriously about Taiwan public opinion and he added that Taiwan should also start to understand why Beijing continues to insist on its "one China" principle.
On the domestic situation in Taiwan, Lo said that although some quarters played up the "ethnic issue" during the presidential election campaign, politics in Taiwan have returned to normal.

He noted that all the major political parties in Taiwan face the problem of generational transfer and the integration of factions within the various parties, and are bracing for the year-end legislative elections, which he said shows that the democratic system is still the best way to sort out problems in the country.
Lai Yi-chung, a researcher at the Taiwan Thinktank, also said that the political landscape will become much clearer after the legislative elections.

According to Lai, there are no national identity questions in Taiwan's political parties and that the question now is the status of Taiwan in the Asia-Pacific region and the values on which the nation was founded.

Tung Cheng-yuan, an associate researcher at the Institute of International Relations of National Chengchi University, said that while both sides of the Taiwan Strait have made some policy concessions in the past, they have come to nothing because of a lack of mutual trust.
He predicted that there will be positive exchanges after six months or one year and that economic exchanges will become even closer.

The three scholars, who came to London with Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, made the remarks after attending a workshop jointly organized by the Asia Research Centre at the London School of Economics and Political Science, Taiwan's Institute for National Policy Research and the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER SPEAKS TO OVERSEAS CHINESE IN LOS ANGLES
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 13 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan on Sunday criticized a demand by opposition parties to form acommittee within the Legislative Yuan to investigate the election-eve shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

Chen, who arrived in Los Angeles Sunday to take part in the 2004 conference of the National Association of Attorneys General (NAAG) , made the remarks when he spoke to overseas Chinese on the political situation after the March 20 presidential election.

President Chen won the election by a small margin of 29,518 votes out of the more than 13 million cast. The opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party has since demanded a re-count of the ballots and the formation of a committee to investigate the March 19 shooting, which it believes unfairly swayed the bitterly contested election in Chen's favor. Both Chen and Lu were slightly injured during the shooting while canvassing in Tainan, a stronghold of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

He said that the demand for a committee to be formed within the Legislative Yuan would not only encroach on the investigative rights of the Control Yuan as stipulated in the ROC Constitution, but would also interfere with the investigative rights of judicial authorities. Police have few leads and no suspects in the shooting so far.

He noted that the U.S. Congress has the right to conduct investigations, but there are no such rights in Taiwan's Legislative Yuan, because the Constitution gives this power to the Control Yuan. The Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, has already begun looking into possible lapses by civil servants, and parts of the ongoing investigation will be announced soon.
As for criminal responsibility, he said that the perpetrator of the shooting is still at large, and whether there is negligence of any civil servants is under investigation.
Chen also talked about the legitimacy of holding the referendum and presidential election on the same day, and explained the activation of the heightened alert status due to the shooting.

The opposition criticized the activation of the heightened alert, saying that it had prevented many military and police personnel, traditionally the supporters of the "pan-blue alliance," from leaving their posts to vote.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH DEPARTMENT DRAFTS 5-YEAR PLAN TO PREVENT SUICIDE

TEXT.P: The Department of Health has come up with a five-year plan to reduce the incidence of suicide, which has become one of Taiwan's top 10 causes of death, Minister Chen Chien-jen said Monday.

Speaking at a news conference where Chen unveiled Taiwan's top 10 killers for 2003, he said the five-year plan will call for an outlay of NT$700 million for establishing mental health counseling centers in various cities and counties and stepping up prevention and control of depression.
Chen said the health department has referred the five-year suicide prevention and control plan to the Cabinet for approval.
According to health department tallies, 3,195 local citizens committed suicide in 2003, marking an increase of 142 people from a year ago and making suicide the nation's ninth cause of death.

It was the seventh consecutive year that suicide has made the top 10 killers list. An average of nine people killed themselves each day in 2003 or one person committed suicide every two hours and 45 minutes.

In terms of gender, men accounted for 67 percent of those who died from suicide last year for an annual growth rate of 2.03 percent, and women accounting for the remaining 33 percent for a major jump of 10.54 percent from the year-earlier level.

By age, those aged under 24 accounted for 7.53 percent of those who killed themselves; those aged between 25 and 44 made up 39.86 percent; those in the age group of 45 to 64 accounted for 33.51 percent; and those aged 65 or over made up 23.75 percent.

The suicide growth rate was the steepest among senior citizens (aged over 65) at 6.9 percent; followed by 4.5 percent for the 45 to 64 age group, 3.7 percent for the 25 to 44 age group and 3.6 percent for those aged under 24.

Meanwhile, suicide was the second-largest killer for those who died young (15 to 24 years old) last year, the top three killer for those who died between 25 and 44 years of age and the seventh killer for those who died at the age of 45 to 64.
Chen attributed the continued rise in suicide to two major causes -- progress in the suicide reporting system and the rising incidence of depression.

Noting that early discovery and proper counseling are important work in suicide prevention, Chen said the health department hopes to set up mental health counseling centers in each city and county to facilitate necessary assistance to depression patients and curtail a further rise in the suicide rate.
"If the Cabinet approves our five-year plan, the health department will invest up to NT$700 million over the next five years to promote mental health and prevent depression and suicide, " Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR GIVES SPEECH AT WORLD ECONOMIC FORUM MEETING IN SEOUL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said that Asian economies should seek to minimize the impact of non-economic factors and that Taiwan should not be excluded from the region's economic integration, according to a press release issued Monday by the Taipei city government's Department of Information.

Ma made the remarks while giving a speech on the outlook for Asian economies at a meeting held by the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Seoul, the South Korean capital, the statement said. The meeting, the Asia Strategic Insight Roundtable, opened late Sunday.

Ma claimed that the information industry plays a key role in Asia's economic recovery and that it must be obtained through a full economic integration in the region. That is the reason why Taiwan should not be precluded from the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum or any such integration in the region, he said.

Ma stressed that the development of Asian economies should not be hindered by political or social uncertainties and that countries in the region should do their best to minimize the adverse impact of non-economic factors on this front.

For the time being, the Taiwan Strait and the Korean Peninsula are the leading flash points in the world, and peace in the two regions constitutes the precondition for steady economic progress in Asia, the Taipei mayor said.

According to Ma, President Chen Shui-bian's second inaugural address on May 20 has helped reduce tensions across the Strait, but the crisis has not be fully diluted. Asian countries should be happy to see Taiwan and mainland China open constructive dialogue to settle their disputes, he added.
The two-day meeting -- a regional session of the WEF -- drew more than 100 government officials and corporate executives from 21 countries to take part.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: March of the Eurosceptics.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER TO ATTEND WORLD FORUM IN COLORADO

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen will travel to the United States Wednesday to attend the 2004 World Forum in Colorado.

Chen said he would attend the event while speaking at an informal gathering for the first anniversary of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy, an organization promoted by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and supported by the Legislative Yuan.
The World Forum is an annual conference of government officials, legislators, business and financial leaders and academics, which is sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute.
Chen said that he was invited by U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney to the annual conference June 17-20.

Chen is expected to stay in the U.S. for a week before returning home. Afterward, he plans to travel to Europe in July to chair a meeting of the chiefs of Taiwan's representative offices in the region.

Meanwhile, Chen said on the same occasion that the ministry hopes that the donations to Costa Rica will be put to their designated purposes, although Taiwan respects the decisions of the Central American nation.

Chen was responding to an AFP report that said five conservative Costa Rican legislators have accused their foreign minister, Roberto Tovar, of diverting funds donated by the Taiwanese government for unauthorized uses.

The report quoted the legislators as saying that the foreign ministry had diverted some US$4.8 million in funds from Taiwan intended to develop trade and tourism in Costa Rica to pay foreign ministry salaries and bonuses.
Chen said that Taiwan has always been clear about its financial aid to other countries, and "soft assistance" plans are usually used on such items as trade and tourism.

Although Taiwan respects the wishes of the recipients, it hopes that they will not divert money randomly in such a way as to undermine possible future donations on such things as schools and hospitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 14, or the 27th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: The US Congress adopts the "Stars and Stripes" as the official flag of the United States.
1838: Yamagata Aritomo, Japanese soldier and twice prime minister, is born. He played a major role in turning Japan into a formidable military power.
1894: After displaying the first commercial motion-picture machine at the World's Colombian Exposition in 1893, Thomas Alva Edison's company presents the first sports-related movie on boxing.
1900: The first Grand Prix, or international car race, takes place in Paris.
1920: In China, war between the Chihli and Anhwei warlords breaks out. Tsao Kun of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction join forces to fight against Tuan Chi-jui of the Anhwei faction.
1936: Chang Tai-yen, a noted scholar of Chinese literature, dies in Soochow at the age of 67.
1940: German troops march into Paris, and the flag of Nazi Germany, bearing the swastika, is hoisted up the Eiffel Tower.
1941: President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the freezing of all German and Italian assets in the United States.
1943: The Battle of West Hupeh ends with Japanese troops driven back to their previous positions.
1949: Bao Dai is installed as president of Vietnam.
1952: The Nautilus, the first nuclear-powered submarine, is put on public display in the United States.
1955: The Republic of China and the United States sign an agreement in Washington on the peaceful use of nuclear energy.
1964: In the ROC, the NT$3.2 billion multipurpose Shihmen Dam is dedicated.
1971: The Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1973: A 10-member Chinese national judo team headed by Mao Ming-chu leaves for Lausanne to take part in the 8th world championships.
1974: Vice Premier Hsu Ching-chung and Deputy Premier Cuthbert Edwy Talma of the Barbados sign a joint communique in Taipei announcing the extension of the Sino-Barbados agricultural technical cooperation agreement.
1975: More than 500 Chinese poets and Dr. Jeno Platthy, chairman of the Organizing Committee of the Third World Congress of Poets, gathered in Taipei to celebrate Chinese Poets Day and pay homage to poet Chu Yuan of the period of Spring and Autumn Annals.
1978: A technical cooperation agreement between Saudi Arabia and the Republic of China is signed.
1979: President Chiang Ching-kuo appoints Huang Shao-ku and Hung Shou-nan as president and vice president of the Judicial Yuan, respectively, following unanimous approval by the Control Yuan.
1982: Argentine troops surrender to the British commander of land forces in the Falklands, marking the end of a six-week conflict that cost 254 British and 750 Argentine lives.
1982: President Chiang Ching-kuo visits the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Taipei to extend his condolences over the passing of King Khalid ibn abdul Aziz.
1989: Former governor of California and US President Ronald Reagan is knighted by Queen Elizabeth II.
1992: Ronald Freeman, vice president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, visits the ROC to discuss Sino-European trade and financial relations.
1997: Vice President and Premier Lien Chan announces that the government will establish a Ministry of Culture.
2000: U.S. President Bill Clinton sends his greetings to the participants in the 24th annual Joint Business Conference of the U.S.-ROC (Taiwan) and ROC-U.S.A. Business Councils, which kicks off in Taipei.
2001: A 23-member mainland Chinese delegation arrives in Taipei to take part in an unprecedented cross-Taiwan Strait long-distance race as part of a campaign for mainland China's bid to win the right to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Your meek men of respectability, are they who unmercifully destroy all sense of moral sentiment in man."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT HAILS SUCCESS IN WINNING RIGHT TO HOST 2009 WORLD GAMES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian hailed Kaohsiung City's success Monday in winning the right to host the 2009 World Games, saying it will contribute to Taiwan's drive to play a more active role in the world arena.
Chen made the remarks while receiving Ron Froehlich, president of the International World Games Association (IWGA), and Co Koren, IWGA secretary-general, at the Presidential Office.
Froehlich and Koren told Chen that after two years of extensive evaluations, the IWGA has decided to grant the right to Kaohsiung to host the 8th World Games.
"This is encouraging news for us, " Chen said. "We are excited and grateful for being able to host the large multi-sports event in 2009."

On behalf of the Republic of China government and people, Chen said, he wants to extend his heartfelt thanks to the IWGA and the International Olympic Committee (IOC) . The IWGA is under the patronage of the IOC.

Noting that international sports meets provide a good platform for forging friendships and promoting world peace, Chen said bilateral and multilateral athletic exchanges should transcend political barriers.
However, Chen said, Taiwan had often failed in its drive to host international sporting events in the past simply because of mainland China's opposition or boycott.

"So we are very pleased to obtain the rights to host the 2009 World Games in Kaohsiung and the 2009 Deaflympics in Taipei. We cherish these opportunities and will make every possible effort to ensure that the events proceed smoothly," Chen assured his guests.

The IWGA was founded in 1980 and the World Games is held once every four years. It is now the world's second-largest international sporting event after the Olympics. The World Games cover more than 30 sports that are not included in the Olympic Games.

Taiwan has consistently sent delegations to take part in the World Games since its inception. In the 6th World Games held in the Japanese city of Akita in 2001, Taiwan ranked 13th among the 87 participating countries or areas in terms of medal count, surpassing mainland China. The 7th World Games will be held in Duisburg, Germany in 2005.

Chen told the two IWGA executives that Kaohsiung, Taiwan's largest commercial port and second-largest city, has modern sports facilities. Moreover, he said, the southern Taiwan city's mass rapid transit system will be completed by the time the 2009 World Games take place.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOT ALL OVERSEAS DIPLOMAS ARE CREATED EQUAL: EDUCATION MINISTRY

TEXT.P: When it comes to getting an overseas diploma, the Ministry of Education warned Monday that if it looks too good to be true, it probably is.

Education officials said that ads that falsely claim that degrees can be obtained from overseas universities or institutes quicker than usual are violating regulations governing consumer protection and that the Consumers' Foundation has started investigating several alleged instances of fraud.
They urged those who want to study overseas be on guard to avoid being duped, and reminded that those who sell diplomas or hold forged documents will be prosecuted.
Ministry officials said that there are a number of methods of obtaining a degree from an overseas institute or university that are not recognized in Taiwan.

First, degrees obtained via correspondence learning are not recognized. Similarly, degrees are not accepted whereby the credits from distance learning are greater than one-third of the total credits earned from actual overseas attendance. Those who obtain diplomas from a Taiwan branch of an overseas school where the branch has not been officially recognized are not valid. Lastly, diplomas from overseas schools that were received by taking classes exclusively in Taiwan under the commission of a foreign institute are not recognized.

The officials urged Taiwan students overseas to have their diplomas sent to a Republic of China embassy or representative office for verification after their graduation so that the documents can be verified.
The officials made the appeal as thousands of new undergraduates in Taiwan are mulling studying abroad this summer.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME TO START SECOND PHASE OF BUILDING DEMOCRACY: PRESIDENT CHEN

TEXT.P: It is time for Taiwan to begin the second phase of building democracy now that the concept has firmly taken root in the country, President Chen Shui-bian said Monday.

The first wave of establishing democracy was to empower the people with their rights as citizens and protect Taiwan's national identity, President Chen said in his speech at a ceremony marking the first anniversary of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy.
In the second wave -- assuring that democracy matures -- Chen said the country should strive to build Taiwan into a society bound by civil rights and a sense of national community.
"How to enable Taiwan to build a partnership of values with the international community will be the major task of the Taiwan Foundation for Democracy," Chen said.
Chen delivered the keynote speech at the ceremony, which also marked the opening of the new building for the non-profit organization initiated by the president in 2002.

President Chen broached the idea of establishing such a foundation to promote Taiwan's democratization experience and to share democratic values with other countries during a high-level meeting held in Sanchih, Taipei County Feb. 9, 2002.

The Taiwan Foundation for Democracy was formally established on June 17, 2003, with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng elected chairman at the first joint meeting of the board of directors and supervisors, while then-Minister of Foreign Affairs Eugene Chien was elected as its vice chairman and Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Michael Y. M. Kau was appointed as its chief executive officer.

In his speech delivered Monday, Chen said that the establishment of the foundation represented a milestone in the country's democratic development. The foundation is the first of its kind in Asia and the fourth in the world, only after similar foundations were set up in the United States, Great Britain and Germany, he noted.

The people of Taiwan are obliged to other governments and peoples around the world for their support and assistance rendered to Taiwan when the country was proceeding with democratic reforms, Chen said.

Today, democracy has become the core value of the people on Taiwan and their source of pride, Chen said, adding that Taiwan will increase exchanges with other democratic nations and share its democratization experience with them through the foundation so that "made-in-Taiwan" democracy and human rights ideals will be disseminated to every corner around the world.

The foundation, which has been financed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and has been operated transparently and in a supra-party cooperation form, has also made exceptional contributions at home over the last year, including the nurturing of legislative aides, the research of initiation and referendum mechanisms and supporting democratization activities around the world, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 160.99 points to close at 5,574.08.
The bourse opened at 5,753.23 and fluctuated between 5,782.67 and 5,560.78 during trading.

A total of 3 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$66.82 billion (US$1.99 billion), a decrease from the previous day's trading session that saw 3.35 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$75.34 billion.

All of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 5.5 percent, followed by textile issues at 3.8 percent, bank and insurance shares and cement stocks both at 3.4 percent, foodstuff stocks at 3.1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 2.7 percent, electrical shares at 2.6 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 1.9 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 817 to 49, with 93 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST TAIWANESE GRADUATE OF USMA AT WEST POINT COMMISSIONED

TEXT.P: The first Taiwanese graduate of the United States Military Academy (USMA) at West Point and three other Taiwanese graduates of U.S. military academies were commissioned by the Chinese Military Academy (CMA) in Fengshan, Kaohsiung Monday.

Lee Wu-ling, as well as Chang Ya-chin and Hsiung Ming-jung of Norwich University, and Lee Pei-chun of Virginia Military Institute, were commissioned as second lieutenants in the Republic of China Army at a ceremony presided over by CMA President Yang Kuo-chiang.
After the ceremony, Lee expressed his appreciation for the government's assistance, saying that he would do his utmost to serve the country.

Lee, 23, graduated from the USMA at West Point in May after studying there for four years. He had studied in the CMA for one year before passing the recruitment tests of the American Institute of Taiwan (AIT) , which represents U.S. interests in the absence of diplomatic ties, to attend the USMA.
Lee said that he worked hard to overcome the language barrier at first. He noted that studying at the USMA and at the CMA is basically the same, although the facilities are different.

He noted that perhaps because of cultural differences, the USMA at West Point has a more lively approach, focusing on academic and physical fitness education, while the CMA attaches greater importance to military discipline.
Lee and the other three graduates will now be sent to specialized military schools, with Lee Wu-ling Chang and Hsiung studying in artillery, and Lee Pei-chun specializing in communications.

Twelve USMA cadets at West Point who came to the CMA at the end of May, marking the first time USMA cadets have entered and lived on the CMA campus, also attended the commission ceremony. They will return to the United States after the CMA's 80th anniversary Wednesday.

Addressing the ceremony, CMA President Yang said that he is honored to commission the students returning from U.S. military academies this year, or the 80th anniversary of the CMA, which was established in Whampoa, Guangzhou, in 1924, with the late president Chiang Kai-shek as the inaugural president of the academy.

He noted that since the CMA moved to Taiwan, 92 cadets of the school have graduated from military academies in the United States or other countries, and served in various departments, which he said shows that the nurturing of young talent in the ROC Army is moving in the right direction.
He expressed the hope that the four students will make good use of their specialities, be modest and learn the needs of the army, and never forget their duty, honor and country.
Robert Van Horn, army program officer of the Taipei Office of the AIT, conferred USMA admission to Chiang Chi-feng, whose mother accepted it on his behalf.

Chiang, a freshman at the CMA, is scheduled to go to the USMA at West Point this summer to follow in the footsteps of Lee and two other CMA students, Wu Chi-ting and Hung Wan-ting, who are currently studying at the academy and are set to graduate in 2006 and 2007, respectively.

Van Horn congratulated the students and their families during the ceremony, saying that he himself was commissioned in the United States 31 years ago. he also said that he felt honored to introduce Taiwan students to the United States.
With Lee graduating and Chiang following his footsteps, he said that the USMA at West Point and the CMA are now studying exchanges and cooperation in the future.
The USMA began to recruit foreign students from Asia in 2000 through the United States' liaison offices aboard. The AIT has conducted a serious of recruitment tests for the USMA 0 the CMA since then.
Currently, there are two CMA students studying at the USMA at West Point, with another 11 students studying at other military academies in the United States and one in Honduras.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANGO EXPORTS FROM TAINAN COUNTY EXPECTED TO HIT RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Exports of fresh mangoes from Tainan County, southern Taiwan are expected to grow twofold to threefold this year, thanks to the establishment of a new anti-pest facility, a local farmers' association reported Monday.

A heat/steam facility -- an efficient and crucial design to eliminate mango's natural killer, the fruit fry -- is scheduled to become operational Wednesday, serving as a shot in the arm for mango growers and exporters in Tainan County, which is the major mango producing area in Taiwan.
The facility will not only help kill fruit fries, it will also help extend the shelf life of mangoes and other fruits, an official from the Tsuochen Farmers' Association said.

The heat/steam facility -- built in a farmers' association building in the rural township of Tsuochen, Tainan County with financial support from Japan's Mitsubishi Group -- is expected to help increase mango exports from Tainan County to Japan this year to some 1,400 tons, an amount about three times that of previous years, the official said.
Tainan County as a whole is also expected to export 400-500 tons of mangoes to South Korea this year, and several hundreds of tons to Hong Kong and mainland China as well, the official said.
The period between June 15 and the end of August is the major mango harvest period.
The amount designated for export will still only be a small portion of the entire mongo production in Taiwan, according to the farmers' association.
Tainan County produces about 60 percent of all the mangoes in Taiwan. Mangoes are also grown in the southern counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung.

The Washington Post: Baghdad Blasts Kill 12 Iraqis, Soldier. Wave of Violence Claims Top Education Official.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-MINISTER TO HEAD TAIWAN DELEGATION TO APEC MINISTERIAL MEETING

TEXT.P: Minister-without-Portfolio Lin Yi-fu will head a Taiwan delegation to attend a ministerial-level meeting on the mining and metallurgical industry to be sponsored by the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, government sources said Monday.
The APEC ministerial meeting will be held in Antofagasta, a city near the Chilean capital of Santiago and Chile's bronze mining industry center of Calama, from June 15 through June 17.

It will mark the first time that the 21-member APEC has ever organized a ministerial conference on the development of the mining industry and metallurgical trade, Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said.
All of the APEC's 21 member economies will send delegations to attend the conference, the officials said, adding that the Taiwan mission will be led by the former economics minister.

Members of the Taiwan delegation will include Chu Ming-chao, director of the MOEA's Department of Mines, and Chieh Wen-chi, deputy director of the Department of International Organizations under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

The meeting's agenda will focus on strengthening cooperation among APEC members in developing new mining technologies, new materials, and a viable framework for stable and convenient global metal trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: CWB CLOSELY MONITORING TROPICAL STORM DIANMU

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) is closely monitoring a newly-formed tropical storm, Dianmu, which is lurking southwest of Guam near the Philippines, the CWB reported Monday.
The tropical storm was centered some 1,000 kilometers southwest of Guam at 8 a.m. Monday, moving in a north-northwest direction at a speed of 9 kilometers per hour.

Meanwhile, temperatures in Taiwan have shot up due to the influence of a Pacific high pressure system, with highs of 32-34 degrees Celsius forecast for around the island over the next few days, CWB meteorologists reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAN SMUGGLING HEROIN IN SHOES NABBED
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, June 14 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan citizen attempting to smuggle more than 500 grams of heroin into the country from Macau in his shoes was arrested at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport Sunday night, aviation police authorities reported Monday.
The 40-year-old man, identified as Cheng Ching-hung, packed the heroin into four plastic sacks and hid them in the soles of his casual shoes.
According to the aviation police, Cheng was walking strangely in the CKS customs check hall, drawing the attention of the police, who later discovered the contraband drugs, weighing 502 grams.

Aviation police authorities said they were tipped off months earlier that a drug trafficking ring was scheming to smuggle heroin from Macau, Hong Kong, Thailand, Myanmar and mainland China into Taiwan by air or by fishing boat with individuals carrying small amounts in a bid to avoid detection, the aviation police said.
Cheng was arrested by the police and will be indicted for violating the Narcotics Endangerment Prevention Act, the Taoyuan Prosecutors' Office said.

Meanwhile, according to CKS police authorities, agents from the Ministry of Justice Bureau of Investigation also arrested two men at CKS Airport Sunday who were trying to smuggle heroin into the country. The two men were said to be each carrying four heroin bricks around their waists.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN ENCOURAGES POLICE TO REALIZE SIX GOALS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian encouraged all police staff Tuesday to make concerted efforts to realize six major policy goals.
Chen made the appeal in a written congratulatory message read at a ceremony marking the nation's Police Day.

The six goals outlined in Chen's message were supporting the government's administrative reform; improving public order by cracking down on crimes; abiding by laws and rules while performing their official duties; developing community-based police mechanisms to prevent crimes; enhancing operational efficiency and service quality; and cultivating a clean image.
