DOC.HEADLINE: BUSH SIGNS BILL ON HELPING TAIWAN GAIN WHA OBSERVER STATUS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 14 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: U.S. President George Bush signed into law a Senate bill Monday aimed at pushing for observer status for Taiwan in the World Health Assembly (WHA) -- the policy-making body of the World Health Organization -- according to White House officials.

Bush's signing of the bill, S 2092, passed unanimously by the Senate May 6, makes support for Taiwan's WHO bid a long-term U.S. policy, and is seen as a shot in the arm for Taiwan's longstanding efforts to take part in the activities of the WHO.

In a statement on the signing of the bill into law, President Bush said that the United States fully supports the participation of Taiwan in the work of the World Health Organization, including observer status.
"The United States has expressed publicly its firm support for Taiwan's observer status and will continue to do so, " Bush said.

Bush said in the statement that the U.S. government's "one China" policy -- under which Washington supports eventually reunification of Taiwan and China but opposes bringing about that outcome by force -- remains unchanged.

The bill, initiated by Sen. George Ellen (R-Va.), authorizes the Bush administration to support and assist Taiwan's bid to obtain observer status at the annual conference of the WHA. Sen. Ellen is a co-chairman of the U.S. Taiwan Caucus, which is a pro-Taiwan group in Congress.
The bill, introduced jointly by 13 senators for a vote by the full Senate, was first approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee April 29.

According to the bill, the U.S. secretary of state is required to submit a non-confidential report to Congress before every April 1 detailing measures the U.S. government has taken to help Taiwan gain observer status in the WHA.

The bill also requests that the secretary of state submit an unclassified report to Congress within 30 days after the passage of the bill and before every April 1 describing the plans and measures the U.S. administration has taken to help Taiwan gain observer status in the WHA.
Meanwhile, the U.S. House of Representatives on April 21 passed a similar bill 416-0 to express its support for Taiwan joining the WHA as an observer.
The House bill calls on the secretary of state to report to Congress annually on progress toward developing and implementing the plan to help Taiwan enter the WHO.

Taiwan tried for the eighth straight year to gain observer status in the WHA at its annual gathering this past May but failed again, despite an increasing number of nations publicly voicing their support for Taiwan, including Japan and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: JOBS, POLITICS WORRY ASIANS MORE THAN HEALTH: SURVEY

TEXT.P: An Asian health survey covering Thailand, Taiwan, China, Hong Kong, peninsular Malaysia and Singapore shows that jobs and politics worry Asians more than their health.

The survey results, issued recently in Singapore, indicate that rising levels of stress stemming from anxiety over growing regional unemployment, political instability, criminal and juvenile violence have resulted in citizens'putting health needs in the back seat.
Keeping Asians awake at night was the fear of an economic slowdown sweeping across the Asian region and the fear of unemployment, mostly in Taiwan (78%) , China (64%) and Hong Kong (61%).

Health matters ranked seventh among priority concerns among Asians surveyed in the six countries. Top of the list was unemployment, rising crime rates, drug abuse and political instability, followed by pollution and corruption.

Highest stress levels were found in mainland China (53%), Taiwan (51%), Singapore (43%) and Hong Kong (42%). Lowest stress levels were in peninsular Malaysia and Thailand, with 30% of their populations saying they were stressed. Workplace stress dominated in Hong Kong, the mainland and Singapore while financial worries weighed down Thais and Taiwanese.

Significantly, the survey found that 60% of students aged 15 to 20 experienced stress. Singapore, peninsular Malaysia and Thailand chalked up the most stressed students -- Singapore (66%) peninsular Malaysia (61%), Thailand (61%), the mainland (59%), Taiwan (58%) and Hong Kong (52%) . Parents who suffered'child education stress'was highest in the mainland (10%) , Singapore (9%) with Thailand and peninsular Malaysia at the lowest, with 1%. Study stress experienced by students was highest on the mainland and in Taiwan (7%), followed by Singapore, peninsular Malaysia and Thailand, with 5% each.

Child-related stress experienced by parents was highest in Singapore (11%) followed by the mainland (6%) and Taiwan (5%). Family problems rated highest in Thailand (17%) followed by Hong Kong (11%) and Singapore/peninsular Malaysia (10%).

An estimated 4,700 adults aged 15 and above from China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand and Taiwan participated in the second BRAND's Asian Health Survey (BAHS II) , from late 2003 to early 2004. The survey aims to understand the health concerns and gauge the general well-being of Asians.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR AMENDMENT TO LAW GIVING LEGISLATURE UNDUE POWER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged lawmakers of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the Executive Yuan Tuesday to study a way to curtail the legislature's newly gained power, which interferes with the Executive Yuan's right to name the chiefs of five independent government agencies.

Speaking at a meeting of the DPP's Central Standing Committee, the president said the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan has encroached on the power of the Executive Yuan by inserting a provision into the Basic Law for the Organization of the Central Government to give itself the power to approve the Executive Yuan's nomination of chiefs to the Central Election Commission, the Central Bank of China, the Fair Trade Commission, and the commissions for financial supervision and for communications.

Noting that the law is a milestone in his party's efforts to reorganize the government, the president expressed regret that the legislature expanded its power at the cost of the Executive Yuan while enacting the law.

Instead of asking the Executive Yuan to return the law passed June 11 to the Legislative Yuan for reconsideration, which is tantamount to a veto of the whole legislation, Chen suggested that DPP lawmakers and the Executive Yuan address this part through a revision to the law.
Vowing that his government will not compromise its goal of reorganizing the central government, he urged the DPP, of which he is chairman, to sort the issue out as soon as possible.

Also Tuesday, Chen urged a group of chiefs of DPP branch offices in various counties and cities to help the party win a majority at the Legislative Yuan in the year-end legislative elections, to cement the party's status as the ruling party.

Noting that the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party failed to sway voters in the March 20 presidential election, in spite of its campaign promises that would have cost the country a fortune to realize, Chen said his party will win the legislative elections through its core values rather than through empty promises.
Having won the presidential election by a narrow majority, Chen said he is confident that his party will ride on the coattails of his success to also win a majority in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNITED DAILY NEWS ACQUITTED IN SLANDER CASE

TEXT.P: The mass-circulation United Daily News was cleared of a charge of slander Tuesday in a case brought against it by Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh.
The Taiwan High Court let stand a lower court decision to throw out Hsieh's charge, despite Hsieh's appeal, and to close the whole case.

Hsieh expressed regret at the decision against him, claiming that he respected the court's decision but adding that the United Daily News should be ashamed of itself for what he claimed was "abusing the freedom of the press."

The lawyer-turned-mayor claimed that the newspaper was supported by the opposition Kuomintang during that party's five-decade rule of the country and has helped the party in its vain attempts to suffocate the country's democratic campaign.

Now, he claimed, the paper is carrying on its attacks against former political dissidents who are now the leaders of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, which is far beyond the freedom of the press, he said.

Hsieh brought the case against the paper after it carried an editorial in April last year questioning Hsieh's integrity and lambasting prosecutors for not probing Hsieh's role in a financial scandal involving one of his aides.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF ARMS PURCHASES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian stressed Tuesday the importance of strengthening Taiwan's defense capability and the necessity of buying such weapons as Patriot anti-missile systems, submarines and anti-submarine planes from the United States.

Chen made the remarks at a meeting with Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, who will lead a legislative delegation Wednesday on a visit to the United States to discuss the arms procurement plan with U.S. officials.

The Executive Yuan presented a budget plan to the legislature earlier this month worth NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) to buy defense weapons from the United States. However, the budget plan was not included on the June 10 agenda of the Legislative Yuan for screening due to differing opinions from opposition lawmakers.

Prior to his U.S. visit, Wang noted that the weapons procurement plan is based on the interests of the nation and is not expected to have anything to do with the re-election campaign of U.S. President George W. Bush.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Bangkok Post: Spy charges after mikes uncovered. The government faced mounting criticism yesterday following the discovery of suspicious eaversdropping microphones in the press room of the Information and Communications Technology Ministry. (Franics Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LAW REVISIONS TO OPEN WAY FOR FTA TALKS WITH U.S.

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun called Tuesday for revisions to relevant key laws in an extra legislative session in order to pave the way for bilateral talks with the United States on signing a free trade agreement (FTA).
Yu made the remarks to Ker Chien-ming, a whip of the legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, during a meeting of the party's policy-making Central Standing Committee.

Yu, who heads an Executive Yuan task force aimed at pushing for strategic alliances with friendly countries, told Ker that the Cabinet is seeking to ink an FTA with the United States and he asked for legislative support to include adjustments to several key laws on the agenda of an upcoming extra session to help push for two-way talks with the United States.

According to Yu, the United States is particularly concerned about law amendments related to the protection of intellectual property rights and the opening of the domestic rice, telecommunications and pharmaceutical markets to foreign competition.

Turning to special budget allocations worth a total of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) put forward by the Ministry of National Defense for major military procurement programs, the premier agreed with Ker to discuss the appropriations in the next legislative session that will begin in September.

As to the special budgets for the Cabinet's five-year "10 New Construction Projects" program worth NT$500 billion, Ker said that legislators of the various political parties will vote on the spending before the deadline for negotiations ends July 23.
The last legislative session went into recess last Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG TO HOLD SPORTS COMPETITIONS TO WARM UP FOR WORLD GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, June 15 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: After winning the right to host the 8th World Games in 2009, the Kaohsiung city government decided Tuesday to organize various sports competitions prior to 2009, as a warm up for the World Games.

Kaohsiung Deputy Mayor Lin Yung-chien made the announcement at a preparatory meeting for the World Games a day after Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh signed an agreement with International World Games Association (IWGA) President Ron Froehlich to host the games.

It is the first time Taiwan has obtained the right to host the World Games, an international multi-sports event organized by the International World Games Association (IWGA) under the patronage of the International Olympic Committee (IOC).

The World Games, held once every four years, consists of official and invitational events selected from those not included in the Olympic Games. Unlike the Olympics, participating athletes at the World Games are representatives selected by the International Federation of each sport, not by their countries.
Lin, Froehlich, IWGA Secretary-General Co Koren, and officials from the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports (NCPFS), attended Tuesday's meeting.
Froehlich said he was very impressed by the efficiency of the Kaohsiung city government and the confidence it showed in its ability to host the games.

During the meeting, Lin also made quick and positive responses to Froehlich's proposals, including the setting up of a Chinese-English Web site for the games, the formation of a World Games office, and the selection of sports executives to be in charge of the hardware and software of stadiums.

Lin added that the Kaohsiung city government will also allow the public to gain a better understanding of the newest sports popular around the world through various channels, and will hold "sports carnivals" in Kaohsiung every summer prior to 2009.
Froehlich also suggested that the city government send a delegation to watch the 2005 World Games to be held in Duisburg, Germany.
He said he will visit Kaohsiung again in November to better understand the progress of the preparations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BEIJING TO SIGN PACT ON ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Joseph Wu urged Beijing Tuesday to sign an agreement with Taiwan on the repatriation of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants detained in Taiwan.

Wu made the appeal after an inspection tour of the Hsinchu illegal mainland immigrant detention center in northern Taiwan. It was Wu's first visit to the center since he became Taiwan's top mainland policy planner a month ago.

Wu said that illegal immigration involves many complicated issues. "We hope the Beijing authorities can face up to these issues squarely and adopt effective measures to prevent mainland people from illegally coming to Taiwan," he added.

Noting that Taiwan's three special detention centers have become overcrowded by the large number of illegal mainland immigrants, Wu said Beijing should negotiate an agreement with Taiwan to address the issue once and for all.
Twelve detainees at the Hsinchu detention center have recently delivered babies and 16 others are pregnant, adding even further to the workload for staff at the center.

With the approach of the Dragon Boat Festival -- one of the major festivals in the Chinese calendar -- Wu said, the mainland authorities should take back those "homesick" detainees out of humanitarian considerations.
At present, Taiwan's three detention centers in Hsinchu, Ilan and Matsu accommodate more than 2,500 illegal mainland immigrants, including 1,100 in the Hsinchu detention center alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL AIRLINES POSTPONE AIR TICKET HIKE

TEXT.P: Several domestic airlines decided Tuesday to postpone planned additional fuel surcharges on passenger flight prices from June 16 to July 1.

The decision was made through urgent coordination by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) among local carriers, and the postponement will involve only domestic airlines, with foreign carriers going ahead with the plan, according to a high-ranking CAA official.

Chen Tien-szu, a session deputy chief of the CAA under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, had said earlier in the day at a meeting attended by several lawmakers, executives of domestic airlines, representatives of tourism agencies and officials of the Cabinet-level Consumer Protection Commission, that he would undertake the coordination among domestic airlines and urge them to postpone the price hike.

A tourism agency representative noted at the meeting that the CAA has approved, in just three days, the airlines' plan to charge fuel surcharges, which has left travel agents with insufficient time to react and has created strong opposition from customers.

Legislator Lee Hong-chun of the opposition People First Party (PFP) expressed dissatisfaction with the plan, saying that the CAA approved the plan in just three working days and claiming that it was done without strict examination and investigation.

PFP Legislator Pang Chien-kuo lamented that civil aviation law has no regulations on surcharges that carriers can impose on customers and added that he and his PFP colleagues will work for an amendment to the law in order to protect the interests of customers.

However, Chen noted that the CAA can only receive airlines' solicitations for ticket price hike but has no right to reject them. He added that he will coordinate among domestic carriers and urge them to postpone the price hike.

The CAA approved last week the applications presented by several airlines, including China Airlines (CAL), EVA Airways Corp., Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd., to impose a fuel surcharge on customers ranging from US$5 to US$14 as a way of reflecting the mounting international oil prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT UNVEILS SIX GOALS FOR POLICE

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian unveiled six goals for the police Tuesday, saying that his administration's agenda depends heavily on their achieving the six goals.

In a written letter of congratulations to the nation's policemen on Police Day, Chen said the reforms pursued by his government in the fields of politics, the economy, finance, the judiciary and society need the support and cooperation of the police and this support and cooperation is their first goal.

As peace and order is vital to the country's economic development, the president said the country will have difficulty boosting its economy if it cannot maintain public security, therefore good public order should be the second goal.
The third goal, the president said, should be for the police to improve their competence in enforcing the law and sticking to the letter of the law while carrying out their jobs.
The fourth goal is to tap into the abundant private resources to check crime.

The fifth is to improve police department efficiency and upgrade services to the public, while the sixth is for the police to maintain a clean image and to serve as a law-abiding example for the people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS TO STAGE PROTEST MARCH AGAINST ARMS PROCUREMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: Environmental, educational reform and student activists will take to the streets Saturday to protest against the government's new massive military procurement project, sources said Tuesday.

Ho Chung-hsun, the chief executive officer of the Nuclear-free Taiwan Alliance, said the planned protest march is aimed at forcing the government to give up its NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) plan to purchase advanced weaponry systems from the United States.
Ho said many private groups dedicated to promoting environmental protection and educational reform, as well as several student organizations, have agreed to join the demonstration.

The Cabinet has put forward the special military budget for the purchase of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992 and the budget bill is now pending approval by the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

Huang Wu-hsiung, a National Taiwan University professor and a co-initiator of the weekend protest, said he does not think such a huge military procurement plan will contribute to peace in the Taiwan Strait.
"The government should instead use the money to boost educational reform and help improve welfare services for local underprivileged people," Huang said.

The protest march will start from the main railway station in Taipei and end at the 2-28 Peace Park. The half-day demonstration will also include lectures and skits to signify the protesters' appeal for peace, environmental protection, educational reform and improvement of welfare services for the disadvantaged.

At the U.S. invitation, a 14-member delegation of lawmakers from across the political spectrum, led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, will leave for the United States Thursday to discuss arms procurement budget issues.
U.S. authorities will arrange for the legislative group to visit major military bases to seek their support for the budget for Taiwan's new arms procurement projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-NEW ZEALAND WORKING HOLIDAY SCHEME PACT TAKES EFFECT

TEXT.P: Young Taiwan people intending to take casual work while traveling in New Zealand are welcome to file applications to do so, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.

Speaking at a regular news conference, Lin Sung-huan, director of the MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department, said the Taiwan-New Zealand working holiday scheme agreement took effect June 1.
Under the agreement, young people from both sides can take part-time jobs while vacationing in each other's country.
"New Zealand-bound travelers aged between 18 and 30 are welcome to apply to do casual work during their stays with a view to getting a taste of the exotic lifestyle there," Lin said.
Young New Zealand visitors to Taiwan are also welcome to apply for part-time work under the same working holiday scheme, Lin said.
New Zealand is the first country with which Taiwan has signed a working holiday agreement, while Taiwan is the 18th country with which New Zealand has signed such an accord.
Under the terms of the agreement, the representative offices in each country can issue visas to 400 young people each year who meet the qualifications for enrollment in the program.

The scheme is based on the principle of reciprocity, so that youths from both countries can have a chance to understand first-hand the social customs, culture and people of each other's country, establish lasting friendships and strengthen long-term substantive relations between the two countries through private contacts.
Lin said vacation, not work, should be stated as the would-be applicants' purpose of entry. They should not take full-time jobs nor should they work for the same employer for more than three months.
"The work they undertake will only be to allow them to earn extra money to finance their living expenses during their stays and work should not be the primary purpose of their visit," Lin explained.
Taiwan citizens made about 25,000 visits to New Zealand last year, while New Zealanders made 54,000 visits to Taiwan.
The two countries signed the working holiday agreement in February.
"We hope the implementation of the agreement will help boost exchanges and enhance bilateral cooperation in various fields, " Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER UPBEAT ON PROMISING ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Boosted by encouraging major indexes of economic indicators, Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh said Tuesday that she is not worried about an "industrial hollowing-out of Taiwan businesses" in view of the steadily recovering economy.
Ho made the remarks while giving a speech on Taiwan's economic outlook at a meeting of members of a Rotary club in Taipei.

Claiming that she has no fear that Taiwan companies will relocate to mainland China in the face of the mainland's strong magnetic effect, Ho predicted that this will not happen, as the Taiwan economy is steadily rebounding, in particular the hi-tech sector.

At a time when the world economy and international trade have been forecast to grow by 4.6 percent and 6.8 percent, respectively, for this year, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has predicted that the domestic economy will expand by 5.4 percent, fueled mainly by private-sector investment and consumption.

According to Ho, private-sector investment projects registered with her ministry have hit an all-time high worth NT$866.2 billion (US$25.7 billion) , while the aggregate figure for the first four months of his year has amounted to NT$466 billion, with 53.8 percent of the projects being carried out.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's industrial production index posted a 13.5 percent growth over the year-earlier level, she added.

Citing data issued by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, she said that the economy, according to the government's five-color gauge system, has over the past five months flashed a yellow-red light that represents a rating of heating up for the first time in 10 years, which is clear evidence that it is steadily rebounding.

The economics minister was especially upbeat on the prospects of Taiwan's high technology industries, noting that the production value of the semiconductor industry is expected to top NT$1 trillion this year and that the LCD industry will manage to hit the level of NT$1.3 trillion by 2006.
"I am not worried at all that Taiwan's industries will be hollowed out by mainland China," she said.
The semiconductor and LCD industries are included in the "two-trillion, two-star" program initiated by the government amid an all-out effort to upgrade Taiwan's hi-tech clout.

Pointing out that Taiwan will continue to play a key role in the global supply chain despite the fact that the mainland is emerging as a world economic power, she called for continued labor-division between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that will benefit both.
She expressed her belief that people on both sides will have the wisdom to settle their current political disputes to forge a "win-win" situation for the years to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS TYCOONS SCRAMBLE TO KEEP DISTANCE FROM POLITICS

TEXT.P: Taiwan business tycoons are scrambling to distance themselves from politics, at least on the surface, after Beijing warned that it will not allow Taiwan businessmen who support the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to do business on the mainland.

Lin Pai-li, the chairman of computer giant Quanta, who is reportedly one of many Taiwan businessmen named by Beijing as a supporter of the DPP and therefore, according to Beijing, also a supporter of Taiwan independence, denied Tuesday that he is a "green businessman" -- a term referring to DPP supporters in the business world -- saying that he is not involved in politics in any way.

Instead, he made a pitch for direct transportation links with the mainland to show his ambition to venture into the mainland, claiming that such links will facilitate the establishment of the peace framework between Taiwan and the mainland advocated by President Chen Shui-bian.
Peace will in turn speed up Taiwan's economic growth, Lin said.

Claiming that the government's foot-dragging on approving Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company's investment in the mainland provides the company's mainland rival, SMIT, a chance to cement its market dominance on the mainland, and Lin said the same mistake could be repeated if the government continues to prohibit local TFT-LCD upstream and midstream manufactures to venture across the strait.

Taiwan is not the only country in the world that owns TFT-LCD manufacturing technology and the restriction on domestic TFT-LCD manufacturers from investing in the mainland will not stop the mainland from getting the technology. Rather, it will cost Taiwan businessmen a valuable opportunity to get a share of the mainland market, Lin said.

Liao Chin-hsiang, chairman of the Chi Mei Group, whose founder Shu Wen-lung was criticised by mainland China's People's Daily as a green businessman, said Tuesday that he has always believed business should be kept separate from politics. He added that he would rather keep aloof from politics for "at least fifty years."

Claiming that he visits the mainland one or twice every year and maintains good connection with the mainland authorities, Liao said he does not think his group has been discriminated against after the People's Daily's lambasting of Shu.
However, he shrugged off questions about whether his group will press ahead with its plan to set up a new plant on the mainland or instead divert its investment from the mainland to the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: PM ASKS FOR ALL-OUT EFFORTS TO MAKE WORLD GAMES IN KAOHSIUNG SUCCESS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has instructed that all government agencies work to ensure that Kaohsiung's hosting of the eighth World Games in 2009 is a success, a spokesman of the Executive Yuan said Tuesday.

The premier made the remarks after Kaohsiung won the right to host the international multi-sports event. The World Games is the world's second-largest multi-sports competition after the Olympic Games and covers mainly sports that are not included in the Olympics.

The premiere expressed his appreciation for the Kaohsiung city government, the Cabinet-level National Council on Physical Fitness and Sports, and the Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee, which have made concerted efforts over the past two years to win the hosting rights.

The premier believes that hosting the international sports event is an exciting thing for Taiwan and is also significant because it will help Taiwan win international friendship and promote sports exchanges, according to the spokesman.

According to an agreement signed between Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh and the International World Games Association Monday, the 8th World Games will be held from July 16-26, 2009, with contests in 34 sports, including billiards, bodybuilding, bowling, boules, faustball, sports aerobics, gateball and karate, plus three demonstration games -- croquet, tchoukball and dragon-boat racing.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN CENSURES MOTC, CAA OVER CAL PLANE CRASH

TEXT.P: The nation's highest watchdog body Tuesday censured the Ministry of the Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) over a China Airlines (CAL) crash two years ago.

A committee of the Control Yuan passed an investigation report on the Hong Kong-bound CAL plane that crashed in waters off Penghu shortly taking off from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport May 25, 2002, killing all 225 people aboard. Human error was ruled out as a cause of the crash.

The report noted that the investigation report by the Aviation Safety Council under the Executive Yuan has yet to be unveiled and that the Control Yuan's report focused only on the administrative responsibility based on the facts already disclosed.

The report faulted the MOTC and the CAA for not properly supervising CAL's efforts to improve its flight safety and the MOTC for not properly supervising the China Aviation Development Foundation (CADF), the biggest shareholder of CAL.
All the directors and supervisors of the foundation, except for the CAL chairman and president, were recommended and appointed by the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW POLITICAL PARTY INAUGURATED

TEXT.P: A new political party was inaugurated Tuesday, with former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya selected to serve as its chairwoman.

The Non-partisan Solidarity Union (NSU) held its inaugural meeting in the auditorium of the Legislative Yuan, with many senior officials and politicians from across the political spectrum showing up to offer their congratulations and best wishes.

Among the well-wishers were Vice Minister of the Interior Lee Chin-yung and Chang Chun-hsiung, secretary-general of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) . Their presence conveyed the DPP administration's goodwill toward the birth of the new party. The Ministry of the Interior was originally reluctant to accept its registration as a political party because its title bears the word "non-partisan."
"We welcome the NSU's inception as Taiwan's 106th legally registered political party," Lee said at the inaugural ceremony.
The new political party was founded by 10 incumbent independent lawmakers and dozens of other veteran politicians, including former Legislator Chen Chieh-ju and former Hsinchu Mayor Shih Hsing-chung.
Chang said the party will nominate at least 15 candidates to take part in the year-end legislative elections.
"We expect to win 15 legislative seats in the new legislature, " added Chang, a seasoned politician who has served as Department of Health minister, a legislator and Chiayi mayor.
Chang also unveiled a plan to seek designs for the party's logo and flag. The top three winners will be rewarded with prizes of NT$100,000, NT$50,000 and NT$30,000, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN VOWS TO CUT JOBLESS RATE, NOT TO INTRODUCE MAINLAND WORKERS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Tuesday that he would not introduce mainland Chinese laborers to work in Taiwan during his term and vowed to further cut the jobless rate to 4 percent next year.

President Chen, who concurrently serves as chairman of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the remarks when he met with leaders of labor unions at DPP headquarters to listen to their opinions after the legislature passed a landmark bill late last week that will transform the current old-age payments for retirees to an annuity system.

The president noted that after 14 years of efforts, the labor pension bill finally cleared the legislature, which he said came about through bipartisan efforts and that he had already thanked Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng.

In retrospect, Chen said that laborers in Taiwan used to have the longest working hours in the world, but the government managed to cut them when domestic and international economies were on the downturn and having difficulties in 2000.

In 2001, the government convened a national economic development conference during which all participants reached consensus on the new pension system and "no one is happier than me to see it pass the Legislative Yuan," the president said.

On the comments on new system by some laborers that "they are not satisfied, but they can accept it, " he said that just as he told the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union, an ally of the DPP, although he had hoped for a perfect score of 100 points, if he can only manage 80 points, it will still be better to have the 80 points than nothing at all and having to start over again from square one. "The government attaches great importance to the rights of eight million laborers and their families, and wouldn't want to see the long-term efforts go down the drain," he said, adding that if laborers accept the system only reluctantly, then it means that "there is still room for improvement."
He reaffirmed that all his promises to laborers during the presidential campaign will be delivered, especially after the most difficult pension law has been passed.

As long as he is in office, he said that he will protect the working rights of domestic laborers and ban the introduction of mainland Chinese laborers and will continue to promote the introduction of the three basic rights, including collective consultation rights, into the Constitution.
He also said that with the continued economic rebound -- export and import orders in May set a new high for a single month -- Taiwan's economy is on the road to recovery.
"I'm confident that the jobless rate will be cut to 4.5 percent this year, and further down to 4 percent next year, " the president added.

Under the current system, most workers cannot get retirement payments from companies because they usually do not stay at the same company for either 15 or 25 years as stipulated in the Labor Standards Law.

The new law calls for the establishment of an individual retirement fund account for each employee with the allocation of 6 percent of monthly wages -- with the employers providing a matching amount. Employees can continue building up the fund even if they change to another job.
The fines for employers who do not comply with the law will be sharply raised, although they can make it up in a period of five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market reported mixed results Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for June rose 64 points to close at 5,604, with 30,121 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for July gained 94 points to end at 5,541 with 19,610 contracts traded, while September futures rose 61 points to end at 5,505, with 14 contracts finalized.
Next March futures lost 156 points to close at 5,450, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for December.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,540 for June, 5,447 for July, 5,444 for September, 5,446 for December and 5,606 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also ended mixed.
June TE futures gained 2.9 points to close at 222.8, with 3,579 contracts traded, while July TE futures rose 2.6 points to end at 217, with 4,785 contracts transacted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO GET SWISS JUDICIAL AID IN LAFAYETTE FRIGATE SCANDAL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) confirmed Tuesday that it has made principled commitments to Swiss judicial authorities in order to receive their assistance in its probe into the snowballing Lafayette frigate procurement scandal.

Vice Minister of Justice Hsien Wen-ting said the Swiss Federal Supreme Court came up with a final ruling last month on offering judicial assistance to Taiwan after rejecting a high-profile Taiwan fugitive's appeal against such a decision.

Nevertheless, Hsieh said, the Swiss supreme court has imposed some conditions on its promised judicial assistance, including no capital sentence for Andrew Wang, who has been wanted by Taiwan in connection with the death of an ROC Navy captain in 1993 and the alleged Lafayette kickback scandal, should he be convicted.
Before his departure for a U.S. visit last Sunday, Hsieh said Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan already signed a "principled promises" document to clear the way for Swiss judicial assistance.

According to the document, the MOJ promises to respect the "innocent supposition" principle in treating Wang, to ensure Wang's right to appeal his case, to allow Wang to retain attorneys and to exempt him from the death sentence.
Hsieh said Chen's signing of the document complies with general customs and practices in international judicial assistance in criminal investigations.

After completing the administrative formalities, Hsieh said, the ministry will send the document to Swiss judicial authorities in near future to secure access to their legal files concerning Wang's bank accounts in Switzerland.
If Wang returns to Taiwan to stand trial, Hsieh said, it will be of great help in solving the Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng murder case and the Lafayette kickback scandal.

In Taiwan, prosecution authorities are only responsible for criminal investigations and have no power to decide whether a suspect is guilty or how to punish a convicted one. Criminal trials are the responsibility of the courts.

Asked whether the MOJ's "no death sentence" promise would encroach on the court's power, Hsieh said abolishment of capital punishment has been an important long-term judicial policy goal of the government.
Hsieh said the MOJ was informed of Switzerland's demand for its "principled promises" on May 11.
"We conducted extensive rounds of negotiations and consultations before Minister Chen signed the document on the eve of his departure for the United States last Sunday," Hsieh explained.
He said the MOJ has drafted the document in English. "The contents will not be publicized," he added.

According to MOJ tallies, the United States is the only country that has signed a formal judicial assistance agreement with the Republic of China. The ROC has signed extradition treaties with six to nine of its diplomatic allies. Switzerland only agreed to offer judicial assistance to Taiwan on a case-by-case basis.

A Swiss federal court ruled last December that Taiwan, France and the Principality of Liechtenstein should be given access to Swiss legal files, particularly documents regarding the Andrew Wang family's bank accounts in Switzerland, to facilitate investigations into an alleged kickback scandal in connection with Taiwan's procurement of six Lafayette frigates from France in 1991.

Wang then filed an appeal against that ruling. The Swiss Federal Supreme Court ruled against Wang's appeal early last month, paving the way for the realization of the long-awaited Swiss judicial assistance to Taiwan.
Swiss judicial authorities have frozen Wang's Swiss bank accounts, which contain some US$600 million in suspected slush funds used as kickbacks from the Lafayette frigate deal.

Wang, an arms broker, fled Taiwan in 1993 and has been wanted since September 2000 for suspected involvement in the alleged Lafayette kickback scandal and the subsequent murder of an ROC Navy captain in 1993.

Wang and his son, Wang Chia-hsing, might also have bank accounts with deposits totaling US$100 million in Liechtenstein and the British-administered Cayman Islands in the Caribbean Sea, according to previous press reports.

Since Aug. 1, 2000, a special investigative team headed by State Public Prosecutor-General Lu Ren-fa has been probing arms procurement scandals allegedly connected with the death of ROC Navy Captain Yin Ching-feng under suspicious circumstances.

MOJ sources said two prosecutors from the Public Prosecutors' Office of the Taiwan High Court are now handling the case. According to the sources, the two prosecutors have made several visits to Switzerland in the past few years and have forged a smooth, informal working relationship with the Swiss federal court.
The ROC Navy purchased six Lafayette frigates built by French defense contractor Thomson-CSF for US$2.8 billion in 1991.
Allegations of kickbacks over the deal emerged after the death of Yin, head of the navy's arms acquisition office, whose body was found floating in the sea off the east coast of Taiwan in late 1993.
It has been alleged that Yin was murdered to prevent him from blowing the whistle on rampant corruption in the military -- including the Lafayette deal.
The investigation team has so far indicted six middle-ranking naval officers on charges of inflating the Lafayette price tag for the benefit of the French contractor.

As for the murder case, no major breakthrough has been achieved because key suspect Wang, who is believed to be deeply involved in the Lafayette kickback scandal, remains at large, reportedly residing in London.
The investigation team has not yet discovered any hard evidence of alleged Lafayette kickbacks paid to Taiwan officials.
To speed up the investigations, the team has recently recruited several prosecutors versed in financial and banking affairs to assist in tracking the money trail.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL ACQUIRES NEW PLANES TO BOOST OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) -- Taiwan's largest carrier -- will acquire seven new airplanes this year to increase its passenger and cargo capabilities, mainly for routes within Asia, according to a CAL executive. CAL General Manager Philip H. H. Wei made the report in a shareholder meeting over the weekend. Purchase and lease of the seven airplanes will help CAL effectively reduce its costs, he said.

According to Wei, three A330-300 planes bought by CAL will be delivered by late June to gradually replace its A300-600R planes. The three new aircraft will help CAL increase passenger seats by 20 percent and provide much greater space for its cargo business, injecting a boost to the carrier's transport volume on Asian routes, he explained.

In addition, two newly leased B747-400F airplanes will join CAL all-cargo operations in June, while another two new B747-400 passenger planes are slated to be delivered in November or December, Wei added.

Looking to the future, competition in the global air traffic market will become fiercer and full of new challenges because of the global economic recovery, Wei predicted, saying that CAL will continue the modernization of its fleet to upgrade its management and explore new markets.
The company has set a goal of posting an annual business turnover of NT$89.07 billion (US$2.66 billion) and an EPS of NT$1 for 2004, he said.

CAL's operations last year were affected by the impact of the outbreaks of severe acute respiratory syndrome and the United States-led war against Iraq, he said. However, he pointed out that it still managed to chalk up a profit for 2003, registering after-tax earnings of NT$1.78 billion.

Amid a drive to expand its business, the carrier also launched early this month regular commercial flight services between Taipei and Hiroshima, while it plans to open a Seattle-Houston route on June 22 and start cargo services between Taipei and Milan on June 27.
CAL opened a Hanoi-Brisbane route and resumed the Taipei-Hawaii route last year. The aviation company was rewarded an "excellent service award" by Commonwealth Magazine in its 2003 November edition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 72.41 points to close at 5,646.49.
The bourse opened at 5,546.27 and fluctuated between 5,646.49 and 5,514.17 during trading.

A total of 3.03 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$66.01 billion (US$1.96 billion) , a decrease from the previous trading session, which saw 3 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$66.82 billion.

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving up the most at 2.6 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.7 percent, foodstuff stocks at 1.6 percent, cement stocks and electrical shares both at 1.2 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent, and construction stocks at 0.1 percent.
Plastics and chemical shares, however, closed even.
Gainers outnumbered losers 492 to 264, with 200 stocks remaining unchanged.
