DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST TAIWANESE TO BE BADMINTON UMPIRE AT OLYMPIC GAMES

TEXT.P: Chang Wen-wei, a Taiwanese, will serve as an umpire for badminton competitions at the Athens 2004 Olympic Games to be held Aug. 13-29.

Chang, who already is an umpire in Taiwan for international badminton tournaments, will be one of the 24 people from around the globe to umpire at the badminton competitions at the Athens 2004 Olympic Games.
Passing many strict exams, Chang was approved by the International Badminton Federation as an umpire two years ago, and this year he was qualified to be one at the Athens 2004 Olympic Games.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOING WELL IN FIGHT AGAINST HUMAN TRAFFICKING: U.S STATE DEPT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The U.S. government says that Taiwan is complying with U.S. and international efforts to fight human trafficking, sources from the Department of State reported Monday.

In its just-published annual report on global human trafficking, the State Department placed Taiwan among nations "deemed to be complying with U.S. and international efforts to fight trafficking, " a group labeled as "Tier 1."

The report praises the Taiwan authorities for having paid close attention to the human trafficking issue. In addition to strengthening law enforcement to crack down on trafficking, the Taiwan authorities have also collaborated with NGO groups in efforts to stem such crimes from reoccurring, the report says.

The report also infers that some Taiwanese women had been forced to engage in the sex trade in Japan, and many mainland Chinese women were conned into coming to Taiwan under the guise of employment but ended up in underground brothels. The report adds that the situation pertaining to Vietnamese women being tricked into coming to Taiwan has also become increasingly serious.
Countries that have made "significant efforts" are placed in "Tier 2."

For the first time in its four-year history, the 2004 report created a "Tier 2 watchlist" for countries that are not yet in compliance with U.S. legal standards and may be downgraded, but have promised to make or are in the process of making significant efforts to meet the requirements, officials from the State Department said.
By far the largest number of the 140 nations surveyed for the study were placed on the watchlist, including longstanding U.S. ally Japan as well as Greece, Turkey, India and Thailand.

Ten nations, including Cuba, Myanmar, North Korea and Sudan, were cited by the report as being in the "Tier 3" group for not having done enough to combat trafficking and will be subjected to sanctions unless they "demonstrably improve their records by October, " the State Department said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SUPPORTER TO FORFEIT U.S. CITIZENSHIP TO RETURN TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, June 14 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A long-term supporter of President Chen Shui-bian said Monday that he will forfeit his U.S. citizenship to return to Taiwan to serve as a senior adviser to President Chen.
Wu Li-pei, founder of the Formosa Foundation and head of an overseas group that is friendly to President Chen, said that he would return to Taiwan in mid-July at the latest.
Wu said that he first thought about forfeiting his U.S. citizenship and return to Taiwan when he founded an overseas group supportive of the president in Los Angles in 2000.
But with increasing members of the group and the founding of the Formosa Foundation in 2002, Wu said he stayed in the U.S. because he wanted to help the deepening of democracy in Taiwan.
Now that the democratic environment is ripe in Taiwan, which he said is his wish come true, this is the best time to return to Taiwan, he said.

The Formosa Foundation is a non-partisan, non-profit, public interest, educational group dedicated to the promotion of human rights and democracy and the exchange of ideas between the U.S. and Taiwan, and to foster better understanding and friendship for the peoples on both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COAST GUARD SEIZE 12,000 KG OF SMUGGLED BETEL NUTS

TEXT.P: Coast guard officials in the outlying island of Kinmen announced Tuesday the seizure of over 12,000 kilograms of betel nuts aboard a Taiwan fishing ship.

Coast guard officials were tipped off that the Ilan-registered fishing boat "Chinfuli" was planning to smuggle betel nuts to Taiwan. In a raid Monday night in waters off Kinmen, they made the largest haul of smuggled betel nuts in Kinmen.
At around 9 p.m. Monday, cost guard officials intercepted the ship around six nautical miles northeast of Peiting islet after the ship sailed out from a harbor of Quanzhou, Fujian province.
Coast guard officials estimated that the 12,180 kilograms of betel nuts came from Hainan, Guangdong, and could fetch NT$12 million (US$358,200) on the wholesale market, or twice on the retail market.

Captain Lee Chung-kuo, crew member Hsieh Chung-liang and a Vietnamese man were arrested, the officials said. Initial investigation showed that the trio sailed out of Wuchi, Taichung, June 11. They loaded the betel nuts June 13, preparing to smuggle them into Ilan, northeastern Taiwan.
Captain Lee claimed that he was hired for NT$200,000 to carry the betel nuts, but he insisted that he didn't know who the owner of the cargo was.

Officials noted that they had seized smuggled betel nuts at CKS International Airport and the outlying island of Penghu recently, apparently because between April and August each year betel nuts are off-season in Taiwan.
They said that NT$100 can buy 40 betel nuts during the peak season, but only 12 during the off-season.

Captain Lee and the crew members were turned over to the Kinmen Prosecutor's Office for violating regulations governing smuggling, national security and the statute governing the relations between the people across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 450 PEOPLE SIGN UP DURING ITRI HEADHUNTING TOUR IN U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 14 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More than 450 overseas Taiwanese have signed up for interviews with a headhunting mission from Taiwan's Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) for high-technology job openings in Taiwan.

The ITRI mission, headed by ITRI President Johnsee Lee, visited Silicon Valley, San Diego, Chicago and Boston in a whirlwind tour of America June 5-12, interviewing over 450 overseas Taiwanese who have studied engineering or computer science in the United States or have worked in related fields.
The non-profit ITRI is offering more than 200 high-tech job openings for the overseas Taiwanese as the institute is envisaging an ambitious "Go Beyond R & D" project to be achieved by 2008.

According to Paul P. S. Lin, director-general of ITRI's Computer & Communication Research Labs, the interviewees include experienced professionals and young scholars who have recently obtained doctoral degrees.

The ITRI hopes to recruit specialists and talent to beef up the institute's R & D prowess in several fields, including electronics, telecommunications, information technology, biochemical/medicine, nanotechnology, advanced manufacturing, automatic systems and energy.

According to Lin, the number of U.S.-trained scientists and high-tech professionals returning to Taiwan for career development has declined to 50-60 annually in recent years from 200-300 annually five or six years ago.

The ITRI, meanwhile, has suffered a high personnel turnover rate over the past several years given that employees from the ITRI have been hotly sought after by private or publicly-run R & D centers at home and abroad, Lin said.
Over the past five years, according to Lin, the ITRI has recruited 172 Ph.D holders and 185 holders of master's degrees from overseas, mainly the United States, to return to Taiwan to work.

The ITRI, a top Taiwan research and development organization engaging in applied research and technical service which was set up by the Ministry of Economic Affairs in 1973, has helped establish 36 high-tech companies in Taiwan, including such big names as Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and United Miroelectronics Corp.
The number of ITRI-nurtured high-tech specialists totals over 16,000, with some 5,000 of these working in key positions at firms in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, including 58 CEOs.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Al Qaeda May Have Delayed 9/11 Attack; Commission Finds Evidence Pointing To Earlier Date.
The independent commission probing the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks has found evidence suggesting the attacks were intended to be carried out in May or June of that year, but were postponed by al Qaeda leaders because lead hijacker Mohamed Atta was not ready, according to sources privy to the panel's findings.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL DAILY HAILS ACQUITTAL IN LIBEL SUIT AS PRESS FREEDOM VICTORY

TEXT.P: The United Daily News (UDN) , one of Taipei's major Chinese-language newspapers, hailed its acquittal Tuesday in a libel suit filed against it by Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh as a "victory of press freedom."

The Taiwan High Court announced earlier in the day that it was upholding a Kaohsiung District Court ruling that the UDN was not guilty of libeling Hsieh by carrying an editorial in April 2003 commenting on vote-buying scandals in the elections of speaker and deputy speaker of the Kaohsiung City Council in late 2002. The high court ruling was final.

"The high court ruling is not only a victory for a single daily but also a victory for all media staff, " the UDN statement said, adding that the ruling once again epitomizes judicial authorities' recognition and protection of press freedom.
The statement further said that it is both a constitutional right and a social obligation for news media to comment on political events and individual politicians in a democratic society.

"We are hopeful that this ruling will provide valuable inspiration for interaction between local politicians and news media, " the statement said, adding that the newspaper also looks forward to seeing news media and politicians cooperate in developing a relationship that is constructive to democratic development.
Hsieh had sued the paper as he felt that the UDN editorial insinuated that he might be involved in the vote-buying scandals.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO SPEED UP REPATRIATION OF DETAINED ILLEGALS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The nation's top mainland China policy planner on Tuesday urged Beijing to speed up repatriation of illegal mainland Chinese immigrants being detained in Taiwan.
Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks when he visited a detention center for illegal mainland Chinese immigrants in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan.

Wu noted that mainland China has unilaterally suspended the pickup operations since March 12 and that Taiwan's three detention centers in Hsinchu, Ilan and Matsu are overcrowded with a record high of more than 2,500 detainees, including 1,100 in the Hsinchu detention center alone.
He urged the Beijing authorities not to drag their feet, to try to sympathize with the "homesick" detainees, and to reactivate the repatriation process immediately.

Out of humanitarian considerations, the Hsinchu detention center has arranged for the detainees in the center to be able to phone back to their families on the mainland before the Dragon Boat Festival, a traditional Chinese festival which falls on June 22 this year. Wu has also donated NT$30,000 (US$) for extra holiday dishes for the detainees.

Wu said that a total of 14 repatriation operations were conducted last year, with more than 2,200 illegal immigrants being returned to the mainland. Five repatriation operations have been conducted so far this year up to March 12, when Beijing stopped sending ships to pick up more detainees.

He urged Beijing authorities to think about the feelings of the detainees, especially prior to the Dragon Boat Festival, saying that the authorities should shoulder the responsibility of taking care of their own nationals.

Faced with rising crime involving illegal mainland Chinese immigrants, the overcrowded situation at the detention centers, and the financial strain of accommodating the immigrants, Wu urged Beijing to communicate through the current channels -- namely Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- and sign an agreement so that both sides can work together toward fighting crime.

The Red Cross Society on both sides of the Taiwan Strait signed an agreement in Kinmen in 1990 to deal with the repatriation of criminals and illegal mainland Chinese immigrants, but the SEF and the ARATS have yet to sign a formal agreement despite talks in the intervening years. The talks between the two semi-official bodies were suspended in 1999 in the wake of then-President Lee Teng-hui's advocacy of "special state-to-state" cross-strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TROPICAL STORM DIANMU BECOMES TYPHOON

TEXT.P: Tropical storm Dianmu, which formed in the Pacific Ocean three days ago, has gained strength over the last 12 hours to become a typhoon, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Tuesday.
Typhoon Dianmu was centered some 850 kilometers southwest of Guam at 8 a.m. Tuesday, moving in a north-northwest direction at a speed of 17 kilometers per hour, CWB meteorologists said.

With a radius of 180 kilometers and packing maximum sustained winds of up to 130 kilometers per hour, Dianmu -- the sixth typhoon reported in the Pacific area this year -- is not expected to directly affect Taiwan since it is expected to shift to a northwest course over the following hours, the CWB reported.
Meanwhile, temperatures in Taiwan have shot up due to the influence of a Pacific high pressure system, with highs of 32-34 degrees Celsius forecast for around the island over the next few days.
The CWB meteorologists have also warned that the ultra-violet ray index around Taiwan will be high for the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 15, or the 28th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1752: Benjamin Franklin, American founding father, diplomat, writer and scientist, flies a kite in a thunderstorm to prove his theory that lightning and electricity are the same phenomenon.
1775: George Washington is elected by Congress as general and commander-in-chief of the army of the United Colonies.
1849: James Knox Polk, the 11th president of the United States, dies at the age of 54. His term was marked by the establishment of the 49th parallel as the northern border west of the Great Lakes.
1860: Nursing pioneer Florence Nightingale opens the world's first school for nurses at St. Thomas' Hospital in London.
1911: The Computing-Tabulating Recording Company (CTR), an American firm that dominated the office equipment and information technology industries, changes its name to International Business Machines Corporation (IBM), becoming the world's largest manufacturer of information systems and equipment.
1919: Aviation history is made as English aviators Capt. John Alcock and Lt. Arthur Whitten Brown touch down in Clifden, Ireland, thus completing the world's first nonstop flight across the Atlantic.
1944: U.S. forces bomb and land on the Mariana Islands, inflicting a heavy defeat on Japanese troops in the west Pacific.
1945: Under the instruction of President Harry S. Truman, the U.S. envoy to China notifies the Chinese government of the Yalta Secret Agreement. Among other conclusions, the U.S., Great Britain and the USSR agreed at Yalta on Feb. 11 that the USSR shall enter the war against Japan on condition that its former rights (in China) plundered by Japan in 1909 shall be restored.
1948: The People's Daily, a Chinese Communist Party newspaper, publishes its first issue.
1957: The Kaohsiung plant of Formosa Plastics Corporation is inaugurated, becoming the first plastics raw material producing plant in Southeast Asia.
1964: The 11th Asian Film Festival opens in Taipei.
1975: Chang Pao-shu, secretary-general of the Kuomintang Central Committee, and four other members leave for Tokyo to attend the funeral of former Japanese Prime Minister Eikaku Sato.
1976: Maj. Gen. Kin Sang Tao, chief of the South Korean Air Force, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1979: After seven years of negotiations, the United States and the Soviet Union sign the second phase of an arms-limitation treaty.
1981: Sun I-suan, chairman of the Taipei Bankers Association, announces an increase in the highest deposit interest rate to 15 percent and in the top loan rate to 18 percent.
1987: The ROC's Legislative Yuan committees pass the proposed National Security Law. The bill was scheduled for submission to the full legislature on June 19.
1987: Premier Yu Kuo-hwa says that the Republic of China is to buy ten commercial aircraft, including six Boeing 747-400 jetliners, from the United States, in an effort to narrow the trade imbalance between the two countries.
1993: The ROC's Legislative Yuan passes The "Public Functionary Assets Disclosure Law."
1995: Premier Lien Chan launches a six-day visit to three European countries -- Austria, Hungary, and Czechoslovakia. He is the highest level ROC official to visit Europe since the ROC government moved to Taipei in 1949.
1999: South Korea sinks one North Korean gunboat and heavily damages others in the Yellow Sea.
2000: The three-day 2000 Taipei International Food Exhibition opens at the Taipei World Trade Center, with exhibitors from more than 10 countries participating.
2001: Chen Po-chih, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, says the information technology (IT) industry will remain be the top player among all industries in the next 10 years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To preach in the public streets the commonplaces which you have picked up on the way is to throw away all your finer feelings."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Straits Times: NS cut by six months.
National service training in Singapore will be cut by six months to a maximum of two years, a reduction made possible with the Singapore Armed Forces relying more on technology and less on having large numbers of soldiers.
The Lianhe Zaobao: Full-time NS to be cut to 2 years from Dec 2004 intake: Singapore Defence minister.
NSmen, who are 18 years of age and promoted to the rank of corporals or higher, will only serve two years instead of two-and-half years. This takes effect from the December 2004 intake.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Bangkok Post: Contract let Cnnel 5 bear debt. The controversial contract two former Channel 5 directors refused to sign, resulting to RTA Entertainment, a firm whose board members include former calssmates of the army chief, and leaves the station to shoulder the debt. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: AGENTS SEIZE SMUGGLED ARMS

TEXT.P: Investigation Bureau agents in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, reported Wednesday that they had seized more than 100 smuggled weapons, including guns and knives, concealed in a container.

Tipped off recently that an illegal ring has for a long time been smuggling guns and ammunition concealed in containers into Taiwan from mainland China and that such a shipment might be arriving soon, the agents heightened their alert.

The agents, in a check of containers Wednesday, discovered the smuggled weapons at Kaohsiung Harbor in a container that was registered as carrying artifacts. The seized weapons included two air pistols, three muskets, and 102 long knives and swords.
As the agents determined the items to be potentially dangerous, the weapons were impounded according to the law, and the agents are currently trying to track down members of the smuggling ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DONATES FUNDS TO YOUNG AMERICAS BUSINESS TRUST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 15 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government donated US$150,000 to the Young Americas Business Trust under the Organization of American States (OAS) Tuesday to help young entrepreneurs in Latin America and the Caribbean launch business ventures.
Chen Chien-jen, ROC representative to the United States, donated the funds to the Young Americas Business Trust on behalf of the ROC government in a ceremony held in Washington, D.C.

OAS Assistant Secretary-General Luigi Einaudi and Dennis Antoine, vice chairman of the Young Americas Business Trust and Grenadan ambassador to the OAS, received the donation on behalf of the organization.
They said the ROC's aid will contribute to the trust's cause of helping aspiring youths create their own businesses and thus boost regional development.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 17 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are major events scheduled to take place Thursday, June 17:
09:30, Vice President Annete Lu will visit Chunghsing New Village in Nantou, central Taiwan.
09:30, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will attend an award ceremony for tips leading to crackdowns of CD piracy at the central Taiwan office of the Ministry of Justice in Tantze, Taichung, central Taiwan.
09: 40, President Chen Shui-bian will visit the Chengkung Hill military base in Taichung, central Taiwan.
10: 00, Food Taipei 2004 will open at the Taipei World Trade Center.
10:30, The Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a regular press conference at the ministry's headquarters.
10:30, The change-over ceremony of outgoing and incoming heads of the Central Election Commission (CEC) will be held at the CEC headquarters.
11: 00, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan will chair the joint meeting of government agencies stationed in the Executive Yuan's joint service center for central Taiwan at Lin Garden Restaurant Taichung.
11:00, The Fair Trade Commission will hold a press conference at the commission's headquarters.
12:30, The National Science Council will hold a press conference at the council's headquarters.
12: 35, President Chen Shui-bian will visit police officers injured in the line of duty and hospitalized at Chung Shan Medical University Hospital.
14: 30, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will depart at the head of a legislative delegation for the United States at the CKS International Airport.
16: 30, The Ministry of Finance will hold a press conference at the ministry's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON DIANMU UPGRADED TO STRONG TYPHOON

TEXT.P: Typhoon Dianmu -- the sixth typhoon reported in the Pacific area this year -- has gained strength over the last eight hours and been upgraded to a strong typhoon, although it is not expected to directly affect Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Wednesday.
Dianmu was centered some 1,800 kilometers southeast of Taiwan at 8 a.m. Wednesday, moving in a north-northwest direction at a speed of 17 kilometers per hour, CWB meteorologists said.

With a radius of 180 kilometers and packing maximum sustained winds of up to 130 kilometers per hour, Dianmu is not expected to directly affect Taiwan since it is expected to shift to a northwest course over the following day and eventually sweep toward Japan, the CWB reported.
However, the CWB forecasters said that Taiwan as a whole should pay close attention to the typhoon over the next 24 hours as weather conditions could change fast.

Meanwhile, temperatures in Taiwan have shot up due to the influence of a Pacific high pressure system, with highs of 34 degrees Celsius forecast for around the island and afternoon thunder showers for mountainous areas in central and southern Taiwan expected over the next few days.
The CWB meteorologists have also warned that the ultra-violet ray index around Taiwan will be high for the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMISSION OF US CONGRESS RECOMMENDS TAIPEI-WASHINGTON HOTLINE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 16 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A commission of the U.S. Congress urged the Congress and the U.S. administration Tuesday to weigh the possibility of installing a hotline between Washington and Taipei for communication in case of emergency.

The U.S.-China Economic and Security Review Commission noted in its 2004 report that any military conflict erupting across the Taiwan Strait won't last long in light of the fact that China emphasizes surprise attacks and hoax military moves, therefore a hotline will give Washington the chance to know and deal with any crisis in the Taiwan Strait in time.

At a news conference called to release the report Tuesday, C. Richard D'Amato, vice chairman of the commission, said the hotline should be established between officials of rather high levels who can get a grip on what is happening immediately.

The commission, set up by the House of Representatives and the Senate in 2000 to work out suggestions to the Congress on economic and security issues concerning China, consists of 12 members, with three members each from the Democratic Party and the Republic Party at the House of Representatives and the Senate.

The commission's chairman, Roger W. Robinson, said China's increasingly military threat against Taiwan, and its diplomatic campaign to isolate Taiwan on the international stage have fueled a schism among Taiwanese, and therefore the United States should review its long-standing "one China" policy, which acknowledges Taiwan as a part of China.

Given the wide political difference between Taiwan and China, D'Amato said Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula for reunion with Taiwan won't work, and the United States should help Taiwan to enhance its international profile as long as Taiwan doesn't declare independence de jure.
In order to maintain Taiwan's economic prosperity, D'Amato recommended the United States resume free trade negotiations with Taiwan.
Noting that the U.S. government is not interested in the negotiations, he suggested Taiwan sweeten the pill by submitting more attractive proposals in the talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTY PROPOSES EXTRAORDINARY LEGISLATIVE SESSION IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) has proposed an extraordinary legislative session be held in mid-August, a party whip of the KMT legislative caucus said Wednesday.

Huang Te-fu, deputy secretary-general of the KMT caucus, said that the KMT hopes the extraordinary session will deal with the establishment of a task force to investigate and get to the bottom of the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, the establishment of a task force to look into the activation of the national security mechanism and revisions to the Republic of China Constitution for legislative reforms.
If the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) finds other issues to be discussed, Huang said, the proposed extraordinary session can also deal with them.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun called on the Legislative Yuan June 11 when the legislature concluded its regular session to open an extraordinary session to deal with some urgent bills.
The premier said that the accumulated number of bills mired down in the legislature has reached 303.
He said that the lack of legislative action will hamper the governing of his administration unless some urgent bills are enacted during an extraordinary session.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF EMPLOYEES IN ECONOMIC PROCESSING ZONES JUMPS

TEXT.P: The number of employees in Taiwan's five economic processing zones exceeded 70,100 in May, an increase of 7,250 over the same month of last year, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
Officials of the MOEA's Economic Processing Zone Administration attributed the rise to the gradual and stable economic recovery.

The statistics also show that the Nantze Economic Processing Zone employed the largest number of workers, with 39,190, followed by Kaohsiung Economic Processing Zone with 16,160 and Taichung Economic Processing Zone with 11,550. Chungkang and Chengkung Economic Processing Zones employed a total of 3,200 workers.
The number of workers in these economic processing zones accounted for 0.035 percent of Taiwan's total manufacturing force, and 53,000 of them worked for electronic and electric companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD RELAX POLICIES TO ATTRACT MORE FOREIGN INVESTMENT: CPDE

TEXT.P: Taiwan should accelerate the relaxation of current regulations to develop as a regional financial service center and attract more foreign direct investment (FDI) , a report from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) suggested Wednesday.

A CEPD official quoting the World Bank's Global Development Finance 2004 report as saying that developing countries, especially mainland China, Thailand and Malaysia are expected to attract more FDI in the coming two years due to the global economic recovery and the increasing economic liberalization in these countries.
According to the statistics from the World Bank, FDI in developing countries totaled US$135.2 billion in 2003, a decline of 9 percent over the previous year.

However, the trend will reverse in the coming years, with the FDI expected to flow to emerging countries, in the amounts of US$152 billion and US$165 billion in 2004 and 2005, respectively, the statistics show.

Asian emerging countries will receive the largest FDI in the next two years, with Latin American countries expected to register small-scale growth, and Eastern Europe and Central Asian countries expected to have moderate increases.

The World Bank report shows that while mainland China continued opening its financial and telecommunications markets, and Thailand, Malaysia, and Vietnam relaxed their controls on many sectors, the total Asia and Pacific area is expected to attract FDI worth US$65 billion and US$74 billion in 2004 and 2005, respectively.
These figures will represent record highs and are expected to recover the economic prospects as they were before the Asian financial crisis in 1997.

In Taiwan, the statistics from the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that FDI slowed for a short period in the second quarter of last year due to the severe acute respiratory syndrome outbreaks. However, the FDI in Taiwan still managed to reach US$3.58 billion last year, an increase of 9.3 percent over the US$3.27 billion registered in 2002.

CEPD officials suggested that the government continue diverse reforms and improve the investment environment to attract more foreign investment and develop Taiwan as a regional financial service center.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET TO WORK OUT POPULATION WHITE PAPER BY 2005 MARCH

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will draft a white paper on population by March of next year to secure Taiwan's competitiveness in view of the country's rapidly aging segment of the population and the nation's declining birth rate, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Wednesday.
The Ministry of the Interior will put forward the white paper by that time while the Department of Health will also start a campaign in one month to encourage parents to have more children, Yu said.

Taiwan's birth rate has rapidly dropped to 1.22 and its fast growth in silver-haired population has resulted in a dramatic change in the country's population structure, putting Taiwan in the position of losing its competitiveness in the midst of robust global competition, Yu said.

The premier made the remarks after the Executive Yuan approved earlier the same day a package of action guidelines in response to the continued entry of foreign spouses, in particular, those from mainland China, with an aim of setting up a harmonious and multifaceted society by blending different races and ethnics.

According to assessments made by the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , an influx of foreign and mainland Chinese spouses will have both sound and adverse effects on Taiwan's society in terms of education, economics, labor and national security.

The CEPD suggested government agencies in charge set up an early warning system to effectively monitor the entry of foreign immigrants and adjust its demographics upward to meet the country's need for an adequate growth in population to secure its economic development.

Under the set of mechanisms in line with actual situations, the government will welcome foreigners with economic power to settle in Taiwan, while the entry of foreign spouses will be justified in accordance with a quota control that will be revised periodically, CEPD officials said.
During the 1999-2003 period, Taiwan approved an average 2,111 and 7,249 residence permits each year for foreign and mainland Chinese spouses, respectively, government statistics showed.
As of the end of 2003, there were about 280,000 foreign and mainland Chinese husbands and wives in Taiwan, accounting for around 1 percent of the country's total population.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY ALLIANCE TO PUSH FOR REFORMS OF ELECTORAL SYSTEM

TEXT.P: A private alliance claimed Wednesday the nation's existing electoral system is flawed and needs much improvement to prevent election fraud and rigging.

The Democracy Action Alliance unveiled at a news conference a number of alleged suspicious findings from a comprehensive scrutiny of voter rosters for the disputed March 20 presidential election to back up its criticism of the current electoral system.

The findings were provided by attorneys who represented the opposition "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang (KMT) and the People First Party (PFP) in scrutinizing lists of all eligible voters in various constituencies around the country last month.

According to the alliance, more than 90,000 ballots were listed as suspicious or problem ballots because of various reasons. As shown in voter rosters, some ballots were cast by those who had died or went abroad or went missing before the voting date, and some other ballots were cast by voters who received blank ballots by leaving their fingerprints but without the endorsement of any election staff. Other problems cited by the alliance included inconsistencies between seals left on the rosters and the names of the listed voters as well as blank ballots stamped with election supervisors' seals.
Former Legislator Kao Tze-min, who is also a member of the alliance, said these problem ballots indicate that there is room for election rigging.

"Since we have found flaws in our presidential electoral system, the ruling and opposition parties should work together to push for reform and improvement of the existing system. Otherwise, Taiwan's young democracy will get rotten and cannot move forward or become deep-rooted," Kao said.

Incumbent President Chen narrowly won re-election in the March 20 election, but the "pan-blue alliance" ticket of KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong refused to concede defeat. Lien has filed two lawsuits to annul Chen's re-election victory and even the entire election so that a new one can be held.

Although Lien has provided little evidence to back up his claim of election fraud, President Chen agreed to a full-scale judicial vote recount. The unprecedentedly large-scale re-tally of all the more than 13 million ballots cast in the election and a scrutiny of all voter lists were completed last month. There has so far been no solid evidence showing that the election was rigged, although some technical mistakes have been discovered. The Taiwan High Court is required to mete out rulings on the two lawsuits in six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MINISTER OF CIVIL SERVICE ASSUMES POST

TEXT.P: Chu Wu-hsian, secretary-general of the Examination Yuan, assumed his new post as the minister of the civil service Wednesday, vowing to revamp the existing regulation concerning government employees' recruiting and retirement to facilitate President Chen Shui-bian's policy of reorganizing the government.

In a ceremony presided over by Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen, Chu took over the official seal of the Ministry of Civil Service from outgoing minister Wu Jung-min to mark the beginning of his new job. Wu has been appointed to be the vice president of the Examination Yuan.
Yao congratulated Chu, saying he is the best choice for the job.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE JOINS APEC BUSINESS TRAVEL CARD PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Singapore has joined 15 other member economies of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum in the APEC Business Travel Card (ABTC) Program, APEC Business Advisory Council officials said Wednesday.

Travelers issued with ABTCs will be able to use express immigration lanes and enjoy greater travel flexibility among participating APEC member economies, they said, adding that the length of stay without a visa in Singapore is at least 60 days.
The chair of APEC's Business Advisory Council, Hernan Somerville, welcomed Singapore's participation in the program.
"It is great to see Singapore becoming a member of the APEC Business Travel Card Program," Somerville said.
APEC Business Travel Cards are issued by the governments of participating economies and the program is overseen by the APEC Informal Experts' Group on Business Mobility.

Participating Members of the APEC Business Travel Card Program are Australia, Brunei, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, Korea Malaysia, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Peru, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan and Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER PRAISES LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS FOR CURBING FRAUD

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun congratulated law enforcement agents Wednesday for stemming fraud and for reducing the number of cases from a year ago last month by a quarter.
There were 533 people arrested in connection with 37 fraud rings in May, and the number of fraud cases was down 25.65 percent from the corresponding month last year.
He also thanks the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Education and the Government Information Office for backing various operations.
The premier also urged the Ministry of Justice to prosecute fraud cases to the fullest extent of the law.
In a common set-up, a fraudster will pretend to be a tax official and call an unsuspecting person, telling him to use his ATM card to pick up his tax return.
If the victims fall for this, he will actually end up transferring his money to a bank account used by the fraudster.

Another scam involves fraudsters who pose as hospital workers and call people saying that one of their friends or relatives has been in an accident and how they require the immediate transfer of cash to pay for treatment. In the same way, the money ends up in the account of the perpetrators and the "accident" turns out to be bogus.
Hoax kidnapping have also been used by criminals to bilk individuals.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXOTIC CULINARY ART TO BE SHOWN AT CHINESE FOOD FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taipei Chinese Culinary Exhibition will open Aug. 12 at the Taipei World Trade Center with exotic culinary art to be shown for the first time at the event.

With its inception in 1989 by the Tourism Bureau, the 2004 Taipei Chinese Culinary Exhibition will organize, for the first time, a world culinary art competition, inviting famous chefs from around the world to add glamour to the activity.

Stanley Yen, chairman of the Ritz Taipei Hotel and convener of the world culinary art competition, noted that according to the latest survey from the United States, the eating habits of the younger generation has changed gradually, with Thai and Japanese foods being their new options, in addition to Western food, Chinese cuisine, and French and Italian food.
"Chinese food needs more renovation and new life to dominate the food market again," Yen added.

In addition, Yen said the exchanges of Western and Oriental culinary arts are a world trend, and this is the reason why a world culinary art competition will be held at 2004 Taipei Chinese Culinary Exhibition.
According to the organizer, teams from Japan, mainland China, Hong Kong, Malaysia, and Singapore have applied to participate in the competition.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PITCHES FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-SOUTH KOREAN TIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Wednesday he looks forward to seeing substantive relations between Taiwan and South Korea grow further for mutual benefits.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with a delegation of academics and business executives from South Korea, headed by South Korean National Assemblyman Lew Jyun-sung.
Noting that Taiwan is now South Korea's fifth largest trading partner, Chen said there is still ample room for the growth in bilateral trade and economic cooperation.
South Korea is Taiwan's fourth largest import source and sixth largest export market. Chen said he hopes that bilateral trade and investment will continue expanding in the years ahead.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Chen said Taiwan and South Korea have enjoyed longstanding friendship. "I'm hopeful that our two countries can further expand bilateral exchanges in cultural and many other fields," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT FROM U.S. DIFFERENT FROM FRANCE: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: A legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday that arms purchases from the United States will be different from purchases made from France and that there is no question of kickbacks being involved.

DPP Legislator Lee Wen-chung made the remarks in the wake of a newspaper report that said Taiwan spent NT$36 billion (US$1.07 billion) more than it should have in procuring 60 mirage fighters from France in the 1990s.

The mass-circulation United Daily News quoted an investigation report by the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog, on the policy-making, price and commission of the Mirage fighters, which shows that the Air Force Headquarters said at the time to the Ministry of National Defense that the price would come to 22.8 billion francs (NT$131.2 billion at the exchange rate then), although the final price tag was 6 billion francs more.

The Control Yuan said that neither the Air Force Headquarters nor the Ministry of National Defense have been able to come up with a plausible explanation for this huge gap and added that it is mulling whether to propose censuring the two organizations.

Lee said that Taiwan did indeed pay an inflated price for its purchase of the advanced fighters and Lafayette frigates, adding that commissions and improper deals were "obviously" involved and that the relevant authorities should investigate the doubts and questionable points raised by the report.

Lee said that as France does not recognize Taiwan diplomatically, the purchases of the fighters and the frigates were not from the French government but from the French manufactures, which, he claimed, was the main reason for the improper dealings.
During that time, Taiwan had to circumvent all purchasing obstacles by buying through foreign politicians, so there would surely have been kickback problems, Lee said.

But he stressed that the latest NT$610.8 billion purchase, which the Executive Yuan passed early this month and is now subject to approval by the Legislative Yuan, will be a direct procurement from the U.S. Department of Defense, so there is question of using brokers or paying kickbacks.
The NT$610.8 billion arms purchase will cover six sets of Patriot PAC-III missiles and eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft.

Meanwhile, a Control Yuan committee, which was scheduled to discuss the report later Wednesday, expressed regret that the newspaper had published part of the report before it was formally unveiled and said that it would withdraw from the discussion because of the newspaper's action.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60 PERCENT OF HI-TECH TALENT EYEING MAINLAND CHINA: POLL

TEXT.P: Despite recent political woes between Taiwan and mainland China, as many as 60 percent of Taiwan's professionals in the hi-tech sector still are willing to work in mainland China, according to the results of a survey made public Wednesday.

The public opinion poll carried out in late May by www.104. com.tw, an executive research Web site, showed that 58.4 percent of the respondents employed in Taiwan's hi-tech businesses are willing to work in mainland China.

In terms of their reasons to relocate to the mainland, 71.6 percent of them said that they are attracted by the "great potential of the mainland market, " while 55.9 percent pointed to the "need to start earlier in the mainland in view of its strong competition."

Some 18 percent said that they think they can get a job with a higher position there because of their "higher-level skills" than mainland Chinese workers, while about 14 percent claimed that they think they will be given a higher salary for working abroad.

In contrast, 64.3 percent of those hi-tech workers who will not consider finding a job in mainland China cited "family and friends" as the leading reason behind their reluctance, while 41.8 percent singled out "better working conditions and environment in Taiwan."

While 40.8 percent said their unwillingness resides in "difficulties in getting necessary information about the mainland Chinese workplace, " some 30 percent said that they are determined to stay in Taiwan to learn more advanced technologies, " the survey found.

Among the nearly 60 percent of Taiwan's hi-tech talent displaying willingness to move to mainland China, male workers account for 61.5 percent, while 64 percent are in their 40s. Around 76 percent already hold middle or high ranking posts in their companies.

According to an executive at the head-hunting Web site, the number of Taiwan workers wanting to find a job in mainland China has risen to 10,214 so far since the beginning of this month. Job opportunities in the mainland are mainly from its electronics manufacturing, foreign trade, computer peripherals, opto-telecommunications and engineering industries, he said.

Although Taiwan hi-tech professionals have long been popular in the domestic job market, the executive said that many of them are increasingly feeling a sense of crisis in recent years due to drastic changes in high-technology trends.
Looking to the future, he contended that working experience in mainland China will be undoubtedly an advantage for hi-tech professionals wherever they are employed.
The problem of how to fend off an exodus of Taiwan's hi-tech brainpower will be a key issue for many domestic businesses, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR PFP LAWMAKERS INDICTED OVER VIOLENT MARCH 26 PROTEST AT CEC

TEXT.P: Four opposition lawmakers were indicted Wednesday over their alleged leading roles in a riot at the Central Election Commission (CEC) March 26 when officials were discussing certifying the result of the March 20 presidential election.

The Taipei Prosecutor's Office said legislators Chiu Yi, Feng Ting-kuo, Lin Hui-kuan and Lee Ching-hua of the People First Party (PFP) should be indicted for violating the public assembly law by igniting the violent protest at the CEC in downtown Taipei.

The indictment said the four lawmakers led hundreds of their aides and supporters to converge in front of the CEC building near the Legislative Yuan after they learned that CEC commissioners would meet in the afternoon of March 26 to discuss certification of the result of the disputed presidential election a week earlier.

Incumbent President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu narrowly won the bitterly fought election by a margin of 0.228 percent, or 29,518 ballots out of the 13 million ballots cast. The sole challenging ticket, Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong, refused to concede defeat and immediately demanded a vote recount.
Nevertheless, the existing law requires the CEC to certify the election result and proclaim the winner within seven days of the election.

Prosecution authorities said the four opposition lawmakers continued to make loudspeaker speeches even after police held up placards demanding that they stop the demonstration, which had not been approved by police authorities in advance.

Worse still, the indictment said, the lawmakers even led their supporters in chants of "Smash the Central Election Commission." The protest then spiralled out of control, with some rioters struggling with police as they tried to storm the CEC building, while others broke glass cases used to display the election results.

Prosecutors said they had scrutinized television footage and videotape shot by police officers as well as reviewing riot police work reports and interviewing many witnesses, before deciding to indict the four lawmakers.

Although the lawmakers claimed that they did not hear the police's loudspeaker warnings and orders to disband the protestors during the demonstration, the indictment said, their claims could not be justified because the assembly was not legally sanctioned in the first place.
The Lien-Soong ticket has since filed two lawsuits to nullify Chen's victory and the entire election so that a one can be held.

Even though the Lien-Soong ticket has provided little evidence to back its claim that the election was rigged, Chen agreed to a full-scale judicial vote recount. The unprecedentedly large-scale recount has been completed and still no solid evidence has been found to support the Lien-Soong ticket's allegations. The Taiwan High Court is required to mete out rulings on the two lawsuits in six months.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CONSTITUTION TO BE BASED ON CONSTITUTIONAL PROCEDURES: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed Wednesday his determination to pursue constitutional reforms and said he will bring about a new constitution through constitutional procedures.
Chen made the remarks when he presided over a celebration of the 80th anniversary of the ROC Military Academy in Fengshn, Kaohsiung, in southern Taiwan.

The ceremony was held against the background of mainland China playing up the 80th anniversary of the academy and holding its own big celebration of the academy at its original home in Whampoa, Guangzhou, using its traditional "united front" tactics by inviting oversea alumni to attend the ceremony.

Although former Premier Hau Pei-tsun, an alumni of the academy, failed to attend, more than 300 other alumni, including past academy presidents, as well as former Air Force commanders-in-chief Huang Hsien-jung and Tsai Chung-huei, as well as Teng Chu-lin, former chairman of the Veterans Affairs Commission, and more than 700 family members of the student cadets, attended the Fengshan event.
Presidential Office Secretary General Su Tseng-chang, Examination Yuan President Yao Chia-wen were also on hand to witness the ceremony.

The president reviewed a dress parade of 1,832 student cadets from the academy and from two other academies -- the ROC Navy Academy and the ROC Air Force Academy -- and expounded on the ideas for writing a new constitution to take effect in 2008 when he completes his presidency that he spoke about in his May 20 inaugural speech.

On the constitutional re-engineering project, he said it is irrelevant to fight over the semantics of whether it is "revising" the Constitution or "instituting" a new one and that the crucial thing is to bring about a new constitution through constitutional procedures.

During his campaign prior to the March 20 presidential election, Chen advocated writing a new constitution through a referendum, causing great concern among the United States and mainland China, who feared it would take Taiwan down the road of independence.
Seeking to allay these misgivings, the president reaffirmed yet again that the new constitution will not touch on the issues of sovereignty, territory or the subject of unification/independence.

He said the new constitution will enhance efficiency and allow for governmental structural reforms. He said it will be a constitution that the military "must defend by all means, " and that this is his commitment and an ideal that all must work toward.
As president of the Republic of China, Chen said he knows that it is his responsibility to seek stable and prosperous development for Taiwan.

Chen said the Constitution stands as the supreme legal basis of a nation, symbolizing a permanent contract between the government and the people, and that he will follow his commitment to the people to complete constitutional re-engineering through constitutional procedures.
He reaffirmed that the new constitution, which will be "timely, relevant and viable," will be ready by the time he steps down in 2008.
The president told the cadets that the military is the army of the Republic of China and that their goal is to defend the survival of the nation and the security of its people.

"Put simply," he said, "anyone who invades Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen or Matsu, anyone who wants to swallow the Republic of China, they are our enemies. This is unequivocable and there should be no doubts at all."

Noting that the academy was originally founded in Whampoa in 1924 with the late President Chiang Kai-shek as its inaugural president, Chen urged the cadets to continue to promote the "Whampoa spirit" -- which is sacrifice, unity and responsibility.

But in tune with the changing times, he urged them to instill the ideals of "courage, faith and trust" with the contemporary significance so that they can become the new values of the CMA in the next 80 years.

He urged faith in the national system and the Constitution and said that there should be no confusion about national allegiance and national identity, in spite of the power transfer between the political parties.

Security at the ceremony was tight but nevertheless there was a small incident when someone darted out from the area set aside for the families of the students saying that he wanted to present an ROC flag to Chen. The man was grabbed by security men.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVOY TO WTO HOPES FOR CLOSER ECONOMIC EXCHANGES WITH SINGAPORE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 14 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The economies of Taiwan and Singapore have much in common and also are complementary in some other fields, Yen Ching-chang, Taiwan permanent representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO), said Monday.
Yen made the remarks during a WTO meeting held to view Singapore's trade policies, in which representative delegations of more than a dozen member states took part.

Citing assessments by the Lausanne-based International Institute for Management Development and the Wall Street Journal, Yen praised Singapore for having the most competitive economy among countries with a population smaller than 20 million, as well as the world's second-freest economy.

Yen said that Taiwan and Singapore have much in common in their economic structures and trade systems and that they are complementary in other areas, giving great potential for the two countries to bolster bilateral trade and economic cooperation.

While hailing Singapore's trade openness and economic liberalization, the Taiwan permanent envoy to the WTO expressed his hope of gaining a better understanding of Singapore's Government-Linked Corporations (GLCs).

Yen said that Taiwan is particularly curious about the role played by the Singapore government in the GLCs, as the GLCs are active members in many sectors of the city state's economy and form a major driving force behind the country's economic development. He questioned whether such a government role dampens the market mechanism.

In essence, GLCs are tools of government. The GLC designation is a sponsorship of an industry that the government wishes to promote. By that rationale, GLCs are merely vehicles for government subsidization, he said.
He also questioned the possibility of whether Singapore is likely to relax the rules on its service market to foreign suppliers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MRT CONNECTING CKS AIRPORT, TAIPEI TO BE COMPLETED IN FOUR YEARS

TEXT.P: Construction of a mass rapid transit (MRT) system connecting Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and Taipei City is scheduled to be completed in four years and open to public traffic by the end of 2008, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) reported Wednesday.
Lee Lung-wen, director of the MOTC's Department of Railways and Highways, denied allegations that the CKS-Taipei MRT development project will be shelved due to insufficient budget support.

Clarifying the situation, Lee said the MOTC has never said that the project will be postponed, adding that it will be carried out as previously scheduled now that the budget plans for the five-year, NT$500 billion (US$14.7 billion) national development plan -- better known as the "Ten New Major Construction Plans" -- have cleared the legislative floor.

According to Lee, the development of the CKS-Taipei MRT system calls for an outlay totaling NT$93.56 billion. Of the total, NT$47 billion is covered under the "Ten New Major Construction Plans, " while the remaining NT$46.56 billion will be financed by the regular annual budget of the MOTC, he said.

Meanwhile, Ho Yuan-hsuan, director-general of the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail, MOTC, also denied the allegations, stressing that construction of the MRT system will begin as soon as the construction plans, contractors and subcontractors are finalized.
The disputed issue on the project -- whether the approach section entering Taipei City should be built overground or underground -- is still under discussion, Ho said.

The MOTC officials made the clarification Wednesday after opposition People First Party legislators Liu Wen-hsiung, Lee Hung-chun and Ke Shu-min called a press conference in which they claimed that the project will be shelved due to lack of budget and controversy surrounding the design of the approach sections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 16, or the 29th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1890: American comedian Stan Laurel is born in England. With Oliver Hardy, he formed the first great comedy team of the talking film era. Their works include "The Music Box," "Hog Wild," "Way Out West," "The Flying Deuces" and "A Chump at Oxford."
1922: China's Chen Chiung-ming revolts against Dr. Sun Yat-sen, bombarding the presidential office on Kuanyingshan in Canton. Sun escapes from the office at night and reaches the naval headquarters at Chuhai aboard the warship "Chuyi."
1924: A school-opening ceremony is held at China's Whampoa Military Academy, presided over by superintendent Chiang Kai-shek.
1935: President Franklin D. Roosevelt's "New Deal" legislative package is passed by the House of Representatives. The Social Security Bill is aimed at tackling America's severe economic problems.
1941: Roosevelt orders the closure by July 10 of all German consulates in the United States.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Kaimaing in northern Burma.
1953: A total of 75 F-84 G Thunder jet fighters, the first batch of military equipment to be provided to the Republic of China by the United States, arrive at an ROC air force base in Tainan, southern Taiwan.
1961: Rudolf Nureyev, the 23-year-old Russian dancer who was the star of the Leningrad Ballet, asks for political asylum in France.
1963: Valentina Tereshkova of the Soviet Union blasts off in Vostok 6 to become the first woman in space.
1969: Earl Alexander of Tunis, a British field marshal during World War II, dies at the age of 78. He directed the British troop evacuation from Dunkirk, France, and led maneuvers in Burma, North Africa and Italy.
1972: Guatemalan President Carlos Arana Osorio arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1974: Gen. John W. Voge Jr., commander-in-chief of the U.S. Air Force, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1975: China Airlines inaugurates a Boeing 747 jumbo jet service to Los Angeles.
1976: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo inspects cadets of the Military Academy on its 52nd anniversary.
1977: Leonid Brezhnev, general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party, is elected chairman of the Presidium (the Politburo), succeeding Nikolao Podgorny.
1977: Werner von Braun, a German-born American rocket pioneer, dies at the age of 65. He designed the German V1 and V2 rockets and later worked as director of the U.S. Army team that put the first American satellite, Explorer I, into space in 1958.
1982: The 11-member ROC Goodwill Mission of Mayors, led by Mayor Jackson C.T. Yang of Taipei, leaves for a 20-day visit to the United States.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of regulations governing foreign exchange, authorizing the Executive Yuan to suspend all foreign exchange controls. Resumption of controls would require the consent of the Legislative Yuan.
1992: U.S. President George Bush and Russian President Boris Yeltsin agree in a summit meeting in Washington to slash their strategic weapons arsenals by about two-thirds by 2003.
1999: Thabo Mbeki becomes president of South Africa, succeeding Nelson Mandela.
2000: A new shortened work-week program, allowing Taiwan's workers and employers to work 84 hours every two weeks instead of the former 96 hours, is passed overwhelmingly at the legislature.
2001: Some 4,000 Taipei residents join professional athletes from both Taiwan and mainland China in road run relays aimed at fostering support for Beijing's bid to host the 2008 Olympic Games.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "With plausible speech and fine manners will seldom be found moral character."

TEXT.P: Any attempts by mainland China to sabotage diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Panama will be futile, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman said Thursday.

Spokesman Richard Shih was responding to reports that mainland Chinese Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Zhou Wenzhong, who is in charge of America, Oceania and Latin America affairs, is scheduled to visit Panama June 17-19.
Shih said that the MOFA learned about Zhou's trip early this month and that it has kept abreast of the latest developments regarding his itinerary while visiting the Central American country.
He stressed that the Panamanian government has assured the ROC that it will follow the policy of only maintaining trade and economic relations with the People's Republic of China.
Panamanian President Mireya Elisa Moscos has no plans to meet with Zhou, and President-elect Martin Torrijos and the two vice president-elects also have no plans to meet with him, Shih said.

Manila Bulletin: JdV assures canvass will continue
Speaker Jose de Venecia yesterday declared the canvassing of votes for president and vice president by the Joint Congressional Committee will continue even if the opposition members of the body walk out of the proceedings.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Walk out, Poe allies dared canvassing
SO FRENZIED were the exchanges among lawmakers on Wednesday that the head of the gavel flew when Senate Majority Leader Francis Pangilinan slammed it down in an attempt to quell passions.
The Philippine Star: If they walk out, we'll replace them -- Drilon
A walkout by the opposition will not derail the canvassing of votes for president and vice president and the eventual proclamation of winners, Senate President Franklin Drilon said yesterday.
The Manila Times: FPJ no-show foils canvass walkout.
THE presidential candidate Fernando Poe Jr. backed out of a plan to show up at the canvassing Wednesday, signaling a walkout of opposition lawmakers from the tabulation, a source at the House of Representatives said on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA TO ASSESS FOREIGN LABOR AGENCIES

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) will begin an across-the-board assessment of Taiwan's foreign labor agencies as early as July, CLA officials said Thursday.

The officials said that they expect the assessment of the more than 800 agencies to be completed by the end of the year and the results to be posted on the Web site of the CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration for reference by employers in Taiwan.
In a bid to encourage foreign labor agencies to improve the quality of their service, provide reference to employers, the CLA plans to use an assessment index it has established to rate the agencies.
The assessment index developed by CLA-commissioned scholars and experts was used last year on 50 agencies willing to take part in the trial assessment.
Out of the 50 agencies, 13 said they were willing to have the results published. Employers can now visit the CLA's Web site to get the information.

As of the end of April, there were nearly 280,000 foreign laborers working in Taiwan. Thai laborers led the pack in terms of numbers, at 98,200, followed by Philippine laborers at 80,000, Vietnamese at 60,100, and Indonesians at 41,300.

The manufacturing sector employs the largest number of foreign laborers at 159,400, followed by the caregiving sector at 105,300, and the construction industry at 9,100. There are about 3,000 foreigners working as maids in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY URGES TAIWANESE KEEP DOCUMENTS TO HAND IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs advised Taiwanese who visit Singapore to keep their travel documents to hand after three women were mistaken for illegal immigrants and detained there for 15 hours.

A statement issued by the ministry said the three Taiwan women, who visited Singapore June 5, were detained by Singapore police June 6 because they failed to produce their visas and were therefore mistaken for illegal immigrants.

The Foreign Ministry said the Republic of China representative office in Singapore was informed of their plight through one of their Singaporean friends and went to their rescue June 7. It also filed a protest with the Singapore police department, which admitted that it did not deal with the case properly and promised to improve police training to avoid similar incidents from occurring.
The statement urged Taiwan tourists to keep their visas to hand to prove their identity and to contact the ROC representative office if they encounter this kind of problem, said the statement.

The three women, who work in a bank, have already returned to Taiwan. They told a local newspaper Thursday that they were treated badly by Singapore police, who forced them to put on prison uniforms and held them incommunicado during their 15-hour ordeal.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWSUIT SEEKING TO ANNUL PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION TO CONTINUE

TEXT.P: A lawsuit seeking to invalidate the March 20 presidential election will resume June 25, sources close to the case said Thursday.

The two parties in the lawsuit pitting opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan and his running mate in the presidential election, People First Party Chairman James Soong, against President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, should put their requests for investigating evidence to the Taiwan High Court before Friday, said the sources.
Lien and Soong brought the lawsuit after they lost the presidential election by a slim margin.
They also brought a lawsuit seeking to invalidate Chen's victory, claiming "irregularities" in the election, although they have been unable to produce any evidence of this.
According to the law, both cases must be concluded in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: With 9/11 report, Bush's political thorn grows more stubborn.
The bipartisan commissioninvestigating the Sept. 11 terrorist attack further called into question one of President Bush's rationales for the war with Iraq, and again put him on the defensive over an issue the White House was once confident would be a political plus.
The Wall Street Journal: Baghdad car bomb kills 35 as SUV plows into volunteers.
A sport-utility vehicle packedwith artillery shells slammed into a crowd of people waiting to volunteer Thursday for the Iraqi military, killing at least 35 people and wounding 138, the Iraqi Health Ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS OPEN ON ISSUES OF CROSS-STRAIT TALKS: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan is open on issues of cross-Taiwan Strait talks based on the principles of equality and dignity, an official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

Speaking at a public hearing on government policies for faster and more convenient cross-strait transportation links organized by Legislator Hong Chi-chang, MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said that government agencies should be invited to take part in cross-strait talks on issues involving public powers.
Many businessmen have asked the government to ease regulations to facilitate the opening of cross-strait transportation links.

Chao Teng-hsiung, chairman of the Far Glory Group, urged the government to take action as soon as possible because a majority of Taiwan businessmen agree with the opening of cross-strait transportation links. National security should be based on the country's economic development, he added.

Wei Hsin-hsiung, general manager of China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, suggested that the government allow cargo planes to ply direct cross-strait routes via the flight information regions of Hong Kong and Macau without having to land in those places.
Wei said that the government could take the measure as a goodwill demonstration and a trial for improving cross-strait ties.

However, Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said that the businessmen should first convince the Beijing authorities to hold talks with Taiwan on the opening of cross-strait transportation links, given that Taiwan has offered many goodwill measures on this issue but has always had them rejected by Beijing.
"The ball is in Beijing's court," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR TO TAKE PART IN MARATHON SLATED FOR OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou Thursday applied to take part in a marathon to be sponsored by China Motor Corp. in October in Taipei and he called on more fitness enthusiasts to participate in the event.

Ma issued the call after registering with the organizing authorities to take part in the annual race -- the third of its kind under China Motor's sponsorship, which this year features the theme "High Running! Hi Taipei! " The Taipei mayor also participated in the run last year.
The 2004 China Motor international marathon is scheduled to begin Oct. 17 in Taipei.

Participants will pass famous landmarks in the city, such as the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall, which is the starting point, the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall and the Taipei 101 Building, before crossing the finish line at the Tachia Park.
China Motors General Manager Su Ching-yang said organizers expect to attract over 50,000 people from home and abroad to participate in the race, applications for which will end Aug. 31.
The marathon will be divided into four groups of different distances to allow runners of different ages to take part in accordance with their physical condition, Su said.
The men's champion will win the top prize of US$25,000 and the women's champion will receive a top prize of US$15,000, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMUGGLED HEROIN WEIGHING 44.5 KG DISCOVERED

TEXT.P: Agents from the Bureau of Investigation under the Ministry of Justice discovered Thursday 44.5 kg of heroin smuggled from Thailand with a street value of NT$500 million (US$14.9 million).

The agents also arrested two suspects, surnamed Wang and Fu, who hid the 116 heroin bricks in aluminum pipes that were transported by sea in a container from Thailand to Kaohsiung Harbor, southern Taiwan.
The two suspects were detained for further investigation and the agents said they will continue to investigate other members of the drug ring.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-CENTRIC NOTION NEEDED TO STEP UP COMPETITIVE EDGE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: At a time when Taiwan is emerging as "a multi-racial society, " the government is committed to building a Taiwan-centric notion among the people in order to inject fresh energy to step up the country's competitive edge, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said Thursday.
Yu made the remarks while giving a speech at a meeting of the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei.

Given that a multi-ethnic and a multi-faceted society is taking shape in Taiwan, the government will do its best to forge policies focusing on the Taiwan-centric concept as a way of cementing the people's identity with the land in the hope of transforming strength into momentum to push Taiwan forward, he said.

"Building a Taiwan identity is not tantamount to de-sinicization, but is rather a pragmatic move aimed at stepping up Taiwan's persistent development and progress, " he claimed, stressing that Taiwan is open to all kinds of cultures and civilizations as long as they are helpful to the country's growth.

Pointing to an influx of 280,000 foreign spouses into Taiwan as an example, he said that these foreigners living in Taiwan have helped create new blood and provide a fresh labor force in a rapidly aging society.

In an effort to help them blend into society, it is important to give adequate education to these new residents in Taiwan to increase their identity and affiliation with this country, he said, adding that only when these immigrants enjoy the same rights and share equal obligations as Taiwan natives will the country's competitiveness be effectively upgraded, he said.

He also thanked the foreign trade sector for its contributions to Taiwan's economic development over the long term and praised it as one of the prime driving forces behind Taiwan's economic development.

The premier vowed to create a "safety net" for all the people living in Taiwan and made it clear that the government is poised to make Taiwan a "normal" country and to engage in forging cooperative alliances with other countries to allow Taiwan's trade and economic spectrums to play a bigger role both at home and abroad.
He also gave his assurances that President Chen Shui-bian will stick to his pledges to revive the economy and carry out a sweeping reforms in his second four-year term.
