DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE DENIES FIRST LADY INSIDER TRADING ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian's office denied Thursday that first lady Wu Shu-chen has been involved in insider stock trading, while a dealer at a security firm is set to give testimony Friday in an investigation into the allegations about the first lady.

A statement issued through the Department of Public Affairs under the Presidential Office said that Chen announced recently that his wife will not buy or sell stocks any more, even though all her trading in the past was in compliance with the law.
The statement said both the president and his wife reiterated during the presidential campaign that all their stock deals were legal and would bear public scrutiny.
In order to end the allegations for good, Chen announced that his wife will no longer play the stock market, the statement said.
The statement said it is regrettable and unacceptable that "a media outlet" published a story Thursday about the first lady's questionable stock transactions.
A prosecutor from the Taiwan District Court who is leading a probe into the allegations has summoned a security dealer who handled the first lady's stock transactions to give testimony.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO HIGHER QUOTAS FOR FOREIGN LABORERS IN FREE TRADE PORTS

TEXT.P: The quotas for foreign laborers imported into Taiwan will not be altered to take into consideration two planned free trade ports in Kaohsiung and Keelung, a labor official said Thursday.

Kuo Fang-yu, director-general of the Employment & Vocational Training Administration under the Council of Labor Affairs, said his administration has to balance the development of the free trade ports against work opportunities for local people and that therefore, the quotas of foreign workers allowed to enter Taiwan will not be increased.
The existing rules provide that the percentage of local workers to that of total workers employed at the free trade port should not be below 60 percent.

In order to avoid unfair competition between concerns inside and outside the free trade ports, Kuo said, businesses in the free trade zones should be subject to the same requirements as those outside when bringing in foreign laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE GROUP PROTESTS PROPOSED U.S. ARMS PURCHASE

TEXT.P: An alliance of scholars protested in front of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Thursday against a proposed arms purchase from the United States.
During the protest, the Democratic Action Alliance had a small girl read a protest letter aloud for the benefit of U.S. President George W. Bush, and then presented it to AIT.

Instead of ensuring the island's safety, the alliance claims that arms acquired through this NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) purchase will only raise the likelihood of a war in the Taiwan Strait, not to mention the financial burden it would be on the nation's coffers for years to come.
The protesters called for a public debate of the pros and cons of the arms purchase, which covers missiles, submarines and anti-submarine aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMCHAM DELEGATION SAYS TIME FOR SIGNING TAIWAN-U.S. FTA NOT YET RIPE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 17 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A delegation of the American Chamber of Commerce (AmCham) in Taipei said here Wednesday that although Taiwan is keen on signing a free trade agreement (FTA) with the United States, the time for such an agreement is not yet ripe.

AmCham President Andrea Wu is currently leading the delegation on its visit to Washington, D.C. to call on relevant U.S. government agencies. The delegation has lobbied and communicated with them on issues of concern after AmCham published its 2004 Taiwan White Paper earlier this month in which it expressed concern over the establishment of direct cross-Taiwan Strait transportation links and the protection of intellectual property rights (IPR).

The delegation said that the signing of an FTA is a good idea, but the time has yet to come because the issues the United States is most concerned about -- pharmaceuticals, IPR protection and government procurement -- have yet to be resolved.

Richard Vuylsteke, executive director of AmCham, said that although Taiwan completed a revision of its copyright law last year, it removed at the last minute the most intimidating part regarding punishments for violators.

On government procurement, he said that Taiwan has yet to sign a government procurement agreement and the United States is almost excluded from government procurement projects such as infrastructure construction projects.
Before such questions are resolved, there will be only limited progress in moves to discuss a FTA between the United States and Taiwan, he said.

An official of Merck Sharp & Dohme Taiwan branch noted that the development of a new drug or new vaccine takes about 15 years and a cost of US$1 billion, and that the developing manufacturers have to be assured that related test information is thoroughly protected when it applies to a government.

If the information is revealed to local manufacturers, then no foreign manufacturer will dare to turn over their information to the government, and Taiwan's plan to turn itself into a biotechnology center will be hard to realize, the Merck official said.

AmCham delegates also said that Charles Freeman, deputy assistant U.S. Trade Representative, was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan in late June but will now postpone his trip until the second half of July.

Freeman will discuss such controversial trade issues as IPR protection. If there is a substantial result, then both sides will be able to restart talks on a trade and investment framework agreement (TIFA). After TIFA, they will be able to address the issues of FTA talks.

On the issues of establishing direct cross-strait trade and transportation links, AmCham delegates said that some Taiwan people worry that direct links will cause a hollowing out of domestic industry because of the flight to the mainland. However, the delegates said that without direct cross-strait links foreign businessmen will be forced by cost considerations to move their focus to the mainland, which will indeed cause an industrial hollowing out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LAWMAKERS LEAVE FOR U.S. TO DISCUSS ARMS PROCUREMENT ISSUES

TEXT.P: Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng left for the United States Thursday at the head of a 13-member legislative delegation to discuss Taiwan's new arms procurement projects.
Wang said prior to his departure that the legislature has three basic stances on the Cabinet's plans to purchase a number of advanced weaponry systems from the United States.

"The three stances are -- the weapons to be bought must be useful in defending Taiwan's security in the event of a war in the Taiwan Strait; their prices must be compatible to the general world market prices; the deals must be helpful to boost bilateral industrial cooperation, including technology transfer," Wang explained, adding that the legislature hopes the United States can agree to a Taiwan state-owned firm's participation in the construction of the eight conventional submarines the Bush administration agrees to sell the island.
Wang said his mission will take advantage of the visit to get a better understanding of the performance, functions and general international prices of the arms that Taiwan intend to buy.
The Cabinet has approved a special military budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the purchase of advanced weaponry from the United States amid mounting mainland Chinese military threats.

The draft budget calls for the procurement of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992.
The special budget bill is now pending approval of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.
Wang said the delegation would first visit the U.S. Pacific Command in Hawaii to receive a briefing on the general regional security situation and visit a P-3C anti-submarine aircraft base.

The delegation will then travel to Washington, D.C. via San Francisco. In the company of ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-Jen, the delegation will visit relevant U.S. administrative departments June 21 and exchange views with their senior officials on Taiwan's defense needs.

On the following day, the delegation will be briefed on special functions of the weaponry systems that the United States intends to sell to Taiwan. The mission will also meet with U.S. congressmen before leaving for Texas June 24 to visit a U.S. Patriot PAC-III missile base. The delegation is scheduled to return to Taipei June 28.

The delegation is composed of 13 lawmakers from across the political spectrum. Three other lawmakers, including two from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and one from the opposition People First Party, will travel to directly Washington, D.C. later this week to join the delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER GIVES AWAY PRIZES OVER IPR CRACKDOWN SWING

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun presented citations and cash prizes Thursday to six government units in recognition of their achievements in cracking down on commercial piracy of intellectual property rights (IPR).

Personnel from the prosecutors' office of the Taiwan High Court, the National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior, the Investigation Bureau under the Justice Ministry, the Directorate-General of Customs under the Ministry of Finance, and two task forces under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, received their rewards at a ceremony held in central Taichung County.

Pointing out that Taiwan has made noticeable progress in IPR crackdown drive, Yu stressed the government's resolve to wipe out copyright piracy and voiced his content that Taiwan's efforts in this field have gained foreign recognition.

Citing statistics compiled by the U.S.-based International Intellectual Property Alliance (IIPA) , the premier said that the value worth of Taiwan's infringements of U.S. IPR products fell markedly from US$848 million in 2002 to US$453 million in 2003.

At the same time, Taiwan's piracy rate of U.S. video game software declined from 56 percent to 42 percent, while its music CD piracy rate decreased from 47 percent to 42 percent, he went on. Its business software piracy rate fell from 53 percent in 2001 to 41 percent in 2003.
The IIPA is a private sector coalition representing the U.S. copyright based industries.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs launched a new intensive campaign in March 2003 to stem Taiwan's rampant piracy of CDs and DVDs, providing rewards worth as much as NT$10 million (about US$300,000) for each piece of useful information leading to a crackdown on pirate manufacturers.

According to Economic Affairs Minister Ho Mei-yueh, police, investigators and prosecutors raided five large plants producing pirated CDs and DVDs over the past year, seizing 630,000 discs and relevant facilities.
The informants and law enforcement officers were rewarded with cash prizes worth more than NT$14 million and NT$3.5 million, respectively, she noted.

A case cracked in May this year in the central Taichung and Changhua areas was a plant specializing in illegally recorded CDs and DVDs, in which more than 400,000 discs were nabbed -- the largest number in a single case in East Asia, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ORDERS CRACKDOWN ON ORGANIZED CRIME, REVIEW OF PAROLE SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun ordered a new crackdown on organized crime and firearm smuggling Thursday, as well as a thorough review of the parole system.
Yu issued the directive after paying a tribute to a police officer in the central city of Taichung who was killed in a shootout with an alleged kidnapper a day earlier.

Lee Chin-fu, 41, a detective unit leader at a Taichung City police precinct, was pronounced dead on arrival at a hospital after he was shot in the chest during the shootout shortly before Wednesday noon. Another police officer, Yeh Hsi-tsai, remained in critical condition as of Thursday evening after being shot in the head in the shootout. A third officer, Lin Wen-wu, was shot in the arm was reported in stable condition after receiving medical treatment. The kidnapping suspect, Su Ming-an, was also shot dead in the shootout.
Yu said he felt deep regret and sorrow over the police casualties and said the government will offer the best possible financial compensation and care for Lee's bereaved family.
In a show of the government's determination to stamp out organized crime and curtail gun smuggling, Yu ordered police authorities to launch a new crime-fighting campaign.

As the dead kidnapping suspect had been paroled earlier this year, Yu said he will also ask the relevant judicial authorities to conduct a comprehensive review of the parole system and tighten the parole requirements. Available data shows that the ratio of recidivism among parolees is relatively high, he said.
"We should review our system and impose more stringent conditions for parole in order to lower the crime rate and improve public order and security," Yu said.

In the company of Yu and several other senior officials, President Chen Shui-bian also paid his respects to the deceased police officer and visited the two injured policemen, who were being treated in two different Taichung hospitals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION TO ATTEND SUMMER 2004 FANCY FOOD SHOW IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: Taiwan will send a large delegation to participate in the summer 2004 Fancy Food Show June 27-29 in New York, promoting high-quality Taiwan gourmet food.
The Fancy Food Show showcases foods from diverse cultures from around the world and this year should attract exhibitors from 52 countries.

The Taiwan delegation, the largest in years, will be comprised of representatives from eight food associations and the Taiwan Provincial Farmers Association and will host a pavilion to introduce various kinds of Taiwanese agricultural products with different types of processing technologies.

Representatives of the Taiwan delegation noted that the island's agricultural industry backed up Taiwan's industrial development several decades ago, and when the industrial sector grew, advanced technologies helped a lot to improve the quality of agricultural products.

The complimentary effects also can be seen in the example of the Asian Vegetable Research and Development Center, which has a presence in Taiwan and has conducted numerous exchanges and cooperation projects with local agricultural entrepreneurs, they said.

Recently, they added, Taiwan's enterprises have invested in other Asian countries, thus allowing them to offer higher quality but cheap products thanks to Taiwan's high R&D and production capability and the low costs of production in these Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CEC CHIEF VOWS TO MAINTAIN IMPARTIALLY

TEXT.P: New Central Election Commission (CEC) Chairman Chang Cheng-hsiung said Thursday that he would fulfill his responsibilities independently and that the public will see that he performs his duties with impartiality.

Chang, whose appointment caused controversy because of his past leanings toward the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and President Chen Shui-bian, made the remarks after a change-over ceremony held under heightened security because several groups had previously gone to the CEC to protest against Chang's appointment.
Chang took over the official seal of the CEC at the ceremony from Rai Hau-min, another CEC member, because outgoing chairman Huang Shih-cheng had gone abroad the previous day.
He noted that with the deepening of democracy in Taiwan, political parties and the public has attached great importance to every election and the CEC has become the focus of the nation.

"Given the public's high expectation and demands for reforms in election affairs, the CEC will face more daunting tasks and challenges ahead, especially after the addition of the referendum vote," he said.

Taiwan held its first referendum in tandem with the presidential election on March 20. The CEC sponsored 10 public debates on the questions on the referendum before the vote on whether or not to increase defense spending in the face of mainland China's military threats and the need to resume talks with Beijing to establish a mechanism to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

"The CEC will work to staff a highly efficient team with the utmost patience and tenacity, " he stressed, adding that the CEC will be operated "fairly, justly, openly and independently" to understand and review any defects that have surfaced in past elections to increase the accuracy of elections.

Chang also expressed the hope that the Legislative Yuan will revise the Referendum Law that was passed in late November last year and make the CEC the agency in charge of referendums. Currently, the Executive Yuan is the one in charge, although the CEC is tasked with carrying out referendum.

Regarding People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong's remarks that Chang's appointment by President Chen Shui-bian was made to pave the way for a new presidential election, Chang said that this will involve a lawsuit filed by the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the PFP to attempt to annul the March 20 presidential election, and he would make no comment until the matter has been resolved in court.
He stressed, however, that he "is not a major supporter of anyone, " and that his past ideas may have paralleled those of the DPP, the situation will change when he takes over as CEC chairman.
Hsu Chi-hsiung, minister-without-portfolio, in presiding over the change-over ceremony, expressed his appreciation for the outgoing CEC chairman.

Hsu noted that Huang, since taking over as head of the CEC in 1999, went through two each of presidential, legislative, mayoral and county magistrate elections, and was at his post during the important first transfer of political power between different parties in Taiwan in 2000 when Chen won the presidency. He was also chairman during the nation's first referendum in 2004. Both events, he said, were milestones in Taiwan's democratic development.

Hsu also lauded Chang, saying that Chang has practiced law for 37 years and has established a fine reputation, and is concerned about the protection of human rights. He was one of the lawyers - along with then-attorney Chen Shui-bian - to defend opposition movement activists, among them current Vice President Annette Lu, for their involvement in the 1979 "Kaohsiung Incident, " a rally held by the opposition movement to mark International Human Rights Day but which later turned violent.
Chang also will concurrently serve as a Taipei Election Commission member. He has been a member of that commission and the CEC for over 10 years, and has been active in public affairs.
Hsu said Chang is "not afraid of the powerful and has great self-discipline," which he said are key attributes for a CEC head.

DOC.HEADLINE: GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY TO DECORATE OUTGOING ROC REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 17 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: George Washington University will bestow a medal to the outgoing Republic of China Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen next Tuesday in recognition of his achievements and contributions in promoting the U.S.-Taiwan friendships and relations over the years.

Chen will be given the President's Medal, the highest honor of the prestigious university. Past winners included former Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel, Greek President Constantinos Stephanopoulos, former Israel President Ezer Weizman, U.S. Senator Joseph Lieberman, U.S. Senate Majority leader Bill Frist and Boston University President John Silber.

George Washington University President Stephen Trachtenbeerg will preside over the decoration ceremony, with officials from the ROC's representative office and scholars from U.S. think tanks who are familiar with cross-strait issues invited to attend the ceremony.

Chien, 65, started his diplomatic career as a secretary at the former Republic of China Embassy in the United States in 1974 and moved to ROC representative to the United States in 2000. He also served as a legislator, a director-general of the Government Information Office and a minister of foreign affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market moved up Thursday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July rose 157 points to close at 5,607, with 62,878 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August gained 79 points to end at 5,563, with 348 contracts traded, while September futures rose 114 points to end at 5,539, with 115 contracts finalized.
December futures gained 143 points to close at 5,549, with 27 contracts concluded, while March futures rose 122 points to close at 5,541, with 20 contracts concluded.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Thursday at 5,450 for July, 5,484 for August, 5,425 for September, 5,406 for December and 5,419 for March.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER ATTENDS U.S. THINK TANK ACTIVITY IN L.A.
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 16 (CNA) (By Lu-sheng Chu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The international community should try to understand how the people of Taiwan feel about mainland China's constant missile threat, ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said in Los Angeles Wednesday.
Chen made the appeal while delivering a keynote speech at a dinner organized by the noted U.S. think tank Asia Society.

Noting that the Republic of China's security and prosperity are the supreme common interests of the people of Taiwan, Chen said the international community, while mulling the Taiwan Strait issue, should not overlook the way that the people of Taiwan feel about mainland China's imposing military threat.
Mainland China has aimed roughly 500 ballistic missiles at Taiwan along the southeastern mainland coast and the number is estimated to increase by 50 or more each year.
Over the years, Chen said, Beijing has forcefully demanded that Taiwan accept its "one-China" principle.
"However, this stance offers no room for the ROC to survive in the world community," Chen said.

While peace in the Taiwan Strait is in the best interests of the United States, Chen said the continued existence of a free and democratic Taiwan with full human rights complies with America's traditional values and its basic national spirit.

Chen, who arrived in Los Angeles Tuesday, said this is his first overseas trip since assuming office early last month. "I want to take advantage of this visit to solicit opinions from U.S. scholars, experts and ROC expatriates about the delicate triangular Taiwan-U.S.-mainland China relationship and listen to recommendations for maintaining peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

American scholars attending the dinner including Susan L. Shirk, a former U.S. deputy assistant secretary of state for East Asia and the Pacific; Stanley Rosen, a Asian affairs expert at the University of Southern California; Carie Cable, Asia Society chief executive; and Charles Wolf, a senior researcher with the prestigious think tank the Rand Corporation.

Chen will leave for Beaver Creek, Colorado Thursday to attend the World Forum -- an annual meeting of politicians, parliamentarians, academics as well as business and financial executives to be organized by the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington-based think tank. U.S. Vice President Dick Cheney is expected to attend the conference that will run June 17-20.
Chen will stay in the United States for a week before returning home. He is scheduled to travel to Europe in July to chair a meeting of the chiefs of Taiwan's missions in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar moved up against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, gaining NT$0.017 to close at NT$33.711.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 104.19 points to close at 5,664.35.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 5,558.2 and rose to 5,709.5 during trading.

A total of 3.7 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$80.7 billion (US$2.39 billion) , an increase from the previous trading session, which saw 3 billion stocks traded on a market turnover of NT$64.34 billion.

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 2.2 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.6 percent, bank and insurance shares at 1.5 percent, textile issues at 1.4 percent, and cement stocks at 1.2 percent.
The other two major stock categories posted losses, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.2 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.2 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 498 to 263, with 190 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF TOURIST ARRIVALS TO TAIWAN DROPS IN FIRST FIVE MONTHS

TEXT.P: The number of tourist arrivals in the first five months of the year totaled 1.13 million, down 7.19 percent from the 2002 level, a spokesman for the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said Thursday.

This year's figures were compared with the 2002 levels since the numbers for the same period of 2003 were anomalous because of the impact of sever acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) on worldwide travel, the official noted.

The official attributed the fall in travel to frequent terrorist attacks in the international community, the re-appearance of SARS in March in mainland China and outbreaks of bird flu that affected many Asian countries early this year. Political uncertainties at home after the March 20 presidential election may also be a factor, he added.

According to statistics compiled by the bureau, the number of tourists from Japan, Hong Kong and Macau, and the United States -- the leading three tourist sources for Taiwan -- all dropped in the first five months compared to their 2002 records. The number of South Korean tourists increased for the five-month period as did those from Malaysia.

In the face of the decline, Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan, who recently began serving as head of a Cabinet task force to boost Taiwan's tourist arrivals, has instructed relevant authorities to promote local festivals and make them a feature to attract foreign tourists.
The Executive Yuan has set the goal of doubling the number of foreign tourist arrivals to Taiwan by 2008, a key segment of its "Challenge 2008" -- a six-year national development plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL FOOD SHOW OPENS AT WORLD TRADE CENTER

TEXT.P: The 2004 Taipei International Food Show opened Thursday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with 741 exhibitors from 24 countries participating.
The Taipei International Food Show, one of the most important food shows in Asia, has been organized by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA).

Countries from around the world are heavily promoting their foods and Taiwan's Council of Agriculture is presenting a "Taiwan pavilion" to showcase the island's high-quality agricultural products, including mangoes, pineapples, teas, rice and orchid flowers.
TAITRA officials noted that the large scale of the food exhibition represents the strong ambition of every participating country to enter Taiwan's food market.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY SHOULD FOLLOW CONSTITUTION, SERVE TAIWAN PEOPLE: CHEN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday that the Republic of China's armed forces should abide by the nation's constitution and serve the 23 million people of Taiwan.
Chen made the remarks in a speech delivered at the Chenkungling army base in the central Taiwan county of Taichung where many new soldiers are undergoing training courses.

The president told officers and enlisted men at the army boot camp that his greatest expectation regarding military education is instilling service members with the concept of the separation of military affairs from politics and enhancing their awareness of mainland China's threat and hostility toward Taiwan.
In this democratic era, Chen said, the military should be loyal to the Republic of China, the ROC Constitution and the 23 million people of Taiwan.

"Regardless of leadership changes and transitions of power between different political parties, all military service members should consistently follow our constitution, serve our people and remain loyal to the Republic of China," Chen said.

Since Chen's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party swept to power in 2000 after more than 50 years of Kuomintang rule in Taiwan, some veterans and senior officers have reportedly been suspicious of the military's mission and role. Some retired and active officers had been quoted in the past as claiming that they would not fight for any pro-independence movement.

Chen's speech was seen as clarifying his administration's military build-up goal. In an address delivered a day earlier to mark the 80th anniversary of the Chinese Military Academy in southern Taiwan, Chen reaffirmed his commitment to pushing for constitutional reform and bringing about a new constitution suitable for Taiwan's present situation through constitutional procedures.

He also stressed in that speech that the new constitution will not touch on issues regarding sovereignty and territory or the question of independence versus unification. He said his constitutional engineering project will mainly be aimed at ensuring good governance and forging an efficient administrative mechanism.

Chen was accompanied by Defense Minister Lee Jye and many other senior officials on his Chengkungling boot camp inspection tour. He lunched together with all the officers and soldiers at the base as part of the celebration of the upcoming Dragon Boat Festival, one of the main festivals on the Chinese calendar. Dragon Boat Festival falls on June 22 this year.

DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Al Qaeda Scaled Back 10-Plane Plot; Attacks Evolved Amid Infighting, 9/11 Panel Reports.
The terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, were originally envisioned as an even more audacious assault involving 10 hijacked jetliners on the East and West coasts, but the plan was scaled back and later plagued by conflicts among al Qaeda's leaders and some of the hijackers themselves, according to a report issued yesterday by the panel investigating the attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 17, or the 30th day of the fourth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1703: British religious leader John Wesley is born. He founded Methodism in 1738, while his brother, Charles, wrote thousands of hymns, including "Hark, the Herald Angels Sing."
1775: The second battle of the American Revolution commences at Bunker Hill and Breed's Hill, just north of Boston, Massachusetts. The Americans lost around 400 men, the British 1,000.
1925: A total of 29 countries sign the Geneva Protocol prohibiting the use of poisonous gases in war.
1940: Red Army forces occupy Latvia and Estonia and pro-Soviet administrations are installed.
1950: The first kidney transplant is performed by Dr. Richard Lawler in Chicago.
1960: The Chinese communists launch 85,965 shells toward the island of Kinmen on the eve of US President Dwight D. Eisenhower's visit to the Republic of China.
1967: Communist China detonates its first hydrogen bomb.
1971: The United States and Japan sign an agreement for the return of Okinawa to Japan in 1972.
1972: Five men are caught snooping around the Washington apartment-hotel complex known as The Watergate, currently being used by the Democratic Party as their headquarters during the US election campaign.
1974: ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Y.S. Sun leaves for Seoul to attend the 9th Sino-Korean Ministerial Level Economic Cooperation Conference.
1976: Hsu Li-teh is appointed vice minister of finance by the ROC Executive Yuan.

1982: Raymond Perodin, Haiti's new ambassador to the ROC, presents his credentials to President Chiang Ching-kuo.
1982: Fourteen generals meet at an army base in Buenos Aires and vote unanimously to fire Leopoldo Galtieri, the president who led Argentina into the Falklands War against Britain.
1982: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung, as President Chiang Ching-kuo's special envoy, leaves for Saudi Arabia to offer Taiwan's condolences for the passing of King Fahd ibn Abdul Aziz.
1986: Nineteen mainland Chinese youths defect across the Yellow Sea aboard a small wooden boat to South Korea to seek asylum in the Republic of China.
1989: Some 400,000 Parisians and tourists from all over the world celebrate the 100th anniversary of the Eiffel Tower.
1990: President Andres Rodriguez of Paraguay arrives in Taipei to sign a joint communique calling for closer bilateral relations with the ROC.
1992: Lin Yang-kang, president of the Judicial Yuan of the ROC, leaves for the United States for a three-week visit.
1996: The United States and mainland China reach a deal to stamp out rampant Chinese copyright piracy.
1999: The International Labor Organization adopts a treaty banning the worst forms of child labor, including slavery and forced military recruitment.
2000: Kuomintang heavyweights at an extraordinary session of the party's 15th National Congress call for party unity while protesters outside the session's venue call for the expulsion of former party chairman Lee Teng-hui.
2001: Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, in a written statement to the 12th congress of the party's Huang Fu Hsing Committee, tells party members to broaden their vision and be rational when face with challenges, saying this would be an important step for the party in the future.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "I hate the way scarlet dims the perception of vermilion. I hate the way the modern popular airs are liable to spoil the taste for good music. Finally, I hate the way smartness of speech in men is liable to destroy kingdoms and ruin families."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DENIES IT IS LAX ON ILLEGAL TRADE OF RARE INDONESIAN WOOD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 19 (CNA) (By W. C. Lin and P. C. Tang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's restrictions against the import of the valuable tropical hardwood ramin are enforced, contrary to a U.S. environmental group's accusation, the Economic Division of the ROC Representative Office to the United States said Friday.

In a news release issued recently, the U.S. Environmental Investigation Agency (EIA) accused some Taiwan traders of illegally importing Indonesian ramin wood through Malaysia and then exporting it in the form of baby cribs to the United States.
Since the ramin trees were cut down in the National Indonesian Park, where orangutans live, the practice endangers the rare animal, the group claimed.

The division said in a statement that in April, the EIA had sent a letter to the ROC office protesting Taiwan's illegal import of ramin wood from Malaysia and requested that the island adopt measures to protect the ramin tree.

Noting that the Board of Foreign Trade of the Ministry of Economic Affairs has amended relevant laws and has adopted measures in accordance with CITIES (the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora) rules to protect the ramin tree, the division said that it also received affirmation from the EIA after notifying the agency what the island has done to prevent illegal trading in ramin wood.
However, it complained that the EIA did not mention Taiwan's efforts in its recent news release and the ROC office said that this was regrettable.

Despite the fact that Taiwan is not a member of CITIES, it still has regulations in accordance with CITIES' rules to protect the precious species, adding that the island reinforces control over the trade of ramin wood.
The division also said that the island's authorities have been investigating Nan Far Woodworking Manufacturing company, the one accused of trafficking in ramin wood by the EIA.

As the EIA has said that Malaysia is the principle illegal transit center for Indonesian ramin wood and that mainland China, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Japan, the United States and Great Britain are all the main importers of the wood, the division said that it is unfair that the EIA only accused Taiwan in its news release.

DOC.HEADLINE: REVISED COMMODITY LABELING LAW TO COME INTO EFFECT JUNE 25

TEXT.P: A revised commodity labeling law will come into effect next week to further protect the rights of consumers, the Minister of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Saturday.
Starting from June 25, all commodities will have to be labeled in Chinese and English with information on the product's applications and usages, as well as a consumer hotline telephone number.

Officials from MOEA's Department of Commerce noted that President Chen Shui-bian promulgated the newly revised commodity labeling law in June 25, 2003 and after a year of awareness campaigning, the law will be enforced.

The officials said that the biggest difference between the old and the revised version of the law is that it used to govern only producers, manufacturers and importers, while the revised law will also govern distributors.

In line with Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization, the revised law also stipulates that the original place of production must be included and labeled in Chinese and English. The Chinese translation should also not be more brief than the description on the original label.
In addition, the revised law also stipulates that if the commodity is a food product, it should also be labeled with usage and preservation instructions.

The officials reminded all manufacturers to beware of the regulations under the revised law, saying that violators will be given a period to improve, but after that they can be fined between NT$30,000 (US$895) and NT$300,000. Serious offenders could face a suspension of their business for a specified period of time under the revised law.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY VISITS BRITISH CITY OF CANTERBURY
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 18 (CNA) (By N. K. Han and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Tien Hung-mao, the Republic of China representative to Britain, paid a visit to Canterbury City in Kent County Friday at the invitation of Canterbury Mayor Martin Vye.
Accompanied by Vye, Tien attended a preview of the city's biennial arts exhibition and visited several noted cultural sites in the city.

Among exhibits on display at the Canterbury biennial arts show is a piece created by Hsiao-ching Li, a Taiwan-born artist based in New York. The exhibition will be formally inaugurated Saturday for a 16-day run.
After looking at all exhibits, Vye hosted a luncheon in honor of Tien and several staff members at the ROC representative office in London. Vye presented a city emblem to Tien as souvenir.

Tien said he hopes cultural and civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Great Britain can be further expanded in the future. During his Canterbury visit, Tien also met with seven Taiwan students studying at a school in Kent County.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 19, or the second day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1566: King James I of England and VI of Scotland is born in the Scottish capital of Edinburgh. The son of Mary Queen of Scots, he succeeded Elizabeth I as the first Stuart king of England. His belief in the divine rights of kings and his attempts to keep the peace with Spain led to the English Civil War.
1623: Blaise Pascal, French philosopher and mathematician, is born. Among his achievements are the invention of an adding machine and the development of the modern theory of probability.
1885: The Statue of Liberty arrives in New York as a gift from France.
1924: The "Red Army" of the Chinese communists takes Lungyen and other towns in an attempt to establish a military base in western Fukien province in southern China.
1935: The British government overrides the Treaty of Versailles signed at the Paris Peace Conference in 1919 by agreeing to allow Germany a massive increase in its naval strength.
1944: The Japanese fleet attacks US ships protecting a landing at Saipan, resulting in considerable air and sea losses for Japan.
1953: Julius Rosenberg, 35, and his wife Ethel, 37, having been convicted by the United States of passing atom bomb secrets to the Russians, are sent to the electric chair at Sing Sing prison.
1956: American industrialist Thomas John Watson dies of a heart attack in New York at the age of 82. He became president of the company that later became International Business Machines Corporation (IBM) in 1924. Under Watson's leadership, it became one of the world's most successful corporations.
1960: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek and U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower issue a joint communique pledging that their governments will "continue to stand solidly behind the Sino-US Mutual Defense Treaty in meeting the challenge posed by the Chinese communists in this area."
1960: Prior to U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower's departure from the ROC, mainland China attacks Kinmen with 88,978 shells. Ordered to retaliate, ROC artillery units destroy eight coastal guns, seven fortifications, and four ammunition depots on the mainland.
1961: An 1899 agreement by which Britain is responsible for overseeing Kuwaiti foreign policy is terminated, making Kuwait a fully independent nation.
1964: Chiang Meng-lin, chairman of the ROC Joint Commission for Rural Reconstruction, dies of liver cancer in Taipei at the age of 79.
1974: Korean National Assembly Speaker Chung Il Kwon and a party of 15 arrive in Taipei for a four-day visit at the invitation of Premier Chiang Ching-kuo.
1975: The Republic of China and Saudi Arabia sign an agreement to strengthen economic and technical cooperation.
1975: The Chinese Pacific Economic and Cultural Center and the Philippines Far East Trade Promotion Center sign an agreement to exchange offices to promote bilateral trade, tourism and other relations.
1976: The US Manufacturers' Hanover Asia Consortium loans US$80 million to the China Steel Corporation.
1983: Li Xiannian becomes mainland China's first president since 1969.
1989: The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Task Force of the ROC announces the government's plan to simplify procedures for the relocation of Hong Kong and Macau citizens in Taiwan and to provide assistance for their emigration to a third country.
1992: The ROC resumes diplomatic relations with Niger.
1992: The ROC Legislative Yuan approves the Law on Foreign Futures Contracts, to take effect in January 1993.
1994: Wu Lihung, Hu Zehan and Yu Aiquin, who were found guilty and sentenced to death by a court in mainland China's Hangchow for killing 24 tourists from Taiwan at Qiantaohu in Chekiang province, are executed by firing squad.
1997: William Hague is chosen as the youngest-ever leader of Britain's Conservative Party.
1999: Prince Edward of Britain marries Sophie Rhys-Jones, a public relations executive, in a ceremony at Windsor Castle.
2000: Fifty-eight mainland Chinese were found suffocated in a truck container at an English port. They died during the trip from Belgium to Britain.
2001: Formosa Platics Group Chairman Wang Yung-ching says that Taiwan should accept mainland China's "one China" principle out of consideration for its mutual benefits at this critical moment of development for the entire Chinese race.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman esteems what is right as of the highest importance. A gentleman who has valor, but is without a knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to commit a crime. A common man who has courage, but is without the knowledge and love of what is right, is likely to become a robber."

A Saudi militant group said Friday that it had carried out its threat to execute a kidnapped American engineer, posting three grisly pictures of his beheaded corpse on a Web site before leaving the body in a remote neighborhood of the capital, Riyadh.
The Wall Street Journal: Militants say they executed American hostage Johnson Hostage Johnson

DOC.HEADLINE: MSCI NEW MEASURE TO HELP BOOST FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN STOCKS

TEXT.P: The Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) Co.'s decision to remove the Limited Investability Factor (LIF) currently applied to the MSCI Taiwan Index will help boost foreign investment in the local securities market, an official said Saturday.
The MSCI announced early Saturday that after completing a consultation with investors worldwide, it has decided to remove the LIF currently applied to the MSCI Taiwan Index in two separate phases.
In the first phase, MSCI will increase the LIF from 0.55 to 0.75 as of the end of November 30, 2004. In the second phase, MSCI will increase the LIF from 0.75 to 1 as of the end of May 31, 2005.

Commenting on the MSCI decision, Wu Tang-chieh, chief secretary of the Ministry of Finance, said it will help encourage foreign financial institutions to increase investment in the Taiwan stock market in the future.
Wu further said the decision marks a recognition of Taiwan's progress in promoting globalization and transparency of its capital market.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE BUST SMUGGLED BETEL NUTS

TEXT.P: Police on Saturday seized more than 3,800 kilograms of betel nuts smuggled from mainland China to Taiwan and arrested three suspects in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.

As now is off-season for betel nut harvesting in Taiwan, retail prices for the product has risen substantially in recent days. Criminal rings have worked hard to smuggle the product, also known as "green diamond" for its market value, from mainland China and Southeast Asia. In the past few weeks, police have managed to seize several batches of smuggled betel nuts.

The betel nuts seized in Saturday's raid were smuggled from mainland China's Hainan Island. They were packed in a 20-ft container and first shipped to the Taiwan-held frontline island of Kinmen before arriving at Kaohsiung Harbor Friday evening.

The owner claimed the cargo early Saturday. Acting on tips, police tracked down on the product at a warehouse in Kaoshiung's Chienchen district. The owner of the smuggled betel nuts, identified by his surname Hsiao, and two of his accomplices were arrested in the raid.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN ARRIVES IN TAIWAN FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Relations between Washington and Beijing may face some new situations after the U.S. presidential election in November this year, a former top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan said Saturday.

Therese Shaheen, a former chairwoman of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) that handles Taiwan-U.S. relations in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, made the remarks after her arrival in Taipei for a visit.

Asked whether Beijing-Washington relations are strained now, Shaheen said it depends on the perspective used in the observation. In her view, she said, some new developments may appear after the U.S. presidential election late this year.

Shaheen is very friendly toward Taiwan. Some of her remarks in the run-up to Taiwan's March 20 presidential election were seen as supporting incumbent President Chen Shui-bian's re-election bid. She abruptly resigned from the top AIT post after Taiwan's presidential election. Previous reports said Beijing had pressured the Bush administration to oust Shaheen.
Shaheen told Taiwan reporters after her arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that a host of reasons led to her resignation from the AIT chairmanship. But she would not elaborate.
The Republic of China government had invited Shaheen to attend President Chen's May 20 inauguration for a second four-year term. Due to her tight schedule, she postponed her visit until Saturday.
Shaheen said she is very pleased to come to Taiwan to meet with her old friends and to make friend with some other people.

President Chen will receive Shaheen Monday to express his gratitude for all the hospitality and dignified treatment arranged by Shaheen for him during his transit stop in New York last August. Chen will decorate Shaheen with the Order of Brillant Star in recognition of her contribution to promoting Taiwan-U.S. ties during her AIT stint.
Several senior ROC officials in charge of diplomatic and cross-Taiwan Strait affairs hosted a dinner in honor of Shaheen Saturday, sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEN ARE ALSO VICTIMS OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Five years after the domestic violence law was put into practice, Taipei Municipal Police Department reported Saturday that the number of men, children and the elderly being abused has increased.

According to the statistics, those who are abused by direct family members have also increased over the years -- 306 cases, or 9.4 percent of the total abuse case in 2003, up from 44 cases (3.8 percent) in 1999.

The ratio of male victims also rose to 274 (12.5 percent of both sexes) in 2003 from only 10 (2.9 percent) in 1999, showing that male victims, instead of feeling ashamed, have come out bravely to ask for assistance after being abused by women.
The abuse targeting the elderly over 60 has also increased yearly, setting a record high of 157 cases last year from the 47 cases in 1999.
Police have handled nine abuse cases toward children in the first five months of this year, and most came at the hands of their parents or babysitter. Two have died.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUMMER SOLSTICE MUSIC FESTIVAL BEGINS IN CHIAYI
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, June 19 (CNA) (By Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: The Asian Musical Festival, an eight-day event sponsored by the Chiayi County Government to mark the arrival of the summer solstice on June 21, began Saturday and will host musical groups from five Asian countries.

Chiayi County Magistrate Chen Ming-wen noted that Chiayi is located at the Tropic of Cancer, where the sun will be directly overhead at noon at the summer solstice. To welcome the arrival of the summer solstice, the county government has organized the Asian Musical Festival so that local residents do not have to travel abroad to watch the performances of excellent foreign musical groups, Chen said.
In addition to foreign groups, the organizer also invited local folk arts and aboriginal groups to warm up the festival.
Chen promised that residents in Chiayi County, which was considered a "cultural desert" in the past, will have more artistic and cultural events in the future under his leadership.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT: Los Angeles, Jun.18 CNA) Los Angeles Times: Air Authorities Were in Chaos,9/11 Panel Says. Federal aviation authorities and the nation's air defense command were uuprepared in virtually every way for the Sept.11 terrorist attacks and were forced to improvise amid chaos and miscommunication,the commission staff investigating the attacks said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA GROUP IN CENTRAL AMERICA TO ASSIST TAIWANESE BUSINESSMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 19 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: A delegation sent by the Republic of China's Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is visiting Panama to offer consultation services to Taiwanese businessmen with investments in Central America.

The delegation, composed of administration experts from the China Productivity Center and Ming Chuan University, hopes to assist Taiwanese businessmen abroad in reducing the risks to their investments and to integrate the forces of Taiwan entrepreneurs in expanding their global deployment.

In a symposium Friday, the delegation members spoke of key administration strategies for Taiwanese businessmen with investments in Panama and transmitted the ROC government's concern about their businesses abroad.
Prior to the Panama trip, the delegation visited the Dominican Republic and will head for Costa Rica after wrapping up its visit to Panama.
The consultation services form part of MOEA's plan to offer industrial services to global Taiwanese businessmen, especially those investing in Southeast Asia and Central and South America.

Lin Yu-cheng, head of the delegation, noted that these Taiwanese businessmen have already taken root in the countries where they do business, and the ROC government hopes that their investment can contribute to the economic development in their resident countries and strengthen Taiwan's diplomatic ties with these countries.
The delegation is scheduled to return home June 24.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. PACIFIC FLEET COMMANDER WORRIED ABOUT WAR IN THE TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Hawaii, June 18 (CNA) (By Lin Yi-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: U.S. Pacific Fleet Commander Adm. Thomas B. Fargo was quoted as having said Friday that he is very worried about an outbreak of war in the Taiwan Strait because of miscalculation by the governments on both sides.
Fargo made the remarks while meeting with a Taiwan legislative delegation, headed by Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, at the U.S. Pacific Command headquarters in Hawaii.
It marked the first time that civilian Taiwan visitors have been allowed to visit the U.S. Pacific Command headquarters and military bases in Hawaii.

Legislator Hsu Yuan-kuo of the opposition People First Party (PFP) quoted Fargo as having told the delegation that three issues in the Pacific region have made him unable to sleep at night -- little progress in removal of nuclear weapons from the Korean Peninsula; a possible outbreak of war in the Taiwan Strait because of miscalculation by the governments on both sides and mainland China's accelerated military modernization as a result of its rapid economic growth; and terrorist activities in Southeast Asia.

Hsu said the U.S. Pacific Command sent several senior officers, including a lieutenant general, a major general and three brigadier generals, to brief them on the command's mission and the general regional security situations as well as the functions of weapons that Taiwan plans to buy from the United States.

In the afternoon, the legislative delegation visited Pearl Harbor. Hsu said he and his colleagues boarded an Arleigh Burke-class guided missile destroyer equipped with the highly advanced Aegis radar system. ROC Vice Minister of National Defense Lei Kuang-shu, who is accompanying the lawmakers on their current U.S. tour, explained in detail the differences between the Arleigh Burke-class destroyer and the Kidd-class destroyer.

The United States has agreed to sell four Kidd-class destroyers to Taiwan and the delivery is scheduled to begin in 2005. Hsu quoted U.S. officers as having hinted that if Taiwan intends to buy the Arleigh Burke-class destroyer, the delivery could not begin until after 2010 or 2011.
The 13-member delegation arrived in Hawaii Thursday on the first leg of a U.S. tour aimed at discussing Taiwan's new arms procurement projects.

The delegation, composed of 13 lawmakers from across the political spectrum, visited a U.S. marine base at Kaneohe to take a close look at the P-3C anti-submarine aircraft, one of the items Taiwan plans to purchase.

The ROC's Cabinet has approved a special military budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the purchase of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992. The special budget bill is now pending approval of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

After the Hawaii visit, the legislative delegation will travel to Washington, D.C. via San Francisco. In the company of ROC Representative to the United States Chen Chien-jen, the delegation will visit relevant U.S. administrative departments June 21 and exchange views with senior officials on Taiwan's defense needs.

On the following day, the delegation will be briefed on special functions of the weaponry systems that the United States intends to sell to Taiwan. The mission will also meet with U.S. congressmen before leaving for Texas June 24 to visit a U.S. Patriot PAC-III missile base. The delegation is scheduled to return to Taipei June 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC JUSTICE MINISTER MEETS WITH OVERSEAS CHINESE IN DALLAS
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, June 18 (CNA) (By Chang Huei-yen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan told overseas Chinese in Dallas Friday night that several government agencies are conducting investigations into the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu.

Chen was responding to questions as to why a committee was not organized to look into the shooting, which left both the president and the vice president slightly injured. Taiwan police have yet to take any suspects into custody and have few clues.

He pointed out that the Control Yuan, the nation's highest watchdog body, and the Criminal Investigation Bureau have conducted investigations into the shooting, and although the names may be different, they are doing exactly the same thing.

Chen arrived in Dallas Friday afternoon to begin a "journey of gratitude" after attending the 2004 summer conference of the U.S. National Association of Attorneys General, which opened Tuesday in Los Angeles.

Chen said that he was in the United States drumming up support for President Chen during his 2000 campaign. This trip is to thank belatedly supporters of the president and the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

More than 100 overseas Chinese attended Minister Chen's speech although there were also around 60 who unfurled banners outside to protest against him, questioning why an investigation committee on the shooting has not been formed and why there has been no movement on investigating first lady Wu Shu-chen's alleged insider trading in the stock market.

In his speech, Minister Chen said that supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the Kuomintang and the People First Party have demanded that the Legislative Yuan form an investigation committee; however, such a committee would be unconstitutional.

He noted that the U.S. Congress has the right to conduct investigations, but there are no such rights in Taiwan's Legislative Yuan because the ROC Constitution gives this power to the Control Yuan, which has begun investigations on possible lapses on the part of civil servants, and part of the investigation report will be released soon.
The Criminal Investigation Bureau is also working on the case and as no suspects have been arrested yet, it is still too early to talk about criminal responsibility.

Chen said that if the Legislative Yuan were to investigate possible political and administrative lapses by civil servants, it would encroach on the Control Yuan's power and if it were to look into possible criminal activities, that would infringe the judicial rights of those legally responsible for criminal investigations.

President Chen won the March 20 presidential election by a narrow margin of 29,518 votes out of more than 13 million cast, and the supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" have since demanded a re-count of the ballots and the formation of a committee to investigate the election-eve shooting, which they claimed unfairly swayed the bitterly contested election in Chen's favor.
Minister Chen's schedule for the "journey of gratitude" is tight. He will fly to Houston after Dallas and then proceed to New York, Boston, Chicago and Honolulu before returning to Taiwan June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATURAL GAS FOUND IN HSINCHU AND KAOHSIUNG: CPC

TEXT.P: Officials of the state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) said Saturday that they have found abundant natural gas reserves in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, and in the waters near Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan.
CPC officials said the company has decided to explore these areas, which are expected to produce a total of some 7 billion cubic meters of natural gas.

This was the second such news for CPC in the last few days, following its recent announcement of the discovery of natural gas in Kuantien village, Tainan County, the hometown of President Chen Shui-bian.

According to CPC officials, Taiwan's terrestrial natural gas reserves center on its western areas and the company estimates that it can discover another 1.5 billion cubic meters of natural gas in the next five years in these areas.

The CPC is conducting an environmental evaluation for the two natural gas fields in the waters off Kaohsiung and expects that the natural gas can be transported to Taiwan proper in 2010 if the exploration work goes smoothly.
In addition, the exploration in CPC's overseas natural gas fields in Indonesia and Ecuador is underway, and work in the natural gas field in Venezuela will begin in 2006.
CPC officials estimate that the natural gas CPC can produce in its overseas fields in the next five years will be equivalent to 90 million barrels of oil.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE JET FIGHTERS TO CONDUCT TRAINING DRILLS ON EXPRESSWAY

TEXT.P: ROC Air Force jet fighters will practice takeoffs and landings at the Jenteh section of the Sun Yat-sen Expressway in July as part of the Hankuang (Chinese Glory) No. 20 exercise, a senior official confirmed Saturday.

Tsai Mao-hsiung, director of the Southern District Engineering Office under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), said the 2.7 kilometer Jenteh section in the southern county of Tainan has been refurbished in preparation for the upcoming military exercise.

The MOTC's Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau (TANFB) has also drafted an alternative traffic plan to minimize the possible adverse impact of the closure of the Jenteh section during the exercise, Tsai said.
It will mark the first time in 25 years that the military has conducted training exercises on the island's first north-south expressway since its inauguration in 1979.

The Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) issued a news statement around noon confirming that jet fighters practicing landings and takeoffs on the expressway is one of the scheduled maneuvers for the upcoming Hankuang No. 20 exercise, the largest combined services training drill of the year, which usually lasts for several months and covers computerized war games and live-fire exercises.

The AFGH statement said the planned expressway takeoff and landing drills are mainly aimed at evaluating the feasibility of using alternative runways during wartime to sustain the armed forces' combat capabilities.
The statement further said the AFGH is negotiating with relevant civilian authorities and will work out a comprehensive operational plan to minimize possible inconveniences for local citizens.

Noting that using alternative runways can help diversify military aircraft deployments, the AFGH statement said the upcoming training drill is part of the Air Force's efforts to upgrade its overall combat capabilities to defend national security.
The Sun Yat-sen Expressway accommodates several sections which can be used as runways for military aircraft takeoffs and landings during wartime.

The Jenteh section is close to President Chen Shui-bian's hometown of Guantien. MOTC officials said they don't think that there is any correlation between the military's choice of the Jenteh section and mainland China's possible attack plan.

According to Tsai, one of the expressway sections that can be converted into military aircraft runways has too many private houses in its vicinity and has thus been ruled out as the venue for the training drill.
Tsai said the MOTC was informed of the military's plan to conduct training drills on the Jenteh section in early January.

"We have since launched a renovation plan which was completed late last month, " Tsai said, adding that the ministry has paid special heed to material quality and workmanship in the refurbishing process.
Tsai said the expressway from the Jenteh intersection to the Luchu intersection will be closed to traffic for at least 12 hours on the days of rehearsal and formal exercise.
"The MOTC has worked out a detailed traffic control plan and will designate several alternative highways for motorists," Tsai said.

Some local citizens said they hope the training drill can be open for public viewing under proper security measures because they have never seen any aircraft using the expressway as alternative runways for takeoffs and landings.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMONSTRATORS ASK TO FREEZE BUDGET FOR ARMS PROCUREMENT FROM U.S.

TEXT.P: A rally to protest Taiwan's plan to spend NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) for U.S. weapons called for the government to freeze the arms procurement plan.

Hundreds of people took part in the rally in downtown Taipei, which was sponsored by activists from civic and environmental protection groups and people representing education reform and workers' rights from the private sector.

The people gathered in front of Taipei Railway Station, wearing green headbands emblazoned with the words "Opposed to arms procurement" and holding posters. They also signed petitions opposing the arms procurement.
They said that they are opposed to government's plan to purchase arms without public discussion and claimed that the deal was dictated by the United States.
If the government insists on spending NT$610.8 billion on military hardware from the United States, they said that they would not rule out the possibility of scuttling the plan through a referendum.

The people walked through the Taipei streets to the nearby Feb. 28 Peace Memorial Park and shouted slogans such as, "Opposed to an arms race, insist on ideas of progress," "Opposed to receiving orders from the superpower and insist on treading one's own path, " and "Opposed to no public discussion and insist on public participation in the nation's policy."
They also performed music and skits in the park to highlight their appeal.

Huang Wu-hsiung, education reform activist and one of the sponsors, expressed the hope that Taiwan can find a third option other than the present plight of relying on the United States while resisting to Beijing's "one country, two systems" unification scheme.
To show that the rally has no party affiliation, no political party flags were displayed throughout the demonstration, and children and their parents led the demonstrators along the way.

According to the sponsors, if the NT$610.8 billion is not spent, the money will be enough to promote 12-year compulsory education 10-fold, a plan which has been on the drawing board for a decade and has still not been finalized. The money could also help sustain an annual environmental protection budget of NT$10 billion for 60 years, and could subsidize the medical bills for children under three years old for 200 years.
But they said the huge arms procurement, which the government plans to sell national land and float national bonds to finance, will squeeze out all other plans.

The Executive Yuan approved the NT$610.8 billion arms procurement early this month to buy six sets of Patriot PAC-III missiles, eight conventional diesel-fuel submarines and 12 P-3C anti-missile aircraft. The package is now pending review and approval by the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ABORIGINAL BAND A HIT IN PARIS

TEXT.P: The aboriginal band "Amis, " made up of musician from Taiwan's indigenous Ami tribe, on Friday gave Paris audiences an extraordinary night with exotic music filled with nature's myths.
The indigenous band, with handmade musical instruments, made their debut in Paris' popular park, Jardin du Luxembourg, as a warm-up for the Paris music festival Fete de la Musique to be held June 21.
Wearing colorful indigenous clothes, the members of the band played flutes, drums and xylophones. Among them a special kind of nose flute attracted much attention and surprise.
The band's show reached its climax when the public joined their dance and after the show the audience gathered around asking where the band came from and how they made and play the instruments.
The Amis will have another two shows at the Taipei Representative Office's cultural center in Paris June 21-22.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERIMENTAL SCHOOLS MAKE EDUCATION MORE DIVERSIFIED: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Education Tu Cheng-sheng said Saturday that experimental schools make Taiwan's education more diversified.
Tu made the remarks while receiving four students from Holistic High School in Sanyi, Miaoli County who just returned from climbing Mount McKinley, Alaska, Friday night.

In a symposium about educational reforms held at National Chengchi University in Taipei, Tu noted that he supports the experimental schools in addition to regular schools, as they may spark creative ideas.

Experimental schools represent a stimulus to official education, Tu said, and urged education departments in counties and cities around the island to open their doors to these experimental schools and supply them with more resources.

Tu cited his own example, revealing that in 1990 he dedicated himself to the study of medical history, which was considered unusual and unpopular at the time, when he was a fellow researcher at the Institute of History and Philology at Academia Sinica, the most prestigious academic institution in Taiwan.
He said this gave him many new ideas and new thoughts.

Huang Cheng-hsiung, president of Holistic High School, who was also present at the occasion, noted that he was proud of the achievements of the four students who scaled Mount McKinley, the highest mountain in North America. Among them, Chang Yuan-chih is only 15 years old and might have been Taiwan's youngest mountaineer on high mountains, while Chen Yi-chih, the only girl of the four, is only 19 years old, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW NATURAL GAS FIELD WORTH NT$2.5 BILLION

TEXT.P: The Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) on Saturday confirmed the reserves of a natural gas field in Guantien, Taiwan County to have about 400 million cubic meters of natural gas deposits worth a production value of NT$2.5 billion (US$74.47 million).

CPC Vice Executive Director Lu Ming-ta said Guantien, which happens to be the hometown of President Chen Shui-bian, was known to have natural gas deposits back in 1992, but the exact location was pinpointed last year.

Lu said that it is estimated that the first well of the natural gas field will have a maximum natural gas production of 46,000 cubic meters daily, and if calculated by two wells with a daily production of 60,000 cubic meters, then it could produce for 20 years and create a production value of NT$2.5 billion.

If the development plan goes smoothly, natural gas in Guantien is expected to provide for Taiwan proper starting in 2010, raising the level of domestic supply of natural gas while cutting reliance on foreign imports.

The CPC rents the rice paddy where the field is located NT$400,000 a year, Lu said, adding that the company will reciprocate to local people depending on the result of the exploitation of the natural gas.
The CPC is the only petroleum and natural gas prospector in Taiwan and has achieved a revenue of NT$150 billion over the past decades.

Buoyed by the find of the natural gas field in Guantien, CPC Chairman Kuo Chin-tsai said that the company will increase exploration, saying that it has appropriated a budget for this of NT$15 billion between 2002 and 2007. Of that amount, NT$5.5 billion is earmarked for land exploration, NT$1.9 billion for sea exploration and NT$7.6 billion for overseas exploration.
He said that the company hopes that the oil and gas exploration side of the business will account for 30 percent of the company's total profits by 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO REVISE CHARTER TO ENABLE PRESIDENT TO NAME PARTY CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will amend its party charter at its upcoming national congress with a view to authorizing the president to name the party's chairman with the endorsement of its Central Executive Committee, a DPP heavyweight said Saturday.

Legislator Ker Chien-ming, who concurrently serves as the DPP legislative whip, said the party charter amendment proposal was presented to the DPP headquarters Friday for extensive discussion and approval at the party congress scheduled for July.
Ker said President Chen Shui-bian, who is now doubled as DPP chairman, is fully aware of the contents of the proposal.
Under the current DPP charter, the president is the party's chairman ex officio.

The proposed amendment will stipulate that the president is the party's chairman or the president can name a vice chairman to serve as the party's chairman with the consent of the party's Central Executive Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTY CHARTER REVISION TO GIVE PRESIDENT OPTION: DPP LAWMAKER

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian won't resign from his post as Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman immediately after the party amends its charter at its upcoming national congress, the convener of the DPP caucus in the Legislative Yuan said Sunday.

Ker Chien-ming said he on Friday initiated the proposal to change the party charter which stipulates that the DPP candidate elected the nation's president is automatically the party's chairman, to give the president the option of stepping down as party chairman.
According to the amendment, if the president chooses to step down as DPP chairman, then the party's Central Executive Committee will choose a new chairman from among the party's vice chairmen.

Ker said that President Chen will have a freer hand in carrying out his two major tasks of revising the nation's constitution and improving ties with the mainland in his second term if he is not the DPP chairman, adding that the revision to the party's charter will give him this option.

The proposal also addresses the problem in the current DPP charter which does not clearly stipulate which vice chairman should take the helm of the party when the party chief is incapable of carrying out his job, Ker continued.
He said the DPP often alters its apparatus to adapt to the evolving policial situation with a view to increasing the party's strength.
Ker said that the amendment has already won endorsement from various factions within the DPP and that he believes it will be approved by the party congress which is scheduled for next month.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOSTS DINNER TO ENTERTAIN FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun hosted a dinner party Sunday to entertain former chairperson of the American Institute in Taiwan, Therese Shaheen who arrived in Taipei a day earlier for a four-day visit.

Vice Premier Yeh Chu-lan and Lin Fang-mei, chairwoman of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs (CCNAA) , the organization that represents Taiwan in dealing with the United States in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, were also present in the party.

Officials of the Executive Yuan kept a low profile on the meeting between Yu and Shaheen. They declined to reveal what Yu and Shaheen talked about in the dinner, but said that the two interacted very well.

The Republic of China government had invited the former top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan to attend President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inauguration for a second four-year term. Due to her tight schedule, she postponed her visit until Saturday.
President Chen will receive Shaheen Monday to express his gratitude for all the hospitality and dignified treatment arranged by Shaheen for him during his transit stop in New York last August.
Chen will also decorate Shaheen with the Order of Brillant Star in recognition of her contribution to promoting Taiwan-U.S. ties during her AIT stint.
