DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE PROMOTION MISSION TO VISIT AFRICA IN NOVEMBER

TEXT.P: The government will organize a trade promotion delegation to visit various African countries in November in view of the increased opening of markets in that part of the world, a Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) spokesman said Sunday.

The mission, to be organized by the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade, is slated to travel to Morocco, Egypt and Nigeria in late November, and Taiwan companies in the fields of medical-care equipment, automobile parts and accessories, hardware, and textiles are particularly encouraged to take part in the mission, the MOEA official said.

Morocco, which has posted an average annual economic growth rate of 5.5 percent in recent years, has a great demand for machinery equipment, the official said, forecasting that the North African country is expected to further open its market following the signing of a free trade agreement with the United States last week.
Egypt, Taiwan's second-largest trade partner in Africa, imported US$186 million worth of Taiwan products last year, according to the official.

He predicted that the second half of this year will present a good opportunity for Taiwan companies to explore business opportunities in Egypt because the neighboring market of Iraq will be boosted with the U.S.-led coalition forces' handing back of sovereignty of Iraq to the Iraqi people in late June.

Nigeria, with a population of more than 120 million people, is a potential market for a wide range of Taiwan industries because many sectors in the African country are in their initial stages of further development, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MUST CEMENT TIES WITH WASHINGTON: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan-U.S. relations are unlikely to undergo a structural change in the coming years, Taiwan still needs to cement its links with the United States amid the many challenges arising from warming Beijing-Washington ties, a well-known political observer said Sunday.

Bau Tzong-ho, dean of National Taiwan University's College of Social Sciences, made the comments at a seminar held by the Foundation on International & Cross-strait Studies with the aim of offering the government valuable advice in view of the many problems foreseen in Taipei-Washington-Beijing ties on the fronts of national security, national defense, cross-Taiwan Strait relations and political affairs.

Pointing out that Washington will remain firm in its position of requesting that both Taiwan and mainland China exercise self-restraint to avoid conflict, Bau warned that pressure from mainland China will become stronger on Taiwan as the mainland begins to engage with neighboring countries.

Despite the fact that relations between Washington and Beijing are getting warmer, the United States still views the mainland as a potential rival and also as a collaborator at the same time, Bau said.

If U.S. President George W. Bush fails to win re-election at the end of this year, Washington's foreign policy is expected to shift toward multilateralism, he analyzed. Should this happen and be coupled with political reform in mainland China, Taiwan will become further isolated diplomatically in the international community, he pointed out.

Therefore, he said, Taiwan should do its best to minimize political rows at home in its pursuit of democratization and Taiwanization so as to maintain its status-quo, which is of extreme significance to the Taiwan Strait security.

As any change to Taiwan's status-quo would pose a very large threat to Taipei-Washington-Beijing's ties, Taiwan should strengthen and upgrade its relations with the United States and step up two-way military cooperation while seeking greater diplomatic backing from the European Union to curb increased pressure from the mainland, he opined.
Taiwan should also promote dialogue between Taiwan entrepreneurs and their counterparts from Japan and South Korea to counter the mainland's growing economic power in the region, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN HAS NO PLAN TO RELOCATE CAPITAL: SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has no plan to relocate the nation's capital, the Cabinet spokesman said Sunday.

Commenting on discussions raised by Vice President Annette Lu's remarks on the issue, Chen Chi-mai said that the question of relocating the capital should be thoroughly thought through, adding that the Executive Yuan currently has no plan to move the capital.

Lu, addressing a dinner party hosted by a group of travel agents Saturday in Kaohsiung in recognition of her contribution to the promotion of the southern Taiwan port city's tourism industry, said that the central government is mulling over relocating the capital from Taipei to Kaohsiung.

Echoing Lu's remarks, three lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , Trong R. Chai, Lin Chin-hsing and Chiang Chao-yi, called for a referendum Sunday on whether to choose a new capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN ASSERTS DPP LEADERS MUST BE CHOSEN THROUGH DEMOCRATIC PROCESS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian has asserted that any leader of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should be elected through a democratic process, a DPP official said Sunday.

Lee Ying-yuan, DPP deputy secretary-general, made the remarks when he commented on a proposal initiated last Friday by Legislator Ker Chien-ming, convener of the DPP legislative caucus, for amending the party charter to give President Chen the option of stepping down as party chairman.
The DPP charter stipulates that the party's candidate elected the nation's president is automatically the party's chairman.
Chen has made it clear that the DPP has no problem on the transfer of leadership and that any party leader should be elected through a democratic process, according to Lee.
Noting that the DPP headquarters has already completed its mission of winning the 2004 presidential election, Lee said that constitutional reform is now the party's most important historic mission.

The amendment to the DPP charter proposed by Ker and endorsed by lawmakers from various factions in the party is to allow Chen to have a supra-partisan and neutral position in promoting constitutional reform which, they believe, will facilitate the reform by helping in reaching consensus among the ruling and opposition parties, according to Lee.

In a related development, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, who is considered as a potential candidate to succeed Chen as the DPP chairman if the president decides to step down from the party chairmanship, said Sunday that he is too busy to be the DPP chairman.

According to the proposed amendment, if the president chooses to step down as DPP chairman, then the party's Central Executive Committee will choose a new chairman from among the party's vice chairmen.
Ker said that the amendment has already won endorsement from various factions within the DPP and that he believes it will be approved by the party congress which is scheduled for July 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFERENDUM TOOL VALUABLE IN RESISTING ONE CHINA POLICY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The referendum tool could be valuable for Taiwan in resisting efforts by Beijing or the international community to impose the "one China policy" on it, a scholar said Saturday.

Teng Li-wen, deputy executive director of the Foundation on International and Cross-strait Studies, noted at a workshop in Taipei held by the foundation that President Chen Shui-bian did not acknowledge the one China principle in his May 20 inaugural address for a second term, and that Beijing did not admit the existence of the Republic of China in its May 17 statement.

The widely conflicting political views between the two sides means that cross-strait relations will swing between "cold war" and "cold peace" over the course of Chen's new four-year term, Dong predicted.

Mainland China has made out a case for its " peaceful rise, " claiming that it is a plus for regional peace rather than a threat to anyone. Meanwhile, Taiwan has thoroughly developed into a democracy and has been trying to win international sympathy through this fact, Dong said.

He said that the United States is tilting toward mainland China in the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relationship because Washington needs Beijing's support in tackling regional and international issues.
Dong called for the establishment of an economic and trade interaction mechanism between Taiwan and mainland China as a way of easing tension across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLAR URGES FINANCIAL REFORM, EASED RULES ON MAINLAND INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan should speed up its financial liberalization, deepen its reform in the field and ease restrictions on mainland-bound investment to help promote Taiwan business interests, a prominent scholar urged Sunday.

Chang Jong-fong, vice president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, made the suggestion in a seminar held by the Foundation on International and Cross-Strait Studies while making public an overall analysis on Taiwan's economic, political, security and social challenges over the coming four years.

Pointing out that Taiwan will experience structural changes in bilateral relations with its major trade partners, Chang warned that the mainland market share currently enjoyed by Taiwan companies will begin to decline and that mainland China's emergence as a major economic power will increasingly marginalize Taiwan.

According to Chang, the appreciation of the mainland currency -- the renminbi -- as well as the mainland's expected entry into the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and its signing of "closer economic partnership agreements" with countries in the region will pose the largest threat to Taiwan in its bid to join in regional economic integration.

Meanwhile, the lack of a mechanism for settling Taiwan-mainland trade disputes, Taiwan's growing financial difficulties, as well as the exodus of talent and capital from Taiwan to the mainland are some of the things that will place major pressure on Taiwan's macro-economy, he added.

He called on the government to craft a white paper to outline its prime economic and trade policies as a way of displaying its resolve in strengthening Taiwan's economic power by taking advantage of its high-quality workforce and manufacturing skills in the face of robust mainland Chinese competition.

Taiwan's complete globalization in terms of trade and economy would not only increase the island's competitiveness but also help protect its political independence, Chang said, urging the government to develop Taiwan into a "high-tech island" and a "world business operations hub" in its drive to seek a role for the country in the international marketplace.

Taiwan's value-added capabilities will help reduce pressure from domestic companies' demands for opening direct trade and transport links with the mainland and will also help curb Beijing's designs to use Taiwan businesses to push the government to the negotiating table, he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Kurds advancing ro reclaim land in northern Iraq.
Thousands of ethnic Kurds are pushing into lands formerly held by Iraqi Arabs, forcing tens of thousands of them to flee to ramshackle refugee camps and transforming the demographic and political map of northern Iraq. The new movement appears to have quickened this spring amid confusion about American policy.
The Wall Street Journal: U.S. Airstrike on Zarqawi network kills at least 16 Iraqis in Fallujah.
A U.S. military plane fired missiles Saturday into a residential neighborhood in Fallujah, killing at least 16 people and leveling houses there, police and residents said. A U.S. official said the target was a hideout of of Abu Musab al-Zarqawi's terror network.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS CALL FOR REFERENDUM ON NEW CAPITAL

TEXT.P: Three lawmakers from the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Sunday called for a referendum on whether to choose a new capital after Vice President Annette Lu revealed a day earlier that the central government is mulling over relocating from Taipei to Kaohsiung.

DPP lawmakers Trong R. Chai, Lin Chin-hsing and Chiang Chao-yi urged in a press release that the government hold a referendum on the issue to let the people decide where the nation's capital should be located.

Based on national security considerations, the three said in the press release, it is better if a nation's political center is separate from its economic center, pointing to the example of the United States whose political center is in Washington, D.C., and whose economic heart is in New York City.
Pointing out that mainland China has hundreds of missiles aimed at Taipei, the lawmakers urged that the central government relocate out of Taipei for the sake of security.

Several lawmakers from the opposition People First Party (PFP) said they won't oppose the idea of having a referendum on the issue, but added they doubt that the DPP lawmakers could get enough sponsorship to be able to hold the referendum.
Meanwhile, PFP lawmaker Lee Hung-chun said the DPP wants to shift the capital to a new location because the party has difficulty wooing voters in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 20, or the third day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1863: West Virginia becomes the 35th state of the United States.
1887: The longest railway bridge in Britain and the second over the River Tay in Scotland is opened.
1895: The Japanese government in Taiwan founds the "Taiwan Hospital" in Taipei, which later became the National Taiwan University Hospital.
1902: Prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War in 1904, the Japanese supreme wartime office establishes the "General Headquarters of Military Service in Manchuria" and appoints Gon Oyama, former joint chief of staff, as its commander-in-chief.
1909: Errol Flynn, the American actor who specialized in swashbuckling and war hero roles, is born in Tasmania. He appeared in such films as "The Adventures of Robin Hood," "Captain Blood," and "The Sea Hawk."
1940: At the request of Japan, France closes the railway between Yunnan Province and Vietnam, cutting transportation links between Vietnam and China.
1960: American Floyd Patterson knocks out Sweden's Ingmar Johansson to become the first boxer to regain the world heavyweight title.
1960: Mali gains independence from France.
1963: The United States and Russia agree to establish a hotline telephone link.
1964: A China Air Transport (CAT) passenger plane crashes near Fengyuan in Central Taiwan on its way from Makung to Taipei, killing more than 50 aboard, including movie industry tycoon Loh Yun-tao, who is visiting Taiwan to attend the 11th Asian Film Festival.
1967: Muhammad Ali, originally Cassius Marcellus Clay, the American boxer who won the world heavyweight title in 1964, is sentenced to five years in prison and fined US$10,000 for refusing to be conscripted into the armed forces.
1974: Dr. Amade M. Yuzon, president of the United Poets Laureate International, arrives in Taipei to attend a meeting celebrating Chinese Poets' Day.
1976: A six-man delegation led by artist-poet Wang Lan leaves for Seoul to attend the Asian Artist Conference and a plenary meeting of the Asian Arts Center.
1978: The Republic of China is listed the 25th-largest trading country in the world by the International Monetary Fund.
1979: American TV reporter Bill Stewart is gunned down by Nicaraguan National Guardsmen as he walks toward a roadblock with a white flag in one hand and his official yellow press card in the other.
1982: The Directorate General of Telecommunications (DGT) opens the first public data switching service in the Republic of China.
1984: Some 70 miners are killed in the Haishan coal mine disaster in northern Taiwan.
1990: South Africa's Nelson Mandela gets a ticker-tape welcome in New York.
1992: Czech and Slovak leaders decide to split Czechoslovakia into two nations, one for Czechs and one for Slovaks. The Czech Republic and Slovakia formally came into existence on Jan. 1, 1993.
1997: Russia pledges to stop targeting Japan with nuclear missiles.
1999: Boris Yeltsin presents U.S. President Bill Clinton with recently declassified Russian reports relating to the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.
2000: Hans Muench, a German doctor in the Nazis' Auschwitz death camp is given immunity from trial at a French court because of his senility.
2001: The 46th World Conference of the International Council for Small Businesses (ICSB) concludes in Taipei after some 500 participants from 55 countries spent three days to discuss how to cope with the challenges posed by the new era.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Of all people in the world, young women and servants are the most difficult to keep in the house. If you are familiar with them, they forget their position, but if you keep them at a distance, they are discontented."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Japan Times: Global truce urged for Athens Olympics; Torch comes to U.N. for the first time.
The Olympic torch came to the United Nations for the first Saturday, and the world body sent it on its global journey with an appeal for a halt to all fighting during the upcoming Athens Summer Games and a silent prayer for lasting peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Bangkok Post: Channel 5 contract faces probe.
Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra will appoint five experts to an inquiry vetting Channel 5's partial privatisation, a deal which his cousin army chief Chaisit Shinawatra appears keen to seal amid widespread scepticism. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Los Angeles, June 20 (CAN) Los Angeles Times:
The U.S. military launched an air strike in Fallouja against what it called a terrorist hide-out, killing at least 18 Iraqis and reigniting anti-American passions in that stronghold of the insurgency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR CHAIRMAN TO BE FINANCIAL SUPERVISORY COMMISSION CHIEF

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has decided to appoint incumbent Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) Chairman Kong Jaw-sheng to head the Financial Supervisory Commission to be inaugurated July 1, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Monday.
Kong, a financial management professional, took over the state-owned Taisugar chairmanship last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR DEVELOPMENT OF CULTURAL, CREATIVE INDUSTRIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian pledged Monday to boost the development of cultural and creative industries.

Speaking at a meeting of the National Cultural Association, of which the president is the chairman, Chen said culture is the foundation of a country and the indicator of its national strength, which is why countries around the world are promoting the development of cultural and creative industries in the hope of turning it into a significant part of the national economy.

The president urged the association to combine cultural development with the development of the community and to create more communities that are unique, such as those communities rebuilt in central Taiwan after they were leveled by the earthquake of Sept. 21, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 22 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are major events scheduled to take place Tuesday, June 22:
09: 00, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will attend the funeral service of Legislator Chen Chung-yi's father in Taoyuan.
09:30, Legislator Liu Wen-hsiung will hold a press conference at the People First Party's legislative caucus office.
13: 00, The first "President Cup" wheelchair dance and sports tournament will open at the Taipei municipal auditorium.
15: 00, The 2004 Taipei International Dragon Boat Race will continue on the Tachia section of Keelung River.
17: 00, The 2004 Kaohsiung Dragon Boat Race will continue on the Love River.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL SECURES LOAN FOR PLANE PROCUREMENT

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) secured Monday a credit loan from France-based CALYON Bank for its purchase of three A330-300 planes, a CAL spokesman said Monday.
CAL General Manager Philip H.H. Wei and CALYON Bank Taiwan General Manager Michel Roy signed the 10-year loan agreement worth US$235 million on behalf of their respective companies.
Wei said at the signing ceremony that he strongly believes bilateral ties between CAL and CALYON Bank will be further strengthened by the credit loan.

CAL -- Taiwan's largest carrier -- will use the preferential loan to buy three A330-300 planes, the first of which will be delivered in late June, with the remaining two delivered in July and December, respectively.

The three A330-300s will replace CAL's A300-600s on routes within Asia to reduce the carrier's running costs in maintenance, personnel training and travel time, the spokesman said, adding that each A330-300 airplane has 313 seats, 18 percent more than the A330-600.
CAL will be able to manage a targeted pre-tax profit of NT$31 billion (US$919 million) for 2004, despite the adverse effect of rising fuel prices, the spokesman forecast.

In a bid to phase out the carrier's ageing fleet and upgrade its service quality, CAL has been searching for financial backup to sustain its expansion program, he added, pointing out that the CALYON loan is proof that CAL profit-making abilities and prospects are endorsed by foreign banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER PAYS TRIBUTE TO POLICE OFFICER KILLED IN SHOOTOUT

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Su Jia-chyuan reaffirmed the government's determination Monday to eradicate organized crime and illegal possession of firearms.

Su made the reaffirmation after paying a tribute to Yeh Hsi-tsai, a detective unit leader at a Taichung police precinct in central Taiwan who died early Monday after being shot in the head last Wednesday in a shootout with a suspected kidnapper.
Su said the government will provide the best possible financial compensation and care to Yeh's bereaved family members.
Moreover, Su said the government will continue an islandwide crackdown on organized crime and gun smuggling to improve public order and maintain a safe living environment.

Afterward, Su also paid his respects to another detective unit leader, Lee Chin-fu, who was pronounced dead upon arrival at a Taichung hospital after he was shot in the chest during last Wednesday's shootout.

A third officer, Lin Wen-wu, who was shot in the arm in the street shootout, has been in stable condition after receiving medical treatment. The kidnapping suspect, Su Ming-an, was shot dead in the shootout.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PURCHASES CAN STRENGTHEN DEFENSES: FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: Former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen said Monday that she believes Taiwan's planned arms purchases can strengthen its defense capability.
Shaheen, a former head of the AIT, which handle U.S.-Taiwan relations in the absence of diplomatic ties, made the remarks during a visit to Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou.
The Executive Yuan plans to purchase weapons worth NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) from the United States, amid strong domestic opposition to the plan.

Ma, who is also a vice chairman of the opposition Kuomintang, said that Taiwan needs sufficient ability to defend itself, but he added that this does not mean there should be an arms race with mainland China.
In addition to defense capability, efforts to try to relax the tension between the two sides of Taiwan Strait are also very important, Ma said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PLAN APPROVED FOR NETWORK AGAINST NEWLY EMERGED CONTAGIOUS DISEASES

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development approved a plan Monday for the building of a biological shield and a defense network against the newly emerged contagious diseases, including severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

The plan, put forward by the Department of Health (DOH) , will cost NT$6.6 billion (US$195.7 million) over four years from 2005 to build eight networks -- a boundary quarantine network, an international cooperation network, an inner-hospital infection-control network, a disease-monitoring network, a contagious diseases-treatment network, an anti-epidemic information network, a communal anti-epidemic network and a quarantine inspection network.
With these networks in place, the DOH said, the country will be better protected against epidemics.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA OFFICIALS URGE LOCAL BUSINESSMEN TO DIVERSIFY INVESTMENTS

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials urged local businessmen Monday to diversify their overseas investments and reduce their over-reliance on the mainland Chinese market, as the mainland is suffering a serious shortage of electricity.

MOEA Investment Commission officials noted that although the mainland authorities announced in April a plan to cool down the mainland's overheated economy, Taiwanese businessmen's investments on the mainland have continued normally, with the amount of investment in the first five months of the year growing by 60.34 percent.
However, the officials said that although the Taiwanese investments are continuing, they believe that the effects of the mainland's cooling-down plan will emerge gradually.

Noting that there is a serious shortage of electricity in the mainland, the officials reminded local entrepreneurs that investment there still has high risk and they suggested that investors consider investing in Southeast Asia, South Asia and East Europe.

The officials also reported that direct investment made by overseas Chinese and foreigners in Taiwan totalled US$1.37 billion in the first five months, an increase of 37 percent over the same period of last year, reflecting foreign investors' high confidence in Taiwan's investment climate.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW COMPUTER-SIMULATED WAR GAME SYSTEM CAPABLE OF OVERSEAS LINK-UP

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Lee Jye confirmed Monday that the armed forces' new computer-simulated war game system can link up with foreign countries' computer-simulated war game systems.
Lee made the confirmation during a luncheon with local journalists, the first time he has met with the press since assuming office a month ago.

Lee said the new system has been tested in a series of computer-simulated war games that were concluded last weekend as part of the Hankuang No. 20 military exercise -- the largest combined services training drill of the year that will last for several months and cover both computer-simulated war games and live-fire drills.
He confirmed that the United States sent some 60 military experts to observe the maiden use of the new combined services command system in the computer-simulated war games.
Lee said the American experts were impressed by the armed forces' better-than-expected performance in the simulated war games with the new command system.

Media reports said the United States has agreed to conduct joint computer-simulated war games with Taiwan from 2005. As the U.S. computer-simulated war game system can be linked up with Japan's, the reports said, Taiwan, Japan and the United States will be able to conduct joint computer-simulated war games through the U.S. Pacific Command headquarters in Hawaii in the future.

Lee would not confirm whether Taiwan's computer-simulated war game system can be linked with Japan's, saying only that if the opportunity presents itself, Taiwan will be more than willing to conduct joint computer-simulated war games with Japan.

Turning to reports that air force jet fighters will practice landings and takeoffs on the Sun Yat-sen Expressway's Jen-teh section of southern Taiwan in late July as part of the Hankuang exercise, Lee said the military indeed has such a plan. In August, Lee said, the army and air force will conduct an integrated air-land training drill.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPENING OF CROSS-STRAIT LINKS CAN BE PRIORITY ISSUE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun quoted President Chen Shui-bian Monday as saying that if the tension between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait relaxes, the opening of direct cross-strait links can be made a priority issue.
Yu made the remarks during a founding ceremony for the Republic of China Futures Association.

Noting that he has met with Chen every week since the March 20 presidential election, Yu said the president always expresses concern about Taiwan's solidarity, cross-strait ties, the island's economic development and prosperity, as well as stressing that the government has set goals for the nation's development in the world community.

Yu said he has great confidence in Taiwan's economic development despite mounting international oil prices and predicted that the country's economic growth will reach 6.7 percent in the second quarter of this year.

The economic growth registered 6.28 percent in the first quarter of this year and is expected to reach 4.6 percent and 4.18 percent, respectively, for the third and fourth quarters, with the economic growth for the whole year estimated at 5.41 percent, according to Yu.
He said that if the cross-strait political situation calms down, interference by non-economic factors will be reduced and Taiwan's economic prospects will be brilliant.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOPES TO JOIN U.S.-INITIATED JSF DEVELOPMENT PLAN: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) has informed the United States of its desire to take part in the development of a new generation of combat aircraft known as the Joint Strike Fighter (JSF), Defense Minister Lee Jye said Monday.
Lee made the remarks during a luncheon with local journalists, the first time that he has met with the press since assuming office a month ago.
Lee said the JSF is still in the research and development (R&D) stage and that the program will take 10 to 15 years to complete.

"We hope to join this ambitious development program. But no concrete progress has been made. The two sides are still discussing the feasibility of Taiwan's participation in the project, " Lee told reporters.
According to Lee, the JSF project is designed to develop a new generation of affordable stealth tactical warplanes for the 21st Century.

Touching on the military's new arms procurement plans, Lee said the MND usually uses its annual budget of about NT$260 billion to finance its weaponry procurement projects, such as the purchase of four second-hand Kidd-class destroyers.

Nevertheless, Lee said, the MND must rely on special budget plans for certain large-scale arms procurement projects because its regular annual budget is not enough to finance such unexpected spending.

For instance, Lee said, the MND has come up with a special military budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the purchase of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992. The Cabinet has approved the special budget bill, which is now pending approval of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

A legislative delegation, headed by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, is presently on a U.S. visit to get a better understanding of the functions of the military hardware the Bush administration is offering. Delegation members said after visiting a U.S. naval base in Hawaii over the weekend that the United States might also be willing to sell Taiwan the Arleigh Burke-class destroyer equipped with the extremely advanced Aegis radar system.
If the United States will truly sell the Aegis-class destroyer to Taiwan, Lee said, the ROC navy will use its regular annual budget to finance the purchase and will not ask for additional budget.
Lee said mainland China's military budget has continued to grow at a double-digit rate. In contrast, he said, Taiwan's defense budget has been maintained at roughly the same level in recent years.

In the face of mainland China's ever-mounting military threat, Lee said, the military needs the three new arms procurement projects to upgrade its defense capabilities. He said he hopes lawmakers and the public will support the projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CALLS FOR FULL PROTECTION OF TAIWAN BUSINESSES IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese authorities should protect Taiwan business interests on the mainland and should not mix politics with economics in this area, a government official said Monday.

Chiu Tai-san, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the call on the grounds that the mainland, as a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO), should follow the WTO's regulations on discrimination.

Stressing that the mainland should live up to its repeated pledges that "economics should be separate from politics, " Chiu pointed out that the authorities of some provinces have gone against the principle set by Beijing and have resorted to various measures to undermine the business interests of some Taiwan companies operating in their jurisdictions.
"The mainland Chinese authorities have an obligation to fully protect Taiwan business interests on the mainland, as long as Taiwan companies abide by mainland laws," he said.

Chiu urged the mainland authorities to realize that Taiwan businessmen are free to air their viewpoints in an open and pluralistic society such as Taiwan and called on them not to use their comments to judge as whether they are welcome to operate on the mainland. "Such attempts severely violate WTO rules, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT FAVORS POPULAR ELECTION OF DPP CHIEF: DPP SECRETARY-GENERAL

TEXT.P: Although President Chen Shui-bian has not said so, it is "obvious" that he supports the idea of having his successor as Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman elected directly by all party members, DPP Secretary-General Chang Chun-hsiung said Monday.

"If the president chooses not to double as DPP chief, he would not necessarily appoint a vice chairman and would not appoint that vice chairman as his successor, therefore the best way is to give the party members the right to choose their chief," Chang said.
However, this changes entails a revision of the party charter and should be referred to a party reformation panel for study, Chang said.

The DPP secretary-general quoted Chen as saying that he could hardly moonlight as DPP chairman in light of the fact that he wants to devote all his energies to constitutional reform and dealing with Beijing during his second term as president.
Ever since Chen let slip Friday that he would rather not double as head of the DPP, speculation has raged as to how his successor will be chosen.

A proposal to change the party charter to allow Chen to quit the job of party chairman was initiated by DPP lawmaker Ker Chien-ming, who suggested that the DPP's Central Executive Committee should elect one vice chairman to head the party in case the president opts not to double as party chairman.
But the proposal, reportedly to be dictated by Chen, backfired among DPP members, some of whom called for a vote by party members for chairman as provided for in the party charter.

The method of picking a chairman through popular election among its members was changed slightly in 2002 when the DPP party congress decided to let any DPP member who won the presidential election become automatically the party chief.

Some of the DPP members criticized Ker for presenting the proposal before the deadline of June 18 for submitting any motion to be discussed at the July 18 party congress, as no other motion in this regard could be put forward.

DPP lawmaker Tsai Huang-liang expressed reservations about the idea of a popular election for DPP chairman, saying that the party might be split if a chairman elected by the party were to compete with the president for power within the party.
However, he favored Chang Chun-hsiung's views on setting up a party reform panel to study the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CONSENSUS NEEDED FOR FULL OPENING TO MAINLAND TOURISTS

TEXT.P: Full opening of Taiwan to mainland Chinese tourists is an established policy of the government but will need full discussion among related government agencies and cross-Taiwan Strait consensus on handling the matter, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san made the remarks after Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said earlier that he hopes for a full opening to mainland tourists.

The government has allowed mainland people studying abroad and those who have obtained permanent resident status overseas to come to Taiwan since 2002, and further eased the restrictions later that year to allow mainland Chinese living overseas -- including Hong Kong and Macau -- for more than four years and who have work permits, to visit Taiwan, along with their spouses and direct relatives.

Chiu noted that although full opening to mainland tourists is an established policy of the government, implementation of the policy hinges on the wishes of both sides of the Taiwan Strait, as well as the integration of views among the relevant government agencies. When the time is ripe, the MAC will make an announcement, he added.
He said that full opening will create problems with visa overstays and legal disputes and added that both sides must reach consensus on such issues before a full opening.
He also pointed out that unilateral opening without the consent of the mainland authorities will be meaningless and will only bring trouble for Taiwan.
Fu Tung-cheng, director of the MAC's Department of Economic Affairs, said that since the opening to mainland tourists in 2002, an average of 1,000 have been coming to Taiwan per month.
"The opening to mainland Chinese tourists is not for the sake of economic purposes, " Fu claimed, adding that the basic consideration is to "enhance bilateral exchanges and understanding."

DOC.HEADLINE: TRANSPORT MINISTER HOPES FOR FULL OPENING FOR MAINLAND CHINA TOURISTS

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san said Monday that he hopes to see the mainland Chinese authorities allow mainland people full access to visit Taiwan as tourists.

Lin also said that he hopes to hold bilateral talks on the matter with He Guangwei, mainland China's director of National Tourism Administration, at the 2004 Asia Pacific Economic and Cooperation forum Tourism Ministerial meeting in Chile in October.

Noting that President Chen Shui-bian said in his May 20 inaugural speech that cross-Taiwan Strait relations should be stabilized, Lin expressed the hope that the mainland will take advantage of this goodwill by allowing its people to use Taiwan as a tourism destination.
As the issue will involve a number of issues such as legal disputes, Lin also said that both sides must have consultations based on dignity and parity.

He admitted that when he attended a 2002 APEC Tourism Ministerial Meeting in Mexico and proposed the issue to He, Beijing refused to discuss the issue, but he said he will take the chance of the Chile meeting in October to try again.
Lin said he had talked with Joseph Wu, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, about opening Taiwan to mainland tourists, and that Wu also said it is a question that can be discussed.

The government has allowed mainland people studying abroad and those who have obtained permanent resident status overseas to come to Taiwan since 2002, and further eased the restrictions later that year to allow mainland Chinese living overseas -- including Hong Kong and Macau -- for more than four years and who have work permits, to visit Taiwan, along with their spouses and direct relatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPOSAL FOR TAIWAN TO PLAY ROLE AS SERVICE HUB FOR MAINLAND MARKET

TEXT.P: With mainland China's increasing emergence as a vast market and a major driving force of the world's economic growth, Taiwan enjoys an upper hand in serving as the service hub of the mainland market amid the many benefits and challenges, according to local experts.

In the face of a new wave of economic evolution across the globe because of the mainland's simmering economic clout, Taiwan stands a good chance of serving as a service center for the mainland market, on the grounds that more and more foreign and overseas Chinese enterprises are rushing to cash in on the mainland.

The mainland's success in economic reforms over the past 20 years has lured a large number of foreign and overseas Chinese investors to set up strongholds there, they said, adding that the influx of huge amounts of foreign capital has created a need for skilled workers and hi-quality management personnel there.

As the mainland is rapidly transforming into a lucrative market and a manufacturing powerhouse that is indispensable to the rest of the world, Taiwan should grab the opportunity to seek to play a key role by using its own unique advantages in view of the many unanticipated opportunities and challenges, they suggested.

Therefore, creating an outlet and building common ground for the potential Chinese enterprises and hi-tech talent around the world has become a significant issue at a time when the Chinese-speaking population and the mainland market are set to become a symbol in the coming knowledge-based era to be dominated by high technologies, they claimed.

By that rationale, the top task now is how to consolidate the potential, expertise and resources of Chinese people across the globe, they said, adding that successful consolidation would be a turning point in history for all Chinese people.

While the Greater Chinese economy has become the fastest-growing region in the world, Taiwan's strong industrial levels and advanced management know-how, along with its research and development capabilities, have made it suitable to serve as a service hub for the mainland market and a platform for Western companies to break into the market, they analyzed.

Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih said recently that geographically, the mainland is an "old continent," but in terms of technological and economic progress, it is a "new continent" full of possibilities.

He encouraged Taiwan businesses to "go west" in search of greater expansion and called for a global combination of Chinese capital, technology and brainpower to gain a bigger slice of the international market.

Taiwan companies are capable of playing a leadership role for Chinese enterprises around the world and full cooperation of the economies in Greater China will undoubtedly be profitable and invincible, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHER URGES EFFICIENT USE OF RAINWATER

TEXT.P: An Academia Sinica researcher urged the government and private sector Monday to make efficient use of rainwater because draught and flooding will be problems on the island in the future.

Wang Chung-ho, a fellow researcher at Academia Sinica's Institute of Earth Sciences, quoting statistics showing that rainfall in Taiwan last year fell 1,000 millimeters compared with past averages. Although rainfall increased 20 percent in the north and fell 10 percent in the south, the days that it did rain, the precipitation was more abundant than usual, Wang said, adding that the number of rainy days declined significantly.

If this becomes a trend, he said, the nation will be susceptible to increased flooding because current drainage systems are unable to move water efficiently. Also, Wang predicted that the number of days without rain will be larger, increasing the chances of draught.

He said that with decreasing rainfall, people will depend more on ground water, especially in the southwestern and southeastern plains that are home to many crops, where 20 million tons of ground water was pumped out in 2000 alone.

A joint research effort between Wang and other academics found that Taiwan's annual rainfall has averaged 75 billion tons over the last few years, with four billion tons seeping into the water table. However, consumption of ground water in Taiwan ranges from between six billion to seven billion tons per year, making a deficit of two billion or three billion tons.

The research team also found that people living in central and southern coastal areas are already pumping water from 200 to 300 meters underground, where the water has been resting for 50,000 years - the oldest ground water in Taiwan.

Wang suggested that future urban development should focus on the efficient use of rainwater resources, and that public and private buildings should be equipped with a secondary water supply system, using rainwater to clean toilets, floors and to water plants.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEMS MEETING TO OPEN IN HSINCHU

TEXT.P: A two-day meeting on the commercialization of Asia-Pacific micro-electro-mechanical-systems (MEMS) and its market development will open at the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan Thursday.
The meeting will be co-sponsored by ITRI's Materials Research Laboratories, Micro and Nanotechnology Commercialization Education Foundation and a Taiwan engineering association in North America.

Officials from the Materials Research Laboratories noted that MEMS has wide applications, including in consumer electronics, optical and wireless communications, automobile electronics and environmental protection, and is expected to become the core manufacturing technology in the 21st century.

The officials said that to promote related technology of MEMS and the commercialization of the system, the two-day meeting will invite 150 leaders in the area from the United States, and Asian and Pacific countries to share their experiences.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CHEN PRESENTS AWARD OF THANKS TO FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian presented an award of thanks to former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairwoman Therese Shaheen Monday in recognition of her contributions to promoting Taipei-Washington ties during her time as the top AIT officer.

In a ceremony held at the Presidential Office, Chen decorated Shaheen with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon, a special honor offered by the Republic of China government to foreign citizens who have contributed to its national cause.
Chen lauded Shaheen as one of Taiwan's best friends and a beautiful guardian angel of the people of Taiwan.

Noting that Taiwan-U.S. relations are as "sumptuous and delicious" as "tsungtzu" -- glutinous rice dumplings wrapped in bamboo leaves which are eaten as part of the Dragon Boat Festival celebrations, Chen said Shaheen had helped enrich substantive Taiwan-U.S. ties just like "putting tasty ingredients into tsungtzu."

The Dragon Boat Festival, which falls on Tuesday this year, is one of the most important festivals on the Chinese calendar. Dragon boat races are held and tsungtzus are eaten on the day in remembrance of Chu Yuan, a famous scholar-statesman of the Warring States Period (403-222 B.C.)
As Taiwan and the United States do not maintain formal diplomatic ties, Chen said, their relations are "like tsungtzu to be wrapped in bamboo leaves."

"Although we can't see tsungtzus' ingredients from the outside, they are delectable foods. Shaheen's greatest contribution is to feed Taiwan-U.S. ties with rich and delightful elements so that our relations have become even closer and more cordial," Chen explained.
During Shaheen's tenure as the top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, Chen said, Shaheen had offered much assistance to Taiwan.

Chen recalled that during his transit stops in New York and Alaska last year, Shaheen accompanied him throughout his stay. "Shaheen's personal charm, kindness and hospitality had injected vitality and exuberance into traditional Taiwan-U.S. interaction," he added.

Shaheen resigned from the AIT chairmanship in April. "Although Shaheen has left public service, I'm convinced that she'll continue to be active in the U.S. political and business arenas. I hope she will continue to use her clout to speak for Taiwan's cause of safeguarding its liberal democracy and to help Taiwan win more support and assistance from various U.S. social quarters," Chen said.

For her part, Shaheen said she had learned a lot during her AIT stint. One of the things was that she came to learn that Taiwan has "good shepherds, " Shaheen said, adding she believes that good shepherds will lead the herd toward the right direction.

Shaheen further said Taiwan people's courage has inspired her to have even greater courage. In her view, she said, it's a special gift to be able to inspire other people. The people of Taiwan have this gift, she added. If the world were an oyster, she said, Taiwan would be its most brilliant pearl.

Shaheen arrived in Taipei Saturday for a four-day private visit. She has met with several senior ROC officials. On Monday morning, she paid a courtesy call on Minister of National Defense Lee Jye. As the ROC Cabinet has approved a NT$610 billion budget for purchasing advanced weapons from the United States, some opposition lawmakers claimed that Shaheen's current Taipei visit might be related to Taiwan's arms procurement plan. However, Lee said his half-hour meeting with Shaheen didn't touch on any arms procurement issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES END LOWER ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) fell 12.75 points Monday, with the weighted index -- the market's key barometer -- closing at 5,556.54 points.
The market opened at the day's high of 5,666.61 points and hit a low of 5,542.36 points.
All eight major categories lost ground, with construction company shares posting the largest decrease of 1.9 percent. Losers outnumbered advancers 537 to 204, while 202 remained unchanged.
A total of 2.55 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$52.67 billion (US$1.58 billion).

Market analysts attributed the drop to an eroded investor confidence prevailing in the market, despite the announcement made by Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) over the weekend that it will increase the inclusion weight of the MSCI Taiwan Index from 75 percent in late November to 100 percent in May 2005.

The MSCI incentive failed to lift the market and the weighted index is very likely to decline to the level of around 5,450 points in the short term, they said, adding that the domestic bourse will regain momentum when international factors surrounding rising oil prices and possible U. S. interest hikes are all cleared up.
They forecast that the MSCI move will have a positive impact on the domestic market in November, when as much as NT$670 billion worth of capital are estimated to be channeled in.
The domestic bourse is more likely to show signs of rebound at the end of the third quarter.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHAHEEN IS A GOOD FRIEND OF TAIWAN: DPP

TEXT.P: Therese Shaheen, a former chairwoman of the American Institute in Taiwan, is a good friend of the Republic of China and she should not be a source of political bickering in Taiwan, a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislative leader said Monday.

Tsai Huang-liang, a ruling DPP party whip at the Legislative Yuan, discounted opposition allegations that Shaheen, who arrived in Taipei Saturday for a four-day private visit, is in Taiwan for talks on U.S. arms sales to the island.
Tsai called for the opposition not to extend domestic political struggles among parties to the development of U.S.-Taiwan relations.

He urged the opposition not to besmirch Shaheen as an arms broker, saying that no one would be Taiwan's friend if an American citizen were groundlessly labeled as an arms broker simply because she or he makes efforts to help improve Taiwan-U.S. ties.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the opposition Kuomintang caucus at the Legislative Yuan ridiculed Presidential Chen Shui-bian's decoration of Shaheen with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon Monday "in recognition of her contributions to promoting Taiwan-U.S. ties during her time with AIT, " as an abuse of the right of the head of state since Shaheen was forced to step down from her post because of her alleged role as brokering arms deals between Taiwan and the United States.
Huang Teh-fu said the DPP administration is bringing shame on itself if Shaheen was decorated this time because of her "true" role in arms sales.
The opposition People First Party's next legislative whip, Liu Wen-hsiung, argued that Shaheen is by no means an architect of bilateral Taiwan-U.S. cooperation.

Shaheen's stepping down reflects the fact that the U.S. administration was not satisfied with her performance, Liu said, adding that President Chen's decoration of Shaheen is tantamount to a slap in the face to the Bush Administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIORS MINISTRY TO OPEN HOTLINE FOR ABUSED MEN

TEXT.P: A hotline for abused men will open Wednesday for them to seek help when battered by family members, the Ministry of the Interior, who is sponsoring the service, said Monday.

Interior ministry officials said that although an average of 10 women died from domestic violence each month in the first five months of this year, according to the Modern Women's Foundation, men, children and the elderly have also suffered from domestic violence. However, this group has no support services for abuse.

A study of social news stories conducted by the Modern Women's Foundation -- a private foundation dedicated to promoting women's rights and wellbeing -- showed that between January and May, 56 women died from domestic violence and 46 others were either seriously or slightly injured.

According to interior ministry statistics, each of the domestic violence prevention and help centers around the island receives an average of 3,008 calls for help per month, indicating that about 3,000 families in Taiwan are under the threat of violence each month.
Although 80 percent of those seeking help were women, many men, children and elderly are constantly subjected to physical or mental abuse by members of their family, interior ministry officials said.

Meanwhile, the Taipei Municipal Police Department reported last Saturday that five years after the domestic violence law was put into practice, the number of men, children and elderly being abused has increased.

In Taipei City alone, according to the police department, those who were abused by immediate family members have also increased over the years -- 306 cases, or 9.4 percent of the total abuse case in 2003, up from 44 cases (3.8 percent) in 1999.

The ratio of male victims also rose to 274 (12.5 percent of both sexes) in 2003 from only 10 (2.9 percent) in 1999, showing that male victims, instead of feeling ashamed, have come out bravely to ask for assistance after being abused by women.
The abuse targeting the elderly over 60 has also increased yearly, setting a record high of 157 cases last year from the 47 cases in 1999.
Police have handled nine abuse cases toward children in the first five months of this year, and most came at the hands of their parents or babysitter. Two have died.
Interior ministry officials said that men who need professional counseling should call 0800-013-999.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, RUSSIA SIGN WATER RESOURCE TECHNOLOGY COOPERATION MEMORANDUM

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Russia have forged a cooperative memorandum on water resources management and related technological exchanges, the Water Resources Agency (WRA) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs reported Monday.

Officials and specialists from Taiwan and Russia gathered in late May for the 1st Taiwan-Russia Water Resources Conference to exchange views on and experiences in hydrology, fresh water resources management and related technologies, WRA officials said.

The participants signed a cooperative memorandum upon the conclusion of the conference that Taiwan and Russia will engage in bilateral exchanges in water resources management and related technological fields on a regular basis in the future, the WRA officials said.

The two sides also agreed that scholars and specialists in the fields will swap visits to each other's countries to boost bilateral cooperation, beginning with a visit to Taiwan by Russian delegates to attend an international water-related technology exposition slated to open in Taiwan Sept. 3, according to the WRA.

In addition to taking part in the water conference, the 12-member Taiwan delegation -- led by WRA Director-General Chen Shen-hsien and made up of WRA officials, academics from universities and representatives from the private industrial sector -- also attended an international hydrology exposition -- ECWATECH-2004, the 6th International Trade Fair and Congress Water: Ecology and Technology -- held in Moscow in early June.

According to the WRA officials, although Russia is no longer a "superpower, " the nation's expertise and research in water and ocean resources are renowned worldwide. The Russian "water" researchers have also long been keenly interested in Taiwan's research in the same field, particularly in deep-ocean research and industrial waste water recycling research.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 21, or the fourth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: The US Constitution comes into effect.
1900: Battles rage in both Beijing and Tientsin after Empress Dowager Tzuhsi of the Ching court declares war on Great Britain, Germany, Russia, France, the United States, Japan, Italy and Austria.
1905: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French philosopher, novelist, dramatist and critic who propounded the philosophy of existentialism, is born.
1908: Russian composer Nikolai Rimski-Korsakov dies at home in St. Petersburg at the age of 64. He was best known for his orchestral piece "Scheherazade" and the opera "The Golden Cockerel."
1919: Twenty-seven vessels of the German fleet interned at Scapa Flow in Scotland's Orkney Islands are scuttled by their crews.
1931: Chiang Kai-shek leaves for Nanchang, Kiangsi province, to assume command of a campaign to suppress communists.
1942: Troops of Germany's General Rommel take 25,000 Allied prisoners at Tobruk on the Libyan coast.
1946: Chiang Kai-shek extends a 15-day cease-fire order to June 30. He had accepted on June 6 General Marshall's proposal to issue a second cease-fire order, instructing government troops to halt "all advances, attacks, and pursuits" during the 15-day armistice.
1970: Sukarno, founder and former president of the Republic of Indonesia, dies at the age of 69.
1976: A 36-member Republic of China delegation to the 22nd Asian Film Festival returns to Taipei from South Korea after winning nine awards.
1979: Premier Sun Yun-suan calls on free nations to assume moral responsibility for Indo-Chinese and mainland Chinese refugees and to take effective action immediately.
1981: Francois Mitterrand's socialists gain a landslide victory in the second ballot in general elections in France.
1982: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo calls on the nation's agricultural experts to work out concrete measures to expand agricultural development in the country.
1984: ROC Premier Yu Kuo-hwa orders an investigation into the cause of the Haishan coal mine disaster.
1990: A strong earthquake rocks northwestern Iran, killing some 25,000 people and injuring tens of thousands of others.
1990: The ROC Council of Grand Justices announces that senior parliamentarians should terminate their responsibilities by Dec. 31, 1991.
1992: Li Xiennien, former president of mainland China, dies of illness in Beijing at the age of 83.
1993: An ROC-US agreement for technical cooperation in the field of environmental protection is signed in Washington, D.C.
1996: Leaders of the European Union reach a deal to end the mad cow crisis with Britain.
1997: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, is invited by the mainland's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to attend the ceremony marking the transfer of Hong Kong's sovereignty to mainland China at midnight on June 30.
1999: The ROC formally joins the International Council for Small Business (ICSB), becoming the 11th chapter of the world trade body.
1999: ROC President Lee Teng-hui describes US$300 million-worth of aid pledged to Kosovar refugees as "the chance of a thousand years," and urges the public to have empathy as well as a broader mindset.
2000: US Representative Benjamin A. Gilman (R-NY), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, submits Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural address for insertion in the congressional record.
2001: New Republic of China representatives to Russia and Germany, Charles King and Hu Wei-chen, respectively, are sworn in in Taipei and both men promise to further strengthen the nation's ties with the two countries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man after 40 is an object of dislike to men, he will continue to be so to the end of his days."

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER PRESENTS SEASONAL FRUITS TO MOFA STAFF

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen has presented seasonal foods to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) staff to mark the Dragon Boat Festival which fell on Tuesday this year.

MOFA officials said Chen had directed his aides to prepare the gifts for MOFA staff before he left for the United States early last week to attend several international seminars organized by noted U.S. think tanks.

The gifts included "tsungtzu," a glutinous rice dumpling wrapped in bamboo leaves which is traditionally eaten on Dragon Boat Festival, as well as mangoes and a special brand of noodles from Chen's hometown in the southern county of Tainan, the officials said.

Chen had met with American think tank scholars during his stay in Los Angeles. He then traveled to Beaver Creek, Colorado where he attended the World Forum, an annual international conference organized by the noted U.S. think tank American Enterprise Institute.
Chen is also scheduled to travel to Europe in July to chair a meeting of the chiefs of Taiwan's missions in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT PLANS TO TURN CHUNGHSING NEW VILLAGE INTO ARTS CENTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Government Chairman Lin Kuang-hua said Tuesday he will come up with a detailed plan to transform Chunghsing New Village in the central Taiwan county of Nantou into a high-profile arts village.

Chunghsing New Village used to be the seat of the Taiwan Provincial Government. With the marginalization of the provincial government a few years ago as part of the island's government restructuring plan, many public dormitories in the complex have been left vacant.
Lin said he plans to transform those buildings into workshops to attract noted local artists, thus making Chunghing New Village into Taiwan's new arts center.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRITISH STUDY SHOWS SMOKERS LIVE 10 YEARS SHORTER

TEXT.P: People with persistent smoking habits live 10 years shorter than non-smokers, according to a British study that has taken 50 years to complete.
Oxford University professor Richard Doll had planned only a five-year project, but later carried on for five decades.

His research studied 34,439 British doctors born between 1900 and 1930. Each was asked about his smoking habits at the start of the study in 1951. They were contacted periodically over the next 50 years to see if their habits had changed. Information was gathered on those who died during the period.

Early findings of the study confirmed a link between smoking and lung cancer, as well suggestions that smoking caused heart disease. Subsequent research showed smoking is linked to another 25 illnesses.

The study also showed that among men who became persistent heavy smokers, about two-thirds died from their habit. These men went into the British Army during the Second World War and acquired the smoking habit from the age of 18. On average, they smoked 18 cigarettes a day.

Doll, 91, said, "It is clear that consistent cigarette smoking doubles mortality throughout the adult life -- middle and old age. It is also clear that giving up smoking can eliminate a very large part of the hazard."
He disclosed that the British government was opposed to making the early findings public because it would "frighten people."

The latest report advised smokers to kick their habit as early as possible. Quitting at 30, smokers can avoid nearly all the risk of dying early, and even quitting at 50, they can still halve the risk.
The findings of the study are published in the British Medical Journal.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIE TO BE CAST ON PLAN FOR SUHUA FREEWAY: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will decide by the end of this month whether to continue with the plan for a freeway linking Suao and Hualien in eastern Taiwan, Cheng Wen-lon, director-general of the Taiwan Area National Expressway Engineering Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said Tuesday.

Noting that the plan for the Suhua Freeway is currently up in the air because of protests by environmentalists, Cheng said a 1998 environmental impact assessment gave the project a green light. Its design meets environmental protection standards stipulated by law, he said.

The current highways linking Hualien to other destinations cannot be effectively widened because of the fragile geological conditions that make the area susceptible to landslides during typhoons and torrential rains.

Furthermore, Cheng said, large trucks, which account for over 30 percent of the traffic using the highways, make the narrow roads a sometimes harrowing experience for passenger cars, making the need for a new freeway all the clearer.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications began a feasibility study on the 86.5-kilometer freeway between Suao and Hualien in 1994 but stopped it in 1998 because of protests from environmental groups that were asking for things that were beyond the legal scope of environmental protection, Cheng said.

The plan was revived in May, 2002 by the Executive Yuan as one of the public works constituting the 2008 national development projects, and was listed as one of the country's 10 major projects the following year.

Cheng said the project is beneficial to eastern Taiwan economically, free of difficulties technically and desired by many people in eastern Taiwan. The only question is whether it can win over the environmentalists, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN RELEASED FROM HOSPITAL AFTER EXTENSIVE FACIAL SURGERIES

TEXT.P: The Indonesian boy staying in Tzu Chi Hospital in eastern Hualien to have a large tumor removed that was covering his face and neck was released from the hospital Tuesday after recovering well from a series of craniofacial surgeries.

The five-year-old boy, named Novendry, came to Taiwan in early March from Indonesia's western island of Padang with the assistance of a group of volunteers from the Taiwan-based Buddhist Compassionate Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, who met Novendry when they traveled to the island to offer free medical services.

Novendry, who has suffered from Von Recklinghausen's disease since he was one year old, was almost blinded in his right eye by the pressure caused by the facial tumor. With his thick facial skin and lips, and protruding teeth, the boy had been cruelly dubbed "hippo boy" by ignorant Indonesian villagers.
Von Recklinghausen's disease is a genetic disorder of the nervous system that causes tumors.
Officials of Tzu Chi Hospital said that Novendry's facial tumor was removed and his face restructured after receiving a series of surgeries over the past three-and-a-half months.

Novendry has been becoming more open and active after his face was restructured to one similar to that of a normal person, they said, recounting that the boy was very timid before being admitted to the hospital.
The boy even performed a dance at a farewell party hosted by medical personnel of the hospital in celebration of his recovery, they added.
He is scheduled to depart for home in a few days, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HACKERS POST DOCTORED PICS ON DPP WEB SITE

TEXT.P: No, that wasn't Vice President Annette Lu bare-breasted and wearing a kimono facing a similarly clad, mustached President Chen Shui-bian on the party Web site Monday night, chagrined officials say.

Visitors to the ruling Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Web site Monday night were surprised to see the picture but party officials say the doctored photograph was the work of mainland Chinese hackers and the site is now back to normal.
The hackers also inserted simplified Chinese characters used in mainland China on the DPP homepage.
It was the latest in a string of intrusions by mainland hackers into the Web site since last week, a party official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER CALLS FOR COMPLETELY OPEN TOURIST EXCHANGES ACROSS STRAIT

TEXT.P: Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san urged Beijing Tuesday to allow anyone in mainland China who wishes to sight-see in Taiwan to come, and he made it clear that Taiwan is willing to open its doors to all visitors.
Lin repeated the call while answering questions from reporters at a ribbon-cutting ceremony marking the opening by China Airlines (CAL) of its Taipei-Seattle-Houston route.
According to Lin, such a two-way opening would help Taiwan and mainland China increase contacts and mutual understanding, helping to boost security and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

The free flow of tourists from each side would make it much easier for people from mainland China to visit Taiwan, he noted, adding that for the time being, mainland Chinese tourists are allowed in via a third country or area excluding Hong Kong and Macau or those with a residence permit overseas.
While Taiwan is willing to brace itself for mainland Chinese tourists, the mainland should also include Taiwan on its travel suggestion list, he suggested.

He issued a reminder that President Chen Shui-bian also appealed for greater cross-strait exchanges and stability in his May 20 second inaugural address, and added that welcoming tourists from either side would be a good way to achieve this aim.

He further proposed two-way government-to-government negotiations on the matter based on the principles of equality and reciprocity, and pointed out that such talks should be led by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- the highest government agency in policy-planning toward mainland China -- on the Taiwan side.
MAC Chairman Joseph Wu has a full understanding of the standing of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications in this regard, he added.
The minister later headed for Houston on board the new CAL flight.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-SOUTH KOREA TOURISM MEETING OPENS IN HUALIEN

TEXT.P: Tourism Bureau Director Su Cheng-tien said Tuesday he hopes the number of tourists from south Korea can be increased substantially in three years.
Su made the remarks at the opening of the 19th conference on Taiwan-South Korean tourist exchanges held in the eastern county of Hualien.

Su said South Korean citizens made about 60,000 visits to Taiwan in the first five months of this year, compared to more than 100,000 visits made by Taiwan citizens to South Korea during the same period.
"We'll make every possible effort to attract more tourist arrivals from South Korea in the coming years," Su said.
The annual meeting brought together scores of travel service operators from the two countries to discuss measures to boost bilateral tourist exchanges.
During the meeting, tourist service operators expressed their hope that direct air links between the two countries can resume as early as possible to facilitate tourist exchanges.

Direct Taiwan-South Korean air links have been suspended since 1992 when Seoul switched diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing. Due to South Korea's reluctance to recognize Taiwan's national status for fear of offending Beijing, the two sides have been unable to strike a deal on resuming direct flight services.

At the moment, the two governments have allowed direct chartered flights between selected tourist cities on a reciprocal basis. Participants to the meeting said they hope the number of chartered flights can be further expanded if direct air links cannot be resumed soon.
Speaking on the occasion, Hualien Deputy Magistrate Chu Ching-peng said the county government is constructing an international youth education center which will be inaugurated next September.

"We hope young South Korean people can travel to Hualien to attend the new center's various educational workshops to get a taste of Taiwan's lifestyle, culture and social customs," Chu said, adding that the center will provide a convenient platform for bilateral cultural and civilian exchanges.
Chu also took advantage of the meeting to introduce the rich tourist resources in Hualien County, which has traditionally been one of Taiwan's major tourist industry destinations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AIT CHAIRWOMAN CONCLUDES VISIT TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Former American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) chairwoman Therese Shaheen departed for home Tuesday after concluding a four-day visit in Taiwan.
Shaheen did not make a statement prior to her departure but described her visit as "super."

At the invitation of the Republic of China government, the former top U.S. liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between Washington and Taipei arrived in Taiwan last Saturday.
During her stay, Shaheen was decorated by President Chen Shui-bian with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon in recognition of her contributions to the promotion of Taiwan-U.S. relations.

Shaheen also met with Vice President Annette Lu, Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and officials of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs during her visit.
The ROC government invited Shaheen to attend President Chen's May 20 inauguration for a second four-year term, but due to her tight schedule, she postponed her visit until last Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARTIES JOCKEYING FOR POSITION FOR EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: The legislative caucuses of major political parties are at loggerheads over whether to hold one or two extra legislative sessions during the summer, the timing of the sessions and just what might be included on the docket for consideration, party sources said Tuesday.

The legislative caucus of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) agreed with the Cabinet Monday that the Legislative Yuan should hold an extraordinary session in late July to deal with a long-stalled constitutional amendment bill that will pave the way for much-anticipated legislative reforms as well as a special budget bill for 10 new major construction projects and several bills regarding crime-fighting operations aimed at improving public order.

However, Kuomintang (KMT) legislative whip Liao Feng-teh said the KMT and its ally, the People First Party (PFP), will push to hold two extra legislative sessions -- one in mid-July and the other in mid-August.

"The 'pan-blue alliance' of the KMT and the PFP, which jointly controls a majority in the legislature, hopes that the legislature holds an extra session on July 19 to screen the constitutional amendment bill," Liao said.

According to the legislature's existing operational rules, the four-month consultation period for the constitutional amendment bill will expire on July 19. As a result, a vote can be held on that day to determine the bill's fate. The "pan-blue alliance" wants to convene the extra session on the last possible day of discussions to forestall any further debates on the bill, which they have tailored to their own predisposition.

Moreover, Liao said, the "pan-blue alliance" will demand that another extra session be convened in mid-August to address the alliance-initiated proposals that a special committee be formed to investigate the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu and that a special committee be set up to scrutinize official files regarding the activation of the so-called national security mechanism in the wake of the shooting.
The four-month consultation period for those two bills will expire on Aug. 12.
"We hope an extra legislative session can be held in mid-August to decide on the fate of these two bills by a vote," Liao said.

In a bit of horse-trading, if the "pan-blue alliance"-proposed extra legislative sessions are held, Liao said the alliance will not oppose discussing the 10 major construction projects budget bill and crime-fighting bills that the DPP is intent on passing.

Asked about his views on Liao's remarks, DPP legislative whip Tsai Huang-lang said he hopes Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng will call a meeting of representatives of various legislative caucuses to work out the date or dates and the agendas for planned extra legislative session or sessions.

Wang, a KMT vice chairman, is currently heading a cross-party legislative delegation on a visit to the United States to discuss Taiwan's new arms procurement projects. He is expected to begin consulting with various party caucuses on extra session issues after his return next week.
However, the legislative caucus of the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), which controls 12 seats in the legislature, said it is opposed to holding any extra legislative session this summer.

The pro-independence party said it prefers to push for the formulation of a new constitution that caters to Taiwan's present needs instead of discussing various versions of constitutional amendments to prop up the framework.

"Since the existing Constitution requires a massive overhaul to suit Taiwan's present status quo and needs, we had better write a new one. Writing a new constitution requires a longer period of time to prepare and discuss. This topic cannot be addressed in an extra legislative session, " said TSU legislative whip Chen Chien-ming.
