DOC.HEADLINE: REBOUNDING ECONOMY HELPS BANKS IMPROVE OVERDUE LOAN RATIOS

TEXT.P: Helped by a recovering domestic economy, Taiwan-based banks have improved their performance by lowering their overdue loan ratios in the first quarter of this year, according to the latest statistics made public by Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC).

Taiwan-headquartered banks posted an average overdue loan ratio of 4.4 percent for the first three months of this year and have managed greater pre-tax net profits and attracted larger amounts of deposits and released more loans, the CBC statistics showed.

Some banks in charge of special designations have outperformed general commercial banks, the same tallies pointed out. For instance, the Export-Import Bank registered the lowest overdue loan ratio of 0.37 percent for the same three-month period, while the China Development Industrial Bank's ratio was 1.66 percent.

At the same time, privately-run banks performed better than state-controlled ones. E. Sun Bank and Taishin International Bank recorded overdue loan ratios of 1.42 percent and 1.5 percent, respectively, followed by Sinopac Bank with 1.69 percent and Chinatrust Commercial Bank with 2.29 percent.
Although public banks lag privately-run banks in slashing their overdue loan ratios, most of them still meet the target of being below 5 percent set by the government.

The Bank of Taiwan posed 2.98 percent, while the First Commercial Bank and Hua Nan Commercial Bank registered 2.44 percent and 3.58 percent, respectively. Medium Business Bank of Taiwan and Land Bank of Taiwan had a higher ratio of 10.35 percent and 5.92 percent.
Meanwhile, Q1 bank deposits grew by 9.72 percent as a whole over the year-earlier level, while the combined amount of released loans increased by 8.22 percent year-on-year, the tallies indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILAN SEEKING HOST FAMILIES FOR INTERNATIONAL FOLK FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: The government of Ilan County in eastern Taiwan is seeking host families in Ilan to help accommodate children who will be participating in the 2004 Ilan International Children' Folklore and Folk Games Festival from July 3 to Aug.3.

The host families program, launched for the first time this year, is aimed at expanding local people's involvement in the festival and to give foreign delegations a valuable chance to experience local people's culture and daily life.

In addition to taking care of the foreign teams put into their charge, the host families should take these teams to and from the airport, escort them on their visits to other teams and show them the local sights, according to the organizers.

The annual event, which features the performance of folk songs and folk dances by children from different countries, will take place at the Tongshan River Park in Ilan. The organizers of the festival said six countries have already agreed to send delegations to the one-month festival, including Russia, Portugal, Ivory Coast, Australia, New Zealand and Mexico.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN KEEN ON ATTRACTING MAINLAND TOURISTS

TEXT.P: The Kinmen County authorities are keen on luring mainland tourists from Xiamen to visit Kinmen via the "three mini links" and are hoping for a full two-way opening of tourists to strike a balance between the two sides.

Since the set-up of the so-called "three mini links" in Jan. 2001 -- direct transport and trade links between Taiwan-held Kinmen and Matsu islands and Xiamen and Fuzhou ports in mainland China's Fujian province -- Kinmen tourists have paid over 100,000 visits to Xiamen via the links, but only a few thousands of Xiamen people have done so, according to Kinmen Tourist Association Chairman Chen Ching-bao.

Kinmen tourists have spent so far more than NT$4 billion (US$118.5 million) in the mainland, creating a huge gap in capital outflight, Chen said. He proposed that the central governments on both sides make it so that general mainland tourists can visit the offshore island.
Chen made the remarks at a seminar held last week on Kinmen to boost Xiamen tourist arrivals to Kinmen.

Kinmen Deputy Magistrate Yang Chung-chuan presided over the meeting, in which members of a tourism promotion group from Xiamen exchanged opinions with Kinmen representatives from the county government, the tourism sector and the "three mini links" execution authorities.
According to Chen Chao-chin, head of the Tourism Bureau under the Kinmen County Government, Xiamen hopes very much to be a transshipment center in cross-Taiwan Strait tourist exchanges.

But the current situation presents a very serious tilt toward the mainland side, and it is necessary for the mainland authorities to allow mainland people to make pleasure trips to Taiwan, he said, adding that if mainland China makes the move to do this, it will provide Kinmen with a boost in its efforts to ask the central government in Taipei to open further the "three mini links."

Yang said this would give a significant boost to Kinmen's economic development if even just 10 percent of the more than 13.4 million mainland tourists who travel to Xiamen each year could extend their trips to Kinmen.

Deputy Xiamen Mayor Ye Zhonggen, who headed the delegation, said that he feels strongly that the great importance attached by the Kinmen government and the private sector to the issue lays a sound foundation for wider tourist exchanges between both sides.
For the time being, Taiwan only allows mainland Chinese tourists to visit Taiwan via a third country or area excluding Hong Kong or Macau or those with a residence permit in a third country or area.

Since the limited opening in Jan. 2001 along with the inception of the "three mini links, " only about 25,000 mainland Chinese tourists have come to Taiwan, a stark contrast to an average of at least three million Taiwan tourist arrivals to mainland China per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC IS MOST COVETED COMPANY TO WORK FOR BY SCI-TECH MAJORS: POLL

TEXT.P: New job-seekers in the fields of science or technology consider Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) to be the most coveted company in Taiwan to work for, results of a new opinion poll showed Tuesday.

The poll, conducted by 104 Job Bank, one of the major job placement service centers in Taiwan, found that TSMC, Chi Mei Optoelectronics and AU Optronics, are the top three Taiwan companies, in that order, that the new job-seekers are most interested in working for. The top 10 companies are among more than 240 listed and OTC companies in high-technology industries in Taiwan that were possible choices for respondents. Those following the top three were Hon Hai, MediaTek, Asustek Computer, United Microelectronics, Benq, IBM and Acer in that order, according to the 104 poll.
The 104 Job Bank poll conducted the survey by e-mail May 21-24 by contacting more than 10,000 people who are in high-tech fields, including job market "freshmen."
The job bank received 4,116 valid responses for the poll, which had a margin of error of 2.5 percent.

According to the poll, "obtaining an opportunity to learn higher-level knowledge and skills" tops all reasons behind the high-tech job seekers' motivation to work with a high-tech company or to join a new company.

Other reasons for the high-tech job-hunters to seek to join a new company is to "put into practice what was learned in school and to realize personal ideals, " followed by "good prospects for career development," "better pay," and "global perspectives," in that order, the poll found.
Meanwhile, the poll also found that nearly 60 percent of the current high-tech professionals in Taiwan are interested in having an opportunity to work in mainland China.
Men who are high-tech professionals born in the 1950s and who have worked at the middle-levels or higher were found to be most interested in working in mainland China.

The poll also found that the recent spate of political suppressions that Beijing has launched against Taiwan businesses that maintain operations in mainland China has had little impact on the mentality of Taiwan's high-tech professionals. They are still interested in heading toward the mainland, chief 104 pollster Chiu Wen-jen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES INAUGURATES TAIPEI-SEATTLE-HOUSTON ROUTE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest carrier, China Airlines (CAL) , will start flying a new Taipei-Seattle-Houston route from Thursday, June 22, CAL sources said.

The first segment of the new route, which connects Taipei and the U.S. northwestern city of Seattle before carrying on to the southeastern city of Houston, is scheduled to depart Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at 4:15 p.m. Thursday.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san will join Douglas Paal -- director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, the United States' top liaison official in Taiwan -- and CAL officials in a ceremony Tuesday afternoon to mark the inauguration of the new route.
Minister Lin, who will also take the flight to Houston, said the opening of the new route will help enhance economic ties between Taiwan and the United States.

This is the first new route to the United States by CAL in the last 21 years, according to a CAL public relations spokesman. All current CAL U.S.-bound routes, including those to Guam, Honolulu, Los Angeles, San Francisco, New York and Anchorage were opened 21 years ago, the spokesman said.
The last new route to the United States by a Taiwan carrier was a Taipei-Seattle route opened by EVA Airways in 1993.
According to CAL Chairman Lee Yun-ning, with the activation of the Taipei-Seattle-Houston route, the number of CAL's destinations in the United States now stands at eight.
Counting four other points -- Atlanta, Cincinnati, Dallas and Salt Lake City -- that CAL operates jointly with Delta Airlines, CAL now flies to 12 U.S. cities, Lee said.

The new Taipei-Seattle-Houston flights will regularly depart from Taipei at 4: 15 p.m. every Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday, while the return flights will depart from Houston at 10: 45 p.m. every Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday. All flights will make stopovers in Seattle, according to the CAL spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU INSTRUCTOR DROWNED AT FULUNG BEACH TRYING TO RESCUE STUDENTS

TEXT.P: A National Taiwan University (NTU) instructor drowned Tuesday in waters off Fulung Beach in northern Taiwan, a spokesman for the Northeast Coast National Scenic Area Administration (NCNSAA) under the Tourism Bureau said.
Shih Shun-cheng, 41, showed no signs of life when he was rushed to Keelung Chang Gung Memorial Hospital. Although doctors administered emergency treatment on Shih, they were unable to save him.

Shih, an instructor at the NTU's Department of Theater, led 21 other faculty members and students from the department to Fulung Beach in Taipei County's Kungliao township Monday for an overnight camping vacation to mark the Dragon Boat Festival.

Several students got up early in the morning Tuesday and swam near the shore. Two of them were swept away by high waves. Learning of the situation, Shih jumped into the water trying to rescue the students. When rescue workers from the fire department picked up Shih from the water, the NCNSAA spokesman said, he had already stopped breathing.

A total of six students were swept out to sea by rough waves, but they were all rescued. They were discharged from the hospital after receiving treatment. But they all broke down in tears after learning of the death of their teacher.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAPTION 22-02

TEXT.P: KINMEN WATER RUSHED TO TAIWAN FOR TESTING

Kinmen Water Co. chemist Tsai Yuan-ming (right) brings water samples and mouse killer chemical dumped in a river in Kinmen's catchment area to Taiwan Tuesday for testing to make sure running water in the outlying island is safe for use.
CNA Photo, June 22, 2004

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPECTED CONTAMINATED KINMEN WATER RUSHED TO TAIWAN FOR TESTING
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, June 22 (CNA) (By K.Y. Ni and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Six water samples from Kinmen River which supplies water to residents on the outlying island were rushed to Taiwan for testing to determine whether the water have been contaminated, Kinmen Water Co. (KWC) officials said Tuesday.

The water samples were taken from the upstream catchment area of Kuangchien Creek after a Kinmen resident on Monday afternoon discovered bags and bags of "Fumieshu" -- an organofluorine compound used by farmers to kill mice -- dumped in the water in the area. He then notified KWC authorities who determined that a total of 87 bags of "Fumieshu" had been dumped, including two 5-kg bags and 85 smaller bags.

The water samples, together with several kilograms of the dumped mouse killer chemical, were then transported by KWC chemist Tsai Yuan-ming first thing Tuesday morning to a Taipei laboratory under the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) for testing.

EPA authorities said Tuesday that the lab is ready to carry out the testing as soon as the samples are received, even though Tuesday is a holiday. They added that the results of the chemical analysis on the samples are expected to be made public Wednesday at the earliest.
Meanwhile, KWC officials said that after preliminary checks, the water company believes that the water in the reservoir located in the downstream area of Kuangchien Creek has not been contaminated.

Pointing to the facts that the dumped mouse killer chemical is past its expiration date, that it is insoluble in water, and that it has not yet reached the reservoir area due to the dry season, the KWC officials said the water supplied by the Kuangchien Creek Reservoir is safe for use.

Although it has been preliminarily determined that the dumped chemical has not contaminated the reservoir's water, the KWC officials have still decided to clean up the upstream area to allay the concerns of Kinmen residents.

The officials said the suspected contaminated section of the creek will be blocked off and the water drawn out and into the sewer system. The cleanup job by some 10 workers is expected to start at around noon Tuesday, they added.

In response to the latest incident, officials from the Taiwan Water Co., which oversees the KWC, said Tuesday that safety and security work at reservoirs, related facilities, and catchment areas will be tightened up nationwide to ensure a safe water supply.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 22, or the fifth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1757: George Vancouver, the British explorer after whom Canada's Vancouver Island and Vancouver are named, is born.
1893: Thomas Francis Bayard presents his credentials as U.S. ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary to Great Britain, becoming the first actual American ambassador after more than a century of ministers carrying out diplomatic representation.
1906: U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt sues John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil Company for operating a monopoly.
1910: Paul Ehrlich, the German bacteriologist and immunologist who won the 1908 Nobel Prize for physiology with Elie Metchnikov, announces he has discovered the definitive cure for syphilis.
1933: German Chancellor Adolf Hitler outlaws both the Communist Party and the National Peoples Party, permitting only one political party -- the National Socialist German Workers Party or Nazi Party -- thus beginning a Nazi dictatorship.
1937: Joe Louis becomes the heavyweight boxing champion of the world. He holds the title for nearly 12 years until his retirement in March 1943. The powerful American fighter successfully defended the title for a record 25 fights.
1940: The French formally surrender to Germany when Gen. Charles Huntziger of France signs terms of surrender with Germany at Compiegne, in the same railroad car in which Gen. Foch had received the German surrender in 1918.
1941: Germany invades the Soviet Union, commencing Adolf Hitler's "Operation Barbarossa."
1941: Italy and Romania declare war on the Soviet Union.
1947: Outer Mongolian troops, aided by planes bearing Soviet insignia, renew attacks on Chinese troops at Peitashan in eastern Sinkiang Province.
1956: Republic of China Air Force jet fighters shoot down four Chinese communist MiG-17s and damage two others over Matsu, an ROC-controlled island in the Taiwan Strait.
1965: Japan and South Korea sign a treaty in Tokyo establishing diplomatic relations.
1977: Gen. Hu Lien, former deputy commander-in-chief of the ROC Army and ROC ambassador to South Vietnam, dies of a heart attack at the age of 71.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs into law the "Taiwan Relations Act" in order to resume arms sales to the ROC following the break of diplomatic ties.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Prime Minister Ezekiel Alebua of the Solomon Islands.
1987: Fred Astaire, one of America' best-loved entertainers, dies at the age of 88. He co-starred with Ginger Rogers, Judy Garland, Lesley Caron and Audrey Hepburn in musicals including "Top Hat" and "Shall We Dance?"
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the revision of the Law on Negotiable Instruments, retroactively abolishing criminal penalties for over 30,000 people convicted of issuing bad checks before January 1987.
1989: Seven students involved in the Tiananmen Square protests in Beijing are executed after televised "show trials."
1991: The ROC gains admission to the Central American Development Bank.
1995: British Prime Minister John Major resigns as head of the ruling Conservative Party in order to conduct a party leadership election.
1999: The second Asia-Pacific technology conference opens in Taipei with over 100 fund managers from around the world gathering to discuss developments in the region's high-tech industry with the heads of high-tech companies from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, South Korea and Thailand.
1999: The Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission releases a draft of the ROC's first white paper on maritime policy to stress ROC sovereignty over the disputed Spratly and Tiaoyutai islands.
2000: Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group has recently begun participating in the "Oxygen Alliance" project led by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in the U.S. The alliance is a five-year project aimed at making computers more widespread and less physically intrusive.
2001: Oscar Alvarez, Costa Rican ambassador to the Republic of China, hosts a "Latin Night" to mark 60 years of diplomatic relations between Taipei and San Jose.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "It is not right to refuse to enter public service. For if it is wrong to ignore the duties arising out of the relations between the members of a man's family, how is it right for a man to ignore the duties he owes to his sovereign and country?"

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION MEETS WITH U.S. CONGRESSMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 22 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A legislative delegation from the Republic of China, headed by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, visited the U.S. Congress' research department Tuesday and met with several heavyweight congressional members.
The delegation, composed more than 10 lawmakers from across the political spectrum, arrived in Washington, D.C. Sunday after a visit to the U.S. Pacific Command in Hawaii.

The delegation's current U.S. tour is organized by the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), a quasi-official organization authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties. The visit is aimed at inspecting weaponry systems Taiwan plans to purchase from the United States.
During their visit to Capitol Hill Tuesday, Taiwan lawmakers met with the four co-chairmen of the U.S. Congressional Taiwan Caucus, a pro-Taiwan group in the Congress.

Earlier in the day, the delegation listened to a briefing by relevant U.S. defense officials at the AIT office on functions of the conventional submarines that Taiwan intends to buy from the United States as well as the C4ISR system.

The ROC's Cabinet has approved a special military budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the purchase of eight submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P3-C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005. The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992. The special budget bill is now pending approval of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 24 IN TAIWAN

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FIRST LADY RETURNS FROM VACATION IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China first lady Wu Shu-chen returned to Taiwan Wednesday from a trip to Japan.
Wu did not make any statement on arriving at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport but to say that her trip was very nice and she was pleased.
Wu traveled to Japan June 18 for a five-day vacation in Hokkaido in the company of her son, Chen Chih-chung.
The trip marked the first time that Wu has gone abroad with her adult son in her capacity as ROC first lady.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO BECOME VEHICLE TECHNOLOGY HUB IN GREATER CHINA

TEXT.P: Taiwan has much potential to become a center for vehicle technology in Greater China because of its expertise and language advantages, experts and industry leaders from home and abroad said Wednesday.

The specialists made the assessment at a seminar held by the Society of Automotive Engineers (SAE) in Taipei, in which scores of experts in the automobile industry and the academic sector from Taiwan and U.S. got together to trade information to sharpen the competitive edge of the domestic industry and seize the opportunity to upgrade its status in the region.

Wang Pai-jong, president of the SAE Taiwan chapter, said that with the assistance of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Taiwan is increasingly becoming a key manufacturer of parts and components in the global industry's labor division system thanks to its strong development capabilities in the sector.
Wang forecast that Taiwan parts and components exports will grow markedly in the years ahead and appealed for greater cooperation among the government, industry and academia to sustain progress.
Taiwan outbound shipments have top NT$100 billion (US$2.95 billion) per year at present.

Su Ping-hui, deputy director at the Machine Industry Research Laboratories under the Industrial Technology Research Institute, said that the SEA -- the premier membership society dedicated to advancing mobility engineering worldwide -- serves as a good access for Taiwan to recruit fresh talent and absorb the newest technologies.

Should Taiwan further step up its design capabilities in key parts, such as engines, and suspension and electrical systems, for compact cars, coupled with its market experience, it will help the country set up a comprehensive manufacturing line and enjoy a greater market share amid fierce global competition.

Now that Taiwan has hi-end capabilities in key parts and components, it should raise the bar and build itself into a vehicle technology center for greater China at a time when the regional market, especially mainland China, is beginning to take off.
Without language or cultural barriers, Taiwan stands an excellent chance of conquering the mainland market, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO HOLD TALKS WITH TAIWAN ON TOURIST EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top mainland policy planner called on Beijing Wednesday to hold talks with Taiwan on cross-strait tourist exchanges as soon as possible.

Responding to Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Ling-san's call to completely open tourist exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, Joseph Wu, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that to allow people of mainland China who wish to sight-see in Taiwan to come should not only be coordinated by related government agencies, but also be discussed by the two sides.
Many details of the issue should be settled and a consensus between the two sides reached before the proposal can be put into practice, Wu explained.
The MAC has no timetable for Taiwan to open its doors to all mainland Chinese visitors, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF THANKS TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN FOR RETURNING FROM CHINA FOR MEETING

TEXT.P: A senior Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) official said Wednesday that he was moved to see many Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China -- commonly known as "taishang" -- "defy Beijing's pressure" by returning to their homeland to attend an SEF-sponsored gathering.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Yen Wan-chin made the remarks at the opening of the SEF-sponsored workshop in the northeastern county of Ilan as part of the celebration of Dragon Boat Festival, which fell on June 22 this year.

The SEF, a quasi-official body authorized to handle exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official contacts, has consistently organized gatherings of senior executives of major Taiwanese chambers of commerce on three important festivals on the Chinese calendar -- Chinese Lunar New Year, Dragon Boat Festival and Mid-autumn Festival.

Since some Beijing officials and several mainland Chinese official news media have recently said they don't welcome "taishang" who support Taiwan's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party administration, SEF officials said last week they were worried that the number of "taishang" who would return to attend the annual SEF-sponsored Dragon Boat Festival gathering might be limited.

Yen said he was very pleased to see more than 80 representatives of major Taiwanese trade associations in various mainland cities, including heads of some 20 such organizations, take part in the SEF-sponsored two-day gathering.
"I'm grateful for your support and admire your courage, " an emotional Yen said in his opening remarks. "I'm moved to see the larger-than-expected attendance."
Yen said the forum will provide good opportunities for "taishang" to brief government officials on the general business situation in mainland China and difficulties faced by them there.

"The two-day meeting will also enable 'taishang' and government officials to discuss feasible measures to help them resolve their problems, " Yen said, adding that the SEF will take advantage of the forum to get a better understanding of pressures "taishang" are under in their mainland operations.
Yen further said the SEF doesn't think that those who failed to return to attend the Dragon Boat Festival gathering lack Taiwan consciousness or are not loyal to the Taiwan government.

To defuse the gathering's political implication, the SEF has for the first time invite representatives of industry associations with close ties with "taishang, " such as the travel services industry and airline industry, to take part in the event this year.

Premier Yu Shyi-kun, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Joseph Wu and Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yueh will attend the meeting to explain the government's basic policies on cross-strait ties and economic development as well as exchange views with "taishang" on other related topics.

Meanwhile, most senior executives of Taiwanese trade associations in mainland China who attended Wednesday's meeting said they didn't feel pressure from Beijing authorities over their return to participate in the SEF-organized colloquium.

Wu Chin-chung, president of the Taiwanese Chamber of Commerce in Xiamen in mainland China's Fujian province, said Xiamen officials in charge of Taiwan affairs fully understand that the SEF's Dragon Boat Festival gathering was a routine event. "They didn't dissuade me from attending," he said.

Nearly all participants said they want to separate politics from business. "We also look forward to seeing a permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait. We hope the government will help cultivate a stable business environment," Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSINCHU MAYOR HOPES TO EXPAND MINI CROSS-STRAIT LINKS

TEXT.P: The government must expand the current cross-strait "mini three links" and restart flights from Hsinchu to Kinmen, Hsinchu Mayor Lin Cheng-tze and Legislator Chang Tsai-mei of the opposition Kuomintang said on Wednesday.

Lin and Chang made the appeal when they called on Lee Chu-feng, magistrate of the outlying island of Kinmen, to get a better understanding of the current situation regarding the "mini three links" -- direct trade, postal and transportation links between Kinmen and Matsu and Fujian province, which began in 2001.

Magistrate Lee said that going from Taiwan to the mainland via Kinmen costs about NT$5,000 (US$148) per person, but having to transit through Hong Kong or Macau instead costs roughly double that, not to mention the extra time spent.

He cited as an example that if a person starts from Taichung to go to Taoyuan's CKS International Airport in northern Taiwan or Kaohsiung's Hsiaokang International Airport in southern Taiwan, he could already be in the mainland if he had taken a ferry in Kinmen to Xiamen.

"This is why the 'mini three links' are getting more popular with Taiwan businessmen in the mainland," Lee said, adding that the Kinmen County Government will ask the central government to expand the scope of the links so that people in Taiwan can shuttle across the Taiwan Strait via Kinmen.

Mayor Lin said that manufacturers in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and even in Taoyuan and Miaoli need the channel to go to the mainland to make money, adding that the channel should not only be open to Taiwan people going to the mainland for religious pilgrimages or if they already have a business operating on the mainland; the policy should be eased to cover people from the industrial sector who do not have businesses in mainland China.

He noted that an airline opened a Hsinchu-Kinmen route in 1998, but canceled it later because of too few passengers and the Hsinchu terminal was later converted to other uses. He said that he will ask that the terminal be reopened to help manufacturers in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park travel to Kinmen.

At the urging of Lin, Chang promised that she would invite officials from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Civil Aeronautics Administration and manufacturers to a public hearing to promote the reopening of the Hsinchu terminal and work with Magistrate Lee to expand the "mini three links."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAY UNEMPLOYMENT RATE RISES SLIGHTLY COMPARED WITH MONTH EARLIER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate in May hit 4.41 percent, a slight rise of 0.05 percent over the April level, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported Wednesday.
The jobless ratio represents some 450,000 unemployed workers last month across the country, an increase of 6,000 more than in April, statistics made public by the DGBAS showed.
DGBAS officials ascribed the rise to seasonal factors on the grounds that May is the time when many graduates will leave school to enter the job market.

They forecast that the unemployment rate for the coming months through September will remain at the current level and said that the situation will improve when an expansion of public service and employment boost program planned by the government for the second half of this year takes effect.
The jobs expansion plan aims to create 45,552 job opportunities for underprivileged people.
The public service expansion and employment boost plan was carried out last year for the first time and it benefited a total of more than 148,000 jobless workers for the whole of 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE RANKED THIRD GLOBAL TOP CONVENTION CITY

TEXT.P: Singapore has been ranked as the world's third top convention city in 2003 by the International Congress and Convention Association (ICCA), a prominent trade organization in the global conventions arena.

The only Asian city to be listed among ICCA's top 10 preferred convention cities, Singapore's third placing marks its best performance to date in the annual global ICCA ranking. Singapore came in sixth in 2002, and was ranked ninth in both 2001 and 2000.

Based on the ICCA's criteria, the association listed Singapore as having hosted 75 out of the more than 3,000 conventions that the association tracked worldwide in 2003, making Singapore the third preferred city for conventions among international associations in 2003.
Vienna came in first with 89 conventions, while Barcelona ranked second with 78 conventions. Stockholm and Lisbon came in fourth and fifth, with 70 and 63 conventions, respectively.
With members in more than 76 countries around the world, ICCA represents specialists in the international meetings arena.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MAINLAND CHINA NOT FEELING HEAT FROM BEIJING

TEXT.P: Some of the Taiwan businessmen operating in mainland China said Wednesday that they have not felt pressure in mainland China but they expressed hope that the government will create an environment conducive to cross-Taiwan Strait peace.
The businessmen made the remarks when they attended a Dragon Boat Festival tea party convened by the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) in Ilan, eastern Taiwan.

As the number of the participants this year was less than last year, the businessmen were asked if that was because of pressure from the mainland following an editorial that appeared earlier this month in the People's Daily -- the mouthpiece of the Chinese Communist Party -- which said Beijing does not welcome Taiwan businessmen who make profit on the mainland and funnel the money back to the independence movement in Taiwan. The paper named Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the Chi Mei Group, as an example.
Chang Shih-chin, president of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Nanjing, said that he has not felt pressure from the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council.

He said the declining number was because some Taiwan businessmen felt embarrassed to attend the party, which was sponsored by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party because they publicly expressed support prior to the March 20 presidential election for opposition Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan's failed presidential bid.

Wan Hai-shui, who operates in Guangzhou, said that he was not aware of any Taiwan businessmen who could not come because of pressure from Beijing and that he has not felt any heat from the mainland authorities.

Wu Chin-chung, president of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Xiamen, said that he had no such worries about attending and that Taiwan affairs officials in Xiamen know that the party is a regular activity of the SEF.

Yeh Chun-jung, vice president of the Taiwan Businessmen's Association in Dongguan, said that with the post-election turmoil, supporters of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and the People First Party and the "pan-green camp" are not in a good mood and it is understandable that Wednesday's tea party attracted fewer participants.
Asked whether they felt pressure because Hsu was named by the People's Daily, Yeh said that as a businessman, the businessmen only want good business and to let politics be politics.
Wang said that all Taiwan businessmen on the mainland want cross-strait peace and he expressed hope that the government will create a peaceful cross-strait environment conducive to doing business.

Wu said that Taiwan businessmen in Xiamen hope for an expansion of the current direct links between Kinmen and Matsu and mainland China so that cross-strait transportation will become more convenient and Kinmen will have a greater chance of economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW AIT CONSULAR SECTION CHIEF ASSUMES OFFICE

TEXT.P: Charles Bennett, new chief of the Consular Section of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , assumed office on June 21, the de facto U.S. embassy in Taipei said Wednesday in a press release.

The AIT, which represents U.S. interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties, said in the statement that Bennett joined the diplomatic service in 1987 and has served overseas at the U.S. embassies in Beijing (1998-2003), Bangkok (1996-1998) and Manila (1987-1989).

Bennett has served at the AIT's Taipei office once before, from 1992 through 1996. In addition, he served from 1989 to 1992 in the U.S. Department of State as a desk officer in the Office of Argentina, Chile, Uruguay and Paraguay Affairs.
Bennett is the recipient of two Department of State Superior Honor Awards and two Meritorious Honor Awards, the AIT press statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW QUOTATION MIGHT CAUSE POSTPONEMENT OF SUB DELIVERY: MND

TEXT.P: A new quotation by the United States for eight submarines on Taiwan's military procurement list might lead to delays in delivery of the vessels, Huang Hui-sheng, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND), said Wednesday.

Huang's comment came after a media report that quoted Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng as asking the United States offer a new quotation for the eight diesel-fueled submarines that are to cost Taiwan NT$400 billion.

Although Huang said that the MND will abide by any resolutions approved by the Legislative Yuan, he claimed that a new price quotation is likely to postpone U.S. deliveries of the submarines by over six months at a time when the Taiwan authorities are hoping to take delivery of the ships five years sooner than originally quoted.

According to MND officials, the existing quotation by the United States is merely a rough estimate that does not take into consideration the model of the submarines. The United States may still offer the same price even if it quotes again, they pointed out, adding that this would be an unnecessary waste of time.

The eight conventional submarines form the most disputed segment of the major military procurement plan submitted by the MND for legislative approval with a value of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) that also includes budget appropriations for 12 anti-submarine aircraft and six batteries of Patriot PAC-3 missiles.
The huge budget allocation has stirred up grave concern among the public and some legislators.
Wang, who is currently visiting the United States at the head of a legislative delegation, made the remarks Tuesday in Washington after being briefed by U.S. officials on the submarine deal.
Wang asked the U.S. side to offer a cheaper price for the eight submarines and bring forward the delivery date by five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO EARLY TO TALK ABOUT JOINT CABINET WITH TSU: DPP LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: It is still too early to talk about a joint Cabinet before the year-end legislative elections, a legislator of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said Wednesday.
Tsai Huang-liang, DPP party whip in the legislature, was responding to media speculation that the DPP will form a joint Cabinet after the legislative elections in December.

According to the mass-circulation United Daily, President Chen Shui-bian and former President Lee Teng-hui, who is the so-called "spiritual leader" of the TSU, have met at least three times since the March 20 presidential election and that they decided that if the DPP and the TSU, win more than half the seats in the 225-seat Legislative Yuan, the two parties will form a joint Cabinet.

The newspaper reports quoted "unnamed sources" as saying that Lee is pinning his hopes on the year-end elections, knowing that the Cabinet will be reshuffled according to the constitutional protocol next February when the new legislature is sworn in. If the DPP and TSU combined can get half of the seats, then the TSU would get five minister-without-portfolio positions, and even ministerial posts, according to the reports.

Tsai said the only goal of the DPP and the TSU is to win the legislative elections and added that after the goal is achieved, Chen will have more room to form a Cabinet and will not rule out the possibility of inviting elite TSU members to serve in the government.

He said that Chen focuses mainly on whether a potential appointee is good for the position, citing the example of Chen's inviting Hau Lung-pin of the opposition New Party to serve as the Environmental Protection Administration head.
The president does not consider party affiliation in promoting a person, Huang claimed.
Tseng Wen-tsang, a DPP official in charge of public relations, echoed Tsai's words.

Tseng said that both the DPP and the TSU are still undergoing nomination process of candidates to run in the year-end legislative elections and that their lists have yet to be finalized, so it is too early to speak of a joint Cabinet.
The focus now should be on how to coordinate the candidate nomination of the two parties so as to increase the number of seats they can win.
Currently, the DPP is the largest party in the legislature, but the opposition Kuomintang and its ally, the People First Party, still have a combined edge over the DPP and the TSU.
Meanwhile, TSU Legislator Chen Cheng-lung said that the reports about forming a joint Cabinet are untrue.
Chen said that President Chen did meet with Lee several times, but not to discuss a joint Cabinet.
He said that the premise of forming a joint Cabinet will be winning more than half of the seats in the legislature, and whether the TSU has personnel qualified to serve in the Cabinet.

However, Chen Chien-ming, TSU whip in the legislature, said that if the DPP and the TSU can combine to get more than half of the legislative seats, then the road to forming a joint Cabinet is "inevitable."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER DELIVERS SPEECH IN RHODE ISLAND
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 22 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland China should honor its much-touted commitment to peaceful emergence by respecting Taiwan, Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Tuesday in a speech delivered in Newport, Rhode Island.
Chen, who is currently on his first U.S. visit since assuming office in April, said democracy and human rights are universal values.
If Beijing wants to truly pursue peaceful emergence, Chen said, it should respect Taiwan's democratic political system and way of life and refrain from saber-rattling against the people of Taiwan.
Addressing a packed audience at Redwood Library in Newport, Chen said Taiwan appreciates the longstanding U.S. moral support and practical assistance in various fields.

He outlined three priorities on Taiwan's agenda -- deep-rooting Taiwan's young democracy and promoting domestic ethnic harmony; forging rapprochement with mainland China and maintaining peace in the Taiwan Strait; and enhancing Taiwan's international profile and fulfilling its international obligations.

While expressing his gratitude for the U.S. support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Health Assembly -- the governing body of the World Health Organization -- as an observer, Chen said the United States, as a world leader, should pay more heed to Taiwan Strait issues.
"Taiwan's security is in the interest of many parties, including the United States itself," Chen added.

Before his speech, Chen presented a "diplomacy medal" to Claiborne Pell, a former U.S. senator, on behalf of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in recognition of Pell's outstanding contribution to promoting Taiwan-U.S. friendship, trust and cooperation over the decades.

Chen recalled that he first traveled from Taiwan to the United States in 1964 to pursue advanced studies. After he received a doctorate in physics, he was unable to return to his homeland simply because of his pro-democracy efforts. He was forced to stay and work in the United States for nearly three decades. After Taiwan ended martial law in 1987, he was finally allowed to return in 1992.

Thanks to his long stay in the United States, Chen said he has come to a deep-rooted conviction for freedom, democracy and human rights. Describing Pell is an "old pal, " Chen said their friendship is built on their shared values of liberal democracy and human rights.

Chen arrived in Boston Monday after attending the World Forum, an annual international conference organized by the noted U.S. think tank the American Enterprise Institute, in Beaver Creek, Colorado from June 17-20.
Chen held a colloquium with scholars at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government later Monday.

On Tuesday, he met with Rhode Island Lt. Gov. Charles Fogarty and Salve Regina University Sister Therese Antone for wide-ranging talks. He is scheduled to meet with Massachusetts Gov. Mitt Romney Wednesday and he will also inspect operations of the Taipei Economic and cultural Office in Boston before leaving for New York.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER INSTRUCTS STEPPED-UP PATROLS OF WATER CATCHMENT AREAS

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs Wednesday to step up security and patrols of water catchment areas around the country to prevent water supplies from being endangered.

Yu also instructed the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) to hasten its efforts on water examination in reservoirs nationwide, including those in the outlying islands, in an effort to secure safe supplies of clean water.

The premier issued the directives one day after a feeder river leading to a reservoir on the island of Kinmen was found to have been contaminated with rat poison, causing panic among Kinmen residents.
Fortunately, water samples collected from the Kuangchien creek were analyzed and determined Wednesday by the EPA to be poison-free and safe for use.

Six bottles of sample water taken from the creek, which supplies water to residents on the island were rushed to Taiwan by Kinmen Water Co. (KWC) officials Tuesday for testing to determine whether the water had been contaminated.

The water samples were taken after a Kinmen resident discovered Monday bags of Fumieshu -- an organofluorine compound used by farmers to kill mice -- that had been dumped in the water in the area. He notified KWC authorities, who determined that a total of 87 bags of Fumieshu had been dumped, including two 5-kg bags and 85 smaller bags.
The water samples, together with several kilograms of the dumped poison, were taken to a Taipei laboratory under the EPA for testing.
KWC officials said Tuesday that after preliminary checks, the water company believed that the water in the reservoir had not been contaminated.

Pointing out that the poison was past its expiration date, that it is insoluble in water and that it had not yet reached the reservoir area due to the dry season, the KWC officials said the water supplied by the Kuangchien creek reservoir is safe for use.

Although it has been preliminarily determined that the reservoir had not been contaminated, the KWC officials have still decided to clean up the upstream area to allay the concerns of Kinmen residents.
The officials said the suspected contaminated section of the creek will be blocked off and the water drawn out and into the sewer system. They did not say how long the cleanup operation would take.

In response to the incident, officials from the Taiwan Water Co., which oversees the KWC, said Tuesday that safety and security at reservoirs, related facilities and catchment areas will be tightened up nationwide to ensure safe water supplies.

DOC.HEADLINE: EMPLOYMENT BOOST PLAN SECURES OVER 40,000 JOBS

TEXT.P: The government sector is scheduled to release more than 40,000 job opportunities in the second half of this year with budgeted spending of NT$6.49 billion (about US$191 million) , as part of its efforts to create jobs for the underprivileged.

The decision was approved early this week by a council under the Executive Yuan in charge of promoting the expansion of a public service and employment boost plan led by the government that was first implemented for the whole of last year and benefited a total of 148,009 jobless people during that time.
The plan helped Taiwan slash its unemployment rate to 4.99 percent for 2003, a drop of 0.18 percent compared to the 2002 level.
The follow-up program for the second half of this year is estimated to release 45,552 job opportunities from government agencies and requires an expenditure of NT$6.49 billion.
In a bid to create the job placements in the government sector, Premier Yu Shyi-kun has instructed relevant agencies to put forward work plans and carry them out in line with the regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU TO PROPOSE ALTERING LEGISLATOR-AT-LARGE REGULATIONS

TEXT.P: The opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) said Wednesday that it will propose a revision of the election and recall law to lower the threshold of votes required by political parties for legislator-at-large positions and political party subsidies from the current 5 percent to 2 percent.
Chen Chien-ming, TSU legislative caucus whip, said the idea is to make sure the voice of a diverse society is heard and a strategic maneuver to disintegrate the opposition Kuomintang (KMT).

Chen's words came after recent suggestions to lower the threshold to 2 percent by the opposition New Party and the newly inaugurated Non-Partisan Solidarity Union headed by former Minister of the Interior Chang Po-ya, so that small political parties will have the chance to be awarded legislator-at-large seats and political party subsidies.
Currently, legislator-at-large seats are awarded to a party in proportion to the number of votes it receives in legislative elections.

Chen claimed at a press conference that lowering the threshold will also ease the current pitting of the "pan-blue alliance" of the KMT and its two splinter parties -- the People First Party and the New Party -- against the "pan-green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and its ally the TSU, as well as the political polarization among the general public.

He noted that when the KMT was the dominant party, the DPP's Chang Chun-hsiung, a former premier and legislator, also proposed lowering the threshold to 3 percent, a proposal that was quashed at that time.

Asked why TSU -- which has former President Lee Teng-hui as its so-called "spiritual leader" and which garnered 8 percent of the votes during its debut in the last legislative election in 2000 -- is proposing a lowering of the threshold while it is expected to gain more votes in the legislative election in December this year, he said that the party has "strategic considerations" in mind.

In addition to making a pluralistic society, he claimed that it will encourage "native" KMT legislators -- as opposed to the old guard KMT who identify more strongly with their traditional KMT roots -- to defect to other parties or form their own political groups or parties and break down further the once-monolithic KMT party machine.

DOC.HEADLINE: TESTING, TFT-LCD MAKERS MAY BE ALLOWED TO VENTURE ACROSS STRAIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan providers of advanced testing and packaging techniques and makers of smaller-sized TFT-LCD panels may be allowed to venture across the Taiwan Strait if it is determined that this wouldn't compromise Taiwan's high-tech development, a government source said Wednesday.

Chen Chao-yi, director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that the IDB has nearly completed an assessment on allowing Taiwan companies of semiconductor testing and packaging technology and makers of 4-inch or smaller TFT-LCD (thin-film-transistor liquid-crystal-display) panels to invest in mainland China, and that the bureau is likely to recommend that Taiwan do so.

The assessment studies the impact of such an opening on Taiwan's job market and capital situation, as well as the competitiveness prospects of the two rival sides of the Taiwan Strait, according to Chen.

In the assessment, Chen said, the IDB has concluded that allowing such manufacturing industries involved in advanced know-how to invest on the Chinese mainland would not compromise Taiwan's own high-tech development, so the IDB has decided that such an opening is feasible.

Chen pointed out, however, that when and whether Taiwan will actually give the green light still depends on the final decision to be made by a supra-ministerial ad hoc committee made up of experts from the academic, government and industrial sectors.
Chen said plans on such an opening have not entered the government screening stage yet.

DOC.HEADLINE: GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY HONORS OUTGOING ROC REP TO U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 22 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: George Washington University on Tuesday bestowed the President's Medal on outgoing Republic of China Representative Chen Chien-jen in recognition of his promotion of U.S.-Taiwan friendship and his contribution to bilateral academic exchanges.

George Washington University President Stephen Trachtenberg, in presiding over the ceremony, lauded Chen's contribution by saying that he has played the role of a bridge between Taiwan and the United States over his long diplomatic career.

Trachtenberg also expressed his appreciation for Chen's support for academic exchanges between the two countries, noting that his university has established close academic relations with Taiwan's Yuan Ze University in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan.

The President's Medal is the highest honor bestowed by the prestigious university. Past winners include former Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel, former Israel President Ezer Weizman, U.S. Sen. Joseph Lieberman, U.S. Senate Majority leader Bill Frist and Boston University President John Silber.

For his part, Chen noted that he has spent 20 of the 37 years of his diplomatic career in Washington and that he has learned not only the importance of protecting one's own nation's interests but also the importance of taking care of the interests of the countries being engaged.

He said that he accepts the honor of the President's Medal with pride and humility. In addition to extending appreciation to George Washington University for its recognition, he also thanked his wife who was also on hand to witness the ceremony.

The university also arranged for Taiwan student Tsao Yi-ying to speak about her feelings of Chen. Tsao, who is currently studying museum management for a master's degree, said that Chen was very kind toward students, which she said changed her stereotyped impression about high-ranking officials.

Nearly 100 people, including academic and diplomatic figures, officials from Taiwan's representative office in the United States, and Taiwan students studying at George Washington University, attended the ceremony. U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs James A. Kelly also attended the ceremony.

Chen, 65, started his diplomatic career as a secretary at the former ROC Embassy in the United States and became ROC Representative to the United States in 2000. He also served as a legislator, a director-general of the Government Information Office and foreign affairs minister.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS ASK U.S. TO GIVE NEW QUOTE FOR BUILDING SUBS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 22 (CNA) (By W.C. Lin and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: An ROC Legislative Yuan delegation visiting the United States has made two decisions regarding the submarine procurement plan and requested that the ROC Ministry of Defense pass on these decisions to its U.S. counterpart, a delegation member said Tuesday.

According to Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the decisions were made after the delegation listened to U.S. defense officials' briefings at the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) the same day on procurement of eight diesel-powered subs and 12 P3C anti-submarine reconnaissance aircraft.

In the decisions, the legislators requested that the U.S. side adjust the price tag for building the submarines, including building subs with China Shipbuilding Co. (CSC) or building them without the CSC, as well as shorten the delivery date from 15 years to 10 years.

Pointing out that the delegation's request demonstrates its dissatisfaction with the NT$400 billion price tag quoted by the Bush administration for the building of the submarines, Lee said that in Taiwan, there are many different opinions concerning the high price.

Instead of procuring 12 P3C anti-submarine reconnaissance aircraft as planned, the legislators hope to make a further study on whether the procurement of eight such aircraft would temporarily satisfy the island's defense needs.

Noting that a newer model anti-submarine aircraft will be produced by the United States by 2013, the delegation said it feels that Taiwan would have a better chance of buying the new aircraft if the procurement eight P3C can satisfy the island's defensive requirements temporarily.

The delegation also listened to briefings by U.S. defense officials the same day on the CISR system, namely an integration of various elements including command, control, communications, computer, intelligence information, monitoring and reconnaissance.
The legislators were scheduled to meet with U.S. scholars and former AIT directors and call on U.S. congressmen later in the day.
Headed by Wang Jin-pyng, speaker of the Legislative Yuan, the delegation is currently in Washington, D.C., to discuss Taiwan's new arms procurement project with relevant U.S. officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 23, or the sixth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1537: Spanish explorer Pedro de Mendoza dies at sea on his way back to Spain from Argentina. He headed an expedition to explore South America, during which he reached the Rio de la Plata area of Argentina and founded Buenos Aires.
1683: William Penn, the English Quaker and advocate of civil and religious liberty, signs a treaty with chiefs of the Lenni Lenape tribe under an elm tree at Shakamaxon, Philadelphia to guarantee peace for his colony.
1757: British troops under Robert Clive defeat the Nawab of Bengal, Siraj-ud Dawlah, at the Battle of Plassey, thereby making possible the British annexation of Bengal.
1848: Adolphe Sax, French instrument maker, is granted a patent for the saxophone, a wind instrument in various sizes with a single-reed mouthpiece and a curved conical metal tube.
1894: British monarch Edward VIII is born. He abdicated in order to marry the divorcee Mrs. Simpson and took the title Duke of Windsor.
1894: Alfred Kinsey, the American zoologist and sociologist best known for his studies of human sexuality and his books "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" and "Sexual Behavior in the Human Female," is born.
1912: Alan Mathison Turing, British mathematician and computer expert, is born. He pioneered the Turing machine, which greatly advanced computer development.
1914: The Kuomintang is reorganized as the Chinese Revolutionary Party in Tokyo, with Dr. Sun Yat-sen elected director-general.
1922: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Wu Ting-fang, who is concurrently governor of Kwantung province, dies of illness in Canton at the age of 81.
1952: The four characters "Wu Wang Tsai Chu," an ancient saying that translates as "Do Not Forget National Humiliation in Times of Peace and Security" are inscribed on a huge stone at Taiwushan on ROC-controlled Kinmen. The inscription is based on the handwriting of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1956: Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, a man who stands as a symbol of Arab nationalism from the Atlantic Ocean to the Persian Gulf, is elected president of Egypt.
1969: President Chiang Kai-shek nominates Gen. Chen Ta-ching as governor of Taiwan.
1975: The First Television Conference of the Cultural and Social Center for the Asian and Pacific region opens in Taipei with more than 47 delegates from South Korea, Hong Kong, the United States, the Philippines, Thailand, Kuwait, Australia and the ROC attending.
1975: The Chinese delegation to the 21st Asian Film Festival returns from Jakarta with seven awards.
1980: Sanjay Gandhi, son of Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi and next in line for political power, is killed in an airplane crash.
1983: The U.S. Supreme Court rules that Congress cannot veto presidential decisions.
1985: An Air India Boeing 747 jet en route from Canada explodes off the Irish coast, killing all 329 people on board.
1987: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the National Security Law during the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion. After the law becomes effective, the Emergency Decree in Taiwan and the Pescadores (Penghu) is lifted.
1991: The International Monetary Fund agrees to offer associate membership to the Soviet Union.
1995: American microbiologist Jonas Edward Salk dies in California at the age of 80. The medical pioneer developed the first effective killed-virus vaccine against polio in 1954.
1999: The ROC and the Republic of Panama sign a press cooperation agreement in Taipei to step up bilateral relations.
2000: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Tien Hung-mao meets with Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski, agreeing to strengthen exchanges of ranking officials as a way to further enhance substantive ties between the two countries. ROC-Macedonia diplomatic ties ended less than a year later when Macedonian pro-Beijing forces gained the upper hand in the nation's coalition government and transferred diplomatic recognition to Beijing.
2001: The Navy General Headquarters says that it has commissioned a lawyer to protect its legitimate rights in a kickback scandal involving its purchase of six French-made Lafayette-class frigates 10 years ago
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who withdraws himself from the world for no other reason than to show his personal purity of motive is one who breaks up one of the greatest ties in the foundation of society. A good and wise man, on the other hand, who enters the public service, tries to carry out what he thinks to be right. As to the failure of right principles to make progress, he is well aware of that."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO GIVE PRIORITY TO REBUILDING TRUST WITH U.S: MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 23 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government has given priority to rebuilding trust with the United States since President Chen Shui-bian's inauguration for a second four-year term May 20, ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen said in New York Wednesday.

Speaking in an interview with the Central News Agency, Chen said Taiwan and the United States have a solid friendship basis. Although mutual trust was hurt a bit before and after Taiwan's bitterly fought March 20 presidential election due to certain reasons, Chen said, bilateral relations have gradually returned to previous levels.

Chen said his optimistic observations were based on positive U.S. comments on President Chen's inaugural speech and the courteous and dignified treatment that Vice President Annette Lu received during her transit stops in Las Vegas and San Francisco in late May and early June.

In his view, Chen said, now is a "testing time" for Taiwan-U.S. relations as the Bush administration is watching whether Taiwan will abide by the commitments that President Chen made in his inauguration address.

Chen further said the ROC's ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must be pragmatic in implementing its party platform and pursuing its party goals. The ruling party must put national interests above anything else, he said.

Taiwan-U.S. relations were for a time clouded by President Chen's insistence on holding a "defensive" referendum simultaneously with the March 20 presidential election and formulating a new constitution for Taiwan in 2006 as the Bush administration thought that those moves might provoke Beijing. However, President Chen promised in his inaugural address that his constitutional reform plan would not touch on the sensitive issues of sovereignty, territory or national title and flag.

Minister Chen arrived in New York Wednesday after concluding a three-day visit to the New England region where he met with Deputy Governor Charles Fogarty of Rhode Island, Governor Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, President of the Salve Regina University in Newport Sister Therese Antone, and scholars from Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School, and also delivered a speech on recent developments in Taiwan in Newport, Rhode Island.

This is Chen's first overseas trip since assuming office in April. His itinerary also included attending the World Forum, an annual international conference organized by the noted U.S. think tank the American Enterprise Institute, in Beaver Creek, Colorado from June 17-20.

DOC.HEADLINE: MODIFIED TOY PISTOL SUSPECTED IN SHOOTING OF PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Police officers leading a probe into the March 19 assassination attempt against President Chen Shui-bian said Thursday they believe a modified toy pistol was the weapon used to injure Chen and Vice President Annette Lu.

In a press conference called to reveal their theory, Ho Yu-yi, director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau, said experiments conducted by forensic analysts in his bureau found that a modified toy pistol, commonly used by local gangsters, would be powerful enough to penetrate the windshield of a car and the clothing of a person, as well as graze the skin of the victim.
Ho said this might explain why Chen was only slightly injured and why the bullet came to rest between his clothing and his skin.

Chen Hsiao-kuei, the director of the forensics department of the Criminal Investigation Bureau who conducted the experiments, said a total of three rounds were fired in a simulation of the March 19 shooting.

All of the bullets penetrated the windshield of a car and the jacket and shirt on a dummy. The first and third bullets ended up between the jacket and shirt after grazing a pig hide covering the dummy. The second cartridge penetrated the dummy.
Chen said the cartridges, loaded with between 0.08 grams and 0.12 grams of powder, were ordinary cartridges used in such modified pistols.

Although the modified pistols can be lethal, they are not as powerful as real pistols and the trajectories of their bullets are lower than those of bullets fired from real pistols, which is why tests conducted in April by a panel of American ballistics experts with laser equipment did not match the ballistic curve of the bullet that hurt the president.

The American panel was retained by Henry Lee, a Chinese-American forensics scientist who was asked by the "pan-blue alliance" of the opposition Kuomintang and People First Party to look into the shooting.
The alliance, which lost the election to Chen, suspects that the incident was an election scheme.

Chen Hsiao-kuei said the hole in the windshield of the car also proves that the bullet was fired from a modified pistol, as it spun in the air in a way quite different from a bullet fired from a real pistol.

Ho said the results of the experiments have been sent to Lee in the United States and might debunk the opposition's claims that the shooting was a political scheme and that gunman who fired the pistol did not mean to kill the president.

The shooting took place on the eve of the presidential election when Chen and Lu were parading through the streets of Tainan City in the same car in an eleventh-hour effort to canvass votes. The parade ended in chaos after bodyguards of Chen and Lu found that the candidates had been wounded and rushed them to a nearby hospital.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER PRESIDENT PLANS SUPPORT FOR TAIWANESE BUSINESSMEN IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Former President Lee Teng-hui plans to preside over a forum Sunday to offer support to Taiwanese businessmen operating in mainland China who have suffered from "political interference" from Beijing.
According to Taiwan Advocates, one of the organizers of the forum, Lee will urge the government, as well as the ruling and opposition political parties, to pay heed to the situation.

An official of the Taiwan Advocates said the mainland authorities should face the reality of the continuation of the Democratic Progressive Party administration in Taiwan after the March 20 presidential election.

Instead the mainland authorities have begun to interfere politically with Taiwanese businessmen with operations on the mainland as a way of pushing Taiwan toward reunification with the mainland, he said.

The mainland government, through its official mouthpiece -- the People's Daily -- named some Taiwanese businessmen, among them Hsu Wen-lung, founder of the well-known Chi Mei Group, as unwelcome on the mainland as Beijing believes they use profits gained on the mainland to finance the independence movement in Taiwan.

The official predicted that the mainland's stubborn political ideology will continue despite Taiwanese businessmen's heavy contributions to the mainland's economy, stubbornness that will greatly jeopardize Taiwan's interests.
The official also asked whether Taiwan's trade policy should be reviewed in light of Beijing's interference, adding that the issue should be of greater concern to the Taiwan people.

In addition to Lee, Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Poh-chih, members of the Taiwan Association of University Professors and other think tanks, as well as several local businessmen who have suffered losses with their mainland investments, will also attend the forum.
