DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR EYEING U.S. INVESTMENT FOR NEIHU HI-TECH PARK

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou promised Thursday that he will head to the United States again in August as part of his efforts to sell Taipei and seek investment.

Ma made the remarks at a meeting held by the development association composed of companies based in the Neihu high-tech park in suburban Taipei after hearing during a briefing that the park registered a business turnover in excess of NT$1 trillion (about US$30 billion) for 2003, a noticeable jump over the 2002 level of NT$760 billion.

Ma was happy to learn the news and hailed the four-year-old hi-tech park for achieving what the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park -- Taiwan's leading hi-tech establishment -- took 20 years to achieve.

The mayor vowed to do his best to help upgrade development in the Neihu district in order to make it a "hi-tech corridor" in conjunction with the Nankang, Shihlin and Peitou areas. He said that the compound has great potential to become the hub for large business concerns to house their research and development centers and business operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER PROPOSES NEW MEASURES TO HELP EX-CONVICTS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 24 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Minister of Justice Chen Ding-nan said in New York Wednesday that Taiwan has much to learn from the United States in helping ex-convicts rebuild their lives.
Chen is currently on a two-week visit to the United States that has taken him to several U.S. cities, including Los Angeles, San Francisco, Houston and Boston.
During his stay in San Francisco, Chen said he visited the California Delancey Street Foundation (CDSF) , which is dedicated to helping ex-inmates rebuild their lives.

"The foundation operates restaurants and home removal companies aimed at helping ex-convicts adapt themselves to normal society after serving their time in prison, " Chen said, adding that the foundation's restaurant department makes a profit of up to US$3 million a year and its home removal company section's annual profit reaches US$4 million.

Chen said Taiwan's ex-convict assistance organizations can learn from the CDSF operations. "Our agencies usually offer loans for ex-inmates to launch their own ventures. But many of them fail because operating a new business is no easy task. In the future, we can follow the CDSF model in helping our ex-convicts rebuild their lives," Chen said.
During a visit to Columbia University's drug addiction treatment research center, Chen said he learned that religious belief can to some extent help drug addicts quit drugs.

Chen said the Ministry of Justice has tentatively decided to transform an idle reform center previously operated by the now-defunct Garrison Command into a drug addict detention and education center. Chen said he plans to invite major Christian, Catholic and Buddhist organizations to help administer the center.
Chen will travel to the state of Vermont Thursday to study its monitoring and control system for sex offenders that have been released from prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERCK GROUP TO SET UP LIQUID CRYSTAL PRODUCTION CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Germany-based Merck Ltd. announced Thursday that it will set up a liquid crystal (LC) production and research center in Taiwan, with investment worth NT$900 million (US$26.7 million), for local suppliers of TFT-LCD display panels.
This will be another major project from Merck in Taiwan, following its investment in the production of chemical materials for electronic products, ITO glass and color filters for TFT-LCD panels.
The planned LC center, to be located in Kuanying, Taoyuan County, is expected to begin full-scale production in 2005, creating 150 jobs for local people.
Merck Chairman Thomas Lee said the LC to be produced at the center is expected to account for 50 percent to 60 percent of the domestic LC market.
Lee noted that Merck, the oldest pharmaceutical and chemical company in the world, is offering different LC materials for the needs of diverse clients around the world.

The Merck group, the largest LC supplier in the world and accounting for 69 percent of global market, is also the major supplier of chemical materials for electronic use in Taiwan's semiconductor industry.
The Merck Group's combined investment in Taiwan has reached NT$6 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POISED TO UPGRADE DEFENSE CAPABILITIES: LEGISLATIVE HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 23 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is fully poised to step up its defense capabilities to safeguard its national security, because it is unreliable to pin hopes on others, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said here Wednesday.
Wang made the remarks at a news conference prior to his departure from Washington, D. C., where he was paying a visit at the head of a legislative delegation over the last week.

The purpose of the trip was aimed at gaining a further explanation from the United States on a major military procurement program that will cost Taiwan NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) to buy advanced defense weapons such as submarines, anti-sub aircraft and anti-missile batteries.

Touching on the controversial deal in which the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has allocated NT$400 billion for the purchase of eight diesel-powered submarines, Wang made it clear that the United States will only help Taiwan acquire the eight vessels but will not assist Taiwan in building the ships.

Although the Legislative Yuan has approved a resolution asking for U.S. help to allow the China Shipbuilding Corporation to have a role in constructing the submarines, Wang explained that the United States backs the idea that Taiwan should have maintenance and repair capabilities but is opposed to the proposal that Taiwan builds its own subs.

In view of the U.S. stance, which is contradictory to the legislature's resolution, Wang acknowledged that "Taiwan cannot turn a blind eye to this fact" and said compromises should be made to bridge the gap.

Wang asked the U.S. side to quote a cheaper price for the planned procurement of the eight subs before the Legislative Yuan's budget appropriation screening to assuage grave public concern over the huge amount of spending. He also demanded a quicker delivery of the subs by shortening the current estimated time of 15 years to 10 years.

After learning of Wang's comments, Premier Yu Shyi-kun said in Taiwan on Thursday that he will thoroughly discuss the issue with Wang and ranking MND officials after he returns from the United States, especially regarding U.S. opposition of Taiwan's constructing its own subs.

Yu made the remarks to reporters ahead of a gathering in eastern Ilan County with Taiwan businessmen's association representatives who returned from mainland China to take part in a seminar on the occasion of the Dragon Boat Festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS IN MAY SECOND-HIGHEST FOR SINGLE MONTH

TEXT.P: Export orders in May totaled US$17.25 billion thanks to the continued strong global demand for wireless and digital consumer electronic products and demand for panels in mainland China, according to tallies released Thursday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Statistics Department.

Economics officials said that despite Beijing's announcement that it is cooling down its overheated economy and the soaring price of international crude oil, export orders still registered an annual increase of 25.68 percent to reach US$17.25 billion in May.
The figure was next only to US$18.03 billion in April, or the second-highest figure for a single month.

In terms of products, export orders for electronic products in May increased US$1.31 billion from the same month last year, or an annual increase of 51.33 percent. Precision instrument products increased US$710 million, or an annual increase of 150.85 percent thanks to the display panel industry's investment in the mainland.

The most orders were placed by the United States, Hong Kong, Europe and Japan, in that order. Compared with the same month of last year, only Japan registered a slight decline of US$40 million, with everywhere else recording growth. The United States increased by US$1.2 billion, Hong Kong increased by US$1.4 billion, while Europe increased by US$660 million. The items that contributed to the increased orders were electronic products and precision instruments.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES CREATIVITY, HIGH-QUALITY IN TAIWAN PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian expressed hope Thursday that the private and government sectors can work together to help establish a national image of Taiwan as a place of "creativity and high quality."
The president made the remarks when he presented awards to winners of the 12th National Awards of Excellence in Taipei.
Chen said that the award represents the highest honor for the winning manufacturers and will help the upgrading of the country's industry.
He noted that Taiwan enterprises, facing the pressure of globalization, have to upgrade and try to promote the excellence of Taiwan products, which he said deserve the highest respect.

Chen said that any product marked "made in Taiwan" represents the image of Taiwan and noted that "a lot of foreigners" derive their impression of Taiwan from its products sold all over the world. The overall national image, he claimed, will decide the market price and the level of the country's products.
He cited digital cameras as an example, noting that cameras made by the same manufacturer and of the same type are more expensive when they are produced in Japan rather than in other Asian countries.

"This is because consumers have `subjectively' concluded that Japanese products will offer more protection, " the president said, adding that "the price difference projects the overall image of a nation's industry."

Chen said that manufacturers that have produced excellent products are the biggest contributors to getting Taiwan products a niche in the world and pushing domestic industry to continue to move toward high value-added products.
Pointing out that he has stressed creativity in industry before, Chen stressed that this should not be confined to a single industry but should apply to all industries.

Taiwan's excellent products should not be confined to only a few products, but should represent all products, the president said, adding that Taiwan must pursue excellence in production, research and development, marketing and after-sales service.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTSTANDING POLICE OFFICER DIES IN OFFICE

TEXT.P: Chiang Ching-hui, an outstanding middle-ranking police officer who had taken part in many cross-border criminal investigations, was found dead on the floor of his office in Taipei early Thursday.

Chiang, 48, had been working day and night preparing a special report to be delivered at an outstanding police citation ceremony in Manila June 28, his colleagues at the Criminal Investigation Bureau's (CIB's) international affairs department said.
Initial investigations show that Chiang did not sustain any injuries and there were no signs that anyone had entered Chiang's office during the night.

According to his colleagues, Chiang was a workaholic, often staying late or even overnight at his office. A graduate of Central Police University, Chiang pursued advanced studies at Northwest University in the United States. He could speak fluent English and had attended many training programs abroad.
"Chiang had made friends with many foreign law enforcement officers and played an important role in cross-border criminal investigations," said a CIB official.

In 2003 alone, Chiang joined forces with police officers from the Philippines to bust a Taiwan-Japan-Philippines car smuggling ring, as well as cooperating with American and Philippine investigators to thwart a cross-border drug-trafficking ring and seizing more than 1,000 kg of amphetamines and 7,000 kg of chemical compounds for making contraband drugs worth some NT$1.3 billion in street value.
Early this year, Chiang again cooperated with Philippines police authorities in uncovering some 4,000 kg of semi-finished illegal drugs in the Philippines.

In recognition of his crime-fighting achievements, the Philippine government invited Chiang to attend its June 28 outstanding police citation ceremony at part of celebration of that country's Police Day.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENCE PARK IN TAINAN FREE FROM WATER SHORTAGE

TEXT.P: Although a water shortage crisis is looming in the Tainan area, the Southern Taiwan Science Park does not currently have any water shortages, according to a park administration official Thursday.

Chen Chun-wei, deputy director of the Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration, said that water supplies for hi-tech facilities should be secured through the end of this year as the Nanhua Reservoir will supply water for the park, which consumes over 40,000 cubic feet of water per day.

Although the park's water consumption has been assured for the rest of this year, Chen still called on the public to conserve water because water levels in domestic reservoirs are running low due to a scarcity of rainfall in the Tainan area.
According to Chen, the Nanhua Reservoir in Tainan County now has more than 52 million cubic feet of water and water supplies will be normal through September.

The Tsengwen Reservoir and the Wushantou Reservoir, two prime providers in the area, now contain a combined 19 million cubic feet of water, a level far short of the estimated 400 million cubic feet needed for the second crop irrigation planned for late June on the Chianan Plain -- Taiwan's leading rice producing granary.
Taiwan has in recent years been plagued by a sharp disparity in rainfall. The northern Taipei, Taoyuan and Hsinchu region has been hit hard by a drought over the past two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PARTICIPATION IN MULTI-LAYER MARKETING HIGHEST IN WORLD

TEXT.P: One person in nearly every two households in Taiwan took part in multi-layer marketing (MLM) activities last year, the highest ratio in the world, the latest survey by the Fair Trade Commission showed Thursday.

The survey showed that 3.81 million people took part in MLM activities last year, up 549,000 from the previous year. One person out of every 1.85 households were in multi-layer activities, up from one person in every 2.12 households the previous year.

But the statistics also showed that among those who took part in MLM activities, only 25.5 percent ordered goods, and among these, only about half received cash awards, with the average being NT$35,478 (US$1,052) a year.
Commission officials said that with more and more people taking part in MLM in Taiwan, the problem is more on quantity instead of quality.
They said that an average MLM scheme has 19.2 full-time staff with each of them having to serve 945 people.

TAIEX Index futures for August increased 35 points to finish at 5,649, with 216 contracts traded, while September futures rose 58 points to finish at 5,650, with 23 contracts finalized.

Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also were higher.
July TE futures moved up 2.8 points to close at 225.8, with 4,471 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 2.85 points to finish at 224.35 with 52 contracts transacted.

No transactions were recorded for other months.

September TF futures gained 17.6 points to close at 960, with five contract transaction, while December TF futures moved up 2.0 points to finish at 960, with four contracts traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, June 24, or the seventh day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1314: Led by Robert the Bruce, the Scots defeat the English army at the Battle of Bannockburn.
1340: The British fleet destroys the French at Sluys in the Hundred Years' War.
1497: John Cabot, originally Giovanni Caboto, an Italian-born navigator and explorer in the service of the English crown, discovers the North American mainland just 35 days after leaving Bristol in his ship, the Matthew.
1812: Napoleon Bonaparte, leading his Grand Armee, begins his invasion of Russia.
1821: Simon Bolivar, known as "the Liberator," leads 8,000 South American patriots to victory against 4,000 Spanish Royalists at the Battle of Carabobo in Venezuela, virtually freeing Venezuela from Spanish control.
1940: Japan formally asks Britain to close the Burma Road.
1948: The Berlin airlift begins as the Allies delivery food and essential supplies by air to Berliners after the Soviets blockade the city.
1953: Jacqueline Bouvier announces her engagement to Senator John F. Kennedy.
1964: Fu Jen Catholic University, founded in Beijing in 1926 and taken over by the Chinese communists in 1950 after the ROC government moved to Taiwan, is reopened in Hsinchuang, Taipei County.
1973: Eamon de Valera resigns as president of Ireland at the age of 90.
1974: Robert E. Page, and Frank W. Beatty, vice presidents of United Press International, arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes revisions to the banking law.
1975: The China External Trade Development Council and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, sign an agreement to promote trade and other economic relations.
1976: A 1,000,000-ton dry dock at Kaohsiung shipyard is christened.
1976: The Executive Yuan appoints Fan Kwei-shu as political vice minister of the Ministry of Justice and Chen Min-ching as commissioner of the Department of Reconstruction, Taiwan Province.
1978: Lieutenant-Colonel Ahmed Hussein al-Ghashni, president of the Yemen Arab Republic, is killed by a bomb carried by a South Yemen special envoy, who also dies in the explosion.
1981: The opening ceremony of the 30th Council Meeting of the Asian Pacific Parliamentarians' Union is held at the Grand Hotel in Taipei.
1983: President Assad of Syria orders Yasser Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to leave Damascus.
1983: Sally Ride becomes the first American woman in space when she blasts off in Challenger with four male astronauts.
1987: Kim Dae-jung and 300 other dissidents are released after two weeks of unrest in South Korea.
1989: Zhao Ziyang, who expressed sympathy with pro-democracy students in mainland China, is replaced by Jiang Zemin as general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party.
1993: A Xiamen Airlines passenger plane is hijacked and diverted to Taiwan by Chang Wenlung, a mainland Chinese youth.
1994: Russia and the European Union sign a friendship accord in Corfu, Greece, designed to help stabilize Russia and bring it closer to its former rivals.
1998: The UNSC agrees to maintain sanctions against Iraq for 60 more days.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government there are five good principles to be kept in mind and respected. First, to benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country; secondly, to encourage labor without giving cause for complaint; thirdly, to desire for the enjoyments of life without being covetous; fourthly, to be dignified without being supercilious; fifthly, to inspire awe without being severe."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER AUTHORIZES GIO TO HANDLE BCC LICENSE ISSUE: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has authorized the Government Information Office (GIO) to handle issues regarding license renewal for an opposition Kuomintang (KMT) -controlled radio company, a senior official said Friday.
GIO Director-General Lin Chia-lung made the remarks ahead of a GIO meeting to screen Broadcasting Corporation of China's (BCC's) application for renewal of its operation license.

Lin announced a day earlier that the GIO will push for amendments to the existing broadcasting and television law to ban any single private radio company from simultaneously controlling more than two nationwide broadcasting channels. Before the proposed "anti-monopoly" law revision is completed, Lin said, the GIO plans to issue only interim licenses to relevant companies.

The BCC currently controls three nationwide channels. In the past, the BCC was given special privileges because it played a role in countering mainland China's attempts to interfere with Taiwan's broadcast transmissions. As the times and environment have changed, Lin said, this BBC function no longer exists.
As part of the government's media reform plan, Lin said, the GIO will push for law revisions to prevent monopolies of broadcasting channels by radio firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSE PASSES RESOLUTION IN SUPPORT OF U.S. VISITS BY TAIWAN OFFICIALS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 24 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. House of Representatives' International Relations Committee passed a resolution Thursday to reiterate Congress's commitment to the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) and to state that serving Taiwan officials should be allowed to visit the United States.

The resolution, jointly introduced by committee chairman Henry Hide and ranking committee member Tom Lantos, and co-sponsored by 20 other House members, reaffirms Congress's unwavering commitment to the TRA as the cornerstone of U.S. relations with Taiwan.

It also states that: "The United States government should not discourage current officials of the Taiwan government from visiting the United on the basis that doing so would violate the 'one China policy.'"
Wu Ming-chi, president of the Formosan Association of Public Affairs, said that passage of the resolution "opens the door for a future visit by President Chen to Washington, D.C."

"The reference to the TRA being 'the cornerstone' of U.S.-Taiwan relations is significant too, since the People's Republic of China continues to claim that the three U.S.-PRC Communiques prevail, " Wu added.

Many members of Congress support a visit by President Chen to the U.S. capital, but the Bush administration may have reservations about such a visit as it does not want to affect its relations with mainland China.
Wu said that "obviously, the U.S. Congress agrees that the TRA is the law of the land and dictates U.S.-Taiwan relations, and not the three communiques."

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH COMPANY SUSPECTED OF BID-FIXING IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: French telecommunication company Alcatel is suspected of bid-fixing in winning a NT$940 million (US$28.03 million) contract to deliver control and safety train detection systems to the Taiwan Railway Administration, investigators from the Prosecutors' Office at the Taiwan High Court said Friday.

The investigators said they found Alcatel had transmitted NT$80 million, about 10 percent of the value of the contract, in three batches to several apparent competitors for the bid for the contract after it was awarded the contract in February.
Investigators suspected the money was payment to bidders who were in collusion with Alcatel and submitted unreasonably high bids to make Alcatel a shoe-in.

The investigators were tipped off on the allegations of bid-fixing by a secret informant and found that Alcatel executives in Taiwan invited their potential competitors to dinner before the contract was put out for tender.

Bid-fixing is illegal under the Government Procurement Act and a bidder who is found guilty of bid-fixing will be stripped of the right to deliver on the contract and responsible individuals will be liable to prison sentences.

Since 1997 the Taiwan Railway Administration has invited bidders for contracts for the railway monitoring systems, which feature 6,200 axle counters, but failed to choose a winner in the last 10 public tenders for various reasons until Alcatel won it in February.
In a news release issued in April, the French company spoke of the contract as the largest ever signed worldwide for this class of railway monitoring solution.

Several local political figures were reportedly involved in fixing the bid. Among them was an aide to Legislator Wang Tuo of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party. Wang said Friday, however, he had no idea of his aide's role in the scandal and he himself had nothing to do with the contract.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN MANUFACTURERS SEE BUSINESS CLIMATE AS SUSTAINABLE

TEXT.P: More than half of Taiwan's manufacturers predict that the business climate for the next six months will be sustainable, according to a report published Friday by the Taiwan Institute for Economic Research (TIER).

The TIER monthly report on economic climate and trends, based on a survey conducted by the institute in May, stated that the proportion of manufacturing companies who predicted that business for the upcoming six months would be "sustainable" increased to 51.1 percent from 46.6 percent recorded in the previous month.

At the same time, 41.1 percent of companies felt that business will become "progressive," down from last month's 46.4 percent, while 7.8 percent considered that business will turn "regressive, " up from 7 percent registered a month ago.
In addition, it noted, the composite indicator declined 2.78 points to 111.93 in May, a decrease for the third consecutive month.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S.-TAIWAN TIES BASED ON SHARED VALUES: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 24 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Relations between Taiwan and the United States are based on the universal values of democracy and human rights; therefore, ties between the two will be easy to maintain unless there are major changes in the world situation, Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said Thursday in New York.
Chen, who arrived in New York on June 23 from Boston, noted that U.S.-Taiwan ties have been based on the Taiwan Relations Act and the three Sino-U.S. joint communiques over the last two decades.

Although mainland China has tried its best to sabotage U.S.-Taiwan ties, it is easier for the two countries to keep their traditional relations alive since these are based on their shared universal values of democracy, freedom and human rights, Chen said.
Saying that he thinks the existing bilateral relations will continue, Chen added that he hoped the bonds would strengthen.

During his U.S. visit, Chen attended the World Forum, an annual international conference organized by the noted U.S. think tank, the American Enterprise Institute, in Beaver Creek, Colorado June 17-20, and met several American politicians and scholars.
The minister also bestowed a medal on former U.S. Senator Claiborne Pell in recognition of his long-term contributions in promoting U.S.-Taiwan ties.
Chen is scheduled to return to Taiwan June 30.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT HEARING HELD IN LAWSUIT SEEKING TO ANNUL PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Taiwan High Court held a hearing Friday regarding a lawsuit filed by the opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) seeking to annul the March 20 presidential election.

Su Yung-chin, a professor from National Chengchi University arguing on behalf of the plaintiffs, said that the presidential election was skewed in favor of incumbent President Chen Shui-bian because of its coincidence with the referendum initiated by the president, citing studies to back his allegation.

However, lawyers for the president and Vice President Annette Lu disagreed, claiming the opposite was true. But for the referendum, they said, the Chen-Lu ticket would not have won by almost 30,000 votes, as was the case, but by more than 100,000 votes.
The four-hour hearing closed without setting the next court date.

In addition to the lawsuit seeking to annul the entire presidential election, the KMT and PFP have also filed a lawsuit seeking to nullify the victory of Chen and Lu. That case is also pending at the Taiwan High Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONE GUNMAN RESPONSIBLE FOR ASSASSINATION ATTEMPT ON PRESIDENT: POLICE

TEXT.P: Investigators have concluded that a single gunman fired two shots that slightly wounded President Chen Shui-bian on the eve of the March 20 presidential election, the director of the Criminal Investigation Bureau said in Tainan City, southern Taiwan Friday.

In a news conference called on the 100th day after the March 19 incident, Director Ho Yu-yi said that based on recreations and forensic analysis, one of the two shots has been determined to have penetrated the windshield of the open vehicle that President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu were traveling in at an angle of 38 degrees; the other hit the screen dead on, or at an angle of 90 degrees.

Given that the car in which President Chen and Vice President Lu were standing in was moving at 6.4 meters per second, and that the interval between two shots is usually 0.65 seconds, it is very likely that one gunman fired the two shots, Ho said.

This analysis is supported by the fact that the two bullets, one of which gave the president a flesh wound across his abdomen and the other grazed the knee of the vice president, caused both injuries at 1.4 meters from the ground, Ho said.
The news conference was held in Tainan City, where the assassination attempt took place.
Also Friday, People First Party Legislator Lee Ching-hua raised questions about the police theory announced the previous day that a modified toy pistol was the possible weapon used in the incident.

Lee said ballistics experiments conducted by police on the path the bullets took are aimed more at debunking critics' claims that the whole incident was a political scheme concocted to boost Chen's presidential campaign than finding the culprits in the case.

Claiming that the assassination attempt had turned the presidential race upside down, Lee said the only way to find the truth would be to set up an independent investigative committee in the Legislative Yuan.
Police have so far not taken any suspects into custody regarding the shooting.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO WATER SHORTAGE FOR SOUTHERN TAIWAN SCIENCE PARK: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Southern Taiwan Science Park will have no water shortage problems this year, although irrigation for the second crop in Taiwan's main rice-growing region nearby has been postponed twice, a park administration official said Friday.

Chen Chun-wei, deputy director of the Southern Taiwan Science Park Administration in Tainan, said the park consumes some 40,000 cubic meters of water daily, supplied by the Nanhua reservoir, which held 52 million cubic meters of water as of Wednesday.
Although the water supply for the park is assured for this year, Chen urged the public to keep conserving water, as other reservoirs in the Tainan area are facing a serious lack of water.

According to the Chianan Irrigation Association, irrigation planned for the second crop on the Chianan Plain -- the island's main rice granary -- was postponed twice in June as result of the serious water shortage.

The Tsengwen reservoir and the Wushantou reservoir, two prime water suppliers for the Chianan Plain, now have a combined 19 million cubic meters of water, a level far short of the 400 million cubic meters needed for the second crop irrigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC GROWTH TO BE BETTER WITH NEW CONSTRUCTION PROJECTS: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: The fundamentals of Taiwan's economy are very good and if the "10 new major construction projects" program can be put into practice, it will ensure that economic growth over the next few years will be even better, the head of a think tank predicted Friday.

Wu Rong-i, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, said that if the five-year, NT$500 billion (US$14.88 billion) program can be passed and put into practice in July, then the economic growth this year could reach 6 percent, with even higher growth in the next few years.

According to a survey of manufacturers conducted by the institute in May, Wu said that the number of those who perceive that businesses will improve in the next six months dropped to 41.1 percent from 45.4 percent in April, while those who perceive that business in the next six months will remain the same rose to 51.1 percent from 46.6 percent and those who think it will take a turn for the worse rose slightly to 7.8 percent from 7 percent in April.

Wu commented that the slight increase in the number of people who think the economy will take a turn for the worse is due mainly to a recent announcement by Beijing that it was taking steps to cool down its overheated economy.
He noted that Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea are all affected by mainland China and that the uncertainty posed by the change of mainland policy is important to manufacturers.
He also said that the post-March 20 presidential election turmoil in Taiwan has also made manufacturers tense.

But he pointed out that the fundamentals of Taiwan's economy are very good and said that if the effects of the mainland's cooling-down policy become clearer, then Taiwan's stock market and manufacturers' optimism will return to a steady high level.

DOC.HEADLINE: COURT ACQUITS PROFESSOR OF SPREADING OBSCENE PICTURES

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court acquitted Friday a university professor accused of posting obscene pictures featuring bestiality on the Internet.
Central University Professor Josephine Ho, upon learning the news, said that although acquitted, the chilling effect of "trying to stifle views on sexual issues" had been felt deep and wide.
Ho claimed that the mere fact of being prosecuted is in itself a punishment to try to prevent her from "airing her views on sex."

She said that during the litigation, she realized the "irrational persecution of moral panic" from the public and the terrible power of a smear campaign, as well as the maneuvering of the judicial system.
In April 2003, Ho was in charge of the Web site of a gender research institute at the university that contained links to bestiality Web sites, believing that it was "necessary for academic research."
When news of these links surfaced, a number of civic groups demanded that prosecutors investigate the case for alleged violations of the obscenity law.

The Taipei Prosecutor's Office conducted an investigation last December and later filed a suit against Ho for posting the obscene pictures, which they ruled could arouse viewers and infringe on morals.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT EXCHANGES ON THE RISE SINCE MAY: MAC

TEXT.P: Cultural, economic and civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait have continued to increase since May, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said Friday.

Speaking at a regular news conference, Chiu said the MAC -- Taiwan's top mainland policy planning agency -- is optimistic about the development of cross-strait relations because bilateral commercial and cultural exchanges have been on an upward swing since May.
Chiu said the MAC has continued to extend olive branches to the mainland and has consistently taken steps to promote cross-strait exchanges.
"We have invited the top mainland negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan, to visit the island and have allowed an additional mainland news organization to post a journalist in Taiwan," Chiu said.
Wang is president of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, a semi-official body set up to handle cross-strait affairs in the absence of official contacts.

Commenting on a proposal by students from mainland China's prestigious Tsinghua University that the mainland should purchase Taiwan goods with mainland currency in order to affect Taiwan's economy, Chiu said the two sides should promote bilateral trade and commercial exchanges in line with World Trade Organization (WTO) regulations and their WTO accession terms.
"Neither side should impose any unnecessary barrier to hinder bilateral commercial exchanges. Such moves would not benefit either side," Chiu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REAFFIRMS POLICY ON ENCOURAGING CROSS-STRAIT CULTURAL EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) reaffirmed its policy Friday on encouraging cultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan's top mainland policy planning agency was responding to a media report that the new general manager of a state-owned terrestrial television company has said that the company will no longer purchase mainland China-produced drama series.
MAC Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san said the council is not in a position to comment on the business strategies of Chinese Television System (CTS).
Nevertheless, Chiu said, the MAC has consistently encouraged cross-strait cultural exchanges.
"We'll encourage any move that contributes to the expansion of positive cross-strait cultural exchanges," Chiu said.

However, Chiang Hsia, a noted actress who assumed office as CTS general manager Friday, said local news media had misquoted her. "I did not say CTS will not buy mainland drama series. The local media quoted me out of context, " she said after taking the company's official seal in a changeover ceremony.
Chiang said the company will continue to uphold its existing business contracts concerning the showing of mainland drama series.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO DENIES MAINLAND CHINA-PRODUCED TV DRAMAS DOMINATING LOCAL TV

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) rebutted claims Friday that mainland China-produced TV dramas have overwhelmed local TV screens.

Legislator Hsieh Ming-yuan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said some television stations have aired mainland dramas profusely and that such shows account for more than 30 percent of all programs, which violates relevant regulations.
Wang added that with so many mainland-produced TV dramas on local TV screens, the livelihoods of local performers are being affected.
Accusing the GIO of turning a blind eye to the situation, he said that according to GIO regulations, mainland broadcasting and TV programs should not exceed 16 percent of the total air time.
But Wang Keng-ling, an official from the GIO's Department of Radio and Television Affairs, said that the legislator's figures differ from those of the GIO.

Wang noted that in fact, in the first five months of the year, mainland-produced TV dramas accounted for 0.8 percent of the programs on terrestrial stations and 1.3 percent of the cable TV stations, or 3.9 percent if re-runs are included.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER VISITS ROC NAVAL OFFICERS ON DE-MOTHBALLED KIDD DESTROYER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 24 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition Kuomintang Legislator Sun Kuo-hua said in Washington, D.C. Thursday that he was impressed by the performance of a group of Taiwan naval officers who are taking part in a Kidd-class destroyer de-mothballing and renovation project in Charleston, South Carolina.

Sun visited a Charleston shipyard Wednesday to show his concern for the 300-plus ROC naval officers working there in preparation for taking delivery of four Kidd-class destroyers that the United States agreed to sell to Taiwan in 2001.
The four destroyers were originally built for the Shah of Iran in 1979 but were later mothballed when Iran canceled the deal.
Sun said he boarded one of the destroyers to see for himself the 9,600-ton warship's cabin facilities and operational systems, as well as the examination and renovation work.
According to Sun, the navy has christened the four destroyers as the Chi-teh, the Ming-teh, the Tung-teh and the Wu-teh.
Sun said all the members of the ROC naval corps, headed by Rear Adm. Pu Tze-chun, have worked hard in preparation for taking delivery of the warships.

Quoting American naval experts, Sun said the Kidd-class destroyers have superb naval and air defense capabilities and can serve as a training platform for ROC naval officers in preparing them to operate the Aegis battle management system-equipped Arleigh Burke-class guided missile destroyers in the future. Taiwan has expressed interest in purchasing the highly advanced Aegis-equipped destroyers, but the United States has not yet agreed to negotiate such a deal.

Sun said one of the four Kidd-class destroyers has already been de-mothballed and launched. If all goes smoothly, Sun added, two Kidd-class destroyers can be delivered to Taiwan before the end of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, June 25, or the eighth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1788: Virginia becomes the 10th U.S. state.
1843: Commercial production of cigarettes begins in France when the French National Tobacco Co. turns out its first batch of 20,000 cigarettes.
1900: Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma, British naval commander and colonial administrator, is born. He was the supreme Allied commander in Southeast Asia during World War II, the last viceroy of India, then the commander in chief of Britain's Mediterranean fleet.
1903: Marie Curie, the Polish-born French chemist and scientist, announces the discovery of radium, a radioactive metallic element found in pitchblende, remarkable for its spontaneous disintegration, and other elements.
1942: Maj. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is appointed commander of U.S. forces in Europe and sets up his headquarters in London.
1944: Chinese Expeditionary Forces capture Magaung in northern Burma.
1945: Representatives of 50 nations, including the Republic of China, attend a United Nations meeting in San Francisco to pass the U.N. Charter. The ROC, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain are made members of the U.N. Security Council.
1947: The ROC Foreign Ministry reveals repeated Soviet Union attempts to block Chinese troops from entering Dairen and Port Arthur.
1950: North Korea invades South Korea, marking the beginning of the Korean War.
1953: Heavy rain hits Kyushu, an island of Japan, killing 1,013 people.
1968: The ROC Cabinet is partially reshuffled, with Defense Minister Chiang Ching-kuo becoming vice premier.
1969: Pancho Gonzalez and Charlie Paserell play the longest-ever singles match at Wimbledon, which lasts five hours and 12 minutes.
1973: Mathieu Vangha Ekra, Ivory Coast state minister in charge of tourism, accompanied by his wife and a party of five, arrives in Taipei for an eight-day visit.
1975: The 22-member Chinese track and field team returns from the Philippine national invitational track and field championships with 27 medals and a second-place finish.
1975: Mozambique gains independence, with Samora Machel, a Marxist, as its president, after four centuries of Portuguese rule.
1975: More than 4,000 refugees from Cambodia, Laos and South Vietnam are resettled in Taiwan.
1982: Alexander Haig resigns as U.S. secretary of state and is succeeded by George Schultz.
1989: The British government refuses to allow residency rights in Britain to ethnic Hong Kong Chinese.
1990: Under international pressure, Beijing allows Fang Lichih, a noted Chinese physicist and democracy activist, to leave mainland China and study at Cambridge University in England.
1990: Reporters from mainland China are permitted to visit Taiwan for news-gathering purposes, and government employees from Taiwan are allowed to visit sick relatives or attend funerals across the Taiwan Strait.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Tsutomu Hata resigns along with his minority government.
1996: A terrorist bomb blast tears through a Saudi Arabian military complex housing foreigners, killing more than 60 people and injuring nearly 400 others.
1997: Jacques Yves Cousteau, French underwater explorer and film producer, dies in Paris at the age of 87. The veteran oceanographer helped develop the aqua-lung in 1943, and popularized underwater exploration with his prize-winning films.
2000: Kaohsiung City Mayor Frank Hsieh is elected as chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
2001: The Council for Economic Planning and Development announces that the government will encourage the formation of 50 private venture capital funds, totaling NT$100 billion (US$2.94 billion), to boost the development of the local bio-tech industry.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To benefit the people without wasting the resources of the country is to encourage the people to undertake such profitable labor as will best benefit them, without it being necessary to give them any assistance out of the public revenue."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER REJECTS NOTION OF TRADE TRANSACTIONS IN RENMINBI

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Ho Mei-yue dismissed Friday "unrealistic" the notion that mainland China's renminbi (RMB) could be used for trade transactions across the Taiwan Strait.

Asked to comment on a mainland scholar's suggestion that Beijing should consider full convertibility for the RMB for trade transactions between Taiwan and the mainland, Ho said that to the best of her understanding, no company doing international trade anywhere in the world would choose to use a currency that is still under government control for import or export trade transactions.

Ho was asked to comment on a recent International Herald Tribune report in which Chen Lin, a researcher with Beijing's Tsinghua University's Business Management College, suggested that Taiwan and the mainland use the RMB as the currency for trade transactions between the two sides.
Ho said that as far as she knows, most of the Taiwan companies operating business on the mainland use either the U.S. dollar or the New Taiwan dollar, as currency for trade transactions.

Taking the information technology industry as an example, Ho said, Taiwan exporters, regardless of whether their products are to be delivered from Taiwan or the mainland, all use the greenback for their quotations.
Ho said she sees no possibility of using the RMB for cross-strait trade even if the NT dollar is excluded for such trade in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVITED TO ATTEND G-10 GROUP MINISTERIAL MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 24 (CNA) (By C.H. Lu and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's top trade official to the World Trade Organization (WTO) confirmed Thursday that Taiwan has been invited to participate in a G-10 Group agricultural ministers' meeting set for July 5 in Geneva.

Yen Ching-chang, ROC permanent representative to the WTO, said that he received a letter the same day from the Swiss delegation to the organization to invite Lee Ching-lung, chairman of the Council of Agriculture, to attend the gathering that will be presided over by Swiss President Joseph Deiss.
It is believed that this will be the highest-level meeting in which Taiwan will have participated in Geneva since the country became a WTO member in January 2002.

The G-10 Group, made up of Taiwan, Bulgaria, Israel, Iceland, Japan, Mauritius, Norway, Switzerland, South Korea and Liechtenstein, is aimed at protecting and advancing the agricultural interests of its members.

Noting that the main purpose of the forthcoming meeting is to consolidate the G-10 Group members' common negotiation stance and to show the group's political strength in agricultural talks, Yen said that due to the importance of the agricultural trade negotiations and the meeting, Taiwan's presence at the gathering is significant.

Lee's participation in the meeting with the Swiss president under the WTO mechanism also demonstrates the substantial interests that the island has gained from its WTO membership and the fruitful results of the efforts made by the island's delegation to the WTO in the past two years, he said.

Deiss, who is also minister of economic affairs, said in his invitation letter that as the negotiation mechanism of the Doha New Round trade talks is expected to be completed at the end of July and that the most important issues of agricultural trade talks have entered a critical stage, the forthcoming meeting will not only give the G-10 Group ministers' an opportunity to exchange their views, but will also give them an opportunity to discuss ways of strengthening their joint stance in the talks.
The president also expressed the hope that agricultural ministers of all the G-10 Group members will be able to participate in the meeting.

The G-10 Group members, which are all small agricultural countries that have been in a relatively weak position in trade talks, have adjusted their negotiation tactics in the past two days and have agreed that future agreements on agricultural talks should be reached by means of multilateral talks and that they will not accept all comprises made by other WTO members or groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA MAY BE SOURCE OF SUBMARINES TO BE SOLD TO TAIWAN: U.S. PAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 25 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Russia may be the source of eight diesel-powered submarines that Taiwan intends to buy from the United States, the Washington Times reported Friday.

Under a plan percolating in the Pentagon, the paper said, Russia would sell the United States eight very quiet Kilo-class submarines outfitted with Russian weapons but equipped with U.S. electronics and propulsion systems, which would eventually be sold to Taiwan.
Quoting a Pentagon official, the paper said, Russian President Vladimir Putin has quietly signed off on the deal on the condition that the submarines are sold to the United States.
"If the Americans resell them (to Taiwan), it's none of Russia's business," the Pentagon official quoted Putin as having told U.S. officials.
Other options call for using another European design or building the submarines from the U.S. Barbell-class diesel submarine design, the paper said.

The daily added that mainland China, which has commissioned several Kilo-class submarines into service in its navy, would vehemently object the sale of the submarines to Taiwan, as it has to all U.S. arms sales to Taiwan.
The submarine deal, however, is still being held up over cost estimates, the paper said.
The submarines were high on the agenda of a visiting Taiwanese legislative delegation, along with the island's plans to buy P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and Patriot PAC-3 antimissile batteries,

The delegation, headed by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, met with Pentagon and other senior U.S. officials in Washington, D.C. this week, including Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz. A key topic discussed was a novel way to build submarines for Taiwan. The United States has not built any conventional submarines for many years.
The delegation visited a Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile system at Fort Hood, Texas, and a P-3C base in Hawaii. The delegation also visited an Aegis battle-management-equipped warship in Pearl Harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. EXPECTED TO GIVE CONSENT TO NEW ROC REP TO ASSUME POST: MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 24 (CNA) (By Eric Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Tan Sun Chen said in New York Thursday that he foresees no problems with Washington consenting to David Ta-wei Lee as the new ROC representative to the United States.

The Bush administration is expected to give the green light to Lee to assume the post, Chen said, adding that the administration is currently pondering the appointment and that the process will require a little time.
Chen, who is on a visit around the United States, denied allegations that the Bush administration has been "procrastinating" in giving its consent for unknown reasons.
"Give them some time, " Chen said, adding that even Taipei spends some time considering the appointments of new U.S. envoys to Taiwan before granting consent.
Meanwhile, Chen clarified rumors circulating in the media that the ROC's formal diplomatic relations with Panama and Haiti are facing challenges because of Beijing's interference.

He noted that although Beijing has tried everything to try to win favor in Panama since the election of a new Panamanian president, bilateral ties between Taiwan and Panama are in good shape, adding that he sees no changes in that situation in the foreseeable future.

Panama and mainland China may have closer economic and trade ties following the new Panamanian administration taking office, but this does not necessarily mean that Panama will sever its formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan, Chen noted.

On relations with Haiti, Chen said that reliable sources have confirmed that bilateral ties between Taiwan and the Caribbean country are firm and will continue to be steady, although mainland China has contributed some peacekeeping troops to the country.

Chen also mentioned that Ministry of Foreign Affairs officials are making arrangements for Premier Yu Shyi-kun to make stopovers in the United States on his way to and from the Dominican Republic where he will attend the inauguration of the nation's newly-elected president next month.
It is still too early to speculate whether Premier Yu will make stopovers in New York or Washington, D.C., or both, Chen added.

A county government official said fishery resources in Taiwan's coastal areas have been dwindling because of poaching by mainland Chinese fishing boats in recent years. Worse still, the official said, mainland fishermen illegally use dragnets in their operations which has aggravated the decline of fishery resources in the region as dragnets also trap smaller fish.

The official said the county government hopes the program can help enhance local people's environmental awareness and lead them to work together with the government to conserve fishery and maritime resources as well as other natural resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR MORE EFFECTIVE ANTI-NARCOTICS STRATEGIES

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Saturday that the government should work out more effective strategies to prevent drug abuse and eradicate cross-border drug trafficking.
Chen made the call in a written message read at the opening ceremony of a national anti-narcotics conference.
In the message, Chen said drug trafficking has become ever more complex and that many new substitute lethal drugs have continued to hit the market.

"These trends have posed new challenges to our campaign against drug abuse and drug trafficking, " Chen said, adding that relevant government agencies should formulate more comprehensive and more effective strategies to contain drug abuse and drug trafficking.
Addressing the confernece, Premier Yu Shyi-kun echoed President Chen's view, saying that the government will devote full energies to fighting against drug abuse and the narcotics trade.
"We must set a timetable for achieving our goal in a specified period of time," Yu said.

The premier said that although law enforcement authorities have successfully busted many large drug trafficking rings, similar criminal operations have continued incessantly. Yu said relevant government agencies should place an equal emphasis on reducing the demand for contraband drugs.

"We should step up a publicity campaign to cut the number of drug abusers. At least we should try to prevent any person from becoming a new addict as drug abuse harms personal health and creates social problems," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, U.S. HAVE NEVER DISCUSSED OPTION OF BUYING RUSSIAN SUBS: MND

TEXT.P: Taiwan and U.S. officials have never discussed formally or informally the option of purchasing Russian-built Kilo-class submarines, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Saturday.
The ministry was responding to a Washington Times report a day earlier that the Pentagon is considering procuring eight very quiet Kilo-class submarines from Russia for resale to Taiwan.

Under a plan percolating in the Pentagon, the daily said, Russia would sell the United States eight Kilo-class submarines outfitted with Russian weapons but equipped with U.S. electronics and propulsion systems for eventual resale to Taiwan.
An MND spokesman said the ministry has never heard of such a plan.

"The option of purchasing Kilo-class submarines has never been brought up in our formal or informal talks with Pentagon officials, " the spokesman said, adding that the position papers the MND has presented to the Legislative Yuan and the news media have also never contained such a proposal.

The MND position papers have only mentioned that the eight conventional submarines the United States has agreed to sell to Taiwan are likely to be built by Spain, Germany or the United States itself, the spokesman said.

He acknowledged that the United States has been mulling over re-opening a production line to build new diesel subs for Taiwan based on its 1950s Barbell-class design after encountering difficulties obtaining conventional submarines on the international spot market. Out of concerns about upsetting Beijing, major countries that still build conventional subs have been reluctant to accept any Taiwan-related orders. The United States stopped building diesel submarines years ago.
The MND spokesman said that after the collapse of the Soviet Union, some arms brokers explored the possibility of selling Russian-made Kiol-class submarines and Su-27 fighter jets to Taiwan.

As the military has traditionally used American- and European-made weaponry systems, the spokesman said, the MND has never included any Russian-made arms into its list of options because of possible difficulties in subsequent repair and maintenance work.

The submarines are high on the agenda of a Taiwan legislative delegation which is in Washington, D.C., this week, as are the island's plans to buy P-3C anti-submarine aircraft and Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile batteries.

The delegation, headed by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, has met with Pentagon and other senior U.S. officials, including Deputy Defense Secretary Paul Wolfowitz, to discuss those arms procurement projects which the ROC military plans to carry out in a 15-year period.
The delegation visited a Patriot PAC-3 anti-missile system site in Fort Hood, Texas, and a P-3C base in Hawaii. It also visited an Aegis battle-management-equipped warship at Pearl Harbor.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSENSUS NEEDED IN TAX REFORM: FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lin Chuan said Saturday that a national consensus must be forged before any critical tax reform program can be implemented smoothly.
Lin made the remarks while delivering a lecture at Ketagalan Institute, a school founded by President Chen Shui-bian to nurture a new generation of leaders for public service.

Lin said Taiwan's income tax system doesn't comply with the general world trend. All major countries around the globe levy income taxes on their nationals regardless of their workplaces, while Taiwan doesn't levy income taxes on its citizens who work abroad.

"It's unfair, " Lin was quoted as having told Ketagalan students. Nevertheless, he added that tax reforms cannot succeed before a national consensus is forged and that all tax reform programs should be carried out in a gradual manner.
Lin also stressed the importance of crafting a fair tax system.
"Fairness is the most important as far as tax reforms are concerned, " he said, adding that tax hikes would definitely draw a backlash unless the existing tax system is modified to become fairer.

Lin further said the government's financial problems mainly lie with its structural budget deficits. The government's budget deficit zoomed from NT$608.4 billion in 1990 to NT$2.2 trillion in 2000 when the Democratic Progressive Party came to power for the first time after more than five decades of Kuomintang rule.
By now, Lin said, the government's budget deficit has further ballooned to NT$3.9 trillion.
"The government's financial situation has further deteoriated, and the issue can only be resolved by overhauling its long-term fiscal structure," Lin added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEMPORARY WORKERS RACE FOR FORMAL EMPLOYMENT

TEXT.P: With a view to gaining formal employment, more than 200 temporary workers of Taichung City Government's Environmental Protection Bureau took part in a grueling physical fitness test Saturday.
Bureau officials said that there are 32 vacancies for cleaners this year and that they intend to hire them from among the temporary workers it currently employs.

In the test, all the participants, both men and women, were required to run for 50 meters while carrying a 30-kg sandbag, with those with the top 32 times to be given formal employment, which would mean a pay raise of more than NT$10,000 (US$296.73) per month and other benefits commensurate to civil servants.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT, PFP PLAN TO FORM GRAND ALLIANCE TO WIN YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) chairman and the People First Party (PFP) chairman have come to a consensus regarding forming a grand alliance among their parties, the New Party and those non-partisan members who have similar views, to try to win the year-end legislative elections, a well-placed source said Saturday.
The source said that the consensus between KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong was reached after the two opposition leaders held a four-hour closed-door meeting Friday.

According to some KMT and PFP legislators, the purpose of creating such an alliance is to consolidate the opposition's forces and to form a majority in the Legislative Yuan by winning the year-end legislative elections.

Some PFP legislators also said that since it is difficult for the KMT and PFP to merge in a short period of time, the opposition forces have to unite to check and balance the power of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party.

The PFP legislators also attached great importance to the rapid creation of such an alliance under considerations of mutual respect, saying that each opposition party should better its coordination with other opposition parties on the total number of nominations of candidates for the year-end elections.

It is expected that the current KMT-PFP working platform will be enlarged and will include members of the New Party and other opposition groups after the formation of the planned alliance in order to have better cooperation among the opposition forces in the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MUST GEAR UP TO JOIN INTERNATIONAL TRADE GROUPS: CEPD CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taiwan must make every possible effort to join major international trade organizations or alliances lest it be marginalized amid the current economic globalization trend, the Cabinet's top economic planner said Saturday.

Addressing a meeting of senior business executives in the central city of Taichung, Hu Sheng-cheng, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said major countries around the world are forming various kinds of strategic economic alliances.

Because of mainland China's diplomatic embargo and boycott, Hu said, Taiwan has had a hard time joining those international groups. "We must use wisdom and creativity to make a breakthrough. Otherwise, our economy will be marginalized," he said.

In his view, Hu went on, signing bilateral free trade agreements (FTAs) can be an alternative for Taiwan in forging strategic economic alliances with other countries. Taiwan has so far only signed a free trade agreement with Panama. For fears of offending Beijing, Hu acknowledged, many countries that maintain formal diplomatic ties with mainland China are reluctant to sign free trade accords with Taiwan.

Against this backdrop, Hu said, the United States can play an crucial role in Taiwan's FTA drive. If Taiwan can sign a free trade pact with the United States, Hu said he believes other major countries would be more willing to negotiate similar agreements with Taiwan.
Hu said the government will continue to try hard to convince the United States to sign a free trade agreement with Taiwan.

As for Taiwan's economic prospects, Hu said, Taiwan must step up infrastructure construction and renovation as well as accelerate industrial upgrading and transformation in order to beef up the nation's competitiveness in the world market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, June 26, or the ninth day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
363: Roman emperor Julian the Apostate, the first non-Christian emperor since Constantine, dies of spear wounds inflicted during a battle with the Persians. He was 32.
1541: Francisco Pizarro, the Spanish conqueror of Peru who played a major part in crushing the Inca Empire, is attacked and killed in his house in Lima. He was 66.
1843: Hong Kong is proclaimed a British colony, with Sir Henry Pottinger as its first governor.
1844: John Tyler, the 10th president of the United States, who succeeded to office after the death of President William Henry Harrison, secretly marries Julia Gardiner in New York. His administration was marked by the annexation of Texas in 1845.
1858: The Treaty of Tientsin is signed, ending hostilities between China's Ching court and Britain and granting British trade rights.
1892: Pearl S. Buck, the American writer who won the 1938 Nobel Prize for literature, is born. Her life as a missionary in China lent a vivid immediacy to her novels, including "The Good Earth."
1907: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, receives an honorary doctorate from Oxford University. He drew on his childhood experiences along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1908: The U.S. Congress votes to return the so-called "Boxer Indemnity" in the amount of US$14.8 million. The money was used three years later to found Tsinghua School and to help finance Chinese students' studies in the United States.
1930: Joseph Stalin announces that his murderous purges are "purifying" the Soviet Union.
1945: Representatives from 50 nations including the Republic of China, one of the U.N. founding members, sign the United Nations Charter in San Francisco. The charter would become effective Oct. 24.
1956: The Tainan College of Technology in Taiwan is formally transformed into National Cheng Kung University.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Malagasy Republic.
1962: The United States declares it will not support any attempt by the ROC on Taiwan to land forces on the Chinese mainland.
1963: A million and a quarter West Berliners turn out to give a tumultuous welcome to U.S. President John F. Kennedy who addresses the 120,000-strong crowd in Rathaus Square near the Berlin Wall.
1975: Indian Prime Minister Indira Gandhi declares a state of emergency and arrests hundreds of political opponents.
1976: A strong earthquake rocks Irian Jaya province in Indonesia, killing more than 400 people.
1986: The ROC Executive Yuan announces that, due to opposition by Lukang residents, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has ordered a hold on the Du Pont Corporation's plan to construct a titanium dioxide plant in Lukang and the carrying out of an environmental impact study on the project.
1989: Student leaders who have escaped from the Chinese mainland after the Tiananmen Square massacre leave Hong Kong for exile to Western countries.
1991: Approval is given to 15 of 19 applications to set up private commercial banks in the Republic of China.
1992: A peoples' court in mainland China's Tsingtao sentences Li Hsienpin, an air force pilot who defected to Taiwan and later returned to the mainland, to 15 years in prison for "surrender to the enemy and mutiny."
1993: U.S. forces hit targets in Iraq following a failed assassination attempt on former U.S. President George Bush while he was visiting Kuwait in April.
1998: President Bill Clinton begins a state visit to mainland China in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, where a protest movement was brutally suppressed nine years earlier.
1999: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang leaves for Auckland, New Zealand, to attend an annual trade ministers meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
1999: The Ever Power IPP, Taiwan's first private power plant to use natural gas to generate power, is inaugurated at Luchu, Taoyuan County, in northern Taiwan.
2001: ROC Economics Minister Lin Hsin-yi signs an agreement with his Guatemalan counterpart, Marco A. Ventura, to help train youth from the Central American nation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the employment of people in forced labor on works for the public good, if you select those who are most able to bear it, who will have any cause for complaint?"

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESEARCHERS FIND 50 SUBSTANCES THAT KILL SARS VIRUS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan research team has found more than 50 substances that can kill the virus that causes severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS).

The research team was led by Dr. Wong Chi-huey, director of the Genome Research Center under the Academia Sinica, and their report has been published in the latest Proceedings of the National Academia of Sciences of the United States, according to Wong.

In addition to researchers from the Academia Sinica, Wong's research team consists of researchers from the National Defense University, National Taiwan University, National Tsinghua University and National Taipei University of Technology.

The work was not without risks. A researcher from the National Defense University became infected with the potentially fatal disease last December while in the laboratory. He recovered after being quarantined for two weeks.
In the last year, the researchers tested some 10,000 substances and found that about 50 of them were able to effectively check the reproduction of the SARS virus in the laboratory.

Some of the substances have already been used for other purposes, such as the early medication for high blood pressure called Reserpine, an anti-inflammatory drug called Aescin, and the insecticide Valinomycin.
Some substances were found in plants, including oil of eucalyptus and extract of honeysuckle and ginseng.
Wong's team combined two drugs used in the treatment of AIDS and found that they were not only effective in killing the SARS virus but also in treating cats suffering from AIDS.
AIDS is a common disease among cats in the United States, affecting almost 20 percent of the cat population there, Wong said.

Noting that pharmaceutical companies might not be interested in developing a drug used exclusively for the treatment of SARS because of the relative small market, Wong said the synthetic drugs created by his team have caught the interest of many foreign pharmaceutical companies because of their potential in treating AIDS in human beings and cats, as well as SARS.
Wong said his team is cooperating with the Development Center for Biotechnology in hopes that their drugs will be commercially developed one day.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABORIGINES HAVE UNFAIR ADVANTAGE IN MILITARY ACADEMIES: LEGISLATORS

TEXT.P: A program to aide aboriginal youths to seek higher education in military academies has resulted in giving them access to the choicest departments for study and the situation is crowding out non-indigenous students, two lawmakers claimed Sunday.

Legislators Lin Chin-hsing and Lee Chen-nan of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party said that parents of non-aboriginal students have complained that the system that awards aborigines with extra points on their military academy entrance exams is unfair.
The legislators asked that relevant governmental agencies look into the matter and establish a fairer policy to enter military academies.

According to Lin, nine out of the top 20 scorers in this year's military academy joint entrance exam were aborigines who scored high enough to enter the most prestigious departments because of the bonus points privilege.
Because of this, they were able to enter the most coveted departments, such as law, Lin said.

Legislator Lee, meanwhile, said that some non-aboriginal parents have complained that some of the "aboriginal" students are actually not aborigines at all, and that some of them were born in cities and don't even know an aboriginal language. The only thing aborigine about them is found on their identification cards that indicates their ethnic origins.
Lee called for the government and the Ministry of National Defense to work out a fairer testing policy that satisfies both sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MINDULLE LIKELY TO AFFECT TAIWAN: CWB

TEXT.P: Typhoon Mindulle, the seventh of this year in the Pacific area, is likely to affect Taiwan in the following couple of days, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Sunday.

The CWB will issue a sea warning Monday morning at the earliest if the tropical storm keeps moving in a west-northwesterly direction at the current speed of 18 kilometers per hour, CWB meteorologists said.

With a radius of 150 kilometers and packing maximum sustained winds of up to 30 meters per second, the typhoon was centered about 800 kilometers east-northeast of Manila at 6: 00 p.m., moving north-north-easterly toward Taiwan at a speed which was slowing down from 18 to 12 kilometers per hour, they added.

Meanwhile, another typhoon dubbed Tingting was located about 2,000 kilometers from Taiwan and was moving west-northwesterly at a speed of 18 kilometers per hour, the meteorologists said, adding that it is still too early to tell whether the tropical storm will affect Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT VOWS TO MAKE SUITABLE CONSTITUTION FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian vowed Sunday to make a suitable and feasible constitution for Taiwan in the coming four years.

Speaking at a meeting of the Tainan County Natives Association in Taipei, Chen, who was also born in the southern Taiwan county, said that a suitable and feasible constitution will make Taiwan "a great, normal and beautiful country."
Chen encouraged the participants of the meeting to continue to support his administration and to be confident in the nation's future development.

Many economic indicators show that Taiwan's economy has been steadily recovering and the country's international competitiveness has been increasing, he noted, adding that the economic and financial reforms initiated by his administration have produced fruits.
During the campaign for his re-election, Chen promised that a new constitution would be written and vetted through a referendum by 2006 and then put into effect in 2008.
