DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTIES PROPOSE EXTRA LEGISLATIVE SESSION IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: The opposition Kuomintang (KMT) and People First Party (PFP) have proposed an extraordinary legislative session be held August 16, a KMT official said Sunday.

Tseng Yung-chuan, executive director of the KMT Central Policy Department, said that both the KMT and its political ally, the PFP, hope the extraordinary session will deal with the establishment of a task force to investigate and get to the bottom of the March 19 shooting of President Chen Shui-bian and Vice President Annette Lu, and the establishment of a task force to look into the activation of the national security mechanism after the shooting.

The proposed extra legislative session should also discuss revisions to the Republic of China Constitution for halving the 225-member legislature because a four-month grace period for a vote on the issue after the political parties failed to reach a consensus on it expired on July 23, Tseng noted.

The opposition parties will also agree to discuss other issues initiated by the ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the extra legislative session, including the budget allocations for the new 10 major construction projects, he added.
Premier Yu Shyi-kun called on the Legislative Yuan June 11 when the legislature concluded its regular session to open an extraordinary session to deal with some urgent bills.
The premier said that the accumulated number of bills mired in the legislature has reached 303.
He said that the lack of legislative action will hamper the governing of his administration unless some urgent bills are enacted during an extraordinary session.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUBMARINES TO BE PARTLY MADE AT HOME REMAINS UNCHANGED: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan has not changed its resolution to have the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) be involved in the building of the eight submarines to be ordered from the United States, Chen Chi- mai, a spokesman for the Executive Yuan said Sunday.

Five days after U.S. Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul Wolfowitz told a group of visiting Republic of China legislators in Washington, D.C. that it would be wrong to let the CSBC play a role in the building of the submarines, Chen said the Executive Yuan will contact Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, who is leading the group, to learn more of the attitude of the United States on the issue.
The submarines are part of a proposed NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) arms purchase from the United States.

Legislators from Kaohsiung are insisting on having the Kaohsiung-based CSBC build parts of the submarines to create more jobs in their constituencies. But Wolfowitz reportedly scuppered the idea on the grounds that it would postpone the delivery of the submarines to the detriment of Taiwan's defense and would impose on the U.S. an extra obligation of transferring part of the work and, therefore, the technology of the submarines to Taiwan. (By Maubo Chang) ENDTIEM/mw

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS COMPETITIVENESS LIES IN INNOVATION: FORMER VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: The competitiveness of a business lies in its ability to innovate and improve itself, Lin Hsin-i, a senior adviser to the president and former vice premier said Sunday in Kaohsiung.

Speaking at a seminar organized by the Ketagelan Institute in Kaohsiung, Lin attributed the current plight of Taiwan businesses -- closures and relocations to the mainland -- to aweakening of competitiveness.

He said many chief executive officers are reluctant to institute changes or examine their businesses and make needed improvements, because doing so would be a denial of the past. However, these steps are vital for keeping a company viable for the future since there is not a single solution that can cope with the ever-changing market and situations that are liable to shift without notice.
Businessmen should keep in mind that the strategy that brings them success today won't necessarily guarantee success in the future, Lin said.

Lin's speech was the highlight of the three-day seminar that ended Sunday. It was one of the programs of the Ketagelan Institute to spread the political advocacy of President Chen Shui-bian, who set up the institute.

DOC.HEADLINE: V.P. HAS FUN WITH FOREIGN BRIDES IN CHIAYI SUMMER SOLSTICE FESTIVAL

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu traveled to the southern county of Chiayi Sunday to join the Asian Music Festival dedicated to marking the summer solstice.
Lu met with more than 500 foreign brides and their families during the festival in which bands, choirs and musicians from Indonesia, Japan, Iran, Mongolia and Taiwan showed off their talent.

The Asian Music Festival, the first of its kind in Chiayi, has been going on since June 19 under the sponsorship of the Chiayi County Government as part of activities marking the upcoming opening of the Tropic of Cancer Solar Museum in Chiayi.

The summer solstice, which fell on June 21, is the day the sun is furthest north of the equator. Chiayi County's Shuishang rural township is exactly where the Tropic of Cancer passes when the summer solstice occurs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO ALLOW IN PROCESSED CHICKEN FROM PANAMA: NEWSPAPER REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 24 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will soon open its market to processed chicken from Panama in accordance with the two countries' efforts to expand bilateral trade and investment under a free trade agreement (FTA) that took effect in January this year, according to a recent report by La Prensa, a Panama-based daily newspaper.

Group Melo will soon be allowed to export its processed chicken to Taiwan after it gains green light from the Taiwan authorities, and it would mark the first time that Panama will ship its chicken-related products to the Taiwan market, the report said, adding that Taiwan will first send quarantine personnel to inspect the chicken-raising farms prior to the shipments.

The report quoted Group Melo as estimating that it could export about US$2 million of processed chicken to Taiwan per year. Group Chairman Arturo Melo was cited as saying that production facilities on his farms are ready to begin processing goods for Taiwan and that he is waiting for approval by officials from Taiwan.
According to Melo, Panama is permitted to export 900 metric tons of poultry products free of custom duties to Taiwan each year under the terms of the Taiwan-Panama FTA.

He stressed that his products will be very competitive in price and quality in the Taiwan market and noted that chicken is the first Panama product to gain approval from Taiwan for export after the two countries inked the FTA last year.
In the past, Taiwan only allowed in beef, pork, seafoods and noni fruit from Panama. The FTA will permit Panama to ship large amounts of other goods to Taiwan.

Citing statistics compiled by the Panamanian Ministry of Commerce and Industry, La Prensa reported that the value of the country's outbound shipments to Taiwan in the first five months of this year had already topped US$5 million, a similar level to the figure recorded for the whole of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY PROCUREMENT PLAN DISCUSSED WITH U.S.: LEGISLATIVE HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 26 (CNA) (By Chiang Ying and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan lawmakers have exchanged opinions with the United States about Taiwan's major military procurement plan and have also made clear Taiwan's strong determination to safeguard its national security, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said in San Francisco Saturday.

Wang made the remarks during a meeting with about 70 members of the main opposition Kuomintang's branch in San Francisco on the last leg of a U.S. tour by a legislative delegation headed by the Legislative Yuan speaker.
The mission has over the past week met with U.S. officials and congressmen to gain a better understanding on the procurement program worth billions of dollars from the United States.

According to Wang, they have asked the United States to re-assess the prices of the weapons that are included in the package, which includes eight diesel-fueled submarines, anti-submarine aircraft and anti-missile batteries, and shorten the delivery time.

In addition to expressing his satisfaction with the trip, Wang said that they also made it clear to the United States that Taiwan was serious about increasing its national security by upgrading the country's defense capabilities through stepped up cooperation with the United States.

Saying that the Legislative Yuan will further screen and have a final say on the items on the procurement list, Wang added that he hoped that the United States would give a positive response to their requirements.

The huge expenditure for the military procurement plan put forward by the Ministry of National Defense for legislative approval carries a price tag of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) and has created much concern from the public.

The NT$400 billion allocated for the eight conventional submarines is the most disputed section of the procurement plan, deliveries of which have been demanded by the legislative mission to be reduced from the current estimated time of 15 years to 10 years.
The legislative delegation is slated to leave San Francisco Sunday for Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, June 27, or the 10th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1801: British troops defeat a French militia force and take control of Cairo, Egypt.
1829: James Smithson, British chemist, mineralogist and philanthropist, dies in Genoa, Italy, at the age of 64. He helped establish the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.
1880: Helen Keller, American teacher, social worker, and writer, who was deaf and blind from birth, is born.
1893: A major stock market plunge begins in the United States, leading to a depression. By the end of 1893, 600 banks and 74 railroads had gone out of business.
1926: Chiang Kai-shek, who became commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces on June 5, launches the Northern Expedition from Canton.
1939: Pan American Airways operates the first scheduled transatlantic air service by the Dixie Clipper, a 19-seat flying boat, leaving Port Washington, New York, for Marseilles in France.
1945: Premier and Foreign Minister T. V. Soong, accompanied by Deputy Foreign Minister Hu Shih-tse, Shen Hung-lieh and Chiang Ching-kuo, leave for Moscow to discuss matters concerning the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship and Alliance.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders US forces into battle to aid South Korea following an invasion across the 38th parallel by North Korean troops.
1950: US President Harry Truman orders the US 7th Fleet to prevent a communist attack on Taiwan and asks the ROC government to cease air and sea operations against the mainland.
1953: Some 30,000 ROC government troops stranded on Dao Fhu Quoc (Fukuo Island) off the coast of South Vietnam begin returning to Taiwan.
1954: The world's first nuclear power station is opened at Obninsk in the Soviet Union, about 55 miles from Moscow.
1973: Dr. Chester W. Clark, new American commissioner of the Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction, arrives in Taipei.
1975: Some 1,000 ROC military leaders conclude a five-day conference on modernizing Taiwan's military equipment and strategy.
1976: Six Palestinians hijack an Air France Airbus from Athens, Greece with 246 passengers and 12 crew onboard and force it to fly to Entebbe, Uganda, where Israeli commandos storm it on July 4.
1977: The Kaohsiung steel mill of China Steel Corp. begins production. The construction of the integrated steel mill was financed by a US$200 million loan from the Continental Illinois National Bank and the Trust Company of Chicago.
1979: The Republic of China's first "buy American" mission of the year, led by H.K. Shao, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade, departs with a shopping list for goods worth US$850 million.
1982: Broad gauge trains begin to operate on the widened railroad on the east coast area between Hualien and Taitung.
1986: The 1986 National Administration Conference opens in Taipei. More than 260 government officials and specialists attend the meeting.
1988: Intrepid British mountain climbers Dave Hurst and Alan Matthews become the first blind climbers to reach the summit of Mont Blanc in Switzerland, Europe's highest mountain at 4,810 meters.
1989: Another wave of refugee boats from Vietnam hits Hong Kong, where closed refugee camps are already bulging with 45,000 "boat people."
1991: Government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming announces that mainland Chinese journalists will no longer have to renounce their membership in the Chinese Communist Party when applying to visit Taiwan.
1998: US President Bill Clinton and Chinese President Jiang Zemin hold a press conference in Beijing. The two leaders clash over dissidents, the Dalai Lama, and the Tiananmen Square massacre.
1999: George Papadopoulos, Greek military officer and politician who became premier after a 1967 coup, dies at the age of 80. He was overthrown in 1973.
1999: A Republic of China congressional delegation led by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng leaves for a visit to Macedonia.
2000: The Legislative Yuan adopts a special resolution requiring the government to reduce the number of foreign laborers in Taiwan starting next year.
2001: A total of 175 illegal mainland Chinese immigrats are repatrated from Fu Su Port on the frontline island of Matsu through arrangement by the Red Cross Societies of Taiwan and mainland China.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Make it your aim to wish for moral well-being and you will never be accused of being covetous."

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Simplicity & austerity policy declared
President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo has asked Cabinet officials to pursue a policy of "simplicity and austerity in governance" and set the example for others in government to follow.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Royal guests, VIPs to attend inaugural
"FRUGAL" and "simple"-two words being used to describe the forthcoming inaugural of the 14th President of the Philippines-do not apply to the guest list which includes one of the world's richest men, Brunei Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah.
The Philippine Star: Erap to FPJ: Don't give up fight
Former President Joseph Estrada called on his bosom buddy, defeated presidential candidate Fernando Poe Jr., to continue the fight to question the legitimacy of the recent proclamation of President Arroyo.
The Manila Times: Noynoy in Speaker race
Representatives Benigno "Noynoy" Aqui-no 3rd and Danny Suarez loom as the likely conten-ders of the Liberal Party for the speakership of the House of Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Washington Post: Group Threatens Marine Hostage; 2 Americans Killed In Incidents in Iraq.
The Arab satellite TV network al-Jazeera aired a videotape Sunday from a group threatening to kill a U.S. Marine it claimed to have captured by luring him from his post, and two Americans and several Iraqi boys were among those killed across the country in a succession of attacks.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MINDULLE APPROACHING TAIWAN BUT AT SLOWER PACE: CWB

TEXT.P: Typhoon Mindulle, the seventh of this year in the Pacific area, has continued to move towards Taiwan since Sunday, although its pace has slowed down a bit, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Monday.

The weather bureau will issue a sea warning at around 2 p.m. at the earliest if the typhoon continues moving in a west-northwesterly direction towards Taiwan at its current speed of 14-10 kilometers per hour, CWB meteorologists said.

With a radius of 250 kilometers and packing maximum sustained winds of up to 48 meters per second, the typhoon was centered about 690 kilometers southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi at 8 a.m. Monday, they said.
The weather bureau warned that Typhoon Mindulle may bring a considerable amount of rainfall to Taiwan when it is nearest to the island between Wednesday and Thursday.

Meanwhile, another typhoon dubbed Tingting was located about 370 kilometers northeast from Guam and moving northwesterly at a speed of 19 kilometers per hour as of 8 a.m. Monday, the meteorologists said, adding that it is still too early to tell whether the typhoon will affect Taiwan.

The meteorologists are warning of high temperatures in Taiwan over the next few days, with highs of 35 degrees Celsius forecast for around the island and thunder showers for north and northeastern areas.
The weather bureau has also warned that the ultra-violet ray index around Taiwan will be high for the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Nation: Media mayhem: Academics:PM must act.
Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra needs to issue an executive order to prevent state-owned television stations from further undermining the authority of the yet-to-be-formed National Broadcasting Commission (NBC) and to prepare them fro far-reaching reform, academics, independent programme producers and media activitists said over weekend. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-U.S. COMMUNICATIONS BECOMING EVER SMOOTHER: SPEAKER

TEXT.P: Communications between Taiwan and the United States have become ever smoother, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Monday.
Wang made the remarks upon his return from an 11-day visit to the United States at the head of a legislative delegation to discuss Taiwan's arms procurement projects.
Wang said his mission received high-level treatment throughout the visit.

"We feel that the U.S. government fully respects Taiwan's legislators and that most of our questions have received answers, " Wang said, adding that the United States has agreed to calculate the price of its submarine sale to Taiwan in terms of "tonnage."

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL WINS BEST AIRLINE AWARDS IN MANCHESTER AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines won two major awards Monday from the Manchester International Airport of Britain after being selected as the"best overall airline"and"best cargo airline"in the airport's Skyliners Awards competition this year.
The presentation of the awards took place Monday at the Manchester Airport. Ma Lung-kuang, a senior division chief in charge of CAL's flight operations, received the awards on behalf of his company.
The Skyliners Awards, now in its sixth year, was held by Manchester Airport to promote noise control and environmental protection. There were 30 awards presented this year.

From among 90 international airlines that operate regular alights to Manchester Airport, CAL was selected as winner of two major awards because of its strict adherence to the standard operating procedures of Manchester Airport when approaching and leaving the airport. This is the first time a Taiwanese air carrier has won such honors in the United Kingdom.

China Airlines inaugurated its Manchester cargo service in April 2002. The Taipei-Manchester route now operates three weekly flights using B747-4000F Freighters. The Manchester route also has a stop in Delhi, India, making CAL The only Taiwanese carrier operating between Delhi and Manchester.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG AIRPORT MOVE TO TAICHUNG COUNTY GOVERNMENT POLICY: CAA

TEXT.P: Relocating Taichung's airport from Taichung City to Taichung County is the policy of the government and the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) is working in tune with this government policy, CAA officials said Monday.

The officials were responding to legislators' questions about the airport's move from the Shuinan district of the city to Chingchuankang in Taichung County in early March, which they claimed has led to a declining passenger rate.

They cited UNI Airways Corp. as an example. UNI Airways officials said that as the supply outstrips demand and the passenger rate is too low, it has applied to the CAA to stop servicing the Taipei-Taichung route.
CAA officials said that they had agreed to the airline's application to stop the route July 1 and will now coordinate with Mandarin Airlines to add some flights.
They cited figures from the first five months of this year to show that in January, the passenger rate averaged 32,000, a figure that dropped to 17,000 in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVENT LISTING FOR JUNE 29 IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The following are major events scheduled to take place Tuesday, June 29:
09: 20, A joint promotion ceremony for generals of the armed forces will be held at the Military Officers Club in Taipei.
10:00, The Green Construction Awards ceremony will be held at the Ministry of the Interior's headquarters.

10:30, Department chiefs of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs will hold a press conference at the ministry's headquarters.

15: 30, Premier Yu Shyi-kun will receive U.S. Congressman Scott McInnis at the Executive Yuan.

16: 30, The Bureau of Monetary Affairs under the Ministry of Finance will hold a regular press conference at the ministry's headquarters.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER ARRIVES IN ROME FOR VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, July 27 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen arrived in Rome Sunday for a brief two-day visit to the Vatican -- the ROC's only diplomatic ally in Europe.
Chen flew from New York to Rome after concluding a two-week visit to the United States. This is Chen's first trip to Europe since he assumed office in April.
Noting that the European Union has recently been enlarged from 15 states to 25 states, Chen said the E.U. will be an important focus of Taiwan's diplomatic work.
"We must go wherever the markets are, " Chen said, adding that the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs will give priority to promoting exchanges and cooperation with E.U. member states.
Chen was greeted by ROC Ambassador to the Vatican Tu Chu-sheng and Lin Chi-cheng, the ROC's representative to Italy. Chen was granted courteous VIP treatment at the Rome international airport.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES AWARDED BY MANCHESTER AIRPORT

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's biggest carrier, has been named the Best Overall Airline and the Best Cargo Airline by Manchester Airport in the United Kingdom, according to a Monday press release from CAL's Taipei headquarters.
A CAL executive was in Manchester to receive the awards on behalf of the airline.
CAL, which began cargo flights to Manchester in April 2002, was chosen from among 90 airlines that use the airport on a regular basis.
CAL, which uses Boeing 747-400F all-cargo planes on the route, operates three flights per week to Manchester.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING DOES NOT WANT EXTERNAL CRISIS: U.S. NEWSPAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 27 (CNA) (By Lin Wen-chi and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland China is tough on Taiwan and Hong Kong because it has a lot of internal problems and an external crisis is the last thing it wants, a columnist wrote in Sunday's Washington Post.
David S. Broder made the comments in an article titled "The Chinese Divide, " in which he noted that the gap between the cities and countryside in mainland China is getting worse.

He cited retired economist Mao Yushi as saying that "China is splitting into two countries, " with the cities developing rapidly under the policies of market capitalism while the countryside is unchanged or falls further behind.

Mao was quoted as saying that if the hope of democracy lies in the growing urban middle class, the danger of a backlash stems from the dead weight of the two-thirds of the population still stuck in the rural past.

Broder also wrote that Beijing "is trying to slow the double-digit growth of the past few years and bring it to a 'soft landing' before what some see as a 'bubble' economy, fueled by foreign investment and a huge construction boom, explodes."

"The roaring economy is depleting China's resources -- and threatening worldwide inflation in oil, steel and other commodities," the article said, adding that pollution has come with the rapid economic growth.

Equally evident is social strain created by the high-speed economic revolution, with a graying population and a social security system that can only cover a small fraction of urban workers and almost no-one in rural areas.

The family structure that has been the linchpin of Chinese society for centuries is under severe stress, the article says, quoting a recent mainland newspaper report that two-thirds of urban youngsters are being raised by their grandparents because both parents work.
With so many internal problems, mainland leaders "do not need -- and say they do not want -- any external crises," the article says.

"That is why, they said, they have drawn a hard line against any dramatic steps toward democratic elections in Hong Kong, and it is why they talk constantly with visitors about the 'threats' of a move toward independence by Taiwan's President Chen Shui-bian. China has declared it would oppose any such move 'at any cost.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CALLS FOR BIGGER ROLE FOR DCS

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu proposed Monday a greater role for the Distinguished Citizen Society (DCS) and urged it to open branches in foreign countries as a means of helping the government cement foreign relations and provide volunteer services.

Lu made the call during a DCS-sponsored award ceremony at the Presidential Office, in which scores of representatives from college student associations dedicated to social service work across the country were cited for their outstanding performance.

In addition to praising the students for their charity work, Lu urged the DCS to expand its horizons by setting up chapters in the 26 countries that maintain diplomatic ties with Taiwan, to assist the government in forging closer foreign relations and providing volunteer and public services in the international community.

The DSC has devoted itself to social welfare services since its establishment in 1968, Lu noted, and she said that the organization should play a bigger role by "extending its reach to the diplomatic arena." She did not elaborate.

Lu also appealed for enthusiastic participation by the Taiwan people in her proposal for sponsoring poor children in Guatemala, and encouraged especially college students to take part in the campaign, which was initiated by the vice president after she returned home last month from a tour of three Central American diplomatic allies.
Only NT$10,000 (about US$300) a year will be sufficient to help a Guatemalan child live without worry, according to Lu.

She wished all the students a bright future and said they should continue to keep their precious virtue of knowing how to love and care for others after entering society because, she said, "life is a true lesson that is worthy of learning by everyone."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO SERVE AS ENVOY AT DOMINICAN PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Premier Yu Shyi-kun has been appointed by President Chen Shui-bian to attend the Dominican Republic's presidential inauguration in August, Executive Yuan spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Monday.
Yu will participate in the inauguration of President-elect Leonel Fernandez Reyna slated for Aug. 16 on behalf of the president.

It remains undecided whether Yu will also visit other countries in the region, Chen said, adding that the premier's itinerary will be decided after the Executive Yuan holds consultations with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
"The major purpose of Yu's upcoming trip will be to attend the presidential inauguration," he said.
Fernandez defeated incumbent President Rafael Hipolito Mejia Dominquez in the May 17 presidential election and will assume the presidency from 2004 to 2008.
The Dominican Republic is one of the 26 countries that maintain diplomatic relations with Taipei in stead of Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA PUBLISHES ALBUM TO MARK 80TH ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: The Central News Agency (CNA) published an album Monday to mark its 80th founding anniversary and the July 1 eighth anniversary of its conversion into a state agency independent of any political group.
Coinciding with the launch of the album was the issuance of a set of commemorative stamps made with 10 of the photos in the album.

CNA President Hu Yuan-hui said the 300 photos included in the album, titled "Six Decades of Taiwan, " were picked from more than a million historical photos accumulated by the agency in its 80-year history.

According to Hu, the album is different from other books of this kind, as it features photos showing the daily lives of the Taiwan people and their land rather than providing a graphic record of the activities of governments and officials.

Mark Ou, deputy editor-in-chief of CNA and the executive editor of the album, said the book depicts the changes in the lives of ordinary people, not official events, and therefore bears witness to the people's emotions.

As a news agency whose history is closely interwoven with that of the country, CNA has seen the same ups and downs as the rest of the country and its fate has converged with that of Taiwan ever since it sent its first correspondent to Taipei in 1945 at the end of World War Two and began sending out stories from Taipei, Hu went on.
Therefore, Hu said, the album is actually a pictorial record of Taiwan of the last six decades.
Sixty of the photos are on display in the agency's newly-opened gallery, the Buena Vista, in an exhibition that will last until July 30.

Hu said CNA is approaching the United Daily News and the China Times as well as other news media and research institutes, with a proposal to pool their photos together and make them available to subscribers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WANTS SUBMARINE REPAIR, TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER

TEXT.P: Discussions about whether the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC) should take part in the construction of submarines that the United States has promised to sell to Taiwan have taken a U-turn, ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators said Monday.

Ker Chien-ming, the DPP whip at the legislature, made the remarks after a delegation of legislators completed an 11-day fact-finding trip to the United States and Navy Commander-in-Chief Miao Yung-ching called on the Legislative Yuan to communicate on the review of the arms procurement budget of which the submarine deal is a part.

The Executive Yuan submitted a NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) special budget to buy 388 Patriot PAC-III missiles, eight conventional submarines and 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft from the United States earlier this month, and the budget is now pending approval by the Legislative Yuan.

According to Miao, it is not feasible for CSBC to take part in the construction of the submarines and the navy will negotiate with the United States on obtaining repair capacity and technology transfers, said Ker.
Miao said that no countries want to buy conventional submarines, which would make it futile to give the CSBC the capacity to build them.
Moreover, the United States has control of the key technology in building the submarines, Miao said.

Lee Wen-chung, another DPP legislator, said that the delegation asked the United States to shorten the delivery period of the submarines from 15 years to 10 years, which reveals that Taiwan has already given up the policy of building the submarines itself.

He said that if the submarines are not built by Taiwan, and based on the price tags of submarines sold by Germany and Spain together with the cost of obtaining repair capacity, then the cost of the eight subs will be NT$100 billion less than the original plan of NT$400 billion.

When asked if the long delivery period of 10 years might affect Taiwan's military strength and tip the military cross-Taiwan Strait balance toward mainland China after 2005, Lee said that although the naval military balance could tilt toward Beijing after 2005, it does not mean that there will be an eruption of war by that time.

Taiwan still enjoys the edge in the air, Lee claimed, and an order of Kidd-class destroyers will arrive at Taiwan by the end of next year, which, he said, means that Taiwan can still maintain its edge until then.
He also said that the United States will deliver the first of 12 P-3C aircraft in 2008, with another three in 2009, four in 2010 and the final four in 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEA WARNING ISSUED FOR WATERS OFF SOUTHEAST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: With typhoon Mindulle, the seventh of this year in the Pacific area, moving toward the Bashi Channel, the Central Weather Bureau issued a sea warning Monday afternoon for ships in the Bashi Channel and waters off southeast Taiwan.

Weathermen said that the location of Mindulle at that time was 600 kilometers southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi, moving west northwest at 10 kph and packing maximum sustained winds of up to 43 meters per second.
It is expected that the location by Tuesday afternoon will be around 390 km southeast of Oluanpi, they added.
The meteorologists said that there are heavy seas along the coasts of eastern Taiwan and the Hengchun peninsula, and said that the public should refrain from going near the seaside.
In addition, the radius of typhoon Mindulle is wide and its strength could strengthen slowly to affect land areas, they added.
The weathermen said they will make further assessments Tuesday but estimated that the typhoon will be close to Taiwan by Thursday or Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW JOINT VENTURE LAUNCHED TO PROMOTE AGRICULTURAL EXPORTS

TEXT.P: A new company funded with joint investment by the Tainan county government and 22 farmer's associations in the southern Taiwan county, as well as private investors, was inaugurated Monday to promote agricultural exports.
Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-chih said at Nanying Agriculture Trading Co.'s inaugural ceremony that the new joint venture will initially focus on tapping Japan's farm produce market.

Noting that Japan's population is six-fold Taiwan's and its per capita national income is three times that of Taiwan, Su said there is great market potential for the county's agricultural products. Tainan County is one of Taiwan's largest agricultural production centers.

Su said Japan's Mitsubishi Group has placed an order with Nanying to purchase 1,300 tons of mangoes. The amount marks an 18-fold growth compared with Taiwan's total mango exports to Japan last year, he added.

Su said Nanying will also try to sell other seasonal fruits, such as lychees, papayas and melons, to Japan. In the future, he added, Nanying will expand its agricultural export markets to many other countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER: ARMS PURCHASES TOO SLOW TO BE HELPFUL

TEXT.P: Proposed arms purchases from the United States is too slow to be helpful in light of the urgent threat the country is facing from mainland China, opposition Kuomintang (KMT) lawmaker Liao Wan-ju said Monday.

Liao, who had just returned from a visit to the United States where she was briefed by U.S. officials on the proposed arms deal, said U.S. intelligence claims that Beijing could intimidate Taiwan with force on a small scale either in 2006 or 2008. She added that the arms intended to preempt this threat will not be ready before then.

Quoting U.S. sources, Liao said the first of eight submarines listed in the proposed arms purchase plan will not be delivered until 2013, with the first seven of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft delivered in 2009 and the remainder in 2011. Even 388 Patriot Advanced Capability-3 missiles will take two years to be delivered, she added.

She also expressed concern over the prices demanded by the United States for the weapons, especially the eight submarines. "We should not be forced to accept whatever price is requested by Washington" when it is much higher than prices asked by other countries, she said.
"Taiwan has been forced to buy expensive weapons in the past that proved to have been relatively useless, so we have to think carefully before we make decisions," she went on.

A budget of US$18.23 billion for the proposed arms purchases is pending review at the Legislative Yuan and the United States, which is eager to cinch the deal, invited a group of lawmakers including Liao earlier this month to visit Washington to attempt to woo their support for the deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT INVITES JCI VICE PRESIDENT TO ATTEND TAIWAN CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu Monday invited Harish Kumar, vice president of Junior Chamber International (JCI) , to come to Taiwan to attend the second Democratic Pacific Assembly in Taiwan in August.

Lu extended the invitation to Kumar and other JCI officials to attend the assembly of the Democratic Pacific Union, which was founded by Lu, in the hope that it will promote understanding between JCI members in the Asia and Pacific region.
Kumar, accompanied by Francis Lee, president of the Taiwan Junior Chamber, was visiting Lu at the Presidential Office.
Lu expressed hope that Kumar will help promote cooperation and exchanges between Taiwan and India.

For his part, Kumar said he would like to promote regional cooperation and exchanges, especially since the Taiwan Junior Chamber is soliciting to host the Asia-Pacific Conference in 2007, an event sponsored by the JCI.

Noting that there will be more than 5,000 members participating in the Asia-Pacific Conference, he said that if the Taiwan Junior Chamber can host the event, it will promote international understanding and cooperation and will boost Taiwan's diplomatic and trade development.

Lu noted that the Taiwan Junior Chamber nurtures a lot of what she described as "elite" members of society, and that President Chen Shui-bian was once a member. She added that the government will always support Taiwan Junior Chamber activities, especially in its efforts to obtain hosting rights for the Asia-Pacific Conference in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
New York Times: Iraq group issues threat to behead a missing marine.
A militant Iraqi group threatened Sunday night an American marine it said it had abducted from a military base unless the United States released all Iraqi prisoners, according to a video broadcast on the Qatar-based television network Al Jazeera. The video shows a man identified as Cpl. Wassef Ali Hassoun sitting on the ground in desert-patterned camouflage fatigues, with a thick blindfold over his eyes and a long, curved sword held over his head. Marine officials said Sunday night that Corporal Hassoun, who is of Lebanese descent, has been missing since June 21.
The Wall Street Journal: In surprise move, coalition transfers power in Iraq early.
The U.S.-led coalition transferred sovereignty to an interim Iraqi government Monday, speeding the move by two days in an apparent bid to surprise insurgents who may have tried to sabotage the step toward self rule. Although the interim government will have full sovereignty, it will operate under major restrictions -- some of them imposed at the urging of the influential Shiite clergy which sought to limit the powers of an un-elected administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REAFFIRMS NO CHANGE TO POLICY ON CROSS-STRAIT ECONOMIC TIES

TEXT.P: The government's "active opening, effective management" policy on commercial exchanges across the Taiwan Strait has remained unchanged, a senior mainland affairs official said Monday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Chiu Tai-san made the remarks after former President Lee Teng-hui said a day earlier that many of the difficulties Taiwan business people are now facing can be attributed to the government's failure to fully implement his "no haste, be patient" policy.

Chiu said the government's policy on cross-strait commercial exchanges was altered from the Lee administration's "no haste, be patient" to "active opening, effective management" in 2001 in line with the conclusions reached at a cross-party national economic development conference.

In his view, Chiu said the "active opening, effective management" strategy largely complies with the basic spirit of "no haste, be patient" while accommodating some amendments needed to facilitate Taiwan companies' global business expansion following Taiwan's admission to the World Trade Organization.

The Democratic Progressive Party administration's "active opening, effective management" policy is aimed at opening the door wider for cross-strait commercial exchanges while formulating effective measures to administer such exchanges to maintain market order and stability.

Addressing a seminar on Taiwanese business people's westward or cross-strait investment activities organized by pro-independence think tanks, Lee said Beijing should stop intimidating Taiwanese businessmen operating on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALLIANCE ISSUES STATEMENT TO OPPOSE NT$610.8 BILLION U.S. ARMS DEAL

TEXT.P: An alliance made up of members of social groups and academic figures issued a 10,000-Chinese character statement Monday to oppose the Taiwan government's plan to spend NT$610.8 billion (US$18.23 billion) to purchase weaponry from the United States.

The members of the Democratic Action Alliance issued the statement to coincide with the return of a delegation of legislators from the United States, believing that a "bargaining" type of arms procurement will not protect Taiwan's security or its interests.

The legislators had met with U.S. government and military officials during their stay in the United States to discuss issues ranging from the apparent higher-than-average price tag for the package to whether Taiwan's China Shipbuilding Corp. should take part in the construction of the submarines.

Former National Assembly member Cheng Li-wen, poet and social activist Chan Che, National Chung Cheng University Professor Hsieh Ta-ning, and National Taiwan University Professor Chang Ya-chung held a news conference at the Legislative Yuan to make public the statement.

The statement seeks to analyze the issue in five aspects: military security, strategic security, economic development, social justice and democratic values, believing that the huge budget for the arms deal, which the Executive Yuan proposed earlier this month and which is now pending approval of the Legislative Yuan, is tantamount to paying "protection fees to the United States."
They also suspected that there could be kickbacks among Taiwan's top brass and huge profits for arms dealers.
According to the proposed budget, Taiwan should buy 388 Patriot PAC-III missiles, eight conventional submarines, and 12 anti-submarine P-3C aircraft.

Professor Hsieh said that the arms purchase is a major public policy and shouldn't be made rashly, adding that he "welcomes the government to convince us [of the need for the weapons], and we would also like to conduct rational debate."

Professor Chang said that the NT$610.8 billion arms deal is "unacceptable," and urged the government to rein itself in before the brink of the precipice, or the alliance will organize a protest or publish the names of legislators who are involved in the arms purchase.

Chan noted that a referendum to step up national defense held concurrently with the March 20 presidential election failed to pass, but the government has proposed a special budget for the arms purchase, which he termed as "illegal."
Cheng said a military purchase should not be a "bargaining game," and that to have a domestic shipbuilder build the submarines is also not a simple task.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMS PROCUREMENT AIMED AT ENSURING TAIWAN STRAIT PEACE: PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian said Monday the Republic of China government's arms procurement projects have consistently been aimed at safeguarding peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remarks while meeting with U.S. Congressman Scott McInnis (R-Colo.) who arrived in Taipei Sunday for a goodwill visit.
The president told his guest that he is very grateful for the Bush administration's consent in April 2001 to sell a robust package of military hardware to Taiwan.
Chen further said he remembered vividly that Taiwan took the initiative to purchase those weapons to meet its practical defense needs.
"We had lobbied strenuously for the procurement project. The package was not the result of any U.S. pressure as some opponents or critics claim," Chen said.

Chen's administration has approved a special military budget of NT$610.8 billion (US$18.2 billion) for the purchase of eight diesel-powered submarines, a modified version of the Patriot PAC-III anti-missile system and a squadron of 12 P-3C anti-submarine aircraft over a 15-year period starting in 2005.

The United States offered to sell the military hardware to Taiwan in 2001 as part of its most comprehensive arms package to the island since 1992. The special budget bill is now pending approval of the opposition-controlled Legislative Yuan.
Chen said the Ministry of National Defense had carefully evaluated Taiwan's defense needs before coming up with a priority weaponry procurement list for U.S. reference.
At the time, Chen said, the eight conventional submarines topped the priority list.

Chen pointed out that the submarines, the Patriot anti-missile batteries and the P-3C anti-submarine aircraft are all needed to beef up Taiwan's defense capabilities in the face of mainland China's military threat.

"Our arms procurement projects are mainly aimed at protecting lasting peace in the Taiwan Strait, avoiding a cross-strait imbalance in military strength and in safeguarding Taiwan's hard-won democratic achievements, " Chen said, adding that maintaining the cross-strait military balance is expected to help be the catalyst for the early resumption of bilateral talks.

Chen also took advantage of the occasion to clarify his administration's constitutional reform plan. In his May 20 inaugural speech, Chen said, he clearly explained Taiwan's urgent need for a new constitution suitable for the present status quo.

"Formulating a new constitution is primarily to ensure good governance and to upgrade Taiwan's overall competitiveness, " Chen said, adding that he already outlined in his inaugural address the scope and procedures for Taiwan's constitutional re-engineering.
Chen said his administration is responsible and idealistic yet pragmatic.

"We are firm in pursuing progress, but we are also realistic as well. We fully understand the importance of forging an internal consensus and solidarity as well as stabilizing cross-strait relations and promoting economic prosperity, " Chen said, adding that he will endeavor to end domestic disharmony and confrontation in the wake of the bitterly fought March 20 presidential election.

This is McInnis' first visit to Taiwan. A six-term member of the U.S. House of Representatives, McInnis has formally announced that he will not seek re-election as a Congressman and may run for Colorado State governor. Chen extended his best wishes for McInnis' success.
Taiwan is Colorado's 11th-largest export outlet. Chen said he hopes McInnis' visit can help further boost Taiwan-Colorado agricultural trade and economic cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD DEAL WITH U.S. ARMS PURCHASE ISSUE ASAP

TEXT.P: By Jay Chen and P.C.Tang CNA REPORTERS

Washington, June 28 (CNA) Despite the fact that Taiwan will hold legislative elections at the end of the year and the United States will have its presidential election in November, the coming few months will certainly be a crucial period for Taiwan to actively deal with its arms-purchase issues.

The coming few months might also be a golden opportunity that Taiwan's ruling and opposition parties should grab in dealing with its new arms procurement plans since such an opportunity will never come back.

A Legislative Yuan delegation, headed by Wang Jin-pyng, speaker of the Legislative Yuan, had expressed serious concerns during its recent visit to Washington, D.C., over the high price tag for the U.S. weapons, including eight submarines, that the island is planning to purchase.

Nevertheless, a Bush administration official recently told the Central News Agency that Taiwan should discuss its arms-purchase plans with a view to considering Beijing's military threat to the island and its own defense capability rather than the issue of price alone.

Noting that the arms that are currently being discussed between Taiwan and the United States are weapons that were requested by Taiwan several years ago, the official who wished to remain anonymous said that the United States agreed to sell the weapons to Taiwan after the Bush administration took office and after a thorough review by relevant U.S. officials who considered that it is necessary for Taiwan to possess such arms.

But after three years, the official said, Taiwan is still murmuring against the price tag and the specifications of the weapons, adding that this has led the United states to question the purpose of Taiwan's earlier request for purchasing the U.S. arms.

Some have said that Taiwan could be trying to use the arms-purchase plan as a tool to test Washington's political commitment to the island, the official said, adding that the island might consider the sale of the weapons as indicating Washington's firm commitment to Taipei.

Although the official would not say that it could be very serious if Taiwan's new arms procurement plan is postponed again, he however assured that the United States would not be treated as a mercenary by serving other countries anytime they needed it.

A U.S. National Defense University military expert said that the worst possible situation regarding the arms purchase issue would be that Washington thinks Taiwan is not willing to spend the money or the effort to protect itself and is relying on the United States for everything.

If this situation is true, the experts said that both the U.S. executive branch and Congress, which has long been in support of helping defend Taiwan, will adopt a more conservative stance on whether the United States should intervene or not in the event of an outbreak of conflict in the Taiwan Strait.

A well-placed source also said that both the Bush administration and the U.S. Congress are hoping that the island will be able to put some of its arms procurement plans into practice as soon as possible since they consider that the mainland's military strength has rapidly increased and that its threat to Taiwan has also increased as the island has not increased its defense budget in the past few years.

The purpose of Washington's push for Taiwan to upgrade its military forces and to speed up its defense reform is that it hopes the island can at least defend itself for a certain period of time before U.S. intervention in the event of a mainland Chinese attack on the island, the expert said.

A senior researcher of the Center for Strategic and International Studies said that the U.S. Congress will be disappointed and dissatisfied if no progress is made by Taiwan in its budget debate on the arms procurement plans in the Legislative Yuan in the coming few months.

Furthermore, some U.S. officials and experts are worried that if the United States cannot prevent leading members of the European Union from continuing their ban on arms exports to mainland China in the future, the possible sale of British, French and German weapons to the mainland will make the cross-strait military imbalance more serious.

As the arms-purchase issue is of vital importance in terms of Taiwan's national security and survival, now might be the right time for the island's ruling and opposition political parties to rationally discuss the relevant issues and to try to reach a conclusion on the issues, the sooner the better.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, June 28, or the 11th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1776: British forces are defeated at the first Battle of Charleston during the American Revolution.
1836: James Madison, fourth president of the United States, is born. His influence at the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia in 1787, which drew up the constitution, gained him the name "Father of the American Constitution."
1838: The coronation of Queen Victoria, 19, is held in Westminster Abbey. Her sense of duty and strict moral code greatly influenced 19th-century British society.
1902: The United States authorizes the construction of the Panama Canal.
1919: A peace treaty officially ending four years of devastating war is finally signed by a humiliated Germany and the victorious allies at Versailles, France.
1919: The Republic of China refuses to sign the Treat of Versailles because German rights in Shantung are given to Japan.
1932: Chiang Kai-shek, who became chairman of the National Military Council on March 18, arrives in Hankow from Lushan to direct the campaign against the Chinese communists.
1940: Japan declares a blockade against Hong Kong, cutting off land and sea traffic between Hong Kong and the Chinese mainland. Air transportation is excluded from the blockade.
1948: A strong earthquake rocks Fukui prefecture in Japan, killing more than 5,000 people.
1948: The Yugoslav Communist Party is expelled from Cominform at a meeting in Bucharest, marking the formal breach in relations between Yugoslavia and the rest of the communist bloc.
1950: Foreign Minister K.C. Yeh (Yeh Kung-chao) declares the Republic of China has in principle accepted the U.S. government's proposal to cease military operations against mainland China and that the necessary orders have been given to the ROC Navy and Air Force.
1950: Gen. Douglas McArthur, commander of the Allied forces in the South Pacific, flies to South Korea soon after North Korean troops capture Seoul.
1958: Brazil wins the World Cup in Stockholm thanks to the outstanding performance of the 17-year-old soccer player Pele, whose real name is Edson Arantes do Nascimento.
1970: U.S. troops begin their pullout from Cambodia.
1976: Fifty-one American scholars, researchers, teachers and students arrive in Taipei for a five-week Seminar on China Studies.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan receives H.A.E. Scheels, permanent honorary vice president of the International Badminton Federation.
1977: Ma Chi-chuang, board chairman of the China Steel Corp., puts a torch to the blast furnace of the company's new Kaohsiung steel plant to signify the start of steel making at the plant.
1979: The ROC government approves two new appointments proposed by the Kuomintang's Central Committee, naming H.K. Yang, political vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Africa, and Ding Mou-shih, administrative vice foreign minister, as ambassador to South Korea.
1981: To promote cultural communication and economic relations, the Sino-Nigerian Cultural and Economic Association is established in Taipei.
1986: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1987: The 70th Annual Lions Clubs International Convention is held in Taipei. The convention lasts seven days, with 40,000 members and their families joining the gathering.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus becomes the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such relations with the ROC.
1999: The 1999 International Seminar on the Protection of Clean Coasts opens in Kaohsiung with more than 100 experts from home and abroad attending.
2000: Just as scientists from around the world have finished the first big step toward mapping the human genome, Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh announces that Taiwan will establish its own genetic research center within one year.
2001: The National Policy Foundation, an opposition Kuomintang think tank, unveils new policy guidelines featuring a "confederation" with Beijing and a "double economic triangle" covering Taipei.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man, whether dealing with a few people or many, with great matters or with small, is never presumptuous and never regards anything as beneath his notice or as unworthy of serious and careful attention -- that is what is meant by being dignified without being supercilious."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA AIRLINES KICKS OFF TAIPEI-MILAN AIR CARGO SERVICE
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, June 28 (CNA) (By P.C. Fan and P.C. Tang)

TEXT.P: China Airlines (CAL) kicked off cargo charter flight service between Taipei and Milan June 27, with flights to be offered twice per week.
This is CAL's second air route between Taiwan and Italy. The airline began offering flight service between Taipei and Rome in 1995.

A source close to the CAL branch office in the Italian capital said that there will be a stopover in Milan on the airline's Taipei-Luxembourg and Taipei-Manchester cargo charter flights on Thursdays and Sundays, respectively.

The source also said that the new route will give direct, efficient and time-saving cargo service to CAL's cargo customers in Italy, as well as strengthen the airline's cargo service capability for the forthcoming air cargo peak season in Europe.

Milan has always held an important strategic position in the European air cargo market, with its imports including high price textile products, industrial design products, electronics components, computers and fresh agricultural products, to name a few.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF OF HUNGARIAN NEWS AGENCY VISITS CNA

TEXT.P: Hungarian News Agency President Vince Matyas paid a call to the CNA offices Tuesday and explored the possibility of his agency cooperating with CNA.

Matyas, who was invited by the Government Information Office to attend the 80th founding anniversary of CNA, exchanged views with CNA Chairman Su Tzen-ping and President Hu Yuan-hui on issues of mutual concern, especially the challenges posed by the rise of the Internet.
He claimed that the free unverified information transmitted rapidly via the Internet has forced the mass media to cater to the public desire for sensational stories and has jeopardized journalism.
Matyas also expressed interest in a photo platform to be inaugurated by CNA July 1.

In addition to the 1 million photos taken by CNA over the last 80 years, the platform will display and offer for sale photos from mass circulation local newspapers such as the United Daily News and the China Times, as well as the European Pressphoto Agency and other research institutes.
Matyas said the Hungarian News Agency would consider joining the platform as a partner.

Matyas is one of seven senior executives from major international news agencies invited to celebrate CNA's 80th founding anniversary July 1. The others include Eric Hall, Reuters' editor for the Greater China Area, and senior executives of the Associated Press, Japan's Kyodo News Agency, Agence France-Presse, Deutsche Press Agency and Russia's Interfax News Agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT CONTEMPLATING LAUNCHING HEALTH CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Vice President Annette Lu said Tuesday that she is contemplating starting a "saving mind" campaign and organizing a seminar on healthy living at her office to raise public awareness about health issues.

Receiving visiting American mental health expert Alice P. Lin at her office, the vice president said she has always been concerned about the public's mental health and has tried several times to raise the public's awareness of the importance of good mental health.

Her efforts included two public campaigns for mental health, namely the "sunshine life" and the "life train," although she did not elaborate on when or even where the two previous campaigns were conducted.

Claiming that mental health is "too academic" to be understood by the public, Lu suggested changing it to "healthy life, " which covers a broader range of health issues than mental health and will be easier for what she described as "ordinary people" to understand.

However, the vice president rejected Lin's recommendation for the government to set up a mental health commission at the Presidential Office to coordinate the efforts of both the public and private sectors in improving the public's mental health, saying it would be difficult for her office to form a commission not provided for in the organic law of the Presidential Office.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND SETS UP DISASTER PREVENTION CENTER FOR TYPHOON MINDULLE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense set up a special task force Tuesday to cope with any possible emergencies as a result of typhoon Mindulle, the Office of Military Spokesman said Tuesday.
The Central Weather Bureau (CWB) issued a sea warning for Mindulle, the seventh of the year in the Pacific area, Monday.
The typhoon, located at 8: 30 p.m. about 410 km southeast of Oluanpi, the southernmost tip of Taiwan, was moving in a west-northwesterly direction at a speed of 8 kph, the CWB reported.
As the radius of the typhoon was entering the Bashi Channel, the meteorologists warned shipping in the area and at sea off Taiwan's southeast coast to maintain high alert against the typhoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS, IMPORTS COULD REACH NEW HIGHS THIS YEAR: BOFT

TEXT.P: Exports and imports are expected to register new records this year, despite several negative factors, a Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) official said Tuesday.

Based on a forecast by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, the official said exports could reach US$170.6 billion this year, an increase of 18.4 percent over last year, while imports could total US$156.3 billion, an annual growth of 22.9 percent.
Economic growth reached 6.3 percent in the first quarter, with the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics forecasting that growth for the whole year will reach 5.6 percent.

Although there are several negative factors that could affect the economy, including an expected interest rate hike in the United States, mainland China's plan to cool down its overheated economy, the rising oil and raw material prices, as well as the tense situation in the Middle East, prospects will be brighter this year than last year thanks to a global economic recovery.

According to a forecast by Global Insight Inc. and the International Monetary Fund, global economic growth will range between 4.1 percent and 4.6 percent this year, with major growth in the United States, Japan, mainland China and East Asia, as well as a gradual increase in the European Union.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSU CHAIRWOMAN VOWS TO PROMOTE ETHNIC HARMONY

TEXT.P: The newly established Non-partisan Solidarity Union (NSU) will promote harmony among ethnic groups in Taiwan and will take a middle-way approach in dealing with public affairs, NSU Chairwoman Chang Po-ya said Tuesday.

In an interview with the CNA, Chang noted that Taiwan's politics have been polarized and its people have divided into two camps -- the "pan blue alliance" comprising the opposition Kuomintang and its two splinter parties of the People First Party and the New Party, and the "pan green camp" of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party and its ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union -- since the March 20 presidential election.

The political rivalry has produced a great rift among the country's various ethnic groups and people who have different political ideas, the former minister of the interior said, claiming that this has also endangered national security and affected social stability.

At this critical moment, Chang said, a middle-way is needed to ease or dissuade the political rivalry and confrontation among the different groups. The NSU will bear this mission and responsibility, she added.
Despite a long career in politics and public service, Chang said that she had never joined a political party before taking charge of the NSU earlier this month.
The former legislator and Chiayi mayor said that her joining the NSU represents a voice for the silent majority and the use of a middle-way force. The NSU will never be "extremist," she promised.

Referring to December's legislative elections, Chang said that her party will nominate one candidate in each of more than 30 constituencies around the nation and hopes to win at least 15 seats in the 225-member legislature.

The NSU will not join a grand opposition alliance proposed by some politicians and parties, neither will it coordinate with other parties on the nomination of candidates nor participate in joint electoral campaigns.
The NSU will play a decisive role in the rivalry between the two polarized camps, Chang went on.

With regard to cross-Taiwan Strait issues, Chang said that her party suggests that the two sides set aside temporarily disputes over sovereignty and jointly seek the opportunity to establish a lasting peace in the strait.
The sovereignty issue can be left for future generations to settle in 50 or 100 years, she added.

The NSU, initiated by 10 incumbent independent legislators and dozens of other veteran politicians, including former Legislator Chen Chieh-ju and former Hsinchu Mayor Shih Hsing-chung, was established June 15.
