DOC.HEADLINE: EPA TO DECIDE WHETHER TO CONDUCT 2ND STAGE ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT STUDY

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) will decide whether the Suao-Hualien Expressway construction project should be subject to a second-stage environmental impact evaluation, Cabinet spokesman Chen Chi-mai said Tuesday.
Chen made the remarks after two groups filed two opposite appeals with the Cabinet earlier in the day.

A group of residents from the eastern Taiwan county of Hualien, headed by Hualien County Council Deputy Speaker Lin LIen-wen, demonstrated in front of the Cabinet building early in the morning demanding that the Suao-Hualien Expressway construction project be launched as soon as possible to boost the county's tourist and economic development.

Almost at the same time, scores of environmental activists also filed an appeal with the Cabinet urging the government to conduct a second-stage environmental impact assessment to gauge whether the damage to the natural environment caused by the construction project can recover or not.

"Unless a second-stage impact study ensures that the natural ecology in the region will not be spoiled irreversibly, the project should not be implemented," said an environmental activist who joined the petition.
Responding to the opposite appeals, Chen said the government must conduct extensive environmental impact studies before any major infrastructure construction is launched.

A first-stage environmental impact study for the Suao-Hualien Expressway project was completed in March 2000. The government was originally scheduled to start construction of the 80-km expressway linking Hualien to Suao in Ilan county late last year. But Premier Yu Shyi-kun announced a three-month delay on the eve of the start of construction due to environmental activists' strong opposition.

Chen said the Cabinet has set aside a budget for building the expressway as part of its 10 new major construction projects aimed at reinvigorating the domestic economy. Nevertheless, he said, the government must make further study on its possible environmental impact. The EPA will decide later whether to conduct a second-stage environmental impact assessment, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN NEW YORK TO GET NEW HOME
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 28 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in New York will move into a new building in Manhattan next March, TECO Director Andrew L.Y. Hsia said Monday.
TECO represents the Republic of China's interest in New York in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.
Its current office accommodates officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau and the Immigration Bureau under the National Police Administration.

Nine other ROC government agencies -- the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Ministry of Education, the Government Information Office, the Council for Cultural Affairs, the Tourism Bureau, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, the National Security Bureau, the Central Bank of China and the Taiwan External Trade Development Council -- have also posted officials in New York who presently work in nine different locations.

With a view to upgrading Taiwan's international image, facilitating inter-department coordination and integrating national resources for more efficient use, the government decided earlier this year to purchase a building in New York to house all of its offices in the area.

After several months of search and evaluation, Hsia said TECO has struck a deal on the office procurement. From next March, Hsia said, all of the ROC's offices in the New York area will move into the same building. The first floor of the building will be designed as a display gallery, the second floor will accommodate the consular affairs section, while the remaining floors will house the offices of various agencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: YOUTH NATIONAL AFFAIRS CONFERENCE SET FOR SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: A national affairs conference of youth is set for September, at which President Chen Shui-bian will be invited to deliver an opening speech, National Youth Commission Chairwoman Cheng Li-chiun said Tuesday.

In a report to the Central Standing Committee of the ruling Democratic Progressive Party, Cheng said the conference, set for Sept. 18-19, will be preceded by regional conferences held in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan.
Only representatives elected by the regional conferences will be invited to attend the two-day conference at the Chungshan Building on Yangmingshan in suburban Taipei.
In order to ensure that the conference will reflect the opinions of the grassroots young people, Cheng said an organizing panel has been formed by young men chosen through the Internet.

Noting that the Chungshan Building was the conference venue for the former National Assembly, many of whose members were chosen from mainland China prior to 1949, Cheng said that holding the youth national affairs conference there will underline the big changes the country has undergone and the long way the country has come in democratic development.
Cheng said she hopes the conference will produce some specific proposals and that the government will respond to these proposals positively.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MEDIA EXECUTIVES TO ATTEND CNA ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATIONS

TEXT.P: Hungarian News Agency President Vince Matyas and Eric Hall, Reuters' editor for the Greater China Area, arrived in Taipei Tuesday to attend the 80th founding anniversary of the CNA July 1.

Hall noted that he visited Taipei in 2002 to interview President Chen Shui-bian and Premier Yu Shyi-kun. He is scheduled to meet with Chen again Wednesday, but the main purpose of his visit is to attend the CNA anniversary celebrations on behalf of Reuters.

Many other foreign well-wishers, including senior executives of the Associated Press, Japan's Kyodo News Agency, Agence France-Presse, Deutsche Press Agency and Russia's Interfax News Agency, are scheduled to arrive in Taipei Wednesday for the occasion.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR MEN ARRESTED AT CKS INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT FOR SMUGGLING HEROIN

TEXT.P: Four men were arrested at CKS International Airport for smuggling heroin into Taiwan Monday and Tuesday.

Tipped off by informers, investigators arrested Tsai Chia-wen, 31, for smuggling 797 grams of heroin Tuesday afternoon. He said during the initial arraignment that he was set up in mainland China in visiting prostitutes and gambling and because he was unable to pay the money he was forced to carry drugs. He was given the heroin in Macau, which he taped to his body.
Meanwhile, aviation police also arrested Liu Wu-hsiung, 60, Yu Tien-huei, 54, and Ke Fu-yuan, 26, for smuggling 2.674 kilos of heroin when they arrived at CKS Airport Monday night.
All four men have been turned over to the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office for violation of the anti-drug trafficking law.

Investigators and aviation police reported that they recently uncovered suspects returning from Thailand, Macau and Hong Kong with drugs. They said that this is because summer is coming and the selling drugs to students reaches its peak during this time of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA CHIEF TO REPRESENT TAIWAN AT G10 AGRICULTURAL MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 28 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Council of Agriculture (COA) Chairman Lee Chin-lung will represent Taiwan at a Group of Ten (G10) agriculture ministers meeting scheduled to open in Geneva July 5.
It will be the highest-level meeting in Geneva that Taiwan has participated in since the island's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
As Swiss President Joseph Deiss concurrently serves as his country's economics minister, he will preside over the upcoming G10 agriculture ministers meeting.

G10 member states include Bulgaria, Taiwan, South Korea, Iceland, Israel, Japan, Norway, Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Mauritius. The agricultural sector in each of these countries is relatively small in scale, so these countries usually have less leverage individually in the WTO-organized farm trade talks and therefore have formed the G10.

Yen Ching-chang, Taiwan's permanent representative to the WTO, said Monday that as the WTO farm trade talks will soon enter a critical period, the G10 countries decided to meet in early July to discuss joint strategies and cement their common stances on major farm trade issues in preparation for the Cancun round of WTO trade talks.

Yen said Lee's attendance at the G10 ministerial-level meeting has both substantive and symbolic significance. "Lee's presence will help upgrade Taiwan's international visibility and profile," he said, adding that it is also the result of strenuous efforts by the Taiwan WTO mission over the past two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW FOREST RANGERS MAY BE TOO FEW TO PATROL HUALIEN FOREST

TEXT.P: A group of new forest rangers will begin working July 1, but officials in Hualien are concerned that not enough of them will be assigned to their area.
Officials of the Hualien District Office of Taiwan Forestry Bureau said that the Ministry of the Interior has assigned 178 policemen to be forest rangers, but Hualien will only get 21 of them.

The officials said that in the past their forest rangers did not have the broad rights that policemen have, and even if they saw people engaged in illegal logging, farming, burying, construction or dumping they had to rely on local police to apprehend the suspects. This delay often resulted in the culprits escaping.

Officials said that the area encompassing the Hualien Forestry Bureau is large, covering a strip of land 125 kilometers by 45 kilometers. The new forest rangers will not be able to keep tabs on the entire area, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKER CALLS FOR LONGER RESIDENCE PERMITS FOR FOREIGN MISSIONARIES

TEXT.P: A ruling Democratic Progressive Party lawmaker urged the government Tuesday to offer longer residence permits to foreign missionaries.
Legislator Cheng Kuo-chung said that under current immigration regulations, foreign missionaries can only obtain one-year residence permits, resulting in many inconveniences for them.
For one thing, Cheng said, foreign missionaries have to renew their driver's licenses and Internet service applications whenever their one-year residence permits expire.
Moreover, Cheng said, the residence permit renewal fee is NT$1,000 per person.

"It has become a financial burden for some married foreign missionaries with young children," Cheng said, adding that a foreign missionary familiar with him has to spend NT$7,000 a year on renewing residence permits as the missionary has five children.

Noting that many foreign clergymen have dedicated themselves to serving local society and most of them have earn only small salaries, Cheng said the Immigration Bureau under the National Police Administration should revise relevant regulations to grant three-year residence permits for foreign missionaries.

"Since the current regulations allow the issuance of three-year residence permits for foreign teachers and management staff of foreign companies in Taiwan, I think similar privileges should be extended to foreign missionaries, " Cheng said, adding that foreign clergymen's contributions to Taiwan society deserve more recognition and respect.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG TO RECYCLE MOBILE PHONES AND COMPUTER DISCS ON TRIAL BASIS

TEXT.P: Taichung City Government's Environmental Protect Bureau will start to collect and recycle components in used cell phones and computer discs starting July 1.

Bureau officials said that mobile phones contain liquefied crystal panels, integrated circuits and other electronic parts and some of them are worth recycling, while computer discs are mostly made of plastics, which can also be recycled.
The officials said the campaign will be conducted on a six-month trial basis, after which the results will be studied to determine if the program should be continued.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION ATTENDS SUMMER 2004 FANCY FOOD SHOW IN NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 28 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is sending a large delegation to participate in the summer 2004 Fancy Food Show June 27-29 in New York, promoting high-quality Taiwan gourmet food.

Andrew L. Y. Hsia, director-general of Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, hailed Taiwan's agricultural research and development efforts during the last few years, which can be evidenced by the exquisite food from Taiwan companies exhibited at the show.
The Fancy Food Show showcases foods from diverse cultures from around the world, with this year's show attracting some 1,900 exhibitors from 52 countries.
The Taiwan delegation, the largest in years, is comprised of representatives from eight food associations and the Taiwan Provincial Farmers' Association.

Officials of Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , which helped organize the Taiwan delegation, noted that the island's agricultural industry backed up Taiwan's industrial development several decades ago, and when the industrial sector grew, advanced technologies helped to improve the quality of agricultural products.
Taiwan has recently exported agricultural products worth US$300 million each year to the United States, one of the island's major outlets for agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO SET UP TASK FORCE TO CRACK DOWN ON SELLING OF TAINTED PORK

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Tuesday that it will create a task force to crack down on the illegal practice of selling products from pigs that died of illness.
The COA's announcement followed a shocking report by the Consumer Protection Commission (CPC) under the Executive Yuan.

The commission reported that the illegal selling of such pork has been hard to eradicate, saying that a total of 161 tons of tainted pork had been found over the past three years. Although the owners of the unlawful abattoirs were prosecuted, law enforcers have failed to track down the final destination of the bad meat and it may have ended up in various products or for sale in markets.
COA officials said that to combat the unlawful practice, they will now publish on their Web site establishments that have violated the law, and keep them on file for regular checks and monitoring.

The COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine will also call an intra-agency meeting Wednesday, inviting officials from the Department of Health, the Environmental Protection Administration, the National Police Administration, the COA's Animal Industry Department, as well as those from major pork production counties of Changhua, Yunlin, Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung to discuss the matter.
Bureau officials are also asking the violators of the law be given the maximum sentences.

Bureau Director Chiang Yi-nan said that to track down the possible outlets of the tainted pork, the bureau will now install satellite positioning systems in vehicles carrying the dead animals to incinerators.

It is estimated that all the contracted 100-plus vehicles will be installed with the system, and the number of pigs they carry will be matched with that sent to the incinerators in the future so as to prevent the drivers from diverting the dead pigs to other places.

The commission has suggested that the COA subsidize pig farmers for their pigs that died of sickness, but COA officials said the issue will have to undergo further study as it involves the questions of fairness.

Bureau officials asked the public to use pork products that carry CAS certification from authorized slaughterhouses, and asked them to call 0800-039-131 if they have doubts about pork products. Those who provide tips leading to the discovery of the illegal practice will be rewarded with NT$500,000 (US$14,880).

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE MAINLAND FISHING BOATS, 13 PEOPLE EXPELLED FROM KINMEN WATERS

TEXT.P: Kinmen marine police on Tuesday seized three mainland Chinese fishing boats along with 13 mainland fishermen and crew caught fishing illegally in waters off the outlying island of Kinmen.

The Kinmen marine police, backed up by a cutter from the Coast Guard Administration, discovered the three mainland fishing vessels poaching in the corridor between Kinmen and Liehyu, or little Kinmen, around 8 a.m. Tuesday.

The police seized the mainland fishing vessel's fishing gear, including 15 drift nets, before expelling the three vessels and the 13 mainland Chinese, including seven fishermen and six female crew members.
All three fishing boats - the "Minlongyu" No. 0751, the "Minlongyu" No. 5015 and the "Minlongyu" No. 5047 -- were from Longhai City in Zhangzhou, Fujian province.
The mainland Chinese were released after questioning by the Kinmen marine police, who determined that they had been poaching in Kinmen waters, but had not used dynamite or electricity to catch fish.

Two other mainland fishermen were not that lucky. Captured for similar poaching and trespassing by Kinmen marine police Monday, also in the Kinmen-Liehyu corridor, the two mainlanders were detained before being transferred to the Kinmen Prosecutors' Office because they were found to have electrocuted fish.

Illegal forays by mainland fishing boats into the waters around Kinmen have become rampant in recent years. The mainland fishermen, who use nets and explosives, and also frequently engage in smuggling, often intentionally ignore warnings from Taiwan marine police or naval vessels.

Residents of Kinmen, most of whom used to make a living by fishing, have complained that their fishing rights are being seriously violated by their mainland counterparts. They demand that the marine police and the ROC Navy do more to prevent Taiwan's territorial waters from being encroached upon.

A resident living near the Kinmen-Liehyu corridor, surnamed Chen, said that there used to be 30 sampans from his village fishing in Kinmen waters. But today there is only one sampan still operating, entirely as a result of poaching by mainland fishing boats.
Mainland fishing boats' destructive fishing gear, dynamite and electricity not only catch small fish, but also kill other undersea life, causing great losses to Kinmen fishermen.

Another Kinmen resident, surnamed Lin, complained that mainland fishing boats have not only been poaching in Kinmen waters, they have also planted stationary nets in waters near Kinmen's beaches for regular harvests. If such harvests are insufficient, according to Lin, they just walk onto the beach to pick shellfish and other aquatic produce.

Answering the residents' complaints, the Kinmen marine police authorities said Tuesday that intensive patrols will be increased to once a week from this week and attention will be specially paid to those mainland vessels using dynamite or electricity during their poaching.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. DOLLAR RISES ON TAIPEI FOREX

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar rose against the new Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, gaining NT$0.016 to close at NT$33.767.
A total of US$510 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at the day's low of NT$33.760 and surged to a high of NT$33.808.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock futures market were higher Tuesday as the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Capitalization Weighted Index for July rose 29 points to close at 5,644, with 29,181 contracts changing hands.
TAIEX Index futures for August increased 25 points to finish at 5,595, with 146 contracts traded, while September futures rose 24 points to finish at 5,578, with two contracts finalized.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index futures trading were set Tuesday at 5,615 for July, 5,570 for August, 5,554 for September, 5,544 for December and 5,527 for March.
Electronics (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, were mixed.
July TE futures moved up 1.7 points to close at 224.4, with 3,237 contracts traded, while August TE futures gained 0.75 points to finish at 221.5, with 25 contracts transacted.
December TE futures moved down 4.6 points to finish at 220.05, with two contracts traded. No transactions were recorded for other months.
July TF futures moved down 1.4 points to finish at 922.6, with 5,344 contracts changing hands, while August TF futures lost 2.0 points to finish at 910, with 208 contracts traded.
March TF futures lost 17.8 points to finish at 907, with one contract traded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices ended higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 31.68 points to close at 5,741.52.
The bourse opened at 5,672.72 and fluctuated between 5,741.52 and 5,652.44 during trading.
A total of 2.2 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$48.19 billion (US$1.42 billion).

Seven of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction issues moving up the most at 1.0 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 0.7 percent, electrical and foodstuff shares both at 0.6 percent, cement stocks at 0.5 percent, bank and insurance shares at 0.2 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.
Only textile issues lost ground, moving down at 0.5 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 415 to 282, with 238 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOON MINDULLE POSING THREAT TO BASHI CHANNEL, WATERS OFF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Typhoon Mindulle is posing a greater threat to the Bashi Channel and waters off southeast Taiwan as it continues moving towards Taiwan, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) reported Tuesday.

After issuing a sea warning Monday afternoon for ships operating in the Bashi Channel and waters off southeast Taiwan, CWB meteorologists said Mindulle, the seventh typhoon of this year in the Pacific area, has continued to move in a west-northwesterly direction towards Taiwan at a speed of eight kilometers per hour.

With a radius of 250 kilometers and packing maximum sustained winds of up to 43 meters per second, the typhoon was centered about 470 kilometers southeast of Taiwan's southernmost tip of Oluanpi at 8 a.m. Tuesday, the meteorologists reported.
Noting that the waters along the coasts of eastern Taiwan and the Hengchun peninsula have been rough, the meteorologists advised people to refrain from going near the seaside.

Since the radius of Typhoon Mindulle is wide and its strength could gradually increase, the weathermen said they will keep a close watch on the typhoon, which is forecast to directly affect Taiwan Thursday or Friday.
The weather bureau warned that Typhoon Mindulle may bring a considerable amount of rainfall to Taiwan when it is nearest to the island between Wednesday and Friday.

Meanwhile, another typhoon, dubbed Tingting, was located about 630 kilometers north of Guam and moving northwesterly at a speed of 19 kilometers per hour as of 8 a.m. Tuesday, the meteorologists said, adding that it is still too early to tell whether the typhoon will affect Taiwan.

The meteorologists are warning of high temperatures in Taiwan over the next few days, with highs of 36 degrees Celsius forecast for the western and northern parts of the island, 35 degrees Celsius for the central and southern parts, 32 degrees Celsius for eastern Taiwan, and thunder showers for the north and northeastern areas.
The weather bureau has also warned that the ultra-violet ray index around Taiwan will be high for the next few days.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
The Times: A new face, a new era for Iraq.
America's proconsul slipped out of Iraq with a lonely wave goodbye yesterday after the transfer of power was given to the country's interim Prime Minister Iyad Allawi.
Financial Times: US hands sovereignty back to Iraqis without fanfare.
The much-heralded transfer of sovereignty to the Iraqi people was stripped of all fanfare and carried out on Monday ahead of schedule and out of sight behind the high walls of the US compound in central Baghdad.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES NEW GENERALS TO CULTIVATE PERSEVERANCE, CONVICTION

TEXT.P: President Chen Shui-bian urged newly promoted generals Tuesday to cultivate three leadership characteristics -- perseverance, wisdom and conviction.

Addressing a joint commissioning ceremony for newly promoted generals from the military's three branches, Chen said senior military officers should evaluate Taiwan's defense needs and work out effective strategies to upgrade combined services combat capabilities in the face of mainland China's ever-mounting military threat.
Chen said mainland China has continued expanding its military strength and is developing new combat strategies, such as unlimited and asymmetrical warfare tactics.

To cope with these new developments and challenges, Chen said, senior military officers should continually pursue new knowledge in warfare, technological and management and apply their expertise in military affairs and combat preparedness.
Chen then spoke of the qualities of a good military leader.

"Military leaders need three special qualities -- perseverance, wisdom and conviction to win on battlefields and defend national security," Chen said, adding that in the face of mainland China's accelerated military modernization, all senior officers should constantly think how to promote reform in military management and combat operations as well as how to integrate limited resources to establish an elite high-tech combat force that can deal with all sorts of tough challenges.
Chen also expressed his hope that newly promoted generals can work with their colleagues in injecting a new spirit of courage, conviction and trust into the military rank and file.

During the joint commissioning ceremony presided over by Minister of National Defense Lee Jye, nine were promoted to lieutenant generals or vice admirals and 25 others were promoted to major generals or rear admirals.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO VISIT DOMINICAN REPUBLIC IN AUGUST

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is arranging a visit by Premier Yu Shyi-kun to the Dominican Republic to attend the inauguration of President-elect Leonel Fernandez.
MOFA spokesman Richard Shih said that the premier, as a special envoy of President Chen Shui-bian, will attend the inauguration ceremony set for Aug. 16.
The ministry is still making arrangements for a possible visit by the premier to neighboring countries in Central and South America, and for transit stops in the United States.
This will be Yu's second visit to the region during his premiership. He visited four allies in Central America in August 2002.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERGER THE ONLY RIGHT COURSE FOR PAN-BLUE ALLIANCE: KMT SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: A Kuomintang (KMT) spokesman expressed his negative view regarding the creation of a grand alliance among the opposition political parties and groups, saying that the only right course for the sustainable operation of the "pan-blue alliance" is a merger between the KMT and the People First Party (PFP).

Media reports have said that KMT Chairman Lien Chan and PFP Chairman James Soong came to a consensus at a June 25 closed-door meeting regarding forming a grand alliance among their parties, the New Party and those non-partisan members who have similar views, to try to win the year-end legislative elections.

But KMT spokesman Tsai Cheng-yuan said while responding to media questions that consideration of forming a grand alliance among the opposition parties and groups is only "temporary" and that a merger of the KMT and the PFP is the only way for the sustainable operation of the "pan-blue alliance".

Pointing out that it is not easy to put the formation of a grand alliance into practice, Tsai also said that the creation of such an alliance might confuse the electorate during the year-end legislative elections and negatively affect the election results for the "pan-blue alliance".

The spokesman said the proposal of forming a grand alliance is absolutely not the right course, adding that from both the legal and practical standpoint, such a proposal would not be easy to carry out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN 4TH LARGEST RECIPIENT OF U.S. PATENTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan obtained the fourth largest number of patents in the United States last year, behind only the United States, Japan and Germany, officials from the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Tuesday.

The officials said statistics from the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office of the Department of Commerce showed that the total number of patents approved by the United States for Taiwan company and individual inventors was 6,676 in 2003. Meanwhile, the U.S. obtained 98,598 patents, Japan got 37,250, and Germany obtained 12,140.

South Korea, France, Britain, Canada, Italy and Sweden rounded out the top 10, in that order, the officials said. South Korea moved up the list to fifth place, while France and Britain slipped a notch over the previous year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER KEEPING LOW PROFILE DURING EUROPEAN VISIT

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen has kept a low profile during his visit to Europe because of the relentless stifling of Taiwan in the international community by mainland China, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Tuesday.
Hsieh Chun-teh, deputy director of the MOFA's Department of European Affairs, made the remarks after Chen flew into Rome following his visit to the United States Monday.

Hsieh said that this is Chen's first visit to Europe since assuming his post in April. He said Chen will preside over a meeting of the chiefs of Taiwan's missions in the region, as well as visit the Vatican, Taiwan's only diplomatic ally in Europe.

Chen said earlier that Taiwan should strengthen its relations with the European Union considering its population, economic strength and market potential after it expanded to 25 member countries from 15 members this past May.

During his visit to the United States, Chen called on several think tanks, met with overseas Chinese and attended an annual conference of the World Forum in Colorado -- a gathering of politicians, academics and financial executives organized by the American Enterprise Institute, a Washington-based think tank.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Moscow, June 29 [CNA] The Moscow Times: Veterans, Disabled Slated for Extra Aid.
Budget money allocated for World War II veterans will be 20 times greater and 10 times greater for the disabled, President Vladimir Putin said Monday as he tried to win support from a skeptical population for his plans to replace social welfare benefits with more transparent cash payments.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Bangkok Post: Iraq/Sovereignty handover/ Us returns power 2 days early.
The Unioted States handed power to a caretaker Iraqi government yesterday in a surprise move, ending its 14-month occupation of the country two days early apparently to thwart militants after a spate of attacks. (Francis Kuo)

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL HEADLINE NEWS
DOC.TEXT:
Manila Bulletin: Arroyo bares 10 key goals
A decongested Metro Manila, an automated 2007 election, "closure of wounds" brought about by the EDSA 1, 2, and 3 Revolutions, and a balanced budget are among the 10 ambitious goals of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo for the next six years.
The Philippine Daily Inquirer: Macapagal pushes tax on gross income
ARMED with a fresh mandate and backed by political allies who hold the majority of seats in Congress, President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo is pushing for corporate tax reforms that would levy businesses based on their gross income, rather than net profit.
The Philippine Star: GMA to push for Cha-cha, gross taxation
President Arroyo is to push for Charter change and gross income taxation for corporations in a bid to increase government revenue and stem a decline in much-needed foreign investment.
The Manila Times: Separate 'inaugural' for FPJ
SUPPORTERS of Fernando Poe Jr. are preparing for his proclamation and oath taking, which will coincide with the ceremony being prepared by the government for President Arroyo at the Rizal Park in Manila and in Cebu City.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, June 29, or the 12th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
48 B.C.: Julius Caesar defeats his brother-in-law and former ally Pompey at Pharsallus and thus becomes absolute ruler of Rome.
1880: France formally annexes the Pacific island of Tahiti (or Otaheite).
1911: Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands is born. He is the husband of Queen Juliana and a founder of the World Wildlife Fund.
1920: China joins the League of Nations.
1928: Peking is renamed Peiping.
1932: A group of Thais revolt against King Prajadhipok, forcing the king to change the government from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional monarchy, thus limiting the power of the king.
1944: China and Japan begin a major battle at Hengyang, a city in Hunan province, with Japanese troops using poisonous mustard gas in their attack.
1953: More than 1,400 mainland Chinese prisoners of war in Korea who refuse to return to the Chinese mainland write a blood letter to Presdient Chiang Kai-shek, asking him to allow them to go to Taiwan to join the Republic of China's armed forces.
1954: A total of 1,735 diamonds, with a total weight of 368.17 carats, are shipped to Taipei. The diamonds were stolen by the Japanese in mainland China during World War II.
1966: American planes bomb Hanoi and Haiphong for the first time in the Vietnam War.
1972: The US Supreme Court rules that the death penalty is unconstitutional.
1974: The ROC government announces the suspension of diplomatic relations with Venezuela, which recognized the Chinese communist regime.
1974: The 6th National Little League Baseball Tournament ends with the Li Teh team from Kaohsiung City designated to represent the ROC in the Asian playoffs.
1978: The ROC government approves a commercial agreement between flagship-carrier China Airlines and Cargo Lux and Lux Air of Luxembourg. The agreement makes it possible for CAL to extend its flight service to Europe.
1980: President Chiang Ching-kuo promulgates the new Commissioned and Noncommissioned Statute of the Armed Forces and the new Entertainment Tax Law.
1981: Hu Yaobang takes over as chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, succeeding Hua Guofeng.
1982: Premier Sun Yun-suan receives Richard Allen, senior counselor for foreign policy to the Republican National Committee of the United States.
1984: The Legislative Yuan approves the long-awaited and controversial Genetic Health Law, or Eugenics Bill, after a third reading.
1986: Argentina wins the World Cup soccer title again in Mexico, thanks to Diego Maradona, 25, who was directly or indirectly responsible for all the goals in the championship game.
1992: Mohamed Boudiaf, president of Algeria, is assassinated as he opens a cultural center in Annaba.
1994: The Peruvian Trade Office opens in Taipei.
1995: A department store collapses in Seoul, South Korea, killing 450 people and injuring 922 others.
1999: The ROC wins the right to host the annual global Information Technology conference in Taipei from June 12 to 14, 2000.
2000: Taiwan-based China Airlines signs an agreement with eight other regional airlines to establish a Pan-Asia Travel Portal webside by the end of this year.
2001: P.K. Chiang, secretary-general of National Policy Foundation, urges the ROC government to adjust its current "no haste, be patient" mainland Chinese investment policy to help local firms accomplish globalization and boost Taiwan's economy.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man has only to watch over every minute detail connected with his daily life, not only of conduct and bearing, but even in minor details of dress, so as to produce an effect upon the public mind, which, without these influences, could only have been produced by fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY SUGGESTS INTEGRATING FOREIGN TRADE INTO DIPLOMATIC WORK
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 29 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government should study the feasibility of integrating its foreign trade affairs into the jurisdiction of its Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) , the ROC representative to the World Trade Organization (WTO) said Tuesday.

Yen Ching-chang, permanent representative of the Separate Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu at the WTO headquarters, made the suggestion at a meeting of ROC mission chiefs stationed in European countries, which opened in Geneva Tuesday, with Foreign Affairs Minister Tan Sun Chen presiding.
Yen, a former ROC finance minister, said that the ROC has had a hard time expanding its diplomatic frontiers due to Beijing's diplomatic embargo.
"I think we may be able to achieve some diplomatic breakthroughs if we can wisely use our relatively strong trade and economic clout," Yen said.

As a matter of fact, Yen said, many countries, including Australia, have merged their foreign and trade affairs departments. Several other countries, such as Japan, have traditionally authorized their foreign affairs ministries to chart their basic international trade policies.

Yen said he hopes relevant ROC government agencies can conduct an extensive study on whether Taiwan can learn from those countries' experiences and allow the MOFA to handle foreign trade affairs to enhance its leverage in the diplomatic arena.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, June 30, or the 13th day of the fifth month of the Year of the Monkey according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1520: Montezuma II, the Aztec sovereign of Mexico, is killed by Hernando Cortez, the Spanish invader who overthrew his empire and took him prisoner.
1815: Stephen Decatur, an American naval officer known for his heroic deeds in the Tripolitan War, the War of 1812, stops continued attacks by Algerian pirates by threatening to bombard Algiers.
1837: Use of the pillory is banned in Britain. The device is a wooden framework on a post, with holes for the head and hands, in which offenders were locked to be exposed to public scorn as punishment for petty crimes.
1859: A crowd of some 25,000 people hold their breath in stunned admiration as Charles Blondin, a daring 35-year-old Frenchman, crosses Niagara Falls balanced on a tightrope.
1894: Tower Bridge across the River Thames in London is opened by the Prince of Wales.
1934: Adolf Hitler eliminates all his political opponents in the "Night of the Long Knives" in Germany.
1943: U.S. Gen. Douglas MacArthur assumes his new post as commander of the Allied forces in the Southwest Pacific.
1950: U.S. President Harry S. Truman orders American forces to resist North Korean troops which are invading South Korea.
1963: Cardinal Giovanni Battista Montini is enthroned as Pope Paul VI. He was noted for easing regulations on fasting and interfaith marriages.
1971: Three Russian cosmonauts are found dead in their spaceship after a record-breaking 24 days in space which ended in oxygen failure in the final stage.
1977: The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization (SEATO) is dissolved after 23 years.
1980: Hung Mao Cheng (Fortress of the Red-Haired People), formerly the British consulate at Tamsui, northern Taiwan, is returned to the Republic of China government after the expiration of a 113-year lease.
1983: Hsu Shih-hsien, mayor of Chiayi and Taiwan's first female mayor, dies of liver cancer at the age of 76.
1987: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo receives Sten A. Akestam, president of the International Association of Lions Clubs, and six other top-ranking Lions officials.
1987: The construction of Feitsui Reservoir in Taipei County, with a price-tag of NT$14 billion, is completed.
1989: ROC Interior Minister Hsu Shui-teh and Vice Defense Minister Kuo Tsung-chin jointly preside over a ceremony marking the inauguration of a national boundary stone tablet inscribed with the words "Shield of the South China Sea" on Tungsha Chuntao (the Pratas Islands) in the South China Sea.
1990: East and West Germany merge their economies, with East Germany adopting the deutschemark as its currency.
1993: The ROC Executive Yuan approves an economic stimulus package to accelerate industrial upgrading and develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center.
1995: The U.S. government officially announces cancellation of the sanctions against Taiwan issued under the Pelly Amendment.
1996: South African Foreign Minister Alfred Nzo arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1997: Britain hands Hong Kong back to the Chinese at the stroke of midnight, ending 156 years of colonial rule.
1999: The U.S. ratings agency Standard and Poor's gives the ROC's long-term foreign currency credit a rating of AA+, indicating its belief that the country has a high level of capability in fulfilling its financial commitments.
2000: A total of 251 sinologists from around the world meet at Taiwan's Academia Sinica to discuss the digital preservation of traditional Chinese literature and language archives.
2000: Opposition Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan is elected as the chairman of the newly established KMT think-tank, the National Policy Research Foundation.
2001: Senegalese President Abdoulaye Wade, accompanied by a high-profile delegation, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit to the ROC at the invitation of President Chen Shui-bian.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "In the conduct of government, the first bad principle to be avoided is cruelty. That is, the undue punishment of crimes committed through ignorance arising out of a neglected education."
